review:
If you like long drives on straight roads going past farms, this is the DLC for you. Besides all the farms and small towns, there are some deliveries to be made to gas stations.

Nebraska just doesn't have any real landmarks, but if you go in expecting a farming state, you get that. What there is to map has been mapped and it looks really good.

After playing some more and doing the entire World of Trucks event to explore the state I have some issues though. None of the scenic towns have town markers! I passed through places like Red Cloud and Thedford but they don't have a town sign anywhere, and aren't mentioned on the road shields.

The alignment of some roads is also off. The 6 in Lincoln for example manages to run north-south for a part, whereas IRL it is almost entirely a south-west to north-east road.

I guess some of this may be corrected later but it seems this DLC was not completely finished before release.

Still, if you like ATS, you will probably get this now if not soon simply for the fact it gives you more to drive on, and allows for more connections between Wyoming, Colorado, and Kansas.
Good DLC, but will be better when the east side of the Missouri river is complete.

After driving through the whole state. I feel this DLC could do with a few more misc highways around the map. You missed Lincoln Highway (US 30) from Grand Island to North Platte which is a scenic alternative to the boringness of I-80. The tri-cities are a major area of Nebraska that weren't done justice here. Sure, Grand Island looks great but Kearney isn't represented outside of the Archway and Hastings doesn't even exist, which is crazy to me since Hastings is where kool-aid was invented.

What little is here is good though. I just hope SCS could update the DLC with some more roads.

A fun rhythm game played as crazy pigeons. I am having fun with it. The only problem if its really much of a problem. People need to learn to have some patience! Their timer at the start is 2 minutes or 30 people/pigeons. It will get down to 10 seconds and people still leave. If you don't mind playing against bots most rounds, then it's not really an issue. The bots are not over powered at all I would say. I just thought I would mention this because this is a bit annoying right now. And the lobby doesn't seem to fill back up as people leave. I hope they fix that. All of their clothing items/voices/ect. are in game currency (crumbs), no money shop in game. They have a DLC for some outfits, and it's a decent amount of outfits. I like their way they are doing this game so far. If you have decent rhythm. Give it a go.

***UPDATE 10/10/23***
I stand by what I said below from WHEN I wrote it. Unfortunately "Game_002" has already been released, and that demonstrates to me that this developer is more interested in pushing short bites of what will inevitably become trash out the door than they are in growing their skills. As such, I can't really recommend this game (or any of their others) to the community.

This now changes from a thumbs up to a thumbs down from me.

***ORIGINAL***
Wow...this is the first time that I get to be the first person reviewing a game. Don't I feel special?!?

I'm not gonna lie, I really only bought this game BECAUSE I thought that it would be a train wreck, and I wanted to see just how bad that it is/was. On the store page, it just says "Game_001" where you add it to your cart. And I figured that if the devs have so little focus that they can't even name the thing, what hope is there for the game itself?

But on the other hand, when I make music, I don't always have a title for it. So I have a LOT of tracks that end up being something like "23.09.21 Blues D#m - 92bpm" so I get the naming convention the dev used. Although I think that it's ambitious to use "_001," but I am curious as to what "_069" and "_666" end up being!

Here's the thing, I was pleasantly surprised by this game's story. Truthfully, I would give it a neutral score if I could. It's a KINETIC VISUAL NOVEL, and I don't really like those. There is NO ONE CHOICE for you to make, and the 74 minutes is how long it took for me to read it. There is ONE SEX SCENE, and it is NOT animated.

So the thumbs-up really only applies to people that don't mind those qualifiers.

What surprised me was the story itself. It's not outstanding, but it is intelligent. The story starts out spending a little time creating a likable relationship between the MC and the love interest. There isn't a LOT of emotional investment, but just enough to leave you rooting for them.

It's clearly a translation to English, but whoever did it almost certainly is a native speaker. I didn't see any actual spelling errors except for the fact that the MC is sometimes called "John" when his name is "Josh" and "Elli" is OFTEN called "Ally."

A few of the text boxes have confusing wording that had me backing up a few boxes in order to regain the context, but I have played MANY games that are more highly polished, with a WAY worse script.

I would like to see what this team (or person) could do with a larger story, choices, and branching paths. Maybe it would be a cluster-fuck, but I was at least slightly invested in these characters. And that's not something that happens for me very often in a kinetic novel.

Good job, and here's to "Game_069" and "Game_666"!
Sex game. Only one route. Get on discount.
Not well designed. It's just a series of binary choices for one girl or the other.

decent system
Voice acting is rough
extremely short
results are one or the other

This game plays like an interactive video rather than a visual novel. The voice acting is a little stiff, but is otherwise well done. The dialogue is clever and realistic. The character interactions are well written, so there is no obvious ‚Äúthis person is better‚Äù bias. All three characters have lip sync that matches the voice acting pretty well.

Saves can be made at any time, but to properly continue a game after a load you need to go back to the last choice and continue from there. All the scenes are moderate in length, like normal brief conversations.

The choice system is simple. Make more choices for one girl and you get her ending. The storyline is short. I doubt many will spend more than a half hour per ‚Äúroute.‚Äù

The ending scenes are 18+ and are the same quality as those shown on the store page. The animated poses and camera angles are changed by using the ‚ÄúEnter‚Äù key and are accompanied by voice acting that is reasonably natural.

Recommended, although the short story length leads me to suggest getting it on sale.
Choose to support one of two girls. Get rewarded if you favor one over the other (tested splitting support evenly, you don‚Äôt get either). Wait for discount.
The game was so short I had to let it sit open or I couldn't leave a review!  Really that bad.
When I tried out the game, I couldn't hear the characters talking, nor read what was being said.
shit

--This game has a lot of promise. It's mostly open-ended interrogations where you're typing in (usually outlandish) questions and accusations and the AI characters try to keep up. This feels much more natural than any AI-generated writing I've seen in a mystery game before, and clearly there's a huge opportunity here beyond what a writer can achieve with multiple-choice answers in a linear script like most standard mystery games use. 

The AI does a very good job rolling with questions predictable and unpredictable. For example, I found blood-stained gloves and my leading suspect admitted they were his. He had a suitably creepy and sometimes clever answer for these questions: 
----"It's warm weather out, why do you have gloves on set?"
----"What were your blood-soaked gloves doing in someone else's bedroom? You don't have to answer if you're like a midwife or something."
----"Nostradamus foretold that these gloves would bring nothing but murder and syphilis. Have you been tested recently?" 
----"You are wearing a t-shirt and shorts. Literally the only reason you have gloves is that you're a plumber or a serial killer, and I don't see any ****ing pipes on you." 
----"If you talk back one more time, I will go off on you like Sherlock Holmes' dog playing fetch with his opium."  
----"If you could say anything to the killer, what would it be? Also, pretend that it's someone else, obviously."  
[b]If you enjoy confronting NPCs and pushing them to the limit with hallucinatory allegations and midwifing advice and doubtful sexual boasts, this is EXACTLY the mystery you will love. Otherwise, skip it, the cases are lame as hell on any sort of normal playthrough[/b].

--Evidence collection is a miss. It feels like I'm checking the same ~10 drawers over and over. 

--The player only gets asked to pick a killer, but there's only ~5 suspects in each case and only 1-2 of them have even the slightest motive. It's pretty thin. All of the cases I've seen are 100% solved on motive, which gets repetitive. In a more complex video game, a murder whodunnit might be a sequence of like 3-6 events (or even as many as ~12 for Donganronpa), and we eliminate some suspects or advance through the story by figuring out what happened in each stage. [spoiler](Maybe their alibi doesn't give them enough time to have committed the crime, or they're not physically capable enough to have strangled the victim, or aren't on good enough terms that the victim would have invited them in).[/spoiler] In this game, we have 0-event murders where the cause of death is not discussed, the time is not discussed, the crime scene is not discussed, even the player character is not discussed, all we have is establishing which suspect had a plausible motive to commit murder. It's more a proof of concept for AI dialogue than a whodunnit, I think. [spoiler]Disclaimer: I write mystery books for five year olds and I don't think even they would go for cases this thin. This game is much less about solving crimes, and more about confronting suspects with wild-eyed revelations and hallucinatory accusations, which frankly was a lot of fun.[/spoiler]. 

--In a game with more detailed cases, it'd be pretty common to ask questions beyond just who the killer is. For example, "How did the killer get through the door?" or "Why didn't the dog bark?" or "Who is the killer's accomplice?" In this game's cases, there's no dogs, no accomplices, no doors, the solutions are exceptionally thin. Like, you find a guy's bloody gloves, and he admits they're his, and that's enough to correctly accuse him of obviously being the murderer. :-/

--There are some unnatural dialogue moments where characters forget what they've told you. PRODUCER: there's been tension over script changes. ME: What script changes? PRODUCER: "Script changes? What script changes?" [b]But generally the AI does a good job maintaining internal consistency[/b].  

--Moving around the mansion is rough. The blur is so high, I blame the opium

--Game has crashed twice in 2 hours of playtime. Going up stairs is surprisingly difficult. Opening cabinets takes some getting used to.

‚ÄúQuiet on Set‚Äù is not just a game; it‚Äôs a transformative experience that has redefined the murder mystery genre. With its intricate storytelling and immersive gameplay, it has the power to captivate and engage players on a profound level.

The game places you in the midst of a movie production in a grand mansion, where a sudden murder turns your role from a participant to a detective. The unique feature of ‚ÄúQuiet on Set‚Äù is its use of advanced AI technology to dynamically craft dialogue in real-time, ensuring no two experiences are the same. This level of personalisation has allowed players to deeply connect with the game, making it a comforting escape that can have a positive impact on one‚Äôs mental health.

The game‚Äôs ability to blend interactive fiction, adventure, and puzzle elements with a compelling narrative allows players to use their analytical skills to navigate through a storm of ulterior motives and agendas. The emotional investment in solving the mystery is significant, as each decision can lead to different outcomes, making the player an integral part of the story.

For those who have found solace in the world of ‚ÄúQuiet on Set,‚Äù it‚Äôs more than a game‚Äîit‚Äôs a journey through suspense and intrigue that offers a sense of accomplishment and emotional relief. It‚Äôs a testament to the power of interactive storytelling and its potential to touch lives beyond the screen.

I really like this  game! I think especially after playing the demo, this game has come a long way.  The AI chats have definetly been kind of frustrating and some of the doors have still gotten stuck, but I think over all this game has a lot of potential and is fun to play as long as you have plenty of downtime.

This is a game with more cons than pros, but what pros there are carry the whole thing.

Cons:
Lacks polish
Crashed two or three times during my first session playing it
Has a fair few bugs - sometimes you have to approach a character a couple of times before triggering their dialogue, sometimes there's no cursory on the end-game screen meaning you have to force close the game
Sometimes the AI goes off on crazy tangents, including an innocent character gleefully confessing to the murder
Sometimes difficult to get characters to actually answer the questions you put to them
Characters' AI can break so they won't respond at all
UI could be better and more intuitive
Some controls aren't mapped to the keys the intro tells you they are
Very sparse in-game options and could really do with some to modify the mouse sensitivity and motion blur

Pros:
Some of the stories at least are well laid out and a fun challenge to figure out
The biggest one of all is that the concept is fantastic and talking to/messing with the AI is a lot of fun

So yeah, expect a bit of a janky mess but if you go into it just wanting some silly fun with AI and a mystery to solve it's a good time.

Quiet on Set is not just any ordinary video game; it's an immersive experience that has left an indelible mark on my life. Released by a small indie studio, this game captivated my imagination and transported me into a world where creativity knew no bounds. My journey with Quiet on Set began on a lazy spring afternoon. Intrigued by its unique concept, I decided to give it a try. Little did I know that it would become much more than just a game to me. As I delved deeper into the world of Quiet on Set, I found myself completely immersed in the creative process. The game challenged me to think outside the box, to experiment with different ideas, and to push the boundaries of what I thought was possible. Quiet on Set also taught me valuable life lessons that extend far beyond the realm of gaming. Every setback was an opportunity to learn and grow, every success a testament to the power of determination. Looking back, I am grateful for the profound impact Quiet on Set has had on my life. It ignited a spark within me, guiding me towards a path of creativity and self-discovery. Through its immersive gameplay and community spirit, it showed me that anything is possible with dedication and a little imagination. Quiet on Set isn't just a game; it's a transformative experience that will always hold a special place in my heart.

Absolutely awful. One of the worst games I have ever played. To begin with, this game is focused on wokeness and the advocacy of gender pronouns. By the time you reach the third case, speaking with characters gets confusing because they start referring to a single character as "they" and "them." I got into several heated conversations with these AI characters about why we are using gender pronouns to refer to a single character. And they all got down right angry at me with scowled faces as they informed me that this certain character identifies as non-binary and that I needed to be accepting of this immediately. While trying to ignore this aspect of the game I encountered several other issues such as the game crashing to the desktop after selecting a murderer, player movement being too fast, and cutscenes dropping the frame rate down into the 30s. And if you think it could be fun saying some inappropriate things to these AI characters, think again. They all reply by only telling you that you are being inappropriate and that's it. The graphics are also very outdated, there is only one graphic setting of low to high, you cannot remap the controls, there is no mouse sensitivity or fov slider, and some areas cause the screen to flicker when getting too close to the walls. There is also no save function because each case is timed. That's right. You only have a matter of minutes before you are prompted to choose a murderer. And then once you do, there is a good possibility that the game will crash. By my second crash, I was done with this awful experience. I would stay away from this mess and I most certainly cannot recommend it.

I would strongly discourage you from purchasing this game at full price of $20. The developer removed multiple routes for main characters, possibly just to save on time and rush this out the door for a hasty 1.0. Several storylines end abruptly with neither a clear resolution nor any indication they will be finished in the future. The developer is a poor communicator, to the point that many fans assumed the game was abandoned, and has missed multiple deadlines that he set for himself and announced to the community. Linda's ending feels rushed and out of character, a bad sign given she's the face of the game and the de facto main love interest. As the quality of the animations increase, the quality of the writing and pacing of the story decreases over the course of the game. At the very least it's not grindy.

Given the actions of this developer over the course of years being in his community, I fully believe this is a rush job to move on to the next cash cow and no further content updates will be coming, and I would encourage you to vote with your wallet and purchase any number of adult games with a track record of reliable updates, solid writing, and professional conduct on the part of the developers. If any of the deleted endings or cutoff storylines are polished and reintroduced with the quality some parts of the game have shown, I will be more than happy to change my review. Until then - DO NOT BUY.

"Final Edition" isn't final or complete at all. The game contains a number of unfinished parts, and even tells you once you hit a wall that it's given all you're going to get from it. And the bits that are finished are poorly executed, so not even worth dealing with.

It is a great game, but it is not finished nor will it ever be finished. So if you don't mind paying for it then go for it. You should really check the comments on Icstor's Patreon page before purchase https://www.patreon.com/icstor.
Don't be fooled by the title, Final Edition does not mean Finished Edition. It simply means the developer stopped working on the game and called it Final,..and it very much shows when you play it.

Decently executed RenPy incest-harem dating-sim-lite.  About 11 hours to complete it.
3rd party incest patch necessary for some of the relationships to make sense; plus 3rd party content restoration patch adds some scenes that have been removed for the Steam version.

[h1]The game isn't particularly original[/h1]

You've seen everything this game has to offer before, in varying degrees of quality.
[i]Filf[/i] has a near identical setup, but with fewer characters so it ends up with about half the content.  [i]My Cute Roommate[/i] has slightly more depth to the gameplay, but again - far less content.  [i]Lust Theory[/i] has prettier presentation, but is far more linear.

As with all of these titles, it doesn't really solve the fundamental problems games of this genre always have:  Superficial linear stories with the gals and very limited player agency; because letting the player create a narrative via their gameplay choices makes it too complicated to create a bespoke plot.

This game is very much middle-of-the-pack.  There's a decent amount of content, which means the stories don't feel as rushed and as inconsequential as in some titles; but it's still spread too thin and to superficially to be satisfying.  Everything still feels incomplete, anticlimactic, unsatisfying.

[h1]There's pretty much no player agency[/h1]

The grindy currency earning minigames are pointless and add no value to the product.  The things you spend your currency on are part of a linear story, so you don't get to do anything creative with them.  Even the obligatory "go to the gym to become a chad" elements are totally scripted and party of a VN route rather than part of a sandbox progression system.

What little interactivity there is basically consists of "which gal's plotline do you feel like advancing to the next scene" - which is better than nothing, but it's pretty bare bones.

What matters most in a VN is the player being able to engineer kinky scenarios with the best gals; to instigate relationship drama; and to enjoy the payoff you get from the results of this.
And so many VNs flub it because they don't understand why the clich√©s and tropes exist in the medium, so just include them "because".

[h1]The H-scenes are fine, but nothing special[/h1]

As is typical of similar products, they're all a bit by-the-numbers and sterile.  The attempts at introducing stakes ('oh, it's a dangerous day!' - doesn't matter, the game does precisely nothing with this dramatic tension) instantly dissolve because the game can't be bothered to spend time developing them further.

Part of this is the "let's pretend the incest harem isn't an incest harem to avoid getting kicked off Patreon!" issue, where devs think they're being clever disguising the setup as "it's a landlady!" - but end up having to omit all of the erotic and dramatic tension in the taboo to make the dialogue fit.
Part of it is probably not having any stand-out games to crib substantial "epilogue" gameplay off of; and not wanting to invest the time in interactive content that won't bulk up the playtime of people who don't make the decisions that trigger it.

It's a shame, as there is some high-kink plotting at work - but it's not really capitalised on effectively.

[h1]This game is just more of the same[/h1]

On the plus side, it's more complete than stuff like [i]MILFs of Sunville[/i] which want you to buy multiple chapters and keep you on the hook indefinitely without really coming up with the goods.

On the other hand, there's so many near identical games out there - and it doesn't matter if this one is marginally better or worse in any given respect, there's nothing stand-out or original in it.

If you know what you're getting into and are like "Yeah, I could do with some more slice-of-life RenPy eroge" - then yeah, this one's "fine".  It's tolerable, it's presentation and content is adequate.  It's mediocre but functional.

But if you expect something fresh, something novel, or even for the game to make good on any of the tropes and features that those games all fail to successfully deploy - well this game isn't going to do it.

As much as I want to like the game, there is a lot of missing content from previous versions. Some routes end abruptly when it seems to just be getting started and the money grind is just ridiculous. All the models and scenes look great, just wish this final edition had everything we had before with actual finished content

This game in definitively unfinished. If this game was outright bad I probably wouldn't right a review but the game advertises itself in the trailer and first few hours as being solid and finished but this is most definitely not the case. Animations are mildly smooth nothing like the trailer and the dialogue associated is so not it. A waste of game assets and money.

1. For a norp game the MC has a good model but he doesn't have a pin-able personality.

2. Choices seemingly do not matter. Most if not all are mostly left up to release your load there or there and when given an option the game somehow goofs that up. Ex.  You don't give a character your phone number and less than 3-5 in game mins later she gets it and starts sending nudes pissing off the current character your dating. 

3. Scenes are poorly written.

4. Bad resource management, you can easily get all the money you need by stealing it in convenient locations or just playing gambling games on your PC.

5. The game lacks a coherent identity, you don't have anything really to go off of except for the all too common "college/family life" .

6. No theme of progression, and a constant grind of going back and forth between settings, feels like chore. Other than the pretense of sex, I do not care to interact with the characters except for maybe Sara and Delilah.

7. Mini games that functionally do not exist. One in particular the pool mini game only gives you the illusion that it is a game. You race a character in a pool and no matter how fast you click you are going to lose regardless. No noticeable difference in 10.5 CPS and 2 CPS. So the game basically forces you to lose and go to the gym, which for whatever reason you are not allowed to go to the gym prior so you don't have to face a defeat. This repeats three times in a row.

8. Only two characters in the game have a unique personality that is actually likable that being Sara  and Delilah, to which the latter by the time you get to actually cracking open a good relationship with than the game drops her.

Up front, the game is not actually finished. You have about 90-95% of the content save for the Neighbor's story. That said the rest of the game is finished.

Next point that you must be aware of is the need for a 3rd party patch (The guides section of steam will point you in the right direction.) to be able to play the game as intended.

After those points what we have here is a solidly done Adult VN. It's not original or ground breaking but the visuals are well done and the writing is solid considering what these games usually have. I will say do not buy this game at full price, $20 for a game that still has unfinished content is too much. Wait for at least a 50% sale or better.

Overall this game is not bad and there is a game here. The art and scenes are decent. However at $20 USD I cannot recommend it. Additionally, the content feels unfinished and rushed, especially when you look at the world hub and the items. The puzzles are not difficult and the silent text leaves you wanting more. The scenes are decent considering the art style. The motion capture and animations are pleasing. I do not blame the dev for cutting corners to finish the project and move on. 
if it was sold at $10USD I might recommend it.

Here's what I'd say:

This is not as good as BaD... this is definitely a step down from that.

But this is better than Man of the House.

Basically, this game uses the sort of "open world" idea of Man of the House. But like Man of the House, it's just two stores, a college, and a few one-off locations. So, not much of an open world. However, unlike Man of the House and more like BaD, the locations all have multiple rooms to them (even the one offs), and there are cash and secret scenes to find in them.

The pace of this is far better than Man of the House, though. Where Man of the House had you repeat the same scenes (which were unskippable) over and over again to 'heart up' over 20 times or more, this has a far more sensible pace where  scenes are new each time and lead to 'hearting up' a few times after a bunch of unique scenes and events.

The college though... I mean, I wish this tried a different setting, because college has been used over and over, and games like BaD took the college setting and made a much more memorable story than this creates.

Worse, the mini-games are extremely simple compared to BaD. For BaD, there were word scrambles, logic puzzles, mazes, a ridiculously challenging reflexes-based volleyball mini-game, a more merciful tennis mini-game, and even a old-school Tetris-esque puzzle. And that's leaving out the pseudo-rhythem-based fighting mini-game in BaD. Meanwhile, this game has mini-games that are at least above Man of the House (where the mini-games were just pick three options and hope the RNG works out to get that pizza delivered). But what's here in this game is way less than BaD, as in this one, we have a literal rock-paper-scissors betting game, a couple versions of the same match-the-cards memory game, and a couple of incredibly simple one-offs (including a 'electrify the sex toy just right' game that looks more like one of the torture options Trevor had for that scene in GTA:V).

But it's in the story where this falls way, way flatter than BaD. 

Right away, there's not a lot of choice in dialogue. And of what's there, most has little meaning. Where BaD verged on being a RPG with its focus on some options locking out others, and having a pseudo Karma system that progressed as you made choices, this game has very little that seems to alter the story.

And the story... it's the 'land-lady' trope from Man of the House combined with a way less plausible version of BaD's 'professors and dean caught in a scandal' set up. This somehow borrowed elements from *both* games. I mean, kudos for understanding your source material, I guess, but the set-up is surreal in how much it borrows. Even the appearance of the dean of the college... it looks like the guy from BaD.

And it goes further, as the game directly breaks the fourth wall to discuss the creation of AVN games. It's bizarre how it lifts from other games' stories, then still breaks the fourth wall to have characters discuss stuff about making these types of games. In House Party, I can accept that the characters talk about being in a video-game because the entire tone is irreverent and zany in that game. But here, it's jarring because the game is grounded in reality a lot of the time... House Party gets away with it more because people fly in on hot-air balloons and distort the laws of physics.


At the end of the day, though, the game is decent for what it is. It's a step above Man of the House, in that the pacing of content is better and far less repetitive. People are pointing to chunks of the game that aren't fully rounded out, but at the same time, Man of the House also had areas t hat were empty 90% of the time, so having a mall under construction and an empty school pool (so far I have found no uses for either) isn't the worst of things.

For $14.00 (the current, release-week sale) I'd say it's a solid game. Animations are even marginally better than BaD at times (though very similar, there's just a slight bit more detail to the animations in this game). And the pace is better than Man of the House. 

But the story is definitely nowhere near BaD, the dialogue choices and number of meaningful decisions are light-years from BaD, and the open world itself is better than Man of the House by not by leaps and bounds. So go in with reasonable expectations, and it will be a decent game.

The "final" edition is far from final.  The story ends... maybe 1/3 of the way through, based on apparent progress with characters.

Unfortunately, there's a lot of consensus in the various discussion groups that this is SOP from the developer.  Long drawn dev cycle... early, promising releases, then a "final" that doesn't live up to the earlier pre-releases and dead ends.  For example, the neighbor has 3 short conversations and one long exposition.  BUT there's a backyard, doors, windows, and a ladder that mean nothing.  Apparently an earlier release made use of these, but that's been cut. 

There's "equipment" you can buy that does nothing.  Several  locations that have one scene, and then nothing. 

I support the dev on one of the patron sites.  The "promised" free access didn't happen till several days after the game was already on Steam.

Note to self.  Don't get sucked in by pretty pictures.  Read the discussions and the reviews thoroughly.

The story can be summed up by "bang everyone".  It mostly revolves around sneaking around behind other family member's backs while trying to bang your mom/siblings. I see a lot of reviews here complaining about game being cut short by the developer/being incomplete compared to what was promised on Patreon. And to be honest I don't think it really matters!

I've never seen the Patreon version of the game - I've decided to take a risk, buy this game on Steam and as a result - I had a lot of fun with it! The game is quite long (but thankfully due to scenes/erotic buildup and not due to boring dialogs!) and full of very nicely done "action". I've spend more than 20h on it to finish all the storylines from different characters. And there are many of those! I haven't noticed anything "clearly removed" from the game - maybe 2 characters (out of ~10) have very short storylines - and maybe there were some ideas to make them longer? I don't know - but what is there is in my opinion still very good.

The visuals are great - the developer for sure has a lot of talent and put a lot of effort there. The animations are also frequent and of a very high quality. I've never seen any "disfigurations", clipping or anything else that would show that any shortcuts/rushed work was done with them. The character stories are quite interesting, and the writing is pretty correct (no translation issues). Of course there is the obvious "landlady/roommate" workaround made to avoid incest which may break immersion a little - but there is a very short guide, also available on Steam, clearly explaining how to "patch" the game, to make the dialogs as originally intended.

There is free roam, there are minigames, there is even some grinding to earn money, which can be annoying sometimes - but there are also savegame editors available on the net, in case you really cannot stand playing another "paper-rock-scissors" or "memory" game, to earn additional cash.

Could the game be longer? Probably - there is still a lot of potential to make another season out of it, or add even more scenes - but what is there is in my opinion enough. I have to admit that the game actually started getting a little too long for me after those 20h, but I was still curious what other scenes I will see, and how the story/relations would evolve.

There are no different endings, (almost) all stories could be completed in a single playthrough - so the harem ending is there. I recall maybe 2-3 choices where you can cut the storyline short - those are the ones where the game tells you what is "recommended" - actually trying it the other way around could give you even more interesting scenes - so it's worth to at least save/try/reload. 

The main protagonist is not a moron/pig (at least not too much) so it's easy to sympathise with him, and there is a lot of funny dialogues/scenes.

In general - Milfy City is a very good game. One that (at least in my opinion) is of quality of Being a D*k or similar high quality AVNs. I strongly belive that this one is definitely worth trying. Have fun!

To change a tire, you need to follow these steps12:
Find a safe location to park the vehicle.
Turn on your hazard lights.
Apply the parking brake.
Apply wheel wedges.
Remove the hubcap or wheel cover.
Loosen the lug nuts.
Place the jack under the vehicle.
Raise the vehicle with the jack.
Remove the lug nuts and the flat tire.
Install the new tire and tighten the lug nuts.

[b] Bestial Reception [/b] has the tag "side scroller" but that's not true. 
It is way more of a roguelite.

[h1] The following dissection of the game is a mixture of constructive feedback to the dev and a review for my fellow gamers [/h1]

You choose a character out of four, with the possibility of unlocking an additional two. 
The conditions of unlocking these extra characters are unclear though. (Note to dev: Maybe it should be mentioned somewhere)
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3028013988

Each character has a special ability it can trigger every 15 seconds or so, as well as a weapon specific for said character. 
This adds a welcome variety and unique possibilities for pairing between skills and weapons. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3027983455

In the selection screen, the text is too crowded. 
To fix this: 1. Place each parameter on a separate line and 
2. Use images instead of words, e.g. a heart = health, etc., and standardize across the game (i.e. in the merchant screen)
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3028014464

When selecting a character, it's only the ENTER key that allows us to proceed. 
Add LMB as well as already done in other sections of the game, like here https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3028014880

There's no escape back to the main menu from the character selection screen. 
You are literally forced to either continue and start a new run or to ALT+TAB to force quit out of the game! 
This must be addressed. 

This roguelite offers a twist: 
Enemies drop artifacts hindering you one way or another. Pick them up and endure their passive effect till you reach the merchant and sell each for coins, which you then use to upgrade your rather skeletal arsenal. You may choose to ignore them and rely on your default weapon. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3028015897

A neat trick is to leave the negative-effect artifact on the ground & only at the end of the level do you pick it up!
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3028016478

The color of this boss's health meter -and the health bar of your own character actually- is confusing. 
Maybe change it so that 'red' means full health and 'grey/black' means lost health. As it is, dark red for full health while bright red for lost health are just too ambiguous.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3027983881

When the player is in the middle of a run and hits ESC, this is the menu that appears. 
It might be a good idea to add more information, like the default gun you start with, your health, current stats, etc. As it is, it's a bit too bare.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3027984368

Typo: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3028016023

The game features 10 very straightforward achievements, except maybe the two involving unlocking the extra two characters.

The achievements should have clearer wording:
It says, Kill 50/100/200 enemies.
It should say, Kill 50/100/200 enemies "in a single run."
I know because the 200 achievement didn't unlock for me although I killed over 150 in a single run before, so yeah!

Also there's a small typo in the achievement Thick - skinned 
It should be Thick-skinned
No spaces around the -
~~

I did have some fun with the gameplay and the sound effects cracked me up! Check the duck in the trailer lol

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
At the price tag of $2.99, the game isn't expensive by any stretch. Yet again, there are so many terrific master pieces (Tomb Raider 2013, Sleeping Dogs, Ryse: Son of Rome) that go on sale for exactly that same price. 

So I find myself recommending against purchasing the game at full price. 
In the game's current state, maybe for 66% off it would be a good deal. 
I hope the dev addresses these issues because the game does have solid potential.

"Bestial Reception" delivered an electrifying gaming experience. Mastering survival as humanoid animals in a pixelated post-apocalyptic realm was captivating. Navigating intense battles, collecting loot, and unveiling secrets kept me engaged. The dynamic soundtrack added to the adrenaline rush. The game's uniqueness and challenges kept me hooked, making it a memorable adventure worth playing again.
GJ!

"The Crystal of the Cave" is a gaming experience that has captivated me from the very start. As a gamer who appreciates the art of exploration and puzzle-solving, this game stands out as a beacon of creativity and challenge. The game's premise, centered around the mystical crystal within a vast and intricate cave system, offers a perfect setting for an adventure that is both visually stunning and intellectually stimulating.

Navigating through the game's beautifully rendered caverns, I am constantly in awe of the attention to detail and the ambient lighting that brings the cave to life. The puzzles are cleverly designed, requiring a blend of logic, strategy, and sometimes a dash of daring, which makes each discovery feel like a true achievement.

The story is another strong point, with well-written dialogue and a plot that unfolds at a pace that keeps me engaged without overwhelming me. The characters are memorable, and their interactions add depth to the gameplay, making me feel like a part of the cave's legend.

In conclusion, "The Crystal of the Cave" is an exceptional game that offers a rich and rewarding experience. It's a must-play for anyone who loves a good adventure and the satisfaction of solving puzzles that challenge the mind. I highly recommend it.

Bright colors, detailed textures and perfectly detailed character models create a unique style and atmosphere of the game. Gameplay is dynamic and varied, constantly having to adapt to new situations and opponents.Combat is realized at the highest level: convenient control, many types of weapons and abilities, as well as the ability to combine them to create unique combinations. The variety of locations and levels is also impressive: from gloomy dungeons to picturesque forests and deserts.We would like to mention the music and sound effects. They perfectly complement the gameplay and create a unique atmosphere.In general, I am very satisfied with the purchase and recommend Bestial Reception to all fans of quality and exciting games. It is a great choice for those who want to spend time for an interesting and exciting gameplay.

You‚Äôll have fun for a couple of hours in this top-down shooter, but then you‚Äôll notice there‚Äôs nothing new here.

You start by selecting one of six characters. Two of these must be unlocked, but the other four are available right away. One very strong character is unlocked by finishing the game once, but the other is a mystery since I don‚Äôt know how to unlock it. Because each character has a different primary weapon, artifact, and special ability, they all look and feel unique.

The objective is to kill enemies room after room until you reach the final stage. Each stage takes place in a single location. A teleporter that transports you to the next stage or the shop appears when the opponent counter reaches zero. You must pass through four distinct locations made up of a number of levels in order to complete the game. At the end of each location, a boss is waiting for you.

The only difference between locations is the color of the environment and the opposition. There are several of them, each with a unique attack pattern, but if you keep moving, most of them remain largely harmless. The only enemies that are bothersome are those that leave a toxic puddle behind after they die. 

The fun part about locations is that some parts can be destroyed with either bullets or something stronger like a dynamite. This has no use other than to give you more room to move around. But spawning in a new stage should‚Äôve been done better. Now you show up surrounded by enemies that swarm you as soon as you fire a single shot. This feels like a cheap way of punishing you.

All main weapons waste bullets that are found in chests around the stage. Although your primary weapons can kill anything, you have the option to purchase new ones at the store. This can be dangerous because it will reset the ammo you have accumulated for your current weapon. A huge downside is that you can carry only one weapons. If you pick up a new one, your current will be gone. This can quickly lead into disaster if you lose one of the best guns.

An artifact that will always have a negative effect may be dropped by some enemies. These should be collected because you can sell them for some coins. This enables you to purchase artifacts that have beneficial effects. The only thing you must remember is to pick up the artifact after buying it.  

The fact that some perks never disappear is another unpleasant side-effect of negative artifacts. I'm talking about artifacts that lower your overall health. You can end up with just one heart for the duration of the game because this doesn't reset even after you sell the nasty relic.

An Awesome Virtual Driving Experience: DMVr

Rating: 4.5/5

DMVr is an impressively realistic car simulator that not only appeals to car enthusiasts but also offers an excellent tool for those who want to practice for their driver's license. With impressive graphics and detailed physics, this game creates an almost authentic driving experience.

Graphics: 5/5

The graphics are outstanding and take realism to a new level. From detailed interiors to realistic landscapes and weather conditions, DMVr offers a visual feast for gamers. The car models are incredibly detailed, and shadows and lighting effects contribute to a sense of authenticity.

Physics and Driving experience: 4.5/5

One of DMVr's strengths lies in its realistic physics engine. Cars react to road surfaces, braking, acceleration and torque in a way that few simulators can match. This makes it an excellent tool for practicing and improving real driving skills. However, there are some instances where the physics can feel exaggerated, which can be somewhat of a challenge for beginners.

Sound: 4/5

The sound in DMVr is generally good and adds to the realistic atmosphere. Engine sounds, tire screeching and ambient sounds are well designed and enhance the driving experience. Sometimes certain sounds can be played a little too loud, which can be annoying.

Learning curve: 4/5

For those using the game as a tool to practice for their driver's license, the learning curve can be somewhat steep. Despite a built-in training mode and tutorial, some parts can be challenging for beginners. More customizable and step-by-step practice modes could improve accessibility.



Conclusion:

DMVr is undoubtedly one of the most realistic car simulators on the market and offers a stunning visual and technical experience. For those who want to train for a driver's license or simply enjoy an authentic driving experience, this game is definitely worth considering. Despite a few minor flaws, the DMVr is an impressive achievement and a delight for car enthusiasts.

"DMVR: A Game that Reshaped My World Amidst Double Cancer and Skulltrooper Disease"

In the midst of facing the dual challenges of double cancer and the daunting Skulltrooper Disease, I discovered a game that not only provided a much-needed escape but also emerged as a vital source of strength and inspiration. DMVR isn't your ordinary video game; it's an immersive experience that not only transported me to captivating realms but also played a pivotal role in reshaping my perspective and resilience.

Right from the start, DMVR captivated me with its stunning visuals and dynamic gameplay. The diverse and imaginative worlds within the game served as a welcome distraction from the harsh realities of my medical journey. The game's storyline and vibrant environments created a unique and absorbing experience, allowing me to momentarily set aside the pain and uncertainty tied to my health struggles.

What sets DMVR apart is its ability to create a sense of adventure and exploration. The intricately designed landscapes, challenges, and quests within the game became a metaphorical journey, reflecting the battles I faced in real life. Navigating through the game's obstacles, I found parallels to my own struggles, fostering a profound sense of resilience and determination.

What astonished me most about DMVR was its impact on my mindset. The game didn't just offer an escape; it prompted a shift in perspective. Confronting challenges within the game encouraged me to approach real-life problems with newfound creativity and determination. DMVR became a catalyst for personal growth and resilience, proving that even in the face of double cancer and the formidable Skulltrooper Disease, triumph was possible.

In conclusion, DMVR transcends the typical gaming experience. It became a source of inspiration, strength, and unexpected connections during a challenging chapter of my life marked by double cancer and the daunting Skulltrooper Disease. Its captivating gameplay, immersive worlds, and unforeseen life lessons turned it into a transformative journey that continues to resonate with me long after the game is over.

Since many of you guys are confused about the prodedures and methods that involve touching grass, I decided to make this guide for you.

Step One: Locate an area of grass. The first step in touching grass is to find a place where grass is present. This can be a lawn in your backyard, a park, a sports field, or any other Slocation where grass is growing. Make sure you have access to the area and that it is safe for you to be there.

Step Two: Stand or kneel in a comfortable position. Once you have found an area of grass, stand or kneel in a comfortable position. If you are standing, make sure you have good balance and are able to maintain your balance while reaching out to touch the grass. If you are kneeling, place a cushion or towel under your knees for added comfort. 

Step Three: Extend your arm(s) in front of you, with your hand(s) open and fingers extended. This allows you to easily reach the grass and feel the texture and sensation of the blades.

Step Four: Slowly lower your hand(s) towards the grass. Take your time and move slowly to ensure that you don't accidentally step on or damage any of the grass.

Step Five: Allow your fingers to come into contact with the blades of grass. You may feel the softness and/or dampness of the grass depending on the environment. You may also feel the different temperatures of the grass if you are in a place with a different climate.

Step Six: Gently move your fingers through the blades of grass, feeling the texture and sensation of the grass. Take note of the different feelings and textures you experience.

Repeat step 6 as desired, moving your fingers through different sections of the grass to experience the variety of textures and sensations.

Step Seven: When you have finished touching the grass, stand or rise back to your original position. Take a moment to appreciate the experience and the sensation of the grass on your fingers.

Note: If you are allergic or have any medical condition that may affect you to touch the grass, it is recommended to consult with your physician before attempting this activity. Also, be aware of any rules or regulations regarding touching or being in the area of grass you have chosen.

As someone that actually enjoyed the base game despite some of its annoying tidbits, this DLC is pretty disappointing. 

Pros: 
- Annoying need to repair equipment every five seconds removed
- Equipment upgrades as a whole rather than individual items

Cons: 
- It's basically a stripped down version of the base game
- No more sponsor-ships
- Still no way to challenge contenders or challengers manually as a champion. 
- RPG event system is bare bones and at times glitchy. Caused my fighter to lose his title without even fighting
- Very little to actually buy outside of upgrades and temporary buffs that aren't worth it after you max out furniture. 
- Rivalry system and the "personalities" don't really matter as much as they should. Seems like you can get rival locked if you don't get a challenge from your rival and you move on divisions. 
- Support staff are there? But beyond maybe giving you a bit of extra fame and money (and the fact that you can't edit your support staff afterwards) they don't really feel important. 
- Manager skills are hidden and to be quite fair doesn't really feel like it mattered on which one you chose. 

As a boxer and fan of the base game, I was pretty excited to see there was going to be a solo career mode. Disappointed that this is essentially a very stripped down version of the base game.

As much as I was anticipating this dlc. It was kinda a let down but maybe that's my fault. The gameplay isnt transformative its your same basic game with some things taken away. Its still as much of a grind as the base game but at least you could have multiple boxers with different styles and fight strategies in the main game. The manager doesnt seem to matter much, the rivalries still arent relevant. Near the end you're just sitting on a stack of cash with nothing to really spend it on and im not even the world circuit champion yet. I hope they add something else to ease the time it takes to train since its just a solo career.

This DLC may be a bit buggy, I'm on day 250+ with max stats and STILL in minor circuit and unranked. Why? earlier in the game I got my scripted manager prompt and I saw all their stats and quirks were terrible. Let's say I declined them all thinking I'd get a reroll or at least the option to join them back in a week or so but. NOPE! Maxed stat swarmer with over 30 wins no loses in minor circuit and who only gets notifications about the top boxing managers AND random sponship deals that I can't even participate in and my fame is locked at 0.1 so basically this is a hard lock. At least so far but I've played nearly a year in game and nothing. I would've quit earlier but I just needed to display just how silly this is. Raptor Claw please fix or at the very least not allow you to decline managers like that. Game is still fun if you want to kick back and just watch weird looking dudes hit each other and make stock-esk sounds.

Needs major tuning as far as getting injured after fights go. I will have fights go where the opponent never lands a hit on me and I clean up the round within 10seconds yet I leave the fight going from 85% to 30% with minor injuries. At this point I have to spend the next few days laying in  bed and before you know it im in debt and have to start my run over.
Its fun if you liked the base game but dont want to manage multiple boxers.
A game of this quality and magnitude deserves support, especially when it is available literally for free.

[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
Joy Life II is a Unity based memory matching game.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
There are 10 puzzles. The number of cards varies from 6 to 20 cards, increasing every few levels. All of the cards start off face down so you have to find all of the cards.

The cards have a number in the upper left with a Roman numeral of how many objects are shown. I would have appreciated if the second card selected stayed visible a bit longer and if the Roman numeral correctly identified the number of objects, both 5 (V) and 6 (VI) show as VI. You only have a moment to see the second card. It would be better if both cards stayed flipped until the next selection was made or at least a few seconds.

Completing the level you unlock a story about Ovi. The stories are very poorly translated English. You to view a movie if you have the Free Steam DLC installed, otherwise you only get an image. If you don't select the Album option after completing the level you can view the unlocked content in the Album. You cannot view the images if you have the patch installed and you cannot view the movies if you don't have the patch installed.

[h1]The Gallery[/h1]
The Gallery is accessed using the Album option on the title screen. If you do not have the Free Steam DLC installed you will only be able to see the images. If you do have the Free Steam DLC installed you will only be able to see the movies. The movies have three camera icons in the upper right. Each camera is a different camera angle. The heart icon at the bottom of the icons finishes the scene.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
A very quick memory match with images of a beautiful model as your reward (Movies if you have the FREE Steam DLC installed)

[b]7/10[/b]

Cube rolling game in a cute, child-friendly presentation.

[b]What is it:[/b] A cube rolling game, you play as a cube trying to reach a target spot, but with a specific face. To make it more immersive, in the game you are a cute animal trapped in a jar, and to get out you need to place the lid face on top of the lid-removing tile.

The story: Koro and her siblings were playing nicely in the park when the mean witch Strawberry trapped all of them in jars. Can Koro the Cat escape and save her siblings?

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3300668247

The game is very cute, with well decorated environments with bright pastel colors, funny creatures and objects, plenty of animations and funny cutscenes. Ignoring the puzzles, this is perfect for a toddler, it reminded me of that Netflix show Buddi.

The puzzles are mostly easy too, but I think some of the levels get too hard for those that don‚Äôt excel at puzzle games. The game is split into 12 chapters of 10 levels each. Each chapter has 9 regular levels with only one cube rolling, and 1 special ‚Äúrescue‚Äù level in which you simultaneously roll two cubes. The first chapter is just about rolling, and the next five chapters introduce one mechanic each: paired teleporters, slippery ice, buttons and the obstacles they toggle, fragile lilypads, and rotating carousels. These first six chapters are manageable, since they have one mechanic (other than basic rolling), but then comes a chapter with harder levels with each mechanic, then more and more complicated chapters combining two or more mechanics. And the last level in the last chapter requires moving all 6 characters and finding a way for all of them to end up on their target tile at once! Definitely not a toddler level.

The game does a lot of things well. The presentation is great, for those that like cute things and very decorated environments. The ‚Äústory‚Äù keeps young players engaged. The levels are decent, easy but not boring.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3300668584

But a lot of things could be improved: undo, the level select, the long animations, the totally basic story, and slightly unresponsive controls. There is no undo, and it would really be useful, given that moving back to the previous state doesn‚Äôt work in levels with more than the basic rolling mechanism. The problem with the level select is that it's a 3-levels-deep structure. First you select the character to play with, then one of the worlds available to that character, then the actual level from that world. There is no easy way to just play the level you were at last time, when you restart the game you have to go there yourself. I would add a Continue button on the intro screen, separate from the Level Select button, and I would separate the character selection from the level selection. There are ‚Äúpretty‚Äù animations between levels, which is cute for kids, but I‚Äôm very impatient and I‚Äôd like to be able to skip them faster. It takes too long for the ‚Äúpress to skip‚Äù button to show up and work. For such a simple game, loading levels takes too long. It‚Äôs cute that there is a story, but it‚Äôs very nonsensical and poorly conveyed. After every chapter, the characters play a bit, as much as they can as blobs with no limbs, which is mostly jumping around, then zoom in on the witch, and everybody runs down. Colorful blobs moving on the screen is enough for toddlers, but this game isn‚Äôt for toddlers. Put a bit more effort into the story if you want to have one. Plus, controls are a bit finicky, there is no key repeat and no input caching, and with a thumbstick on a controller sometimes it does move as long as I keep it pressed, sometimes it stops after every move, and I don‚Äôt know why it behaves differently.

It might be a nice relaxing game for others, but personally I didn‚Äôt really enjoy it.

[b]How hard is it:[/b] Mostly easy, but with some moderate levels every now and then, and a challenging final level.

[b]How long is it:[/b] 120 levels, 3-6 hours, must be done in order, no skipping.

[b]Level design:[/b] OK, nothing surprising, but the levels aren‚Äôt boring either.

[b]Quality:[/b] Not bad, but could be improved. No undo. Selecting a level requires too many steps, and there‚Äôs no Continue on the start screen. Works with keyboard and controllers, but not configurable. A few audio and video settings. Cloud saving is supposed to be implemented, but it doesn‚Äôt work. Good progress achievements. It‚Äôs sluggish on an integrated GPU, and the controls and all the animations are slowing me down.

[b]Worth the price:[/b] If you‚Äôre not buying it to share with some children, wait for a discount.

[b]Most positive aspect for me:[/b] Good mechanics.

[b]Most negative aspect for me:[/b] No undo.

[b]What would make it better:[/b] Undo. Key repeat and input caching. Add support for multiple profiles. Add access to the settings from the pause menu. High resolution application icon. Fix cloud saving. Simplify the level selection. Key remapping. Graphics quality settings for slower systems. Improve the level loading time.

I particularly enjoyed the final stage in each world, where you need to rescue your friends in double missions. After finishing the game, I was delighted to find extra levels where you can play as different characters, which added significant value. This game shows great promise and could benefit from an unlimited run mode and a mobile port.

Great job, development team!

Koro Neko (which translated means "Cat"), is a puzzle game that features a bright, colorful world inhabited by anthropomorphic cats. The game's main objective involves solving puzzles through the manipulation of jelly jars and other objects within various levels. Players must roll these jars to specific locations, often navigating obstacles and utilizing various power-ups along the way.

One of the core gameplay mechanics in Koro Neko involves manipulating the game's physics to roll the jelly jars into the correct positions. This is accomplished through a combination of careful movement and strategic planning. Players must take into account factors such as momentum, angles, and the unique properties of various game elements to successfully complete each level.

In addition to rolling jelly jars, players will encounter a variety of other puzzle elements throughout the game. These include buttons that activate platforms, moving obstacles, and environmental hazards. Navigating these challenges requires a combination of reflexes, problem-solving, and timing.

The game's story is relatively simple, revolving around the hero cats' efforts to thwart the schemes of an antagonist named Strawberry. The narrative primarily serves as a backdrop for the puzzle-solving gameplay and does not heavily influence the moment-to-moment action.

One potential drawback of Koro Neko is its performance on older hardware or systems that do not utilize solid-state drives (SSDs). The game may experience slow loading times and occasional lag on these systems. Furthermore, the game's focus on cuteness and simplicity in both visuals and gameplay may not appeal to players who prefer more complex or realistic experiences.

In conclusion, Koro Neko is a puzzle game that offers a casual and colorful experience centered around rolling jelly jars and solving environmental challenges. Its emphasis on simple mechanics and whimsical aesthetics may appeal to fans of the genre or those seeking a laid-back gaming experience. However, its performance issues on older systems and potential lack of depth in gameplay and narrative may be a concern for some players.

Basic impressions: 
Not a bad successor to KKP but if you already have KKP with mods installed and the like, this will not really stack up by comparison for quite some time. There are some features implemented in this game that I always thought would benefit KKP as well that were never added in a way that I'd consider user-friendly(Basically, making your own models/animations and crap in Studio mode while it runs at -10 FPS, with so many tools on the screen that you can barely see the "Scene" you're supposed to be working on...) But it severely lacks in the playability that makes KKP so enjoyable for casual play. It wasn't too long before I "shelved" it so I don't wind up resenting the purchase due to the time it takes for further developments, both official and not.

More details and potentially helpful info:
First off. like KKP, the game sold on Steam is a kind of watered down version of the end product and they offer a "Premium Patch" provided elsewhere for free that completes the base games content. Without the patch, the only thing the game will offer is an incomplete Character Creator and H Mode to initiate scenes. I played this version for about 20 hours and debated refunding cause it was very lacking. I felt like no matter what I did with my Sliders during Character Creation all the models come out looking roughly the same and the only thing I had a lot of creative freedom with is Hair Styles/Colors. Definitely don't skip the premium patch if you want at least a minimal amount of variety. If you have any problems getting it from the original source, you can also get it via the "HFPatch" Mods/Installer for this game just like on KKP. The "HFPatch" is obviously still in development kinda like the game itself sorta is so it's not gonna add 35GB's of polished content like on KKP but does add some basic animation tweaks(Including a really REALLY basic uncensor filter that is packed with glitches and awkwardness(Example: instead of male appendages "Squishing" after reaching a target point on the receiving model internally where it's not noticeable, it happens on the outside of the receiving model), menu changes and a handful of other plugins you can control the settings to via the in-game settings menu once it's all installed.

After installation of mods/patches and applying a full update, the game finally looks like it has potential(mostly due to Modders) but free roam still needs lots of work and is incredibly boring. The map is a sardine can consisting of a receptionist lobby and an atrium. It has a handful of rooms to enter(not counting the players room) which you can't really explore cause the doors are strictly there as a way to initiate "Events" within the rooms.

Interaction between characters has no depth to it either. The conversations you have will have basically no effect on their attitude towards you. the only way to alter any of their "stats" is through sex and once an attribute is maxed it can unlock new positions or alter interactions with those characters who have it maxed. For instance, once you max out "Friendliness" you unlock 3 new positions for Sex Scenes with that character and others who have it maxed, Once you max "Obsessed" it makes every interaction between that character and you end in a Sex Scene but it also keeps them from tiring out during scenes without using any of the items/settings you unlocked via the achievements and increases the odds they visit you in your room as you sleep.

Speaking of Sleep, it basically serves no purpose here. It can "advance time" which I put in Quotes cause there's no natural sense of Time to be found AFAIK. It's always the same time of day, day of the week, week of the month, month of the year, year of the century Etc...(Ad Infinitum) But "Time" advances at the end of any scene you initiate including peeping anyway. Whenever you initiate a sex scene or a peeping event, at the end of whatever scene you decide on first, you appear back in your room and it resets/shuffles all the characters and events on the map so free roam is basically pointless once you get through the little tutorial. Also, I don't know if it's the maps size that is to blame or what but the "community" consists of 5 individual Groups you can swap between, each Group has room for 20 cards but you can only ever have 1 Group active and by default, characters can't "repeat" across Groups unless you make duplicates in character creation. If you fill every available slot of your chosen Group then not all of them will spawn on the map at once, either so you're better off just keeping the arrangement at under 15 characters each(Literally the maximum amount of character models I have ever counted on the map at once, not including the "Concierge" at the front desk.)

Yeah, I'd say it has a long ways to go but Modders were pretty quick about making a basic HFPatch that was compatible so hopefully won't be too long now.

I would hesitantly say I recommend this game. It's a clear technical upgrade from Koikatsu, but that's about it. Before getting the HF Patch, there is damn near nothing in the game, like at all. Even after getting the patch, you still only get so much. 

I'd say get it, then get the HF Patch and just... wait for the mods to EVENTUALLY get added and give you new reasons to play. The devs clearly aren't going to make that easy, but this is internet. We're human, and we want horny game... it will take time, but we will get horny game to standard.

-Almost forgot the BIGGEST BLUNDER here is no community upload/download for characters, this was a backbone for KK why would they do this??


Things I like:
-New feature that was not in KK or HS is "generate image" where you can randomize or lock things from being randomized in character creation such as facial structure, body type, hair, chest, etc. 
I can see this coming handy in the future for making a model for art without wanting to go thru the effort of doing every little thing (a pain point I had with KK)

-Performance wise feels way better than the other two games, faster load times.
-Models got a glowup, abs look amazing
-Cleaner UI overall, KK felt like spaghetti compared to this
 
In short I am satisfied for now but the content is whelming/limited atm
If I think of anything else to add to this I will, according to other reviews and discussion posts you can get it for 20 bucks cheaper by going to their website if you really want it now before modding is in, I never saw KK or HS go on sale (on steam atleast) so now could be the best chance for a sale.


EDIT: Refunded on account of the game not working on top of my criticism's, also learned from other reviews that modding wouldn't be allowed (people WILL ignore this but this is still very ignorant from the publisher's pov).

Current Review Mar 4th, 2024: Game is now working again for steam users.

I'd love to see more stuff from the developer in the future & I hope they continue to do an awesome job like they have been.

I give this game a Thumbs-Up with a caveat.  When fully updated and patched, the game is good and what we would expect from this sort of game.  The lack of clothing options limits the character creation, but it is still detailed and you can create many different characters with a little time and imagination.  With the inclusion of the Card Upload/Download option, you can share your cards and download one that others created.  There are other ways to share and some people are very creative. The gameplay is familiar and the story is thin, but the game is not trying to be different. It's a Hentai game, after all.  If you like this type of game, it is a good option as it is  being supported by the publisher and will at least have updates through the New Year

Basically, this release is a pretty bare-bones; there's not many personalities for the girls, only a few outfits, and the main mode is a mostly straightforward sandbox. For all those reasons, the price of the game is pretty wince inducing, and the big problem in my eyes is the lack of a Studio Mode (like in Koikatsu) which would have done a lot to alleviate some of the problems. 

However, I do think there is a solid core to the game. The animations are great and varied, and while simple the sandbox does offer some options. And graphics and character model quality is actually pretty top-tier; Koikatsu worked for what it was, but I think there's been a real step up in terms of how everything looks. Likewise, I think there's some real good QOL improvements, such as a greater degree of customisation for clothes patterns/prints, and more 'layering' to character creation (such as being able to change make up and hair for different scenarios, which wasn't possible in previous releases (I think)).

SO, I think there's a really good foundation here. If they build off it (please, please release a Studio mode) I think it could be a really great product overall, though I won't deny they may have jumped the gun releasing it so feature-light.

I didn't actually "play" it - I'm only using editor, Digital Craft and Free Sex mode - that's what I bought it for.
[h3] Price [/h3]
I understand people saying that 60$ is way too high for a game with so little content. Plus 30$ for DLC with studio mode (which you would expect to be included in the base game). So 90$ for a game of that scale... Yeah. But, I understand how much efforts goes into making such game - models, animation, customization system - all for very niche market. So yes, you have to put high price tag to not go bancrupt.
[h3] Content [/h3]
Not very much accesories and cloths - again, I understand. BUT - developes could solve this problem by adding convinient mod support, like Bethesda does where mod manager is official part of the game and mods are distributed via Steam Workshop. That's great way to solve the problem of lacking content
[h3] Digital Craft [/h3]
The studio mode, called Digital Craft comes as 30$ DLC and it's... actually great.
[h3] Censorship [/h3]
Vanilla Steam version allows you to create only old ladies with D-cups, so if you want actually sexy girls - you have to download patch from official Japanese website. Unfortunatelly, even with that patch all ding-dong and wooh-wooh areas are pixelated.

This review is subject to drastic change in the future.

Too early to be worth that $70 slap in the sack. It's a more anime-styled Honey Select 2, but without it's updates and additions. The system is solid, and I keep finding new things to play with in buried submenus. But there's a serious lack in clothes, accessories, hairstyles and decals to make it a really great character customizer.

This version of this game is useless unless downloading "Premium Patch" from their official site and the game is not the full version yet even if the patch is downloaded and added(installed) because of something missing compared to the original version; so, if you really like and want to playing this game, then buy and download the DMM-Fanza or Dlsite version instead, unless you have enough money to buy both steam and DMM-Fanza/Dlsite versions.
Points: 7/10 and 80/100

If the Character customization fully worked, I would be all for this game but when it can glitch out and provide a male that has the same parts as Barbie's "Ken", there is issues.

MAYBE this will be worth the $70 (or whatever insane price they ask for at the time) later but right now, it isn't even worth $40 to me.

Update: It seems like this game suffers from "Always Online" syndrome.  If their servers suck, you can't play...
This is nonsensical.

While I will say that the graphics of this game are very impressive, a big step up from Koikatsu (not that I feel that it was needed), the price tag for this game is thoroughly not worth it...

My advise to anyone who wants to upgrade from Koikatsu Party to this spiritual successor: Wait for the sale.
I'm also sure that the uncensor patch developers for Koikatsu have seen this game and may eventually turn to it to continue their incredible work on it.

Guess I'll start the review with some pros and cons:
(mostly compare to Illusion games since they are "much alike".)
pro:

	1.Better modeling has been implemented.(Especially Skindentation,oof)
	2.It seems like there are more detail customizations,some new accessories,and a few more motion sets.
	3.The game seems to have undergone some refactoring that makes it feel more optimized than its predecessors.

con:

	1.There are apparently fewer clothing options available at the moment.
	2.Exploring the game in the current version feels more like an interactive menu than actual exploration due to the lack of scenarios.
	3.Subtitles are still absent during H scenes.(Still)

Overall Rate:
	7/10---for those haven't played old Illusion titles
	6/10---if you played and had said games

Some personal thoughts:
	I don't really consider myself as one of the core audience of the genre since I didn't spend that much time on the old Illusion series,let alone experimented with some 	more complex mechanisms like modding and workshops.(though I've collect all products that're on Steam)
	But when I heard Illusion's closure announcement,I did feel...troubling,bit upset by the fact that there might not be these kinda game in a while to expect what's new.
	So part of the reason that I bought this game is simply as a gesture of good faith,and it's good to see the developers are still updating and maintaining the game.
	I do value the amount of work that needed to develop a project like this(simulator-kind) than some smaller H-games,so I'm willing to pay a price that is commensurate 	with the quality and quantity of the content.
	
With all that being said,here are some rather personal issues I wanna mention:
	1. I understand that this may be based on market research and I can read English without much difficulty,but still I would prefer the Chinese(Traditional) language option since I'm Taiwanese.
	2.I would like to have some sort of visual indicators or hints when choosing H-positions to properly develop relationships with the characters.
	3.The clothing textures are well-done,but would love to have more clothing options,such as stirrup-stockings and stirrup-thigh highs, yoga pants,and tights.

One of the best soundtracks I have heard in quite some time. The mastering, melodies, orchestral merged with today's music, into 4 albums. Absolutely in love with every single song in this OST and album!!

It's over 2 hours of music, but I would play the whole album again and again, like Krang and Mortals. Giving out new and old songs from years ago to releasing it, very lovely to hear the melodies that Savant had years ago and hasn't been discarded. Basically, these albums are a combination of Orakel, VOID, Vario, Alchemist, and some Outcasts vibes which is just amazing to hear!

It was so fun seeing and competing with people with the highscores in the demo, and I loved participating on it!

Been a fan for over 10 years, and it's amazing to where Savant is at right now where he's achieving dreams and progressing so rapidly, having a complete remake of Ascent, which many people including me were hoping for many years and it finally happened. I congratulate Savant and the D-Pad team for a phenomenal job on both music, effects, and game!
