If you like Trains. If you like managing things. Then this really is the game for you! 
Train Traffic Manager is such a pleasant game to play. Everything about it feels how it should be.
It was already fun to play the game on the Nintendo Switch. So I'm very happy it came to Steam as well.
Now I'm waiting for Cooking Arena to also be announced for Steam. That's also made by Baltoro Games.
I hope you'll enjoy Train Traffic Manager just as much as I do.

Train Traffic Manager is a relaxing and exciting game at the same time. The graphics are fantastic to look at with very pleasant colors, great art design and entertaining animations. The music and sound effects are good and fit the game well.  Now and then you'll get a hard level and you'll have to put in more attempts to be able to clear it for three stars. It's all based on logic. So the more attempts you play on a level the clearer it becomes what you have to do to solve it. You have to put some thought in. So the challenges you get are entertaining. And that's what makes it exciting to play. Because when you crash the trains, you'll laugh about it since it's your own fault. And it makes you say let's try again. Also because the graphics are keeping you entertained a lot. I highly recommend it!

Technocide happens to be one of the most original STG designs I've come across in quite sometime.  It's very non-traditional in its configuration as a non-linear and choice driven STG.  Slight roguelike features such as random planet/mission choice and random purchasable shop items make each playthrough feel fresh as does its core gameplay loop of ever increasing difficulty.  The weapon/overkill system and how kills are scored/tallied is superbly designed as well IMO as is the players #1 priority to protect the mothership from enemies exiting the screen. There is not another STG like this that I know of.  This is a real hidden gem.

P.S> If there is anything that should be added its online leaderboards for expert mode. The game deserves it.

EDIT: Also wanted to mention that the BGM is superb as well!

Completed a run on normal difficulty, will give expert a shot soon. 

Pros:
- Punchy weapons, overall brilliant gamefeel
- Really nailed the nostalgic artstyle of early 00s(ish) homegrown games
- Chain scoring and other shmup mechanics add depth and are presented in a beginner friendly way

Cons:
- OST has a few weaker tracks that are used during the first few levels

An easy recommend for fans of shmups like Raptor and Jets 'n' Guns

Reminds me of a legendary DemonStar, but plays very differently. Has some interesting twists in mechanics that work really well like that the objective is to protect your base ship by not lettings enemies through instead of trying to survive and thinking when to go for overkills for massive points.

With the price tag this is highly recommended for any shmup fans!

Definitely one of those pick and play type of games. Though I haven't played much, I can recommend it. The trailer tells most of the gameplay. You play as a someone in a spaceship defending a cargo/mother ship from enemy forces. The gameplay goes as this: the scene starts and you pretty much have to prevent the enemies that are appearing from the top of the screen from reaching the bottom of the screen. And that's it. You get upgrades every once in a while and are able to repair your cargo/mother ship in between missions. It's simple but it works. 

The only downsides are that if you die and lose all the cargo ship's health, you are done with your current game and have to try again from the beginning which I don't like, since I'm not good at these types of games. I haven't been able to progress through the story because of this. I probably won't ever but I have a feeling that other people will get good enough to finish the game.

Plays great on steam deck!

The first hour of technocide is amazing, as it seems like it's a fresh and interesting hidden gem. And it still could be. But the game has some pretty fundamental design problems at the same time that really prevent it from being great.

The biggest issue is the weapon balance is not good. The basic pea shooter you get at the start is the best weapon because all the enemies tend to move horizontally, and it's the only weapon with a movement pattern that deals with that. Later on you can "fuse" weapons which just makes them worse. Situational patterns to use other weapons (like are present in the trailer) mean you have to play worse to set them up and don't really come up in game.

The game also has issues on the steam deck. There is extreme input lag, it seems 200 ms+, and the enemies are so tiny they fuse with the background art. This is also probably going to be an issue for anybody with vision problems on a PC.

I'm still giving it a thumbs up because it's interesting from a design perspective.

Very fun shoot em up.

I'm easy to impress and like simple retro games, but... i think the dev tried to do his best, but it is just not enough, i presume the dev is probably inexperienced, they wanted too much and the result is this barebone game with a small annoyances, which could be evaded.

This review is a really small spoiler, not about the story (as far i went, there were like two hints about it), but about what you can do in the game. So, here is my impressions:

General:
- I was lost in the game, there is no help to understand how it works, you have to try and learn.
- The background story is very brief, i have no clue how far the story will go or what kind of story we get. :D
- Not much talk in the game, but the text bubbles lack the name of the talker. I mean, i forgot the name of the benefactor because they told me few times in the beginning and never again. :D
- I find the vertical doors on the space station confusing because of the perspective, i barely recognized them, also i bumped into the wall the first time and generally just annoyed me after that. :)
- On the space station there are doors which would not open for you at the beginning. After the surprise vertical doors, it was strange. Finally a door, i can recognize it, why it doesn't open?! :D
- There is a room you have to visit to left the station with your spaceship, but because you find the spaceship before that room, you wandering and wondering, why you can't interact with the ship at all.
- I find the resource gathering punishing, ever building needs several different kind of aliens to be killed and harvested.
- never felt i need a base or just to build something, except a "capturer" because i needed to capture an alien. But because the story just began, maybe it has a reason to build bases later...

Space:
- I was confused why i can't enter a star system, why they are restricted. I missed the text about a red star (or something like that) i should visit first. There is no history about the texts, so you can't read them later.
- in the space, i hate how slowly the spaceship turns, i missed systems several times because of it and turning back is so slooow. Also many times i have to zoom out to see where i want to go, but i can't see which direction my ship will go, because it is just a small dot when i zoom out. Also because the huge distances, zooming from ship to galaxy view and back is slow.
- Because there is no guide about the game, i wandered around the galaxy for few minutes until i finally pressed the "switch state" button which shows "territories" of the galaxy, different colors, later i figured out they represent what kind of aliens lives there. Several territories overlap each others so their star system type can be like blue, green, orange, for example. So i found a star on the red territory and i could land. After that, i could land anywhere.

Planets:
- After landing on the planet you can see what is around the ship. But when step out, the game is so zoomed in, you can see maybe like 10 meters/33 feets away. Everything is almost jumps on you.
- Every color represent a hostile alien type with the corresponding color. There are moving red goos, fast blue rat things, a green tentacle, orange volcanos spiting brown jumping rocks and finally rolling purple giant eyes. That is all. You can stun the first two with a net and kill any of them with one or more cuts and loot their colored resources. They are deadly, they touch you and you are dead. The fight is very simple, you net them or cut them before they could reach you. The corpse harvesting is slow, you can't interrupt it, so other aliens probably can kill you.
- I liked chasing the planets and the zooming animation when i land on them. I'm easy to impress. :)))
- I liked there are different biome, even if it means not much. Mostly i liked the music.

Story:
- After some exploring i had no idea where i find the space station, but i remembered there were a lot of stars, it is the center of the galaxy, so i found it. Now, one of the locked doors opened and i could make "building types": deployable weapons, floors and walls.
- Because i got the quest to capture a red alien, i made a capturer and with the switch state button i switched to build mode on a planet, selected the capturer and deployed it, led a red alien into it. I was not sure if i got the alien because i can't see how many captured aliens i have or how many capturer left.
- Anyway, i flew back to the station, there i could contact with the captured red alien (i captured it as it turned out). It just tried to kill me and i got some command to do some experiment on the hostile alien. I had to splash it with some liquid by leading them into a sprinkler, i cut them and finally i should reverse the direction of the alien, but i didn't figure out this. There were direction marks in the room and some thingy, but i didn't know how to use it. Supposedly more successful experiments means more reward, but i have no clue if i got something, maybe red resources? After that i got a small description about the alien in my inventory.
- Surely there is some story of it, because your benefactor sometimes gives away hints about an organism they dislike.
- Now i should capture a purple alien, which means i should kill more aliens to make anouther capturer. I think i pass.

One of the more bizarre incidents of the war happened when PACT forces somehow made their way to Canada.  Records of the original operation have mostly been lost, but it is believed that a small group of Polish and East German mechanized infantry were dispatched from Murmansk with the objective of securing either the oil transfer stations in Scapa Flow, or disrupting NATO operations in Iceland.  

Whatever the reason, and why they found themselves instead on the shores of New Brunswick, may never be known.  But on that day PACT forces found themselves deep in NATO territory with no way home.  It was fight or die, and the Great North War had begun.

Frantic 9-1-1 calls reporting the PACT landing were initially dismissed, perhaps not unreasonably, as fear mongering and paranoia.  One commander, however, saw this as an opportunity to conduct some ad hoc exercises.  The 4th Canadian Mechanized Brigade Group had been waiting in perpetual reserve for the day they would be sent to Europe, their morale and cohesion decaying each day they sat on their hands.  So it was that when it was confirmed that PACT forces had indeed landed in Canada, a single mechanized brigade was already constructing fortifications in preparation. 

The following battle was extremely one-sided, with PACT forces taking heavy losses.  By 13:00 of the first day they had entirely withdrawn from their assault, without taking any territory from the 4th.  By 18:00, Canadian reconnaissance  had begun probing northward into what they suspected was occupied territory.  PACT forces were on alert and it was thought initially that very little intel had been gathered by NATO.  But signal discipline was poor among PACT forces, allowing the Canadian forces to identify numerous high value targets.  Throughout the night they launched several deep penetrating raids, targeting command and control centers, and the irreplaceable long range rocket batteries.

After that night's disaster, PACT commanders knew they had to break though this resistance before further NATO forces could be scrambled to the region, overwhelming them by sheer numbers.  Launching a morning attack, this time with fresh Polish troops, they hoped to break through Canadian lines, gaining access to the TransCanadian Highway and beyond it, the shipyards in St. Johns.  Maybe then they could find a way to friendly territory, or at least have a bargaining chip.  Initial attempts were fruitless against another well prepared defense, but by afternoon, Polish forces had gathered enough forces to break through several first line areas.

Unfortunately for them, the Royal Canadian Air Force had spent a sleepless night preparing for daylight operations, which they unleashed with a fury.  By 22:00, the Canadians had gone on the attack, each assault heralded by rocket sorties from a seemingly endless supply of RCAF fighter-bombers.  By morning PACT forces had been pushed back to the beach, and with no defensive positions left, they surrendered en masse to the victorious Canadians.  As quickly as it had begun, the first invasion of North America by a European power in two centuries had come to a close.

I was a huge fan of the Winds of Change Operations and even the minimal narrative they provided. So initially, I was a bit bumped that the new War Paths mode in this DLC would be procedually generated. But I just went into a new War Path campaign and it maintains all the thrill of the classic Operations campaign while giving you so much more room to try out all the different units in the game. And that is absolutely the right choice because with this DLC you get so many new "toys" to play with, the Airborne infantry option alone is worth the price of admission but there are so many new units and factions on top of that. All told an excellent DLC for an already excellent game. Can't wait to see what's next for this game.

A must-have DLC, it adds so much! With the new Warpath mode, you essentially get unlimited campaigns, all within the battle/reorganize/battle system we are accustomed to. Add in all of the new nations and the airborne units and the replayability of this game just increased by a factor of 10. Czechs, Dutch, Canadians, Brits, French, all with their own equipment, tactical approaches, and highly detailed models, changing countries changes the gameplay quite radically.

High quality models, graphics, and a severe attention to detail make this one of my all-time favorite wargames. Slow paced and tactical, it really forces you to think about how to deploy your forces and adjust your tactics to the units you have to work with, and the enemy you are facing.

Recommend Winds of Change 100%.

Absolute must-have DLC that not only adds lots of great content in the form of new nations and units, but more importantly adds in an infinite mode for operations that lets you play randomly generated missions as long as you like. The Warpaths mode is gold and has set the bar for a feature every RTS needs.

Excellent title and a great edition to the base Regiments game, for the price there's tons of content and as others have stated the new Warpath mode has added much replayability outside of skirmish and the scripted Operations.

Many will probably compare this to WARNO but if you can't hit 100 actions per minute and  you like slower paced cold war tactics with an emphasis on realism, fantastic AI that really puts up a fierce fight and less about multiplayer "deck" balancing then this the game for you.

10/10 highly recommended, now have nightmares about the Fulda Gap.

This is an easy recommendation for those who like the campaign mode of Regiments. It provides a massive increase to the ability to enjoy new operations and explore different army types and compositions. I think there is space to tune the capture point distribution or to generate less complicated / smaller operation segments or maps but nothing that couldn't be fixed in a balance patch. 

Very happy to see this game get a shot in the arm and the chance to spend more time with it. 

Fellow Canadians can now rejoice in ADATS: A one-of-a-kind anti-everything missile platform that our country sadly chose not to pursue or maintain long after the wall came down. It chews ammo supply but will knock down a tank just as easily as a jet at almost 3Km.

The perfect DLC - not just new units, but builds directly on the game's strongest parts by bringing procedurally generated operations effectively multiplying the game's variability and replayability by an order of magnitude, or two.

Winds of Change is a great expansion to Regiments that adds in a ton of great factions and a brand new mode.

The French and Canadians really stand apart from the other countries in game. The French have a large focus on light armor and thus focus a lot on speed and flanking, but have additional firepower compared to previous nations that focused on that (British Dragoons and Belgian recon if you a wondering). The Canadians get really good infantry and AT options, and have a whole regiment dedicated to heliborne infantry which allows you to zip all over the map. Haven't tried Dutch and Czechs yet, but they look interesting.

The real draw is Warpaths, the new roguelike campaign mode. I didn't really like the skirmish mode of this game because I didn't see a lot of replayability in just beating the AI over and over. I ended missing out on a lot of content from nations not featured in the campaign, which I loved. With the Warpaths mode, I can take any of the skirmish regiments through the game's campaign system with procedurally generated missions, creating a lot of replayability missing from skirmish.

In short, if you like Regiments, you'll love Winds of Change.
Warpaths makes it a whole new game!  Great to have the additional nations and units added.  Interface is easy to use and smooth to operate.  Overall really enjoying the game and the new DLC!

If you like Operations get this dlc.

Worse part of the DLC is that it arguably ought to be integrated into the main game.

DLC adds procedural operations and a handful of new interesting nations; now you may take your favourite regiment through a series of highly customizable and randomized scenarios in the same vein as the original campaign (limited resources, permanent losses and continuity between battles). Choose operation length, starting units, enemies, resources and battle fatigue; then let the algorithm cook up the operation with some random conditions. 

Some new types of units are also introduced, such as the quickly deployed heliborne troops and air superiority fighters to lockdown the skies. Absolutely recommended to all Regiments fans.

Goedemorgen!

More Regiments, including procedurally generated Operations, heliborne platoons, multiple new [strike]M113s[/strike] nations, and Regipedia unit quotes.

Must-have if you like the base game (or wait for a sale if you're lukewarm towards it).

Adds replayability, new countries, airborne troops and actual air supremacy options. By far worth the purchase and glad to see a DLC that adds content, and hopeful for the game to continue down this path of quality and quantity.

Fantastic extension of the base game. New nations that bring more lovingly modeled units, some new features like airborne infantry deployment from transport choppers. The biggest draw is the War Paths mode, though. It is essentially a random campaign generator with total user control over length, forces involved, etc. The intermission mechanics from the base game's campaigns where you refit/upgrade your platoons, purchase new task forces, and select random events are all present in war paths. Its like having an endless supply of new campaigns. Highly recommended.

Winds of Change presents enough new content in the form of the new nations as well as the War Path mode to pretty much be Regiments 2 in a sense. It combines all the best aspects of the free-form customizable Skirmish mode with the tactical, logistical and timing considerations that come with the scripted Operations. Customization options for the new War Paths mode allow for a truly crazy amount of replayability, and most importantly allows you to live out all your late Cold War power fantasies of combined arms warfare, be it with Soviet, East/West German, American, Polish, Czechoslovak, Dutch, Belgian, British or French units, the sky is the limit.

A pretty good idle game, but nothing compared to the first game. Some new mechanics and different systems that take up a lot more time but don't feel that rewarding. The game is mostly building up components, resetting, and repeating until you unlock a new system or a new currency. The issue persists where some of the mechanics aren't explained - how does score work? How much score do certain modules have? Is there a screen where I can see what the scores of each module are? Strange and confusing additions to the first one but still a pretty decent idler at its heart. 5/10

I got this game for free from one of my friends who happened to be a tester for the game and gave me his steam copy since he didn't need it. I gotta say, I'm genuinely impressed with the quality of this game. As of now, I've completed the game, outside of the time based achievements of 36 and 48 hours which are exclusively in game. For it's price, this is definitely one of the better idle games out there. Sure, it isn't graphically great, but the gameplay is fun, it's addictive, and above all, it has extraordinarily good pacing. Never once did I feel I was going way too fast or way too slow, it felt just right. This is simply an easy recommend from me. I really did enjoy playing this game.

The interface is stunning and the progression, albeit initially slow, is incredibly rewarding. The upgrades are thrilling, and I'm eager for the potential future acceleration. The concept is simply amazing for those seeking a casual Idle gaming experience that impresses.

I started playing this game on Android and I liked it so much that I decided to buy both games on steam.
I have read negative reviews saying that this game is worse than the first one. That it is not easy to understand what is expected of your or how to play it.
It is a typical case of "The first game is better". People don't remember playing the game but only have a fuzzy idea of what they played.
I played the first one after being on T4 on this one and I can tell you I was completely lost on the original game.

So, acordiing to me, this game is better.

It is a very polished incremental game. In fact, the only place I hit a wall was in T4 because it is taking forever to have enough research to unlock the uber laboratory. Maybe I just don't know the best combination of hacks and modules to produce a lot of uploads very fast in order to reach enough T4 research credits.

I was able to share my android game to steam. I didn't try the reverse but it is great to be able to continue to play on my phone or vice versa!

Slow start compared to the previous in the series, which I feel contributes to some of the negative reviews about "not being as good". It feels like it takes a lot longer until you start unlocking automation compared to the original Upload Simulator, and it's only once you do that the new mechanics start to feel like an addition to the game rather than a needless chore. Once you get past that pacing issue, it feels more enjoyable and more fleshed out. The micromanagement until you get to that point might mean you go looking for a less "hands-on" idler though.

You'll have seen most of the game's content within 40 hours, there's a few "unique universes" hidden away in a menu that it's probably quite easy to never notice even after 100% achievements. The core mechanic changes haven't interested me enough to try any.

I had fun while the game lasted, and it's super cheap when it's on sale - it's worth the price, but there's also plenty of free idle games with far more content, depth, and mechanical complexity, so it's a thumbs up but can't avoid the context that there's a lot of competition that's at least as good as this.

Played extremely actively for a solid month. Here's my perspectives.

Gathering hero's and building up your troops is fun for a while. Cool system with five hero's per troop set up. Decent to customize and counter your opponents set up. Increasing their strength is more than just gaining xp in fights though. You can gather spell books to increase the hero stats. 20 of each att, def, and command per hero. Sounds great, until your running 10+ troops with over 50 hero's. Who all need to hunt 60 spell books each to max out their potential.

The city building is ridiculously grindy. As you gain levels you get the ability to have another town. At first it's awesome, and then by the time you have your main city, plus 10 more cities to develop the exact same buildings in. It feels like a punishment to get another town. Sure, having 10 level 20 tax offices, or warehouses, ect, increases your overall daily production and capacity, but it's the same buildings over and over again, and each new town starts off with nothing but a level 1 city hall. Essentially, you feel like you are starting over again, repeatedly. Ok, let's do this all over again for the how many times now?

There are ages the game goes through, and if you didn't start at the very beginning, you will NEVER catch up to the players who did. The ages go fairly fast, and if you don't make this game a part time job, you will fall behind quickly. Or P2W.

The community is actually friendly, even rivalry is generally communicated and organized. The community is very small though. About 30 active members on global server 1.

The top ten players are so strong that they can basically take down miracles and monument cities solo or in a small group. That means, unless you are online when they do this, you will never get to attack anything fun with your alliance. They already conquered everything while you were sleeping. And that's the best way to earn Merit as well. An important aspect.

You snowball as you grow and gain more and more because of your strength increase. So those top players continue to skyrocket with merit gains, while everyone snails. The distance and divide only increases.

It's colorful and definitely a mobile game ported in. It does a few things better than most games of this type, but it is absolutely not balanced at all, it has a ton of bugs, actions and in game content locked behind certain ages, so even after my play experience there are some aspects the game still hasn't even let me try or learn about. And it gets really repetitive.

I don't regret trying this game, fun for while. It would be nice if you got bonus' to your main city instead of a brand new identical, but bare city to build all over again. And then another, and another. It would be better if they balanced the game so 3 people can't run around the world taking over all of the special cities by themselves.

It's not difficult at all, just time consuming and very repetitive. Anyway, thanks for reading my experience. 

Happy Gaming Everyone!

Another pay-to-win game. It is very complex and does not have a complete guide for the many non-intuitive features of this game. The support staff are not familiar with the game and will ask for screenshots for even the simplest concern.
I must say that it has the potential to be a very addictive and stimulating game if they make a few changes:
1. Provide a built-in translator, they currently tease you with a translator for a limited amount of time and then turn it off and inform you that you'll need to pay for it.
2. Fix the bugs, some things work for some but not for others. E.g., they have a 'novice protected area' which protects you from attacks however, I've lost over 30 villages but cannot capture others villages. Support ignored the issue when I reported it.
I'll add more when I get time.
3. Too many features have vague or no descriptions e.g., archer, cavalry, and infantry 'redifs.' What is a redif and how are they obtained?
4. There are long intervals of time between ages where your heroes and lord once maxed cannot advance. The game gets very boring. Example: I'm between the Castle and Kingdom ages (14-day interval). My Lord reached maximum levels 2 days ago; 12 days until he can take advantage of xp's, So I cannot increase the number of a troops (currently capped @ 11; CC@), b) heroes CC@ 55, c) territory CC@ 129, and villages CC@ 72. Which means I cannot compete with the heroes in the various challenges as they are not restricted to the same limits.
5. They have a 'Hero Roulette' wheel that seems to be rigged to give you a 5-star hero shard that you have collect 100 before you can cash them in to get a hero.

Fairly standard RTS game that has been ported for PC compatibility as well as on other platforms (mobile/cell, etc).
Population of the game is somewhat on the quieter side, though at time of writing it's still newly released so that may change in the future.
There does exist microtransactions, though it's not constantly flashed in your face (at least on PC gameplay) and it's quite viable to keep up the pace as F2P if that is your style; the P2P route doesn't really give that much of an advantage as there's quite a lot of chance rolls incorporated into the game, so it keeps people at a somewhat steady flow. 

The UI could be neater and more efficient for PC play, but that may be something they work on down the line, though there is room for improvement in regards to quality, connectivity and efficiency.
The map is quite large, so plenty of space to settle.

They have incorporated "ages" into the game, and these act as a soft time cap, so it helps further to balance out F2P and P2P players to keep them on similar pacing. 
In-game mechanics exist to replenish energy other than paying for it, so the options are there to suit both styles of play.

[i]Midnight Ramen[/i] is a treat to experience. A story rich game with memorable characters, each with heartfelt stories. Flavourful and full of soul. 

[h3]The Story[/h3]

You play as an apprentice to the owner of a ramen stand that operates throughout the night. As customers come in you engage with them and listen to their troubles. As time progresses you get to know the customers more and more as their stories unfold. The stories of the characters are really quite heartfelt and the writing in this game is very, very well written. 

In the background of talking to the customers the mystery of your own story starts to unfold. 

I am not going to go into specifics about the story itself as there is a twist to the whole narrative that is best experienced. There is depth to this game. If you love the Coffee Talk series (like I do) I really believe you will love this game as well. 

[h3]Gameplay & Features[/h3]

The game is divided into 14 nights (chapters) with an ending chapter and a mysterious after-story chapter. After you complete each night the game will automatically save so no save files are needed. You just boot up the game and hit continue. Or you can choose to replay any chapter (any night) at any time. The game is mainly narrative, you listen to and talk to the customers but you do not make any choices that influence the story. You cook their food and serve them drinks while conversing.

In some cases alternate endings will be available and will appear in the timeline chart (where you go to select chapters to replay), that have a question mark. 

Game settings include audio settings, dialogue speed, resolution settings, language selection and tweaking how to lift items in game (by holding or clicking them). The game does recommend keyboard and mouse to play (which I chose) but also does support controllers. 

* Due to being able to replay any chapters you‚Äôve previously played at any time makes getting the achievements much easier.

[h3]The Visuals & Audio[/h3]

Visually the game art is beautiful. Each character has some pose variations and the anime style is colorful, unique and each character has personality. The key moments in the game (and there are a few) have nice computer graphics of the characters at pivotal moments. I chose not to share any of them as they will give away important parts in the story. 

The music is lo-fi beats and very relaxing. There are no voice overs but some ambient sounds such as birds chirping and footsteps. 

[h3]Trigger warnings[/h3]

‚ùó This game does deal with some very sensitive issues like death, suicide and losing loved ones so a warning should be given to those sensitive to such issues or going through a rough time. 

I myself was in tears (happy tears) the last hour of the game. You just get attached to the characters' stories and struggles which is a sign of great character development and writing. [i]If a game can move you to experience strong emotions then it is a game worth experiencing.[/i] 

[h3]Overall Experience[/h3]

I loved this game, and I believe if you loved games like Coffee Talk (also a favorite of mine), then you will really enjoy [i]Midnight Ramen[/i]. Great story-telling and memorable characters. Also the element of cooking up the orders while listening to lo-fi beats is relaxing and enjoyable. üçú


Otome Lovers wishes to thank [i]Cointinue Games[/i] for providing a free review copy for this game.

[quote]Please follow our curator page, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/4680120/]Otome Lovers[/url], if you'd like to see more reviews like this one! [/quote]

Midnight Ramen is a narrative-heavy game that is most similar to Coffee Talk, except you make ramen, not coffee. I was pleasantly surprised by the decent writing and intriguing characters, with the ramen making minigame being very simple, but lots of fun.  Note that there are many sensitive topics discussed and the game can be quite emotionally evocative.

[b] [u]Pros[/u] [/b]
[list]
    [*] Decent writing & fantastic characters
    [*] Covers sensitive topics
    [*] Inspired by Coffee Talk & VA-11 Hall-A
    [*] Cooking ramen was fun & simple
    [*] Easy to replay chapters from a branching path & unlock new endings and routes

[/list]
[b] [u]Cons[/u] [/b]
[list]
    [*] Soundtrack can be repetitive
[/list]

[quote] If you would like to see more reviews written by me, please follow my  curator page and help support my work [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34936724/] Cookie Reviews[/url]. [/quote]

[h1]Story (no spoilers)[/h1]
You run a late-night ramen stand and listen to your customers stories and struggles, trying to help them in their journeys. Each character is very unique, but doesn‚Äôt fall precisely within specific stereotypical boxes and feels as if they are their own person. As the story progresses, cracks begin to surface in the protagonist‚Äôs own life as well, as she begins to truly understand her purpose, and what lies ahead.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3296451376

Clearly inspired by the likes of Coffee Talk / VA-11 Hall A, Midnight Ramen will make you feel attached to each of its characters. Although there aren‚Äôt many, and the game only lasted just over 4 hours (including 100% achievements), the stories were captivating. I was completely engaged reading every piece of dialogue to better understand their perspectives. I specifically loved how after finishing the game, you can go back into the branching chapter paths and replay specific levels and even find different endings for some of the characters. The attention to detail in Midnight Ramen surpassed my expectations and it left many options available to players to explore.

I was sad when the game was coming to an end, because of the story but also because I wanted it to continue. I wanted to hear from new characters‚Ä¶ I just didn‚Äôt want it to end. This is very rare for me and demonstrates the games excellent storytelling abilities.


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
If you have played Coffee Talk, you know how this game will play. Lots of conversations between customers and also between the stall owner, which you are an apprentice to. And of course‚Ä¶ cooking ramen! I absolutely adored this minigame and the layout was very easy to use. With bright, large buttons and easy, uncluttered ingredients to choose from. However, I do wish that more ingredients and options were added as the game continued, as the ramen making minigame does not change from start to finish.

Choose your level of noodle softness, abide by the ramen recipe book‚Ä¶or don‚Äôt, it‚Äôs up to you! Add sides of chashu (or others), mix your broths and don‚Äôt forget the seasoning! After finishing the story once, going back to play specific chapters to slightly change their orders and witnessing different dialogue was satisfying and displayed further depth to characters that I thought were not as developed as they could be‚Ä¶ but it was just under a hidden storyline for keen players to find.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3297113136

Dialogue can be automatically skipped by holding S, and the dialogue boxes were clean and easy to click through. Saving occurs frequently at the end of each chapter which was very handy as well.


[h1]Visuals & Sound[/h1]
Midnight Ramen features very bright, cartoonish visuals with anime-style characters. The simple style helps to focus on the dialogue and felt fitting for the setting. The ramen made me hungry and I appreciated the small details such as seeing the ramen slowly disappearing infront of characters as time passes, the cursor is in the format of two chopsticks that pinch together when you click and so much more.

Sound is ok, it has low-fi beats, similar to Coffee Talk once again, but it did feel slightly repetitive at times and lacked some variation. However, this is only a small gripe and is just something I noticed towards the end of the game. 


[h1]Technical & Stats [/h1]
[quote][b]This game was played using a keyboard & mouse, and with the following PC specs.:[/b]
AMD Ryzen R5 7600x 5.4 GHz
32GB DDR5 5200 CL36 RAM
Radeon RX 6800 XT
2560x1440 resolution
NVMe 3.0 SSD
Windows 10[/quote]

[b]Playtime:[/b] The game took me approximately 4.5 hours to achieve 100% achievements and finish the game.

[b] Controller Recommended? [/b] No, but it is supported if you wish.

[b]Replayability value:[/b] To witness different story paths and for achievements only.


[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Midnight Ramen completely surprised me with its quality story-telling and engaging characters. I knew it was heavily inspired by the classics of the genre such as Coffee Talk, but I did not expect the emotional depth and polished ramen minigame that it provided. I barely have any qualms about the game, mainly that I just wish it was longer. I would love to play a sequel or hope to see new content added in the future. I highly recommend this game for fans of conversational, relaxing games...just prepare for some emotional scenes ahead!

[quote] Follow our curator page, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32732116-IndieGems/] [b]IndieGems[/b][/url] if you enjoyed this review and wish to see more like it[/quote]

I had the opportunity to play a preview copy of this game before its release, so do bear in mind this review applies to that.

This is an excellent little story-based game where you operate a ramen stall that opens daily at midnight. People come and go, and they chat and you learn about their lives. It reminds me most of the Coffee Talk games, but also of Spiritfarer, as there is a fair amount more tragedy to their tales.

The writing for this game is very good, and I would say is the highlight of the game. The world building seemed to me to be deeper than either of the games I mentioned before, and I appreciate that. But it doesn't let itself intrude too much, the stories do remain focused on individual characters throughout. The main story is fairly short but it opens up more post-game, which I haven't explored yet.

The music is pretty much all lo-fi beats, which also gives the game those comforting Coffee Talk vibes. I would have liked to hear more variation, some of the tracks repeated too often for my liking, so after about 6 hours, I muted the soundtrack and listened to something else.

Overall, I think this is a very good 1st game from this developer and would like to see more from them in the future.

After playing the Demo I have been waiting for the Release of this Game more than any other and frequently been checking it up. I'm so happy it's finally here and it most certainly does not dissapoint. The vibes are immaculate and instill calm in me, the story is interesting and the characters are loveable. I'm having a wonderful time unraveling their stories and serving them ramen and I think a lot of people will to! I could (and will) be playing this for hours - but [i]beware![i] A craving for Ramen might just ensue!

Ever wanted a game that tugs at your heartstrings? Makes you crave good food in the middle of the night? Play Midnight Ramen.
I played the demo before and was very interested to see what the full story would be like and it made me tear up 3 separate times, so it gets a big PLEASE PLAY IT from me. There is no stressing or time limit involved when fulfilling customer's request (aside from an optional achievement that I managed to get by pure chance anyway) which is godsend. You just combine all the items in whatever order you want and if you do mess something up you can always just throw it out and try again before presenting it. The music is very cozy and the whole atmosphere of the game really envelops you in warmth. I hope we get to see more games like this.

So I like this game, but it has it's issues.

Good things:
- Making Ramen is fun! I like the options and the ability to mix it up when you want to, and the fact that it is a simple mechanic but at the same time really interesting to do. 
- The music is nice. It  goes really well with the story-telling
- The characters seem relatively well fleshed out, and moderately believeable!!
- Nice to just read as an activity light game

Negatives:
- This game REALLY needs to come with a detailed trigger warning. It covers a lot of things about death and related stuff, and people should really be warned properly about this before they play
- Lots of grammatical mistakes and spelling errors. If this kind of thing takes you out of the immersion, then I wouldn't recommend this game. 

Overall I would recommend this game, unless you are currently grieving or have strong emotional reactions to discussions of death.

I Loved this so much!  The story line wasn't over complicated, and was a little thought provoking.  i didn't feel stressed or anxiety in making the meals. I loved it when i could have some creative licensing with them also! I hope there are more  like this in the future with more characters and stories to follow, and maybe the ability to learn new recipes.

I can't remember the last time I was grateful to have played a game. I've definitely never dreaded the end of a game before. And I don't think I've ever cried this much for any game. 

It's not even really much of a game, more of a story but with a fun little minigame. The characters are amazing, the minigame is satisfying, and the story is... devastating.

Please. Please play this if you're in a spot to be able to. It's very heavy, it hurts to play, you know what's coming and you can't stop it. But if you can get through it, it's an amazing story worth knowing.

This is the single most impactful game I have ever played, ever, and I am thankful I randomly found it.

To the Developers: Fuck you, holy shit you wrote this, and published it, and I had no way to know it would be so beautiful. And Thank you for Coming.

tl;dr: This is a very well-written game! I have enjoyed the story and loved the cooking "mini-game" aspect, which felt low pressure while having a good challenge between scenes. I lost my mom several years ago at a young age and this game was a very heartfelt way to spend my evening. No spoilers in my review!

I bought this game this evening as I got an email it was available, and I've been waiting! What a great purchase. I loved every bit of the story. I wanted to play through this in one sitting to really take in the story and I'm glad I did - but it's not something everyone has to do. I just wanted to get into it through an evening on the couch under the blankets.

A big part of the game is preparing food and serving customers. It's not as in-depth as the story side of the game, so I'll knock it out first. You're tasked with cooking ingredients, preparing meals and beverages, and serving the customers. Some cooking mechanics require you to time things well, but there isn't a timer for the overall cooking experience, giving you plenty of time to review a recipe and get things right. For timed mechanics, there are audio cues to help you catch what's going on. If your meals are missing key ingredients, like a number of topping or side and beverage, you'll be warned when you pull the service cord. There's a trash can to throw items away as well. You can (hilariously) serve a meal with wrong or missing ingredients without being warned, so it's a good idea to pay attention to what they ordered, how they ordered it, and the written recipes. Fairly laid back experience with fluid drag-and-drop mouse controls for each of the cooking hotspots and clear instructions for each of the recipes, as well as tips for how to do things with each of the hotspots.

The artwork, animations, and user interface are all very nicely done. I haven't encountered any issues or bugs as of yet. Things work smoothly, controls work as expected without lag, and I'm able to find all of the information I need where I expect to find it. No complaints, well done. However, the English dialogue has a handful of grammatical errors, a few typos, the usual. A quick run-thru should clean it up, but that's on the developers. It doesn't detract much from the story.

The story is often more complex and in-depth in games than their mini-games, so that's next! The premise of the game is fairly simple. You play in part as a young, inexperienced cook at an all-night ramen stand (as well as the stand's owner) and you serve customers that bring rich, engaging stories with them each night, and looming secrets that unravel for you, the player, as you follow along with the story.  Customers go through unique circumstances and share their stories with you as they enjoy their meals. Some face tragedy and hardship and look to you for a supportive ear or shoulder to lean on. You learn about them as individuals and peek into their lives on their recurring visits to the ramen stand. Money-earning is not a game mechanic - just preparing food, serving food, and unraveling the story of the world around you.

The personalities between customers are varied and the writing feels very well done in both of these aspects. This is another difficult task to accomplish, in my opinion, and personalities/voices are hard to fully carve out in any type of literature. When an author is able to give unique and definitive characteristics to each character in the story, it adds immense depth and value. I love what they've done here to give variety to the characters in their words and actions.

The game does a great job of world building, showing without telling, by dropping tidbits of information about the different customers and the world around you. This is a huge selling point for me, because a lot of games rely on partial fourth-wall breaks or dry telling without showing. I love being dropped into the world the author has created and being able to feel, connect, emotionally, etc etc. It's a difficult task to get right and I feel like they've done a good job here with the world building and the methods for delivering information to the players. There are secrets unknown to you and you learn little things and big things as you go through each step of dialogue. I found the story to be overall engaging and I loved how it was presented.

The story itself is a roller coaster of emotions and takes you, quite seriously, through the lives of your customers and gives you many avenues to connect with them as the player. Some customers reveal lovely stories about their lives and others share their problems and look for comfort and support. There are lots of philosophical, mythological, cultural, and ideological references here as well and I enjoyed learning a few new things. There really is some incredible depth here and, without spoiling things, gives you stories with the concepts of abuse, abandonment, suicide, death, love, loss, grief, acceptance, and personal growth.

A small but important note: details were given to each scene, such as disappearing ingredients from the customer's plates and bowls as they ate through their meals, or differences in the customers as time goes on. These little touches are small but so, so appreciated. I feel like I don't see attention to detail like this as often as I did in the past, and it's nice to see it here.

Overall it's a great game. The story takes you on some twists and turns and you learn more and more about the customers you serve and the world you're in. Definitely no regrets here, just wish I could play it over again for the first time.

A game that is warm and with very lovable characters! The story can get very heavy so a fair content warning to be had but.. Other than I can not recommend it enough! There are some powerful messages behind all the feelings.

You'll enjoy this game if you're willing to get yourself into it.

For me it's been an experience well worth the full price. There's no much gameplay. You're a cook at a ramen stall which opens at midnight and you have to serve the customers you get by cooking the noodles and adding the right broth and toppings. There're also drinks and side plates you have to take into account. You have different recipes and, usually, you must give the customer what has been ordered. Apart from that you only have to listen to what they want to tell you.  It's easy. It's an experience more than a game.

BUT... for me it's been a emotional rollercoaster and I didn't want to reach the end of the game. I wanted to continue listening to their stories. I frequently find myself wanting to finish a game. At the end is almost a chore. But with this game it's been different. This is like when you're reading a book or watching a series you really enjoy and you don't want it to finish because you know you're not going to see those characters anymore.

It's not a game for everyone. But if you're into this kind of slow, meditative games, this one's one of the best.

[h1]Do not buy.[/h1]
As a man of culture, I played all of Lil Hentai Games and enjoyed them thoroughly. I only bought this because I assumed it will be more of the same. Oh, how wrong I was.

Where do I even begin?

The art (and especially how it's animated) is... Very pretty, but at the same time nothing to write home about. In this entry it has a strong AI-generated vibe, though and it's certainly nothing special. It's very repetitive, because the girls' poses rarely change, it's usually just their outfits or lack of them.

That's it. That's all I can say semi-positively about this. Apart from the visuals, there's literally nothing good.

The music sounds AI-generated too. It's one of the most generic and boring pieces of [i]muzak[/i] I ever heard. It's better to just play some lo-fi beats to sleep/study to in the background.

The UI is glitchy jank.

The casual puzzle gameplay from previous entries is gone. Now you just click through dialog.
That would be OK, but there are also RPG-style TESTS to pass if you want to impress the girl in a certain way. To pass, you throw a 20-sided die, as in D&D. If the die's result combined with your perks is at least as high as the test's difficulty, you pass. Talking to girls gives you experience with causes you to level up and unlock perks which can raise your chances in 4 "attributes" for the purpose of these tests. This whole mechanic is just a huge waste of time and effort and brings literally nothing of value.

To pad the game's content, there are cards to collect. You get cards when you reach a specific point or outcome in a conversation. Most often these are connected to certain tests and their results. So, if you want all the cards for a certain girl, you need to replay all of their conversations, [b]without any skip feature[/b], attempt different tests than before, and succeed/fail as needed. Fortunately the cards give you a strong hint on how to get them, but it doesn't help the overall game and ultimately doesn't bring anything of value either.

The example of an end-game loop looks like this:
[olist][*]Click to load conversation
[*]Click 20 times, but not too fast, to get to a choice
[*]Select a test of difficulty 5 that you need to fail
[*]Roll a natural 20
[*]Click 30 times, but not too fast, to end conversation
[*]Click the button to restart conversation, which is not possible without doing all the above steps first
[*]GOTO 1[/olist]

And you will have to repeat this over and over for up to 20 minutes per easy test you want to fail, because the dice rolls in this game are broken. How can you fail so hard to program a simple dice roll? How on Earth is that possible? A difficulty of 5 should mean that you will fail 25% of the time. It should be astronomically unlikely to pass 20 times in a row. Yet, here we are.

And this could all have been fine for me, because I was a fan once. But the writing also went downhill. It used to be that the girls in this series had cute personalities. Their dialogues were [b]short[/b], but fun. Psychologically believable, let's say. Especially with each sequel, when it was already established that these girls were FWBs with the main character named after you, the player. They sounded like girls who seem fun to be around and they spoke things that people do say to each other in real life. I actually 100% these previous games just to see all the dialogue. Because it was fun.

Now? Well, now every girl addresses you as [b]anon[/b] IRL (every girl pronouncing it differently). Why??? What kind of pron-brained redditor might have thought this to be a good idea? The dialogues are much longer and complete cringe. Instead of just flirting with each other in a manner not requiring suspension of disbelief, the characters somehow regurgitate sentence after sentence of complete and utter meaninglessness that is difficult to bear. They literally talk about nothing "Ooooh I like the place, so cool!", "Oh did you know ninja were created in the XVI century? So interesting.", "Wow, anon! Your knowledge is so impressive! I like you so much!".

Worse still, the girls now have full voice over. Half of them sound flat and boring, reading every single sentence in the same way, like a machine. Yet, it's not Text-to-Speech. I'm not sure that's a good thing, because these are the better half. The other half sound like some mass-produced Chinese V-Tuber. Like the fuggin pine pepsi woman on DikKok. Or like Maangchi. It's full-frontal cringe with engrish pronounciation and a thick East-Asian accent. It's not sexy at all.

This game should have profile features disabled, because, unfortunately, unlike the previous games in this series, it is blatant shovelware that you can 100% in under 2 hours ez and refund. Unless you want to farm the cards too.

[h3]All the above elements combined make the experience with this game feel like being isekai'd into a 4chan sexual RP thread or like being subjected to subliminal hypno hentai messaging by a couple of Chinese Communist Party scam agents incompetently impersonating cute girls with excessive AI filters to steal your secrets. Like, Jesus Christ.[/h3]

This is not a puzzle game like the Mosaique Neko Waifus games, it is a simple visual novel game with a 20-sided dice roll mechanic for different personality traits. Excellent art and awesome voice acting, A common bug I witnessed was the disappearance of the "continue" button sometimes after dialogues. Quitting the game sometimes causes it to crash. "Anon's Neko Waifus" is a visual novel developed by a studio specializing in anime and console culture. The game invites players to enter a world where the main character meets several "neko" girls - half-human, half-cat.
The graphics in the game are made in anime style and it can be noted that the character designs are quite attractive. If you like bright and colorful animation, then you will be pleased. However, it should be noted that this game contains some animations with explicit content, so it is intended for adult players only.
The plot of "Anon's Neko Waifus" is quite simple, exploration involves meeting various characters and making connections. Your task will be to get to know the "neko" girls better and make decisions that will affect the outcome of their stories. Even though the storyline isn't particularly original, it might grab your attention if you're a fan of anime-like stories.
One of the game's downsides is its limited length. Since this is a visual novel, you will only have to spend a few hours to complete the game. Some players may feel there is a lack of depth and longevity in the gameplay.
Despite these shortcomings, "Anon's Neko Waifus" can offer some entertainment for fans of anime games and visual novels. If you like these types of games and are interested in exploring stories with compelling characters, then it might be worth giving this game a chance. However, if you are not a fan of the anime style or are looking for a deeper and richer gaming experience, then it is better to turn to other options.
It's the shortest game they brought us thus far. It's just okay compared to the other ones. The art is okay. I'd say worth a pickup between 50 cent and 1 quid.

Certainly different from the previous games, especially with included voice acting. With this one, you don't need to even complete the game to get all achievements (but I did it anyway). Can be beaten with all achievements in less than 20 minutes.

This is a game called Neku Waifu Anon, where players assume the role of an anonymous protagonist. The objective is to assist girls with their requests, and in return, embark on thrilling adventures with them. These girls, known as Neku, are similar to cat-girls but with unique personalities. Prepare for an enthralling journey with each individual. Don't miss out on this game, seize the opportunity to meet these charming girls. I highly recommend this game to anyone seeking a fun-filled time.

I recently dived into the world of Neku Waifu Anona, and boy, was it an unexpected delight! As a gamer with a penchant for unique and engaging experiences, this game managed to hit all the right notes.

To start, the art style is an absolute feast for the eyes. The character design, vibrant colors, and attention to detail contribute to a visually stunning environment. It's evident that the developers poured their creativity into crafting a world that's not only captivating but also visually charming.

Gameplay-wise, Neku Waifu Anona offers a refreshing take on the genre. The controls are intuitive, and the mix of action and strategy keeps you on your toes. The storyline is surprisingly immersive, with unexpected twists and turns that had me hooked from the start. It's rare to find a game that combines solid gameplay with a compelling narrative, but Neku Waifu Anona nails it.

One standout feature for me was the soundtrack. The music complements the game's atmosphere perfectly, enhancing the emotional impact of key moments. It's clear that the developers invested time in curating a soundtrack that elevates the overall gaming experience.

I also appreciate the character development in the game. Anona, in particular, is a well-crafted character with depth and personality. The interactions with her felt genuine, adding an emotional layer to the gaming experience that I didn't anticipate.

In conclusion, Neku Waifu Anona exceeded my expectations. It's a game that not only entertains but also surprises and engages on multiple levels. Whether you're a fan of the genre or simply looking for a fresh gaming experience, Neku Waifu Anona is a must-try. I'm excited to see what future updates and expansions this gem of a game has in store!

The girls are cute as usual, we all understand that the gameplay and plot in all such games are just for show, so I won‚Äôt rate it, even though in the previous Neku Waifu games it was more interesting for me to poke puzzles. Voice acting, interesting mechanics with a cube, but unfortunately these are no longer those favorite puzzles in which you spend 2 hours playing for all the achievements

As always, these games can be enjoyed with one hand or to lighten the mood through character dialogue. In this game, the developers have taken a different approach from the traditional puzzle-based gameplay, creating a visual novel that uses the Dungeons & Dragons (D&D) system (in the form of dice, which allows players to demonstrate their Charisma or Knowledge in various areas).

The artwork has improved, as always, with this developer's work. With the release of each new game, the developer continues to improve the overall experience, making it more enjoyable. The background music provides a relaxing atmosphere, and it doesn't interfere with gameplay. The Neko-Waif characters are well-drawn and pleasant to look at.
The developer continues to showcase his love for the latex costumes, which adds a unique touch to the game. The funny dialogue ensures that players will laugh and enjoy the experience.
The interesting idea of the game itself, pleasant and relaxing music, a few accidents, as well as elaborate scenes make it exciting and unforgettable.

It's encouraging to witness the ongoing improvement in animation skills by the developers behind this series, particularly evident in the stunning portrayal of the catgirls.
Within the game, interaction is limited to conversations with only four girls, where the reward lies in glimpses of them without attire. However, beyond this initial allure, the gameplay lacks depth. Conversations offer choices, some contingent on passing checks for characteristics like charisma. 
Ultimately, while the game may hold some appeal, particularly for fans of the genre, it's advisable to wait for a discount before making a purchase.

Nice characters, the voiceovers are good too.

It has voice acting in a game that is less than $5. Some of the art looks a little off, but overall the art is pretty good.

Once again, like the other games from this publisher the art for this is amazing.  All the characters are great and the designs are well done, the detail is exceptional. Likely the best art in cheapy H games. It is also fully voiced which is new.

Compared to the previous games, the gameplay has been changed.  Now its more of a visual novel, with branching dialogue options protected by skill checks via dice rolls.  You can earn points for winning the dice rolls that add bonus points to your dice rolls. This is done by choosing your perks, giving you the edge in winning over the hearts of the 4 girls. Your choices don't really matter, and win or lose you can usually progress to the next scene, or just "replay".


At the moment it seems slightly unfinished.  Everything is there looks great, the voicing is fine and the dialogue is ok.  It could benefit massively from a art gallery. There is a way to revisit everything, but it has the dialogue boxes popping up. It also looks like the perk tree has text specifying a unused method of purchasing the perks. Just feels like it needs a bit more.

All in all you'll get maybe 30 minutes of play out of it.  Its certainly not as engaging as the other games, as you actually had something to do there.  But by the end it gave you chronic eye strain! This is more read the text, chuckle a bit. feel lonely that this sort of thing never happened to you in your twenties (not that neko girls exist) and then look at the achievements that remain after completing the game and attempt to back track and fail/pass exhaust all options.

Worth a look if you liked the content of the previous games in the neko series.

Version 1.1.0:
Gameplay: 8/10 - great, the game has plenty of characters and scenarios to unlock and enjoy, however just a little bit of more in-game content would be greatly appreciated.
Graphics/Visuals: 9/10 - gorgeous, the art and animation is flawless, all I would ask for is options for different clothing or an ounce of romantic animations like off-screen handholding or kisses.
Story: 8/10 - great, there are plenty of characters to chose from and meet them in engaging conversations, there are quite a lot of action and also plenty of fun to have, all it needs is a little bit larger quantity of them in the future.
Adittional content: 9/10 - gorgeous, all I could ask for is different "positions".
Value: 8/10 - great, you get quite a good amount of things to do for the price, and it is worth it even if it is not on sale.
Overall Score: 8/10 - great, the game feels really good to play and gives me a lot of excitement to meet new characters and engage with them in variety of conersations and action, all I could ask for is different options for clothing, little bit more animations and more "positions" in additional content.
System Played On: i5-10400, gtx1650, 16gb 2666mhz RAM.

Personal Opinion:
I really enjoy this game a lot, it is constantly being updated and the developers truly listen to their players, any small bugs are fixed nearly right away and the game gets some quality of life improvements as well. The newest character added in version 1.1.0 is my new favorite, I jsut have to admit admit, all the girls are starting to occupy my entire headspace whenever I think of the Neko Waifus franchise, it is quite a sweet one if you're into it and don't care about what other people would think if you play it. This game is really fun, and I cannot wait to see what developers will come up with for this game. Keep up the good work yall!

I'd say this game has an interesting gameplay concept, with the combination of an rpg-like dice rolling system. but there are still some certain bugs that hold it back from being a well developed game. Major bugs such as the ones that prevent you from playing the game, or even corrupting the save file itself is very devastating. Aswell as some more minor bugs like stacking perks, but with no additional increase, so it just eats your point with no return on investment. Though, hope you can continue developing this game into something greater!

The only good thing I can say about this game is the art, but other than that it is a big mess. There are glitches where it deletes my file, the characters' bottom half is not rendered, or it does not unlock achievements. As I have played these games more bugs and glitches have arisen and it seems disappointing because I like the games they make with the great art and fun puzzles it's nice that they are trying to change it up now with the voice acting and not making it a puzzle game but I feel it is straying away from the reason I have liked this franchise so much. Overall, I don't recommend this game in its current state. 4/10

It is painful to say this but, this feels like a prototype of something great rather than a complete experience.
This is also the first VN game they make which means they are experimenting.

Pro
- Character art is eye candy
- the dice roll and RPG mechanic were interesting for VN anyway
- The chibi art on the collectible card is nice.
- the intro to the scene was pretty nice.

Cons 
- This should be standard for all VN but the lack of log, replay voice dialogue. Save, and load ( Unlocks after you finish the game). But imagine if the routes were longer, it would be torture if you want to go back to choices or reread a line.  
- Art feels inconsistent. I think this is because trying to put the character in the background with a different art style makes them feel floaty. I think a more traditional VN format will work better. 
- the game is short, WAY too short for 4 characters. It is very hard to feel immersed in such a short time. 
- Personal opinion I would love to read more inner monologue of the character. It doesn't have to be complex nor give a blank character a personality, but just as a guide on how should I feel in a particular scene.

You know what I see potential in this style. Keep cooking!

[h2]MimiCries: A Victorian Nightmare[/h2]

MimiCries is a psychological horror adventure game that weaves a chilling tale of mystery and suspense within the confines of the Griswald mansion. This Victorian-era setting serves as a backdrop for a narrative-driven experience that blends exploration, puzzle-solving, and atmospheric horror.

Players assume the role of a nameless protagonist, venturing into the depths of the mansion armed only with wit and a lantern. The game's core gameplay revolves around exploration and puzzle-solving, with a heavy emphasis on atmosphere and storytelling. As you navigate the labyrinthine corridors of the mansion, you'll encounter a series of intricate puzzles that require careful observation and logical thinking to solve.

The game's visual style is a standout feature, with meticulously crafted pixel art that captures the essence of the Victorian era. The mansion is brought to life with intricate details and a haunting ambiance. Sound design plays a crucial role in creating a sense of dread and isolation, with eerie background noises and unsettling sound effects that contribute to the game's overall atmosphere.

Light is a central mechanic in MimiCries. Your lantern is your only source of illumination, casting long shadows and revealing hidden details. However, it also attracts unseen horrors lurking in the darkness. The interplay between light and darkness is a core element of the game's horror elements, as players must carefully manage their light source while navigating the mansion's treacherous corridors.

The narrative unfolds through environmental storytelling and cryptic clues. Players must piece together the mansion's dark history and uncover the secrets hidden within its walls. The game's pacing is deliberate, allowing players to immerse themselves in the atmosphere and unravel the story at their own pace.
While MimiCries excels in atmosphere and puzzle design, the game's horror elements might be more subtle than outright terrifying for some players. The focus is on psychological horror, building tension through atmosphere and narrative rather than jump scares.

Overall, MimiCries is a captivating experience that offers a blend of exploration, puzzle-solving and atmospheric horror. The game's Victorian setting and pixel art style create a unique and immersive world. While the horror elements might be more subdued than in some other titles, the game's emphasis on atmosphere and storytelling is commendable. If you enjoy slow-burn horror games with a strong narrative focus, MimiCries is definitely worth exploring.

The [b][i]Isonzo: First Wave[/i][/b] DLC bundle is a rich and immersive addition to the World War I shooter, expanding the game‚Äôs customization options with historically accurate uniforms, headgear and facial accessories. Combining four core packs‚Äî[i]Elite Units, Alpine Units, Veteran Units and Reserve Units[/i]‚Äîthe [i]First Wave[/i] bundle adds a comprehensive array of cosmetic content that covers a wide spectrum of soldiers from elite combat veterans to rear-line troops. Whether you‚Äôre a fan of historical accuracy or just want to personalize your characters, this bundle offers a wealth of engaging options.
[h2][b]A Deep Dive into History - The Core Unit Packs[/b][/h2]
The [i]First Wave[/i] DLC pulls together four distinct unit packs, each focusing on a unique aspect of the Italian and Austro-Hungarian military forces. This variety ensures that players can find a style and look that matches their personal preferences while keeping the experience historically grounded.
[h3][b]Elite Units Pack[/b][/h3]
The [i]Elite Units[/i] Pack introduces some of the most specialized and highly regarded soldiers on both the Italian and Austro-Hungarian sides. On the Italian front, players get access to the Bersaglieri Cyclists, a unique and mobile unit known for their agility and speed. These soldiers come with a distinct feature‚Äîfolded bicycles on their backs, which adds a quirky but historically accurate detail to their appearance. Also included are the Arditi, Italy‚Äôs elite shock troops, known for their daring combat tactics and instantly recognizable Fez hats.
On the Austro-Hungarian side, the pack features the feared Bosnian troops. These soldiers were known for their discipline and fearsome fighting style and the ruggedness of their uniforms reflects their elite status. The [i]Elite Units[/i] Pack also includes five iconic mustaches and three facial items, allowing players to give their soldiers a distinctive, battle-hardened look.
[h3][b]Alpine Units Pack[/b][/h3]
The [i]Alpine Units Pack[/i] shifts the focus to the cold and unforgiving landscapes of the Alps, where soldiers from both sides had to endure freezing conditions. This pack outfits Italian troops with snow camouflage uniforms, helping them blend into the snowy battlefields. These uniforms capture the essence of high-altitude warfare, where survival depended as much on the ability to endure the environment as it did on combat readiness.
For the Austro-Hungarian forces, the pack provides thick greatcoats that are both visually imposing and functional. The heavy fur-lined coats and winter headwear make these soldiers look like they‚Äôre ready to withstand the brutal cold, while also showcasing the aesthetic of winter warfare. The attention to detail, from balaclavas to snow goggles, makes the [i]Alpine Units[/i] Pack a must-have for players who appreciate cold-weather aesthetics. It also includes five wintery mustaches and beards, adding even more ways to customize your soldiers to match the frozen terrain.
[h3][b]Veteran Units Pack[/b][/h3]
For those who want their soldiers to look like they‚Äôve been through the worst of the war, the [i]Veteran Units[/i] Pack delivers. This pack focuses on battle-scarred, gritty soldiers who have survived the horrors of trench warfare. The uniforms are worn, dirty and reflect the experience of hardened troops.
The Italian side gets the famous [i]Sardinian "Sassari"[/i] uniforms, a symbol of resilience and determination in the face of overwhelming odds. These uniforms are rough and battle-tested, showing the wear and tear of extended service on the frontlines. The Austro-Hungarian faction receives the [i]Hungarian Honved[/i] uniform, known for its veteran status and loyalty to the empire.
This pack also includes five iconic mustaches and four facial items, allowing players to create soldiers who look as tough as the battles they‚Äôve fought. The [i]Veteran Units[/i] Pack is perfect for players who want to command troops that have clearly seen their fair share of combat, with uniforms that tell a story of survival and perseverance.
[h3][b]Reserve Units Pack[/b][/h3]
The [i]Reserve Units[/i] Pack offers a different perspective on the war, focusing on the rear-line and support troops who were crucial to the war effort but often overlooked. These units may not have the same battle-hardened look as the elite or veteran soldiers, but their uniforms offer a fascinating glimpse into the less glamorous side of war.
On the Italian side, players can equip their soldiers with the uniforms of the [i]Carabinieri Reali[/i], Italy‚Äôs military police. These troops were responsible for maintaining order and discipline and their uniforms, complete with archaic hats, reflect their formal and authoritative role. On the Austro-Hungarian side, the [i]Standsch√ºtzen[/i] uniforms represent older reservists and defenders, who played a key role in supporting the war effort despite not being frontline combatants.
This pack includes four mustaches and four facial items, giving players the ability to outfit their support troops with a more refined, dignified appearance. The [i]Reserve Units[/i] Pack is ideal for those who want to explore the diversity of military roles beyond the battlefield, adding depth and variety to the Isonzo experience.
[h2][b]A Wealth of Customization[/b][/h2]
The [i]First Wave[/i] bundle‚Äôs true strength lies in its wide range of customization options. With over 50 cosmetic items, including uniforms, headgear, mustaches, facial items and new faces, players can craft their soldiers to match their vision. Whether you‚Äôre looking for the polished appearance of an elite officer, the rough and ready look of a trench veteran, or the formal attire of rear-line troops, the variety in this bundle ensures that you‚Äôll find the perfect look.
The historical accuracy of the uniforms and accessories also adds to the game‚Äôs overall immersion. Every detail, from the design of the uniforms to the headgear and facial customizations, reflects the realities of World War I, enhancing the sense of authenticity that Isonzo is known for.
[h2][b]Cosmetic-Only, but Deeply Immersive[/b][/h2]
While the [i]First Wave[/i] DLC is purely cosmetic and doesn‚Äôt alter gameplay mechanics, its impact on the visual experience is significant. The different styles of uniforms and accessories add a new layer of immersion, allowing players to feel more connected to the history and the characters they control. From the elite units of the Bersaglieri Cyclists to the rugged trench veterans, the diversity in appearance brings the various facets of World War I to life.
For players who appreciate historical detail and character customization, the [i]First Wave[/i] bundle offers a deeper engagement with the game, turning every soldier into a unique reflection of the era. Whether leading a charge through snow-covered mountains or commanding reserve troops behind the frontlines, this DLC enhances the overall Isonzo experience by making it more personalized and authentic.
[h2][b]Verdict[/b][/h2]
The [b][i]Isonzo: First Wave[/i][/b] DLC is an excellent collection for players who want to enrich their experience on the Italian Front with a wide variety of customization options. By combining the [i]Elite Units, Alpine Units, Veteran Units[/i] and [i]Reserve Units[/i] packs, this bundle provides a comprehensive look at the different types of soldiers who fought in World War I. The attention to historical accuracy, from the ruggedness of the veteran troops to the elegance of the officers, ensures that every player can find a look that suits their style.
For players who value immersion, historical accuracy and customization, the [i]First Wave[/i] DLC is a must-have. Whether outfitting your troops for the brutal winter or leading a squad of elite units into battle, this bundle brings the soldiers of the Italian Front to life with authenticity, variety and attention to detail.
