Rhino Runner is a platform indie game where the player needs to avoid deathly traps in order to find balloons in different maps. I have not enjoyed playing this game, since the controls are quite wacky and annoying. It consumes a lot of GPU. And the music is very repetitive and silly. Not recommended. 4/10.

It reminds me of Ninja Warrior contest on TV, but with simple and easy mechanics, and the path is wild and you don't need to go through every trap actually. The traps are moviving spikes pillars mostly, with some rotating doors and sand bags to push you down from the path. It's not that easy when you start playing, and there's no checkpoint so no tolerance to any mistakes. I managed to beat level 1 but that level 2 is too difficult as everything goes x1.5 faster. 

Overall it's a relaxing little game, adding a timer and a leaderboard would be more fun.

You play as a Rhino, and have to overcome very hastily assembled obstacles. There isn't much more to say about the game or the developer who has released 12 games this year alone. At least it is cheap.

https://youtu.be/0EEgPhflsdY

[quote][b][url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asset_flip]Warning: Asset Flip![/url][/b]
Rhino Runner is a Digital Homicide style asset flip, or what Valve calls a "Fake Game". The "developer" paid for/pirated a few Unreal Marketplace packs, dumped them all in a blender, and submitted it to Valve as if they're real game developers.[/quote]

Two notable criteria for what makes an asset flip instead of legitimate use of stock assets are whether those assets comprise the majority of the game, and whether the "developer" properly credited the people who created most of the assets in the game.  This game fails both of those tests.  The "developers" here didn't credit any of the artists and real, actual game developers who created the assets here, so this is plagiarism, as well as cash grab shovelware.

In this case, the asset flipper took a bunch of Unreal assets like the rhino character, which he stole from the [url=https://www.artstation.com/marketplace/p/Bn5Om/fighters-pack]Fighters Pack[/url], created by actual game developer, Maksim Bugrimov.  These stolen assets got dumped on a very poor quality, lazy third person platformer template.  This is possibly in violation of the ArtStation Standard License, but Tero likes breaching intellectual property and copyright licenses to dump this toxic garbage onto Steam, as a paid product.  It has no value or merit as a real game.

Tero Lunkka/Valkeala Software have shown a repeat pattern of unethically dumping other people's work onto Steam as a cheap, nasty cash grab, through this account or through closely linked/alt accounts.  Here's some examples so you can see for yourself:
[list]
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/581200]Nash Racing[/url]" = [url=https://www.unrealengine.com/marketplace/en-US/product/advanced-tuning-cars]Advanced Tuning Cars[/url] developed by James Novih
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/777270]Thirsty Bubble[/url]" = [url=]Low Poly Scenario Pack+POLYGON Knights Pack+Simple Dungeons[/url] developed by 
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1639090]Survival Isolation[/url]" = [url=https://www.unrealengine.com/marketplace/en-US/product/easy-survival-rpg]Easy Survival RPG v3[/url] developed by Easy Systems
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1643280]Fancy the Frog[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/2d/characters/pixel-adventure-1-155360]Pixel Adventure 1[/url] developed by Pixel Frog
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1776540]Lawnmower Game: Pinball[/url]" = [url=https://github.com/freezy/pinball-construction-kit]Pinball Construction Kit[/url] developed by Epic Games
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/713580]Nash Racing 2[/url]" = [url=https://www.unrealengine.com/marketplace/en-US/product/advanced-tuning-cars]Advanced Tuning Cars[/url] developed by James Novih
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/768060]The Warrior Of Treasures[/url]" = [url=https://www.unrealengine.com/marketplace/en-US/product/dynamic-combat-system]Dynamic Combat System[/url] developed by Grzegorz Szewczyk
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/989340]Aliens Dont Exist[/url]" = [url=https://craftpix.net/freebies/2d-game-alien-character-free-sprite/]Alien Character - Free Sprite[/url] developed by Craftpix
[/list]

Taking this shovelware seriously as if it was a genuine attempt to make a game, it doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

The game assets are fairly mediocre/low quality, in some places they appear mismatched... Ultimately the quality of these assets, and thus the overall visual quality is lower than average, and low quality always makes for a less than optimal gaming experience.  Remember, we're looking for the best of the best of 100,000+ games on Steam.

The controls can't be customised, which will be an annoyance for many, but it can also render the game unplayable for differently-abled gamers, left handed gamers or gamers using AZERTY or other international keyboard layouts.  

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

The poor quality of this game is reflected by how many people spent time with it.  At the time of this review, SteamDB shows the all-time peak player number was only 5 players, and the worst part is these weren't genuine players, these were the Russian fake review accounts that the developer paid to make the fake reviews.  Since the fake reviews are all done, now the only player activity occurs once or twice a month, presumably someone loading it up to see what it is then quickly uninstalling it.  Considering there's over 120 million gamers on Steam and well over 100,000 games for gamers to choose from, the overwhelming lack of interest in this low quality game is to be expected.

It's also important to note the "developer" here has connections to a number of shady Russian asset flippers and review manipulators who show an organised pattern to scam and defraud gamers with fake reviews and asset flipping the work of others for profit.  While reviews are about the games, gamers should be informed when developers act unethically.   Whether these connections are the same developer using multiple accounts, or just working closely with other unethical developers, gamers should be warned about the harm to gamers by this developer and their associates.  Buying games from unethical developers puts your money at risk.

[quote][b][url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/erikkain/2017/01/18/steam-takes-down-art-of-stealth-after-developer-posts-fake-reviews/?sh=750e13e12354]Warning: Review Manipulation![/url][/b]

This game features a number of fake positive reviews from accounts known to be in the business of review manipulation/paid reviews.  They're all written in either Russian or broken English, appear at almost exactly the same time, very shortly after the game launched on Steam, all have a direct Steam purchase of the game, and the accounts are used consistently to write fake reviews for asset flips and other cash grabs/scams.  The "Positive" review score on this game should be disregarded due to this blatant, unethical review manipulation.  This is done to deceive and scam gamers into paying for a bad product.[/quote]

So, should you buy this game?  Is this one of the best of the 100,000+ games on Steam?

Rhino Runner is relatively cheap at $2 USD, but it's not worth it. Given the defects and quality issues with the game, coupled with the unrealistic price, and the questionable ethical nature of the developer and/or their associates (as outlined above), this is impossible to recommend.  Remember that if you buy a game from an unethical developer, you're putting your money at risk.

[quote][b][url=https://partner.steamgames.com/doc/marketing/profile]Profile Features Limited![/url][/b]
Valve have marked this game as "Profile Features Limited" at the time of this review.  This is usually caused by poor sales figures and low community acceptance for the game (to date).  Until this status changes, this game will not give you +1 to your Game Collector badge count, appear in profile achievements or any other Steam meta-accomplishments, nor can it be displayed in some profile showcases.  If these factors are important to you, it may be worth holding off before buying this game.[/quote]

[h1] Information / Review English [/h1]

Rhino Runner is a casual arcade game developed by Tero Lunkka games.

[h1] Gameplay / Story [/h1]

Right from the start you have the opportunity to choose from 9 different cards, which differ from each other. The main character is a tough rhino that moves gracefully through the map despite its size and weight. Your task is to collect balloons in each section. The levels contain moving objects, rotating objects, moving deadly traps like moving spikes and moving balls. Also if you try to get off the map you lose and your progress is gone and you have to start from the beginning. Precise jumps and skill are the key to success. The whole thing is accompanied by suitable music. It is controlled with a mouse/keyboard, which is easy to use.

[h1] Per [/h1]

+ 9 different maps
+ Main character is a rhino
+ Clear menu and controls
+ suitable music
+ Value for money
+ Achievements

[h1] cons [/h1]

- no long-term motivation

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Rhino Runner offers you a solid casual game that challenges your reflexes and tests your ability to reflect.

[h1][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/26335619-Adult-World-Gamers/] First of all, thanks to the developer for providing us with this key for the group. You can find more good reviews from others and me here and if you liked the review then we would appreciate a thumbs up. [/url][/h1]

Overall, this is a fun arcade-style time waster with some neat End of Watch-style elements. There are some flaws, though.
- No subtitles (makes it hard to figure out who is who).
-Can't skip some of the cutscenes (especially the intro one, even on repeat playthroughs).
-No separate mode that allows checkpoint restarts or extra lives (Would've loved the option along with the hardcore mode that restarts all the way from the beginning.)
-Some shots appear to require specific placements, making it awkward to hit (especially the last suspect at the end of the first level).

Edit 2: Just completed the entire game. Hope to see more someday.

Rating: 8/10

It's short, but it's a pleasant nostalgia trip back to classic FMV rail shooters.

The story is something out of an action B-movie. You play the last remaining cop after your unit is attacked. The story won't blow you away, but it's still good. The video quality is excellent, however it is unfortunate that it cannot be rewatched as a bonus feature. You cannot skip uninteresting parts, such as the intro sequence, whenever you start or die. Dying is extremely simple.

The gameplay involves shooting enemies as they show up on the screen. You use the left mouse button to shoot and the right mouse button to reload. The mechanic works, but it looks strange. When you shoot an enemy, it appears to glitch into the video for a few seconds. You can also keep shooting at it until the visual glitch repeats two or three times. Kills earn you points, but it doesn't matter. 

The challenge is to remember when the enemies appear, as it is quite difficult to complete the game on the first try. You must eliminate enemies as soon as you spot them, or you will lose one of your three lives. Sometimes you have to start shooting at a location just to survive. You can die in extremely cheap ways, like when an enemy destroys the robot you control over a tablet, but that is the hallmark of this genre.

The game is pretty short but fun. If you're bored and want something laid back and just shoot then this is it. there are a few bugs where you would shoot straight on the enemy and it wouldn't count therefore loosing a life and most likely starting from beginning. yeah there are no checkpoints which is annoying but makes you pay attention and really tests your reaction time.
This game is wild, there's nothing like it. A short and sweet gem, must-have title!

I played this for a good 2 1/2 hours and really enjoyed it. The character selection is adorable, and the graphics are cute. Fans of survival games will enjoy this, especially if you like couch-coop and online multiplayer or would just like to play solo.

It's easy to learn and easy to play. It has "crossroads" where you have to decide between two paths so you can challenge yourself to make the gameplay a little more difficult if you find it too easy. Overall, it was really fun. I haven't encountered any problems during the playtest other than the game lagging/freezing for a few moments while at a crossroad.

Okay, i want to be completely straighforward with it: [b] It feels like a technical demo [/b].
Is it bad? No, not at all. As the description says, it is a project from some students, so lets cut some slack for that.
However, it is not a full game at all, not even a trial i would say atm.
I am glad to see that the project has received an update a few weeks before this review, since it has a lot of things that could be improved and is an AWESOME idea.
[h2] What i like [/h2]
[olist]
    [*]The graphic part of the game is astonishing, with some fancy good visuals and a setting that quite obviously takes inspo in Cyberpunk 2077, but not as a bad thing at all.
    [*] The flying car level is a really good idea
    [*] The concept is really enjoyable and a really good starting point.
[/olist]

[h2] What i would upgrade/add [/h2]
[olist]
    [*]Controller support/wheel support
    [*]Car handling, right now is so easy to just drift the rear end of the car without analog inputs.
    [*]A way for the game to recognize when audio is being played from an app or even in general, so you dont have to manually put the songs in the files.
[/olist]
[h3] A bit more in depth comment and conclusions [/h3]
It is, again, a superb idea. But if you want to really make it enjoyable, you should add eventually things such as: controlling the traffic density, more car options for the same track, and what i mentioned earlier of the game detecting the songs automatically and the synth doing its thing in consequence since most people (myself included) dont have any music downloaded, we simply listen to it through streaming. Also, i would focus the aim of this game into something like Shutoko (a highway driving mod with traffic for assetto corsa) and its experience in a more arcade-ish way, if you manage to bring those cyberpunk vibes into something like that mod with controller and/or wheel support and tweaking a bit the car handling for it to be a bit more steady, i would stay for hours in here no doubt. 
I cant emphasize enough how good of an idea this is, and i would love to see the project if it is continued. But sadly, at this moment it is not the most enjoyable experience, though not horrible by any means, just needs some improvement.
All things considered, the possibilities are huge and hopefully I will be spending lots of hours into this game, thx for the effort devs.
P.S. This is just a nitpicky comment, but if this ever gets steam deck compatible with the controller that would be awesome as well, but since i dont know how easy/hard it is to do, I wont add it to the main comment.

Great for thinking about probability and turning odds to your favor. I mean, doubling on losses can be done anytime. as long as you have a 1, a 2, a 4, a 8, and so on even if your bets are weird, as long as you make the rule work it is fun to do. hell, say you pin bet results as + for a win and a - for a loss. You can change so many things up. This would work and doubling on loss : 1-, 1+, 1-, 2+, 2-, 4+. The way I see it, it works like this: You flip a coin eight times. You then select say flips 1, 5, 7, and 8. Each flip has a indepedent probabilities, but what is the chance they are all tails? the same as the chance for 1, 2, 3, and 4, to all be tails. As long as an understanding of odds is there, it aint luck. The whole process makes me think I am psychic, hence the game is quite funny to play. It reminds me of back when my friend got me into Honkai and I calcuted basic odds for qingze, probably the nichest character in the game. I am now realizing that this game would be great to teach probabilities with.

[h1] AT A GLANCE [/h1]
[list]
[*][b] Game Name: [/b] 5050
[*][b] Original Release: [/b] 2023-08-20
[*][b] Genre Tags: [/b] Casual, Gambling
[*][b] Estimated Playtime (Campaign): [/b] Endless
[*][b] 100% Achievements Playtime: [/b] 30-60 Minutes
[*][b] DLC Required for 100% Achievements: [/b] No
[*][b] Multiplayer Aspect: [/b] None
[*][b] Replayability: [/b] Some
[*][b] Recommended To: [/b] Casual Gamers, Achievement Hunters
[/list]
[h1] REVIEW [/h1]
[b] 5050 [/b] is a casual, gambling game. 
[h3] STORY [/h3]
There is no story, background, or setup to the game.
[h3] GAMEPLAY[/h3]
You start the game with 100 points and must wager an amount and click the button. You have a 50/50 chance to double your bet or lose it all. Your goal is to get the highest amount possible. There is no time limit and you are free to either take as long as you want or as fast as possible. The game allows you to keep your progress between play sessions, so if you wanted to play for a bit and come back to your balance it looks like you can.
[h3] PLAYTIME [/h3]
The game is pretty easy and is only as hard as what your luck is. Play time for this game is ~30-60 minutes to get all achievements.
[h3] COMPLAINTS [/h3]
There is nothing specific to complain about for this game.
[h3] REPLAYABILITY [/h3]
There is no end game and you could continue to play forever if you wanted to.
[h3] RECOMMENDATION [/h3]
I would recommend this game to anyone that likes casual games or is an achievement hunter, and since it is free there is no reason not to have it.

I tested the game as a Democrat and Republican.  

Narrowly won as the Republican, and barely lost as the Democrat.

The game benefits from the simple menu options,  with different eras of the electoral college and different turnout options based on prior years elections.

Other reviewers had a couple of suggestions that I agree with too, however.

For example, Playing as an Independent Candidate.

I noticed the game has a factor option for how the third party candidates perform. That's a nice addition and it seems to work, however, there's no option to play as an Independent candidate.

If you choose to update this game, or release a new version,  you must add that option.  It will provide us with some form of replayability if we get tired of playing as the main parties. 

The policy selection options and campaign system is okay, it's a little underwhelming,  but it's simple enough for the average person to understand even if they're not into politics.

I would recommend this game but just be aware that future updates or versions have room for improvement. 

7.5/10 Review Score

This game is okay, but still leaves a lot to be desired. For those that are wondering, it works well on the Steamdeck & uses the tracking pads.

I'll get in to what I like:
* It is simplified & mostly easy to understand.
* On election night, you get to see the map as the results start to come in & it even has projected winners.

----------------------------------------------------------------

For a political simulator game it is very bare bones. Here's what could be added to improve it:

* Allow players to give their candidate & their opponent(s) names & not just select randomly generated names.
* While some basics on political issues are covered such as the economy, national defense, border security, & the environment, it is lacking in other areas. What about Constitutional issues (free speech, gun control, etc.)? Immigration? Repealing certain laws? What I mentioned just bare scratches the surface. 
* Allow players the option to create a custom third party, complete with custom party logo & determine their party's primary color ( for map tracking purposes).
* Allow players the option to play as a third party candidate. While it hasn't happened yet, its still a far off possibility. If you get enough people steamed at the two major parties, they have been know to throw their support behind a third party candidate.
* Allow players to completely customize the two major parties involved. Allow the option to determine what those parties will be & allow customization of their party logos & their party's main color (purple, yellow, green etc).
* When playing, allow the player to determine where their candidate's home state is. In elections, sometimes a home state can give a candidate an advantage.
* I like how you get to choose electoral maps from various years like 2000, 2012, & 2020. Would it be possible to include electoral maps every election year since 1952?
* Speaking of the electoral map, what about allowing a player to customize their own electoral map? Give players the option to determine toss up states, blue states, & red states (or gray states, orange states, & turquoise states) . Allow players to also determine the number of turns they have prior to the actual election.
* Between turns, have news updates on the player's progress & the opponent's progress (such as newspaper headlines, TV news reports (coverage of a campaign stop in a state), or interview. 

Like I said before, it you like a simple, easy-to-understand campaign simulator, this game is good for that. If you're expecting something with more details, then you'll be severely disappointed. On a scale of 1 to 5, I give the game a 2.

Each title in the collection brings something fresh and distinctive to the table, whether it's an innovative gameplay mechanic, a unique art style, or a thought-provoking narrative. From surreal exploration games to fast-paced platformers, the collection pushes the boundaries of what games can be and invites players to explore new worlds and experiences.

Visually, the AploVVare Collection is a feast for the eyes, with its vibrant colors, striking visuals, and imaginative art direction. Whether you're traversing a dreamlike landscape, navigating a dystopian cityscape, or delving into the depths of a mysterious dungeon, each game in the collection offers a visually stunning experience that draws players into its world. The attention to detail and craftsmanship evident in the collection's visuals is a testament to the passion and creativity of the developers behind each title.

Beyond its visual appeal, the AploVVare Collection boasts engaging gameplay experiences that are both challenging and rewarding. From brain-teasing puzzles to heart-pounding action sequences, each game offers a unique gameplay experience that keeps players coming back for more. Whether you're solving mysteries, battling enemies, or exploring vast open worlds, the collection offers a wealth of gameplay variety that ensures there's always something new and exciting to discover.

One of the strengths of the AploVVare Collection is its focus on fostering a sense of community and collaboration within the indie gaming scene. By curating and promoting the work of talented developers, the collection provides a platform for creators to showcase their games to a wider audience and connect with fellow developers and gamers. This spirit of collaboration and mutual support is evident in the collection's diverse lineup of titles, which celebrate the creativity and innovation of indie game development.

In conclusion, the AploVVare Collection is a must-have for anyone who appreciates the artistry and creativity of indie games. With its diverse selection of titles, stunning visuals, and engaging gameplay experiences, the collection offers a captivating journey through the rich and vibrant world of indie game development. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or new to the world of indie games, the AploVVare Collection has something to offer for everyone.

This game is really creative and fascinating, it's a collection of simple indie games that are fast to play and intuitive. My favorite was cactorio but the other titles were really interesting as well. The game presents itself with a launcher from which you can choose from a good variety of new titles. I do think it doesn't get the recognition it deserves because all the games, even if small and quick to complete, feel really polished and well made.

While most of the games aren't for everyone, at least one of the games should be for someone.  Which is to say, if you play this compilation of small titles you will probably find at least one or two that you like.

For me, most of them didn't exactly pull me in.  And I encountered a glitch here and there that would cause to game a crash or need to be forced closed.  But I can definitely see a lot of talent here.  A lot of the games could use a bit of fine tuning IF they were to be made into full-sized games....but I don't really think that is the point.  These are small games that are being offered for free without the need for the developers to continue to dump tons of time into them with tweaks and fine tuning.

Keeping THAT in mind, this collection is fantastic.  Weld may not have clicked with me (for example), but I can recognize the interesting game concepts there.  The RNG of Terato Tamer may have turned me off of it, but the combination of steamy and horror isn't typically seen (especially in a turn-based RPG type game).  I liked the conversations in Reversary...and the fact that Terato Tamer seemed to connect to that in some ways was interesting.

All things said, I cannot see myself booting any of these games again.   But I've played enough games to see that there is a lot of talent and passion here, even for bite sized games with quirks.  I'd definitely recommend anyone give it a shot.

AploVVare Collection tries to simulate the feeling of having a Megadrive with a lot of cartridges to choose from (currently 23, they keep adding more and more). These cartridges are gamejam projects/short games the devs made and packed them in this neat little collection. Games can be hit or miss and often experimental but they're often charming enough to [b]not[/b] be just a prototype that must and should be forgotten because it's so raw it's barely anything.

The biggest highlight of the collection is the DLC that simulates the 32X; an addon for the Megadrive that basically attempted to "upgrade" the console so you didn't have to buy a new one. What does that DLC do? It adds +18 content to every game.... yeah...
the developer AploveStudio is quite horny and they don't hide it! The games themselves without the DLC can have some horny content, but most if not all of it is contained to the DLC. From simple nudity and sprite/art swaps to new synergies and effects and characters, the +18 DLC is by far the most relevant thing about this.

*I forgot to mention this and I don't know where to put it, AploveStudio's characters are all over AploVVare Collection, but it's fine if you haven't played any of their games. Hell, you might meet and know them this way a bit more easily.

Honestly, I don't understand the overwhelmingly positive reception of this game. For the most part, I failed to enjoy the game at all. I found issues with all 16 of the games, and enjoyed maybe 2 of them at best. 

WELD:
The game is way too vague and confusing with bad controls. I had no idea what I was doing for the majority of my time playing the game, and didn't enjoy it at all. Trying to manage your bars as well on top of all this and getting confusing tasks done, made it a very unpleasant experience.

Hellfire Pizza:
This is one of the few games that I actually liked. It's got an actual story, it's got comedy, and the gameplay isn't bad at all. I didn't really encounter any problems with it, and definitely enjoyed it. But it's very short and made up a very small percentage of my overall playtime of the games, so it's definitely not enough to salvage my opinion of this collection.

Malice Boutique:
While it isn't terrible, I found that there were countless times where I fulfilled what they asked for, but it simply wasn't enough. I tried combination after combination but just couldn't find the 5 star result for some of them, so definitely ruined my impression of the game. Not to mention, the game itself is just a bit stale in general and lacks content. 

Bloodsoil:
It's okay, but the controls feel very awkward, and the lack of diagonal movement made it very awkward. You also can't choose what your weapon chooses to target, so you could be trying to cut down the last plant, but it focuses on one of the zombies, and you lose because you were one hit away. 

Loveblade:
While the concept is unique, it isn't good. Very frustrating and boring gameplay, and there was no enjoyment I found from this game at all.

Noirwood:
 This game was unique, and seemed interesting, but it got very repetitive and frustrating very quickly. The wendigo enemies in the main game got way too fast and spawned in places that made it completely impossible to win if unlucky enough. The side game for the achievement was an absolutely miserable experience. I understand that's part of the point and the comedy of it, but it got so incredibly frustrating trying to deal with the game that It completely ruined this game for me.

Terator Tamer:
Easily the best of the 16, I had no issues with it, and it was the one I enjoyed the most. The problem is that a lot of the routes aren't complete and the game is just unfinished. Assuming it gets finished, it could be great, but I really don't think they plan on finishing it. 

Reversary: 
Honestly, when starting this review, I forgot about this one. This one was a gem. I really loved the visual novel aspect of it and while the actual gameplay was mediocre at best, I did enjoy this one.

Buckler:
This isn't fun. It's so ridiculously easy and you need to play through 10 matches in order to get the achievement. It was tedious, repetitive and boring

Something:
It was alright, I didn't really enjoy it, but I didn't particularly dislike it either. Probably just not for me.

Battery Acid:
Boring, overly easy and a tedious experience. I didn't enjoy anything about it, and finished it on my very first run. 

Chainlink:
I thought it was a cool experience, and then I realised that you spawn at the very beginning no matter where you die from. Made the experience way longer than it had to be and way too tedious, it should've been split into stages and you respawn at different points. 

Haulaway Joe:
The fighting mechanics were just terrible. Sometimes the skeleton attacks would be completely invisible, sometimes your attacks would just not do any damage. It was a buggy mess. 

Deadrounds:
Way too easy or way too difficult, short with a pretty bad storyline. Felt strongly like a waste of time

Clockwatch:
This game has no positives. It is legitimately one of the worst platformers I've played. It was excruciating and I don't wish playing this on anyone. 

Cactorio:
The game lags way too easily, and cannot stand more than maybe 100 cactus being farmed at one time, and that's being generous. Despite this, the achievement requires you to plant 1,000 cactus, 10x the amount that the game can even handle. An absolute laggy mess.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
While there's definitely a few games in here that could be worth playing, the overall collection isn't. I enjoyed the way they tied different games' stories together and how well they connected, but that was about it. I cannot recommend this game, it was too tedious to play through.

Haven't played every game but here are my thoughts on the ones I played and finished

Malice Boutique: Just a dress up game with what I believe are some of this guy‚Äôs OCs.

[b] One of my closest friend who I play with said if I post a review on the game and it gets 69 likes and 69 Awards that he will buy me a new gaming chair to replace my floor mat and a new keyboard to replace my current apple keyboard. So im just gonna leave this here. Help a brotha out [/b]

[b]My Playtime:[/b] 23.5h (100% achievement, finished the game)
[b]My First Playthrough:[/b] 
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (~1 achievement).
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (12 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]Monstronomy[/b] is a monster-taming game with some gruesome lore beneath it. You'll see some jumpscares and videos that are unrelated to the game as you play, which tell about something else that went behind the scenes.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- 101 monsters to catch
- Secrets to discover

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Slow combat
- Lack of QoL fixes
- Long backtracking inside building areas

[b]Specs[/b]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]No.[/b]
[i]The game lacks several QoL fixes and feels pretty much barebones, plus it doesn't use its strength for puzzle solving well.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
The game looks like a watered-down [b]Pok√©mon[/b] game, especially on the battle screen. On the good side, the monsters all look great and diverse - there were cute ones as well as the scary ones mixed in. Also, the evolutions give some sort of resemblance to their prior forms while still showcasing new features.

However, the edited videos need some work, especially on the text. Some text can be hard to see, and I'm not even talking about the ones that were made intentionally hard to see. Some of them used colors that either didn't mesh well with the background or were too dark, and the font sometimes didn't match the video. As for the content itself, it hardly shows anything of value and tends to be repeated from the ones already shown.

[h3]Story[/h3]
[b]Monstronomy[/b] is a dark take on the [b]Pok√©mon[/b] game. It starts just like any other [b]Pok√©mon[/b] game where you have to pick your starter and go on an adventure. Then you'll quickly realize that something was wrong. The game wasn't subtle in showing these secrets and urges you to find out. You are supposed to figure out what happened on your own, although it shouldn't be hard to figure out a glimpse of what's going on as long as you pay attention.

The postgame is where you'll mostly figure out everything. Sure, you might be able to access some content before finishing the game, but you might have to do it several times if you do it that way. You are supposed to gather clues from the videos and dialogues in the game, which you can use to do some tinkering on your own. However, I was kinda disappointed with how it turned out. It wasn't as scary as I thought; the worst of it is just some intended inhumane experiment. I was hoping for some creepypasta within them all, but it never shows up. Heck, I even wondered what the use of the jumpscare and the scary atmosphere in those videos is if it's being like this.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3228622966 

[h3]The Game[/h3]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
Just like [b]Pok√©mon[/b], you have to explore the map and capture some monsters. The monsters are varied, but resources are limited. You'll have issues finding enough money to catch the monsters at first, especially if you don't want to sell anything. This will be rectified after you finish the game, although I wished that it wasn't made as scarce in the beginning.

I liked how the game made use of status and stats modifiers. Both of those skills seem to be the best in this game - you'll have a hard time defeating a monster that raises its defense stat a few times, and some status ailments can permanently stun you if done right. However, that also means that strategy will be limited to one tactic, which is used by different monsters with different typing to cover the weakness and resistance chart. This also makes some monsters seem to be better than others, especially if they have access to these skills easily.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3228620308 

Fights are boring. You can't speed them up, so you have to wait for the slow animation to finish. This is made worse when your character leveled up - the exp gain sound and delay will be repeated twice, meaning that you have to wait twice as long until the fight ends. The thing is, the game never differentiates the length whenever you get a huge or low exp, and this also applies to when enemies' HP is depleted.

On the plus side, I like how the evolution works. All end-game evolution grants a secondary typing, and once you get a certain item, you can switch between the two and learn moves from both evolutions. This expands the monster capability as well as the move coverage, especially when faced with enemies that give you a disadvantage.

Despite the numerous puzzles, some of them feel bland. They tend to be similar in nature, forcing you to input combinations based on the given hints. Well, the method of acquiring the combination may be different, and it sometimes can be too vague to figure out. The ARG puzzle that requires you to browse in the real world was clever, although the next steps can be too confusing to figure out on your own.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3228619675¬†

[b]Monstronomy[/b] is a game where you have to take notes, figuring out the story based on the given hints which sometimes might lead to secrets. However, the game doesn't seem to make use of this strength - there aren't many puzzles that were made like this, and the ones that do barely reward you with anything. I know that you will learn more of the truth in some of them, but I wish there were more than that.

[b]Length and Difficulty[/b]
I finished everything in 23.5h. You can finish it faster if you want; I was taking my time and collecting all the monsters with their evolutions, which took a lot of time to do. The game isn't difficult to beat. You can just grind to bypass any difficulty. The one that can be challenging is to beat the post content, but even that will only be difficult if you don't have a lot of high-level monsters.

The game has 2 endings, but there aren't many differences between them and you can see them both by saving before the final boss.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]Monstronomy[/b] is a unique game. It feels like those creepypasta games that will try to give you the creeps as you play, except that they didn't deliver. As you continue playing, the creepiness is just gone and replaced with puzzles and secrets. It might be interesting to figure out what happened, but the game doesn't use much of this strength.

In my opinion, the game was lacking several QoL fixes; the monster-taming game feels barebones with its simplistic strategy, the UI is too simple and too similar to [b]Pok√©mon[/b], and there was a lot of backtracking needed when you are inside areas with a lot of enemies. Not to mention that all enemies are the same. I know it's being like that because of the theme, but I wish there were some differences, including more of the in-game plot instead of the "endless" fighting and random videos popping left and right. I wish I could recommend it, but I realized that I wasn't feeling much when I played this game, and the battle's slow pace irritated me in the end.

This review is spoiler free.

I can only recommend this game to  those who enjoy diving deep into a shallow pool. There are plenty of hidden mysteries and files that make for a solid ARG experience, but I can't say this game will blow anyone away from a narrative perspective even once the cat is out of the bag.

What really drags this game down however is the overly simplistic mon collection and battling portions. The system is very bare bones, the monster designs while well done are surprisingly dull, and unless you want to challenge yourself you can beat the entire game with a single mon. The final stretch of the game was a slog against goons with very little in the way of diverse teams or challenge. They also lack a unified 'theme' which takes away the charm evil groups in games like the Pokemon series gives.

If you are looking for a ARG style experience there are worse ways to spend a few hours, but as a game I cannot recommend this at full price.

"What happened to you mom?"

If you consider buying Monstronomy expecting a monster-tamer game you are right. And you are wrong at the same time. The game has a lot of things, you will be familiar with. And at the same time, Monstronomy throws a lot of strange at you, right from the beginning. In order to showcase this, I will give you a summarization of the first 5-10 minutes. You start at a desktop. Files & folders are there, you can click through. Most important are the controls-file as well as the Downloads-Folder where you find and can start the actual game you expected. So you start the Monstronomy file inside Monstronomy. You wake up in your room and go downstairs where your mother tells you to feed your monster. You go to a chest in the garden where you can choose your starter. You have the choice between an Order-, Chaos- or Demon-type monster. You return to the house, your mother lying on the gorund, blood everywhere. Dead. You leave the house, dead people and monster everywhere and your first fight against a cultist. Here starts your quest for revenge.

The monster-tamer game is quite solid. I absolutely love the different monsters and their design. The choice of two final evolution forms for every monster is a really neet idea and later on, you can even switch constantly between the two. The strengths and weaknesses are well balanced as well as the whole game. You level fast, and in each fight, the whole group gains experiences. Overall balance is also okay. The game isn't really difficult but you have to pay a bit attention or go back healing. You can catch new monsters with chests and in the end-game there are even "legendaries". The attack-design I would consider on the weaker part though. You do not have move limitations but stronger attacks have lower accuracy trying to cancel it out. Overall, the gameplay is not as complex or deep as the most well-known competitor but it is functional and shines especially in the monster design.

Though, weird as it is - the game and the situation - Monstronomy shines the most in the moments it isn't a monster-tamer game. The story alone is already unusual. But it only gets weirder and at one point you find yourself intrigued. Trying to understand what is really happening here. Inside the Monstronomy game world a lot of - let's say disturbing - videos are scattered around. Often you find them on TVs, sometimes on random objects and sometimes they are unavidable during story events. Aside from the videos, you notice that NPCs start behaving weirder and weirder and across the game world, you have green and sometimes even red texts. Certain names reappear over and over again. Progressing in the story, also unlocks new files on the Desktop (where you start the game) although locked by passwords. All of this creates a great mystery, you might want to solve. I wouldn't call Monstronomy a horror game but disturbing on certain levels. And in the end-game I would call Monstronomy even a puzzle game where you try to solve the games puzzles & mysteries. You will try to find the "legendaries", trying to figure out the real story, trying to unlock the desktop files. All of this comes together in one fulminant ARG, leading you temporarily even outside the game. And while there exists a guide, telling you how to solve most of it, I would implore you dear potential buyer, to try figuring out all of this stuff by yourself first as it makes for a far better experience.

The games also has music which I am undecided on. It is only a few tracks and most of the time, you hear this happy-to-lucky overworld tune which doesn't really fit. On the other hand this discrepancy may be well intended. From the technical side, I have encountered one "critical" bug where the stops working after certain attacks during fighting and does not react anymore. I am not exactly sure what causes it but it happened most often for me with Wind-type attacks causing a status effect. So, saving often is recommanded to reduce frustration. Futrehmore, the game's movement feels kinda choppy. The game has also achievements which need you to solve most of the game's mysteries. The main story itself probably takes around 6-10 hours. If you go for the post-game endgame content, you can add another 5-10 hours if you try it for yourself. Less if you use a lot of help.

If all of this sounds interesting to you then [strike] apply for Project Dreamcatcher today [/strike] consider buying the game. If you have more questions, leave a comment and I'll try to come back to it.

I'm going to write a more detailed review later, but oh my god, this is what child me obsessed with edgy romhacks dreamed of. An actual, well-done, well-sprited, *fun* Pokemon horror game, where you can catch and tame the 'horrifying' monsters instead of only fighting them. 

The ARG elements were such a fun twist, the battle mechanics are surprisingly deep, the two final evolution paths for each monster opened up so many opportunities for teambuilding, and the designs are absolutely my favorite part - genuinely so creative and gorgeous. 

SPOILERS of some of my current favorites, for people who want to go in completely blind: [spoiler] An anglerfish that evolves into two different deep-sea sharks, a horrifying pile of dead meat and skulls who acts like a big puppy, a tragedy/comedy split evolution, a cordyceps deer, an origami mouse that becomes other origami animals, Gun, a UFO monster with very fun evos referencing old horror movies, a stickbug made of bamboo called [i] Bamboozler, [/i] he's perfect [/spoiler]

 (I had a team of rotating monsters for the whole game, NON-STORY SPOILER: [spoiler] The Pocketwatch item that lets you switch between the final evolutions at will is insanely fun, letting you adjust your team's typings on the fly to cover whatever weaknesses you might have! The move relearner letting you learn the moves of both evo lines opens up so much customizability in different sets and coverage! Digimon-esque, I loved it there and I love it here. [/spoiler])  

Monstronomy is fun, spooky, genuine, earnest, and I love it so so much. This isn't even going into the actual plot, I just reached the postgame and there's still so much left to see.

10/10, fulfilled my childhood dreams of Pokemon horror games actually being good
This game is super cool and has such a unique concept, I can't wait to keep playing!

The horror/pokemon combo is unique and fun and I can't wait to finish the game!

Loved the retro-style of the game. Momo is a very cute and charismatic character! It takes me back to the classic 8-bit and 16-bit era.

The music is very catchy and fits the game perfectly. The sound effects reflect the game's art style, including touches of other sounds and 8-bit sounds that blend well.

It's a challenging game that engages you to learn the right way to pass each stage, offering a rewarding learning process. I loved the retro filter option; it looks like you're playing on a good quality CRT.

Amazing game. Recommend!

Short precision platformer with exaggerated playtime due to frustrating bosses.

You take the role of a miner mole who has to go check out what‚Äôs going on in the mine. Since this is similar to old-school platformers, there‚Äôs no story as you progress though the game. 

There are only four "chapter" in the game, each with ten stages. A chapter is simply a cave setting with a different color scheme and a new mechanic. For example, in one, the surfaces are slippery. The next world has its own mechanic and retains everything from the previous ones.

A stage is single-screen platforming challenges that can be finished in less than a minute. It‚Äôs very fair because it also involves one checkpoint so you don‚Äôt have to restart from the beginning after each death. Some stages have a collectible matchstick that requires a bit more effort. 

The focus is on gameplay. Despite the adorable and nostalgic pixel graphics, the game requires a certain amount of precision platforming. It doesn't go overboard with the difficulty, but the difference between making the jump and colliding with a threat is generally hidden in a fraction of second.

The mole is not a warrior or a hardy creature, so even a single contact with something dangerous can kill him. However, he possesses a very useful ability that he may use in a variety of scenarios. Regardless of the surface, he can always dig into the ground to avoid enemies or tight spaces. What I don't like is a slight hop when you come out of the hole.

However, because this is a platformer, you will be unable to progress without the leap. It has a respectable height, but you'll need to get used to the double-jump mechanism, which involves jumping first and then quickly pressing the dig button. 

This move is essential in boss fights. Well, it‚Äôs not actually a fight because all you need to do is dodge the boss‚Äô attack patterns until it becomes bored. But while normal stages are decent, boss fights are frustrating because they constantly increase their attack speed and force you to restart the entire thing if you take a hit. Due to constant dying, they will take longer to beat than all the normal stages combined.

Momo and the Mine stands out as a great precision platformer that offers an enjoyable experience. The character Momo, along with the art style and the retro-inspired screen display, transports players back to the nostalgic era of 8-bit and 16-bit consoles, engaging the gameplay from the start.

The gameplay itself is both fun and rewarding, challenging you to master each stage with the right strategy and timing. The music and sound effects enhance this immersive experience, representing tones of the 8-bit era, in addition to have addictive melodies. 

Totally recommended

"Momo and the Mine" is a fun precision platformer with a cute mole to play as! There is also a retro filter that you can turn on and off while you are on the menu. The graphics will touch the hearts of everyone liking 8-bit games! The levels are well designed and require tight controlling. Our mole is capable of that! And with his cute technics he will manage to light yet another lamp, progress the levels and beat the bosses! The soundtrack was equally fun as were the menu options and layout as well (you'll understand when you launch it).

At the time of writing, you can't remap the buttons and they aren't so convenient but you can get used to them. That's an option that should definitely be added. It will probably play better with a controller. The jump doesn't always feel 100% steady but it won't be a big problem in passing the stages.

For this price, it's a must try! It's a good game and a lot of fun! Quite memorable as well.. Who can resist such a cute little mole?.. ^^

A fun game with tight controls, cute graphics and great soundtrack. And some *very* hard bosses. It's short too, so pick it up and play it. Recommended!

Tip: holding the double jump button will make you dig if you touch the ground and are still holding it. So when you release it, you will do a little hop again. Be mindful of that if you don't understand what's happening! Once you master this you're going to breeze through the levels.

I still didnt finish he game, but it's super challenging and fun! The soundtrack is awesome too, it totally brings me back to the SNES games I used to play when I was a kid.

Definitely recommend it!
Such a great game with an amazing soundtrack! If you want to spent hours playing a great platform game, Momo and the Mine is the right choice!

A mostly charming NES inspired platformer... BUT THERE IS ONE BIG ISSUE I HAVE WITH IT.


Just got done playing this the other day, and it was a decent time waster. The graphics and music pretty much nail that retro 8-Bit Goodness, and I like the one-room approach to levels they make for some brief yet satisfying challenges (and they can get pretty tricky later on). Also having a playable title screen and options menu is a neat touch, I like that!

Our hero has a Unique moveset... one that takes some getting used to, I'll admit. The game makes use out of your required abilities, and even tests your knowledge of what this mole can do by the end-certain sections were a lot easier once I remembered that "Burrowing" is pretty much your RUN button. Though I'm not a fan of popping out of the ground and needing a moment to land before you can properly jump again, but other than that, the rest seems doable.


On paper, a game like this should take an hour or so to beat, tho you may notice I have 3.8 hrs on record at the time of me writing this, and most of THAT was spend going against the BOSSES.

There are four bosses in total-one for each world-and while the first and fourth were decent if mildly frustrating chase sequences, the second and third boss are TEDIOUS beyond belief. You don't have attacks in this game, so you're expected to wait through several minutes worth of dodging stuff before the game can let you proceed... And if at any point you choke towards the end of the fight, or the boss does something Sneaky that you weren't prepared for, you're doing it all over again!

I could easily go in detail on JUST how much I didn't like the third boss in particular, but for now... here's my recommended improvement: CHECKPOINTS. These Boss fights would be A LOT LESS PAINFUL if the player could at least SKIP the first couple waves of attacks upon respawn. The first and fourth bosses had checkpoints, so I don't see why the others cannot have them.


WITH ALL OF THAT SAID... Even though the bosses aren't very fun, the levels still are which is why I'm still going to give this game a positive recommendation at the end of the day. Talent clearly went into this, and I'm curious to see what the future holds for Tamboril. If ONLY the bosses can be improved somehow, I can see this going from a 3/5 Game to a 4/5, but you can still do worse for the price.
Very nice game ,touch and feel  let you enjoy the game more, realy fun to play .

For the price of one snack you get a super short, but really solid piece of platforming inspired by both modern precision platformers and the slightly unfair late 2000s "I Wanna Be The Guy" trend. An evening well spent.

[h1]This game skips too much![/h1]


Practically every chapter ends just when things are getting interesting, and the start of the next chapter is always a time-skip with a couple pages of explanation as to what happened in the intervening year(s). You don't get to experience things with your character for the first time - you're always thrown in the middle/near the end of events.

First day of Y«íngsh√¨ school? Nope, you go from discovering you're a Y«íngsh√¨ at the end of chapter 1 to being a student about to graduate at the start of chapter 2. Final exam? No matter what you do your rival has you dead to rights and... the next chapter starts, 3 years later, with your character ruminating about how you somehow got out of that very unwinnable situation and barely beat out your rival in a no doubt impressive turn of events that everyone thought was super cool.

Something exciting happening? Better skip ahead a few years, nothing's more exciting than the ending or being told about it after it's already happened!

Also, the romances are just a checkbox. You barely spend any time with these characters and your only option to express any romantic interest is after interacting with them - interactions that don't even have a lick of romantic interest/flirting mind - and choose the choice that says "they are everything I want in a lover. We are soul-mates. I am crushing so hard". I'm not even exaggerating, that's how intensely written the "romance please" options are, which make no sense for how little we interact with them. I just want my character to show a mild interest or maybe open to the idea of that character making a move... [strike]but God forbid any on these games have characters that show romantic interest in the player without having to actively pursue them.[/strike]

All that said, it's not [i]bad[/i]. It's written well, as far as I can tell (I am a troglodyte so YMMV). It just feels incomplete not only because of how much is skipped, but [i]what[/i] is skipped. In my opinion, the most interesting parts of the story are missing, and that's a shame.

(Also, my time played isn't an accurate representation of how long the game is. I just kind of left it running in the background (even when writing this review. Because I'm dumb.))

This game can be broken down into 2 halves.

I did not enjoy the first half much and would give it 5 out of 10. Choices are abundant, but barely affect anything plot-wise. I also found romances lacking. The game just throws 6 potential romantic interests in a row at you one after the other and prompts the player to express their interest (or lack there of) on the spot after a couple interactions and... thats it, you won't meet them again until the second half.

The game redeems itself with the second half where player choices start to truly matter and the story picks up. I would give it 7 out of 10.  And hence the "thumbs up".

While I've enjoyed the game overall, the first half could've been better.

It started off interesting and I wanted to see where it went, so I tried just going with it and letting it do its thing. However that turned into giving it passes which turned into disinterest, then calling it quits.

It's a good concept but it's heavily expositional and too fast-paced. I know it's hard to fit a huge timespan into a single game but it goes by in such big chunks while basically just telling you what's happening in detail, often in dialogue, that it feels like the game is passing you by. This lead to very simplified choices as well where you get one chance to choose a path- like which general to support or who to romance- and then that's just set in motion and you watch it play out almost without you. Aside from these major story-altering choices that come up your choices seem superficial.

And it's not just the setup phase either. I quit at the discovery of the second crane almost three hours in. It fell victim to [i]all[/i] the above flaws. I expected a challenger and the crane patron spirit had been talked up so much only for the main character to find another kid like them and go "Whoa, another crane! That's crazy!" and then it's just accepted on like one piece of evidence that "yeah there's two now actually" and then you're moving forward again.

I think the idea was just overly ambitious. This game's full potential doesn't fit in one game, or maybe just didn't fit in the timeframe the writers were working with.

This is a really well-writen IF (Interactive Fiction) that definitely deserves some more love! The story's pretty captivating from the very beginning and, while there were some... weaker moments (looking at you chap. 4), it really picks up around chapter 5.

Some pretty significant parts of the game (including a whole chapter) are pretty much open for you to choose and do whatever might compel you, be it boosting your own standing in court, assisting the military, or even the emperor himself. Your choices are also [i]really[/i] important - supporting certain characters in chapter 3 and 5 will (indirectly) bring far-reaching consequences up to the preparations for the final battle.

Hell, even your origin story (like whether your character was born in nobility or not) is relevant in most chapters. Take that, Cyberpunk.

Fights were engaging and not too challenging, though I wish a few stat checks were less demanding. I'm sorry, I'll never agree with using personality stats as a skill. My character made a quick joke two pages ago and now she's precisely 1% less Serious‚Ñ¢, so she'll fail this next check and have a scar for life :(

Jokes aside, like others have said, Tale of Two Cranes does suffer from an unfortunate case of having just enough to create a very compelling and interesting narrative, but not fully dedicating enough time and depth to all of its arcs. Almost every chapter starts with a two- to five-year timeskip - there's nothing necessarily [i]wrong[/i] with that, of course, but it does skip through very intriguing moments right to their resolutions.

All that to say I often found myself a bit disconnected from my character and the current plot, as I didn't see most of the events unfolding. The writers did manage to do a good job at describing these past events after the facts, yet... I still wish I had actively participated in the full-on wars we missed out on. It's still a REALLY long game, so I understand why they couldn't reasonably spend too much time fleshing out every single conflict.

This also applies to romance and more importantly to the characters themselves. While I liked most of their introductions, the protagonist's main party didn't develop much at all through the story (with one exception which I'll mention later). Also, the game really insisted in only ever allowing the player to talk to up to 3 characters during "free roam" sequences, so, yeah, I never chose to actively interact with a few of the more standoffish characters, as my character would reasonably have a preference to spend time with her spouse, best friend, master, and/or family. That made it so that most moments of camaraderie, such as when your friends would gather to party or celebrate victory, felt a bit... empty?

"Here ya go, you won the war! Time to celebrate and see how the others are feeling!"
[Interacts with a single character].
"Welp, that was fun! You'll see them again three years from now."

Big spoiler warning here: [spoiler]The Other Crane is definitely the most important NPC and I wish he had a bit more time to fully develop. He's a major character in chapter 3 and 4, but he suddenly turns into a side character like most others up until chapter 6. Everything that happens following that caused a bit of whiplash, even if I expected it beforehand, to the point where the title Tale of Two Cranes felt almost ill-fitting before then.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]Kinda reminded me of Revenge of the Sith? I guess???[/spoiler]

While I wish we had more "personal" quests and interactions with the companions, I still had fun with the latter half of the romances. Stakes are high and the characters are pretty realistic about it. You didn't hear it from me, but a few scenes did make me tear up a bit... Chapter 5 and 6 also let you spend a bit more time with characters by selecting them to help you with your own goals, which is neat! Just wish we saw a bit more of the opposite too.

Finally, the last two chapters were awesome. I wanted the final choice to detail its consequences a [i]bit[/i] more, as my character completely changed a few, uh, important things, but I'm alright with it.

Overall, I think the plot would've benefited if it was split into two or three parts/games, each fleshing out its wars and such (big spoilers: [spoiler]so Tale of Two Lords, Tale of Two Empires, and Tale of Two Cranes[/spoiler]), but it's still a great story as it is. I had fun and I'd recommend it for anyone interested in Ancient China or other IFs such as The War for the West.

TL;DR: It's great! just wish it was more fleshed out. 9/10 :3

First, the positives: The writing is good, the epilogue is lengthy, and it's an interesting setting.

The bad: Many choices are presented that lead to bad outcomes not because of a skill check failure but because the choice itself was misleading. E.g. when choosing how to prosecute a war, if you select the option that is basically to exercise caution and surgical strikes, the *actual* choice and way it is perceived is cowardice.

The story is much more on rails than most CoG stories.

It leans far more into "game" than "story."

The ROs are bland and you have too few interactions with them.

I lost count of how many situations are lose-lose no matter what you do. Going back and altering save files to maximize skills, alter personality traits, and increase relationship scores - in many situations, none of this will alter key outcomes. This is forgivable with situations like when a particular lord is killed while you are away, but I can't fucking stand it when it's something like failing to persuade someone or getting your ass kicked in single combat. Why even present the reader with the the illusion of choice, the illusion that you have any control? Anytime interactive fiction titles pull that, I view it as the author expressing contempt for the audience.

The vast majority of the story is also barely about the central conflict. It comes up at the very end as a sudden betrayal by a character I'd disliked from the moment they were introduced.

My playtime is crazy long because there were several times when I got so irritated that I just walked away from my laptop without bothering to close the game.

The writing here, in terms of prose alone, is good, the setting and the overall plot are a solid backbone to build a story off of. But the execution is lacking. There's a whole entire mechanic around building up your estate and deciding what to do with it, but it is only tangentially relevant to the plot and you never get any sense of connection to it. I feel almost like the authors were inspired by Lords of Infinity, but didn't pick up on the fact that that was the third title in the series and is explicitly structured as being part of a buildup that will pay off in future books.

I really wanted to give this one a positive review, but I think the simplest indicator to me that I wasn't enjoying myself was seeing how many tabs in my text editor I had open with prior save states to revert choices because I realized that a seemingly innocuous option selected previously had led to some stupid outcome that wasn't even slightly hinted at when the choice was made. When I start making more and more checkpoints for myself to go back, the entire exercise becomes less and less about immersion and enjoyment and more about frustration that the poor structure and deceptive choices are breaking up the flow.

As one who loves stories such as these, this one went from interesting enough at the start and ended with something that couldn't be called lackluster at best

The main issue wasn't a dozen paper thin characters or a dozen stats that did next to nothing, choices where if you didn't pick the "correct" stats to spec into you would be doomed to fail (IE: 3 choices and all of them using your lowest stats out of a possible **4** stats) or even that those stats degrade or raise for no apparent reason but rather the uncountable number of times wrong events would trigger; be they the low/neutral/high relationship value dialogue showing up right after the others, making a choice and it acting like i didn't or in a particularly noticeable time acting like i picked one when i didn't or just flat out not flagging. As stated in another review it's a constant "build up, time skip, resolution while talking about what happened in the time skip", but i'd rather focus on another part, that being the character you play as, they are erratic and hardly in line with at least how i was playing; it makes total sense that a stoic, noble and forgiving character would be yelling and making rash choices about an order that they *know* to be a lie or something they just wouldn't care about which bring me to the "classes" and not just that calling them that feels *off*; one can detect lies which you'd *think* is helpful but it's mainly just flavor much like your other powers (at least if you pick strategist) or the crane which does nothing but tell you to stop interacting with it

I wasn't going to write a review but then i finished the game and got perhaps the biggest slap in the face "everything you did didn't matter" ending even though i was not only well liked by named characters but groups such as the army and court; as i sit here writing this i *want* to say something at least decent about it but,

TLDR: it tries to do too many things at once, has too many characters, doesn't expect you *not* liking some characters, keeps teasing the idea of you *doing* anything, gives options where you might just have no chance to pass, bugged flag and skips around so much that nothing feels like it matters since the next page could be years in the future which makes the sudden events at the end feel even cheaper

The game throws a massiv curveball, everything changes, your efforts are negated regardles of stats and then comes a three year timeskip.

This is great in a story when it happens ones or twice but here it happens ever single chapter.
Your just left exausted and often confused at the change of fortune. It kind of takes the joy away.

The Monkey King is probably one of the absolute best hero skins, but as with all hero skins before, it suffers from the exact same problems.
The customization is limited, with only two of the three colors in available palettes being used and placed a bit strangely.
Monkey Kings fur is also very bright and washed out, making an all red or all black Monkey King isn't possible, as red becomes almost pink and black becomes greyish, meaning that your options to look unique with the character will be difficult.

The skin isn't worth the price, how I would make the offer more enticing for a customer:
Include the Event Exclusive "Ruyi Jingu Bang" execution that came out the same time as the skin, add an Exclusive Emblem Editor Symbol that resembles the Monkey King.
This would make the offer of buying the skin with money more appealing and justify the higher price. I would want more such as unique voice lines, but based on what can and cannot be done, the execution would be the easiest to do.

You'll get more from the Hero Offers (Warmonger, Gryphon, Kyoshin, Pirate, Medjay, Afeera, Ocelotl) that gives you a new hero, an exclusive ornament, an elite outfit, 3 scavanger crates and seven day champion status for less the price of the hero skins; buy the skin with steel, it is not worth it over the cheaper hero offers.
I bought it only so I can leave and repeat my problems with these skins lmao

It does not add anything new to the hero, such as having a unique execution specific to the hero, effects specific to the hero, dialogue that replaces voice lines from the default hero look or a unique symbol for the Emblem Editor.
Better to get this skin for the in-game 25000 steel than pay for it, even if it's not worth it in-game either unless you really like this appearance.

They hired a voice actor to represent the character of Baigujing in the event for this skins introduction, but they did not think to hire a voice actor for Monkey King or use existing voice lines or use additional diaolgue left on the cutting room floor that could have helped make this character stand out, they are fully capable of doing this, yet they refuse to do so.

It's a costly cosmetic that doesn't feel entirely worth it's price, much like the other skins.
They are fully capable to add unqiue sounds and more customization options to these skins: on 1st April 2023 they had a small event as part of an April Fools joke where they briefly replaced the appearance of heroes, replacing the effects they use and replacing some of their dialogue with funny sounds.

And they couldn't add unique dialogue to the Hero Skins because...?
Demanding quality of products is a customers right, regardless if you pay through money or your time.

Have been playing this game for just an hour and it already got me hooked! Its like vampire survivors with a more elaborate fighting system. You actively enagage in the fight and don't just run around. More akin to something like hades in that regards. 

And from what I could tell so far there is a surprising amount of content for an EA title with such a small price. Many different abilities you can combine and various different enemy/boss designs will await you.

And the menus!! They feel soo nice and juicy. I know thats probably not a deciding factor here, but shows how much love and care was put into this game!

This game is just a pure work of art ! Tho its quite under rated the Game play mechanics and Art style are just fabulous which follows its amazing soundtracks and different levels . 

Developed By : TEAM DASH GAMES 
Release Date : 13th May 2024

Visuals:   The visuals are cool and graphically the game is so good , the art style is quite hyperpop pyschedelic type and the concept of placing a darker colours as base in the game and everything be colourful and vibrant is just amazing , i assure you this game is going to hook you up for many hours. 

Soundtracks: The soundtrack perfectly complements the game's tone, with haunting melodies and adrenaline-pumping battle themes. The sound effects are crisp and impactful, adding to the overall immersion.

Gameplay :  Basically hack and slash but with more and more powerups and abilities . Talk about abilities there are many cool abilities which can be unlocked permanently and some boosters which u can gain while in action smacking the enemies.

Overall the game is pretty good and i liked it myself , If you would say to rate it i would definitely give it a solid 7.5/10 
With upcoming updates who knows it be a solid 10/10 ?  I would totally recommend trying out this game .

[h2]Chaos, Carnage, Neons and Upgrades![/h2]

In Dash x Survivors, prepare for an adrenaline-soaked journey through relentless waves of robots, where your only objective is survival. This hack 'n' slash action roguelike throws you into the thick of the action, challenging you to carve your own path to victory amidst the chaos.

The gameplay is a whirlwind of excitement, with every moment filled with fast-paced combat and strategic decision-making. Whether you're dashing through enemies with lightning speed or utilizing a vast array of weapons to unleash devastating combos, each battle is a thrilling dance of skill and strategy.

However, it's worth noting that the game lacks a traditional story. Instead, it thrusts you directly into the action, allowing the gameplay itself to take center stage. 

In conclusion, Dash x Survivors is a must-play for fans of hack 'n' slash action and roguelike games. With its heart-pounding combat, deep upgrade system, and endless replayability, it's a game that will keep you on the edge of your seat for hours on end. So, gear up, dive into the fray, and prepare to fight for survival against the relentless onslaught of enemies!

[b]Rating:7/10[/b]

Despite the fact that the game is in early access, it is not bad both in the visual component and in the game part. The game has a color changing mechanic depending on the choice, which adds dynamics to what is happening, changing color and music depending on the direction of action of the ability, so when using a defensive ability, the music changes to a slower and relaxing one, and in the case of an attacking one, it changes to a more dynamic one. Rating: 6.5/10
On my way to play an actual game.

Metafictional game where you want to find all the secrets.

The title of the game‚Äôs not far from the truth. Most of the time you‚Äôre not required to do anything at all. You simply sit and observe the words on the screen. True, you must occasionally hit a key to advance the game, but that key is very specific, and you must adhere to the game's rules.

The game is presented as text on an in-game computer screen. Someone is speaking to you and instructing you to hit a key. They want you to carry out their exact commands. If you interrupt them before they finish what they're saying, they'll be extremely rude to you and simply start the sentence again.

The experience lasts around half an hour. You get an achievement for following the rules and you‚Äôre instructed to hit ESC to exit the game. You can't close the game in the usual way till then. There is no menu, and the only way out is to force quit.

However, there are secrets to be found. If you look at the screen closely, you will notice various things that could lead to something more. The most obvious hint is that each key on the keyboard creates a unique pattern in the game. Then there's a series of numbers, flashing hearts, and specific words from the text. If you keep playing it a few times, you‚Äôll open another part of the game. 

The only major criticism is that you can't see what you're typing. As if that wasn't unpleasant enough, you also have to press enter to confirm the word. You may have thought of the correct solution, but the game would not accept it because you unknowingly made a typo.

Another small nuisance is that you need to quit the game if you want to try another path. Also, if you miss a clue and have to go through the normal game again, you won‚Äôt be able to skip forward.
Great game. Worth it. Bit difficult though.

I grinded through this entire thing as I've read every other translated Kataoka Tomo VN and wanted to keep up that tradition. Don't follow my example, this might as well not be translated.

The translation is terrible, every sentence is at best, stilted, at worst, grammatically incorrect or nonsensical. If you're wondering, no it's not machine translation, it is done by a company called Tokyo Translation Team, looking at their website they seem reputable and fine enough, but they are clearly not. G-MODE/Nekoday you got scammed, please go back to MangaGamer or another actual good translation company for your next VN.

As for the actual plot, it revolves around the mystery of the main character who is immortal, and unable to leave Shinjuku. Except the first 2 chapters (out of 4), are fairly dull slice of life scenes with the mafia/public safety department/church, nothing much happens. Then the final 2 chapters do delve deeper into the mystery, and the reveals are fine, there's some solid scenes, but it's still nothing that notable.

Also the presentation here is a step-down from Christmas Tina, which is a shame as the art was a great in that, here it's just not as good.

Overall, if you want to read a great visual novel written by Kataoka Tomo surrounding the mystery of somebody being immortal, then read Winter Polaris, that actually has a nice translation.

By the way if you want to see if the translation is actually that bad, there is a demo, check that out instead of buying this.
Translation is so bad it's probably MTL. Not worth it.

The game itself though isn't anything that special, I will admit a lot of my enjoyment is from factors that exist around it then things it does itself. Highly recommended to anyone who enjoys dungeon crawlers.

Big kudos to the team behind it, making this super fun game even more accessible to people, and thank you G-MODE for preserving and allowing us to play these neat, old mobile games.
