Really charming game. I intend to get lost in this for a while yet. I'd love to see more customization rollouts for things like changing road layouts or tracks, changing ground type, and of course adding people and new types of buildings.

But so far this is absolutely worth the price of admission, and I'm very much enjoying myself.

A cute, relaxing puzzle game - great if you're into Japan and trains! I would describe this more as a toy than a game - the puzzles are straightforward snap puzzles in which you assemble various train components, ultimately completing the entire train car.

You can choose from three difficulty modes, with two of them providing guidance on where to place the pieces. The game doesn't judge your performance, but it does keep track of your completion time and offers achievement challenges.

The layout mode is purely for relaxation and it allows you to choose from several different landscapes to build on, you can decorate each with all kinds of objects, place your trains, and enjoy the photo mode. It evokes the feeling of playing around with a nice model train diorama.

The encyclopedia mode is a nice way to learn more about each of the three featured trains, and you will be able to step inside each one to take a closer look. 

The trains in this game are all licensed but you won't find any real tracks, stations or station melodies, sadly.

The presentation is well done, I had one small issue where a certain puzzle piece was invisible against the background (white on white) and the controls on Steam Deck do not default to 'Gamepad with Joystick Trackpad' which the game is designed around, so you will have to change that yourself before playing on Steam Deck.

I'm also experiencing some of the achievements not tracking correctly, though I assume that will be resolved with a patch. This title is priced perfectly for what it is.

[h1] "A Platformer Gem That Defies Gravity" [/h1]

"Titled" takes the platformer genre and flips it, quite literally, on its head. With its unique gravity-defying mechanics and captivating world, this game offers an intriguing twist that's both challenging and refreshing. While it might not achieve perfection, "Titled" is a standout addition to the platformer landscape that will keep you engaged with its gravity-altering puzzles and captivating atmosphere.

Innovative Gameplay Mechanics:
The core gameplay mechanic of altering gravity introduces a whole new level of complexity to the platformer genre. Navigating the levels involves strategic thinking as you switch between different gravitational forces to overcome obstacles and uncover secrets. While it might take a bit to get used to, once mastered, it offers a rewarding sense of accomplishment.

Mind-Bending Puzzles:
"Titled" doesn't just test your platforming skills; it also challenges your cognitive abilities. The game's puzzles require a mix of timing, reflexes, and logic. Some puzzles might leave you scratching your head, but the feeling of satisfaction when you finally crack them is unparalleled.

Immersive World Design:
The game's visuals and world design deserve praise for creating an immersive environment. Each level is a unique setting, from floating islands to mysterious underground caverns, all intricately designed to fit the gravity-manipulating theme. The attention to detail in the environments enhances the overall experience.

"Titled" successfully innovates in a genre that often treads familiar ground. Its gravity-defying mechanics, mind-bending puzzles, and immersive world design create an engaging experience that will keep you coming back for more. The game's unique concept and well-executed gameplay make it a platformer well worth diving into. If you're looking for a fresh take on the genre and enjoy a challenge, "Titled" is a title you won't want to miss.

I have some stuff to comment on here:

- It would be nice if there were more pieces of evidence of them being the killer [spoiler] (other than bloody weapons [Pilot and Civilian] and just telling the AI that they did it [Enginer]) [/spoiler]

[h1]Talking Dirty While Balls are Bouncing on the Screen[/h1]
[b]Hentai Direct-her[/b] is the kind of game you play with low expectations and ends up surprising you because of how fun it is. The game is a Pong clone in which you pick a girl to audition casting couch style (but without the couch) and play against her, hitting some clapper cards that make them moan, talk dirty, or strip. The gameplay is decent and comes with three different difficulties and the option to adjust the ball's speed, allowing you to make the game either a piece of cake or hard as balls. Also, the visuals are pleasing and improve the experience, so give it a shot if you're looking for a fun game to kill some time with.

So you think you're good at pong?? WELL THINK AGAIN, NERD!! This ain't pong! This is legally-distinct pong with boobs jiggling in your face! It's porng! Still think you've got what it takes? Try playing on the hardest difficulty, maximum points, and the fastest ball selected all while trying to score when sultry women moan and talk dirty in your ears and then we'll talk. Think you've got what it takes to last long enough?

[b]TL;DR[/b]
GreatherGames continues to put out some really good quality arcade-style games that add a nice lewd twist to classic games! Overall, I'd say if you're looking for a good way to pass the time and maybe get a bit of naughty fun out of it, this is a real good one to pick up!
+ Neat character descriptions to give you an idea of what to expect from each girls' dirty talk
+ Music is a real bop
+ Supports local co-op ;)
+ Voice acted to funnel that lewdness directly into your ears
+ Dev is receptive to feedback and making changes
+ Game difficulty is customizable, is as easy or difficult as you want it to be
- No real sense of end-game
-----------------------------------------

[h1]--- Overview ---[/h1]
Play legally-distinct non-trademarked pong-style gameplay against five unique girls auditioning to becoming p*rn stars, each with their own character, dirty talk, and personalities in this lewd romp of an arcade game! The more you win, the more girls you unlock until you've unlocked all five girls!

[h1]--- The LEWDS ---[/h1]
I consider this game's lewds to be akin to an appetizer. That's not a bad thing, some of the best food on the planet are appetizers. But if you want to pass the time and feel a bit naughty in the meantime, it's a really great game to go to.

As you play the game, you collect clapper cards that contain a prompt for the girl to do. Whether that be moaning in your ear, saying dirty talk related to their specific kinks, or strip off a random piece of clothing, it really makes concentrating on the game that much more of a challenge. What I find especially awesome is that the stripping off of random clothing means you can get some really nice combinations of top on + bottoms off or bottoms off + top off.

Each of the five currently-available girls have specific kinks that they pander to, whether you're looking for a lewd girl to call you daddy, a domineering mommy, or just plenty of lewd JOI-style comments telling you what to do~.

Sarah best girl, this is not up for debate, she's even the title girl. Game knows she best.

[h1]--- Gameplay Overview ---[/h1]
When selecting your difficulty, you're given three options to choose from, the opponent's AI difficulty, the score you're trying to reach, and how fast the ball goes. In my opinion, the best way to experience the game is with all of these options at their highest level possible! The other options aren't bad by any means, but I really enjoyed the challenge. Even with these options, you can still clear all 5 girls in under an hour.

Something worth noting is that when you score a point, the game doesn't pause, it just continues again immediately. This can (and likely will) cause you to unfairly lose quite a few points as the ball immediately goes through your goal or you just can't react in time for it. On the other hand, the same thing can happen to your opponent as well. It would have been much more intuitive to click to start the round again.

You can also play with local co-op if you've got someone irl to play with you, allowing for mouse controls for one person and keyboard controls for another! I did mess around with this a tiny bit by myself and it seemed to work pretty well, though I can't say I'm brave enough to ask someone irl to help with more thorough testing.

As it is, your Reputation is entirely based on how many points you score. Whether that means you set up a fake 2-person game to ensure you unlock the girls as fast as possible (but sacrifice the lewd content for whatever reason) or decide to have some *real* fun by playing Hard -> 7 points -> Fast for the ultimate experience, the actual difficulty of the game is entirely yours to decide.

[h1]--- Issues / Bugs ---[/h1]
¬∑ Can't hit ESC to pause the game while playing, have to click the top right icon (meaning, basically don't try to pause unless you just want to go back to the menu)

[h1]--- Final Thoughts ---[/h1]
A very fun, albeit short, lewd arcade game (roughly under an hour of game time)! I'm honestly surprised I haven't seen a game like it before on Steam but it's a welcome addition! The developer is also very receptive to feedback and does his best to accommodate any changes they feel is worth it, which automatically puts this game above most of the cash-grab uncaring devs you've got in this genre of Steam games. It's definitely worth a grab for some raunchy arcade-y pong-like fun!

"Hentai Direct-Her" is a naughty Pong clone. The idea is for you to direct the girl via aiming your ball to strike the clapperboards and, at the same time, score your opponent to take the point. You collect points to unlock more girls but also to strip your current girl. The clapperboards have different functions, you can make the girls talk dirty, strip and moan.

There are 5 different girls, fully voiced. The music is upbeat since you are in a match! You can pick between 3 difficulty levels, 3 score points needed to finish the match and 3 ball speeds. None of them matter to the score, you get 1 point for every goal regardless of anything else.

It's a welcomed naughty change of a classic game. For this price, it's worth it!

Nice distraction, but repetitive gameplay and resource scavenging aren't very exciting.

The game has two modes. There's survival, in which you look for gear, improve, and gradually progress throughout the entire landscape. This might be called the primary mode. Horde mode is more action-oriented, with adversaries constantly attacking you. Both modes can be played at any of five difficulty levels. 

Don't worry if you don't enjoy survival components. Despite the name, the game does not include any. The only thing you have to worry about is energy. Lack of energy results in slower stamina restoration. This is easily addressed when you sleep in a bed. Sleeping also gives you a momentary perk. 

The controls are typical for a first-person shooter. You roam around, shoot zombies, gather anything you can find, and simply try to survive. Healing isn't automatic, so keep an eye out for two types of bandages and two types of shield kits to replenish your shield. 

New weapons are uncovered is supply rooms. There's a good selection, but you can only take three at a time. Another interesting element is the weapon and equipment upgrades that can be found flying around. They are divided into four tiers, with the legendary being the finest, boosting every single stat of a weapon. Using lower tier upgrades might be a waste of resources because one single legendary is all you need too fully boost a weapon. 

When you go to a workbench, which is always available at supply locations, you can upgrade or make new items. You can also swap any weapon you've discovered. Grabbing every valuable resource is critical because it allows you to build ammo and even upgrades. Resources can be located in containers like purses and briefcases. This is a bit of a pain because they're difficult to see in the environment and there's no visible cue on the screen to direct you to one. 

The map is open.  It‚Äôs not very huge, but it allows you to search a few buildings for resources. The city is divided into four sectors that you can win by surviving waves. If you survive, a new supply rooms opens where you can stock up for the next switch. Zombies are not smart because they come at you in a straight line. Most of the times you can take out an entire wave by moving backwards while shooting forward. It‚Äôs also quite challenging because it‚Äôs easy to get stuck in the environment. Once you‚Äôre surrounded, you‚Äôre practically dead.

You can build traps and repair explosive barrels, but you will waste resources that could be used for weapons and crafting. Since resources are limited, you can't afford to create just everything.
Very casual shut your brain off and play kinda game. It's been fun to play so far. Simple mechanics, simple game play, L4D level basic. Would love to see more get added to the game and see it grow.

It is with a heavy heart that I give a negative review. I like the story, but the level of English is inferior. The game has a small amount of animations and they look good. But, a very large part of the time you have to look at a static view that doesn't match the story and this is bad game design! The game isn't unplayable, but it's a rather clumsy piece of work.

Wow, the animations are messed up and almost non-existant, the dialogue doesn't come close to matching the activity and there are obvious and glaring errors in continuity during individual scenes.. This is an absolute bare bones effort, made worse by terrifyingly poor English and it comes across like it was written by a 12 year old. This is so bad

Reviewed on: 2024/06/08
Score: 2/10, only because it's a finished game.
Playtime: About 6 hours for a single playthrough, much more if you're a completionist and are [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3263603160]stuck guessing the effects of choices[/url], and haven't [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3263536065]unlocked text-skipping[/url].

[h3]TL;DR:[/h3]
In all honesty, I'm having trouble finding words to describe this AVN that wouldn't insult the dev. So, instead of a TL;DR, I'll just let the game speak for itself (verbatim, except spoiler tag):
[i]"He wasted no time flipping [spoiler]Courtney[/spoiler] around and sliding his dick into her ass and ready to fuck it like he had never done before. [Player] got the lube he had as you need lube to put it in anyone's ass. As he sldie the lubed cock in her ass slowly"[/i]

[h3]Gameplay:[/h3]
Dialog choices will change how Love Interests view the MC, but the effect of the player's answers aren't shown. Worse, most choices only affect the single line the MC says, with the other character always having the same reply/reaction. The dev has also disabled the ability of the player to skip seen and unseen text.
This is player unfriendly design. You not only have to guess what each LI likes (if you care), but also have to keep clicking to skip text when replaying and trying different paths.  Luckily, the number of points needed to get the "good" ending is low, and players can luck in to it.
The game is divided in a prologue and 21 days, with a single-choice freeroam section dividing them. From reading the code, I get the sense that the dev's original plan was a lot bigger, with the MC having a stamina stat (limited amounts of actions per day). In this version, the freeroam's only use is to make the player navigate to a specific LI's room, to do that day's event.

[h3]Adult:[/h3]
There are a few renders of naked women, and lots of text describing what they and the MC do with each other.  The main theme of the game (I think) is about dealing with grief, unresolved conflict, and coming to term with past mistakes.

[h3]Visual[/h3]:
During dialog, cutouts of characters are placed on top of a blurred background, slyly looking straight at the camera while talking to each other.
These cutouts will move their mouth while talking, and will sometimes change their facial expression, but that's it.  They won't change their posture or move their limbs.
This background doesn't change often enough either. Text describes how the MC visits a different location, or takes part in certain activities, without it being shown.
Seeing how text-heavy this game is, this design seems like the bare minimum, if that.

Lewd scenes get special treatment. Bodies are actually posed, and one or two renders show the gist of what's going on. These renders are also accompanied by a lot of text, describing things we never get to see, usually foreplay and climaxes.
Some lewd scenes have a short animation. Sadly, I can't be very positive about these either. For instance, in the animations with Cheerleader and Lawyer, we'll see the MC thrusting, but his penis just remains static (as in, not going in & out).  The animations also look as if they're cut together by playing a shorter animation in forward and reverse, then repeating this segment a few times.
Looking at some animations side by side, it's obvious the dev saved time by re-using the same scenes and animations, only replacing the LI's model.
Some animations are outright nauseating, like the anal scene with [spoiler]Courtney[/spoiler], with the camera bobbing in an X-shaped motion as if it's the bouncing logo meme.

[h3]Sound:[/h3]
There are no sound effects or voices/sex-sounds, yet the volume sliders are present for them.
The game has music, with scenes have their own track. These tracks usually contain lyrics and are fairly high energy, often not matching the atmosphere of what's happening on the screen.
Personally, I find this type of music distracting while reading and viewing.

[h3]Novel:[/h3]
This game's writing is unlike anything I've ever seen, and not in a good way.
Example: [i]"They make out with their naked bodies together with [Player]'s dick getting hard and so big. cheerleader is surprised he is so big."[/i]
Or, how about: [i]"Cheerleader kisses him passionately and they put each other's hands all over their hot bodies. She takes his dick into her mouth and begins to suck on it. It tastes salty and feels warm as his cock hits the back of her throat. she deepthroats it several times"[/i]

This isn't a translation issue. Even a machine translation would be better if the writer mastered their native language.  Huge amounts of typos and spelling mistakes also betray the fact that the writer did write these lines, and not pasted them in from an external tool.

It's not only the quality of the writing that's bad, there is no common-sense progression to the story.
A certain LI will tell us she slept with her teacher to get good grades, later, we learn she was sexually active for years before the MC arrived. The MC also has penetrative sex with her, and somehow, a few days later, he'll feel her hymen break during another romp.  And, to top it all off, at the end of the game we'll learn that [spoiler]the MC's dad had sex with all LI for years.[/spoiler].
By telling the story about the MC and his father in a segmented and sometimes anachronistic way, it becomes even more difficult to understand.

During my first playthrough, I thought that the pacing of the growing intimacy was relatively well done. However, on the playthrough where I made negative choices, everything still happened the same way, except for the ending.  This is too bad. If LIs would actually react differently toward the MC based on his behavior toward them, at least the game would've had this going for it.

[h3]Conclusion:[/h3]
Despite my negative review, I do respect the dev for publishing a finished game, I think Dad would be proud.  It's far from perfect, but the basics are there. Story concept, thousands of words, structure, renders, animations, ... It's clear some shortcuts were taken, and maybe playtesters didn't provide actionable feedback.
I hope the dev keeps at it and hones his skills, starting by polishing this game a bit more before starting on Episode 2.
For now though, avoid this game.

IFoundO.

UFindO is a short find-the-difference puzzle game. The game houses 10 levels with each 20 differences between them. As the time you take to find the differences increase, so decreases your score. Need help finding some? You can use the Hint option for a 1000 point reduction. If your score reaches 0 you lose.

The hard drawn pictures have a certain charm to it. The game runs smooth and will take about 30 minutes to an hour to complete. There are two down sides though;
-No sound option.
-A few hitboxes are very very small.

All with all the game isn't bad for the price they ask.

Taking this shovelware seriously as if it was a genuine attempt to make a game, it doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

The artwork here is terrible, it's all just amateurish "My First Wacom Tablet" style drawings used instead professional looking game assets.  It's unclear if this is due to lack of budget to arrange someone who can create graphical assets properly, or lack of talent, regardless, the overall visual quality of the game is extremely low, enough on its own to deter gamers.

The controls can't be customised because the game has such a dumbed down, simplified interface that it's just point and click stuff like a browser/Flash game.  The fact that the interface is this dumbed down might be seen as a problem in itself, however... this is a fairly shallow experience if you're the kind of gamer that likes to play games with deep, rich control schemes and interaction.  You'll get none of that here.

For gameplay purposes, because the user interface for this game is mostly just 2D static text/images... it might as well be a web page.  It's functionally no different from a browser game.  And we all know, Steam isn't here to compete with Chrome and Firefox.  If the game can be done in a web browser, it's just not rich or compelling enough to appeal to serious gamers on PC.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

The poor quality of this game is reflected by how many people spent time with it.  At the time of this review, SteamDB shows the all-time peak player number was only 2 players.  This is a remarkably low number, and now, the only player activity occurs once or twice a month, presumably someone loading it up to see what it is then quickly uninstalling it.  Considering there's over 120 million gamers on Steam and well over 100,000 games for gamers to choose from, the overwhelming lack of interest in this low quality game is to be expected.

It's also important to note the "developer" here has connections to a number of shady Russian asset flippers and review manipulators who show an organised pattern to scam and defraud gamers with fake reviews and asset flipping the work of others for profit.  While reviews are about the games, gamers should be informed when developers act unethically.   Whether these connections are the same developer using multiple accounts, or just working closely with other unethical developers, gamers should be warned about the harm to gamers by this developer and their associates.  Buying games from unethical developers puts your money at risk.

So, should you buy this game?  Is this one of the best of the 100,000+ games on Steam?

UFindO is relatively cheap at $1 USD, but it's not worth it. Given the defects and quality issues with the game, coupled with the unrealistic price, and the questionable ethical nature of the developer and/or their associates (as outlined above), this is impossible to recommend.  This is also competing with over 11,000 free games available on Steam, many of them far better than this paid product.

Dreamsweeper is a fun puzzle game that combines a roguelike minesweeper puzzle with battling monsters through a rhythm game. You'll keep descending floors to the next puzzle and the next and the next. The type of enemies that walk around are based on which of the 4 worlds you're playing. You'll unlock a new world after completing a world, which also opens up endless mode on the previous world. The monsters in later worlds felt harder, but that might also be because their timing is less forgiving than the purple attack the enemies in the first world do. 

It feels like the main character walks a little slow, but this seems to be on purpose because you don't want to set a step too far while working out a puzzle. Another thing that I noticed only very late is that while you can have 3 heads with you, you can only wear one, and that one is which buff you currently have. While typing this.. it makes sense.. it is a hat.. we don't wear stacks full of heads. However, with the design in the game and the shop selling always 3 heads, it wasn't so clear to me before. 

Dreamsweeper has a bunch of nice achievements. Most of them aren't hard and you'll unlock them just for playing the game. There are achievements for playing the puzzles and battles on the highest difficulty. I don't recommend combining those but just do them one by one. As the battles are way longer and the floors are way bigger in both cases. Finding the treasure room requires some luck. You have a chance to find it each time you change floors. The developer just increased the spawn frequency so it shouldn't be too hard to find it while going for the rest of the achievements. 

I give Dreamsweeper 3 out of 5 stars.

Despite slight grind and repetitive play to unlock new stages, minesweeper mechanics are fun enough to get you to the ending.

Your objective is to reach the exit stairs by walking across tiles and avoiding black holes. Gameplay is easy because you only need to take steps across the floor and mark risky tiles. This is accomplished by utilizing minesweeper mechanisms. As you walk, you will either expose multiple tiles because you walked on an empty tile, or a number tile that indicates how many black tiles surround you.

Most are situated right on the path you need to walk on, so you can flag them and make them harmless. If you make a mistake and tread on one, you will lose one of your three hearts. When you lose them all, you will wake up in your room and be forced to restart the entire stage. 

Rhythm plays a role during enemy confrontations. All you have to do is watch for arrows and press the button when one lands on one of the four markers. Projectiles come in a variety of types, and some can even heal you or force you to press the opposite button, but precision is not essential. The only difference between "bad" and "perfect" is how much damage you cause. 

Your skill level, or lack thereof, is not an issue because the game may be tailored to your preference. Aside from the overall difficulty, which increases the quantity of bombs and room size, you can also adjust the rhythm difficulty, which may be appropriate for people who are not as quick. 

Flagging all holes each floor and defeating enemies will earn you the game's cash. This can be used in a shop to purchase one-time items that make life easier. Some of them are keys that unlock chests containing additional money and books that restore a heart. While objects are designed to solve the classic minesweeper problem, this does not always work. There are still too many occasions where you must guess which tiles are safe. This becomes brutally obvious at the highest difficulty level, resulting in impossible scenarios and forcing you to rely on luck.  

This feature isn‚Äôt very useful because you can find a lot of items all over the stage. Although you can only carry two goods, this is not a major issue because they do not disappear. Accessories are another aspect that is not really useful. While you can only have one equipped, you can fast switch between them to use their effect. Accessories are more like modifiers in that they can make things simpler or harder; for example, you can add or remove an extra heart. 

Stages are random, so you can be lucky and locate an exit right away. However, you will still have to clear a few rooms because exits are frequently sealed and require a particular number of stars (a star is awarded for defeating all enemies in an area or flagging all tiles). One annoying bug is that the game changes from full screen to window mode each time you play a new stage. You either have to press Alt-Enter each time, or simply play in window mode.

You are encouraged to clear as many tiles as possible in order to earn rewards. The better you do, the more you will fill the bar, which unlocks new furniture for your room, music, new items that may come in the game, and, most importantly, next worlds.

The game consists of four worlds, with each new world increasing the amount of stages required to complete a world. The reward is a dream sequence that offers more information on the entire story, as well as the world's infinity mode, which allows you to play for as long as you wish or until you run out of hearts.

The grind to open new worlds is the only criticism. Beating a world doesn‚Äôt give you enough, so you need to play the infinity mode. Luckily, you can play at the lowest difficulty and quickly clear a floor.

A super chill and relaxing twist on minesweeper, fairly true to the original. If you like minesweeper then you will like this game, it's that simple.

There are a few day one bugs that make the game annoying right now, but the devs have said they are actively working on ironing them out. In addition, there are a couple of QoL features that veteran minesweepers might want to see added in the future, but this is a relatively minor nitpick.

The rhythm mechanic seems a bit out of left field when paired with minesweeper, but it doesn't feel bad at all and adds some speed in an otherwise very calm and slow game.

Much like how minesweeper is best played while on a bus or on the toilet, this game would do very well on a mobile platform like Nintendo Switch (another thing the devs have said they will work on), so look forward to that.

DreamSweeper is a really fun game that takes the old MineSweeper game and turns it into an adventure. I like the game because it has cool power-ups and the tougher levels make you think.  It's also cool that you have to use your timing skills to take down the bosses.  I also really enjoy the music and the game play makes things fun.  Two thumbs up.

In Dreamsweeper, you play as a girl who falls asleep listening to music each night, only to awaken in a mysterious dream world where she must confront her deepest fears and anxieties. The game's narrative is simple, and the dreamy setting adds a touch of surrealism that makes the player's journey all the more entertaining.

Dreamsweeper's gameplay is a seamless blend of various genres, primarily focusing on dungeon crawling, roguelike elements, and Minesweeper-inspired puzzle mechanics. As you explore the procedurally generated dream worlds, you'll encounter Minesweeper-like rooms that require logic and deduction to navigate. Each step you take carries risks, and successfully clearing blocks will provide numerical hints to help you locate hidden dangers.

To combat the menacing enemies representing the protagonist's anxieties, the game employs rhythm-based mechanics that require precise timing and focus. The fusion of these diverse gameplay elements creates a truly unique experience that keeps players engaged and challenged throughout their adventure.

You can customize your gameplay experience with a range of accessories, adapt to different challenges, and uncover hidden collectibles throughout the dream world. Visit in-game shops to purchase items and accessories to enhance your journey. For the truly daring, an infinite mode provides a thrilling challenge to test your skills and experiment with new strategies.  

One of Dreamsweeper's most defining features is its distinct lo-fi musical aesthetic, which complements the dreamy atmosphere perfectly. The game's visuals are charming and whimsical, bringing the fantastical dream world to life with vibrant colors and imaginative designs. The music is an integral part of the gameplay experience, providing a soothing backdrop to the tense moments of puzzle-solving and combat.

In conclusion,  Dreamsweeper is a one-of-a-kind gaming experience that successfully combines elements of dungeon crawling, roguelike, and Minesweeper, all set to an enchanting lo-fi musical backdrop. With its imaginative setting, and captivating presentation, this game offers a truly memorable adventure that's not to be missed. Whether you're a fan of puzzles, roguelikes, or just looking for a unique indie gem, Dreamsweeper is definitely worth your time and attention.

The game's style is another highlight. It looks fantastic and has this great blend of old-school charm with modern flair. The concept is like a next-level Minesweeper, taking something familiar and making it way more interesting and fun.

What truly stands out is the story and adventure elements, which are top-notch. There's a sense of unfolding excitement that keeps you hooked as you play. The controls might seem a bit tricky at first, but they start to make a lot of sense once you get the hang of them.

Dreamsweeper combines all these elements perfectly. If you're looking for a game that's visually appealing, has a great story, and offers a fresh take on a classic concept, this is definitely worth downloading.

Nice cozy game. It feels right at home on the Steam Deck and runs perfectly. 

I found it to be a bit too easy when playing on the default difficulty setting (at least in the first world), which feels strange to say about something clearly meant to be relaxing, but luckily there are multiple difficulty sliders that can be adjusted separately to get the game to your liking (do you want harder/easier tap timing mini games or harder/easier minesweeping?).

I've only played a few levels so far, but I'm hooked! It combines a bunch of my favorite game genres - puzzle game meets rhythm game meets dungeon crawler roguelike! Time flies while playing this game. The puzzles and traversal are stimulating while the environment and music are soft and soothing. Really well done :)
Very nice aesthetics in this game. The graphics are very delicate and the music is simply sublime. Simple, but very effective gameplay.

A soothing way to ease your mind while also getting a mental workout with the steady puzzles. Fun for all ages with one heck of a sleepy laid-back soundtrack.

[h1]A traditional VS like experience[/h1]

Nyran Survivors is a traditional VS like, which while enjoyable, doesn‚Äôt bring anything new to the table. Personally, I enjoyed the art style, along with how balanced everything felt. While I do enjoy overpowered skills, I eventually end up following the same build, ruining my experience.

My experience with Nyran Survivors was good, however, there wasn‚Äôt enough to keep me going. The dopamine hit I feel in other VS likes wasn‚Äôt felt here and I‚Äôm not sure why. It could be due to the lack of flashy skills which feel overpowered, or what felt like a slower pace gameplay experience.

Ultimately, it‚Äôs not a bad game and I do recommend it to those who like the genre. If you‚Äôre expecting a fresh experience however, I‚Äôd look elsewhere. Nyran Survivors follows the formula to a T without innovating in any meaningful or notable way.

Nyran Survivors is a roguelite game. Is the classic survivors like in 3D, there isn't much inovation in comparation with other survivors like but it's well designed and balanced with a big variety of skills classes and builds so it's fun with high replay value.
Doesn't really bring much new to the table, but that isn't a bad thing. It's a solid vampire survivors-like that's worth the 7 bucks :).

Definitely gives you a decent amount of fun and play time for its cost, I would say it's a unique take on the "horde survivor" genre to an extent, both graphically and mechanically.

One con, or maybe even pro for some, in comparison to other games is the lack of automatic aiming or aiming at nearest enemy, a lot of abilities are cursor aim focused which can also be what distinguishes it from a lot of the other games in the genre.

The game also has a dodge mechanic I haven't seen in most other horde survivors, this uses space and essentially allows you to skillfully get a short moment of immortality, useful for facing bosses and what not.

It seems like the game does have some degree of AFK capability by focusing majorly on blocking and healing upgrades, initially this was not that intuitive to me and it was a thing I was missing for a while early on, in comparison to other games in the genre.

Very enjoyable game overall.

Very good for casual gaming, jump in and out for a quick session, which is what I prefer for this genre of game. Also has a leader board for those which are more competitive to rank your score vs others if you like that type of thing.

Different classes are available for all play styles which includes level and characters unlocks - good for people who like 'progressing' and levelling up etc. Fun type graphics that don't take itself too seriously but work well.

For the price you are paying you can't go wrong really at this price point - even if your not much of a fan of the genre itself. Its great to pass any idle time you may have - regardless if you have a short amount of free time available or alternatively prefer a longer game, both in fact do work with this game regardless.

Not innovative, but fun and well-priced.

Would recommend.

[i]Lighthouse Simulator[/i] - the ultimate tool for those who should be doing something else! Why settle for boring fireplace and aquarium screensavers when you can admire a majestic lighthouse on a tiny rocky island instead? Adjust the weather and swell at any time, choosing between the gentle breeze that accompanies you as you tidy up or do the dishes, or the wild storm that reminds you of your unanswered mails.

As the hours pass and day and night alternate, complete relaxation unfolds in your body and mind. After all, who needs sleep or rest when the mesmerizing effect of a virtual lighthouse ensnares the senses? Zooming in is not possible, instead you can scroll freely around the lighthouse while wondering why you stopped cleaning the house.

After ten days, your digital girlfriend arrives on the island. At the foot of the lighthouse, she opens up a new dimension of love that silences even the ocean waves. Nevertheless, this unexpected twist makes [i]Lighthouse Simulator[/i] seem a bit like a confused sailor in search of his compass: A short animated sex clip is shown before the game continues endlessly without the flame of passion blazing once more.

This program will make your dream of a windswept island come true while you sort through your sock drawer. The apartment just feels a little more maritime when the glow of the lighthouse gently wanders over freshly laundered, fragrant sheets. Experience the roaring sea, the screeching of seagulls, the everlasting alternation of sunshine and dark.

[b]And they said that the easiest way to get chicks was to give them flowers and chocolates, the real key is to lock them in dungeons and let the monsters ‚Äúprepare‚Äù them for you. [/b]

[h1] Review [/h1]

[h2]‚úíÔ∏è Overview [/h2]
Dungeon ‚àû Create is a quite short game (shorter than one hour) that tries to mix a tower defense with dungeons, monsters and sex to create a solid gameplay, but which unfortunately disappoints you, limiting this ‚Äú gameplay ‚Äù to only one strategy that always wins out over the others. Although it has good art and uncensored sex scenes (if you download the external patch), it does not end up being entertaining or exciting at all.

[h3]üìú Story[/h3] 
The story is totally focused on the introduction of the game, telling you how the main character, a person who was sent to an isekai at the request (obligation) of a succubus, ends up as the master of a dungeon. In which he has to manage, distribute traps, place monsters, etc. And the only dialog or lines of text there are during the game are congratulatory sentences from the succubus to the main character for overcoming the "hordes of adventurers" and little introductions to the girls the MC has kidnapped for sex. And that is basically the whole story, with no plot to follow and just random dialog, without even an ending, as it ends subtly.

[h3]üéÆ Gameplay[/h3] 
This section should be one of the most remarkable, since in theory the game is about designing a dungeon as strong as possible so that the adventurers do not pass, where you place poison traps, spikes or a variety of enemies such as goblins, demons, bats, minotaur, etc. In the style of a tower defense game. In addition to this, there is also the possibility to unlock new paths for the adventurers to deviate and take them more time to overcome, thus trying to expand the "complexity" of the title. But unfortunately, all these mechanics end up being useless because the game is not balanced at all and to overcome "ALL" levels you simply place a goblin at the entrance of the dungeon and spend all the upgrade points to level up this goblin, making it practically invincible, eliminating any strategic or playable element, reducing everything to pressing the Ctrl key to see how you "overcome" the levels.

[h2]üîûSexual content[/h2]
[h3]* You need to install the external patch from the official publisher 072 project store.[/h3]
The game has only 3 sex scenes, these have no censorship, so you can see the genitals of the girls clearly, besides the art quality of these scenes is good. The scenes also have decent quality motion animation, but no voice acting or SFX.
In terms of genres or fetishes, they are all non-consensual sex, with loss of virginity and big breasts. Since there are so few of them, there is very little variety and it is difficult to satisfy all tastes.
The game has a scene gallery, so once you have unlocked a scene, you can always watch it again.

[h2]üí≠Conclusion[/h2]
I know that the game tells you that it will be short, plus its price of 3 dollars is not very high, so if it was well done it would be a decent recommendation, but the problem is that it is not, you can break the playable system very easily due to the little balancing of the units, it takes away all the sense to the game and makes it boring to play, besides that it is totally repetitive, the game also has some bugs, such as freezes when you kill a monster, or that sometimes the life of some monsters increases instead of decreasing, making the game even easier to overcome. As for the sexual content, it is not bad, but the number of scenes is very low, at least double the number of scenes would be adequate for the price of the game and the last thing I dislike the most about the game is its "ending", since it basically tells you that you will not get any more sexual events, but you can continue "playing", making it seem like an incomplete game, with this anticlimactic ending.
I really can't recommend to buy this game, because even for 3 dollars it's not worth it, if they fix the game solving the bugs and balancing the units, only in that case you could consider buying this game, or also if you see it at a price even more reduced like 1 dollar or dollar and a half, otherwise a hard pass, there are better games for this price, even games from the same developer.

I thought the game had an interesting concept. However there is too much randomness to the whole thing and it really encourages reloading saves. Example a weak enemy gives 300 DP, then a strong enemy gives 50. You also can't load saves until after the enemy dies, so if you get an unlucky 2k hp opponent in round 4 you just have to wait for them to kill you to reload the save. Enemy HP is completely random and the DP they reward is so I ended up saving after every round and reloading until I got something that didn't kill half my creatures and awarded a decent amount of DP. 20 rounds in, not a single girl yet on another run I got the first girl at like round 5.

If you download the adult patch it seems that it changes the dialogue entirely to Japanese. Cannot read anything that is happening and the UI is in Japanese. Unless there is a known fix to this, I found that having the patch ruined being able to play the game.

[td]"Dungeon ‚àû Create" places players in the role of an unsuspecting protagonist who wakes up in a mysterious cave and is thrust into the role of dungeon master. [table]

[th]üéÆ[b]Gameplay:[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
Take on the role of a dungeon master and strategically defend your dungeon from waves of adventurers. Utilize various traps and monsters to thwart their attempts to reach the dungeon core. As you defeat enemies, earn DP points to upgrade your defenses and unlock new units.

The gameplay emphasizes strategy and planning, with a focus on placing traps and managing resources effectively. Each defeated female adventurer rewards players with a unique sex scene, adding an explicit layer to the game.

üîß [b]Strategic Defense:[/b] Place traps and monsters to create an effective defense strategy.

üí∞ [b]Resource Management:[/b] Earn DP points to upgrade defenses and unlock new units.

üé® [b]Explicit Content:[/b] Defeat female adventurers to unlock sex scenes, adding mature themes to the gameplay.

üîÑ [b]Replay Value:[/b] Experiment with different strategies and approaches to optimize your dungeon defenses.

Despite its strategic depth, the game is relatively short and can be completed in a few hours. However, the inclusion of multiple units and upgrades encourages players to refine their strategies and replay the game for a more optimized experience.
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[th]üìñ[b]Story and Depth:[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
The protagonist wakes up in a cavern, greeted by a lazy fallen angel who declares him the new master of a dungeon. Tasked with building and managing the dungeon, the protagonist must defend against adventurers seeking to plunder its treasures. The narrative unfolds through interactions with the fallen angel and various adventurers, each with their own motivations and backgrounds.

The story is straightforward, focusing on the protagonist's journey to become a competent dungeon master while dealing with the mischievous fallen angel. The game incorporates mature themes, adding an erotic twist to the narrative as players unlock explicit scenes by defeating female adventurers.

Character interactions are minimal but provide context to the dungeon management and defense gameplay. The fallen angel serves as a guide and occasional antagonist, adding humor and personality to the story. The adventurers, while not deeply developed, offer varied challenges and rewards, keeping the gameplay engaging.
[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
[th]üèÜ[b]Verdict:[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]
"Dungeon ‚àû Create" is an engaging tower defense RPG that excels in strategic gameplay and features mature themes. Despite its limited number of explicit scenes and some minor technical issues, it offers a visually pleasing experience with high-quality CGs and semi-animated sequences. Nikukyu's distinctive art style adds a unique charm, making the game appealing to fans of their work.

For enthusiasts of similar titles like "Dungeon's Legion", "Suzukuri Dungeon: Karin in the Mountain", or "Two Months of Devil King", the content may seem sparse, especially in terms of erotic scenes. However, the game provides enough challenge and entertainment to keep players engaged for several hours. Considering its more than affordable price, "Dungeon ‚àû Create" offers excellent value and is a worthy addition to any tower defense lover's collection.

In summary, "Dungeon ‚àû Create" is recommended for its strategic depth, appealing art style, and unique blend of tower defense mechanics with mature themes. It provides a short yet enjoyable experience, especially at such a low price, perfect for fans of the genre.

[b]Dungeon ‚àû Create[/b] is a short puzzle game in which the protagonist is set up by a lazy succubus to manage a dungeon's defenses so she can feast on their energy without lifting a finger. The gameplay is decent and consists of setting up traps and monsters that keep those pesky adventurers away from stealing the dungeon's core and capturing the few female warriors who get inside the dungeon. Moreover, beating each foe rewards you with DP points you spend on more traps and units or leveling up your monsters, and you get a sex scene if you defeat any of the three female enemies that come to the dungeon.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3292059075
Visuals-wise, the game shares the same detailed and polished art other Nikukyu's games like [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Nikkunamesu/recommended/2395680/]Unyielding Succubus Princess of Arrogance[/url] and [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Nikkunamesu/recommended/2499670/]Idol Cultivation Process: Unspoken Rules ‚òÖ„Éü[/url] have. However, the sex scenes are very few, given that each female adventurer only has one scene.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3292059088
[b]Dungeon ‚àû Create[/b] also has a few issues here and there that impact the experience, such as the slime's stats not showing up properly or losing your newest units when you lose after beating the first female adventurer. Still, it's a decent game to get at a discount and play whenever you have a few minutes to spare.

I'd always been a fan of the slide puzzles from the Legendary Mahjong games, so it's nice to see the game mode release in its own title with over 90 new puzzles to work through. And let me tell ya, the puzzles ain't messin' around this time. The difficulty has significantly increased, but so has the tedium of slowly working through each board. Still, clearing each stage feels like an achievement when you've been boggling over just how in the heck you're going to avoid getting pieces stuck over and over again. Fortunately, if you're TOO stuck, video walkthroughs are available in the game itself to help you through, but I prefer to puzzle them out myself. That said, puzzle fans will definitely want to check this one out. But if you're looking for something a little more casual, the Legendary Mahjong games may be a better option for ya.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3025567325

Looking at my Post Office Box in front of my Lair.
Oh, HH-GAMES visited me again.
What have we got here?
Another LEGENDARY Game!
Very nice, i love those Series.

So welcome to LEGENDARY SLIDE!

Do you know LEGENDARY MAHJONG 1 and 2?
Yes? Then you will feel very, VERY familar with this Game.
Because it felt a little bit like it is fallen out LEGENDARY PART 2.
You don¬¥t know them? Okay then follow me.

LEGENDARY SLIDE is a Mahjong Game. 
In Mahjong you have to make Pairs to solve them.
Normally you click on both ones and they vanished.
Here it is different.
Here you have to move them to side by side to solve them.
Sounds easy? Oh no it isn¬¥t.
What easy starts, will get harder and harder because of obstacles and other things.
It is not just moving, it is also thinking and sometimes you are stucked.
But don¬¥t panic, every Level has also a Video Guide, if needed.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3032792940

Solving over 90 Levels will give you points to raise your Character in Ranks, what will give more motivation.
There is not really a big Story, just save the Temple of Air.
The Graphics are very nice, the Gameplay is wonderfull fluid and the music is amazing ...... again.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3032792701 

Well LEGENDARY SLIDE feels like ... no IS exactly like LEGENDARY MAHJONG 2 (LM2). While LM2 got 7 Game Modes,
LEGENDARY SLIDE is one of them. It may be a little bit confusing because here on Steam LEGENDARY SLIDE came out after LM2.
You should know that this Game came out in 2017 and LM2 in 2022 if i remember right, so LEGENDARY SLIDE is not a half Game, LM2 
is the new upgraded Version of it with much more Game Modes, which i HIGHLY recommend, because for me it is the best Mahjong out there.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3032793145

So, yes! I recommend LEGENDARY SLIDE because the Game Mode is pure Fun. I love the Levels and i took my Time beating them, not using 
the Video Guides. The Price is absolutly okay for the Playtime and Fun you get. 

Thanks again, dear Dev, i really love this Game.
Hope to see more in the Future.

And thank YOU for reading.

[b]legendary slide[/b] is a mahjong-based sliding game from 2016. gotta move individual pieces around until they can meet, match and disappear. it's just like [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/dohi64/recommended/1070250/]notes[/url] or [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/dohi64/recommended/1501090]yin yang[/url] on steam but there are probably other examples that escape me at the moment.

[b]93 levels[/b] unlocked one by one, divided into numerous packs within numerous packs. optional animated [b]tutorials[/b] teach the rules over and over, as the same one plays before every single level. can be turned off but then you might miss new info later. because of course there are [b]various mechanics[/b], not always explained, so I guess you won't be missing anything. not a huge deal, leaves something to find out for yourself. ice tiles are static, sand disappears if conditions are met, locks need keys, there are portals, arrow tiles, 'hidden' ones that need clicking to reveal for a second what they are, etc.

controls are mouse-based, work as they should, esc brings up the pause menu, no other hotkeys. [b]no timer or move limit[/b], just a [b]3-star rating system[/b] based on the number of matches. remove everything for a perfect rating but [b]the final pair to finish the level with only gets revealed (randomly from the remaining tiles) after reaching 2 stars, so it's impossible to finish any level with a single star[/b]. what's the point of the whole system then?

there's a counter for remaining tiles and a toggle to show movable ones. [b]what's missing is a next level button[/b] on the level complete screen, continue just drops you back at level select where there aren't level previews or numbers, so that isn't done well either.

so far so good enough but [b]no undo in a sliding game is a total dealbreaker[/b], made even worse here by [b]no reset button[/b] either. have to bring up the menu and do it there, then wait a bit until things slowly reset.

since it's the [b]platinum edition[/b], not only does it come with more levels (only 84 in the butchered version on big fish), but [b]video solutions are available for every stage[/b], turning a 100 mb game into 1 gb. there's a seek bar and pause button, good stuff, but [b]since the final tiles are randomly chosen, the solution might not work 100%[/b], e.g. if it shows to match 2 tiles next that became finishers in your game. the walkthrough selection screen has layout previews and level numbers at least, and [i]that[/i] has a dedicated button on the ui while playing too. there are possibly other extras, unlocked after completing the main levels, which I didn't bother with the way the game works.

it [b]looks exactly like the developer's other mahjong titles[/b], same menus, ui, tiles, everything. possibly the same audio as well, can't confirm that. customization options are pretty good though, backgrounds, tilesets, tile shapes and colors. separate volume sliders, game cursor and windowed mode make up the settings, available anytime, plus there are player profiles.

would be a fine little game despite all the recycled assets (just look at [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/701290/]legendary mahjong[/url], which also has slide levels that may or may not differ from the ones here, lots more content for about the same price), but as said above, [b]no undo means it can't be recommended[/b]. bummer.

Puzzle mahjong + unique + 90+ levels = A challenging and fun experience. Slide the pieces so that you can match each pair. Various stage setups and mechanics to increase difficulty.

[h1]While the homage to [b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/246900/Viscera_Cleanup_Detail/]Viscera Cleanup Detail[/url][/b] is very clean cut, this is an excellent example of taking a genre and advancing it to the next level[/h1]

While being a single player experience and thereby skipping out on the potential shenanigans and tomfoolery available in it's inspirational granddaddy game, the depth added via the storyline mode and what clearly will be a series of connected experiences couples wonderfully with all the gadgets available to you.

For those of you criminally unaware of [b]Viscera[/b], the premise there was you are a cleaner tasked with removing the detritis left behind after a [i]Computer Game Hero[/i] blows through a level (Doom, Shadow Warrior, etc.). In this world, you are a contract cleaner for the shady. Think Mob hits that need to not be known to have happened.
[list]
[*] The method of tool usage are excellent. Very intuitive and neat, with no annoying hassles.
[*] Location(s) are very cool, with detailed realism and immersion
[*] Voice acting and plotline (from what we see) are top tier
[*] The "moreish" aspect is immediate. While the Demo/Prologue is just the right length to expose you to things, it does leave you wanting a bit more!
[/list]

All in all, a complete mini game as a demo, that will very clearly depict to you if this is your cup of tea or not. Take note big Developers and follow suit!

I am an avid fan of [i]Viscera Cleanup Detail[/i] so as soon as I saw the store page of this game I decided to download it immediately. If you have played [i]Thief[/i] then this game will be somewhat familiar in the sense that you are not out cleaning on official business but this is a 2nd job you have since with your janitorial salary you barely make ends meet. Plus, medical bills are especially high for a certain family member. Yeah, well, we won't get fond of this game because of the story.

Your home serves as a hub area where the computer we access to pick up missions. It's nice looking around in your apartment and interacting with everything you can (including your dog). You hop into your car and you'll find yourself on scene and you can immediately start cleaning. Now, the game says "prologue" but the mission details mention this is the 6th one. I assume they included a later level to showcase that several items available at your disposal to do the cleaning. You also notice that apart from the cleaning you can collect (steal) money, jewelry and other items, plus, you have several skill trees you can look at (but in this "demo" buying and assigning skill points is not possible). Oh, and you can also collect (remove) evidence that the cops would otherwise find (including erasing camera footage).

The basic concept is identical to that of [i]Viscera[/i]: get a bucket full of water and use your mop to clean every surface. Your mop requires cleaning and your bucket needs fresh water after a while. In [i]Viscera[/i] accidentally kicking (and tipping over) your bucket was possible but here I didn't notice such a thing. Also, bigger levels would be better so that a friend could join you but, sadly, this will remain a single player game. First, you are outside then you go inside and beside the ground floor and first floor you also have to do the cleaning in the basement. Taps for the bucket are always close so this won't be an issue.

Now, the interesting part is how you need to collect broken pieces of glass or bullets. Anything you break if you don't pay attention will be added to the amount of trash you need to dispose of. Once your trash bin is full your character can produce a sac. The game favours a casual approach and every equipment is easy-to-use and you don't feel stuck. Multiple sacs can be combined and disposing bodies is the easiest since you just have to pick them up. The back of your truck automatically applies the body bags. You can also hold left click to ensure multiple pieces of broken glass can be picked up quickly and efficiently.

There's more! A power washer for surfaces outside, a sponge for the same on the inside since a mop would break objects close to blood stains. Sponges are for a more careful, more meticulous cleaning exercise. You can apply detergents to the water to ensure stains disappear more quickly or that your mop lasts longer. Now, cleaning is not just about making everything spotless - remember it's about pretending nothing happened. So, all pieces of furniture must be put back to their original place. Locations are highlighted when you get closer - otherwise use your special crime sense to find out where everything belongs and if statistical data says a room is 99% clean only your sense will highlight that missing 1%. 

In [i]Viscera[/i], a special item provided audio cues so searching for every piece of stain towards the endgame was a challenge. Plus, no statistical data was provided while performing the job. In fact, here you can get percentage values per location. Again, [i]Crime Scene Cleaner[/i] leans towards a more casual playerbase. But this is fine! And while cleaning you can listen to music and your protagonist has some one-liners when spotting a new dead body. These remarks are actually pretty funny.

This prologue lasts for an hour or so. I look forward to the full game! I think [i]Viscera[/i] and / or [i]Thief[/i] fans will like it! I didn't include all pieces of equipment we can use in this demo so feel free to find out!

I liked this a lot more than I thought I would, but it was super, super fun. The only things I would change for the final game are:

666 Second Rule is a rather dark themed  mix of a Clicker and Tower Defense game where the player is put in the shoes of a parrent who has to protect its baby from insects crawling into its brain and infecting it. and if that doesnt suit your style you can always beat the living hell out of it instead. It could propably also be argued that the game even though a clicker has some ressemblance to whac- a-mole games as the player has to frantically kill off the insects with various weapons from above.

There are four different weapons varrying from a hammer to 3 different types of slippers and one being the Jesus slippers.
5 different powers that works basically as the tower defense part of the game.

A pretty short indie game and a bit overpriced at 4.99 at its baseprice but for for me who generally isnt too fond of Clickers i had a pretty good time playing it even though its a bit repetitive.

It took me 2.5 hours to 100% the achievements....

This game is one very simple concept. That's it. If you're not a very casual gamer, I would recommend passing on this one.

This game deserves to get a neutral review because it looks nice, there's obvious care put into the game, and there's a nice feel to it; but it has seemingly no rhyme or reason between becoming the other planets, and the achievements are the only reason to play it past the first winning run. Maybe it's sticking to absorbing specific planets or dark/light asteroids, but I tested this twice and kept getting cracked planets. This doesn't mean that's not the case. Maybe the initial planet is random, and growing it with like planets will make it grow to a bigger version of the same one. 
It's a major lack of content for me, and my rule of thumb on indie games is $1 per hour of content, which this doesn't even have 1 hour of varying engaging playtime. If you look at all the reviews, they didn't play very far past reviewing it, and that's a red flag for me when looking at games. They were all positive though, so it was a bit deceiving.  
This is a single player themed Agar.io with a very low cap that makes you reset the game. There's no missions. There's no advancing the game in different ways. You can't grow to be the biggest thing on the map. You get to a black hole in less than 5 minutes, then you can endless run to continue doing the exact same thing over and over to boost your score. I'm an achievement hunter, so I'll be playing it to get all the other achievements, but I feel like I'm going to be torturing myself by doing as such.
Edit: I realized that multiple achievements are broken and don't unlock... of all the ones I have left: 
I'm not going to try for a higher score when the 15k didn't unlock.
I literally discussed getting cracked planet multiple times in the review before I started hunting and still don't have it. I also got a wasteland planet but that didn't unlock. I'm not exactly sure what the planet destroyer achievement is, but I've ran into them multiple times to try unlocking it and it didn't happen. Now I suggest avoiding the game entirely

[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
Vae Victis Khan is a RenPy adventure game.

[h1]Story[/h1]
You've spent four years, locked in a cell. A dirt floor, stone bed, and a bucket for your bodily functions is all you've had. Even after four years, you don't know why you're here.

Four years ago you returned home from the Academy, in the spring. You went to the seamstress' home. You had shared her bed with her and her daughters and were wondering if they would be pregnant when you walked into the house. Instead the Shadow Guard were waiting for you outside her house. You fought with them, annoyed that they would attempt to arrest a prince. You killed one guard, but the rest overwhelmed you and you've been in this cell ever since.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game starts off by allowing you to limit fetishes you do not have an interest. Even if you have a fetish enabled, it will normally be optional. You will also set your pubic hair preferences, hairy or trimmed.

Next up you set your name, Karder by default.

Combat is a rock, scissors, paper system. One of my least favorite games to play, especially if your opponent uses a truly random tactic. In addition to the rock, scissors, and paper you can choose a normal, defensive, or aggressive stance. On the plus side, it seems that the opponent attacks are scripted. Goblins, for example will always parry (rock), so if you always use slash (scissors) you will win. Normal attacks do normal damage, Aggressive attacks do double damage, Defensive attacks do one point of damage, but mitigate your opponent's incoming damage. The basic strategy is to stick with Defensive attacks until you determine your opponent's pattern. I would advise saving at the start of each fight also, as a loss ends the game. You just need to survive the fight, your hit points will be refilled the next time you need to fight. So, there is no need in playing until you win unscathed.

When you have an option that will include a scene, that information is part of the prompt selection.

There are a number of quests where you need to explore an area. In the upper right is your map, so that you can ensure you do not run around in circles. There are also city maps. In the upper right corner is an hour glass, this changes the time from day to night, for when your quest requires you to be at a location as a different time of day.

After a brief introduction, you encounter the tutorial on kingdom building. You can limit the kingdom building portion of the game by using the VN Mode in the options. Additionally, Army vs Army combat is normally automatic, but you can toggle it to a more detailed system in the options. Next you are shown what the more detailed system looks like.

I would recommend the VN Mode. I played the kingdom building mode and conquest is severely limited. You start with 30 troops and you have a troop cap of 20 troops per conquered territory, plus 10. Where this is an issue is that early on your territories are attacked by neighboring territories and you can lose obedience. The only way to increase obedience is to station 30 troops in the territory, which you can only do for one territory at a time. But, that's not where it is really an issue. The real issue is when you want to attack another territory, you really only have 10 troops to spare. In order to attack a territory you have to remove the troops from most, if not all, of your territories into the mobile military. Then after the battle you can move them back. Except for the fact you will lose troops, so you have to wait for them to be trained. The way the game is set up you have to follow a basic path as you won't have enough troops available until you conquer a territory with a smaller army.

The art varies from stills to lightly animated to fully animated, with the majority being stills or lightly animated. The quality of the animations varies from scene to scene, some are smooth, others not so much.

[h1]The Gallery[/h1]
The Gallery is accessed from the Scene gallery option on the title menu. There are ten different sections, broken down by territory, with Interludes as the final section. There are at least nine scenes per territory, some have as many as 21. You can only view scenes that you have viewed in the game. They play the same as they did in the game.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
A decent game, with dated looking art. The art is plentiful, over 200 scenes to unlock. Heavy breeding and pregnancy content.

This is the best AVN and developer that I have come across. I had a "bug" which turned out to be player error. I didn't see the cursor prompting me to hit enter. The game gave me a choice to change a name and I couldn't get the game to progress. It was late Friday night. I went on discord for help and members sent a message to doorknob22. In minutes he was online and helping me in person. This is a small indy developer doing all of this himself and yet the excellence and quality show through everywhere. You can tell this is his passion and he takes pride in his work. The main character is a real bastard in the game. The developer is a class act. Usually it is the other way around.

What can I say about this thing...

First of all this thing can be called a "game" as it's not just a cilck to skip matter. It is not complete at this time, let's say it's 50% or about 50% done. The story is decent even if you have to read tons of lines too keep up.
The illustrations and animations are decent too even if sometimes cut by the UI placing the reading text on the lower screen where frequently happens the main "focus" is placed too, causing some auto-censorship. So the UI, all and all, could have been done better.

The game is filled with kinks for all tastes: incest, being a control freak, bestiality... Among them all, the main principal ones are pregnancy and voluptuous-chubby huge-breast and huge-butts women. Sadly both not my thing but I won't judge kinks here. Told so, it comes by itself that is a man-sausage focus game: you are a prince enjoying conquering lands and building up your reign (tactical part) while "filling the unprotected womb" (sorry bit this "unprotected womb" is really a laugh) belonging to mainly each single and always willing woman you met (sexual part).

Usually in these kind of games I give my Character a silly name. This time I named him "Idiot Male" and all the lines became even more funny to read. Just try it: it's a certified laugh to tears.

Is it worth 20 buks? Honeslty no: 10 would have been enough, so wait for Steam sales as i did.

Enjoy!

This is NOT and AVN.   I see reviews here saying it's a good AVN, lol.  This is a game.  What does that mean?  There are mechanics to fight scenes, there are quests, there are empire building aspects, and there is as much detail as you would ike. Great writing, dry humor, awesome sex scenes (the early ones are not animated sadly but most are). I was surprised by the world building, the different races and nations are not cookie cutter cliches, each bringing a unique flavor with its own slang, music, clothes etc. I skipped the 1:1 combat at first but when I gave it a try I saw it‚Äôs pretty easy to figure out: your opponent will attack in one of three attacks, each has their own animation. Once you learn which animation means which attack its super easy to counter them, barely an inconvenience. Great game!
Far too many decisions to be made, and some appear to not work correctly at all.  Art is not that good.

Not a bad avn at all. It has a pretty basic story premise with the mc trying to conquer every "country" in the realm, but that gives it plenty of options on how you do that. You can decide if you want to be a very dominant ruler that doesnt care about others even having the option to rape a lot of women, or you can play as a more friendly guy that still gets all the women. There is a big focus on impregation of all the women here and definitely a domination focus wiht the sex scenes. There are also a lot of sex scenes in general and the game for sure has set a focus on them. Nevertheless I also quite like the world around it and the story parts which mostly come in quests where you go to the different countries to try to get either some information, or sabotage them or whatever other advantage you can get. There are also a bunch of different races with elves, goblins and centaurs for example.

There is also a lot more gameplay than in your average avn as this has a combat mechanic, that is a more advanced version of "rock, paper, scissors" and a combat mechanic for group fighting when invading another country. Then there is also the managment portion to consider and some other smaller mechanics during the quests for example. All in all there is quite a lot and all the things work quite well if you want to do them. However you also have the option to alter how to play which I really like. The game offers you the choice on if you want to skip the group fighting for example, or if you just want to play the entire game without having to manage anything.

Overall a great avn with a ton of sex that also offers enough other content around it to manage to keep you interested and wanting to keep playing to see all the different countries.

"Vae Victis - Khan" is an adult game. Fantasy RPG in the form of a vn. It is set in medieval times and you play as a betrayed prince trying to reclaim his rightful place on the throne. Conspiracies and spies are everywhere. Choose to be a brute or try to be the nice guy. You must unite the regions to overthrow your own mother! Unifying them won't be easy! Prepare to.. "sweat" for it.. From many different activities! You can be bad, you can be good, but the 1 thing you cannot be is... not being a lustful beast! ^^

Refreshing dialogues that don't try to downplay anything and feel natural. They are more realistic and down to earth which helps with the immersion. The gameplay is mostly in vn format and from the options you can make it only vn (you can auto win every battle). [b]Do the sidequests![/b] While skipping combat won't make you lose anything, if you skip the sidequests you will miss 70%-80% of the game and the adult scenes. 

The game is currently in early access and not 100% finished. This includes and the animated scenes; especially at the start of the game, most of the content is still images. The dev plans to upgrade them to animated, like the majority of the later game is, before the final release.
As far as adult content goes, it has everything. Almost every fetish and position/scenario you can think of! Rule the regions by making one baby at a time! ^^
From the menu, you can opt out of certain content or have it optional.

Choosing content also applies to the actual strategy game. You can turn battles on and off at any given time without repercussions (except locking yourself out of some achievements that look broken regardless for the time being). It has both steam and in-game achievements. Manage your regions and your army! Build, transfer, take care, protect from raids and have romances! Reclaim your birthright to become the King!
Battles are turned-based when it comes to armies and a variation of rock-paper-scissors for simple enemies and bosses. The RPS game isn't based on luck. You can predict your opponent's move and there is a strategy to figure it out. The tutorials are good; including those for managing your army and conquered regions/Kingdom.

It could use some improvements but the content is vast and interesting, same as the combat and the adult scenes!

Are you ready to FIGHT??!!!
