A very enjoyable game in the genre. A very good story; engaging, well written and paced with some decent kingdom building aspects and good mini games. The NSFW scenes are very good and there are a LOT of them. Thoroughly recommended!

What a game.  What does a fantasy game need?  World building.  And this one has it in spades baby.  I'll get to the lewd stuff later, but first I have to give proper credit to how amazing this world is.  Every fiefdom has it's own unique culture you must navigate in order to conquer it.  How do you bring elves, orcs, elfikin, amazons, hobbits, and a diverse cast of humans under your banner?  You better figure it out, because this is not your average conquest.  Brains and brawn are required to reclaim your throne as the rightful Emperor of this troubled land.

It's good to be the King.  Or in this case, the Khan.  As the ruler of an empire, there is no shortage of women.  The only choice is how you will take them.  You can take them all by force.  Or you can take them all by seducing them.  Or maybe you take the wicked by force and the kind softly.  It's totally your choice.  You are the Khan, and your empire is yours to rule as you see fit.

As the Khan, you must maintain your empire.  You have the option of skipping this part, but I would not suggest it.  Keeping your empire happy and obedient is a fun challenge that I personally enjoyed.

In conclusion, this title is one of the most entertaining games I have played in a very long time.  I'm going to have to take a break from AVNs for a while because nothing else is going to compare.

I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised with this game.

The developer has put a lot of effort into this title and deserves high praise.

The novel aspect of the game is very well written and had me laughing regularly, especially when choosing the dominant path within conversations.

With regards to renders and animations, there's a really good variety of females to conquer none of which look like characters from other games which makes a nice change. Each area explored looked different with elements of free roam as well. 

As the game goes on, you can tell that animations were also improving and becoming more frequent which gives promise to future work from dev.

The music and sound effects are also pretty good, the latter being damn hilarious in places as they admittedly don't always match the event, but this added to the humour for me.

My only gripe at the start of the game was that the tutorial was a bit bleak and didn't explain very well how you go about managing the world map. 

I soon overcame this hurdle and found myself conquering the world and all the women it had to offer.

Overall this was a very enjoyable game worth paying full price. 

The only downside was that I was left questioning my morals but that's a small price to pay....... right?
combat makes the game unplayable. Gotta make it to where it can be skipped. Refunding the game until then.

The game is awesome so far. Part empire building / manage resources, free roam and plenty of side quests to explore the various kingdoms There is surprisingly a lot of content avail considering the game is in early access. Well worth the price  The overall story and renders are great and I like how diverse all of the females are in their appearance. I am looking forward (hopefully) to the continuing adventures of the MC and the various characters that have been introduced, I would give it a ten out of ten.

[h1] (3.2-hours in...) DLW RATED 8 of 10[/h1] (7=passing) [b]Vae Victis - Khan [/b] is an Adult/Choices/Story-Wargame(?) (5.9 Gigs) game where you begin as an heir to the throne but accused of poisoning Dad, thus imprisoned in the dungeon by your (‚Äúyou really wear that thing around the help?‚Äù) sexually overt mother, for 4 years‚Ä¶ but have now managed to escape with plans for your future. 
[h3]UPSIDE:[/h3] 1) After escaping, you no longer have a stink-bucket for a restroom. 2) Graphics are somewhat dated, but sufficiently decent as of 6/17/24. 3) In game Prefs/Options area is very nicely set up. 4) That you and Dad are known as ‚ÄúKhan‚Äù encourages you to have barbarian shit-for-morals, but it‚Äôs your choice‚Ä¶ 5) I like the effort at coming up with an approach apart from 80% of games within this genre; and so will you, see?
[h3]SUBJECTIVE:[/h3] 1) English writing skills are a bit wanting. ‚ÄúBaptize yourself‚Äù? ‚ÄúNone of them is true‚Äù? Perhaps it‚Äôs just the 1000th developer in the world who has never heard of proof reading‚Ä¶ 2) The author has a thing for ‚ÄúBush‚Äù which can be turned off in options (thank you). 3) High heels in ‚ÄúRoman‚Äù times lets you know it‚Äôs a pure fantasy game‚Ä¶ 4) The 1-v-1 Melee system is a more-complicated (believe it or not) version of Rock/Paper/Scissors, and is actually interesting... 5) Barlin is George Lucas, huh?
[h3]DOWNSIDE:[/h3] 1) One hour in, despite animations on the Store Page, I have seen none at all. 2) Multiple consecutive black screens for summing-up sort of end narration are on panic order disconcerting, when you seem them, cuz it's like "wait... what?", so naturally lazy by recent standards. 3) ...and so is that same image for 40 straight conversation screens. 4) Manipulating the Big Picture of your world conquest is not as intuitive for us as they have in their minds. They should provide a walk-through of a few turns to get us onboard. I suspect, the Gold needed to get the ball rolling on all resource fronts is connected to Mini-Quests, otherwise (Which can be auto-won). Also, it does give the option to go simple when it comes to the managing the Big Picture stuff, early on. Interesting  but hard to rate the game high 3.2 hours in when it‚Äôs Slow going, and I hope becomes faster.
[h3]SUMMATION:[/h3] 1) Unfortunately, the overall gameplay is difficult to assess one hour in, but the game does have multiple, relatively original aspects‚Ä¶ 2) I have all these dots, see?‚Ä¶ .. . 3) The game seems to head into a Straight-up Wargaming format, but I may be judging it to soon. We know from example screens more sex is on the way, so hopefully, this does not pull to far from that...

It sounded interesting enough to see past it being a VN, but it's slow and boring with rock-paper-scissors as a combat system.

You can skip the combat (missing out on an achievement), but I also didn't really find the story interesting enough to stick around

As you can see it almost took 30 minutes to get to the conquering part of the game, and it was not interesting enough to keep me here.

Although the game is at an "Early Access" state, it feels like a below average visual novel from the early 2010 (ish)!!!
[list]
[*] In 2024, the game's graphics are simply unacceptable!
[*] The game's combat is clunky and boring to say the least. The developer has made it difficult (even though you have an in-game option to make your life a little easier) in order to make you burn through your two-hour refund period, I'm guessing... ;)
[*] The game's user interface is totally outdated!
[/list]

I could go on and on about other things I didn't like about a game released in 2024, but I hope you get the gist!
Cheers

Here is a description of a playthrough:
Press S then 1 to start a single player game.
From the achievements available I guess there are 3 levels.
Controls
WASD do the moving.
Left click for the shooting.
Drop some sort of beacon with G, it is the only thing thus far that I can suss directional sound that gets louder the closer you are to it. For what purpose? Your guess is as good as mine.
Press 1 for a beepy noise that will stop sometimes ond become a high pitch screech at others. For what purpose? No idea.
Press 2 for a sonar noise that does seemingly nothing. the noise has not changed in any way whilst in use.
Press 3 to make a random scratchy noise, again serving no apparent use that I have found as yet.
Okay so wander around until I happen into a whiney noise. If I stand still the whiney noise gets louder until eventually a cockerel crows and I am dumped back to the menu.
Guess you need to avoid the whiney noise.
Try again, see if beepy/screechy noise is helping you pinpoint the hen firer. Maybe but no matter how much I shoot when it becomes screechy I cannot dehen the thing. Get cockerelled again.
back to menu.
Try sonar thing, still does nothing get cockerelled.
Try scratchy thing.... Cockerelled.
So can a blind person play this game? Yes about as well as everyone else at a guess. in other words not very.
Will I play again? Yes.
I will decockerel the whiney noise some how.
Please leave a comment if you get any further. I'm sure I'm missing something obvious to the Dev, just not the rest of the planet.....
If you enjoyed my playthrough description, welcome to the world of the Visually Impaired, cookies are welcomed!

The art is gorgeous, the mystery is intriguing, and the music is peak!! I might've spent too much time listening to the title screen music as you can see from my hours.

Story:

The story starts off light, focusing on the slice of life and idol routine, but quickly takes a dark turn as a crime is committed, building into an intense climax. 

After finishing the demo, I was hooked in the mystery. The writers did a great job of making you want to know what happens next. 

Gameplay: 

The gameplay is like Ace Attorney/Danganronpa where you have to select evidence to support/contradict a statement. The difficulty wasn't easy, but wasn't frustratingly hard either. I felt it was a good balance that made you think.

The game also has 'free time events' and a character relationship meter which reminded me of Persona or Kara no Shoujo.

This is great for those who want to spend time with the characters and learn more about them, but for me, I chose to spend time in the detective's office to dig for more clues (I'm glad the devs allow us to do that for those who prefer the mystery).

If you're a fan of mystery VNs, this is by far one of the most interesting ones I've played and worth checking out!

Whispers of the Luminaries is one of the best graphic novels you can play. It has a really well thought out storyline which is full of mystery and has you on the edge. The artwork is reallllllly good as well as the OST's. Also seeing the progress that the developers had so far was really charming. So if you're looking for a VN to play I commend you this brilliant game.

Murder mystery? Check
Somber atmosphere? Check
GORGEOUS artwork? CHECK CHECK CHECK
Protagonist with a face? Check (not a given, so +)
GORGEOUS characters?  CHECK CHECK CHECK (have you seen that hot bespectacled man? oh boy)

There was another demo prior to this and one can really notice the difference in quality between them. The UI is more refined and responsive in this one (even if a little awkward still). Writing has also seen an up in quality. Some artwork (such as scenes or character sprites) have been added. Also an actual banger song at the end of the demo. All of this to say the devs are actively addressing issues, and building upon their existing work.

I don't doubt that given further time and experience they will make a great game.

"Alibi: The Dinner Party" is surprisingly good, considering it is Monabi Games' first effort.

The soundtrack's jazzy mix complemented the unfolding plot; started laid-back and became increasingly more frantic as the progression reached a crescendo. Speaking of, the story's pacing was impeccable, holding my attention throughout the game. The suspense and intrigue, passed the opening, was so compelling that I completed it in one sitting, as I had to know the conclusion.

The game's true strength lay in its logical design. It refrained from convoluted puzzles or game mechanics (looking at you, Danganronpa), allowing the focus to remain on solving the mystery at hand. This approach made me feel engaged, accomplished and smart as I was able to deduce the correct answer without resorting to absurd reasoning.

In essence, "Alibi: The Dinner Party" is a refined visual novel that skillfully combines music, narrative, and logical plotlines. If you're in search of a captivating experience, this game comes highly recommended.

A detective visual novel in which there are no bad choices.

There has been a murder, and you have been assigned to conduct the investigation. It happened at one of your friends' house during a party, thus you must keep your personal feelings apart from your professional life. 

The gameplay is comparable to that of any other visual novel. There is a lot of reading and clicking the mouse button to proceed to the next text. Because you're in the role of a detective, you have a few more options to help you feel like you're actually doing some work. However, the game is still linear and does not allow you any freedom.

There is no looking for clues or solving logic puzzles on your own. All you have to do is move around the house and click on potential evidence that the game presents you. You will not miss anything because all important information is immediately recorded in your casefile. 

Once you‚Äôre done with the house, you move to interrogation. It's simple; you listen to the suspect, occasionally put pressure on them by clicking on highlighted words, provide evidence to make them crack, and point to important rooms in the house. And once again, you can't make a mistake. Even if you choose the incorrect option, the characters will just remark that it is wrong and you will be able to choose again until you click on the one that is right.
A short little detective game in a similar style to Phoenix Wright. A nice attempt for a first time game developer

tl;dr it's okay, worth spending an evening on

gah writing reviews without spoiling story games is a pain
i almost want to write a review as a message to the developer rather than for those who're looking to suss out whether they should buy and play this
it's not glaringly bad at anything, and there's noticeable awkwardness here and there, but the game and the story is not in any way ruined by that, so there
it's a competent detective story, it's interesting enough, it's a pretty good purchase

p.s.
regards to the developer, i do hope to see more if that's on the cards

I have enjoyed most of this developers point and click titles, so I do not think I am being too harsh here: 

The total content is around 2-3 hrs.. absolute tops, probably far less if you aren't high/wasted. There are some interesting point and click segments that involve strange interactions with the environment, but there is maybe a grand total of one-two hours of these segments and at least what feels like 30+ minutes of holding down a key and waiting for something to happen. 

I honestly feel like not much effort was put into this game, since compared to previous titles, or even other point and click titles the interactions seem sparse and there isn't an iota of the detail that you will find in the previous gems from this developer. Not to mention that there are no real puzzles and the game is much more of a walking simulator than a point and click. 

All in a all a pretty big disappointment.

Welcome to Turtle Bay, a beautiful tropical Oasy where the rarest turtles live happily in their natural and protected environment.
But our help is needed because an earthquake has caused damage to houses and shops, endangering turtles, many nests have been devastated and the eggs dispersed.
Our task is to help Kanoa and Malia restore the island, its community of inhabitants and search for the lost eggs of our turtle friends.

It's very relaxing, there's nothing difficult, it's about finding objects to match, alternating with sections of "Bingo" where we have to find numbers that parade before us in a snake of balls.
When we complete these sections we will receive a part of the island map, coins, pearls or rare eggs; they are all objects that are needed to restore the island and make it a paradise again.
If we want to collect more coins there is "Gameroom" with many beautiful games that will make us win easily.
Collect as many coins as you will need to unlock "Collectibles" which are aids for the island.
When we have saved all the turtles and collected the pearls, "Bonus Contents" will be unlocked where you will find:
Bingo blitz
Infinite matching fun
Solitaire collections
Pachinko blitz
Show intro
Gallery
Collectibles
Music

It is an excellent game suitable for those who want moments of relaxation, with engaging music, the graphics are very beautiful and you can admire many landscapes full of flowers, animals, plants and the blue of the sea.
It's a virtual holiday to get away from the daily routine!!!!!!!

[h1]I SAVED THE SEA TURTLES![/h1]

I fell in love with Mixo Games after playing a really unique game called Lost Amulets
https://store.steampowered.com/app/2184970/Lost_Amulets_Four_Guardians/¬†
They have found a unique way to incorporate Bingo and Marble Popping to create a challenging and addictive hybrid in a game called Twistingo!

In this third installment of Twistingo, we travel to Turtle Bay Island to help the locals restore their shops and locate missing sea turtle eggs. Hold on tight; you're in for a wild ride!¬†

You can choose to play in a Casual Mode (slow animations, more hints, easier gameplay), a Normal Mode (faster bingo balls, fewer hints, more challenge), or an Expert Mode (quick bingo balls, no hints, harder levels) so everyone can enjoy playing at their own pace.
¬†
You begin by playing a Hidden Object Scene, but these aren't your average, typical HO scenes. The camera angle is probably the first thing you'll notice because it's as if you are standing and looking down at the objects. The second thing that catches your eye is the uniqueness of the objects themselves. These aren't junk items thrown into a pile on a table in the corner of a room or random household items scattered around the scene. At first glance, it seems as though there are only a handful of objects; some of the items even appear to be quite large.¬†

There are two variations of HO Scenes. The first type requires you to find a specified number of items that are listed on a strip of paper, such as 5 Keys. As you remove the listed items, you'll uncover more strips of paper with different items to search for. Incredibly, the scene that appeared to have a scant amount of objects, turns out to be a multi-layered, multi-faceted, complex hidden object scavenger hunt!
¬†
The second Hidden Object type is a Matching variation where you remove pairs of identical objects. Again, at first glance, the scene appears to have only a few objects, but as you remove pairs, they uncover a whole slew of objects below them! Somehow, this developer has mastered the art of deception and is able to hide objects in plain sight!

The goal of each Hidden Object Scene is to find Bingo Balls to play a game of Twintingo, or recover the missing Turtle Bay Map pieces, which allows you to progress through the island. As you progress, you will also be tasked with finding amulet fragments to restore Seven Sacred Amulets or sets of Pearls to restore the Island Artifact.¬†¬†

Twistingo has two variations. The first variation requires removing Bingo Balls as they travel in a single-file line (some levels have two lines & two openings). The Bingo Balls also rotate slightly, but this feature can be disabled. You can remove a ball by either clicking on the actual ball or by clicking on the number from the Bingo Card itself. The Bingo Balls must match the number and the color shown on the card(s). If you select incorrectly in this variation, the line will advance closer to the opening. If the bingo Ball line reaches the opening, you will lose and will have to replay that level. As you progress, Bonus Balls will appear in the line, such as Wild Joker Balls or bonuses that freeze time or push the line backward a bit. In this variation, you can earn extra coins when you finish bingo cards, but you must click on them before they disappear.
¬†
The second Twistingo variation is a lot less challenging, but I actually like this version better. Instead of bingo numbers, each ball has a picture or symbol. As the balls roll out of the opening, you simply click its matching onyx stone from the pile. Although you don't have to worry about the balls reaching the end of the line in this version, you do have to refrain from random clicking because additional stones are added to the pile if you make a wrong selection. In this version, you will uncover Turtle Eggs to save the sea turtles that can only be found on Turtle Bay Island!

The Coins you earn are used to purchase Island restorations or feed turtles, etc. This is also an unusual feature because it's in the form of a movie clip with incredibly beautiful scenery. The coins can also be used to purchase Casino tickets to play various mini-games, such as Solitaire, Pachinko, or a game where you must guess if the next card will be lower or higher. If you win the game, you will earn up to four times the amount of coins spent; if you lose, you only lose the small amount you paid to play the mini-game. The Pachinko game is really fun; it's similar to pinball; I just wish¬†it had flippers you could click to try to flip the balls back up as you would in pinball!

[h1]COLLECTOR'S EDITION EXTRAS:[/h1]
Bonus Stage, Casino Games: 6 Extra Bingo Blitz games, 6 Extra Infinite Matching Fun games, 18 Extra Solitaire Games, 9 Pachinko Blitz, Show Introduction Movie, Island Art Gallery Slideshow, 10 Tropical Music Soundtracks with Music Player, Collectibles Showcase (items purchased with Coins)

Check out my Group/Curator page¬† at¬†https://steamcommunity.com/groups/thewoodsforum
and don't forget to stop by my nature-themed chat forum at¬†https://thewoodsforum.boards.net/

The third installment of the Twistingo series takes us to another island paradise where sea turtles nest.  This time, earthquakes have destroyed the landscape and you are tasked with finding the peoples' lost artifacts, help them rebuild their businesses, and rescue the turtle nests.  You will be playing through a mix of marble popper variant and HOS, with side quests in the "game room" where there are one-up one-down solitaire, a guess the higher or lower card game, and Pachinko machine ball-breaking layouts to help you build up funds to buy assorted extra goodies for the benefit of the locals.  As in the previous game, you must construct your pathway through the island by finding the jigsaw puzzle pieces of the map as you're going along and assembling the puzzle until the entire map is built.

This CE has an extra chapter of content tacked onto the end of the SE content, but it's not obvious as the game just keeps going along the pathway with a few extra jigsaw pieces until you rescue a seventh turtle nest (the SE has just 6 turtle nests/chapters total).  I would not have realized this myself except for noting some very specific numerical typos in the storyline texts (now fixed) while beta testing!  The storyline this time is much improved and while it's not great literature, a lot less contrived than in earlier games, and all the scenes are voiced-over.  Other CE extras unlock after you've finished the main quest on the map and include: 6 bonus marble popper levels (3 regular, 3 no-lose), 6 "clutter" style HOS, 18 solitaire games, 9 Pachinko games, a music player, and a relaxing slideshow of pretty tropical images with an ambient soundtrack in the background.

If you like the spin on the Zuma-type marble popper play where you must click on numbers in bingo cards as the same numbers appear on marbles in the chain, yes, those levels are back.  Turn off the rotating numbers in MP levels unless maybe you're super good at this sort of game.  The "click on rocks matching the marble symbol" to rescue a turtle nest MP levels appear at the end of every chapter.  But the vast majority of this game is HOG: either traditional find stuff in a scene with the "list" gradually revealing on cards as you find things, or "clutter" type where you pick 2 of the same.  While in the HOG scenes you must also locate fragments of artifacts, bingo balls (numbered marbles) to unlock the next MP level, or lost pearls.  Every chapter is somewhere between 7-10 levels long and there's never more than 2-3 MP levels plus the one super easy turtle nest MP level per chapter, so I was getting a little HOG-ged out going through one HOS after another and would have preferred a few more of the marble popping levels.  The level of challenge in the MP levels isn't all that intimidating...I'm not an extreme expert at the genre, but didn't struggle all that much even on the hardest difficulty and the game is pretty forgiving of letting a couple of marbles go into the drains before you lose.

For some reason, the 3 "regular" MP levels in the CE extras are serious marble rage games which I wouldn't recommend playing except maybe on the easiest difficulty; I don't think they are winnable on the hardest difficulty (I tried and tried and finally swallowed my pride and switched to normal for those levels, and barely scratched my way through).  The rest of the CE bonus levels are quite enjoyable, as are the side games in the "game room".  I don't know exactly how many solitaire and Pachinko layouts there are in the game room, but I played the game room for at least an hour before I saw any repeats.  If you enjoy HOGs and don't mind something a little different here and there, much recommended.  But three games in this series is enough for me if they're going to keep in the mostly HOG vein, as it was the MP aspect that originally drew me to this series.

This game is very much like the others in the series.  It is a good game that is a HOG plus marble popping game.   The other reviews did a great job at describing this game.  I like the game and think it is a unique game that I don't think you will find anywhere else.  I purchased the other two in the series on another site and  let me just say I don't regret buying them.

 If you have a problem or a question the developer will address your concerns.  I had a problem with Norton going off and was told there something in the game that causes that and it will be taken out in a few days.  I selected always allow because I trust the developer and Steam. I have no problems with my computer and it runs like it should with the game on.  I played for over 4 hours and I am only half way through the game (not including the bonus content).  It is a very good game and well worth the money.

First, I can't say enough about the art work.  Its beautiful.  But, more important, its clear and vibrant.  So the HOG parts of this game are fun and interesting instead of frustrating and muddy.

I like the HOG (Hidden Object Game) type of games.  But I rarely play them because they usually rely on trying to pick objects out of barely recognizable, muddy, layouts.  Not fun, or interesting, for me.

Turtle Bay is completely different.  The artwork is beautiful, like I said above.  But the hidden object layouts are so much better than I have seen anywhere else.  The first thing I noticed is that some objects are large.  Unusual but welcome.  Next, they are laid out in a jumble or pile.  Noting like the Clutter games which are way more than I like.  At Turtle Bay, its just right.  Sometimes your task is to match pairs of the same item.  Other times you look for a certain number of items printed on slips of paper in scene.  I really enjoy them.

There are also Jewel Match levels, to earn extra gold to "buy" in game extras, as well as Pachinko style levels.   I have only played either of those a little.  But they are great too and just as beautiful as the rest of the game.

Finally, there are Luxor style bingo levels.  I don't much care for them.  BUT, that is only because I don't much like that style of puzzle.  It seems like I am always hunting for  a certain piece and then spending the entirety of the session in the last few inches of the track, trying to avoid the end.  Not fun for me.  You might love them though.  Technically, they work and look great.

tl:dr If you love HOGs, Jewel Match, or Luxor style matching, you will love this game.
The puzzles are fun and the art is amazing! There's large subtitles and good voice acting too. Thanks very much for making this game!

A simple jewel crafting simulator. The final product, no matter how horribly you screw up and get lowly graded, looks shiny, unique and appealing. However, if you are a perfectionist or have OCD, you might be slightly disappointed.

There is only 2 main tasks that you repeat over and over: 
Directing the gemstone's face to grind & grinding the gemstone to the directed line.

The $300,000 upgrade tool automatically takes away the former task. By the time you save up that much, you probably deserve that luxury.

As other reviews had mentioned, there is no tool tips nor any form of tutorial. Hopefully the devs will do something about it. For now, „Åø„Åø„Åø„Åø„Åö provided a very informative guide in Japanese language so do check it out.

In my opinion, the most useful tools to start out with are the $5000 ones: 
The 'Circular 3 Arrows' icon tool which lets you slow down your gem rotation significantly. 
The 'Down arrow' icon tool lets you slow down the speed your gem lowers down onto the grindstone.
The 'Gem' icon tool lets you slow down the speed of grinding your gem on the grindstone.

There's also a $5000 upgrade (Wrench > Crosshair icon) which lets you reset the gemstone to default position with the 'H' key, but you can actually 'Settings > Return to Title' then go back to the gemstone for that function. This might be patched eventually.

the controls are janky and awkward, the background is unusually low detail despite everything else, the UI iconography is impossibly vague despite the devs wishing for it to be a "language free game anyone can understand", a huge amount of the tools are locked out and have to be paid for with ingame money earned from making the gems and theres not much else to be doing other than making the gems and naming them once youre done

...yet, despite all of those complaints, i can't deny it's not a very pleasant and compelling game. it's very satisfying to finally figure out the right way to do certain cuts and see your rank and skill in making the gems rise over time. getting my first SS rank was extremely gratifying, and its nothing more than a vague statistic attached to your finished piece. definitely not going to be for everyone with how samey it is and both literally and metaphorically grindy it is, but hey, that's how it goes some times. the devs are also clearly taking on feedback and putting out patches to make it even better, so its all smiles over here from me!

Refunded: Unplayable due to inexcusably poor UI. 

You cannot rotate the gemstones using the mouse: keyboard inputs only. And yet no other keyboard input is properly recognized for navigating the UI - you can't even use ESC to exit a window. (ESC inexplicably opens the graphics settings menu.)

Instead, you have to use the mouse cursor to push buttons displayed on the screen for just about everything. Furthermore, the most commonly used buttons (ACCEPT, EXIT, etc) are deliberately programmed as "Hold to Accept", meaning that you need to click on them for a long time before the input is recognized.
 
At first glance, it would appear that a team of specialists in programming and psychological torture had put their heads together with the single purpose of creating the worst, most frustrating UI in the history of gaming. More likely, however, is that this game was originally designed for touchscreen smartphones and absolutely no effort whatsoever was made to convert it to PC. Note also that there's no controller support. Why? Because, again, it's a smartphone game that assumes you have a touchscreen. 

Also, this game does not support multiple aspect ratios. 16:9 is the only one available, meaning black bars on the sides for anyone using any other aspect ratio monitor - yet another testament to how utterly lazy and unskilled the devs truly are.

I honestly cannot comment on whether or not the gameplay itself is enjoyable or rewarding. I requested my refund after suffering through 8 minutes of painfully frustrating, absolutely jaw-dropping developmental incompetence. It's truly unfortunate, because with just the tiniest effort, this could have been a wonderfully nice, cozy, relaxing game. Alas, in it's current state, it is all but unplayable.

For the first time this game looks interesting. But after I created several jewels for 5 hours, I really felt BORED. And this game expects me to create jewels with an overall rating of SS or higher, 100 times. NO THANK YOU...!!! -_-

Move aside Mario! Move aside Lisa from 'Imagine: Master Chef' for the Nintendo DS! Move aside Sonic!
Orbo has secured his spot on the throne of gaming greats, and don't expect to see him ousted anytime soon.
The gaming mascots of old have dissolved from the modern zeitgeist, and Orbo alone remains.
Why you ask? It's simply a matter of marketability and relatability.

It's a well known fact that children with underdeveloped minds used to be the primary consumer of video games. This led to the popularization of video game mascots characterized by nauseating neon colors and cocky irreverent attitudes. 

Whether it is due to efforts to protect children from LGBT propaganda, new opportunities for children to work in mines/quarries, or the devastating consequences of sending minors to the metaverse; the political happenings of the last decade have essentially taken children out of the picture today. 

Only one class of people remain to decide if games are good or bad, 30-65 year old white-collar desk workers. Behavioral studies have proven time and time again that these salary men spend (at a minimum) 55% of their day playing games on their Lenovo ThinkPad while their boss isn't looking. And as of 2023, their game of choice is Orbo! Staring an icon who accurately depicts the trials and tribulations of modern office life like none before. The AAA gaming industry has finally woken to the stark lack of representation of the white armless man, and they're receiving dividends in return.

We invite you (given that you fit into the correct demographic) to engulf yourself in the lisztomania of Orbo, a movement that's on course to rank between Protestantism and Catholicism in the census of 2030.
This game's pretty short, but its really fun. There is a bit of a learning curve when starting off, but its pretty easy to get the controls down once you play around with them for a bit.

Humor in games generally struggles to land for me, I'm not fond of comedy games with silly premises which come off as a desperate comedian's attempt at winning over a laugh: "Look, this Goat is flying! Goats don't do that, LOL!"

Orbo's Odyssey is genuinely funny. It employs violent madcap humor, as if the absurd is its sword and bafflement its shield. Most of this game's humor feels as if it comes from a pure source, what I mean by that is there's a clear lack of comedic structure. Why are there cardboard cutouts of what I'm pretty sure are stock images of rats scattered across one area of the game? I don't know, but it's hilarious.

Don't let the comedy overshadow what really makes this game good: the gameplay. As far as protagonists of platformers go, Orbo's a charmingly unique character who's blisteringly fast and able to fly across large areas of the map with ease. His quick hops and fast flying actually handles really well, impressively so when you realize you're guiding around what's basically just a person-shaped missile. The music is great, too, and I would love to buy the soundtrack down the line.

Safe to say the only con this game has is that it's pretty short, I beat the main story in an hour. There's secrets to find, sure, but that short length may be off-putting to some players. To those players I say this: Orbo's Odyssey is what happens when someone passionate sits down and creates something for you. 

Orbo's Odyssey is a sandwich, lovingly made with store bought ingredients, which gives you the impression that you could have made that sandwich on your own. After all, it's just a sandwich. Hell, you could've went to a deli and got a sandwich with imported ingredients, crafted by a sandwich artist who you know takes their job seriously because their sandwiches come with a wood skewer. But that sandwich you're looking at, made with store bought ingredients, was handed to you by a person who didn't ask for anything major in return. In fact, you were craving a sandwich, and someone put their heart into putting one together. And before you know it, you've devoured said sandwich, and while its taste is washed away with a quick swig of water, the memory remains.

So yeah, buy this game.

Orbo? More like [i]Blorbo.[/i] A consistently hilarious and fast little 3D adventure, with absolutely nothing sinister going on under the surface.

Also, gotta say, this game's tutorial might be one of the best I've seen in a platformer. Good info and very accessible.

I greatly felt the absence of a roll, which I think would have been a great asset for a game like this especially since the character already spins in one of their moves.

This is a smaller side note but I was also a little underwhelmed on how much weird stuff was in the game. Most of the really weird stuff I found was the stuff I already saw in the trailer, although admittedly I pretty much blitzed through this game and didn't really stop to explore much.

Still a pretty good game, but I overall felt underwhelmed.

[h3]Air Drilling Fun[/h3]

This is a pretty cool short indie platformer with the unique mechanic of air drilling like a bullet. It is a bit too fast for me to control with the camera which I lament not being to enjoy it as much because of motion sickness. With 4 levels, 1 boss and 1 secret ending, I hope the level mods address the lack of content or time trials to elevate its value and provide an avenue of challenge aside from speed running the base game. Beyond the mechanics, the vibes and quirky setting does add to its charm such as the vampires and anomalies and not to forget the music.

I can recommend this game and hope the developers make a more expansive successor to it.

Orbo's Odyssey is a simple and sweet speedy platformer with simple movement, high ceiling use and neat exploration. You only have around three moves, Jump, dive, and stomp, with some variations in between those moves. The beauty of the game is to combine these moves to you're own liking and watch Orbo soar across the levels. Because oh boy, you can go really fast, really fast.

Orbo's adventure is a pretty unique one at that with interesting art style that is uncanny in the best way possible, both in world design and characters. The comedy is also pretty funny as well to me. I just wish there was more of it.

My only problem with with this game is that I wish there was more of it. Witch is a good problem to have tbh. Would defiantly love to see more of this style and humour combine with the unique free movement it offers.  If you have a few dollars in you're account with 1 to 2 hours to kill, this is definitely it. 

I wish the developer great luck with there next project, because if it's anything like this, it's a instant banger.

Orbo is a fast-paced 3D platformer that is similar in structure to Mario Odyssey (each level features multiple gears to collect, which are strewn about the level or hidden behind small challenges). The main star of the show is the movement, which feels excellent to control; it's simple to get around with, but the skill ceiling is so high that you can always go faster. This speedrunning mentality is most present in the time trials (one of which is available on every level), which also feature dev times to beat for an achievement.
The "narrative" does take a backseat, but a game like this really doesn't need it to be front-and-center. There is a few characters to talk to, and their dialogue is consistently goofy and funny.
Despite being all royalty free music as far as I can tell, the soundtrack is a banger and fits the vibe of each level perfectly.

The game is short (although the dev did say they are planning to address this in some way), currently featuring 4 main levels and taking about an hour to beat. Although with how fun the movement is there is a lot of replayability in attempting speedruns, whether it's just a timetrial, a whole level or the full game.
Despite the game's length there is plenty of secrets hidden around, and all the levels look & feel super unique.

They rarely make 'em like they used to, but this game is just a pure joy to play, simple as. GO ORBO!!!.

Fun little game, enjoyed it very much :3

Orbo's Odyssey is a bite sized 3d platformer with focus on a trippy visual style, fast paced momentum gameplay, and exploration. Its certainly a short game, but the experience is quite tight, and there's never a dull moment. You can easily finish the campaign within an hour if you so please, but if you're going for completion, your time with this little game will be a fair bit longer.

There is also a fair slew of secrets to uncover with this little game, but I'll leave all those for you to find on your own.

Overall, I'd highly recommend checking this game out, as it has already cemented itself as a recent favorite of mine.

Hobby, brain teaser, mini-games, fun.

It's not just a game, but a collection of classic mini-games like Search for Objects, Find Differences, Paint, Match, Memory.
 It also contains unique word games: small crossword puzzles, words to look up on the board, or recompose famous phrases.
The "Connect" game is nice where you have to join various points to form triangles and create the figure.
Even "Jigsaw" you didn't expect the classic, you won't find the usual pieces, but the photo is broken down into many pieces of different shapes.


The graphics are beautiful, and the music never gets boring because there are 15 different tracks to listen to.
In addition to the 22 mini-games in the "CE Content" you will find wallpapers to download, music player and 23 additional levels.
The nice thing is that there are no locked levels, it's all manageable by you: decide and choose the minigame you want to play at the moment.
Achievements will be unlocked simply by playing the game and completing levels.
If you're in trouble, click on the star and it will help you.

I have to say that I found these mini-games really fun, there is nothing difficult and it is suitable for everyone, plus it satisfies many different tastes.
I would suggest the idea of creating another collection of mini-games maybe with a more cheerful theme such as animals, flowers, paintings, landscapes, sports etc.

A collection of casual games that are ideal during a quick break.

These types of games are typically found as mini-games in HOGs. There are approximately twenty different mechanics, all of which are well-known and easy to understand. Classics such as jigsaw puzzles, finding differences, memory games, slider puzzles, and many more are included. 

You can choose any puzzle you like because everything is available right away. All you have to do is choose a puzzle mechanic from a list and one of the puzzles in that folder. The only thing missing is the feature to filter out completed from uncompleted puzzles. Because most mechanics only have four puzzles, the selection is somewhat limited. If you're only interested in certain types of puzzles, you probably won‚Äôt find it here. 

Puzzles aren't difficult. But if you get stuck, there‚Äôs a hint to help you arrange one of the pieces in the right place. It recharges over time, allowing you to use it again. As a result, anyone can finish the puzzle.

Charming game that ticks off some of my boxes, but it's got some significant technical problems, abundant typos as if no one proofread it, confusing design, and lacks basic ease of life features. Dialogues and decisions repeat unnecessarily, the gallery is poorly realized, and you can't even delete save files.

I'm ambient toward this one. It has an interesting premise and makes a good initial impression; but the quality tapers off in the second half and the story ends fairly abruptly, fumbling the climax and the epilogue (such as it is). The artwork feels like a poorly upscaled Flash game from the 2000s - both arousing and disappointing at the same time.

While I can see the appeal if novelty outweighs quality; I wouldn't be able to recommended this game to my past self.

[h1]OBJECTION! Wait, Wrong Game ^^u[/h1]
[b]Erotic Justice[/b] is what you'd get if you grabbed Ace Attorney, gave it a cartoonish art style, cranked up the silliness to eleven, and filled it with absurd jokes. It's a fun romp in which we play as the inspector Max Chusets as he uses his powers to Penetrate The Lies‚Ñ¢ of the people he questions to solve cases. What's more, the game features multiple endings based on different things, such as how well you did in your investigation or if you had an "accident" with any of the women in the game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3077947440
The mechanics behind the MC's powers are well-though since you only have one shot at using your powers right during a question, and the only way to recharge is by railing any of the women you meet, including your assistant Fizz, or by watching them get down and dirty with each other. Moreover, it includes a luck-based mini-game that determines whether you impregnated someone you had sex with or not.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3077947402
As for the visuals, the cartoonish art style reminded me a bit of that Derpixon animation with the mimes. Maybe it was because of the protagonist's designs, who knows, but I dig the style and the whole cast's character design. Most sex scenes are still shots except for a few animated scenes added here and there to spice things up. The content is vanilla for the most part, though it includes some optional futa scenes in case you're into characters that can offer the best of both worlds. So yeah, give it a shot if you're a fan of Ace Attorney games and always wondered how a porn parody of it would be or if the art style appeals to you, or both.

A pretty good VN, all things considered. Art is simplistic and cute, the story is pretty fun to follow, the characters are all charming in their own way. Being a lewd game, if you're willing to explore, it has a very good spread of fetishes, depending on what you're into. In 3 hours of playing, I played through twice, so there's not some sort of grand narrative to follow, but honestly it doesn't need it. 

I'd prolly give it a 8/10. Give it a try :3

I usually do not leave reviews. However, I did not see a lot of reviews for the game and  I would like to see more content from this developer in the future.  It is not very often you find any voice acting in this style of game and is usually just a cheap put-together cash grab of porn art. But this game put in the effort to include extensive audio content in their game so just because of that alone I would recommend this game. Not to mention I would say the price is about right for the amount of content given.

Could need some QoL improvements to reduce the number of clicks between screens to get to where and who you should talk to, but it didn't bother me too much.  It's a good first game.

I need to begin this by saying , I don't usually leave long form reviews but felt this game was worth the extra effort to do so.

[b] TL;DR: [/b] a labour of love lewd visual novel with cute graphic design and a fantastic plot, well worth your money, sale or not.

Erotic justice is a lewd visual novel in three acts. You'll spend your time looking for clues , attempting to solve three separate mystery's that reveal an overarching plot. Although it is possible to ignore or skip though the dialogue the player is rewarded for paying attention and overall pays to a better experience with the game.

[b] Art style [/b]
Despite the fact that on first glance, the art may appear minimalist, it serves well to the games style and is clearly a labour of love. Each character has a unique and memorable design that pops and the lewd scenes are beautifully illustrated and animated. The hand drawn characters are contrasted to a 3D rendered background that initially, was jarring but slowly grew on me as I spent further time with the game. Whilst strange at first, the simplicity of the rendered backgrounds works in its favour, enhancing the colourful pop art style of the game.

[b] Lewd Scenes [/b]
As mentioned above , the lewd scenes expectantly , contain some of the best drawn scenes in the game. Most of the scenes are still images with small changes to match dialogue and infer action , but there is a larger portion than I had expected that were animated. Unlocking the entire scene gallery takes multiple playthroughs, and is something to be aware of if you enjoy being able to view the entire gallery. The lewd scenes, much like the game itself, manage to carry with them an overt sense of humour that does not detract  and in most cases compliments the moment.

[b] Plot [/b]
The narrative is by far, one of the best I have seen in a lewd game as of late. It's rare to find time and effort put into a lewd game to this extent let alone such careful steps taken with the world. I significantly enjoyed my time immersed within the stories and the characters. Both kept my attention well , and I found myself caught off guard at times by some of the narrative turns that were taken. The main character has an interesting gimmick that blends well into the overarching plot and gameplay to keep the player immersed. The humour employed was entertaining and worked well for the world they had created.

[b] Voice Acting [/b]
There isn't too much to say in this segment. The voice acting that the game has is of a high quality for a game of this size and a game of this price. It can be a little repetitive at times due to some phrases being repeated when talking to characters but its mostly able to be ignored. My largest criticism, when at first I playing through the story, the narrator would be jarring enough in quality drop in comparison to the rest of the voice acting cast that I would be immediately brought out of any level of immersion I was experiencing. Fortunately their voice lines are far enough between that it rarely comes up. It needs to be said that although the quality difference may be obvious they are still clearly trying and do a good job regardless.

[b] Final Notes [/b]
I usually review games with the idea of their achievements or collectables in mind and although disappointingly, there were none to be found here , I still greatly enjoyed my time with this game and would recommend it to anyone looking for a quality lewd game. It's a labour of love and it clearly shows as you playthrough what it has to offer. I look forward to what this developer has to offer in the future and future exploration into this world of theirs!

I'll be honest here. I've never given the time of day to play a visual novel, let alone an 18+ one. It was one of those genres of games where I didn't get the appeal at first.

But after playing [i] Erotic Justice [/i] after a recommendation from a friend, I can happily confirm that Erotic Justice is a great time through and through! The dialogue is written very well. The characters designs are top notch (big ups to Teliodraw and Ringumu for bringing these characters to life). The voice acting in this game is really good. The music smooths the senses. Some of the detective work makes you feel like you're an actual detective! And of course, the sex scenes are very... well, erotic! Some of the sex animations are animated well, too! Not to mention, this game is hilarious! You'll be horny while having a good laugh by the time you reach the credits!

Needless to say, [i] Erotic Justice [/i] was a lot of fun and a great entry point for those wanting to jump into the world of VNs! I wholeheartedly recommend it to those wanting to get down and dirty while also have a laugh along the way!

As of now, quite the narrow gap separates this "recommended" rating from a "not recommended" one. This free game doesn't yet feature all modes, classes, etc. it seemingly will have, but it already has a surprisingly high amount of weapons - all food-themed, too. Interestingly, it even features both a Vampire Survivors-esque timed mode and a Brotato-inspired round-based one, though the latter doesn't feel as polished or well-designed all in all. There isn't anything blatantly wrong with the game, hence the narrow recommendation of mine, though it does feel a little slow and enemy variety is pretty low, rendering the matches a bit repetitive. There's also no permanent upgrades or anything of the sort yet, thus after beating both modes once I felt like I saw most everything. I plan on revisiting the game in the future because there's some quality in here that can be iterated upon.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
The Sweetest Ring is a linear visual novel.

[h1]Story[/h1]
You were finally able to purchase one of the new 3D TVs due to it being on sale, at a massive discount. You don't have to wear glasses to get the 3D effect. Unfortunately, even on sale, the TV cost a lot of money and you only had enough left to purchase a 3D movie from the discount bin. When you get your purchases home and get everything connected you put your new movie in. At first you think it is broken, as all you get is snow on the screen. Then a long haired girl crawls out of the screen, these 3D effects are just amazing. You back up and move around the room. Sayako, the girl, tells you that she's coming to kill you. It's just a movie‚Ä¶until she touches you.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Eventually you get to the point where you introduce yourself to Sayako and enter your name. I use the space bar to advance the text, so I didn't notice until the cursor started moving. This is the only interaction you have with the game.

The English is good. I didn't notice any spelling or grammar issues.

[h1]The Gallery[/h1]
There are seven scenes in the Gallery, which is accessed from the title or save menu. All of them are images from NTR scenes, without the text. The one scene with you and Sayako isn't in the gallery.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
This is an short NTR game. The concept is interesting, you release a girl's ghost from a cursed video disc and end up in a relationship with her‚Ä¶then she finds your porn.

[h1]Cucked by The Ring[/h1]
[b]The Sweetest Ring[/b] is an NTR-oriented VN about a guy who meets Sadako, a ghost girl residing in the cursed video he tested his brand-new TV with, and eventually marries her. However, boredom pushed Sadako to explore the protagonist's DVD collection, unaware of the sexy fun times that awaited her in that unmarked DVD.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3168746029
It's similar to [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Nikkunamesu/recommended/2358490]Goblin Down[/url] as it's also a short kinetic novel that you can beat in under an hour. Even so, the story is entertaining from the beginning to the end because of the sheer absurdity of the plot. For starters, the only reason the protagonist wasn't scared of her when they met was because he mistook her for some hyperrealistic effects he imagined his new TV had, utterly shocking her. What's more, her interactions with the many porn movies she goes in are hilarious as she sometimes isn't aware of what she got into, and other times she does what it takes to alter it just enough to get herself rawdogged.

On another note, the game's visuals are nothing short of beautiful as Sadako's character sprite and the many CGs with her in it are gorgeous, the glitchy effects used at the start of the VN are top-notch, and all sex scenes are nicely animated. As for the sex scenes, it has the usual stuff you'd expect: blowjobs, facials, group sex, etc, while also featuring a scene in which the protagonist sees his wife take a pounding like a champ.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3168801055
[h1]Verdict: Decent[/h1]
Some may find The Sweetest Ring too short for its price, but the quality of the visuals and how fun its plot is justifies getting it at full price. If a bite-sized NTR kinetic visual novel is what you're looking for, then consider giving it a shot.

The game itself involves the well-known scene where the girl from a horror movie comes out of the TV screen. More specifically, the meme or fantasy where the scary girl turns out to be a very hot chick. Since you play a dummy who think this whole thing looks so real because of the new TV with the latest 3D technology, you take advantage of it for your personal pleasure.

The game doesn‚Äôt take long and there are no decisions. It‚Äôs just a short story that can be experienced in a single sitting.

I applaud the novelty and the boldness to do something differently, but I don't think the game lives up to its potential.

This is a text mystery game. It plays by you clicking on objects or locations and getting new options or items to use, which lets you progress and make choices and discover different endings to the mystery. 

Sounds good really. But it wasn't interesting enough, it wasn't clear enough what the options were, and in general I'm not one to replay the same exact story just to get a different ending.

It's cheap so I'd say give it a shot for yourself, it might click better with you.

Absolutely loved this game! I've been playing it for quite a while now. It's got a bit of a spooky and challenging vibe, but those jump scares are an absolute blast. Would like to play see more levels in the future!

It's interesting, unique, and pretty cheap. Basically a point and click adventure game without graphic, so there's no pixel hunt, just puzzle solving and investigation. Even if you're not going to deep dive into every individual cases and try to unlock their every endings, it's worth it even if you're just going to try every provided mysteries once for the uniqueness of the concept, but if you do want to explore the each mysteries deeper, there's a lot of time you can spend here.

I have not played any text-based games in years, and this is honestly a diamond in disguise. 

Apparently it was translated to English not too long ago, so you cannot find many information in this language (google translate can work its magic on that!), but do not focus on that and explore the game itself.

There are 3 main stories, and lots more that can be accessed through the workshop (may be in Chinese though). Many possible scenarios, almost each move creates a new branch in the story line, with each story getting more deep and intricate. 

Some achievements are easy to get by progressing through the story and unlocking ends, some others require repetition.
An interesting way to play a text-based game. The mysteries are interesting. You can make and play created levels besides the basic ones too.

Honestly, this game is weird and confusing. Somehow, it's still really entertaining? Kind of like a visual novel,  without the visual part? I still don't quite understand how certain decisions lead to the results I get, but it's fun.

At first I was interested in this game because it seemed to be an interesting story exploration. I played the tutorial and the first proper level. Playing the first level took a little more time than playing the tutorial and after that I was told that there are 7 endings for the first level. I managed to get 4 which are easy and then just tried getting different endings for about 20 minutes but all I did in the end is replay the level with the same outcome. It's like 'sing me a song but if you fail a note I won't tell you which one it was so keep trying'.
Secrets in other games are hidden on a map where you can search for them without punishment if you fail. You walk by you can come back. In this game it feels like secrets are hidden in time which sounds cool but if you miss it you have to redo the entire sequence. The first time on the proper level I got to a garden and vaguely remembered how I started the level but I could never get back to it.
UI is fine, controls are fine, concept is interesting but the content just didn't work for me.

It's very interesting but the bgm quite creepy XD
Multiple choices to explore, but can we have a checkpoint somewhere?

All the discussion posts are Chinese too (except for, like, 4 English ones and a single one that I can't recognize.) So, yeah, the game is not English friendly. But it does have English built in, so it isn't keeping you out. All in all, seems like a great game. I just wish I could learn to use the level editor.

For all the underwhelming programming that I experienced in this game, I see a lot of good ideas overshadowed by a junky design, if anything the game lacks polish more than it lacks vision, if you clean up the game and adjust how you build the tension, it could go from being "whatever" to being pretty good. As I was playing I constantly felt like it reminded me of Puppet Combo games, and then I realized it is actually listed as the inspiration, so I am like ah, now it makes more sense, and honestly, even if you just did more testing to fix the technical issues and improve the slower parts of the game when building that atmosphere, I think it would not be that far away from the Puppet Combo, you like 60% there, which may not sound like a complement, but it's not that I didn't like the experience overall, I think you got a lot of smaller moments wrong, not the overall feel of the story.

Obviously, there are a lot of technical issues, I am sure you are already aware of those, you can definitely improve on making better hotspots, like trying to put the stool at the right angle or grab the powder next to the door, just overall finding the correct place to interact was a consistent problem within the game. On that note, since the save system is a bit unpredictable, I wish you gave us some unlockable chapters as well. 

To be honest, I am not a huge fan of the whole "stalker" trope, it's almost a subgenre of horror games now, so many of them, sometimes it's a coffee place, sometimes it's a gas station, or something else, but always with the same premise. That said, using the whole survival-horror aesthetic instead of doing it first person is a welcome change, and I think you did enough foreshadowing to actually reflect on the first several days and realize there were constant clues. I think the second half of the game worked a lot better, I enjoyed the vibes a lot more from the start of the party and all the way toward the end, and I think it even had a few neat moments that can get your attention. There were a few moments that I think you could have done better, for example, the first time you see him over the fence (2 of them actually), I don't think they work that well because you just show his model from a distance, maybe if you at least gave him a better entry into the scene, make him show up the first time from a camera angle you can't see, and then make him follow you, with a nice subtle jump scare. Whenever you let the player have a good look at the killer and realize it's just a model it will hurt the suspense, that is something I think you need to work around, or at least use those moments more sparingly. I also think you could give him a nice sound effect of screaming when he gets hurt by a knife.

I usually love tank controls and fixed camera angles, although this game was not the best representation of this craft. I will say that I liked some of the perspective changes, like the following camera in the long corridor, you are getting some of them correctly, but I think mixing them poorly with open areas where you were unable to create those long shots was not working in your favor, perhaps a bird view perspective would have worked better there - it's almost like you have a bad habit of placing the camera a bit too low if that makes sense. Maybe if you had more narrow locations you could get more creative with them, you know like the alley camera follow in Silent Hill, something like that, open area, but give yourself some objects to work with.

[h1] Pros: [/h1]

(+) To be fair I think the game got my attention a few times, not always for the right reasons, but I liked some of the silly and edgy moments in the narrative. I also liked some of the foreshadowing which was not apparent until I completed the game. I do think the slow burn with the boring tasks is a nice element for a game like this, I just think you made them a bit clunky so it was hard to focus on the atmosphere. 

(+) You not getting the fixed camera angles as well as I would like, but there were occasional locations where it looked a lot better, like the corridor or the church. I mean, maybe just go back to those classics and pay attention to where they place the camera relative to the character, sometimes I felt like you placed it too low or not showing the angle that I needed to see. 

(+) The game has some multiple endings, I didn't do all of them. A few optional things as well.

[h1] Feedback: [/h1]

I kind of already mentioned it in the review, but obviously, the technical issues, make the hotspots easier to use, and make the walking a bit easier so she does not stagger as often. Some of the camera angles look good and others feel like you had no idea where to place the camera, maybe it was too low sometimes, I think whenever you would place a fixed angle it would feel better like that shot in the corridor with doors or the church. When it comes to the killer, you probably want to avoid giving the player that feel like he is a model in the distance, there has to be a better way to use him, maybe if he would appear over the fence with a jump scare, and then he would chill around. I felt like he needed a sound effect for getting hurt when you cut him.

Another small thing, sometimes you would have dark corners or angles with low detail, my thought on this is that surface with a texture will always look better, you can still make it low res and dark, but whenever I feel like something has nothing there, to me it feels like more cutting corners on not adding detail, so I always want to see a bit of extra effort there and make sure I can see the design of the room.

[b] Overall Thoughts: 6/10 [/b]

Honestly, the game didn't make a good first impression, and there were many clunky moments, but I still see some redeeming qualities, keep working on it, and don't neglect the interactive side of the game so I am not there for 20 minutes trying to pick up the item, and just be more careful with those "killer appearance moments" so you not draining the tension. With a bit more practice, I think you could make games of similar quality to Puppet Combo. 

[code]Niche, obscure and underrated games: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31294838-Hidden-Gem-Discovery/ [/code]

Good PSX-like horror game, I would have liked it to be longer but on the other hand its price is very good.
The first half does an excellent work in creating a very tense atmosphere that works perfectly as a build-up for what it's going to happen. The actual gameplay is kinda janky but still manageable. I appreciated how the developer was very quick to fix and address bugs and suggestions.

It is notable that the game also acts as a social commentary, depicting, between crudeness and satire, the hardships that women have to face not only in extreme cases (like with the game's stalker/killer), but also in daily life with "normal" men.
This creates a sick and disturbing atmosphere that permeates every moment of the game, blurring the line between horror and realism (also accentuated by the lines you see during loading time and when you die, lines that are depressingly familiar and still too much common).

Pros:
-It's edgy/ironic in its presentation, but not controversial. All the points are pretty agreeable: Women aren't believed when they're assaulted, women are disproportionately Harassed on the job, lesbians are called terrible things by incels that cant frick em, Etc‚Ä¶
-From what I read on the devs patreon, the art isn't AI. It's all scanned copies of the devs actual art, and It's all pretty unique.
-The price to content ratio can't be beat
Cons:
-The game has a slow-burn start. There is foreshadowing etc that the beginning levels set up, but it doesn't get dark until the later half of the game.
-The Stationary cameras suck at default settings.
-The tank controls suck at default settings.
-The launch bugs weren't great‚Ä¶ but they seem to have been fixed mostly
-Optional content, but lacking lore

For the Devs:
Polish polish polish. You seem to have done a few rounds of updates and you've gotten a better game out of every one. Why didn't you start with more play tests instead of jumping the gun on release? Also there's a bug where the bathroom door won't open unless you exit to main and relaunch after you find something in the tub.

For the players:
If you're looking for an edgy commentary on how women are treated when they're attacked, this is your jam. Heed the game's initial launch warning, however. It is definitely for mature audiences.

I've heard rumours that it's not Twitch TOS safe, but from what I've read that's not true as long as you have a mature content warning, because it's just naked art on the wall.

There are 4 different endings you can get in the game. I got 1. The feminine rage ending is damn cathartic for survivors. You can tell the developer gave every ounce of her own rage when writing it. That doesn't mean it won't be uncomfortable, but there's something special about a game that can make you feel so deeply. Props to the dev for being so vulnerable and saying what nobody else will. I hope they make their social media public again when they realise they're safe <3

I have some gripes but for a ¬£1.69 game, it was very very good and with a lot of content. Take the trigger warnings seriously, this is absolutely "Dark" romance that cannot be avoided in any playthrough, and the Devs were right to include the initial warning and disclaimer. Had me genuinely unsettled in some scenes, and even though the "timed" answers were a joke with the mousewheel allowing me all the time in the world to respond, I was quick saving like a huge coward. 

The writing is well done, albeit the stories are a little unimaginative. I like that it asked our genders and pronouns and disclaimed that they would be sexualised - it's a spoiler, somewhat, but I appreciate it being there to protect people's comfort with gender dysphoria. The art, whilst sometimes crude, changed perfectly for a little psycho and matched the tone well when they "snapped". 

It's not perfect, of course. It's cheap, so there's no voice acting. The menu to save and load is a nightmare and you're constantly trapped in a loop unless you press escape. There's broken achievements, so you cannot 100% this right now (unless you used an achievement manager like some people have). There's "achievements" and endings in the game that don't have achievements on steam, and it's inconsistent. Probably most people won't notice that, but I wrote a guide the entire time I played it, so I did notice. They also have barely any CGs and the CG slots they do have are repeated in both routes - I wouldn't have cared if there was simply less to unlock, but having multiple blank unlockables that turned out to be the same exact image felt really boring and disappointing considering how much I was enjoying them.

I also think the game itself is way too weighted towards Jak, but he's apparently a character in another game not yet on steam, so whilst I felt he was too focused on for nothing special, I can understand a good call-back getting more endings than the character I preferred - Wade. 

This flew under the radar for most and was released on steam with very little fan-fare because it was released on itch.io previously. Very reminiscent of Amnesia: Memories and Toma's route in that, and there's so many dead ends that it also reminds me of First Bite, only a lot cheaper. Regardless, I enjoyed my time with this and I'm absolutely going to buy their next game.

A classic platformer with interesting mechanics and unique level design resulting in a fun and entertaining gameplay experience. The tether mechanic is well done and fun to play with, and levels are challenging but not frustrating.

Good fun flying across levels and solving puzzles

Pros
- gameplay mechanics are solid and fun
- swinging on the tether and releasing it to yeet across the level
- engaging puzzles to solve, running away from vines and dodging bad guys
- lore collectables available for more challenge
- game is a lot more relaxing than I would have expected

Cons
- tutorial is a little long and difficult, the game gets more interesting afterward, starting in chapter 3
- some levels are visually confusing when you first load into them

For those of you that miss those old platforming flash games look no farther. While the game is in Early access the only thing early access about it is the art. The platforming is fun and engaging and the story slowly unfolds while you adventure! The levels vary in difficulty, but I haven't felt any rage or unfairness in the game.

Perfect to speed run or relax with!
Game has fun movement mechanics. The music is chill. Recommended if you like platformers and or speed running.
Challenging, interesting little platformer. I'm still early in it but I think it's going to be a lot of fun once I get the controls down.

I like playing this game, it is easy to get started, but still challenging.  I am used to console games, and its been easy to transition into playing this.  Fun to play. Clean and safe for all thanks guys! Definitely recommend!

Extremely fun and additive game play for the competitive player with an adorable overall design.  And the dev team is really quick and responsive with updates for any bugs found.  Overall a solid first game for a budding company!

This game is a fun platformer with an intriguing story to keep you going. One of its primary mechanics is a cool tether to let you swing around levels and an addition that I think many platformers haven't used before as far as I know. The level of difficulty for levels at times can rival that of other high intensity platformers so if those are something you like this will likely be up your alley.

pros:

-Developement team is always looking for feedback from players on ways to improve the game
-Fun tether mechanic that makes swinging across levels a blast
-Challenging levels that can have you racing to the end 
-Ratings at the end of levels so if you think you can do better you have a reason to go back and better your score

Cons:

-Graphics (I would like to preface this by saying I was a play tester before it was on Steam, and even since it's release to early access the graphics have been improving immensely and I'm sure it will keep getting better with time)
-Music (depending on length of playtime soundtrack can feel a bit repetitive)

A challenging but fair platformer that will force you to master the tools at your disposal. Very rewarding and fun level design. The tether mechanic and the wall jump take some getting used to, but add some unique flavor to the game once it "clicks".

This is a game made by people who are honing their craft, and their passion shows. The mechanics are frenetic, the level design goes from brain melting to freewheeling to breakneck, and the tree guy is a huge sassy bitch. 5 Stars.

I could have easily overlooked Kaeli in the myriad of games, but am glad I didn't.
The tether option makes it different than most platforms, Challenging yet fun.
I like that a level can be solved more than one way, continuously adds unique challenges, puzzles and dangers throughout
Lots of play time. I would definitely recommend you give it a try.

I enjoyed my short time with this game. I am not usually a platformer-type gamer, but this one had enough unique mechanics to keep it more interesting than just running and jumping. 

Starting out, I took me a tiny bit to get used to the control scheme. They're not bad or unfamiliar, but I did not realize I could change the keybinds until I was nearly 45 minutes in (I kept clicking on the leaf with the key instead of the leaf stating the action). Changing my tether to my mouse helped me get farther, but I think that is because of my FPS-goober brain.

The music was good enough for the duration I played, but I hope more tracks come with future updates! The audio options are more robust than I thought they would be by having multiple sliders for master, music, hostiles, game.

Graphics are good and the aesthetics are cool. I dig the different environments and having the objectives fit/change with the setting is a nice touch. The menu feels like a 'ye olde' flash game and I hope to see it evolve. That being said, I don't exactly know if that is the style, but the text is affected by this, so it could be difficult for some to read certain prompts or story beats.

Overall, the game will improve in time and more will be added, but it gave me a good first impression. I'll have to get this installed on my Steam Deck and see how well it works on the go!
