Take my words with a grain of salt till the developer spends some more time optimizing the game and more updates come out. I'm just posting my impressions and thoughts.

I'll be honest, this game conceptually absolutely rocks and is right up my alley. It's like if someone said decided to fuse Devil May Cry's combat and the Atelier series' aesthetics and visual design, with hints of NIS and the Tales games. There's also the fact that this is free, to which my experience freeplay games on Steam aren't always the best, so this came as a surprise. I love Character Action Game style titles and this scratches an oddly specific but still enjoyable itch. Good on the dev, I would pay for more stuff like this.

As of when this review is posted, the game is getting continual updates that increase its stability. I've played so far only on Steam Deck and its slowly eased out over time, although it's still a bit of a roulette when the game will croak. I've had some issues with the menus and viewing certain things like moves and so on, so I'd hope that's fixed soon. 

All in all though, I would say that this game looks damn cool, and its got a quality charm to it with the amount of stuff right out the gate like voice-acting, a style meter, turbo mode, etc. Try it out once the developer cleans up it after awhile, it's a pleasant, if small (and kinda shaky) surprise.

As it says in the title, this game is a prototype and as such is rough around the edges and understandably might have some bugs here and there as well. While the prominent things that happened to me were mainly just the characters getting stuck in places and having to reload old save files, it's clear that this game still needs some time to cook and work out its kinks. Once it does work out said kinks, this honestly has a lot of potential. Between the beautiful world design, realistic and heartfelt story/dialogue and a combat system that has a lot of depth to it (none of which I found myself really able to fully grasp honestly), this is a game that's worth keeping an eye on as it continues to get updated.

[THE THUMBS DOWN IS ONLY FOR THE TECHNICAL BUGS, NOT THE ACTUAL GAMEPLAY]

The game's UI, character design, artwork, music, action, and environments are all charming and I really want to like this game but the software itself really needs heavy working on. 

It's basically a roll of the dice what goes wrong with each time I restart the game
-Sometimes the music doesn't play at all
-Sometimes the game chugs a bunch during combat
-It never seems to remember whenever I change the inputs or audio volume, every time I either load a save or start a new game, the controls go back to default
-When I press A to show the full dialogue in the text box, it ends the voice audio. Sometimes it doesn't even advance the dialogue but it still ends the voice audio.
-The list of places that the game's stopped responding from both controller and keyboard/mouse range from in the "skip cutscene" confirmation box, in the change input menu, way too many times in post-battle rating screen, etc.

game 200/20
quality of life 0/20
an incredible and complete game, but with a lot of bad things in UI and keyboard play (Play with the controller!).
how can this game be so under-represented?

This is a neat little demo, with a nice graphical direction, two well fleshed out characters for how little of the game exists so far, and some fun combat.  The art style is pretty without being overbearing, the effects look nice even if it's hard for me to tell what kind of attack the enemy is trying to use.  The environment is needlessly large, and the very indistinguishable environmental objects make it easy to get turned around from a camera reset after battle.  The main character is given enough dialogue to make a very "ragna the bloodedge" kind of character, at least from the initial look at her, and the slime friend cements their role as a silent companion foil to the talkative protagonist.  The voice acting is well done, though the battle voice lines are a bit too frequent with how basic attack heavy the game seems to be.  On the topic of combat, it feels really good when you're on the offensive.  There's very little feedback when you hit something making the combat feel floaty, but the basic attack chain is satisfying.  Being able to reposition as needed during it or interrupt with special attacks gives the feeling that you should always be basic attacking, using specials and charge attacks when you feel it would help when you need to stunlock something.  Being able to dodge mid combo without interrupting but also dodge at the end of a combo to remove end lag feels really good, partially because it feels rewarding to learn when to dodge to maximize that sweet sweet DPS, but it doesn't feel excessively punishing to miss the window.  Defensive combat gets a lot more rough, unfortunately.  If you get knocked up at all, there's not really anything you can do, no dodging out of laying on your butt and no invulnerability frames when you're waiting to stand up.  For slower line AoEs, this can lead to you getting juggled across the battle arena from full to dead, which would be less of an issue if it wasn't for the needlessly complex warning system.  As of right now, enemies flash one of four colors to indicate what they're going to do, and keeping track of this while maintaining your attacks is certainly a system that's learnable, but the colors can be very difficult to see amidst all the particles from your own attacks.  While this may encourage a more reaction based playstyle, every other aspect of combat promotes extreme aggression.  

Overall, I'm excited to see how this project turns out.

The only game breaking bug I found was an issue where I paused the game and it wouldn't accept any other inputs, just after the tutorial fight but before being told our little slime friend had joined the party

Aside from some minor technical issues like menu names buggering up, it seems most of the bugs have been fixed, hence why I gave the game another go as of late.

First of all, I love the aesthetic and tone. Yelette is a wonderfully fun character. She absolutely reeks of early 2000s deviantArt edgy JRPG OC energy‚Äîshe's the "Lord of Nightmares" and has a single black wing that pops out for special attacks, for crying out loud‚Äîbut she's also keenly aware of this, even having pages in her journal dedicated to awful one-liners and phrases to say to her enemies to sound cool. They do not sound cool at all; they are too long and lack eloquence and flow, and my trained literary eye does not determine these flaws to be on purpose. However, since Yelette trying too hard to be cool is part of her character, it actually turns out to work, so props to the devs.

I like her monologues. I love her awesome clothes. I even like the brief interactions she has with others that make her seem gracious and good-natured without being an idiot that makes a fool out of herself, nice social traits that a lot of JRPG heroes of the early 2000s lacked. I especially like that she's a world-saving hero and this lil' prototype is about her on a fetch quest for the sake of her sister. Yelette takes it all in stride and it's fun. She is the sort of character that I've come to want to know more about just from reading about her journal entries. I'm captivated.

Combat's not bad but it needs an overhauled control scheme. I see the [u]Devil May Cry[/u] influences clear as day but these bloody direction-sensitive controls aren't working for me and I can't pull off the attacks I'm trying to pull off. What [b]especially[/b] doesn't work is the tutorial system. I do not care who you are; I am not going to start a game and patiently read and try to memorise [b]nine pages of basic combat mechanics[/b]. I'm especially not going to do that for six tutorials in a row! Please, tutorialise us on mechanics [i]as we are introduced to them[/i], not all at once. We also need examples, because a lot of the mechanics do not make sense upon first reading.

Sadly, I found myself losing interest rapidly after a certain point. I gathered all the ingredients, returned to camp, and was graced with a long cutscene before something happened and I was taken straight to a boss fight. I don't know why I couldn't have been made to travel there, perhaps save my game and prepare my equipment and perhaps do anything else that I wanted to do beforehand because the autosaves don't work right, because now I was up against a boss that was killing me in a single hit and I didn't know what I was doing. I'm not particularly invested in the idea of going back.

It would be nice if we could jump around the world map. There are times when I'd like to jump up and down a ledge or a slope or over a fence without having to need to run around it. This would also open up the world design a bit and make exploring more fun. That said, I think there might be a crafting system and that fills me with dread. I don't like crafting systems in general but that's not helped at all by the game's user interface, which requires me to make a few too many clicks just to navigate menus; there's an awful lot of going in and out of menus that I'd rather not do. 

Speaking of, when the game starts, you're introduced to the Options menu. It would be nice if the top left of the screen wasn't covered by a "Start game" button so I could see what's being obscured under there because I figure it could be important. Heck, the first time I played, I skipped it because I thought "I'll just get to the area map and go back to the Options menu from there and figure it out". Then I had to go through two cutscenes, a tutorial fight (complete with the nine pages mentioned above), and then TWO MORE CUTSCENES before I could finally access the Options menu again. Like I said with the boss fight above, it could've helped if I could've travelled a bit between the two cutscenes so that I had a moment to get my bearings in-game.

[u]Horizon to Crinoa[/u] has a strong foundation for its writing and tone. It's the mechanics and programming that most concern me. But I am eager all the same to see where this goes.

I think this game is generally pretty solid. The gameplay is great, the story is decently good so far, and the complaints I do have are mostly directed at some bugs and general 'scaling'.
As somebody who doesn't fight literally everything in my path, the Chilchek fight felt awkward, since they would constantly two-shot me. On top of that, I'm not sure if it's a bug or otherwise, but there were times in that fight where I would be stuck dashing in a single direction and starting the animation for Ragna Blade. Apart from that fight, the audio mixing is a little weird, with the magic activation noise being incredibly loud compared to just about everything else, apart from more minor things.
Overall though, I'm giving this a positive because I'd genuinely love to see where this game goes in the future, and I'll keep my eye on it for its high potential.

Okay so I'm going to redo the first half of this review because the more I play the more I have to say.

This game has one major problem that is less of a "early access" problem and more of a "design direction" problem. I understand wanting a complex combat system, but the combat is far too flashy and fast paced to have all the systems going on at once that it does. When I saw the combat tutorial 3 and all of the 10 pages of colored enemy flashes, types of cancels, strange parry terms that seem overly complicated when simplified terms that are more understandable would work, etc. I realized that the devs are overly bloating the combat system.

This is a problem because, even in the combat in which that tutorial appeared for me, even SEEING red flashes from an enemy would have been impossible. The enemy is a red slime with big red visual effects that would easily disguise anything like that. Between that and all of the special effects on the main character's attacks and the extremely fast pace of combat this game is borderline impossible beyond mashing buttons and hoping.

This is not helped by the fact that enemies are damage sponges and you are DEFINITELY not. I have gone from full health to 0 in a single combo against basic enemies. I'm not saying you can't have a complex combat system, but if you do it needs to be slowed down a bit, particularly on the part of the enemies, and visuals need to be cleaned up enough to be able to SEE the complex visual indicator system and tell the difference between what is a visual effect of an attack and what is a notification of an attack.

I think a good solution would be to reserve the flashy effects for big important moves. Look towards games like Sekiro, for instance. It has a pretty simple enemy indicator system, but it's easy to visually see and stands out starkly, plus the only big flashy effects are your special attacks and most enemies' attacks pause with the indicator before unleashing the move. Perhaps this is happening in this game, but if it is, it's too difficult to tell against two red slimes with red attack visuals and red indicators overlapping one another.

I do still like the concept of this game and I think this is very impressive for a new developer. The animation and effects look nice, the voice acting is surprisingly good, it looks very nice and animates well, there's just a number of more mechanical issues the game has that I think go beyond simply not being finished yet and more are problems of visual design and some of the chosen direction. I do also think perhaps narrowing down the amount of cancels in the game would be very beneficial... having four types of cancel is a bit much. It's somewhat reminiscent of DmC Devil May Cry having two dodges, which was interesting in concept but in execution it was needlessly complicated and one of them was objectively better.

This is clearly a new developer and they're getting the ropes, so I won't admonish these issues. Especially since what /is/ here is interesting, even in the current state. There is some level of it being a rather typical anime arpg, very reminiscent of the Tales series, but I think this game has a lot of potential to put its own twist on the genre as a lot more action focused.

Also, it's free, it's not like they're ripping people off for an underbaked game. 

I really, really want to see this game polished up and finished, and then see what the full version brings.

This section is for the devs, this is a list of the things I noticed in my brief play of the game that need to be addressed organized neatly for you to have as helpful feedback:

- Constrain mouse to window.

- Hide cursor during gameplay.

- The UI for the controls menu is on top of the actual keybind menu, making them overlap and making it difficult to read some things.

- I would map the escape key to be how you open the menu personally, or at least make it the pause key, since P is fairly unintuitive.

- Some audio doesn't seem to be properly linked to its slider, such as the sound when you complete an objective which blew my ears out despite me having everything turned way down, no slider seems to change it, either. Many combat sound effects and victory noises and such fall into this category.

- Mouse doesn't work with some of the menu, forcing you to use arrow keys to change categories and such.


I know some of that is KB+M specific and this game is largely designed controller first, but the cursor issue at least needs to be addressed since it means KB+M players in windowed mode or with multi-monitor setups just cannot play this game at all, which is unfortunate.

I hope to see this game polished up and see what comes of it!

This game has a lot of bugs. There's a lot of forced encounters, but those encounters assume that you have been killing literally everything you come across, or else you just die and reload the last save you made... (there is no autosave!!)


- The audio cannot be muted or lowered for some sounds. there are SEVERAL sounds that are just really loud.

- I cheesed all my battles by turbo spamming right click and doing the despair flash ability to kill everything instantly. that is AFTER being stun locked multiple times and dying in one hit to some random ability

- I don't think the EP meter updates visually? I can do skills when its empty

- I got stuck in the results screen and I could turn in it?? 

- I got stun locked and died in a battle with a bunch of slimes after getting knocked down once..

- I came across some random sword at lv 5 and it teleported me to a VERY hard boss battle that one hits me. Why is that enemy there? Theres nothing harder than a level 5 slime around me at all times...

- I died DURING the beginning combat cutscene with that water jelly lady, It switched me to the jelly dude and he just got blown up immediately. 

- There is no autosave in the game. There needs to be one if you are just randomly throwing the player into a battle they are not prepared for.

- The game's help shows something about an adjustable difficulty setting but its simply just "not available" in the menu

- Why is there a sun lens flare in the cave?

The art is nice and the voice acting is serviceable. Maybe if the bugs are fixed, the game would be worth playing through, but the amount of bugs and weird game design decisions in this game makes it not fun to play.

Peanut Butter Kiss Cookies

Ingredients

    1 cup peanut butter
    1 cup sugar
    1 large egg, room temperature
    1 teaspoon vanilla extract
    30 milk chocolate kisses

Directions

Preheat oven to 350¬∞. Cream peanut butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in egg and vanilla.
Roll into 1-1/4-in. balls. Place 2 in. apart on ungreased baking sheets. Bake until tops are slightly cracked, 10-12 minutes. Immediately press 1 chocolate kiss into center of each cookie. Cool for 5 minutes before removing from pans to wire racks.

I commissioned some bunnies 2 is a fun find a bunny game

I believe this is #25 in the "I commissioned some..." series, and as the titles says, the 2nd where we have to find bunnies and carrots.

I prefer the releases that feature animals other than bees (though they're not bad) because they require artwork that blend animals... the games with bees "only" require little doodles that sometimes look like bees, sometimes not so much.

I've been excited for the release of this game for about a couple months, before the month delay, and now that I've played it I can say that excitement was justified. Don't get me wrong, this game isn't for everyone, but it's not supposed to be. It seems like the name is supposed to be a riff on only up, but that's honestly a disservice to this game. The platforms, while erratic and seemingly random, are chosen with care, from a sword resembling the goddess sword and energy sword, gems resembling the chaos emeralds, a donut you can jump through above a nuclear power plant, it was all put together with care, if not for the player. There are plenty of atmospheric effects, like wind, the skybox changing based on your height, lots of little attention to detail things. It's charming, and fun if you have an unnecessary amount of compulsion to play every car platformer on offer and can handle some frustrating falls.
Pretty fun, got alot of obstacles that make you think differents ways to do the jumps, got few problems with the camera but if you enjoy the platform and hill games, give this one a chance.

Get it if you‚Äôre a fan of the genre, but others need to stay away.

You don‚Äôt need to look twice at the images to realize the game falls into the rage platformer genre. The goal of these games is to climb up by jumping on random objects floating in the air. There are no save spots or checkpoints, and if you drop over the edge, you will fall all the way down. 

Since it‚Äôs losing popularity because they all look the same, developers try new ways to stand out. One of them is to replace the human characters with all kinds of other, more ridiculous options.

This game decided to use karts and bikes. Both have a variety of skins, but the impact is solely visual. However, because there are just two wheels instead of four, the bike feels a little simpler to handle on narrow platforms. Controls are standard for a driving game, which means platforming is complicated.

You have the following controls: throttle, brake, jump, and turbo. Because you can't easily turn your vehicle the way you can turn human characters, you'll have to tread carefully while using reverse and forward. Physics engine is generous so you won‚Äôt fall down because of a tiny bump. 

The low-poly graphics are pretty nice and objects don‚Äôt stand out due to different art style. The bad part is the camera. While the camera may be rotated around the car, it cannot be turned down or up. This makes it impossible to see where you‚Äôre going. Most of the time, you're forced to jump blindly and hope for the best.  

You‚Äôll either give it a go for five minutes or play it for hours until you get to the top.
Good game, entertaining, even better than only up xD

I play A LOT of simulator games, and I was pretty excited to give this one a chance. I thought it was a nice chance to watch videos while scanning items. I wasn't personally a fan of having to total the cost of all the items and looking back and forth constantly. The graphics are very pleasing, but doesn't quite make up for the lack of content overall. 

It would be interesting to have more work to do within the store as if you were the owner, like hiring employees, or even things like cleaning up if the floors were to get dirty. Small tasks like that would make it feel like draggy as you wait for customers to spawn and walk in.

I wouldn't buy it as is, but if they decided to add more features in the future, I think the game could have a lot of potential to be a really fun simulator game!

No, the screenshots of that game aren't from early development. That is the entire game. For $7 (on sale) this is possibly the worst paid game I have ever seen. 
You can see NPCs spawning and despawning from the shop window, and the stance they take and the way they walk shows they are either having a spasm attack, or as possessed by the devil.  
There is next to nothing to do, and each day is exactly the same, with the 'upgrades' actually making you earn less money and only filling the pathetic empty space. Some 'upgrades' don't do anything whatsoever.

Do you like watching youtube videos, but wish there was something that made you do simple mathematics every few minutes while staring at the latest cat videos?

Then look no further, as Cashier Simulator is the answer you're looking for!

Harnessing the incredible power of the Unreal Game engine, you are thrown into the dystopian nightmare of the retail industry in a world where a grocery store employee is, somehow, able to afford living on their own in an apartment without having 2 side hustles, and an and etsy shop selling homemade jewelry as you desperately try to fight off the disaster of the current global economy, and its treatment of the "unskilled labor force".

Is the game a job/career simulator? Not really. It is a resource management game? No (you *DO* have to stock the shelves, but that's just a simple task of walking to a shelf, pressing a single key, and the items are automatically placed perfectly). Is it a finance/investment simulator? Nope. The store will make $1 profit for every item sold as long as you add up the cost of the items correctly. The store doesn't have any expenses (so no electric bill, taxes, salary... anything...)

But oddly, if your looking for something to do while watching the best of twitch streams of games you enjoy playing... this is the answer you're looking for.

Lots of room for improvement... sadly, at this price point, I doubt we'll see any of them being implemented.

The game is boring and full of errors and bugs. You just buy a shelf, sell it, and return it to be refilled, and it has no goal of collecting money. It is very, very bad. I do not recommend buying it or even thinking about it.

I hope since I purchase they come with a update with new things. Then maybe I can change my out look of this game.

The game is a simulation where you play as a cashier in a supermarket. Your character doesn‚Äôt get hungry, fatigued, or need to use the restroom which is great. You start the game in your one-bedroom apartment and make your way across the street and down the alley to the shop that you run.

As you progress through the game, you can add more and more stock items for your customers to purchase. You can also add upgrade items such as a TV, which is a great feature that allows you to watch online videos or browse websites while playing the game. However, I do not recommend the chair upgrade as it gets in the way.

In my opinion, this game delivers exactly what it promises in the game description left by the developers on the product page on Steam. There are plenty of opportunities for future updates as well.

The game is currently priced at under ¬£6 on Steam, and I think it‚Äôs worth the asking price.

[b][i]Cool mystical first-person horror. You go to an abandoned village to find the missing girl.[/i][/b]

You need to explore a large location, pick up and use items, solve puzzles and run away from a creepy flying ghost.

I really liked that the game is bright and light. There is no darkness that strains the eyes. You don't have to run around with a flashlight and constantly look for/change batteries.

Progress is saved automatically. If you get killed by a ghost, you will not have to start from the very beginning.

+ Beautiful graphics and pleasant music.
+ Intriguing story and mysterious atmosphere.
+ Good optimization.
+ Jump scares, ghosts, bloody scenes.
+ Interesting puzzles.
+ Two endings.
+ There is no eye-straining darkness here.
+ There is the map and hint markers/text hints.
+ There are automatic saves.
+ Achievements.

This was a decent horror game that wasn't that scary and was interesting game on finding your girlfriend who was kidnapped by the grim reaper. There isn't anything too crazy though when it comes to details and it is a simplistic horror game such as scripted chases by the main antagonist and collecting things to progress. 

Other than that it was ok and I beat it in an under an hour 

https://youtu.be/aMDieSO-5eI

Cool indie horror game that can be finished in an hour.

The plot revolves around a man who receives an e-mail from a girl who was allegedly kidnapped. The communication includes certain coordinates and a codeword, leading you to believe it is serious. 

Although you reach the location by boat, the game doesn‚Äôt take place on an island or some remote place. If you glance at your map, which is always available and displays your current location as well as the next objective, you will notice that you came across a lake. Furthermore, the playing area is restricted by a short fence that might have been easily jumped over. But you quickly forget about that because the game manages to pull you in.

Controls are standard for a walking sim. You can only walk, run, jump, and interact with things. Since the map allows some freedom, there is a good chance you will miss certain interactions. Most provide only a short description, so you won‚Äôt miss much. There are also notes to read and jumpscares or visions. 

Occasionally, you will also encounter the game‚Äôs antagonist. He usually just shows up to scare you, but some scripted events force you to run away from him. These are rare and don‚Äôt ruin the game. Saving is automatic, so you won‚Äôt lose progress even if you fail.

Now, the game isn‚Äôt open in a way that you can explore the entire map right from the start. There are gates that prevent progress until you do what needs to be done in a certain area. Luckily, a visual hint points to important objectives. A few logic puzzles are easy and items are used automatically. If you want a more immersive experience, you can download a mod from the developer‚Äôs site that removes tips. 

The text is fine and doesn‚Äôt have any awkwardness. The only issue is the voice feature. It uses AI instead of real people, so everything sounds really weird.

[h1]Graphics aren't bad, but that's it.[/h1]

I was ready to praise this as a cute first attempt at a "game".  It has graphics and controls, and you can click on things.  Then I realized that this is (at least) the 10th game this guy has made in the past 5 years.  In that light, it's inexcusable for this to be so random and meaningless.

In this "game", you wander around and look for things to click on.  Then those things disappear and you wander around looking for other things.  When you click on those, they disappear too.  You will (temporarily) befriend such allies as an exploding pig, a flying suitcase, and a talking mushroom.  Eventually you will save your girlfriend and live happily ever after, or maybe not.

I don't want my $1.59 back because the guy made an effort and this is a smooth running and bug free experience, but it's neither a good game nor a good story, and I wish I hadn't wasted my time on it.  I think it's well past time for this dev to join a larger team with some decent creative direction where he can use his skills to help create something worthwhile.

Liquid Space is heavily inspired by Star Fox (in my opinion mostly Star Fox 64). Instead of being a one to one recreation of those games and their mechanics it adds neat elements on top. Weapon charging is a major factor in how you play Liquid Space. Next to your basic blaster you are given three different charge shots. A precise and penetrating long distance rifle shot, a spread out short distance shotgun burst shot and a 4x missile lock-on. It is relatively easy to spontaneously swap between them and utilise each for different situations. The shotgun burst is good for downing small enemy groups that are about to fly past you, focusing on this weapon leads to quick and hectic flying action that feels very satisfying in seeing dozens of enemies being wiped out in short succession. The rifle shot is great for sniping big and bulky units from far away and occasionally comes in handy to destroy barriers. It is slower to use but ends up being a great mixup that offers a short breather from the else often chaotic flying. I used the missiles less often, but they kinda bridge the two other charge shots. It takes a bit to get them prepared so they are not super fast paced, but they act as a diverse tool that can be effective against more spread out enemy groups than the relatively compact burst shot. Combined with a very agile ship that has the option to drift - basically instantly turn around in 360¬∞ combat or shift from one end of the screen to the other in on-rails mode - this game can be super fun to get good at.

All in all the core concept is good, but the execution has issues. The first thing I have to mentions is the feedback. Coming from Star Fox 1 or 64 or Zero I am spoiled by games that have very clear and crisp feedback on what's going on. Being shot at, being hit, locking on to enemies, hitting them, hitting ground, how far away you are from obstacles, which mode you are in, how fast you are flying. Liquid Space to me often felt very muted, as if I was playing with shades, mufflers and gloves. Music was blaring and stuff happened, but I did not feel connected to it. I regret not being able to phrase this better, but this is the part where I feel like this is early access. It's missing the juice!

Other than that I feel like the levels are very hit and miss. The tutorial and first levels are very easy, bordering on bland. I would suggest to stick with it until you reach the green acid planet, here I felt like the game gets it right. Exciting level design and a good challenge. The following level ramps it up a bit and has a few tough spots that in my opinion demand a bit too much from players who were not really forced or incentivized to engage with the drift mechanic up until that point. This culminates in a boss fight that got too frustrating for me and ended my first session there.

Overall if the bulk of the game felt as engaging as these two later stages, I might be looking forward to starting this game up again. It is afterall a score hunter. But as it stands I'm not terribly excited to try those early stages again.

Still, I draw a positive conclusion. Not the least because I am very interested in the Star Fox fan scene and most competitors get not just the juice and level design wrong but often even the basics like aiming, shooting and flying. In that regard Liquid Space is very competent and deserving of attention.

Liquid Space is an absolute marvel, leaving me utterly blown away by its narrative prowess. Without delving into specifics, the storyline unfolds like a celestial ballet, weaving an intricate tapestry of mystery and intrigue that had me on the edge of my seat throughout. The sheer depth of the narrative, coupled with unexpected twists and turns, evoked a sense of awe and wonder rarely experienced in gaming. The emotional resonance of the characters and the enigmatic universe they inhabit left me captivated, yearning for more with each passing revelation. Liquid Space isn't just a game; it's a testament to the power of storytelling in the gaming medium, a cosmic journey that has left an indelible mark on my gaming experience. I am, without a doubt, profoundly blown away by the narrative brilliance encapsulated in this extraordinary title.

Liquid Space is a low-poly space shooter with both on-rails and free-flight sequences that take a lot of cues from the SNES and N64-era Starfox games. It has colorful visuals and an interesting soundtrack, and the controls are mostly competent. It is however noticibly faster then Starfox, which creates some issues with the gameplay.

In addition, the game's difficulty curve is a 90 degree upwards right angle. The first five or so levels are very easy as compared to the game's inspirations, but my progress came to a screeching halt at the boss called the "Supreme Inhibitor", who throws a lot of geometric bullshit at you and is only vulnerable to damage for a few seconds after destroying small crystals that are blocked by said bullshit, which will also quickly shave off your health.

Overall the game feels a bit amateurish. If they give it a serious difficulty rebalance I'd be willing to give it another chance, but for now if you are looking for this kind of experience, EX-Zodiac might be more to your liking.

Arcade with cool music and colorful stages that don‚Äôt last long.

The game is quite retro. You play Sid, a space warrior who is fighting alone against the space tyrant. During what is supposed to be the final battle, Sid finds that the tyrant is virtually unbeatable and possesses enormous abilities capable of opening portals to other dimensions. When Sid is dragged through one and lands in an unknown world, he is greeted by a god who provides him with a new weapon to aid him in his struggle. 

The story is barebones. The prologue, which also serves as a tutorial, is where you‚Äôll get most of what you need to know. The main mode is actually pure arcade where you have a limited number of lives to get through seven stages in a linear order. There are only few bits of story in those stages and in the ending.

You take control of a fighter called Space Drifter. It plays like a standard action game. You can fly around, fire the main laser, and do a couple of acrobatic moves. The fighter will fire a burst when the laser button is held down for a second or two. The downside is that burst has a very short range. 

The other move is simply space drifting. It‚Äôs not as exciting as it sounds because it‚Äôs just a fancy mechanic to let you make faster turns. However, it also allows you to turn back, hover on the spot and take out enemies behind you. 

More advanced moves will have to be mastered in order to play the game efficiently. The roll is great while flying through narrow spaces, and it can advance into a barrel roll when you press the roll button twice. This is a crucial move because it is linked to two special weapons.

When you charge the laser and perform a barrel roll, you will either activate a precision laser beam that goes far and kills most targets with a single shot, or a swarm of torpedoes that will fly towards marked targets. The fire mode is determined by the barrel roll direction and fires only when you release the fire button.

A stage is typically divided into two sections. One is comparable to a rail shooter in that you fly forward on a predetermined course. You can still perform all of the movements, but you can't turn back. The second section is a free flight zone or an arena where you must complete a predetermined objective, such as destroy 10 enemy fighters. You can fly however you want in this zone, but you can‚Äôt leave the area.

The game is quite short. Although each stage is unique and features low-poly graphics that add a certain charm, they don't stay long. It's also very simple because there are no prerequisites to meet in order to pass a stage. There is a score system, but it is optional. Points are earned by collecting gold icons and destroying enemies, and it drops to zero when you are hit.

There are no extras unlocked after beating the game and no achievements.

In my opinion, this is a very boring janky low-budget third person indie shooter that should actually be free. Charging money for such crap is just wrong. To begin with, this game is poorly optimized with constant frame rate drops and there is only one graphic setting of low or high. You also cannot remap the controls, the fov is low and cannot be adjusted, there are no footstep sounds, shooting guns feels weak, and getting too close to some walls obstructs your view by placing your view behind these walls. The environment is also excessively dark and there is no gamma or brightness option. You can only see what's inside the small circle of light from the flashlight, which you constantly have to keep turning back on. The environments are also typical spaceship dark corridors that seem like a confusing maze that you aimlessly wonder through. There is also no single player campaign. You just go on roguelike runs in the same dull areas to collect resources. Zombies also constantly rush and corner you to where the mission ends in failure and you must then start that mission completely over. If this game was free then perhaps I could see some value as a time waster because that's precisely what this game is in my opinion... a waste of time.

Overall, not a bad game but one with a few flaws.

It's alright, but it bothers me how neglected the guy's story is in comparison to the girls. His story is just as serious and impactful as hers, but is left with only 1 third of the length. The girl's story is full of details that just aren't present in the guy's story, which makes it strongly reek of bias and seems like the developer views women's issues as more severe than men. Maybe I'm taking it the wrong way, but it seriously sat wrong with me.

[i]Alex's Hope & Alex's Solitude[/i] is a dramatic, emotional kinetic visual novel developed and published by Violet Horizons Productions.  It narrates two different stories, both of which have the main character, Alex.  However, one Alex is male while the other Alex is female.  In the first story, [i]Alex's Hope[/i], a boy named Alex is living in bleak conditions, trying his best to attend school while working a part-time job.  However, his mother abuses him to the point of stealing his hard-earned money, so that it would make escaping that situation extremely difficult.  Alex is in so much despair that he feels like it would be best to [spoiler]end his life[/spoiler], but then a chance encounter with a cute animal changes it all.  In the other story, [i]Alex's Solitude[/i], a girl named Alex is feeling scared of attending her first day in high school.  Alex ended up spending a lonely summer, being isolated by her middle school friends, because [spoiler]Alex learned that one of her friends, Briane, brought alcohol and decided to report it to a teacher[/spoiler].  Despite that high school should have been a fresh start for Alex, the consequences of the incident I just mentioned follow Alex to the point where [spoiler]Briane spreads ugly rumors about Alex to make sure that no one would befriend her[/spoiler].  This hurts Alex to the point where she finds herself becoming friends with an upperclassman who is more on the wild side, and fascinated, Alex decides to find out what it's like.  Since both stories are linear, I'll stop here to avoid spoilers. ^^

In regards to the gameplay, both stories are linear, so you just play through the stories from beginning to end since there are no choices.  When you're in the main menu, you can choose which story to read.  A few CGs are shown although there is no CG gallery in which you can view them.  There are a few tracks present as well but no voice acting.  Also, a few Steam achievements are present although they won't count towards a user's global total until the game is out of "Steam is learning about this game".

Now that I've gone over the story and gameplay, I'll move onto my thoughts.  It has been quite a while since I last played a free-to-play game, so I thought it'd be a good time to highlight one that caught my interest.  With that said, I'll first talk about the stories.  I enjoyed reading both stories.  Although they both touch on dark topics like [spoiler]depression, suicide, bullying, etc.[/spoiler], I like when games focus on these topics rather than just ignore them, as though they don't exist.  Out of the two stories, I must say that [i]Alex's Solitude[/i] feels more fleshed out.  Even though I enjoyed [i]Alex's Hope[/i], especially because that hope comes in the form of a [spoiler]sweet, adorable cat[/spoiler], I felt that [i]Alex's Solitude[/i] had more story depth.  In [i]Alex's Solitude[/i], I could feel both sympathy and empathy for Alex.  On a personal note, I know what it feels like to be isolated, all just because you take a stand and make the right choice, even though others cannot clearly understand that.  The story definitely has its dark, depressing moments when Alex decides to [spoiler]go on the dangerous side.  Fortunately, Alex learns from her experiences and knows who she is as a person, even if it goes against peer pressure and whatnot[/spoiler].  Despite the topics that are addressed, both stories have hopeful endings.

As for the writing, the pacing is fine.  Both stories are short, but for a free-to-play game, I feel like this is fine, especially if you're looking for a quick read.  I didn't notice any typos or whatnot, so major kudos to the editor/proofreader. ^^  All the achievements unlocked for me as well.

In regards to the art, it is beautiful.  Both the sprites and backgrounds are drawn and colored very well.  The use of colors feels right, never being overly bright.  Especially, the CGs are done well.  I just wish that there was a CG gallery where I can view them, especially the CG of the cat. ^^  With the music, there are a few tracks and they fit well in the scenes they are placed in.  They give off an emotional feel, which is perfect since both stories are dramatic and emotionally driven.

Overall, would I recommend [i]Alex's Hope & Alex's Solitude[/i]?  If you're looking for a couple of short stories to pass a bit of time and don't mind dark, depressing topics, then I think this is worth checking out.  It's free-to-play, so really, there's no reason not to give it a try.  I enjoyed reading both stories, especially [i]Alex's Solitude[/i], and I hope that the developer will continue to create more visual novels like this one and bring them to Steam. ^^

[quote]For more detailed, high quality reviews like this, please follow [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44702020/]The Introverted Gamer[/url], prioritizing heart and soul always. ^^[/quote]

[h2]unrealistically real game[/h2]
I really like the wording of the scenes ^^

[h3]Alex's Hope & Alex's Solitude[/h3]

The game shows us the incredible life stories of a boy and a girl named Alex. The game shares the thoughts of the characters, allowing you to feel their experiences and understand what difficult period of life they are going through.

The first character, living his life in the endless routine of working and playing on the computer, has no friends, no girlfriend, and no interests in life in general. Spending his salary on not very useful hobbies, he sinks deeper and deeper into the abyss. And one day, seeing that his mother hid all the money out of harm‚Äôs way, he decides to put an end to it. You know, there‚Äôs a phrase, You truly realize what you‚Äôve done only when you‚Äôre already flying after jumping off a cliff. But nothing can be changed anymore. [spoiler][b]Hope[/b]fully, he has understood it before he jumped.[/spoiler]

The second character, a girl, lost all her friends after an unpleasant incident. Having the opportunity to start over from scratch at a new school, Alex decides not to be a bore and starts drinking and smoking in order to fit into the company of friends. But at one moment she realizes that this is not at all the life she wanted. And all these ‚Äúfriends‚Äù are actually dragging her down. Having come to her senses in time, she again distances herself from them, but this time she does not regret anything.

The visuals in the game are amazing. Every scene, every character is beautifully drawn. Such attention to detail makes you admire every frame.
The soundtrack is also excellent, allowing us to immerse ourselves in the atmosphere of what is happening and get into the reading experience.

I would like to praise the developers for creating a short but very strong game in which they showed quite serious problems of young people, to which many, almost everyone, turn a blind eye. Loneliness and misunderstandings from parents often lead to sadness, which turns into depression. And if you don‚Äôt support a person in time, what will happen will happen.

[i]Sometimes just the purr of a little kitten is enough to save an entire life.[/i]

[code]If you read the review and liked it, don't forget to give it a thumbsup;)[h3][i]The further - The better‚ô•Ô∏è[/i][/h3][/code]

I had a good enough time playing it and have been watching the progress on the HFPS and UHFPS Discord server. I also played the Demo when it was released back in early November. I really enjoyed the visual style and some of the unique features I saw, including things like squeezing through objects and pushing them aside.

However, there were also a LOT of issues I found. Most of the safe-related puzzles are not really solvable. There isn't enough given to the player for them to be able to figure it out. I had to rely on an old message in the discord server in order to solve the first safe puzzle with the ghost girl, and then used a video walk through for EVERY other safe puzzle. The final one, with the 2 optional codes (I think) actually require BOTH codes to be input at the same time.

Also, I was able to sequence break a few times, and also got the AI stuck twice. Along with this, some items such as the one that gives boosted stats doesn't work completely. I don't get any bonus health from it.

And finally, a lot of the hints that the player gets (like interacting with items) are given to the player AFTER they have already done it before. You get a prompt telling you that glowing items are interactable ones AFTER you already pick up the key outside and enter the house. It was super confusing for me.

If you wish to view any of the issues I've seen, I have 2 streams and an upcoming video which will include most of the issues I encountered: https://www.youtube.com/@Decager

And if this game DOES receive the necessary updates to where it is stable, I will gladly change my review.

[b] TL:DR- This game is if Footsies had different characters. With a quick game-play loop "hopping on for a few matches" will quickly turn into 50+. Buy the game, get wrecked online then start teaching people how to air parry your tech traps. [/b]

For a 2-button fighting game, Dojo Masters radiates mechanical depth and nuance that some modern fighting games fail to capture or obfuscates behind "system mechanics". Each "Character" contain so much identity that you quickly forget they are effectively an avatar for the fighting style. The beautiful pixel art and unique move set ensures no two characters play the same and yet they never feel like they are breaking the rules. From Boxer with their Roman Cancel like Spin Dash to Taekwondo's feints and movement it feels amazing both learning a single character as well as trying out the cast. 

Winning a match is simple. Get your opponents health low and knock them down. But once you add tech recovery and parry to the mix it quickly becomes a game of high speed hard reads. Even if you only want to play casually there is still ample enjoyment beating on your opponent. Dojo Masters's fluid animations and responsive controls just feels good to play.

While I can't say the game is without it's cons, my complains are relatively minor. Due to the retro aesthetic, the location and description of some menu options are not immediately clear. In addition the input buffer is pretty lenient which is generally great but not my personal preference. 

If this style of game is not for you, It's well worth giving a shot. Even if you don't love it, I'm sure you will like it!
Excellent combat and fun online play so far. I enjoy all the characters, specifically the boxer and Muay Thai fighter the most. Would love to see more styles of fighters in the future!

Easy to play but hard to master. With only two attack buttons this game can create some of the hypest moments I've had in a fighting game in a while. If you like fighting games this is easily worth picking up.

Dojo Masters is sort of like a modernized Karate Champ, but there are several different martial arts represented as their own characters. There are only 2 attack buttons, but some techniques require really tight timing windows to pull off, so it's not really an "easy execution" game. To win you have to deplete the opponent's stamina, then get an un-teched knockdown.

The online play and matchmaking/rematching flow is smooth and there are good, detailed tutorials on the game and each character. There isn't much to do single player as the arcade/survival options are pretty bare bones, but the dev has been working hard to update and improve the game in even just the short window since launch. So I think it will improve with time.

Dojo Masters is pretty light on content at the moment, but it's cheap and takes up very little hard drive space so it's easy to look past that and enjoy a solid fighting game.

It only uses two buttons (three if you use the dash button,) there's no supers, there's no anti-air because there's no jumping, and there's no okizeme because there aren't even any health bars (you win when you knock your opponent to the ground.) As such, it's the rare fighting game that can be easily picked up and enjoyed by people with no experience in the genre, or possibly video games in general. Despite being so simple, it's not shallow or boring because the mechanics are refined to emphasize skill and concentration. You won't win by mashing your two buttons.

Easy to get into, but requires a bit more effort to master which is a good thing in my opinion. All styles has depth to them and the matches can get fun from the intensity. I'm really vibing with the kendo and taekwondo styles so far

Easy to pick up and hard to master, Dojo Masters is a fun 2D fighting game, very much leaning more towards realism than your Street Fighters, but still very much in the video game-y territory of logic that it's in.

It takes the familiar concept of multiple fighters of differing martial art backgrounds (Street Fighter, Tekken, etc.), and paints it in a shade closer to real life combat sports, with knockdowns resetting the round and positions, and the "health" equivalent being basically stamina. Add to that the fact that you can tech knockdowns and parry with the right timing, alongside the simplified control scheme, and you have something very unique on your hands.

Looking forward to seeing where the game goes in the future!

This game is SICK, I love all the different playstyles, I love how every fighting style teaches you habits you can take to any other playstyle, like how muay thai focuses on footsies, and boxing focuses on rushing down, but learning them will help you with kendo (focused on zoning).
If you think martial arts are awesome and you like simple fighting games, this one has a lot to offer, and is definitely worth the price.

With everything these is to love, this game has some of the worst settings I‚Äôve ever used in the entire FGC. 

Remapping your controls for in battle also remaps your controls for menu navigation. So lets say you like your punches and kicks on your bumpers, well now you also have to use those as your ‚Äòaccept‚Äô and ‚Äòback buttons‚Äô

Also, why do I have to go all the way back to the main menu to change controls. Nothing like having 4 friends with 2 connected controllers and having to go back to the main menu after every single switch to fix peoples preferred buttons. 

Want your punch buttons above your kick buttons like pretty much every other fighting game ever? Well your going to have to use A for back and X for accept. It just doesn‚Äôt make sense. 

The way the trials progress means that if you want to keep practicing what you‚Äôve been taught you end up missing critical information. There should also be indicators that the opponent is about to attack so you can properly learn the timing of parries and timed moves like perfect ducks. 

Finally, I wouldn‚Äôt mind an option to make grab two buttons, but that‚Äôs not a large deal. 

Still love the game and will be putting some time into getting good with friends. Just want these things to be noted as they do get in the way of the experience, especially for my more casual friends.

[b]TLDR: Buy it.[/b]

Full review here --> https://pastebin.com/zQJzCAqU

[h1]GAMEPLAY OVERVIEW[/h1]
You have a stamina bar (represented by stocks of bamboo) at the bottom of the screen. Once they've depleted, you have to 'down' your opponent with a move that knocks down to win a game. There‚Äôs a variety of ways to knock your opponent down outside of just using a move with the knockdown property. Games can be over in a flash or take a while as both you and your opponent adjust to one another's fighting styles. Most games won‚Äôt take that long tho.

The controls are simple. No complex inputs whatsoever. You have Punch and Kick as your attack buttons, Left and Right for your movement buttons, and an optional Dash button. You cannot jump or crouch in the game which limits your movement to moving back and forth. This puts a TON of emphasis on spacing your moves properly. While the inputs and movement are simple, the gameplay still has depth and some moves in the game require STRICT timing, but are not required to have fun or play decently online. It‚Äôs easy to pick up and play, but there's a ton of room to grow if you want to learn.

[h1]PRESENTATION[/h1]
The art style in the game is lowres and has really cool animations. When you hit an opponent, they shake around for a split second which makes hits feel powerful. The sfx are chunky and crunchy which fits the retro aesthetic. The music is a really good mix of drum and bass, hip-hop, and rock. The music is dynamic in some way, though I‚Äôm not sure how it works exactly. I believe it changes based on the timer, so as the timer ticks down the music gets more intense. The songs that are available are really nice and get you in the mood to fight.

There are SO many stages and the stages change if you go into overtime, making the matches feel extra tense. I cannot express to you how many cool stages there are in this game. Some are static, but some have moving parts, like the Bridge-2 stage that wiggles a little when you walk on certain parts of it, OR the Bridge-1 stage that has a wave crashing in the background when you land a parry. The Forest-1 stage has little lightning bugs flying around if you go into overtime and it‚Äôs beautiful. The polish on these stages make the game feel alive and super cool! I‚Äôd love more stages like this. I think most are static, but they‚Äôre still pleasing to look at.

Each character has two colors in their outfit that you can mix and match as you please before every match. There‚Äôs at least 20 colors you can unlock as you play the game and level up your account. There‚Äôs also 10 different skin tones that are available right away. There‚Äôs a shoe or no shoe option for characters depending on your tastes. Lastly, there‚Äôs only two hair styles, short and long. Each character has unique short and long styles of hair. For example, The Taekwondo character either has a double bun or a buzzcut, but on the Karate character you have the options of a ponytail or a bowl cut.  I kinda wish there were more options, but the styles we currently have are kinda great imo.

[h1]COMBAT[/h1]
The combat is simple in theory and in execution, but where it gets complex is the mind games. Since this entire game is basically neutral, you are constantly playing footsies with your opponent, dancing back and forth trying to get that one or two stray hits in. Every hit counts in this game. The mechanics feel well thought out. You can tech to save yourself, if you ever don‚Äôt know how to deal with a move you can parry, you can use quick jabs to knock opponents out of the air, etc. It seems like there‚Äôs an answer for nearly everything as long as you are willing to experiment.

[h1]ONLINE[/h1]
This game has rollback netcode and feels great for the most part. I'd like to see a signal strength filter implemented in the future.

[h1]CONCLUSION[/h1]
This is one of the most fun fighting games I‚Äôve ever played. I think that games like Fantasy Strike sacrificed a lot of longevity for their game in the name of simplicity, but I think Dojo Masters has struck a perfect balance. It‚Äôs beginner friendly and has depth. Each character allows for expression in playstyle while also having a distinct playstyle on their own. It‚Äôs clear to me that a lot of thought and love has been put into this game. It‚Äôs perfect for a party game or for hardcore sweats or for people who just wanna have a little game on the side away from their main title. I‚Äôve been having a blast playing it every day since it came out and I hope that the dev(s) continues to work on it because I think they made something special here.

For only $15, this game is a MUST BUY for those that are fans of the fighting game genre or for anyone looking to dip their toes in.

I make gaming sessions with friends in my house once a month. We usually play some Retro games (I have quite a collection of consoles) and some common multiplayer games (stuff like Duck Game or Ultimate Chicken Horse)

Since I bought Dojo Masters, it quickly became a favourite. It's easy to pick up, controls are really simple, so anyone can quickly start playing it. The fights being so lightining quickcly are great for "King of the Hill" matches between a fair number of people.

As we keep playing it, you start picking up a winning strategy, which then someone will pick up and have a counter strategy, and then you will counter his counter... and I guess it's easy to understand how it goes.

The game also has a 4 player mode which is pretty fun because of the chaos ensued, but not as a strategic and deep as the normal 1x1 mode. Still a lot fun with friends, so a great addition to the game.

Single player modes are pretty meh, can't say anything about the online. But playing with friends is a blast, I recommend it a lot.

In short, Dojo Masters is an incredibly fun fighting game that's (as many have described it as) easy to learn, hard to master. Tbh, the only fighting game that I've played extensively is SSBU, so it took me a second to get used to how this game played in comparison to that, but once I got the hang of a couple martial arts the game really had me hooked. Each martial art is unique and focuses on different styles, techniques, and strategies. For only having two main buttons for attacking, this game has some great depth.
So far, everything feels pretty tight, but my main complaint isn't really about the game but rather the lack of players on it currently. Again, hopefully more people do see this game and get it so that wait times won't be too long. 

 If you do pick it up, consider leaving a review so that more are exposed to the game and also potentially pick it up as well. Hopefully later on we get more arts like wrestling or capoeira.

Barebones arcade fighter with a good-enough tutorial. Two buttons, two directions, and a whole lot of character mechanics to stretch that out into a full fledged fighting game. My only concern is that the game moves so incredibly fast that mindgames won't even be visible sometimes, so the game will be pretty thrash-heavy and hectic as opposed to thoughtful and skill-expressive. I'm having a lot of fun with this game so far. Definitely it is a nice change of pace from most fighters. Also the rollback netcode is good! The asking price of $15 is a bit much, especially since ranked mode is not out yet (says to come out in august). On sale for $12 I would recommend it, if the price drops to $10 it is definitely a buy for fighting game fans or martial arts fans.

A complete waste of time.  There are only three "decision points" in the whole thing, and they have zero effect on the outcome. It seems that the "decision" you make are only there to give it the appearance of a game.  Four scenes strung together to fulfill a casting couch fantasy.

This was a completely spontaneous purchase, driven by the low price of one euro and the hope that they probably didn't mess this miniscule 60's psychdelia exhibition up, because why else would you release this and charge money for it, right? The concept and visuals looked inviting enough.

Turns out I was completely wrong, as nearly nothing here works as it should:

- The game controls with WASD, only that the "D" key doesn't register for some reason
- If you look straight up in the sky, the camera can't control itself
- The outside garden seems like an area to roam free, instead there are invisible walls everywhere
- The audio cuts abruptly, which is a constant issue in a simulation that constantly surrounds you with different music sources
- All of the texts are incredibly superficial, simultaneously failing to explain even the most basic terms while also never going in-depth about any of the well-established classics of the era; not even fun trivia or lesser-known-details are included
- At each painting, you have to manually trigger both the music and the page of surface-level information

With more space, polish, effort and finetuning this could be a worthwile ~20 minute gallery but in its current form, "Psyche60s" fails as a interactive experience, doesn't work as an educational tool and certainly doesn't offer a trippy, psychdelic or worthwile journey - reading about acid and Rock'n Roll in such a dry, uninvolved and stale manner really doesn't do the subject any justice. 2.5/10

I get better in this game by working out in real life!  This (free) game connects to a workout mobile app, so my progress in the gym or cardio translates to levels and buffs in the game. This can be played in short segments and if I get stuck, there is an option to move forward with more workout points in real life.  It helps me identify with the character in the game. For someone interested in both video games and physical fitness, this is worth a look.

I like the one-time cost (on the mobile app) with no subscriptions or ads.

In the vast realm of indie gaming, "Fittest Fire" emerges as a true gem, weaving a unique tapestry of gameplay that sets it apart from the mainstream. The idea of having the fitness app and logging my exercises boosting my gameplay is a big motivation for me.

Graphics and Art Style (9/10):
"Fittest Fire" may not boast the high-budget graphics of triple-A titles, but what it lacks in sheer visual fidelity, it more than compensates with its mesmerizing art style. The hand-drawn landscapes, vibrant colors, and imaginative character effects create a visual feast that captivates players from the opening scene. The game's minimalist approach is a testament to the artistry and creativity that can flourish within the indie gaming scene.

Gameplay and Mechanics (8/10):
At its core, "Fittest Fire" is a puzzle-platformer with a twist. The mechanics are elegantly simple, yet the challenges presented are anything but. Players navigate through stages, solving puzzles (where to jump back to back etc.) that seamlessly blend with the narrative. The controls are intuitive, and the game strikes a perfect balance between accessibility and depth, ensuring that both casual and hardcore gamers can find satisfaction in its gameplay.

I really enjoyed playing the game. It has it's own challenges and sometimes you need to solve the mechanic to get to the next stage which is entertaining.

If you're looking at this thinking it is just some crummy typing game, you'd be wrong. Apart from having polished as hell visuals which make it a feast on the eyes to play, it's gameplay is also incredibly polished. There are many mechanics which make the gameplay much deeper than "see letter, press letter". You have PARRIES, special abilities such as slow mo and bombs, achievements, there are varied enemy types then have varied attacking patterns.

This game feels like an arcade game with modern polish, mechanics, and visuals. It's very cheap and very impressive, you should at least try it.

It's fun, but to be honest I put it all the way to the easiest settings and I was not able to get to the first major game mechanic (looping). I don't really know what is beyond that, but I type for a living and the thing that makes it really hard as the mechanic gets faster and faster is that I never type most of these letters with my left hand. 

None of this is really a criticism of the game, but without any progression mechanics or grindable things you can purchase if you hit a brick wall like I have you're kind of done with the game. A lot of people won't have this issue, but after a few dozen runs I've never even come close to getting past that letter orb thing and I don't think more runs will make it easier. 

I'd be interested to play this with keyboard only as I think that would be easier. I don't know that I've ever played a bullet hell game with the mouse for movement. So I'll check back in occasionally to see if that feature or other features get added to make it so I can experience the rest of the game. I still ultimately recommend it for the price. 

I'm sure a lot of people will dismiss this as someone who's just not willing to grind it out. That's fine if you think that, I almost exclusively play games like this so that's not the issue for me.

I had the luxury of checking out this game while it was in development and watching it get nurtured from a little alien fetus thing into a sweet little baby- A baby that Mavis Beacon's grandson Typing of the Dead had with its partner named Vampire Survivors.

I had no idea how to type before I played this. Now I'm fluent in at least 26 keys on my keyboard. 10/10. My game key got revoked because I became TOO GOOD at this game, but make no mistake, I will be purchasing extra copies with my hard earned blood money, because it's THAT good.

Also whatever awesome score you THINK you got- I promise you in a day someone will beat that by about a million. You're gonna have to hit Q and stuff a hell of a whole lot more to beat THAT person.

Anyway, buy this now- it's worth it.

Unfortunately, although I love the ideas this game has, it is not executed as well as it could be. The menu is riddled with bugs, to the point where I have to click on certain options in order to adjust OTHER options. It seems as though fullscreening the game does not change where the hitboxes are for the buttons on the menu.

As for in game, while I fully admit to not being able to personally keep up with this game's level of difficulty, which is completely fine, trying to fix that by adjusting the "enemy spawn speed" does not, in fact, change the enemy spawn speed. And while rapidly switching between 3 keys is fine, it soon becomes 6, then 9, then 13, and I haven't even left "Loop 1" yet. So at some point my screen rapidly fills with enemies, and I find myself rapidly spamming QWE while just using bombs on the rest because I don't nearly have enough time to move my hand around the keyboard before being attacked. If I could re-assign the keys, so that I had better control over how far my hand has to travel across the keyboard, maybe I would have less issues with some of it.

The other issue is that the enemies, jewels dropped by enemies, as well as your "player orb" can traverse behind the UI, leading to many hits feeling cheap, as it was the only available place to dodge and I could not have known an enemy was hiding behind it. This causes me to naturally stick to the lower half of the screen, allowing for enemies to gang up quickly and perpetuate problem 1. Or, I will hit a few enemies and all their jewels will fly behind the UI, and I just simply ignore them because its not worth risking the hit.

Finally, I have noticed many times where I freely and fully collide with enemies and am not hit, and then times where there are no enemies in the direction I move my mouse and I take damage. I am wondering if this, too, is a disconnect caused by playing in fullscreen. 

The long and short of it is, this game gets very complex very quickly, and not in the fun way. And while I do not possess the skill set this game requires of you, I know that this game does not give me the opportunity to learn it, and increases its pace at such a rapid rate that I am never given enough time to wrap my head around the new letter keys that randomly pop up and start attacking in new patterns. Vampire Survivors has a lot going on, but the player has simple mechanics of movement. This game has just as much going on, if not more, and ALSO asks more of the player. All of this taken with the multiple bugs this game has (at least in the fullscreen experience), and I just don't feel like coming back to it, like I do with VS and other games of its style.

First thing's first.
It's actually easier to define this game by what it is NOT:
1. A typing game. I know what it looks like. I know there is the urge to call it one. See 2.
2, A game where you at any point type full words. That just wouldn't jive with the level of reflex decision making going on here (which is easily the most addicting part of it).
3. A game that uses the full keyboard very frequently. Your six most used keys by far will be q w e a s d. 
4. A game that will hold your hand or explain its mechanics. It doesn't need to, it's a very simple design where everything is clearly communicated and you learn what to do or your run will end.
5. An easy game. The last time I was playing something this unapologetically difficult to progress in, it was Exit the Gungeon.

Don't be put off by any of this. Persevere you will find an instant classic in this game.

Really good! You have to thread the movement needle with your mouse hand while managing a growing horde of chaser enemies by typing. Most typing games ask you to formulate words or sentences, but Typecast is all about the individual letters. As such, it plays with your expectations by throwing stuff in different hand positions, rather than more complex words. Very clever and I'm glad I played it. Will probably hop in for quick sessions during downtime in other stuff, since the game is so lightweight and sessions are pretty short.
Super simple arcade game that has been polished into the impossible. The voice acting is just the cherry on top. Meta progression would be awesome but that's my monkey brain talking.

It is fun, but very limited - one game mode, kinda like tetris ramping up from easy to hard over time. I was hoping for a twist or new idea for a typing game, and its a very cool idea, but I can't really consider this a typing game since you only learn the left hand.

[b] Target Audience: [/b] [I]  Those looking for an interesting twist on the typing game, or something completely different.  [/i]

[b] Summary: [/b]  

This is one of those games that you're going to get frustrated with, but in what I think it's a good way. It's an interesting twist on the typing game formula: using the mouse in conjuction with typing, and really punishing the spamming of letters. It feels difficult: but it's more so the fact that you've got to be precise with keys and mouse movement, and if you're used to high mouse DPS, you may want to reconsider that for a game like this. I admit, normally typing games really are in my wheelhouse, but this one caused me a lot of problems: and I like that it did. It felt like a breathe of fresh air in several genres: including survivors. 

The thing is, this is one of those reviews that will probably change over time, mostly because right now? I suck at the game. Like literally, I suck. I probably haven't seen some of the craziest stuff in it. It's still good design: I like the basic of the progression of enemies and what the game throws at you, and I like the tools/health system. It feels balanced. It's just my achilles heel when it comes to the way I play mouse/keyboard games, particularly the mouse.

But the thing is, I wanted to retry it again pretty quickly after every attempt, and I do see progress happening. The music is alright, the visuals are sharp, and it's one of those games I'll play here and there. It's one of my overlooked games of 2023.

Typecast is a brutal [b]bullet hell[/b] typing game but not the usual style. The controls are unique, since you tap keys to shoot instead of typing words. It's complicated by the fact that you must move the blue ball away from enemies with the mouse. 3 hands would be useful here! I love the control you have over the ball and can get into and out of tricky situations. The game is tense.

The enemy variety should be praised here too since the game is constantly throwing new enemies at you to make it more complicated. Although they do appear in roughly the same order every time. You do need the entire keyboard and my split keyboard makes this game extra difficult.

What's great is that It's easy to jump in and play since there are settings to adjust the challenge. What isn't great is how much the game hides. I wish the scoring was explained a bit more. There's a way to play that will maximize score but I'm still trying to figure it out.

I had fun though

The idea of the game is great but a bit flawed. On the community Hub, a lot of people asked the possibility to change the Keybinds to kill the enemies, specially to be able to kill the most common enemies with ASD (opposed to QWE), the home row of the querty layout, but the dev really doesn't want to update the game anymore. 

It's important to notice that those reviews were from the same week when the game launched. This game was already abandoned.

Okay, the game is really cool and feels really nice to play ! I haven't gotten really far yet, but there seem to be a nice variety of enemies, and the game has a lot of flair (thanks to the nice animations, adorable sprite design and really good ST)

Overall a really nice game with a really pleasant gameplay, interaction with devs is also responsive (bug reports). And it's cheap too

I'm curious to see how the game will evolve too, because I think there is room for that too !

This is an arcade game where you move with the mouse and attack by typing with your left hand.  Enemies have corresponding letters and when they are in range, pressing that letter will automatically shoot them.  It's an interesting concept with many execution flaws.

First an foremost, it doesn't run well enough.  60 FPS is just not enough for a game like this in the year of our lord 2024.  I have been moving my mouse at 120Hz+ for more than a decade now.

The HUD covers up part of the already cramped play area.  If the play area was just smaller, that might be ok, but there's a strip at the top where enemies can spawn, you can move, and powerups can drop that is completely covered by the opaque hud.

If you press a key when an enemy is not in range, your gun will 'jam' and you will be unable to attack for several seconds, or until you mash that same wrong key a couple times.  I feel this is overly punishing and confusing.  Often, there is an enemy that [b]did[/b] have that letter, but you were just barely out of range.  The difference between being in range and running into the enemy is fairly small and the enemies do not have precise hit boxes, so it's easy to make that mistake and the punishment is too severe.  If you do press a completely wrong key, then having to press the wrong key [i]again[/i], ie repeat your mistake, is an unintuitive way to proceed.  If you press the key one too many times you'll likely jam again immediately.

There is a moment where a huge circle of enemies will spawn and crush in on large portion of the arena.  They have an unusual letter like V or R.  It doesn't show you the letter until they spawn and there just isn't enough time to react.  Plus if you react to early you'll jam because the circle of enemies starts out huge and out of range.  The combination of reaction time + position + precision timing required is just unreasonable to me.

There is a moment where a line of enemies will spawn at the top or bottom of the stage and wipe vertically, covering the whole screen.  They all have the same letter, so this is generally fine.  Except they will spawn directly on top of you with no warning, causing unavoidable damage.

When you game over, it's almost always because of a frustrating chain reaction of falling behind and getting jammed and enemies spawning on top of you or spawning in a weird way due to rng.

There's a bug with the menu where item that is highlighted is not the actual thing you are clicking on. I also ran into problems switching from fullscreen to windowed where the game ended up super zoomed in and cropped into a small window.
Super fun actually! I do wish it had support for other Keyboards, I use a Dvoark layout so I don't know querty as well, but despite that,still quite fun.

Banger of an arcade game. It's not a typing game, it's just a game that uses your keyboard as a controller which feels like a weird distinction but as someone who can touch type it made me realise I apparently have no idea where any letters are on my keyboard. 

Has a high skill ceiling as you can optimise your play on a moment to moment level to maximise your score.

I think this game succeeds at pretty much everything it's trying to do. I want more games of this sort of scope and scale and quality.

A random game a friend suggested I try because I enjoy typing stuff. I bought it on a whim and have come to love it entirely ^^

Give it a chance, it's pretty addicting.
