i recommend this game, wahoo

The one word that I'd use to describe this game is:
"Clean".

The controls are relatively simple without compromising on depth. It is one of the most "no bullshit" experiences I've gotten in quite some time. Before we continue, disclaimer, I mostly play this game offline, so my actual time put into this game are a lot higher than the recorded online numbers may suggest.

With that out of the way. So why is it a uber clean game?
Simply put, everything is extremely well thought out and balanced. To put it bluntly, if I die in this game, it is objectively my fault, full stop. The game gives the player just enough mechanics to pull through in any scenario the game throws at them. So unlike some other games, there's never a point where I've ever felt I've been "cheated" so to speak. Because again, the game never puts me into unwinnable situations.

Continuing on this idea of ultra balance, each tool/move the game gives the player (right off the bat I might add) has their own trade offs and more importantly, have multiple usage cases. Allowing for extremely noticeable player expression. Its seriously impressive how each player can have their own way of fighting that is immediately noticeable at a glance.

As for those moves (that I'm aware of atm), they're all fairly straightforward.
* Movement: The character is tied to the mouse cursor. Moving the cursor moves the character basically 1:1 to the speed of the cursor. So movement is ultra snappy, fast, and has a immediate feeling of precision.

* Shooting: (Most) Enemies have letters that the player "needs" to press to kill them. However, this shooting mechanic has a relatively short range. The bullets also have a travel time. This means two things, one, this is a highly aggressive game, two, even though the shot is relatively accurate, if a enemy is moving fast, the player can still miss.

Secondly, Shooting has a extra mechanic, if you press the key multiple times, it will fire multiple shots. If one of those shots kills the designated enemy, further projectiles can kill anything else in that line even if they aren't the "correct" letter.
Meaning you can on paper, extend the range of the shot to hit further targets. (Assuming its timed properly)

Shooting also has a extra mechanic that is INCREDIBLE. Jamming. When the wrong key is pressed, a enemy is out of range, so on, the character will "jam" meaning I cannot shoot until I am unjammed. This is done either by waiting, or pressing the key that caused the jam in the first place.

For the first few (and I mean the first VERY FEW) frames of jamming, the character is temporarily invincible and the character turns yellow.
If a enemy hits the character when they're yellow, they will die, spawn more point pick ups than usual, and automatically gets rid of the jam. This is called a "Parry".
And no cap, CLEANEST mechanic in video game history!

Here's why, so long as a enemy hits the character when they're yellowed, they will die. There's no real limit to how MANY enemies this can take out. So if there's a bunch of enemies from one end of the screen to the next, I could hypothetically speaking if I am fast enough, clear out all of those enemies with one parry. And, it, feels, insane.

Once the player gets enough points to fill up this bar, some mana and health is recovered. Due to parry's causing enemies to drop more points, this incentives being aggressive without being reckless. Since the parry window is rather small. Btw, it happens SLIGHTLY after the jam. Not immediately at the same time as the character jamming.

As for mana, that leads us to the next two attacks.
One.
* Bombs. It costs a lot of mana to do, but it basically clears everything in the character's attack range.
One really fun application of this is combined with parries. This game is relatively new (at the time of this review) so a lot of techniques don't have names yet. So I'll call this one carpet bombing.
Basically parry into a large group of enemies, set off the bomb, and then get out of there before the invincibility expires.

Two,
* Slowing down time: This drains mana rapidly until the player stops using it, or runs out of mana. When a enemy is parried, it will for a moment, go back to full speed time. So don't use it expecting to clear the screen easily with parries with time slowed down.
It can however make that shooting mechanic where the player presses the same key repeatedly, MUCH easier.

And that's basically the, well, basics. The rest is all skill and player creativity.
For basically $5.00 USD, you get a no bullshit experience that is as skilled based as a game could get. So RNG card fuckery. Just, "here's your moves, get good with them".

PS: One last mechanic, when a projectile is parried, it extends the parry window and slightly slows down time. THIS STACKS.
So if there's a lot of projectiles everywhere, you really could just pull off an anime maneuver, run along multiple projectiles (and enemies), and have everything explode the moment time goes back to normal. Yeah did I mention this game is mad satisfying?

PSS: This game can do double duty of being both a excellent warm up game while also being a excellent PC gamer trainer. As it trains basically every fundamental skill imaginable. Positioning, resource management, precision, speed, technique, etc. And again, $5 bucks. From here I would say something that could be improved on but honestly, this game is precisely where it needs to be. The Dev. has a vision and executed it damn near flawlessly.

The literal only nitpick I could think of is that is there's a LOT of enemies on the screen, some of them can block the letter of other enemies if the player is going after those specific ones. But again, due to all the other mechanics in place, much like everything else in this game, skill issue.

Typecast is a beautiful three-axis chimera born from Nuclear Throne, Vampire Survivors, and Typing of the Dead.

It is frenetic, snappy, and enthralling.
It is one of the cleanest and most competently designed roguelikes ever made.
It is one of a scant few clever videogames to truly acknowledges the keyboard.
It is QWOP for Shmup lovers.

Evil and difficult, but a very good and well-executed concept.

Reminds me that I never learned touch-typing.

This is not really a typing game, more a game about you having a LOT of interactions that you have to contend with during fast-paced gameplay. Picture Mario but instead of one "jump button" you have an entire keyboard of them and you have to match the letter to the enemy during fast-paced arcade-style gameplay. 

You have to basically leave traditional typing rules behind you to play this game. So it subverted my expectations, because I was expecting a twist on a game that was going to teach me how to traditionally type faster. I'm not bothered by this but thought I'd throw that out there for anyone who may be interested in this for that reason. One thing they did do that I like is they group up the key presses especially at first via typical qwerty rules (qwe, asd, zxc, etc). This does help the onboarding experience significantly, otherwise I think folks would drop off even faster than they probably already do.

This game has huge cognitive overload problems, between the fast pace and the number of button presses that is required. You WILL lose your "spot" as your hand hovers over the keyboard and when you look down to see where you are, you probably get hit. It's also worth it to make sure your mouse sensitivity is "just right." The gameplay is so fast that sometimes you get punished because a key press is "wrong" because everything on the board moves so fast that it gets out of your destroyable zone before you can press the required key. I find these things really made it hard to stay in flow state while playing, which is likely working against this game's favour for many players.

Super hot take here but to me slo-mo feels like the solution to a problem I never said I had. You use a lot of your energy just to get one key press in... Once that's done you go hard into the (very fast-paced) gameplay again with no transition. It's way easier to just get used to how fast the game is and use the bombs instead. But just my opinion.

I feel like I'm being too negative here. The game is ok and Ill very likely play it more, and the price is really reasonable. Overall I'd say if you like bullet hell or super arcade-y games this is something different to play with. I do think this game is niche and I obviously wouldn't recommend this for anyone looking for something more "chill."

If you're on the fence about Typecast, you don't need to be. It's an outstanding arcade score chaser, although the appeal is entirely dependent on enjoying typing games. It's infuriating, but in all the best ways. I've been having a great time trying to work my way up the leaderboard.

I would advise, however, not to be fooled by the aesthetic similarities to Vampire Survivors. They have nothing in common, there are no permanent upgrades and the gameplay is limited to a small arena.

One of the game's biggest weaknesses is how often you end up with crystals near the edge of the screen that can't be picked up without being taken off-guard by upcoming enemies you can't see yet. I understand not wanting to give too much of a magnet radius for balance reasons, but could you perhaps add an indicator arrow pointing in the direction of approaching enemies when you have off-screen letters within your attack radius?

While less of a typing game than I had initially expected, Typecast brings together elements of bullet hells, schmups, and typing games to create a thrilling, leader board chasing, arcade experience that keeps me wanting to beat my newest high score.

I have been humbled by [I]TYPECAST[/I].

As a touch typist who could type 90 to 100 words per minute, I thought this game would be a walk in the park for me. It wasn‚Äôt. I couldn‚Äôt even get past the first loop.

Being an experienced typist didn‚Äôt help me much at all. Although I knew to keep my left hand on the home row (with my right hand on the mouse), I found myself inevitably shifting my left hand to WASD position during the frantic moments. It totally messed me up when I had to press the R, G, H and V keys.

But, with some perseverance, I managed to get far enough to score myself 42,517 points with 723 kills. All I had to show for 4 hours of playing is a screenshot of my game over screen with that record. I didn‚Äôt even earn an achievement for my effort.

[I]TYPECAST[/I] is unapologetically difficult, but it‚Äôs the fun kind of difficult. While I might have not made ground with it, I can see it being a source of virtually endless entertainment for those who seek high-level challenges.

What if Vampire Survivors, but also a typing game?

OK, that's somewhat reductive, but while TYPECAST's inspiration is clear, this is not just another Vampire Survivors clone to add to the sea of those we're seeing from indie devs lately. You will be fending off endless waves of...creatures(?) but you do so by moving your gem around the screen with the mouse and pressing the keys that are on the various enemies. Anything within the circle dies and your score goes up. If you mistype, you have to mash the wrong key to unjam your weapon. You can also build up combos and collect the letters in FEVER to start a score doubling mode.

It's a simple, but very addictive premise. Sessions will often be quick and get quite hard quite fast, but you'll get "one more run syndrome" very quickly here because it's so quick to restart a game. While there are no replays, there are online leaderboards, which adds a great competitive element.

TYPECAST is simple, but focused at its core and I think it takes what the industry is quickly turning into a worn out idea and doing something cool with it. Great value for the money.
The games graphics are fun but it's a REALLY difficult game. The enemies are so fast! Good luck

üåü [h1]Overview:[/h1]
[code]"Butterfly Again" plunges players into a dark fantasy world where magic exists alongside evil entities known as Alluring Demons. Players engage in a gritty narrative where defeating these demons is crucial for survival, not just through combat but through the accumulation of SP to partake in prostitution‚Äîa controversial yet integral part of the game‚Äôs mechanics. This RPG challenges players to navigate morally complex scenarios in a world where only the magically endowed can see the true horrors that lurk.[/code]

üéÆ[h1]Synopsis and Gameplay:[/h1]
[code]In the game, players control two main characters, Butterfly and Mellie, each with their own tragic backstories and diverging paths in the world of prostitution. The gameplay revolves around defeating Alluring Demons to earn SP, which is used to engage in various prostitution activities essential for survival. The combat system is straightforward but requires strategic thinking to maximize the use of SP for both personal advancement and survival strategies.

Throughout the game, players explore diverse settings and interact with different characters. The RPG mechanics are interwoven with a narrative that explores deep themes of exploitation, survival, and personal redemption.[/code]

üìñ[h1]Story and Depth:[/h1]
[code]The story of "Butterfly Again" is rich with dark themes and moral complexities. Butterfly, a seasoned prostitute, decides to escape the brothel with Mellie, a newcomer sold by her own parents. Together, they navigate a perilous world, using their wits and bodies to survive and possibly thrive outside the confines of their previous lives in the brothel. The game does not shy away from the harsh realities of their professions, instead using these elements to fuel character development and plot progression.

As they venture through the game's world, Butterfly and Mellie encounter various characters who offer help, hindrance, or temptation, affecting their journey and moral compasses. The narrative delves into themes of freedom, betrayal, and the search for identity in a world that often sees the characters as mere objects.

The bond between Butterfly and Mellie deepens as they face challenges together, leading to a complex dynamic where loyalty and necessity blur the lines of their relationship. The game intricately explores the consequences of their actions, highlighting the complex interplay between survival, and morality in their quest for liberation. [/code]

üèÜ[h1]Verdict:[/h1]
[code]"Butterfly Again" offers an intense, immersive experience that is not for the faint of heart. It combines traditional RPG elements with a story that challenges the player's ethics and emotional resilience. The game's mature content, involving themes of prostitution and survival, is handled with a narrative depth that respects the seriousness of the subject while providing a compelling gameplay experience.

The combat system, while simple, supports the game's darker themes by linking survival directly to the characters' ability to engage in prostitution, a stark commentary on the dire situations they face. This setup provides a unique gameplay mechanic that intertwines with the story, enhancing the overall depth and impact of the game.

For players seeking a game that pushes boundaries and explores dark, mature themes with sensitivity and complexity, "Butterfly Again" is a must-play. It offers not just a game, but a narrative journey that questions the limits of what one is willing to do for survival. The replay value is high, with different choices leading to new revelations and outcomes, encouraging players to explore all facets of this richly crafted world.[/code]

Disclaimer: I have only played the game in english.

"Butterfly again" is a dystopian story-rich JRPG. The primary focus is the story as it is a narrative-driven game but great thought has been put into the battle system (even if it isn't overly complex). You play as Butterfly and Mellie on their way to go back to Mellie's village and to her father that sold her off. Their journey has many unexpected turns and twists that will surprise you and, as the story unfolds, it will become darker and darker..

Seemingly filled with innocence, our girls and the world are far from it.. And that's what makes it so sinister and deep. There is a twist that you won't see coming, despite the hints throughout the game. Are you sure it's all over?.. ^^

In this world not everyone can use magic. Only those that can use magic can see the Alluring Demons and realize the Insect Demon's infestation that's been plaguing the kingdom. It's up to you to figure out what's going on and survive. The girls will need to adapt and grow in order to reach their journey's destination. Meanwhile, Butterfly starts remembering..

Hidden behind the innocence facade, lies a sinister and twisted world filled with magic. Delusions and illusions run rampant until paranoia strikes the final nail on the coffin of this immoral world. But, not everything is what it seems and sometimes the victim can be the perpetrator, even if it appears to be the opposite. Desire can be created and manipulated; it is a seed that you can plant..
Apathy, lies, secrets, manipulation, abuse, taking advantage of, love, desire, lust, innocence, naivety, being oblivious and blind to the facts are only the tip of the iceberg. Below the surface an abundance of social, psychological, patriarchal and feminist issues arise, that, if you indeed think about them deeply, will make your head spin.
A briliantly crafted story that will upset your stomach in a subtle and calm way all while being filled with raw and lustful sexual acts.

[b]Warning: The game is twisted. I loved the bottom line and the way it is expressed. It's very powerful but, I must stress out that if you can't stand hard scenes with below 18 girls, then this game isn't for you. Abuse, humiliation, torture and degradation come in many forms and shapes; not everything is about raw power and brutal violence. While this isn't overly aggresive, the psychological aspect of it might leave many at unease.[/b]

The combat is turn based. The difference here is that there Œ±œÅŒµ no armors or weapons. You only get to chose 2 willstones out of a big selection that you either earn or buy. There needs to be synergy between the 2 characters in order to win the tough fights. Oh! And there miiiigt be some costumes for you to find ^^
It seems simple and for the most part it is but, some willstone powers are very technically complex and I'm glad to see them used (the complexity of the [spoiler]desire-purple willstone[/spoiler] took me aback - don't forget the game engine). There are a couple of consumables but, you have to plan for them, as you can only use them prior to a battle. You need SP to unlock the prostitution events that are crucial for your survival!

You can replay all the unlocked scenes in the memory room (gallery) but, contrary to past games, you can't unlock them at will. The artwork is very good, detailed and fully uncensored! It really helps with understanding the mindset of the characters and how they feel.

I'm glad to see that the translation is good and[b]a lot[/b] better than the previous games of the developer! Only some few grammatical errors and misspellings. Like in the other games, the same problem with some text being cut off at the edges of the dialogue boxes exists. Here it isn't as bad and, generally, it won't break the immersion or make you miss something. The most annoying thing is probably the willstones' descriptions, as for some you might need to experiment to fully understand what they do, due to the bottom text being cut off. It has good flow and the dialogues are natural, like someone would actually speak in real life and not like a machine or direct word to word translation that makes little to no sense.

The game runs perfectly. All the mechanics and features work without any issue or bugs.

The game is too text heavy, and when skipping most of the text, the story becomes void and the even the  skipping is slow. The "interesting" part is not more interesting than what som AI can draw. I fell asleep two times while trying to give this game a chance.

Wow... i did not expect all this from this game.
It is... phenomenal. So let's start from the little things - and i do not mean the girls starring in the main roles ToT
The music might all be public domain but it is very well selected and high quality. Fans of Black Souls will recognize a few tunes... fans of Black Souls will also like this game in general and not only for the cunny.
The combat isn't hard but it has its twists to the usual rpgmaker formula. Combat is all about magic and your MP(not to be confused with Mana) is limited to 10. It recovers each turn a little bit but your attacks and skills can cost anywhere from 1 to 9. It also doesn't return to max between battles nor after leveling up so you need to use it well - MP recovery items are rare and a bit expensive. [spoiler]There is also a reason why they are not called mana potions but "flu medicine"[/spoiler]
After each battle you get SP and EXP. Exp is self-explantatory. SP meanwhile... calling it "sex points" wouldn't be wrong but by the end of the game you will know that it actually stands for [spoiler]Spread Parasite[/spoiler]
Battles don't earn you gold - sex does. To have sex you need to have enough SP and find a client. Then you can use the gold either to buy regular items or a thing called "Willstones"... which you will learn the true nature of later. But for now, think of them as equippable skills. Most of them teach you a new spell and raise some attribute. Some only raise attributes. You only have 5 slots at a time though so you have to swap them around.
Now... to the story. On the surface, you are a little loli mesugaki who escaped from the brothel together with an oppai loli on a whim. The loli mesugaki's name is "Butterfly" and said butterflies are a common symbol in the game. She slowly remembers various things during her travels... or maybe, she knew them all along and is just sharing them with us? Either way... none of those things are good.
I decided to stop myself short from spoiling everything in a big spoiler section. Find that for yourself by playing. I finished the game in 5 hours but a certain optional boss would require a bit more grinding than that. Still, the story is really amazing and it will stay with me for a while.
...the cunny is pretty good too ;3
As for problems - there is a bit of text wrapping problems and a few text boxes that aren't translated or have a bit wonky grammar. But it is better than many other chinese games i've seen translated on steam.
Now, the only single spoiler i will leave you with is that there is a happy ending - because even loli prostitutes deserve respect and happiness.
10/10 would uooohhh for Butterfly again ToT

A rather shorter side of the rpgmaker eroge, this game took me about 6-7 hours to both beat and 100% this game have a really good story- infact, I think it's the main selling point, with the plot twist sprinkled through the story itself, I didn't expect it at all, it made whole lot of sense and conceptually, it's very cool. I really like the world building that leads the plot to the twist. The game have 2 Endings(?) Good and Bad ending apart from your generic "game over".

Now for what I don't quite like about the game, The art itself is great, its well drawn, however the creative choice behind it are.. questionable at best, out of very little CGs it had, there's only 2 H-scene that I like, with only 17 H-scene in total. There's option to "do it" with other NPC but there's no actual changes to the scene itself, but only the dialogue- which I don't really read. Lastly, the battle system, I understand why they make it like how they make it, but it is really unintuitive and not fun, making most of the passive skill useless, hell, I still don't understand the MP mechanic with the character having 30++ MP but ended up only capping at 10 while in combat, difficulty itself are quite easy and there's not much to talk about.

Overall 6/10 - Maybe wait for discount or when you got alot of money to spare
TLDR;

Pros:
Nice art
Good story, character, and worldbuilding

Cons:
Very little CG & Repetitive
Unintuitive battle system
Some translation error

I haven't finished this game yet, and I have to say... This isn't what I expected at all.

First of all, gameplay is fun, meaningful, and challenging (unlike many games of the same kind). Sexual content is mandatory for gameplay, not a side stuff you can skip since this game features prostitution as a main theme, and you literally have to do it for survival (don't forget to apply R18 patch on their official website).

What makes this game beautiful though, is the story, the characters, and its thematic narrative.

The game tackles the morality of being a prostitute, not just the normal kind of prostitute also, ch**d prostitution.

You will get to play as a couple of children having to do stuff in order to survive on this harsh world, where you need money to be independent, to procure food and place to sleep, to survive, and not everyone will see you in a good light as it is considered a dirty job for many.

This is just one of the main theme though. The game is much more than that.

It is a world where magic exists... for some.

Suddenly, monsters appear on places throughout the country. Most people couldn't see them at first, but some do, and the ones seeing them are prone to be attacked by them. These monsters only attack people capable to see them. They aren't as helpless though, since if you can see monsters, you will be capable of using magic to fight as well.

There are mystery to explore regarding this stuff, and you'll get to explore it while traveling the world selling your body here and there in order to stay alive.

This game is awesome. If you can handle this kind of stuff, you won't regret buying it.

[h1]100% Uoh üò≠[/h1]
[b]Butterfly Again[/b] is a game that's not for everyone due to the characters' designs and the subject matter, but it's a surprisingly engaging JRPG once you get past that. It features a decent story about the journey of Butterfly and Melly as they search for the latter's father and entertaining game mechanics that take some inspiration from FFVII while giving it a unique touch. So yeah, give it a shot if you're looking for an entertaining JRPG and you don't mind the err... "cute and funny" characters.

Okay, I've had some time to think and have started my first replay, academics can wait. I should preface this by saying that my initial thoughts are below, marked with the date and play time. I also feel the need to state that I am not a picky reader at all and enjoy almost everything, with my average VNDB rating being ~8.5.

I should start with what I consider more superficial but still impactful aspects of a visual novel. I had no problems with the visuals and found them to be quite nice, although I admit they are far from the best I've seen (particularly I noticed during the ending credits, the compression was usually high). 
The audio was quite pleasant, although nothing sticks out in particular to me. I hope this changes once I listen to the soundtrack a bit more and identify my favorite tracks.
And finally, I found the UI and controls to be a bit confusing at first since they mostly utilize the function keys, but maybe an hour in I found it to be non-intrusive and easy to learn, so I wouldn't mind seeing this UI and keyboard layout in the future. 

As for the characters, I realize they are not as well developed as, say, those of Little Busters!, but given the run time I think this VN does a good job. I admittedly can't really relate to Ryusei in any way, as I'm a rather boring person, but I found him to be a fun character that I could find myself getting along with, which made it easy for me to get absorbed in his story and feel the weight of its events. Ginka is absolutely adorable and I should stop myself from spoiling anything. I also enjoyed the rest of the cast; although they fit rather neatly into their stereotypes, I personally find no problem with that. It's an easy way to accelerate their characterization, so if anything I think it works in GINKA's favor. 

And finally, the story. Once again, the individual components aren't really that unique. If you've read any significant number of visual novels, you've seen all these troupes before. But personally, I really enjoyed how they interwove these story components, and how it all came together. 
The foreshadowing and flashbacks set up the story really well in my opinion; the VN will tell you the full story if you just want to turn your brain off and enjoy it, but if you enjoy theorizing the story as it happens, I think GINKA both sets you up for those predictions, as well as throws some unexpected curve balls. It's was very enjoyable for me, as you might be able to tell. 
And of course, can't have a romance story without romance. I think this is rather subjective so I'll just give my impression, I thought Ryusei and Ginka were very cute together, and I love a good childhood romance. Nakige is my favorite genre, so I enjoy all aspects of these games. The romance, drama, humor, all come together to make a beautiful story, and the cheesy, cliche, and even slightly cringe moments are just the cherry on top. 
I still am processing what the story means to me, as I found a lot of points touched on in the story to be very thought provoking, so I'll mostly skip that for now. Suffice to say, I think this resonates with me in a way that the To The Moon series does, which I referenced in my earlier reaction. 
Overall, I greatly enjoyed the story and think it is very well put together. 

Finally, to address the elephant in the room, yes this is basically Summer Pockets Lite with sprinkles of other nakige. I find no problem with that, although I'm also the type of person to reread a story over and over again and enjoy just as much every single time. If you, for some reason, despise seeing the same story and troupes over and over and haven't read Summer Pockets Reflection Blue, I'd point you in that direction instead of GINKA. That's not to say GINKA isn't good, in fact if you've made it to this point you surely can tell I love it, but Summer Pockets RB is unquestionably one of my favorite narratives of all time. 

If you've made it through this word-vomit of a review, then I need not tell you that I heavily recommend this game. All its aspects come together to make a wonderful experience with a captivating story and lovable characters. I hope this visual novel becomes popular (well, as popular as a visual novel can get outside of Asia) because I think it's a very approachable and well written story considering its length of only ~10 hours. I hope you enjoy this visual novel as much as I have!


(2023.10.27; 7.9 hours)

Despite the looming threat of two midterms and two design reviews, I tore through this game. Although it's past 3 AM, I need to get my thoughts down.

First and foremost, what an amazing story. GINKA nailed literally every point for me. The music, graphics, drama, humor, and even the cheesy and cliche moments, GINKA did not miss a beat. There is not doubt in my mind that GINKA has quickly become one of my favorite visual novels of all time. 

As I'm writing this, I feel the same soul-lifting joy that I felt after finishing Little Busters!, Summer Pockets, and ATRI. It hard to explain but it's an incredibly freeing feeling, the pure joy I feel for Ginka and Ryusei, as well as all the other characters. Despite the relatively short length, all the characters grew on me and I got completely absorbed by the story. From the depths of despair to the hard fought moments of hope, happiness, and triumph, this is nakige at its finest. 

On that note, the story. Absolutely incredible. I stand by the fact that its individual aspects are not particularly unique, but the storytelling and overall composition are masterful. The foreshadowing and flashbacks were engaging, and made for an enjoyable active reading experience. Whether I was completely blind sided or nailed a prediction, I couldn't get enough of the story. I absolutely need to read this game again soon, as I'm sure I missed many details and foreshadowing, and I have yet to collect my thoughts on GINKA's overall message, and what it means to me. I shouldn't spoil anything, but at least for me, the story had me deeply contemplating at times. In a way, it reminds me of the To The Moon series (another one of my favorites) for those who have played that.

Wrapping this up, in the simplest words, reading GINKA has brought me incredible joy. As you can probably tell by my rambling, this game has deeply impacted me in a way that few stories have. What a beautiful visual novel; I wait in great anticipation for future releases. 



(2023.10.26; 2.7 hours)

At the moment it feels very much like Summer Pockets Lite, which is by no means a complaint since I am a huge fan of Summer Pockets and Key in general.

Initially, I expected Ginka to provide a similar experience to Atri, one of my favorite visual novels, but the story turned out very different and surprised me in various ways. 
Ginka, despite having ‚ÄúLove‚Äù as the driving force of the story, isn‚Äôt romantic-centric like Atri; it‚Äôs more of a mystery, intriguing, action type of story with romance as an afterthought.
Foreshadows are provided throughout the story that all come together at the end, bringing a satisfactory conclusion. All remaining questions were answered in the after-story which is rather nice despite taking more than half a year since the release day to do so.
The CGs are terrific, the OST is good but not remarkable. I wish the writer expressed the romantic aspect of the relationship between the main couple more colorful since the ‚Äúpureness‚Äù of their love was established too early and remained unchanged even when the story ended, to be honest, it was frustrating that the couple didn‚Äôt express more affection despite so much hardship they went through together. 
Overall, Ginka is a truly engaging story that can keep your eyes glued to the screen till the curtain falls. Definitely check it out if you‚Äôre a fan of mystery, devoted love, and mythology stories.

loved every second of it, memorable cast and amazing OST. truly an experience for my first visual novel.

it isn't about what you see, but how you feel.
two dreams, one world.

OK, this was a really good VN, probably a solid 8/10. I will have to say it's not perfect though. It took me about 15 hours to get a full playthrough. This is one of the few VNs I actually wanted to take my time and read all of the text. Don't expect any adult content, this is a childhood longing that carries into being grownups, and that is absolutely fine.

The art is fantastic, the music is ... ok. There is a lot of supernatural things that happen, and plenty of twists even after the "main twist." There's a lot to unpack in the story. 

There is one "true route," 2 bad ends, and 1 end that's bittersweet, and probably should have been the true ending.  The "after story" is surprisingly long, and is where the bulk of the story really is. I think it was a bit convoluted and could have been trimmed down a bit. Don't get me wrong, it's a good story, but it kind of runs out of steam towards the end. 

If you get the true end, [spoiler] make sure you click "extra" again to get the true, true end [/spoiler]

One real gripe I have is the CG library only has the absolute minimum number of characters in it. I know Ginka is the story, but where's the pictures of Rin, Sensei, and the others??

If you are trying to learn Japanese, you can have both English and Japanese subtitles on the screen at the same time. Also, the interface is top notch, with plenty of save slots and customization options. No flow chart though, so save at the choices.

Shout out to the best cat around.
Best vn I ever had, I love the small details such as moving the character sprites and it was cute. The art also gorgeous.

I was already planning on reading Ginka from long ago and I won the Twitter Steam Giveaway. However I never got the time to entirely sit down and focus so I never got to start... until today. Thankfully I managed to read before the JP Ginka Package arrives and reading it definitely made me more motivated to actually get the package (Special Edition with Dakimakura Cover)

Now for GINKA itself, I don't have heart issues but I definitely relate to Ryuusei's heart issues whenever things happen. I liked the story's overall direction from start to end -- if you could call it that since in the end its like connecting two dots together but you go do a lot of detours before finally connecting them. That is how I ended up thinking of how the flow went but that isn't a bad thing. I almost cried while reading certain parts but once the credits rolled out I was just tearing up.

so i sat down and played the entire game in one sitting. nine and a half hours....

first things first, i'm a huge sucker for happy endings so the fact that this ending was happy is :D

anyways, this novel combined three of my favorite things: supernatural mysteries, dramatic plot twists, and cute anime girls doing cute things.

alsoooooo, the OST is an absolute BANGER

would recommend

I liked the game, nice music, art, and characters. The story was good, but I think I liked Atri My Dear Moment‚Äôs story better. When I finished Atri I felt a more satisfied. It might be due to me not liking the supernatural element of the game and it‚Äôs implication on the story. Having magic allows the story to (major spoilers)[spoiler] magically solve problems and they all live happily ever after because the powers of god[/spoiler] it is still a good story and a decent ending though.

Note: the above is my original thoughts from a few months back. Now after playing the new After story, I will say the after story made me like the ending A LOT better since the original ending felt way too abrupt.

In case anyone is wondering, I keep mentioning Atri My Dear Moments because they are made by pretty much same staff development wise except VAs. Highly rec both games. Also this game reminded me of Summer Pockets as well, another favorite. There's an expanded version called Summer Pockets Reflection Blue that should get an official translation soon. Or, you can buy and download on Dlsite, then look up Alka Translations who did a really good fan translation on it.

By the end I was very conflicted on how I feel about my time with this one. Overall, I appreciate the experience but at the same time I feel annoyed because I expected and wanted something else out of it.

I wanted a blossoming relationship between two childhood friends but I never got that. Instead, I was left as frustrated as the MC at some points with the weird meandering directions the story was taking.
The big overarching story surrounding the island and its inhabitants plays a very big role and keeps being  highlighted as such to the point where the VN is all about that, but I ended up not caring as much about it because it treated the two characters I cared about the most like garbage and by the end they were nothing but passengers. The story made the main heroine behave in ways that frustrated me even though it made sense, and everything else just felt like it was getting more and more absurd the longer it went with all the new problems the MC was faced with. 

I probably would've enjoyed it a lot more if I didn't want a romance so badly. Because of that, I'm left peeved. Regardless of what I want however, I would say that this VN is still fairly solid. Good artwork along with characters I enjoyed reading about. The story outside the two main characters is fine despite it not being aligned with my interests and desires for the VN. If you can go into this wanting to know more about the whole picture rather than hyper focusing on the main pair like I did, you'll probably like it.

[h3] Audio [/h3]

[h3] Conclusion[/h3]
A solid visual novel overall, would recommend if it's on sale.

[b][i]Open-world RPG with spells in the form of a deck of cards and hardcore turn-based combat in the form of a button-mashing mini-game.[/i][/b]
Gameplay:
https://youtu.be/AUWluBXbKlg

Everspell is reminiscent of the ROBLOX Game "Arcane Lineage". You explore the world around you in real time, trade and communicate with NPCs, complete quests and fight monsters in hardcore turn-based battles.

The character has an inventory with items and equipment. You can use weapons and armor.
There is a special inventory for spells. Spells are like cards, you build your deck before battle.

As soon as the battle begins, the game moves you to an arena divided into a grid layout. You can move your character across the cells of the field and attack the enemy with spells.
To cast a spell, you must have time to press a sequence of buttons that the game will show you.

[u]You can read other reviews and subscribe to our curators. Welcome![/u] 
[url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/25737869/] 5 minutes of game [/url]

Everspell is a simple tactical RPG that uses vector graphics. It's very likely from a solo developer, though I can't confirm this for certain. 

You choose a character class and begin wandering around a semi-open-world engaging in turn based combat. The game incorporates some light platforming elements. 

Unfortunately, the game suffers from balance issues and various UI choices that make it a chore to play. A general list of these: 

 A. When casting spells and using abilities, you have to play very small mini games which involving tapping keys in a sequence. If you fail these games, your spell will fail. This mechanic is clunky and overtuned. 
B. Several UI elements are text only, and placed directly over things you do not want to click. This can result in dropping abilities. 
C. Stat bars and other elements lack texturing and polish. This isn't particularly an over sight, it's just hard to look at sometimes. 
D. Enemy life bars are fairly chunky. This can result in combats which are a foregone conclusion continuing for many turns longer than they need to. 


It's quite likely the mechanics of the game need some revisiting. The developer would likely find better results hyper focusing on specific game mechanics and fleshing them out. Currently the card choose mechanic for abilities isn't complex enough or interesting, and the mini-games-for-spells mechanic just gets in the way. It's hard to say who the target audience is here... Some parts of the game suggest a nice entry level tactical game for children, but the punishing nature would put off most adults. 

Hopefully it's developer Bublik's first attempts at running out a unity engine game, and they can take some of this on board and produce some better games in future. Compiling a functioning game is always an achievement. 

No specific game breaking bugs encountered.

From the little I've played what's easy to tell, is that the dialogues with NPC's and the cutscenes have been interesting so far.

Regarding the combat I've been able to unlock quite a few spells although I've just started the game. The game encourages experimentation as the player can switch around a variety of spells to see how each of them works for thier playstyle, combining them is also another factor that adds even further dept to the game. 

One final thing I'd like to note is that the music is great, hope the full soundtrack is released at some point. Going to be putting more hours into this game as time goes on and I recommed you pick it up too.
One of the best indie strategy games to come out this year. I love the simplicity of combat and the exploration that comes along with it to enhance my experience. Definetely give this a try!

"Everspell" is an RPG masterpiece that swept me away into a world of enchantment and adventure from the very first moment I stepped foot into its immersive realm. As an avid gamer, I've traversed countless virtual landscapes, but none have captured my imagination quite like Everspell.

One of the most captivating aspects of Everspell is its vast and meticulously crafted world. From sprawling forests teeming with mythical creatures to towering castles shrouded in mystery, every corner of the game is begging to be explored. Each area is brimming with detail and lore, making every journey a new and exciting experience.

But Everspell isn't just about exploration; it's about the journey you take and the characters you meet along the way. The diverse cast of characters you encounter throughout your adventure are richly developed, each with their own unique personalities and motivations. Whether you're teaming up with allies to vanquish powerful foes or engaging in heartfelt conversations with NPCs, every interaction feels meaningful and memorable.

Beyond its stunning visuals and engaging gameplay, Everspell also boasts a captivating storyline that kept me hooked from start to finish. From epic battles against ancient evils to heartwarming moments of camaraderie, the narrative unfolds in a way that is both gripping and emotionally resonant.

In conclusion, Everspell is a true gem of the RPG genre, offering a captivating world to explore, memorable characters to meet, and thrilling gameplay to experience. I thoroughly enjoyed every moment spent in its enchanting universe, and I cannot recommend it highly enough to fellow adventurers seeking their next epic quest.

First and foremost, the world of "Everspell" is enchanting and awe-inspiring. Every area is adorned with detailed and meticulously crafted visuals. From the depths of dense forests to the peaks of towering mountains, each location is filled with secrets waiting to be discovered. Every corner of the game presents a new story, keeping the experience continuously fresh.

In terms of gameplay, "Everspell" is both innovative and enjoyable. The combat system offers strategic depth, challenging players to think critically. Additionally, the abilities and upgrades of characters allow players to personalize their play style, making each player‚Äôs experience unique.

The characters in "Everspell" are the heart of the game. Each one is richly developed with intricate backstories and complex personalities. Interacting with these characters is one of the most satisfying aspects of the game. Being part of their stories helps players form emotional connections.

Storytelling is one of "Everspell's" strongest points. The game takes players on a compelling adventure from start to finish. The narrative is enriched with surprising twists and emotional moments. Players will encounter new developments at every turn, making it difficult to put the game down.

In conclusion, "Everspell" is not just a game; it is an experience. With its deep story, complex characters, and enchanting world, it brings a fresh perspective to the RPG genre. Every detail of this game is crafted with care, offering players an unforgettable adventure. For RPG fans, "Everspell" is undoubtedly a masterpiece not to be missed.

Fun and charming little collect-a-thon inspired by the Sly Cooper-series.
Hide your cheese - Mousey is in the housey!

Great collectathon platformer full of little details and flourishes in the animations, texture work, and level design that give it a tonne of charm and character. The game is split up into dense open-ended stages with collectibles scattered all over the place (some obvious and some fiendishly tucked away) with the mandatory ones unlocking additional levels, and the secret ones unlocking cosmetics, concept videos, and even new levels. It's a fun little throwback that wears its influences (Sly Cooper, mostly) on its sleeve, and I really [i]really[/i] had a lot of fun with it. I sincerely hope we get a sequel in the future.

A sequel, and a way to turn off the depth of field. It's a bit on the heavy side.

A big surprise! Traditional 3D platform game like from old good days with proven mechanics that grabs You and won't let go until you've accomplish everything you can. Everything is mainly about jumping and finding objects. Some are for unlocking new levels, some for new skins and some are just collectibles. Challinging, but amusing experience. The main hero is a mouse, which is cool. Worth it.

The developer sent me a copy of this game for review, and I really enjoyed it. Very much in the vein of 2000's collect-a-thons with its animal protagonist and open level design. I've always loved the "exploring human spaces as a very small character" aspect of it, and it even felt a little Tome and Jerry-ish, which is a good thing. There were only a couple things I would change: 1) add a little more music so it isn't quite so repetitive, and 2) make the forks easier to land on (maybe I'm the only one who's bad at it). Regardless, this is a solid game which I enjoyed a lot.

It's pretty small of a game and a little rough around the edges, but boy, this is one heck of a Sly Cooper clone, and an incredibly great one at that! Platforming is very reminiscent of that, the atmosphere works so well in the levels which are all incredibly engaging to traverse in, and the extra content is definitely something I'll be sure to come back to for more fun! All helped by the overall presentation of the game with its cell shaded art style, sound design for collecting cheese, jumping, attacking and such, as well as the great musical score provided by the accompanying soundtrack. 

Me only real complaint with the game is that there's only one save slot, meaning if I want to come back and do a fresh new play-through of the game, I have to delete progress from me last save which...was never something that aged well between the 7th and 8th generation of gaming and for good reason. And considering that time trials are a thing in this game, with time records to beat, yeah, I'd much rather avoid deleting me old save if it means I can keep that record saved for meself.

But that's really it as far as criticisms goes. Other than that, game's still pretty great! Can't wait to see how much more gets added to this game as time goes on!

[h2]Kharkiv Neo-Noir - or how I drank too much coffee to get an achievement[/h2]
[i]a futuristic Ukrainian detective Story[/i]

Have you ever made a video game? Maybe yes.
Have you ever made a video game in a warzone? Probably not.
[i]Brenntkopf Studio Kharkiv[/i] from Ukraine have.
[b]Son of Perun Kharkiv[/b] is the fifth (!) game the studio released since the full-scale invasion. I bought their first game out of curiosity, then I got all in into this niche. I really like indie games. I really like indie games with voice-over in various languages. I like first-person-shooters. Son of Perun Kharkiv is all three.
It comes with a energetic soundtrack straight from the city. I will link the full soundtrack below. The game has four well-placed achievements. You will be able to earn all achievements during one play-through. 
Play the game to get into the story. It‚Äôs about a badass war veteran cop who‚Äôs on a mission in a rough city with lack of morals but surplus of caffeine.
The humor is fantastisch, fighting is well-balanced and all the characters speak Ukrainian Language. For a indie shooter there is surprisingly much voice-acting! Mission text and npc-dialogues all have voice-over. Huge respect.

See you in Kharkiv!
[spoiler]P.S.: there's an ingame music-player which works like a regular mp3-player in rl![/spoiler]
[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aMhdvTRLKuo&list=PL7YY1TXn9yWQlpwCxvcpBKeeqiHl1RQev&index=1&ab_channel=AksiyUA]Son of Perun Kharkiv soundtrack by Aksiy (YouTube)[/url]

Hello all, 

Firstly i want to say this game has huge potential, talking as a professional game quality assurance tester. 

Unfortunately, it is not currently close to being up to par in my unbiased opinion. There are so many aspects that not only need to be improved but also completely reworked. 
I hope the dev reads this whole thing attentively, for the same reason i did not refund this game. I think you can improve, and i think you can learn a lot. I really really want this game to be good, and i think it could be insanely fun with enough work put into it.

Im going to list off the things that popped to mind as i played casually without trying to search for bugs or break the game : 

[list]

    [*]The farming system needs an overhaul. It is way too long and tedious to water and ferment every plant one by one, to an extent where it is much easier to completely ignore this aspect of the game to get wood, rock and buy stuff from the merchant.

    [*]Speaking of the merchant, i understand he is called the wandering merchant, however he wanders way too far and wastes a lot of your time just to find and get to him, even by using the map. 

    [*]We desperately need a clock, watch, timer, anything to indicate what point in the day we are. Exploration is clearly encouraged, however, you nearly cannot explore at all before night comes and you are too far to get back in time. Additionally, days need to be longer to make the resource gathering, exploring, and crafting viable in any way. 

    [*]The sprint speed is satisfying considering the lack of time, and the enormity of the map. However, Cave exploration is rendered unremarkable as you can simply run past every enemy, press e on the chest, and leave. I recommend adding a "Kill all enemies" restriction to these chests, as well as better rewards in them. 

    [*]There are lots of unfortunate glitches that need to be worked out, such as pressing escape in any menu such as inventory or the shop will softlock your game and lose your save without exception. Sometimes the audio does not play at all, which is a shame because i think your audio is one of the strongest points of this game currently.

    [*]The inventory would also need to be reworked, as it currently feels very clunky. I wish when i bought or crafted items, they went straight into the empty spaces of my hotbar. Id love if the hotbar had more slots as well. The click and drag, is tedious as you need to click, stop clicking, move to the hotbar, then click again which can be severely annoying in normal times, and infinitely more so during combat.

    [*]The game could benefit from a short tutorial explaining crafting, resource gathering, farming and combat. I understand games that don't hold hands and i respect that, but even dark souls has a short explanation of its main features.

    [*]There needs to be more tower defence aspects, i think you could take inspiration from games such as Plants VS Zombies to merge your farming and defence to an extent as there are so many enemies.

    [*]The map is pretty and big, however it feels empty as there are not many places to actually explore, or they are all very far apart. I think you could add some more simple cabins, camp grounds, roads, fences and etc just to give it a bit of life.

    [*]I think detailed damage and HP could be added as descriptions to items and weapons, perhaps also to enemies.

    [*]I don't know if there is a repair tool or not, i could not find it if so. I really wanted to repair everything. 

    [*]I don't understand why you put so much emphasis on the game being an FPS when there is no shooting, only melee weapons. Perhaps you could lean into the fantastical such as the monsters and make magic related weapons?

    [*]This game would benefit a flood-worth from 4 player co-op multiplayer in all aspects. It would be several times more manageable, more fun and overall a better experience. Even if the game remained exactly as it currently is, but with multiplayer, it would be much more worth putting in some hours with friends to survive more than 3 days.

  

[/list]


Finally, i apologize profusely that i wrote such a long amount of text. I am so incredibly frustrated that i did not have fun playing this game, when the concept was so interesting to me. I know you are a solo dev or small team, and i know its easy to say all these things, when they would takes months of work to pull off. My sincere hope is that you do pull it off, because i think you can. 

Don't hesitate to add me if you want to talk about it, im sorry again i was so insanely critical.

As of right now I cannot recommend this game. There is clearly potential, but with no news for any planned update and the current state of the game I would say don't buy this.

Negatives:
Currently it is incredibly difficult to survive the first night. It took me probably three tries or so. The pacing of this game is rushed, the direction is lacking, the hitboxes have a lot of play in them (for enemies and for things like watering your crops), the balancing of resources you obtain versus the amount you need is not quite there (it's not the worst but the jankiness scales with how rushed you are to get turrets and fences down just so you can survive), the farming takes too much time and after a single yield of tomatoes and one yield of three plot's worth of potatoes I just stopped farming, and the information of items and objects is severely lacking. There's no numbers anywhere on cost, sell price, damage, health, nothing. It's all a guessing game. I really cannot stress enough that in a game that advertises itself as a farming game, farming is completely pointless. It's the only means to heal yourself, but the starting tomato yield will be plenty for days on end, and it is impossible to know what the yields will get you or how much money the crops make you, so don't even bother.

Positives:
The monster design is really cool. Incredibly varied and though they're not monsters you haven't seen before it's really fun. The premise is good, though executed with a sloppy hand, and the mix of FPS and tower defense is really great. The dev is clearly creative, and exploring and fighting are the highlights of this game by far.

Summary:
The negatives I've listed are easy fixes, if the dev cares to. The game is PLAYABLE, it just currently sucks to do so. So first and foremost I would do this if I was the dev: quality of life and ease of play (at least early on in new games), including things like: increasing the day time, giving more resources for chest finds, decreasing resource cost for bulk objects such as fences and plots, removing the resource cost for repairing your placed objects, SLOW DOWN your enemies, and reduce the initial spawn count/frequency the first few nights, give us numbers for quantifying HP, damage, and sell costs so we can figure out selling and buying, and fix the hit boxes. Literally just do that and you'll fix this game.
I like the concept a lot. The game itself is fun though a little buggy here and there. Honestly could turn into a really awesome solo developed game with a bit more love and time.

In it's current state I really can't recommend buying the game for the cost.
For the first hour or so it's a good time but it just gets repetitive.
The crafting is limited and the hordes seem to be a bit...off. It's not necessarily buggy but the next wave doesn't start until the one before has been completely destroyed and sometimes the monsters seem to get caught in places..which means you get one wave of monsters then..nothing.

After a couple fixes and maybe expanding on some of the basic ideas I think this game could be great-especially as a multiplayer game. Currently...it needs work.

Currently in its state I cannot give it a positive review. the reasons why is the achievements are not working, the first night is pretty hard (but doable), after the third day the merchant has nothing new to sell. Also, I was able 2 defeat the game in 14 days. I won't go into details, but I have to say there is a lot of potential in this game. The only main problem now is the developer needs to get into gear and continue with some updates. It‚Äôs been a while since the game has gotten a update. We shall see if they do.

This action/crafting game gives you a real purpose to your activities ‚Äì you need to build up your defenses (fences, automatic turrets, food to heal you) during the peaceful daytime so that you can survive the alien attacks at night time. You can also swing your ax during the nighttime to try and protect your farm, but the aliens are pretty tough, so it's much more survivable if you have good defenses. 

Note that there's almost no hand-holding so expect to die a lot at first while you figure out what you can do, and what actually helps you survive the onslot at night. A nice change of course from the games that constantly tell you want to do every 10 seconds! There also seems to be a fairly large map to explore, 1 hour in I've only seen a small part of it, and there's definitely loot hidden out there. The game kind of reminds me of a simpler, single player Ark Survival Evolved, but with considerably more utility to crafting structures than in ark, and no boring downtime at night. I do wish the controller support was a bit more robust though. The game is definitely playable without mouse and keyboard, but I did have to do some button remapping (and use steam input to invert Y) before all features were accessible.

Not recommended in its current state.
The game has potential, sure, but no part of it is fleshed out in any way.

The farming part is bare-bone at best. And there are annoying bugs like targeting farm plots to water if you build them " too close" to each other.
Harvesting resources is just tedious.

And the night-time defense sequence isn't working right either. There doesn't seem to be any rhyme or progression to the attacks.
It should be easy first nights and then gradually become harder. As far as I can tell, it's the same monsters every night.

The day is too short. You have barely time to chop some wood, and maybe tend to your farm before the night attacks start.

Also, the achievements don't seem to work.
I have been waiting for over a month for something as simple as inverting the controls on the mouse.  Can't play the game as it is but now its too late to refund.  Enjoy my money scab.

During the day, you'll find yourself managing and growing your farm, which is a staple of farming sim games. This entails cultivating crops and other aspects like resource management and building. The farming aspects offer a peaceful and relaxing gaming experience, allowing players to create and customize their farms.

However, the twist comes when night falls. As the sun sets, you're thrust into a survival scenario where you must defend your farm and yourself from terrifying creatures. This switch from a laid-back farming simulation to an intense FPS experience as they need to fortify their defenses, upgrade their weapons, and fight off waves of menacing foes.

I have definitely never known the developer or played other of his games, but I got to say this one has been worth the purchase price for me even though I'm on my 1st run through. I generally like base building, tower defense type games like 7DTD, Empyrion, Space Engineers, SmallLand, Conan Exiles, etc.  While this game of course doesn't rise to the level of those, it is better than hundreds of other similar ones in my library.

At first, it's hard to get used to the extremely quick day/night cycle. I don't think its adjustable and really flies by. But I think that is for balance since you could probably gather and craft so much during the day that the mob attacks at night would be too easy otherwise.

The art style of the enemies vary. Probably asset placeholders to be replaced if he continues to enhance the game into the future. 

There are some UI bugs that are easily worked around.

There are a few biomes and a large enough map.

Run speed is very fast, which is nice, so I didn't think there would be fall damage but found out the hard way that there is.

I wish the dev well and will check back soon to see if his design choices and continued efforts can make a real gem.
I love it. The mechanics, game sounds, feelings are all absolutely perfect. It makes a difference with its open world and fine details. I definitely recommend it.

Another great game by Applebomb. A mix of farming Sim & fps Survival where you farm and gather resources at the morning and at night you have to survive the monsters attack. THe character and the monsters design are awesome.

It seems fine so far, nothing to special. Like the concept, was 7 bucks. 

However after an hour or two I stopped because pressing esc pauses and instead of exiting the menu, as small as this is it really hinders my flow.

[h1] Awful[/h1]
The day night cycle is too short, with no way to change it. 
Just a game of speed.
No substance.
A money grab.
Stay away.
Nothing else to say.

So I have t played long, just 4 nights in, but there is ONE fatal flaw I can already see: daytime length. At first your biggest priority would be getting a weapon/sentry turret, and then you can focus more on farming and gathering resources; however, and this is especially true as nights progress, daytime is so incredibly short that you will oftentimes be unable to even gather enough resources to craft new defenses or maintain the ones you have. This is compounded by monsters getting exponentially tougher as nights go on. It basically puts a hard cap to how far you can survive because eventually you'll hit a resource deficit if you slip up on your progress even slightly. 

The game itself is fun for what it's worth, it's a decent little defensive survival craft. I would definitely continue playing it, it's pretty fun mechanically and combat wise - and the laid back theme is pretty relaxing. That crippling daytime length though is the biggest, most blatant issue with the game thus far.

03/12/2024 - Update! Game is abandoned. Unfinished, unpolished, imbalanced, and no word from the developers in eons. Very sad.

Original review below:


This is a VERY RELUCTANT recommend.

Things about this game that genuinely angered me:

1: Hitting ESC to open the menu CANNOT be used to close the menu. You have to use your mouse to click on resume.

2: Pinpoint precision. Hitting trees, hitting rocks, if you hit the button to swing even 1 inch off of it, and 99% of the animation hits the rock, or tree, it results in an empty swing. Very annoying.

3: Watering plants is annoying. Not because it's a chore, but it's also a PINPOINT accuracy type of thing. You can sit there staring at the plant with your water draining out, and not give the plant a single ounce of liquid unless you are precisely on the right spot, which can take a couple tries to even find.

4: Turrets. They're awesome, but they steal your kills. Normally, killing an enemy with your weapon gives you money, but your turret kills do not give you a dime.

5: PACING - I had to replay the first day about 9 times till it felt like I was mastering a speed run because of how short the days are before the nightly wave.

My speedrun tactic for surviving THE FIRST DAY is as follows:

SPRINT to the box in front of the barn, SPRINT behind the barn for the chest, then SPRINT to the nearest clump of trees, and chop down as many as humanly possible in the shortest amount of time so you can afford the pickaxe, if you can find the trader in time, sell ALL of your wood to buy the pickaxe, and start over with SPRINTING to trees and rocks till you have enough for about three turrets. 

6: Merchant. Having money isn't enough. You need to harvest resources ALONG with having money in order to buy most things. This is really annoying because you don't go to Ace Hardware with clumps of iron ore and logs in order to buy tools. It just doesn't make any sense considering the merchant is just aimlessly wandering around, and has no way to actually use these items to make the things that are being sold, which would make sense.

7: ... Actually, I'll just cut it off at 7. This game is clearly a labor of love, and hopefully these tip of the iceberg issues get solved someday.

Things about this game I genuinely enjoyed:

1: Building! It's fun to put fences around, fun to place crops, and it's fun to place turrets, and not to focus on the negatives, but beware when building too close to your barn, as there are no hit detection for the walls. Enemies can go inside the barn and absolutely devastate anything built too close on the other side.

2: Exploration. Despite not really being given more than a couple minutes of daylight to RUSH to grab resources like it's a speedrun on day 1, it is kinda fun to go into a cave and find some rare minerals to sell.

3: The concept is genuinely fun. You're a farmer, you've got a farm, and you're trying to grow stuff, but enemies come at night. It's a cool idea, a cool concept, but the quality of life just isn't there yet.

I genuinely think this game could someday develop into a really cool game, but as it stands now, it's just not there. I want this game to succeed, and I want updates to get them there, thus the positive review, but again, it comes very reluctantly.

You also want some fps survival? we got you!

This game is still in early access so its incomplete with many mechanics obviously lacking content that will later be added, and will hopefully get better. 

For now though, I'd say this game is pretty good

Pros:
The character models are nice looking and pretty sexy looking. the fact that every female character also has large tits is very appreciated.
The animation is also very good. seeing a characters assets swing about as they move is a lovely detail.
Can be played with one hand
Story is promising. an adopted son building a drug empire to avenge his adoptive father and protect his family, whilst darker forces move in, is very promising.
Characters are mostly one note but still nice to be around. there's no point in the game where i've been forced to interact with a character i didn't like.
I encountered no major bugs in my first play through.

Cons: 
levelling up is boring. you do get exp from doing missions but the bulk of your levelling comes from doing the same shooing range mini game over and over again, and if you want to get to max level your going to have to shoot a lot of targets.
The mechanical difficulty isn't difficult. the character creator makes it sound like the different choices will make your run easier or harder, but really it only makes the game longer or shorter. despite technically being at war with all the surrounding cartels, they never actually attack your home so you can just sit at home selling weed till you can steamroll the first city. from there its just grinding levels.
Lack of choices, maybe more will be added over time but at the moment there are very few choices your character can make, meaning most of the time you're just watching events play out with no influence on those events.

I hope development will be kind to this game since there is a lot of potential. so here's what i would like to see.
One, add some fluff choices. the choices that do exist seem to have actual meaning (or at least they eventually will as development progresses) which is good, but having some extra fluff choices to allow a player to personalise their play through, even if those choices have no wider effect on the story would be nice.
Secondly some more cartel management content. maybe other cities unlock further in the game, but at this point, having taken over, fully upgraded, fully garrisoned the first city I can't attack the second city. so I'm just sitting around banking millions of dollars and stockpiling guns just in case.
so either more things to attack, or even random events. like "oh hey your base in under attack by a rival cartel. do you have 50 spare guns or 20 spare men to fend them off, or else you'll lose a lot of money."
or
"one of our men betrayed us! are we gonna gun him down or are we gonna spend some cash to reward the loyal ones?"

Two, their needs to be more risk. you're in a war with cartels and yet i feel like I'm playing against the easy mode AI in an RTS, they kind of just sit there and let me attack them piece by piece, and i can replace my garrisons way faster then the enemy can deplete them. if there was an auto garrison button, i'd hardly notice the attacks on my businesses. I think if you had to keep some men sitting around home to defend against enemy attacks or your family members might be kidnapped or you get killed, that would be good. Implement mechanics that if managed poorly kill me, but if managed well, reward me. that would be nice

Third, more stuff to do with your money would be nice, as this game gets developed more stuff will be added of course, but being able to bribe officers to look the other way, or bribe the mayor to harass other cartels preventing them from attacking me, or hand out loans to businesses for future profit, would be nice.

Four, and I know this has nothing to do with the game itself, but as the game gets developed in early access, slowly increase the price of the game as it gets more content. that way people can't just buy the game before it comes out, wait a month or two, then get the full game for a fraction of the price.

This game is being released in Early Access. That means that the game may, or may not, change from its current state.

[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
Cartel Simulator is a RenPy visual novel with a heavy management lean.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Your adoptive mother, Sophia Hernandez, was the leader of a cartel. She adopted you because she didn't have a male heir. Sophia has stepped back from the running the cartel, and your family moved. However, news has reached Sophia that your lives are in danger from the other cartels. You decide it is time for you to get involved in the family business.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
There is a short introduction to the game and then you set your first name. Your last name is Hernandez and cannot be changed. Next you pick your difficulty level. Each has its pros and cons. Next you pick the flag for your Cartel and set the name of the Cartel. Next you select your best friend, one of the four female main characters.

The first year introduces you to the backstory of the game and takes a half hour to 45 minutes to get through. After that the game is very much grindy. There are quests, but you need to make a lot of money to complete most of them, $1,000,000. Once you get the club you're making $25K a day, so that is 40 days to make the money. Then you can sell weed, but that is less than $15K a day. It wasn't until late in the game I found how to access the other cities, the map button in the upper left of the map, so this could probably be sped up by taking over businesses in another city. That's the funny thing, some things are blocked until you start taking over businesses in another city and the map starts on your starting city of Teruca. I only found the other cities by accident.

You can go to the shooting range to gain experience. It costs $150 to go to the shooting range. As far as I could see, as long as you have more than that you can use the shooting range, but the money isn't deducted. Targets pop up and shoot at you approximately every two seconds that they are up. Once your health is gone the session is over. I spent a lot of time trying to actually shoot the targets as they pop, then I found out that you only have to press the mouse button and you will hit the target. So, place your cursor on the line under the bullets, to the left of the word bullets and click when a target pops up. Then when you are out of bullets you are on top of the reload button.

I can't tell you how leveling works exactly. You click on the gun in your hide out to access the leveling screen. Your main way to gain experience, at least early on, is the shooting range. However, you can't gain multiple levels at a time. So, there is no point getting a massive score at the shooting range. However, I was level 14 and the stat screen showed that I needed 1000 XP, that works out to 4,000 points at the range. So, I got my 4,000 points, but no level up message. So, I went dancing to get some XP, I got 4 whole points. Now the stat bar is showing 1004 / 1000, but still no level up message. Bottom line, the status bar is not an accurate indicator of the experience you need for the next level.

The developer has released one update since release. Since the game has only been out for a month it isn't clear if that is the continue plan. Some of the story lines have "End of current content" messages, others do not. The developer has stated that they plan on updates approximately every two months.

Most of the achievements depend on your choices, in certain situations. Theoretically, you could get all of the achievements on one playthrough, using save slots and selecting all of the options after reloading.

[h1]The Gallery[/h1]
There is no Gallery. Some of the scenes are easily repeatable, others are a one-time thing. So you can use save slots to replay the scenes you like.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
A decent game, with okay art. There is a lot of room for improvement. As this is Early Access those improvements may, or may not, arrive. Updates are planned every other month.

[h1]System Specs[/h1]

Motherboard: Gigabyte X670E AORUS EXTREME (rev. 1x)
RAM: G.SKILL Trident Z5 Neo Series (AMD Expo) DDR5 RAM 64GB (2x32GB)
Video: ASUS TUF Gaming GeForce RTX 4080

The game is clearly in early access. There are obviously several stories and features lacking at the moment, and some minor bugs here and there to iron out. That being said, what has been present so far is well written, and both the still frames and animations look great. It's clear that much effort was dedicated to making those work - there are no graphical glitches, and the only thing that might bug some people is that the movements don't perfectly loop indefinitely. You will notice a stutter before things reposition to start the animation cycle again. The game cycle for some tasks is repetitive, but once more features are added, the greater variety of ways to do things should help reduce the monotony of something like going to the shooting range to level up because it's the only reliable way of large amounts of exp. Overall, a pretty solid game that just needs more content to be added.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW

Compared to the first release of this developer (Never Meet Your Heroes), this one is an improvement in every aspect, especially the scenes which are way better, but also longer (Not always a 3-second loop animation). It's easy enough to understand and not grindy when you need money. I applaud the developers for not making a copy-paste like others often do.

Now for the negative... I usually read everything, but I felt the story in this one was just dragging on and on (Which I felt the same for Never Meet Your Heroes). Too much text with barely any scenes. I'm pretty sure I did everything that was offered in this version, and I only got like 5 scenes. Now, like I said this is still early access, but I felt there was something missing.

Again, this might change with future updates but right now, the game is worth it, and I'm looking forward for what's next !
