It's ok. The topic and approach is innovative and interesting; especially for a game using the Ren'Py visual novel engine.

I wouldn't say you "navigate" the drug trade though. There's really only one main path the protagonist is obliged to follow. As you'd expect, there's lot of indiscriminate murder and mayhem. More problematic is the railroaded plot - as you can't spare some people (such as the schoolgirl you are obliged to murder) whilst you are forced to intervene and spare others (a certain highschool crush) despite the implied risk.

There's some content and obviously a lot of potential; but when the Early Access content runs out, there's no indication in the game that this has happened - so you'll be spinning your wheels for a couple of weeks of in-game turns before realising you've actually run out of road.

Tentative recommend for people that don't mind a janky user interface overhaul of Ren'Py and playing as a bad guy (not a "good" bad-guy; an actual bad bad-guy).

Being a fan of David's work (particularly Chop Goblins), I decided to buy this game!

It's a cool little title where you navigate through a dark factory, killing mutated unicorn/human hybrids with your pistol.

The pistol shoots faster the longer you hold the trigger, which is a satisfying mechanic that I can't recall seeing in any other games. That being said, this is (obviously) not a high-speed boomer shooter where you're constantly fragging enemies and hopping around like Gordon Freeman. It's slower, and has a stronger focus on presentation/atmosphere than gameplay. No running, and no jumping. Just shooting and a small story told by pages found throughout.

It must be stated that this game is [i]extremely[/i] short, clocking in at about 33 minutes. The asking price is pretty inoffensive (especially for an indie), but it should definitely be considered before purchase. There are also a few modes to help with replayability, though I think you'd have to be a specific type to run through the game multiple times as it's very linear.

If you're okay with spending a few dollars for a half-hour experience w/ optional replay modes for challenge (with the added bonus of supporting an indie dev), then, [b]yes, I recommend this game[/b]. Ideally, a title this short would be free, but I understand game development is *not* free.

I don't know how David Szymanski keeps managing to make games based exactly on whatever genre or niche I thought "Wow, I wish someone would make something like this again." about.
I play Quake and Blood, he makes DUSK. I play Doom 3, he makes The Pony Factory, I play Manhunt & Condemned, he's making that now. It's getting weird. Stop looking at my Recently Played for inspiration.

Anyways, this is a short half hour long horror game where you can't have a flashlight and your gun out at the same time. No duct tape mod to be found. You need to scan your surroundings quickly to check what's out there, then fire at where it might be. Muzzle flash also lights things up, but ammo is a limited resource. I had good fun with it, and I'll probably play it again on one of the challenge modes in the future. This release also includes some goodies and the soundtrack in the files. Lovely little treat.

David Szymanski is my favorite solo game dev, his games have a simple charm and he often takes really simple but clever concepts and turns them into surprisingly fantastic games.

However I don't think this game should have gotten it's own standalone release, it's simply not that great compared to his other works. It was originally part of Dread X and made in only 7 days, and even with the remaster this version honestly still feels like that. It just doesn't do anything that other games don't do better, even some of David's own games.

If this game looks interesting to you, I'd honestly recommend just buying Dusk instead, by the same developer. It's a very similar concept but much more fleshed out and fun. 

I still won't be refunding it because I love David and want to support his future works, but I don't think I can recommend this game for any other reasons than that.

A surprisingly good game that's pretty reminiscent of Cry of Fear.
A brilliant and striking narrative about how corporate greed will twist and rend any wholesome dream into a hellish nightmare... I think...

Another great one from this dev. Frankly juggling between being able to See and being able to Shoot is probably some of the most fun I've had in a while with a shooter. It makes the game so much more tense and it forces you to think more about how you're using the tools given to you. Do I take out my flashlight to get a better look, and risk getting myself killed in the second it takes to switch back to the gun? Or, do I use the gun as my light, and risk wasting bullets, in the hopes that I might hit something that I can't see yet?

The atmosphere is great. The crisp black shadows make it difficult to parse things, but not in a fuzzy, annoying way. The noises, especially the ponies, are horrifying in the best way, not to mention those noises being another way of keeping yourself safe: Even if you can't see them, you can still Hear them.

The story itself is so silly it wraps back around to being genius, IMO. I feel like with a lot of horror you get a lot of ultra serious stuff, and a lot of stuff that's Trying to be serious but falls flat. This is not that. This is a game where you can pick up a note and read that Fred Flintstone is a canonical character in this universe and is, indirectly, partially culpable for the forced physical transformations of an entire town into gross, flayed, magical ponies. I like that a lot.

Obviously its a short game, and the AI wasn't the best (I got a lot of cheap kills that I probably shouldn't have gotten, LOL), but even despite that I enjoyed myself thoroughly. I'll likely play it again to show my friends. My only critique is I wish you got an achievement for jumping in The Precarious Death Pit, but hey, you can't win em all.

This game is amazing, it really brings out the human instinct of fear of the undead four legged creatures commonly found on planet Earth. This game puts you in a really immersive mindset of something like a Chicago police officer handling violent animals by calmly diffusing the situation with an entire mag to their body. My only critique of the game is there is not nearly enough precarious death pits to make the game feel well rounded and realistic to the world within the game. Overall this game is a 10/10 experience and I would recommend it to those who enjoy brutally murdering animals with advanced killing machines.

Better than what the trailer presents, and I love that cheesy music score. It's perfect.

Typically love these types of PSX indie horror games and David Szymanski has a pretty good library, but this isn't great. Story was going for silly and it fell flat; music was nothing but a theremin making alien noises; enemy variety was lacking; and the gameplay was walking down a hallway and then back again. 

Not great. Not even really worth the small price.

This is what I imagined a kidnapper's basement looked like when I was a child, and the trials and tribulations I'd have to go through to escape. If you're off-put by the idea of killing magic ponies, don't worry, they're not very nice. In fact, I'd go as far as to call them mean.

Buy this game for the atmosphere, not the combat; it doesn't excel in PvE. Enemies can get stuck on walls, which isn't great for immersion or tension. Being forced to hold either your weapon or flashlight was effective in making me feel the littlest bit more vulnerable than the dark closed-in setting already did. It's a simple gimmick that works as intended, but isn't fleshed out by any notable design. I personally loved the grim, noir lighting and sparse glowing windows and lights. Keep in mind that the main game can be completed in around 30 minutes.
Only Szymanski could come up with a game in which you have to shoot your way through a factory for My Little Ponys from hell. Genuinely spooky as well and can be beaten in one session

Even though the limitations are visible that this was made for the 7DFPS game jam with the limited enemy variety, repeating backgrounds, and storytelling relegated to mainly documents, it's the pacing, gameplay, and scares that are still effective. Having to walk around with a flashlight because the environments are nearly pitch dark black-and-white, but if you spot an enemy, you have to switch to your bolt gun to put down these magical hellish ponies and you're basically spraying and praying. The bipedal ponies that hit you with a mage-like attack make it easier to spot them in the dark but you'll have only that millisecond to aim at them. The shooting feels good, and the enemies gib well as expected for a David Szymanski game. It's quite an inspired setting, mixing religious horror with a meat plant and turning humans into ponies so they sin less to the point where sinning is calculated. The saves are for each level, so if you die, you have to repeat the whole level which are usually a few minutes long but because it's so effectively scary (got jump scared a handful of times), I would be relieved after each level. You can shine a light on a pony, and they won't notice you, so you can strategise when to move and shoot in the dark. Once you complete the main objective, you're escaping all the way back those levels, and even on normal difficulty, you will definitely want to use all the health kits and ammo pickups. Colour gets introduced in this latter half to moody effect, and the story has a great final twist about your character. For less than 2 hours long, finally using the Doom 3 gimmick to good effect, and this price point, it's an easy recommend.

Short, sweet, simplistic and to the point! The Pony Factory, by the devs that brought us "Dusk", comes this cool Horror FPS. A full playthrough will take about 25-35 minutes. It reminds me just a bit of the first-half of RE7, and I love that kind of vibe. Recommended!

Regardless, someone could probably turn this into a real, full-fledged game.

I'm frustrated.

David Szymanski was my favorite author -- because each of his games was packed with deep story, neat idea, interesting approach, vivid and original gameplay design -- except DUSK, which was just a dynamic shooter and I enjoyed playing it (don't know anything about Gloomworld, didn't have a chance). I was perplexed during the release of ‚ÄúChop Goblins‚Äù, because it looked like a sale of unused maps from DUSK, absurdly crammed into one game (thanks to time and space travel, that game has a modern city, Rome, Dracula's castle, and even another universe), but I didn't judge it harshly, even when David confessed that he releases games for the sake of making money, not for the sake of the idea.

However, having gone through this one it's impossible to keep silent anymore: this game is made for the sales. It has no idea, no interesting gameplay (excluding black-and-white darkness & flashlight/weapon-modes combo), or exciting gamedesign. You just walk along the same type of corridors and shoot at the same type of nuns. Periodically you pick up health kits and ammo, or try not to step on electricity. 

Don't get me wrong: the game is done very well, and it's quite enjoyable to play. But I was expecting what David had always done: a mind-blowing pearl; this is just basic storyless slightly creepy indie-shooter. To lengthen the process of the game (after all, the game can be completed in 40 minutes without rushing), the whole second half of it is made of the same maps you already gone through, but in reverse (you "get into the factory and get out of the factory"). 

And I probably wouldn't even leave a negative review if the game was two-three times cheaper, but 5$ (Finland) for unreasonable expectations for 40 minutes -- that's too much. :(

I'm frustrated. I know David can do much better. Hopefully, he'll show up brighter in the next games -- just like he did in the "Iron lung", "The music machine", "The moon silver", "A wolf in autumn" and "Fingerbones".

I love Szymanski, but there is pretty much zero story and zero build-up or variety. It would be pretty good if it was free but it's not. It seemed like all the effort went into the level design which was really good. I love the atmosphere except for one music track which is pretty goofy but its only scary for the first 5 seconds. And when text pops up on the screen telling the player how to do stuff instead of the game design showing you in subtle ways take me out of the immersion. I love all of David's other stuff tho, very talented game developer.

[h1]Friendship is magic[/h1]
[b]...but magic is heresy[/b]
Bearing a title hinting at the right kind of dark humour, The Pony Factory has hit the Steam‚Äôs proverbial shelves at the beginning of 2024. Created by David Szymanski, the mind behind Dusk and Iron Lung, follows the trend of more recent, short entries by the developer. The game is a bite-sized piece of survival horror, meant to be finished within a single sitting as it takes under an hour to complete. To give credit where it is due, dimly-lit corridors of the factory carry a spark of ingenious design which made David Szymanski a household name among indie fans. However, The Pony Factory is not what you might expect it to be and for multiple reasons, we will get to these.
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3320219700[/url]
[b]Long-range tactical husbandry needs[/b]
As a toothy grin of an equine skull peering at the player from the main menu may indicate, the titular Ponies are less than wholesome creatures. Similarly welcoming is the industrial interior of the factory, both desolate and shrouded in monochromatic darkness. Despite a sardonic spin on the horror genre, the game efficiently establishes oppressive atmosphere, once tormented wailing of [i]a pony[/i] begins to echo throughout the narrow corridors.

To stave off the encroaching darkness, the player is provided with an Automatic Bolt Gun, capable of delivering 40 rounds of industrial-grade pony-processing firepower. Neatly showcasing simple yet smart design ‚Äì muzzle flash of the weapon is the primary source of illumination during the early levels of the game.
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3320219957[/url]
Another aspect of the game more than worthy of a separate mention is how The Pony Factory utilizes its ever-present notes. Admittedly, random pieces of paper plastered all around the place, are something of an indie horror staple of narrative exposition. What elevates the notes in this title is the corporate language they are filled with. Full to the brim with absurd euphemisms, they add a distinct humouristic quality to what often is utterly underwhelming part of the game.

[b]The other side of the coin[/b]
Truth be told, while there is a couple of fun details I‚Äôve left uncovered, delving any further into a 40-odd minute title would approach writing its novelization. Instead, let‚Äôs address the elephant in the room, as I would imagine even David Szymanski fans (who I believe to be the only target audience of this obscure game) may end up disappointed upon approaching The Pony Factory blindly.

To begin with, this isn‚Äôt the first time this game was made available for distribution. Original version was created as a part of the first Dread X Collection. More importantly, Dread X entries are created in a game jam format. In this particular case, the game was supposed to be completed within a week. While impressive [i]given the circumstances[/i], understandably concessions in terms of quality and complexity had to be made.

[b]Toss a coin to your dev[/b]
All things considered, The Pony Factory is a mixed bag in my book. To be fair, it does deliver a fun and intense experience, however only once the circumstances of the game‚Äôs conception are known, does it become any impressive. Should you happen to come across this game blindly, it is likely to end bafflingly quick. Furthermore, while the price tag is symbolic, Chop Goblins ‚Äì the actual newest game by David Szymanski at the time of writing, offers a lot more content and polish. Ultimately, purchase of The Pony Factory boils down to whether you would like to toss a coin in direction of your favourite indie dev or not. I will leave the matter at your discretion, but should you lean towards ‚Äúno‚Äù you are probably better off giving The Dread X Collection a go instead.
It's great! A definitive and worthy improvement over the previous Dread X Collection version. The gameplay is intense and dramatic thanks to the hard-hitting enemies and the flashlight mechanic.

Great game. I love the use of darkness, plus the shoot/flashlight switching mechanic. It's a very creative story and monster(s). My only complaint is the extremely high look sensitivity but I'm glad you can change it in settings. Another great entry by one of my favorite indie developers.

One of my favorites of Szymanski's short games. I consider myself fairly desensitized to horror these days, but this one really gets under my skin. It makes you feel like an urban explorer, walking down the decrepit factory halls full of rusty machines and sharp turns. It features a b&w aesthetic with some great use of baked lighting, has a basic combat system with some light resource management, and lots of terrifying encounters. There's a beauty in it's simplicity.

Really cool game with a neat premise. It's obviously limited in length and scope, but a great experience nonetheless. Despite some corniness and really silly references in the notes (like Fred Flintstone being a character), the atmosphere and pacing is spot on. It is legitimately tense walking around not knowing when monsters will appear, and it's startling when they do most of the time. It takes the original concept of Doom 3's flashlight, where you have to balance shooting and being able to see, and it makes a lot of encounters really interesting, despite only fighting the same two enemies over and over.

 To me the length is perfect, and there are extra modes to shake up the gameplay if you feel like going through it again. The only real criticism I have is the final boss is incredibly simple and not very interesting design-wise, but that hardly detracts from the overall experience. All in all a great short experience.

I completed this in under an hour, and I thought it was pretty fun! It starts off fairly tense in dark areas, but actually turns into a very fun dungeon crawler as the uncolorful hell light opens up these arenas to shoot hellspawn in. 

0/10 made me a brony.

If you like David Szymanski's other games, you will probably like this too. Even though it was quite short (38 minutes), I still think it is worth the money, because it is a fun little horror game that managed to scare me quite a couple times and had a pretty good atmosphere. Another thing this game did great is limit your weapon and flashlight usage, you can only have one out at a time. Music is pretty good too as expected.

My only real complaint is that the sensitivity slider is not very good if you play on lower sensitivies, not that it is a big deal considering the length of the game.

Looking at this from a design perspective is fun. Designing levels that are playable from both ends, experimenting with lighting in interesting ways and taking elements from older Dooms (mostly the third one), implementing them into this killer atmosphere and adding a freaky story to the equation must've been fun creatively. But the end product doesn't offer the same element of fun from that process. For example, after finishing the game I really didn't want to check out the remaning difficulties and modes because I simply guessed that it wouldn't be too fun. However, like I mentioned, this has a killer atmosphere and delightful enemy designs (as expected from the person who also made Squirrel Stapler). I genuinely felt scared at certain segments and not many games can do that, for that and because of the reasonable price point I give this a recommendation. Just don't expect much.
Love this game. The 50's aesthetic is great, gives a unique feeling. It has a few extra difficulty modes which gives more replayability.
A highly polished and interesting horror shooter. As expected by legendary indie developer David Szymanski. Short but sweet.

This is " Umm actually you not being able to hold a flashlight and a gun at the same time in Doom 3 was a good mechanic and enhanced the horror"- the game. So much so that the all of the core mechanics of the game are centered around this idea. You switch between your flashlight and the only gun you have in this game with your right click, so you can try to shoot down skeleton pony that is running toward in complete darkness as fast as possible. 
It's incredible how much this one simple mechanic has enhanced the horror. You can use flashlight to light up the area and see the enemies, but you can't shoot them. If you switch to your gun, you can only see the enemies through either A) the ambient light of the level B) the light of the enemies's projectiles as it being hurled at you or C) the flash muzzle of your gun as you frantically shoot at them. It gets to the point that you would see a well lit area and you start to get scared because you know this going to be the place where flashlight is of no use. 
Speaking of gun, you basically have this wacky SMG/Nail gun as your only weapon in this game. That's right, there is no shotgun, no pistol, no BFG, only this weird as SMG that has a lot of recoil. This gun also increases the horror element due to its inaccuracy. So if the enemy is sniping you from far or is behind a cover, your gun might not be able to get it. You have to let the enemy get close to you, so all your bullets can hit him, but in that case, your chances of getting hit increases. 
The game is dead simple. The levels are you going from one door to another door while navigating a bunch of hallways, corridors, and big rooms. All the while, these enemies that are basically the Wendigos from David Szymanski's other joint, Dusk, and their hybrid with Dusk's other enemies, mages, will try to kill you. The level design is straightforward and linear so much so it kinda reminded me of Half Life. One of my friends always hated FPS games for how linear they are, and this game reminded me of that friend. However, this game uses its linearity to its advantage (and later on when you have to backtrack those levels). Because the goal of the game is to create a simple mood piece and atmosphere, not to create the next big thing. You go from one room to another hallway, killing zombie ponies, and hoping to god that you have enough ammo and health left behind in the previous rooms to survive this level.
Speaking of god, I kinda didn't care for the story of this game. I don't want to spoil anything. However, you going to have lot of fun if you consider this game as a criticism on the brony fandom (I'm not saying this as a joke, there is some truly sick and twisted individuals in that fandom). Otherwise, this is yet another "Religion is Bad" video game. I am an atheist and even I am getting tired of these types of stories. I personally love Dusk and its story, which is another this type of story trope that I mentioned. However, Dusk was very minimalist in its approach. Meanwhile, in this game there is a lot wacky of letters left behind explaining why has everything gone to hell (pun intended) that were just so annoying. All in all, this aspect of the game was not my cup of tea, but it didn't diminish the over all quality. 
In conclusion, this is another great joint from the uncanny valley man himself. This is the "Sin City"-fication of Chop Goblins.

I like this game. It has a very cheesy horror feel going for it as well as its scary yet goofy as hell soundtrack. My only complaint would be the boss at the very end because its a bullet sponge plus there's barely an indication for when its gonna shoot a projectile. But good game none the less

I had almost forgotten this little gem! I played the original release of Pony Factory as part of the very first DreadX Collection, and I remember I was truly impressed by the sheer amount of pure HORROR that exuded from this short Doom3-inspired first person shooter. So I decided to try out this new standalone release, and I was not disappointed. Brand new lore (that creates a surprisingly deep story), a brand new gameplay mechanic, and even a brand new section are here for you to enjoy! If you have already played this game, I tell you this new version is definitely worth your time and money. If you haven't played it yet, I recommend you do it now, you'll discover a surprisingly scary and atmospheric experience that will keep you on your toes until the very last moments. And possibly will give you nightmares for a few nights ahead. Like all David's games, after all!
Cheers guys!

A nice little homage to Doom 3 and it's flashlight mechanic that a lot of people didn't like back then. As said on the storepage, it's short but there's bonus modes if you're looking for some replay value, an extra challenge or two, or just simply want to get the most of what the improvements offer.

Love the real passion driven development, fueled from inspirations of the past that I have also experienced. Have never had a bad time playing any of these devs games.

What David Szymanski does in regards to games is the exact same thing I want to do. Seriously admirable. Would recommend every single game he's put out.
It's a sort scary game which is pretty fun 8/10 I don't like the scary ponies and I think I'm going to be sick :(

Completed this game this morning. I have some good notes and some bad notes. I will start with the bad:

 I do have some issues with it though. I know the darkness is part of the gameplay, and switching between the flashlight and gun is part of the challenge, but even with the flashlight it's genuinely hard to see enemies sometimes. The runner ponies are simple enough to kill, as they just run straight for you, but the mage ponies that shoot projectiles at you are can cause unneeded headaches. The projectiles feel a bit too fast for me to adequately dodge on occasion, and their thin profile and frantic running speed make it genuinely hard to hit them sometimes, especially at a distance. If they're in a bigger room, or at a lower elevation, you sometimes have to deliberately expose yourself from cover to get close enough to hit the buggers, putting yourself in their line of fire in the process. I've experienced multiple instances of running out of ammo in a room due to missing too many shots on the mage ponies as they flitted around at high speed, blending into the background textures. If they're already close to you, sometimes they even walk past/behind you, so you have to turn around and back away from them to get a clear shot, only to see that they're already charging a projectile in the 1.5 seconds you took to do so. Similar problems apply to the boss unfortunately. The boss room is genuinely too dark to see it in certain places, so you either have to get him into one of the colored light sources, or lead him into the dark with nothing but your flashlight to tell you where he is, and at that point he's close enough to pelt you a few times while you shoot him. I genuinely feel like better lighting would alleviate it at bit, allowing you to actually see the targets you're shooting at before they can hit you back. A faster movement speed or at least a limited sprint option would also help imo. Though maybe that's just my noob ass accustomed to the faster and more open combat of boomer shooters like Dusk and Amid Evil that's talking. Another issue I found involved the in-game collision. Occasionally I'd get backed into a corner by a runner pony, or turn a corner too tightly on some stairs, and get stuck in the level geometry. Once that happens there's basically nothing you can do but reload a checkpoint, because there's no action you can do to shimmy your way back out.

That being said, even after all those complaints, I still don't hate this game. I understand that all of the jank and glitches I experienced is due to this being a 10-20 minute long micro-game made by two people for a game-jam. I can't really hold too much against it for that. It still has a lot of sincere charm to it. It's relatively short and straightforward, never overstaying its welcome. It's atmosphere is well done, balancing bleak and gritty horror with cartoonish absurdity. The sense of absurd dark humor in the lore notes, and even in the overarching premise is pretty great, exactly what I would expect from the guy that made Iron Lung, Chop Goblins, Squirrel Stapler, and Dusk. I definitely recommend this game, as long as you have more shooter/horror game skills than my dumb ass, and can get past the janky bits better than I could, and also enjoy these kinds of schlock horror b-movie vibes in your games. I also wish David best of luck on the development of Butcher's Creek. I hope it turns out well. Peace.
I had tons of fun playing this game with my friends, recommend it 100%.

I bought this game on release date for a reason:

I've always enjoyed formidable obstacle courses that take brain power and extreme hand eye coordination to pass (Mainly for bragging rights)

I was astounded when I found out the precision needed to make every jump, the accuracy is bonkers and it really makes you squint your eyes. Sort of like turning the radio down to find a parking spot. You will be punished if you make a bad decision, which to me adds to the suspense of beating it. I get lost in the appealing art style and shadowy effect the game offers. The chill music is also very catchy.

You cant beat the price for what this game offers. Highly recommend. 9.99/10

I recently had the opportunity to try out "At Light Speed," and my experience left me with mixed feelings. This ambitious project has some noteworthy aspects, but it also has some areas where it falls short.


The graphics and visuals in "At Light Speed" are impressive, to say the least. The attention to detail in the starships, planets, and celestial objects is commendable. The vastness of space is beautifully rendered, immersing players in a visually captivating universe that's a treat for the eyes.

The game's music is exceptional. It is perfect for the setting of the game and makes you feel calm in a somewhat frustrating game. 

However, "At Light Speed" does have some issues. The controls can be somewhat complex, which may pose a steep learning curve for some players. However, the game is designed to be difficult so it isn't really a problem. What is a problem though is that you cannot change keybinds. This can make playing the game tiresome as your fingers are uncomfortable after a certain time of playing the game. 

The performance in this game is very smooth. I didn't drop any/many frames when i was playing, which led to me having a smooth experience playing this game. 


In conclusion, "At Light Speed" is a game with potential and grand aspirations. Its stunning visuals and great music make it a game worth playing, but the controls could be better for a game like this where your moves need to be so precise and hopefully they add customisable controls in the future.

What a blast!

This is a frustrating precision puzzle platformer similar in concept to the likes of Only Up, ALTF4 and many others. What I really like about this game compared to those is the skill element. The controls are crisp and precise allowing for a satisfying feel in the air and on ground. It swaps the randomness and frustration of some other platformers and allows you to focus on getting better and streamlining your runs. I love getting better at the wall running mechanic to shave that extra second off my run and it feels great when you pull it off perfectly.

It is deceptively addictive. I find myself constantly saying "one more run" and finding justification for why my previous run "didn't count". 10/10 recommend.

[b][i]Sci-Fi Platformer with gameplay reminiscent of the game "Only Up". You need to help the astronaut return to the ship.[/i][/b]
Gameplay:
https://youtu.be/dD1mFjRRwVs

A complex game with simple rules. You must reach the top of the map to win the game. 
You need to run, climb, jump over various objects and dodge traps to get higher and higher to the very top.

If you fall, you will be reborn at the nearest checkpoint, but if you leave the game and return, you will have to start the run from the beginning.

+ Nice graphics.
+ Pleasant, relaxing music.
+ Complex, dynamic gameplay.
+ There are checkpoints.
+ As you progress, you can find hidden objects and other astronauts.
+ Achievements.

This game takes you on an emotional roller coaster ride in the best possible way!  The genre is not one I am normally drawn to, but this game surprised me with its depth.  The ambiance and feel of the game are very calming and can be a welcome reprieve when testing your mental fortitude as your character jumps over moving space rocks!  A well-made game by a great publisher - I'm looking forward to more! 10/10.
An insanely satisfying 3D platformer that may also make you want to end your life. Definitely recommend

Its like Only Up in space and if the developers actually put thought into the level design lmao.
Good game, hard game, get ready to have to get better to progress.
A great platforming game that challenges you with fun and fluid movement! You very quickly get hooked on progression and trying to reach the end!

A frustratin' yet addictin' platformer. I fell soo much that I got better at the first section of jumps ha. Not bad for under 5 bucks. 

Sample gameplay: https://youtu.be/OL8X73hqYd4
Extremely challenging but crazy addictive/fun. Be prepared to fall A LOT!
Challenging level design, and super fun!

FUN AND CHALLENGING

For me SokPop adventure games have been the highlight of their catalog, even though they are not as popular, I feel like there is more warmth and thought put into how they are made. This game is a bit similar to Pocket Watch and Sokfest, with a small world to explore that has various puzzles and creative mechanics, such as using multiple characters for their special abilities like swimming or jumping. It's a bit strange, I find that these games don't do as well as their sim games, but the reason I prefer these is because they are just so chill and wholesome, full of creativity, and I think this is one of the better games they made, with very little frustration compared to Pocket Watch.

The hand-drawn style was a nice touch, I think a lot of SokPoP games have a tendency to look very similar, but this game felt very different in terms of aesthetic. The game was extremely playful with the interactions, something that SokPoP has been doing very well recently but I don't want to take it for granted, I think making a wholesome game where you enjoy interacting with characters is not easy. You can complete the game in under 2 hours, but be careful because if you complete it, you won't be able to return to collect all of the coins.

For the most part it plays just like any adventure game, although I wish I had the option to just click instead of holding the mouse. Most of the puzzles were easy, the only frustration was finding some items in the grass, so you kinda have to check everything just in case. I thought the character mechanics added a nice flavor to the puzzles, you can use other characters to swim or jump. Very lighthearted story so there is not a ton to talk about, but I thought it ended in a satisfying way, without overlapping previous ideas.

I like that you brought the day/night mechanics similar to Pocket Watch, sometimes you have to use the cycle change to enter stores when the characters are sleeping, so the puzzles can make you think outside the box.

[h1] Pros: [/h1]

(+) Very playful in terms of character interactions and limited narrative, I thought it was occasionally funny and just overall charming.

(+) I like that puzzles were not very hard, it's a very chill playthrough for the most part, with a few creative ideas like using other characters for their special abilities, as well as the day/night cycle.

(+) The change in the aesthetic was really nice, visually the game was very enjoyable to navigate. Music as well, I like the nice OST change when you swim. For a lighthearted game I thought it was very immersive. 

[h1] Feedback: [/h1]

[u] Just some thoughts: [/u]

- It would be nice if you could add a checkpoint right before the ending so you could return to it
- Add a screenshot feature, which helps to share your game
- The last song puzzle was a bit confusing with the matching 

[b] Overall Thoughts: 8/10 [/b]

From start to finish I thought this short game was extremely charming, and unlike Pocket Watch or Sokfest, it had less frustration with the puzzles, very chill experience overall. The puzzles were fun, the world was fun, and overall it was very creative. The art style and the music choices complement the story very well, and with that said, it was just really good for a tiny game, love to see it.

[code]Niche, obscure and underrated games: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31294838-Hidden-Gem-Discovery/ [/code]
Great hand drawn art style. Short and sweet, took me about an hour and half to finish the whole game. 100% recommend if you're looking for a lovely game that can be finished in one sitting.

Bad things:
1. The final puzzle is unfair. It took me about 50 tries, then i watched community center and saw that it was actually purposely unfair and almost all players had this problem.
2. There is a place where you can just stuck riding a duck under the bottle, and you will be unable to reset, cause you can't pause while you riding a duck. I got to use cte+alt+del. Luckily after resetting you start from a different place on screen.
Good things:
1. Art. Nothing to say, art is very lovely and creates all atmosphere.
2. Metroidvania elements. You finding new abilities to get in new places.
3. You can't stuck using some object in a wrong place, there will be enough worms or seeds or money.
4. Crown achievement. It is like best ending aside of normal ending, and it is not that hard.
5. It is short and easy enough to beat just exploring the area and trying different things (except final puzzle)

So, there is much more good things about this game than bad ones, i reccomend it.

Sokpop does it again, for a genre I am not a fan of they take out all the pain points I usually have and let me enjoy a point and click adventure! Short and simple, careful to respect your time by putting in enough hints and trying to make sure the player can find their way towards the next objective such as putting a road block on a zone once you're finished even with text that says "you're done here so I'm just helping out by blocking it off" very nice to enjoy a game like this =)
Beautiful and cozy game. Perfect game after a hard day's work. The music is beautiful, the characters are simple but lovingly designed and the story is entertaining. I liked it very much.

How to make perfect exposition in less than 10 seconds: magical fairy gives ordinary frog ability to think (the worst possible curse as we know). Et voil√†, you're golden! That's it! Cute little hand drawn adventure can begin. World opens up, other creatures and puzzles emerge. Nice few hours on the road back to sweet oblivion pass fast, but the smile remains.

a pretty short but cute point & click adventure, another great Sokpop game!

that speedrunning achievement was a bit stressful however lmao. would still recommend though

This is a pretty fun game, I loved every part of it, there was so much back and forth and I was happy that the snail block the area for me :) overall, it is cute and fun, my only problem was to play the notes based on the listening. I am have some problems differentiating the notes and failed miserably and I had to ask someone to solve it for me. Maybe add an option for that part as I was stuck for 30 mins trying to play the notes. The other thing moving between lily pads sometimes annoys me as I need to move my mouse back to press on the arrow itself and doesn't use the direction to jump. It would be amazing if that is possible too as it will reduce a lot of headache of moving the mouse back and forth. Overall really fun game and easy to play.

I really loved this game! I think we can all relate to the story ‚Äì isn't everyone tired of having a brain and thoughts sometimes?
The art style is absolutely adorable, the story was interesting and the puzzles were actually way more challenging than I expected. I originally just downloaded the game because I thought it looked cute but ended up having a really nice evening thinking about all the possible solutions together with my partner. Highly recommend the game, especially for the price :)

I received this as a gift. I grew up playing a decent number of point-and-click adventure games and always had a soft spot for them. And during the pandemic, we got into Stardew Valley, as did many others. This was our gateway into the modern 'cozy game.' Frog's Adventure is a nice little diversion that scratches both itches, while not requiring much from you. It's a good game to play after a stressful or tiring day. It's not super complicated, but has you tracking what's going on enough that you're not really thinking about anything else, and yet not thinking too hard about the game itself either. It's a nice sweet spot to be in to wind down your day or just have a cute lazy afternoon. I will probably play this again at some point to see if I can get the last couple achievements, but my first playthrough, without looking things up, took me just under 2 hours. I'd recommend this to people of any age as long as they can read, from kids up to adults who just want to relax. $5 is a good price for 2 hours of cute, wholesome, artsy entertainment. Become Frog, have a little adventure, help out some other animals, and solve the overall plot for an ending that takes you right back to where you should be.
Beautiful and sweet adventure. The art and sound are super lovely. I enjoyed it a lot, even tho the puzzles are simple they are rewarding and meaningful.
Very cute and cozy game, I enjoyed it a lot. As long as you use a mouse or trackpad you can play it on the steam deck without problems. :)
Super cutesty, great story, and super fun gameplay dynamics
There was a lot more to it than I expected! Loved the dialogue, sound effects, and cute art style <3

This game is pure bliss and so relaxing.

As you can see from the screenshots "Frog's Adventure" is a game with no age restrictions. You coulkd give this to your youngest ones, as long as they can read, and provide them with a good time.

The controls are very simplistic with mouse + left-click only, the given story has no stress or urgency to it, and there is lots to discover. Gradually new gameplay aspects are introduced to keep the short lifespan of the game fresh.

I absolutely loved the music, especially when [spoiler] riding the duck on the ponds[/spoiler].

Frog's Adventure is a great relaxing game especially for young kids. This could be their first adventure. After that, please introduce them to Monkey Island and Day of the Tentacle to keep a similar style of fun going!

I could probably just write "hey, look at his lovely game heehee 10/10", because the cute art style is what drew me in in the first place while I went looking for games that have frogs in them. But then it turned out, it was also a delight to play. A great mix of having to use a bit of brain power along with a sense of exploration, and a good balance between gameplay, puzzles, progression and well-spirited silliness. I really enjoyed it, so hey just look at this lovely game, heehee 10/10.
Amazing, cute and relaxing game. The only problem i found was the lost connection between Steam and the game (I read it was because I am running it on a Mac). I totally recommend it.

A simple point-and-click with pretty hand-drawn-like art. Very pleasing to look at, and fairly relaxing to play. There are a few puzzles here and there that are a little bit more challenging, but for the most part it's quite simple.

Usually not a big fan of the genre because of how convoluted the puzzles are, but this one did it for me.

A cozy and charming little adventure. I love the level of puzzles and exploration in this; enough to keep me challenged, but never stressful. Also the sound effects are super cute. 

If you want a spark of joy to keep you company on a grey wintry day, help this lil frog out.

So cute and charming! It has a couple of visual bugs, but nothing that takes away from the story or gameplay. The puzzles are a perfect amount of challenging, they make you think, but not too hard that you get frustrated and want to quit. The story is adorable and the visuals are incredibly unique. Would definitely recommend to anyone looking to spend just a couple hours with a cute, cozy game!

Fun little game with some difficulty solving the puzzles but only because I'm not smart enough for them. 
The character voices are super fun to listen to and the art is also fun to look at. Would recommend if you want to spend 1 ~ 1.5 hours on a cute little game

I ADORE THIS GAME. It's very quick but there's so much love in it. There was a spot where I almost got stuck, but since it's a point-and-click style puzzle, that's a good thing. It's a delightful little piece of art with a surprise twist! I want more. If you like simple games that are more a piece of art than a game that's got hours and hours of content, this is a good one. 

There was a tiny bug where some text was in the wrong place but it didn't take away from the experience at all.

Frog has brain.
This game is such cozy fun and the art style feels nostalgic from doodling as a kid. Very cool idea for a puzzle like game.

Very sweet! Lovely little riddles, cool art, nice story! All around good times! 
I think my total play time was 2-3 hours from start to finish. Buy this if you want a cup of sweet, calming tea for your mind.

This game is honestly just a delight, the story is simple but the hidden object puzzles add a bit of challenge. Get it on sale because it is short, but I do think the challenges the achievements set up add replay value :^)

I got this game in a bundle with some other neat little games.

This game is short and cute. I love that I can play it with just my mouse.

The story is silly and cute, the characters are silly and cute, the game play is silly and cute.

I completed it in about 2 hours, but may come back for a second playthrough.

The characters are charming and all have their little personalities !
The hand drawn graphics are lovely and tickles your curiosity !
The game is relaxing, with small fun puzzles and interactions with the environment.
The music is really nice and have an animal crossing feel ! 
Also the nature ambiant sounds are absolutely cool for immersion !

Definitely a small gem !

I loooved this game!! the puzzles were really fun, the graphics are sooo good and the sounds are so satisfying. the world was so immersive and charming and I will never get over the hand-drawn style! the only downside was my hand got sore from click to move lolll but other than that this was such a delightful experience.

agree with the message too, brains bad üëç
Nice game, makes you use a brain, cute story, innocent looking crimes.

My girlfriend got me this game as a gift today and I knew instantly that this was gonna be a total home run! It was short, sweet, and it's puzzles were not too terribly complicated. It's writing is fantastic and will give you some laughs! The art style of this game nothing short of adorable and really lures out some nostalgia from your inner-kid. If you are reading this, no matter who you are or however old you may be, please consider giving this one a shot cause there really aren't many games that get it so right quite like this one.

Love cute little games like this, very wholesome. I enjoyed it overall, but I don't recommend playing on steam deck. It worked but the controls used the trackpad which felt very uncomfortable.

I liked one playyhroigh, but it's not a game I'm going to pick up to complete the other pesky achievements.

This is a delightful little game with some replayability, focusing on a frog who has been made sentient. You have to remove that sentience. It's very fun and pleasant, with lovely graphics. The controls take a bit of getting used to (just pointing and clicking) but once adjusted to it it's absolutely fine. Overall, well worth the price.
Chill puzzle game for frogstars and toadspeers, makes a great gift. Check out my hopthrough if you get stuck <:]
Beat this in about 1.5 hours. A very charming little game. Art style is wonderful. The only thing I could possibly complain about is accessibility concerns with a sound puzzle.
this game is unnecessarily confusing and difficult, but its extremely fun at the same time. rip my brain tho

very cute game! everything from the animation to the music to sound design were perfectly cozy and charming. i wish the achievements would work... finished the game with none somehow. even so, this is perfect for a rainy night in, definitely recommend
Such a charming little hand-drawn game! short, sweet fantastic music and characters that are way too cute!
cute graphics, cute puzzles, i really enjoyed playing this game!!

A short but sweet game about the horros of having thoughts.

The levels aren't big, but packed with little things to find and places to reach once you find out how - a bit metroidvenia like.
This is a very relaxing and charming point and click adventure game, with a very cute art style and simple but rewarding puzzles, enjoyable for all ages, best part about it is being a frog :)

It has its issues--playing in full screen mode made the frog's walk speed almost unbearably slow (this might just be my PC, though), sometimes the text floats out of their designated boxes, and there are a few bugs (my friend who also played the game somehow managed to swim on the ground, and couldn't progress until he restarted). Getting stuck on a puzzle may make you feel really dumb, because Frog's Adventure's whimsical coloring-book art style may make you underestimate it (this might also just be a Me problem). The frog can only be controlled with the mouse/trackpad, which can make your fingers sore if you play for too long; being able to move with the directional or WASD keys would've been nice. 

But it has its charms. The aforementioned art style is wonderful, a treat for the eyes. The story, while nothing breathtaking, is fun to read. The game isn't very long, either; even if you take your time, it's unlikely for one run to go beyond 2 hours, so whatever frustrations come from getting stuck with a puzzle probably won't last long. (There's an achievement for doing a run in under 20 minutes.) 

Though I have my gripes, it's hard to hate. If you're looking for a short and sweet all-ages game, you can't go wrong with Frog's Adventure. 


*As of writing, the only negative review this game has is about getting stuck on a puzzle because they "did it in the wrong order", which isn't actually possible. The solution to the puzzle is always just somewhere. There's always a way to keep going. ...But it's not impossible to feel stuck, since sometimes the items needed to progress are hard to spot.
Short, funny and charming point & click adventure game. Recommended for all Frog lovers.
A very charming, peaceful and surprisingly meaningful experience - and I'm not just saying that because I love frogs!
A pleasant little adventure with fun puzzles. Similar vibes to A Short Hike, but point and click.
Fun casual point and click adventure. Great if you like small woodland animals.
Wonderful little 2 hour experience. Some of the best execution on "hand drawn"  aesthetics I've seen, especially at this small scale. Really enjoyed it.

I got this game cause it looked cute but unfortunately, there are some MAJOR BUGS to this game which makes me don't want to continue.
For example the worms in chapter 2, it requires you to get 1 worm for the fish to get the key which is important to progress in the story, but it also asks you to give 3 worms to the duck to enter its house. The problem is there were ONLY 3 worms that you can find in the map. If you didn't give that 1 worm to the frog, instead you gave it to the duck (because how am i supposed to know whom to give first???) then you wouldn't be able to proceed the story. 
Also in chapter 5 where it requires you to get lily pad seeds in different spots and there aren't sufficient seeds you can get in the map(some seeds you have to FIRST get the seed to get to it)

However, you could start over and follow the steps in its correct order but it totally destroys the experience. NOT ENJOYABLE! I wish this game was designed better, if it wasn't for the flaws I would totally recommend it.
This is a wonderful little puzzle game with cute characters and a charming art style. Short, fun and definitely worth the money. Don't underestimate the speedrun achievement!

Well, took me 4 hours but I completely finished the game, I normally don't say this but read the tips and trick section of this review, it will save you hours of grinding, it will be after the review itself and I might put it in a guide since there are only 2 guide for the game currently.

The game was fun, especially when I found a trick that saved me time otherwise I was thinking of stopping after finishing most of the quests and not completing everything.

Gameplay: There are 2 main things to do in the game, do quests which are mostly fetch quests and material gathering which is hell, it takes like 4 hits to break a stone/tree and only get 1-2 materials from them, and it is so slow too, it is awful, I can't imagine how long it will take to finish everything doing it normally. As for the quests, they are okay, just a lot of running around, when you get the wand (Item that let's you ride animals) always be on an animal, it will save so much time.

Story: There isn't too much, but there is some story, mostly about the character, but even that isn't too much, still, I had fun reading the dialog, although there were a few times were the dialog wasn't translated.

Sex: I have mixed feeling about it, it wasn't bad but also wasn't amazing, it was sometimes okay and sometime good, I'm talking about art to animation, the art looked good at time and at other had me go "Okay" since I could see a few mistakes, though not big ones, the animation, you could see missing limbs or how some of the body dislocates from the rest for the movement, overall I wouldn't say it is bad, but it isn't amazing. On the plus side, there are a lot of animations, each character has 2 (With one character having 3 and another having a few and letting you control it which is different from the rest) and 2 pixel animations (I think that's what it's called or maybe 2dlive animation, anyway, it is the character having sex in the background instead of big art and animation) it is mostly the same with a bit of a different look but at least 1 was different from the big animation.

Sound: Now this is where I had to scratch my head while letting out a chuckle, I recognized some of the moans in the game from 2 other games I played, now, I checked and this is a different dev from the one that made the other 2 games, so when there was a reappearance of the moans in the second game I played from the other dev, I was "Okay, same dev" but now I'm wondering if there is some Chinese moaning site or something where you can buy moaning sounds (I assume there is) anyway, it was funny to me, sorry for going off track. other than that, it was okay, the moaning wasn't anything special, it is just moaning and the music is nice.

Overall, for the price I would recommend the game, it is a fun game and has a lot of animations with a good art (Okay sometimes), if you want a game where you can kind of mindlessly do quests and get sex as a reward, I would recommend this game, now to tips and tricks. Those that leave now have a great day.

Now, I will start with something I found near the end of the game and could have saved me so much trouble, I will tell a bit of a story, I was planning on putting in the review a warning about selling gold, because gold is important, you need so much and it costs a lot, but after finding this trick it doesn't matter, the trick needs the magic wand, which I don't know how to get since it just appeared in my inventory out of nowhere.

The magic wand allows you to ride an animal and if you click the wand it stores the animal in your inventory, now, money is a pain to get in this game and so is all other materials, that is until you get this wand, it is beyond broken, a stored animal sells for 200 (pigs) and 250 (cows) and now is the broken part, if you go beyond the bridge at the starting island, it is cow heaven, everytime you go into that zone like 10 cows spawn, so if you go in, catch all and out, and repeat, you can in 2 minutes get a few 10k money, and with that you can buy everything you need, it is an absolute game changer that saves hours of grind materials slowly.

As for how to get, like I said, I don't know when I got it, but it might be either from a main island npc or the one on harmony island (The one with the merchant). That's it, check your inventory and if you have the wand you are sorted.

Second tip, when you go into the pyramid, take 30 gold and bandages from the merchant, the pyramid is a maze so it is annoying to go back and forth, this way you have everything with you. As for the maze, I don't remember it completely, but at the start go left once and then up until you reach near the top and try going right, it is like in the middle right of the pyramid where the npc is.

Third, there is a slave in the desert, you can buy her when you max your house.

That's kind of it I think, I had more but they became useless when I found the wand trick, I guess a bit of a quest help, grow 20 carrots (10 seeds), the harmony island carrots don't work for quests, also, remember to go get those carrots and the watermelons in the desert, great energy source.

Oh! I almost forgot, after finishing Susu's quest line, there is a dialog without translation, but after that you get a magic stone, I didn't even know I had it, I only found out when I went to the portal on the left of starter island after that quest, so I'm pretty sure it is from her. The stone is for the portal.

Well, I think that's it, the wand trick should let you have an easy time, just go to where the cows spawn, put the wand on the 1 button or another easy one and then just go around, when you see a cow press 1 (Assuming you are on a mount) which will put the current mount in the inventory and click on the other and repeat until you only have the cow you are riding and go up to the next area and back down to respawn the cows and repeat, you get tens of thousands of money easily like that.

I came back to add, build at least one sprinkler, the range is huge and it will save you a lot of work watering everything which is extremely slow, sprinklers are easy to make too, you buy the blueprint from the carpenter.

Anyway, I hope this helps, if you read to here thank you and I hope you have a great day,

[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
Hooligan Crusoe is a Unity based farming game.

[h1]Story[/h1]
You awaken on an unknown island. The local chief comes to greet you on the beach and offers you a tent. You stay on the island, and your adventures continue as you explore other nearby islands.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game starts off with the language defaulted to Chinese. Language is the third option from the top.  When you start a new game, the first thing you do is to set your character name. There is no default name.

Each woman has three quests for you to complete to unlock their content. Some of the quests are simple, others, not so much. There are six different islands to explore. Each island offers different women to assist. If the women don't live on your island, you can build a house for them and they will move to the island to make it easier for the two of you to get together.

There are at least 19 different women. After you have done their quests and unlock their content they have two scenes that you can switch between.

The English in general is fine, there are some things that are not translated, the first Neko on your island being the one that is the most notable. The developer is still updating the game, the last update was last month.

There are a lot of improvements that could be made: increasing the passage of time (like one second real time equals one minute game time) and improved resource collection items (faster collection times), for example. The time is a big one, you can use all of your stamina in the first half hour of the day and things you plant require days to go by in order to grow. You can easily restore your stamina with food, the problem is that you can do a whole lot before you have to go to sleep.

[h1]The Gallery[/h1]
There is no Gallery. You can visit the women again, after you have unlocked their content and replay it. This can be made easier by building them a house on your island.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
The game isn't great, but it is an amazing value for the price. There are a ton of quality of life improvements that could be made, but you can't beat the value.

[h1]System Specs[/h1]
CPU: AMD Ryzen‚Ñ¢ 9 7950X3D
Motherboard: Gigabyte X670E AORUS EXTREME (rev. 1x)
RAM: G.SKILL Trident Z5 Neo Series (AMD Expo) DDR5 RAM 64GB (2x32GB)
Video: ASUS TUF Gaming GeForce RTX 4080

[h1] A hidden gem held back by it's length [/h1] 

I should start off by saying that i was very pleasantly surprised with Last Resort, so much so that it has earned a spot among my favorite VN experiences of all time (with emphasis on ‚Äúexperiences‚Äù, I‚Äôll go into more detail about this later on) and exceeded my expectations that were set from other reviews.

[h2]The Good[/h2]

The biggest praise i could give to this game would have to go towards it's excellent writing, that, despite it's short length, managed to convey the exact emotions it aimed for with such accuracy that it made me sob a few times, and even made me take a break to recollect my thoughts, despite not being the kind of person that‚Äôs usually affected by games to such a degree. It‚Äôs a shame too, because I feel that a lot of people might‚Äôve misunderstood the developer‚Äôs intentions and attributed that to the writing being ‚Äúbad‚Äù. It‚Äôs kind of hard to explain stuff like that without making them feel like a ‚Äúto be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand Rick and Morty‚Äù type of situation, but bear with me. At the end of the game, you receive a note by the developer stating, among other things, that ‚Äú[spoiler] Every one of us wants to run away from our problems from time to time [/spoiler]. That‚Äôs [b] the feeling [/b] I‚Äôve tried to put into the ‚ÄúLast Resort‚Äù.‚Äù And, knowing the vast thematic scope that the game went for and it‚Äôs incredibly limited runtime, it couldn‚Äôt really be any different. The point wasn‚Äôt for the player to emotionally connect with the characters themselves per se, but for the characters to act as a reflection of the player‚Äôs own life struggles. The emotional resonation is meant to happen through the incredibly accurate representation of the thoughts and feelings that the protagonist goes through during the events of the game. Or at least that was my personal interpretation that allowed me to enjoy the game as much as I did. Aside from the writing, the artwork is also very pretty, the animations were better than I expected them to be and the soundtrack was nice too.

[h2]The Not-So-Good[/h2]

Considering the game‚Äôs main theme is escapism due to disappointment in our everyday lives, it‚Äôd be nice to see a bit more of the protagonist‚Äôs everyday routine and actively experience his thoughts during it instead of being quickly filled in on his background before going straight to the main plotline. However, that doesn‚Äôt mean it went on for too long. On the contrary, the main issue lies in the game‚Äôs incredibly limited length which didn‚Äôt allow it to deviate from the main plot. In that sense, the execution couldn‚Äôt have been much better, but at it‚Äôs current state it almost feels more like a proof of concept and the developer‚Äôs talent in writing rather that the full-fledged visual novel it could have been. It‚Äôs not an incomplete visual novel by all means, but based on it‚Äôs scope it doesn‚Äôt feel fully realized. However, it still does offer a worthwhile experience at a fair price. Aside from that, there‚Äôs a violin track that plays around the beginning and the end of the game that has a weird 360 effect where you hear the violin constantly rotating around your head if you wear headphones. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs intentional or not, but I found it incredibly distracting. I‚Äôll also agree with other reviews that the bouncing in the eyes‚Äô irises was a bit excessive, and in my opinion so were the bouncing question/exclamation marks and multiple hearts. It would maybe make sense in an H game to signify progression, but in a normal vn they were a bit too much, and a simple face expression or at least fewer popup symbols could‚Äôve done the job. Lastly, while I wouldn‚Äôt outright categorize it as a negative, the voice acting unfortunately ended up breaking my immersion more than anything so I opted to disable it. I personally didn‚Äôt find the deeper voices and the Russian language to fit the characters that, unless I‚Äôm missing out something, weren‚Äôt supposed to be Russian. But again, it‚Äôs not really a negative. The voice acting is more of an added bonus from the developer, and the lack of voice acting is just as serviceable.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]

Hidden Resort is an emotionally engaging, worthwhile experience that unfortunately doesn‚Äôt deliver as much as it could due to it‚Äôs short length. Despite it‚Äôs shortcomings, it delivers what it promises at a fair price.
[b]Final Score:[/b] 8/10

this game feels incomplete but doesn't show much to make you want to see it further. the concept of going back in time to fix our past is nothing new and there's nothing here that makes it fresh. the characterization feels loose, the motive feels loose, everything about the writing is empty. i like the idea of some of the intent the author writes out in the ending but it's not here in the game itself.

Disclaimer: I received a review key for free.

Last Resort is a very short, but solid game. It tells a very succinct story with very ambient music, good Russian voice acting, and Live2D models that really make it pop! Even at full price it's a nice little game that I'd recommend.

PROS:
+Clean and detailed setpiece art
+Well rigged Live2D heroines
+Good voice acting! At this price point that was VERY surprising!

CONS:
-Very short. It tells multiple tales in a very short amount of time.
+/- Has auto advancing dialogue as an option, but it cannot be adjusted.


It's $4 at the time of this writing. Go check it out for a short morally driven story that wastes no time doing exactly what it claims to do.
Game's pretty fine, but too short (1-1.5 hour maybe). Also, the plot is VERY dynamic, so... the ending was unexpected.

Even though this game took me only twenty minutes to finish, I really liked the story a lot, it really resonated with me and is super relatable, amazing art and pleasant music.  The voice acting was good but I turned it off because I'm not a Russian speaker but I could tell it was good voice acting. 

Pros: 
Beautiful 
Fun
No Wasted Words
Satisfying Game and Great Achievements
Cons
Short
No English Voice Acting (for me)

9/10! If it was a little longer with more fleshed out endings, this would be perfect!  But in and of itself, it's a wonderful game!

While short, this story was very sweet and touching. I was hooked from the moment I started reading, and didn't stop until I had all the endings and achievements. Also, the art. WOW is all I can say! I absolutely loved every picture and character art. Several times I stopped to just admire the backgrounds. While I did get this game in a giveaway, I would gladly have paid the small price to experience this sweet story. While it is apparent English wasn't the first language for the game, the translation was very well done, and I didn't notice any real big mistakes when reading thru myself, aside from just some odd wording in a couple places. The only thing that bothered me a bit was the main character just being labeled as "Him", but that is such a small thing it barely needs mentioning. Maybe in a future update a name could be given to him or just change the label to "Me" or something, as I was confused for a minute about who "Him" might be. I highly recommend this visual novel for those looking for a quick read that has a very sweet story!
The cool drawing is animeshnaya and the storyline is interesting. You need to play for a guy who decided to go his own way, overcoming difficulties. I recommend playing.

This game actually released in October 2022; what you're looking at is a second "duplicate" listing that only includes the battle royale mode, Eternal Battle. The original game [i]should[/i] have released for free with optional paid DLCs for the other modes (like how Tetris 99 is free on Switch but you can pay for single-player modes), but since they didn't release it that way, the next best thing would have been to change the original listing to work like that. Instead, they made a completely different listing for the free version.

You may think it doesn't matter that they made a duplicate store listing, but 1) if you switch, you need to redownload the entire game (thankfully it's not that large), and 2) your playtime and achievement progress will [i]not[/i] transfer from the F2P version to the paid version. (Only leaderboards will transfer, since those are stored server-side.) Unlike what the F2P store description implies, you cannot purchase the other modes individually and continue playing this version; if you want the other modes, you need to switch to the original, paid version of the game.

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1717270/Arkanoid__Eternal_Battle/]The original listing goes on sale for $2 pretty often.[/url] What I would recommend doing is trying the F2P version to see if you like how Eternal Battle plays (you will end up playing with AIs because the online is dead) and then picking up the paid version for the full experience.

A great game that definitely needs more players. Very good visuals and music. Gameplay mechanics work very well with the battle royale formula. Absolutely worth playing.

Some suggestions:
- Extend "waiting for other players" time, or make it customizable.
- Add the option to invite and challenge friends.
- Add more rewards (other than custom backgrounds) or achievements to keep players coming back.
- Let human players join an already started game.
- Give names to AI players.

I like the visuals and how much fun playing the game is. However, as many have said, it was released way too late. You won't be able to fill the whole game with real players, but luckily you can still play with bots. As you can guess, it gets boring very fast if you only play with AI.

What I don't like is that, especially at the beginning of the game, other people's screens are flying left and right in the background. It's too distracting and, at least for the old me, I lose track of my own ball(s) all the time. There's also no support for keyboard and you can only move your paddle craft using mouse.

I had hoped it would be much more popular - it's not Tetris, of course, but it's still disappointing to see so few people playing it. But, as much as it pains me to say it, it might be the developer/publisher's fault for deciding to release the free version so late. We can only imagine that it would attract a much larger player base, and those players could end up buying the full game. But that's just me playing a little guess game.

I recommend everyone to give it a try. If you remember the original Arkanoid, you'll be surprised by this one, and the "end phase" of the battle royale matches is something interesting that I never expected to see. For that alone, it's worth downloading and playing through, even with bots.

The release is a bit way too late but better late then never. I get it, if this was released the same time as the full version no one would of got it, so instead you release it when the full version of the game is pretty much dead. The full version price should of just been adjusted then releasing a free version over a year later.

This is a fun game and the battle royale makes it great but unfortunately you will be mostly be playing with bots as the full version didn't attract enough people because of the price. Maybe with the release of the F2P version more people will return to this game. If you love this game I strongly encourage you to get your friends to play along and help populate the servers. Graphics are good and also so is the music. Make Arkanoid Great Again!

As someone who has played through Squirrel Stapler through the Dread X Collection II, I can't say that I was too impressed with the additions that the stand alone release provides. I wouldn't be surprised if it took Szymanski a day to implement all of the changes of the stand alone release. Considering the asking price of the game is only 2 dollars less than the dread x collection 2, which contains an extremely similar version of squirrel stapler along with 11 other games, I would have to recommend the dread x collection instead as its just a way better value for your money

Squirrel Stapler, as the store page puts it, is a game where you hunt squirrels, staple them to a corpse, and meet god. This game is not simple. Appearances in this game are often deceptive. Likewise, I assume that anyone reading this review will have the intellectual engagement to read its contents, rather than expect it to run like an answer key to a multiple-choice quiz.

Since Squirrel Stapler is such an open-ended game, no single understanding of the events of the game can be regarded as "correct" above other understandings. The purpose of the discussion in this review is not to establish a final authority on the events of Squirrel Stapler, but to provide one unified grasp of the game that answers the majority of the questions presented within the game. 

As I have played and studied the game, I have concluded that the plot of Squirrel Stapler exists on four different levels of narrative reality. These four levels of narrative reality are:  the Cosmic level; the Political level; the Individual level; and the Squirrel level. All of these narrative levels progress at the same time, and they interweave through each other. In the interest of keeping my explanation unconvoluted, I will describe the flow of each of the four narrative levels, insofar as they operate independent of each other. 

The Cosmic Level of the narrative is the easiest to describe. However, I should clarify up front that there are three different entities known as "Stapler" in this game. They look alike and speak alike; they are related to each other; however, they are distinct from each other. I will describe each of them, as they relate to their respective levels of narrative. The "Stapler" on the Cosmic Level of narrative is the character who I refer to as "Germanic Stapler," or G. S. I name him "Germanic Stapler" because his manner of living suggests that he belongs to a spiritual tradition related to Western religious heritage, which is dominated by religious traditions that find their roots in Germanic history.

G. S. is described as "the squirrel stapler." His rival is the Squirrel, who is described as storing and preserving "the Nuts of God." G. S. represents Western culture and civilization: Europe and the Americas. The Squirrel represents Eastern culture and civilization: the Asian continental nations and Japan. During the first day of the game, we see that G. S. uses energy drinks (in the Squirrel Stapler group) as transportation. He and the Squirrel have a long history of friendship, though they seem to regard each other with professional (rather than personal) affection. They reflect upon their competitive relationship as experienced via chess games; most of the time, G. S. wins.

David Szymanski (the visionary developer of the game) has been quoted as remarking that G. S. and the Squirrel represent "the futility of war." This seems most keenly expressed in the game's final epilogue, which occurs 5 days after the game begins in the forest. I do not disagree with David Szymanski's comment; I would add, also, that it seems to represent the inevitability of war and the eternal irresolution of differences between East and West, so long as one attempts to aggress upon the other. 

At the end of the first day, G. S. fires a tank-piercing bullet at the Squirrel, who dies and is attached to G. S.'s wife after having been killed by its impact. This moment signifies the beginning of the "chess game" that occurs in the forest, through the course of the game's events. The only time G. S. appears is when he is in the company of the Squirrel. 

Squirrel Stapler is a post-modern story, and (as such) leaves many holes for the gamer to fill with his or her personal explanations. If I wrote this review with the intention of wresting those holes from the reader and filling them with my own explanations, then I would have betrayed the vision of the creative team.

This game delivered me a different emotion. I used to look down on modern art such as the creations of Picasso, but that was until I got this game recommended to me by the devil and then I look at the time and I already realise I've been playing this game for 15 days (don't pay attention to my playtime). Now I sit alone, isolated, forever opaque from my once humanity and all I know is to staple squirrels until my death. 

All around... 8/10 game!
Could use more dolphins though.

Literally a life-changing experience. A friend who beta-tested the game introduced me to it and I've never been the same since now that I've been enlightened by this glorious game. My only hope is that after Markiplier finishes making the Iron Lung movie, he works with David Szymanski again to bring Squirrel Stapler to the big screen, too.

The fact that this is 8 dollars is a crazy. The only thing that it adds are soda cans that make you faster and a mode where the squirrels are huge. There is one extra shed that shows a jpg of a squirrel for two seconds and adds points to the useless score mode, and a one minute long joke game in the goodies folder. Really don't buy this if you have dreadX 2.
