[h1]This is how average honeymoon look like[/h1]

There is so much that you can say about this game, but I'll make it short. [b]It's a social commentary, a statement, an education tool[/b]. It talks about [b]greedy women[/b] that chase the beauty no matter what, even if it's gonna cost a dozen squires their lives. It teaches you to [b]respect the woods[/b], to not disrupt the natural order of things and most importantly, [b]don't camp at supposedly cursed land[/b]. It teaches you the basics of hunting: [b]be sneaky, be patient, use your ears and special tools[/b] to make prey give away it's own position. [u]It's simply a masterpiece.[/u]

Main protagonist is one cold son of a b!tch. Every day he commits destructive acts against nature to gain personal benefits, and you gain points for that. Game even gives you the opportunity to raise your "score" by committing sins at certain shady shack every day. Squirrel genocide is no joke. Follow the path of righteousness, treat everything with respect or face rage of the force beyond your comprehension. 

[b]God is here.[/b]
Toes the line between deliciously eerie and wonderfully stupid. Good sound design, bare but fun gameplay and a finale that will getcha even if you know it's coming. Respect the squirrels.

Squirrel Stapler is not new. It is also playable in Dread X 2, which released on Steam 3 years ago. Dread X 2 contains a whopping 12 games like this one, but for almost the exact same price.

I played Squirrel Stapler in Dread X 2 and enjoyed it, so i was very excited to replay this standalone release after reading about it on the store page and seeing that it has "a more alive forest", "quality of life" and "new goodies". I completed the entire game, and discovered all the content. I very much stand by the opinion that despite what its store page says, this game does Not contain any noteworthy new gameplay-related content that increases its value.

The game is much easier in this release, which i actually see as a downside, because i thought Squirrel Stapler in Dread X 2 had a nice difficulty curve. The new Energy drinks makes the enemies much too easy to not interact with.

The game's forest is not more alive in any noticable way. There is one new building that doesn't change how the game is played, and a new squirrel that behaves the same but gives two points.

I like Squirrel Stapler. It is very stylistic and charming. But i cannot recommend this version whatsoever. It is very overpriced and changes nothing noteworthy! Buy Dread X 2 for the same amount of money and enjoy Squirrel Stapler there.
If you ever wanted to add some dark religious undertones to killing vermin for an hour then this is the game for you.

Suspense game hidden in a "poorly designed" hunting simulator. Nothing to hate about this game except that I wish there was a night mode and more creepy things to kill me. 

In the game, you have 5 days until god comes.
Right now, you have 5 seconds to buy this game if you haven't already.

10/10

And you may find yourself, living in a shotgun shack
And you may find yourself in another part of the world
And you may find yourself behind the stock of a varmint rifle
and you may find yourself in a beautiful house, with a beautiful wife without skin and there are Squirrel's you must staple to meet god...
And you may ask yourself, "Well, how did I get here?"

Amazing as always. No one creates uncomfortable atmosphere like Szymanski.

I want Brad Pitt for the movie.

[h1]Squirrel Stapler[/h1]
[h2]Putting a drunken idea to work[/h2]
David Szymanski is known as Dusk developer first. "My favorite boomer shooter youtuber made a video on his game once", and this is where the story ends. But over the years David accumulated a sizable library of good games. For example - Iron Lung, which not too long ago Reddit review bombed after OceanGate disaster. "Repeating the joke 20 times makes it 20 times better"; The Music Machine is a hidden gem for any autist obsessed with art directions in games, such as myself; and Gloomwood is taking forever to just come out. And today's star: Squirrel Stapler, which originally started as one of the games in Dread X Collection 2.

[h2]Stapling the squirrels[/h2]
This game is dumb, utterly retarded even. It's a cocktail of absurdity and horror. It shouldn't work, but it does. I don't know how else to describe this anomaly of a game.
The forest is an open map with half a dozen points of interest. It could be notes, which tell two separate stories every day, shady shack or just consumables. The best thing to do here is hunting for squirrels. The second best thing is enjoying the atmosphere. Sounds of animal life, the wind howling, and rustling of leaves - I wouldn't normally care about that, but Squirrel Stapler is an exception. It's the matter of contrast. What this game goes for works because there is a contrast between normal and absurd. David Szymanski got away with making a borderline shitpost, and I applaud him for that.
I have nothing else to say. This is one of those games that you should play for yourself. Don't watch anyone play it - jump right into it blind. Play Szymanski's other games too, while you are at it.

Now THAT'S a game for me.  A game that knows its a game, a game that respects my time, a game that has that sprinkling of fun Szymanski detail. 

I want more.  I cannot wait to get my hands on David's next game, the Condemned-inspired Butcher's Creek, but I'd also love some Squirrel Stapler XL in the future.

I committed sins at the shack, drank some energy drinks, hunted double-headed squirrels to staple onto my wife, read some nice poetry, met God once again and learned that the wise man stores his nuts for the proper time.                                    
             10/10 re-release would commit sins and meet God again.

The Good:
I enjoyed the horror-comedy of the game. It was entertaining and fun, It was serious and unserious and did not feel like a gimmick. The pixelated grungy look appealed to me. The squirrels are scary... I actually jumped really good at one moment in the game. My B*tch wife isnt beautiful enough. She need more of God's beauty. 

The Bad:
Cant critique it that bad tbh, short and sweet game. Wish there was a bit more content. Like maybe more gimmicky modes like the large squirrels, maybe a nightmare night when the hunter sleeps going after the ghost squirrels.

The Ugly:
I did not get too witness more of the rodents beauty.

Outrageously overpriced for what it has to offer, just like most of the Szymanski's games, except few.

It's very hard to rate this game because the concept is definitively there. It's dark, twisted and menacing, but at the same time the realization is [b]so[/b] cheap it just makes it a total cringe fest / interactive meme-product and while playing you can't stop thinking what did I just really pay for. Something like this should literally be [b]free[/b], just like his early [i]"Fingerbones"[/i].

Anyways, if you dig this perplexing weird vibe, look into the old VHS tape called [i]"Exploding Varmints"[/i] from the bootleg [i]"Ensuring your place in hell: Volume 1"[/i]. I'm sure some inspirations were taken from there.

Ok listen, I didn't know this game was a horror game when I first got it, and that's my own fault for not heeding the warning of steam telling me that this game was similar to Iron Lung. I about shit myself when I encountered my first squirrel-bear when out hunting, and ran in pointless circles with it until I finally shot it and it EXPLODED. Which scared me even more since I had no idea what the hell I got myself into. Despite not researching it enough and kind of just getting it cause it seemed silly while on sale, I did actually really enjoy this game. It was challenging but not so hard that I just wanted to quit, and I was able to get 100% achievements! Which is always nice. overall 10/10, God comes weirdly fast on day 5.

I still love this game! It was the reason why I bought Dread X Collection II to begin with. If you're new to the game, its one hell of a ride haha. A short but sweet ride. Unique concept with some strange stories to unravel as you trot through the forest looking for those damn squirrels! No spoilers. You've got to play it!

For returning players such as myself, there isn't too much extra to bite into unfortunately. There are some extra items to look out for, a new unlockable Big Squirrel Mode, and achievements to unlock. It was worth it to me as a big fan of this game, but I really wish there was an additional map to explore and engage in squirrel genocide. I also don't mind giving Dave Szymanski my money as he has produced some outstanding games over the years. 

I love it. Unique, fun, and squirrely. Highly recommended for new players, but i will leave it up to the previous Dread X Collection II players to decide if its worth paying for it again

This game really does simulate a hunting fps. One which slowly descents from madness even if it was there to begin with at the start. The shooting is nice, the atmosphere is also nice, same with sound design. My only complaint would be the map and the fact that the player is shown as a yellow dot. My issue is that I don't know what direction I'm facing. Maybe changing it to an arrow that points to what direction I'm facing would help.
EDIT: I forgot to mention at the pause menu, for some odd reason, you can't hit the escape key again after pressing it to unpause the game. Not anything too big just a nitpick.

Finally freed from the shackles of the iconic Dread X series, the standalone version of Squirrel Stapler is just everything but more. On the surface it is just a simple remaster of an already great game, but it adds some welcome finishing touches that enhance the horror and comedic aspects of the game greatly.

So the game itself is a slow-paced hunting sim, although the brevity and clarity of the game helps it avoid the tedium that usually plagues the genre. It's more focused on creating an enjoyable experience than it is on anything akin to realism or challenge, and you just have to love it for that. The horror aspect is surprisingly well done for how often it mixes in overt jokes, although considering the dev's legacy, that's no surprise. There's not much replay value, but it's not designed with that in mind, and honestly it's no issue. It's uncomfortable, weird, but undeniably a great experience. It's Dave Szymanski. It's stapling squirrels to your wife's corpse. It's exactly what you think it is, and a little more. Absolutely recommend.

After 100% completing it i can say that this sure is the squirrel stappler from dread x 2. The game had many nice improvements and additions. The energy drinks i found especially nice for achievement hunting altough i did feel it removed the small bit of challenge the game originally had i feel it would have been better if you unlocked energy drinks after finishing the game once. The sin shack was fun altough i dont get the point of getting more score, is there maybe a secret ending if you get enough score? I dont believe so but ill try it. The double squirrel was a nice addition for when they show up and the other improvements where nice. I do wish there was some third mode though which included a lot more new stuff(primarily squirrel types) but i do understand the dev for not wanting too add more then nessecary although i really wish he did.

This is pretty much almost the exact same as the version from Dread X Collection 2, here it just has more quality of life features in the settings, drinks to go faster, modes to unlock after finding all collectables, all simple yet welcome changes that continue to make Squirrel Stapler the memorable gem it still is.

A short and sweet horror game that tells the story of a deranged nutcase stapling dead squirrels to his deceased wife, the atmosphere in this game is unironically eerie and sometimes you will hear bizarre and strange noises, the hostile NPCs in this game are terrifying and the ending of this game just creates a cliffhanger for a possible sequel, although i highly recommend getting this game through the bundle when its on sale due to how short the game is and how fast it can be completed.

I'm usually not able to handle horror games, but I had a feeling the absurd premise meant this one would be tolerable enough, and I was correct - I had a very fun time with it. I was scared, but mostly by the atmosphere, I was not disturbed enough that it would haunt me later. Definitely a great game to have friends watch, too.

Also met god, that was pretty cool.
If I was having any more fun, I would be put on PETA's "Top 10 Most Wanted" List.

[h1] A Perfect Blend [/h1]

Squirrel Stapler, much like David Szymanski's other shorter games like Iron Lung and Chop Goblins, is an incredible experience that is unique, fascinating, and just plain crazy. It's the type of experience that you can only get from a David Szymanski game. Squirrel Stapler puts you in the shoes of a hunter who goes out to hunt squirrels to staple onto his wife. Yup, that's the plot of this game. As you go about your days though more obstacles are thrown your way which change the way you approach the game. It's very well done and keeps the repetitive tasks fun and engaging. You can also do a little bit of exploring to uncover a pretty insane story. The map was surprisingly bigger than I was expecting and you quickly learn how to use the landmarks to help you navigate and know where you can run to in order to resupply on ammo and health. This is definitely an experience worth playing and I think the price tag is justified despite being very short due to the very high quality and memorable experience you get here. For more reviews, follow my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/40795588/] curator page. [/url]

"Laruaville 5" is a great match-3 game with unique mechanics and minigames (Mahjong, spot the difference and hidden object games). It runs flawlessly and it will stimulate your brain! A very tricky match-3 with power-ups and unique ways to solve the puzzles. Help the cute ghosts survive and build a boat to go back to the mainland after their ship sunk!

The levels themselves are hard but leave an impression and above all they are fun. So you will be glad it wasn't a piece of cake that required no thinking and ended in 10 minutes. The visual effects, animations and music will help a lot in keeping you calm and focused on the task at hand.
If you are stuck, you can use the hint system, which I find very good, comprehensive and helpful. On top of that, they have added a beautifully crafted grimoire as help.

It will keep you busy for hours but without overstaying its welcome and you can always replay it due to its nature. Featuring different modes, minigames and building your town!

One of the most fun and intriguing match-3 puzzle games out there.

For more reviews, follow my curator https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44864435-Mewesome-Reviews/

Not a bad game by any means, though there are a lot of caveats to that.

So first off, League TD is extremely oldschool style tower defence. Like we're talking Starcraft 1 era maps or earlier, not even Warcraft III era. It's good for what it is in that regard, and if you like those old tower defence style games, it's totally fine for what it is.

So what do I mean by that?

Well, all the towers more or less work the same way with very, very few exceptions. Almost all of them are just "shoots at a target" style. Meaning things like poison towers are kind of awful because they'll just shoot a single target over and over, making them pretty bad. There's also the whole status effect immunity thing that a lot of old games had, so of course enemies can be immune to ice (freeze in spot), lightning (slow movement), and poison (damage over time) which further makes these towers not that useful, and after about halfway through the game, every level you go to will have some of each.

There's also of course the flying enemies that are immune to everything but a single tower type and only if you upgrade that tower type with a specific optional upgrade for each individual tower. And invisible enemies that can be detected one at a time by a specific tower type with a specific optional upgrade again as well.

There are no buildings you can place on the track itself, so no mazing, no "enemies have this effect when you walk over it" (except one optional upgrade which can draw a weak damage straight line across a lane), and basically just assume that you're looking at the absolutely earliest days of tower defense games in terms of conceptual mechanics.

Now, with that in mind, the towers can be upgraded quite a few times, with each individual tower getting to choose optional upgrades at specific levels, basically as follows:
Level 3: Pick one of 3 stat increases
Level 5: Pick one of 2 special abilities
Level 8: Pick one of 3 with 1 and 2 being upgrades to the level 5 version, 3 being the core tower
Level 10: Pick one of 2 weird things

The thing is, most of these upgrade options do almost nothing. They do let you customize each individual tower, but the customizations aren't that important other than the ability to attack air and invisible enemies. Things like "do the equivalent of 1 attack's worth of damage as AoE every 5 seconds, but you attack 10 times per second so it's not actually noticeable."

There's a large tech tree... sort of. Except absolutely everything on the tech tree is locked behind needing to progress past certain levels, and the resources you acquire are rather limited in how they're handed out so the choice is largely an illusion rather than a real choice. It didn't really need to be a tech tree, and there's not much need to grind for resources hardly ever because most of the towers aren't actually useful at all (poison tower for a really obvious example again due to how the game mechanics work), unless you explicitly forgot to purchase the ability to upgrade your new "can shoot air units" tower so it can actually, yanno, shoot air... and spent all your resources and are now stuck on a level with air. Fortunately you can just play any given level as many times as you want and it still gives full resource drops each time.

The game has a looooot of levels... 50 of them, in fact. They probably honestly only needed 20, because it mostly drags on after about halfway through where you're not really getting anything particularly new to do and the enemies are more or less the same from that point onward. They keep gradually adding new enemies, but they don't really do anything particularly meaningful. Yes, they have new status effects they can put on your towers, or can put up a shield on themselves, but it doesn't actually change your build any so it's kind of meaningless. It's just longer levels with enemies that have more HP and you get more starting money to spend on more towers. That's about it. If you like that, which you probably do if you're playing this kind of super oldschool tower defense game, then yay, you should be happy with this as it's just an excuse to do more of the same.

The graphics are fine, nothing too special, but it does look nice to see your towers actually being modified with extra guns slapped onto them, the upgrades actually visibly shown and so on. Each group of 10 levels has a different set of new enemies and a different background, each individual level within the group of 10 is a different layout with some unique appearance to it, but it's a tower defense so you're probably not really concerned about eye candy. The attacks are fairly generic, but the sound effects are fairly well done, and fast firing towers actually fire fast which I appreciate.

There are a few issues to consider though other than gameplay.

First, it's a Chinese game. It wasn't fully translated, and there's some pretty notable issues with Engrish here and there. Usually it's fairly clear what they're trying to say, but sometimes it's really not obvious at all. Many of the tooltips, even when set to English, will still be half in Chinese.

The tooltips themselves are also often not very helpful. Not just as translation errors, but because they don't actually cover the information you want to know in the first place. LIke it'll tell you an upgrade increases the range of a tower, but often it won't tell you by how much. You have no idea what the base range or damage of any tower is either, so it's pure guesswork on whether an upgrade is actually worth it or if you'd be better spending your resources or money on something else. This is again, fairly oldschool in setup, so you may be used to this concept already.

There are a number of typos and bugs, such as tower tooltips which were clearly copy/pasted over from another tower and never re-written, or one situation where a tower upgrade to give it anti-air failed to actually attack air units. That was the only gameplay bug I saw though, and it only happened the one time, so it's "mostly" bug-free in any meaningful way, but there will be a ton of little, obvious errors all over the place.

There's also the fact that it's a Chinese game, so... they steal stuff. There are direct references to the Zerg, for example. You just kinda expect that from a Chinese game though, they're not really that big on intellectual property laws over there, but if stealing stuff is a deal breaker for you, you should be aware of it.

Otherwise... it's not a bad game. It does absolutely nothing groundbreaking or new. It doesn't even try to do anything new, and suffers from all the problems Tower Defense games circa 2002 had, when WC3 was just new and people were just learning what you could do with them but not what was a good idea to do yet. If this is what you want, it really does have that oldschool TD feel to it, but it doesn't really have anything for modern nicities other than the graphics. It's worth the full $5 CAD that they're asking for I'd say, it's fine even when it's not on sale.

Just, as stated, it will feel OLD. It will feel unpolished, unfinished, but it's not actually legitimately broken in any way.

The closest thing to broken it comes in, is it starts off in Chinese text to begin with, and if you don't read Chinese, then you'll have to guess at each menu option until you see one which has a menu option with a British flag you can click on for changing things (about 3/4, anyway) over to English.

Overall it's fairly solid, if simple, and while it doesn't do anything particularly new, nor does it do anything with any sort of grace or elegance, it does it fairly competently. It's not a bad tower defense game at all, but go in understanding it really wants to be from the first wave of early WC3 TDs, or the last wave of SC1 TDs, and it really isn't going to deviate from that throughout the entire experience. It's about the most generic "oldschool style TD" that you will ever see, but it does that well.

Its a solid tower defense. There are a few imperfections. Game has to be changed to English by navigating  Chinese menu to settings then clicking on the British flag icon. There are some boss sounds that play even when the sound is turned off. Gawargh!!!! Once upon a time, in a quaint little village, there lived a young and adventurous girl named Silly Alice. Known for her playful and mischievous nature, Alice was always seeking new and exciting experiences. One sunny day, she decided to explore the enchanting woods surrounding her village.

As Alice delved deeper into the woods, she could feel an air of mystery and secrecy. The sunbeams peering through the thick foliage created a mesmerizing dance on the forest floor. Unbeknownst to Alice, she was about to stumble upon an extraordinary encounter that would change her life forever.

Suddenly, a peculiar noise broke the silence of the woods. Curiosity piqued, Alice followed the sound until she reached a secluded clearing. To her astonishment, she came face-to-face with a towering ogre named Oswald. With his mossy green skin, bulging muscles, and an intimidating presence, Alice couldn't help but feel a mix of fear and intrigue.

However, Silly Alice was not one to back down from a new adventure. Instead of running away, she approached the ogre cautiously but with a mischievous smile on her face. To her surprise, Oswald reciprocated with a friendly grin, revealing a softer side to his formidable appearance.
They began conversing, exchanging stories and laughter as time flew by. Alice discovered that Oswald was not as fearsome as he seemed. In fact, he was a gentle giant, misunderstood by the villagers due to his daunting appearance. Oswald lamented his solitude in the woods and how he longed for the company of someone who accepted him for who he truly was.

Alice, being the caring and compassionate soul she was, extended her hand in friendship to Oswald. She assured him that appearances meant little to her, focusing instead on the beauty that lay within people's hearts. The ogre's eyes glistened with gratitude and they formed an unlikely duo, embarking on incredible adventures together.

Their adventures were legendary, with Alice's quick wit and Oswald's strength complementing each other perfectly. They journeyed through mystical lands, braved treacherous mountains, and encountered fantastical creatures. Along the way, they both learned valuable lessons about acceptance, friendship, and the power of looking beyond appearances.
Back in the village, rumors of Alice's extraordinary exploits spread like wildfire. Through their courageous acts, Alice and Oswald managed to bridge the gap between humans and magical creatures, fostering a newfound harmony within the community.

And so, the tale of how Silly Alice befriended an ogre in the woods became a beloved story, passed down from one generation to another. It taught people the importance of embracing differences, recognizing the beauty within, and that true friendships could be found in the most unexpected places.

From that day forward, Silly Alice and Oswald the ogre remained inseparable, forever reminding the villagers that the world is full of enchantment if one has the courage to seek it.

A nice set of small, but often satisfying puzzles. It's quite short and easily beatable in three or four hours, but it's still enjoyable, and the asking price is just right. I only see two issues with this game: the first one is that it starts in an awkwardly-sized window that you can't resize, and the key to toggle full screen mode isn't given anywhere in-game. (It's F4, for some reason.) The other issue is that difficulty is all over the place, and some levels left me thinking ¬´Where was the puzzle in that?¬ª. But I wouldn't be surprised if there was more to them that I've missed.

A short, easy but fun puzzle game. The concepts are fun to play with, it's similar in feeling to 'you control multiple characters, desync them by blocking one but not the other' but more in terms of numerical quantities that rise and fall based on global state. The music is very good! I'd love if there were a way to get the soundtrack (checked youtube and soundcloud, and don't know how to extract from Unity resources). I do have some nitpicks, namely:

* there's lots of animation delay on moving, so if I want to go some place fast it's annoying.
* No undo key! Luckily the puzzles are simple enough that I could do without it.
* Some missing settings: Controls rebinding, resolution. Full screen toggle exists but is not documented (it's F4).
* There's some overworld traversal jank - there exists a way to place a junction that the player stops at, but other times there's T and four way junctions that the player flows past in unintuitive ways.
* Some of the puzzles are based on hidden information (priority between two identical things, elements not visible in the starting configuration) or have an annoyance (a long traversal time between two parts of the puzzle), but the puzzles are few and short enough in number that I could get over it.

But if you want a puzzle game that'll take you 1-2 sessions to beat and is a fun simple time, this will do the trick.

A cute little puzzle game with some really neat mechanics! Each new mechanic's introduction feels natural leading to a very smooth difficulty curve. It's easy to keep saying "one more level" once you're in a groove. Catchy music too!

Quick Description:
-Side by Size is a a minimalist logic puzzle game that packs quite a punch.  This game is a little rough around the edges, but it makes up for it w/ over 120 well designed, challenging, and innovative levels.  There are a handful of mechanics that build upon each other as well as a good amount of secrets to be found.  The UI isn't pretty, their is a slight bit of input delay, and their are a couple of odd difficulty spikes (there are a handful of very difficult levels between 50-60 and then most of the rest of the game is quite a bit easier imo).  Fortunately, I can easily overlook all of this b/c this game is an absolute steal at $5.

Consensus:
-Solid Game (Tier 3 and makes up 35% of my reviews).  I completed 90% of the game before giving up.  This game has a couple of really tricky, creative, and thought provoking levels.  In fact, I took a break for about 3 months b/c I was stumped by two of the levels around level 60, before coming back and finishing most of the rest of the game.  Logic puzzle fans are sure to enjoy this one.  Pick this gem up and don't look back!
Very fun puzzle game with a simple yet clever gimmick!!

Challenges increase over time and it's honestly addictive. Each level may take you between some seconds to some minutes, I think that's why it feels so addictive. Retro art and music is also lovely.
Lovely puzzle game with simple but very clever concept and a well-balanced difficulty curve. Well worth the price!

I would not say it's a badly made graphic adventure, but there was just not enough of a kick to the narrative, if there was some hidden meaning behind it I don't think it translated on my end, I am not sure if it's just lack of experience, but I felt the story was just too primitive. Honestly with the game being 15 minutes or less, if you just gave me like another 10 minutes of context for both characters, it would probably make the difference between a negative review and a positive one.

It has some dark vibes so I thought the plot would go interesting places, but there are only a few characters, and not one of them is explored in any meaningful capacity. To be honest I am not even sure what you were trying to say at the ending, it just seemed like 2 people frustrated with life, that is pretty much all I got from it, that seems to be the extent of their relationship, either that or you failed to convey your intentions. I am not even trying to nitpick the story, you could keep it the way it is, but you just need more time with the characters, give them a bit more background or just add a few layers to the plot leading up to the ending, I don't mind short games but this is a good example of a game that needed more time with the character, perhaps a few extra panels would help.

The game can be completed in 10 to 15 minutes with no prior knowledge, The correct path only has about 5 minutes of dialogue, but the choice-based progression makes it a bit longer, plus there are a few optional achievements. Your partner randomly goes missing and you have to repeat the same day to find the "correct sequence" of events to save her in time, so there is a bit of trial and error with the choices.

I actually love these deducting games where you have to avoid dead ends, not many people do, but it reminds me of those classic text adventures, I kinda of dig them personally. I like that you had a few optional events, but I would like to see you expand on them if you make another game, just add 1 or 2 extra acts, maybe a few optional endings as well. I do think you would benefit taking more risk with the story, it's okay to have a simple plot sometimes, but if you take no risk, there is no reward, and while I didn't hate the game, you didn't even give me much to work with which is somewhat frustrating.

While I do think you picked a decently moody song for the game, I would recommend thinking about game music in a form of manipulation and complementing the scene instead of playing the same song over the game, you could try slowing it down or slightly modifying it for different locations or perhaps even changing it entirely if the dialogue calls for silence or something more subtle and atmospheric. I didn't mind the visuals, the only thing I would say is because the actual scenes didn't have much going in them,  I don't think that you made it very compelling to explore, I think you need to give yourself more opportunities to create interesting imagery in the game. 

[h1] Pros: [/h1]

(+) Now I can't say that there was any part of the game that I really liked, but I think you have the basic format down, I like having those optional outcomes like the path talking to the school friend over and over. You not doing anything wrong, just need more layers to the experience. I liked that dark atmosphere and the look of the game, but even there I think you needed to do a bit more mood progression to make it compelling

[h1] Feedback: [/h1]

[u] Just some thoughts: [/u] - not to repeat myself, but like already mentioned, I just don't think you doing enough with the plot, you need more scenes to develop the characters and give more weight to the narrative. I don't mind the art but I also think you need the plot to give you more opportunities to draw more interesting scenes in that art style. For music, even if you have one song, you could try slowing down or changing the pitch a little between different locations.

That and honestly just make the game a bit longer, even if you make something decent you just never going to get much across in 10 minutes.

[b] Overall Thoughts: 5/10 [/b]

It's not a bad game but the story just didn't have enough of a kick to it, sometimes you can get away with something simple, but even then I think you need to provide more details for the reader to care about the plot. I was somewhat compelled to find her, I will play almost any game with a dark atmosphere, but you really didn't reward my time. I think you got the basic format down, just need to focus more on the characters and add more context for the plot. Give yourself more opportunities to come up with interesting locations to draw, take more risk with the story. 

[code]Niche, obscure and underrated games: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31294838-Hidden-Gem-Discovery/ [/code]

"It is what it is" is the first thought that comes to mind.

In short, no spoilers, you learn this within the first 2-3 minutes and this info sets you up for the rest of the game: your friend sent some peculiar texts that hint that something not very good has happened or is going to happen, and no one knows where she is. Her parents have called the police but otherwise they're not really that bothered and take no responsibility. A friend at school spoke to her just before the disappearance but is reluctant to give you any information other than what you already know. Why would she hide things from [i]me[/i] of all people?
You keep doing the same things over & over in a cursed time-loop. How can you make it stop? How can you find her?

It's a nice enough little narrative adventure. The concept that you re-live the same day over and over can make it a bit repetitive but enough new things happen to not burn you out and it is of course quite short, but it isn't offensively priced.

I really like the art-style and colour-palette, atmospherically it fits really well and the map mechanic and time-loop concept proves that this developer is able to be a bit creative and unique. It's not another identical visual novel narrative made in the same way as all the others.

I wouldn't say the story is amazing but I wouldn't say it is horrid either, I don't know... I found it a bit weak and not as hard-hitting as I wished for & I found the main character to be a little aggressive and irrational, I was not a big fan of that.
Again, [i]it is what it is[/i]: a mediocre little game where a [i]Mixed[/i] rating would be more appropriate than a Thumbs Up or Thumbs Down.
It's this developers first game and it is a fairly strong start for what the game is, [i]practice makes perfect[/i] as they say, and they proved that they are able to do some of their own thing and think outside the box in terms of how the game is paced.

It feels as if people so often expect and demand a life-changing experience from anything they play nowadays when it is a story game, set your exceptions in a more realistic place. And if you're not willing to pay 2$ for an as-advertised short game then don't buy it.
It is pathetic how many people give games negative reviews for literally no other reason than it being short when that is made very clear in all reviews and written very clearly on the store page to indeed be the reality of the situation.

[h1]Curator page[/h1]

[i]If you liked this review or otherwise found it helpful in deciding whether or not to buy this game, feel free to follow [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/29162366/]my Curator page[/url].[/i]

Overall, for what it is, it's a neat little game. The two-color palette is pretty oppressive and really helps the tone of the game come across. The ending felt like it conveyed what it wanted to, and I enjoyed it.

The writing is very..... utilitarian. There really isn't much to it, every conversation flowed a little unnaturally and very much felt like a way to get you from point A to B to C. The narration suffered from this too, its definitely readable, it just feels a little..... clunky. Lots of "tell", not a lot of "show". I completed the game on the second try and felt no real need to hunt for the other achievements because I wasn't sure if there was a real point to searching the world for alternate paths. Stronger writing and better prose would have probably helped this.

But, for it's price point its a neat little experience. I'm glad I played it

[i]Meet Her There[/i] is dark-themed visual novel developed and published by Sinisthesis.  You take on the role of an unnamed teenage (or perhaps, slightly older) female who ends up receiving a strange text from her girlfriend.  The text implies [spoiler]suicide[/spoiler], which, of course, alarms the MC.  Thus, she hurries to various locations to find her girlfriend and stop her before it's too late.  That's the basic story premise, and I'll stop here to avoid spoilers and all that.

As for the gameplay, you're presented with a map of the city, and various locations are marked where the MC can visit in search of her girlfriend, or at least, any information as to her whereabouts.  In each location, you'll get one of two choices as to what the MC should do.  Thus, the gameplay continues like that until you either get the ending where the MC is too late to save her girlfriend or you get the true ending.  Unlike a lot of visual novels, no CGs are present.  However, there are Steam achievements, but they won't count towards a user's global total until the game is out of "Steam is learning about this game".

Now that I've gone over the story and gameplay, I'll move onto my thoughts.  [i]Meet Her There[/i] stood out to me because of how different it is from a lot of visual novels out there, so I decided to give this a try.  Before I get ahead of myself too much, though, I'll first comment on the story.  Right away, I could tell that the story atmosphere is meant to detect some imminent danger when the MC receives that ominous text from her girlfriend.  Along with the art and music, I definitely get that feeling.  Understandably, the MC is in a panic, so she searches in several places to find her.  In regards to the MC, I found her to be hot tempered (but that is understandable due to the situation), but it's obvious that she deeply cares for her girlfriend and wants to save her.  As to the various characters the MC meets, their personalities and temperaments vary.  While the girlfriend's friend at school is a nice enough, friendly character who can tell that the MC wants to find her girlfriend (yet, she is conflicted because she was made to promise not to give the MC any clues as to where the girlfriend might be), the girlfriend's parents are hostile, attacking and blaming the MC for their daughter being the way that she is.  It's implied that [spoiler]the girlfriend might have been a guy, but that's only if you carefully read a certain line of text[/spoiler].  As to the story's true ending, this is where conflicting views come into play.  As I played this visual novel after the Steam update, I'm getting a slightly different perspective from those who played it before the update.  Without going into spoiler territory, all I'll say is that it left me feeling [spoiler]sorry for the MC, but the reality is that she would have never been able to stop her girlfriend from committing suicide[/spoiler].

Regarding the writing, I found it to be passable.  I didn't notice any typos although it's definitely on the short side.  The pacing is fine since the story itself takes place within a span of a few hours (probably).  As for the gameplay, I liked the map presentation and the concept of a time loop.  Thus, if you reach an ending where the MC is too late to save her girlfriend, you'll get taken back to the start of the story and have to make slightly different choices as you aim towards getting the true ending.  All the Steam achievements unlocked for me without any problems, and they're pretty easy to figure out how to obtain (for the most part).

As for the art, I like the style that is used.  It's in a pixelated style with red and black colors being the primary colors.  Combined, it helps give off that dark, intense, scared feeling, which is probably what the developer intended.  In regards to the music, there are only a few tracks.  However, the tracks that are present, like the art style, give off that dark, intense, scared feeling as well, setting the atmosphere adequately.

Overall, would I recommend [i]Meet Her There[/i]?  For the developer's first game, I think it's adequate.  I would give this a neutral rating, but since Steam doesn't have that option, I'll give it a positive.  The story execution could have been better even though I believe the update makes the story's message a little clearer.  I would have liked for there to have been CGs, but I can see why that might not have been possible.  For the asking price, I'd say that if you want to give this a try, it's best to wait for a sale.  It took me a little over 30 minutes to obtain all of the achievements and get the true ending.

I bought the game with the intention to try it out, played it for about 20 minutes, and immediately felt the need to write a review.

Here are my recommendations, but I can say that the game is definitely worth buying, and it has a lot of potential.

What I really liked:

Even though there were some aspects that took me a while to grasp in my initial experience, it gives a pleasant feeling.
We feel a sense of empowerment, which is very satisfying.
The combat mechanics provide a lot of enjoyment.
The perks and blacksmithing system are quite enjoyable, and the constant sense of progression is a lot of fun.
The visuals are impressive and look very charming.
Would be nice to have:

Some mechanics aren't perfectly polished, but they aren't too bothersome.
Sometimes, I find myself searching for enemies on the map, and it would be great to receive a reward or information when I've cleared the last 1 or 2 enemies. A few times, I kept looking for enemies even though I'd completed the map.
Traveling on the map is nice initially, but it feels long when you want to return to spend diamonds."

It's in early access and I've encountered some bugs, but none of those ruined my game. I had a lot of fun playing the game. At the beginning, I wondered if it might be a bit challenging, but I got used to it over time. It's not a game where you can just rush through all the enemies; you have to use tactics based on the type of enemy you're facing. For example, there's an enemy that shoots lasers; I retreat when it shoots, then I attack when it stops, and then retreat again.
I don't know if it's due to early access, but there was a sword that hits really well, but it slows me down as a perk. There was also a skill in the game that increases my walk speed, when I used it together, I was able to walk my normal speed and I started hitting really well.
The graphics are beautiful, and the gameplay is very fun to play. For now, the gameplay time is short, but it's a game worth its price.

A surprisingly fun and lighthearted platformer. It's very much on the sillier side of things, and is only a couple of hours long, but there's something to be said for games which you can pick up and play through in a single session.

In terms of gameplay, the frequent checkpoints double as a fast travel system so it's easy to get around the world and back to where you were if you die. The regular platforming is also quite forgiving, but there are a couple of notably harder spots which may require repeated attempts (the cars near the start, and the ducks at the lake).

Definitely worth checking out if you have a couple of hours to kill, especially given that it's free.

[h3]Summary[/h3]
[b]Stories in Glass: Winter[/b] is a stained-glass jigsaw puzzle game centered around folklore Christmas stories. Its relaxing gameplay, beautiful graphics, iconic music and warm, cozy vibes make it the perfect game to get you into the mood for Christmas! Suitable for all ages. You can also re-paint any puzzle and save the result!

[quote][b]Disclaimer:[/b] I don't get compensated for any reviews I write. This is my honest opinion of the game.[/quote]

[h3]Stats[/h3]
[list]
     [*] Time played: 10+ hours 
     [*] Story books played: All five 
     [*] Achievements unlocked: 14 / 14
[/list]

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
[list]
     [*] The game consists of five books, each tells a folktale through eight chapters / puzzles.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3105768636

     [*] It's like a children's book (or five), simplified even more and made into a fun and interactive game.

     [*] Once you complete any of the puzzles, you can change the color of any of the stained glass pieces!  

     [*] Further more, you can directly save your new customized art work as a wallpaper for your desktop! I haven't removed mine since I first put it up; too cute!
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3104905626
     [*] 40 puzzles in total, so plenty to do. 
[/list]

[h3]Graphics and audio[/h3]
[list]
     [*] Beautiful visuals
Very pleasant to look at.
 https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3112147852
     [*] Immersive music
Plenty of classical Christmas tunes play back to back in the in the background with nice fading. 

     [*] Nice sound effects
The searing sound of a glass piece being welded into place never gets old for me! Very satisfying.
[/list]

[h3]Pros[/h3]
[list]
     [*] Polished and smooth gameplay
Only one bug in my 10 hours of play time. Otherwise, my experience has been stellar.

     [*] Very relaxing
I really needed that and this game scratched that itch. 

     [*] Satisfying gameplay
It's a nice feeling when you're done with a puzzle and just look at it for a moment. This beauty? Yes, you helped make it complete.

     [*] Replayability 
The ability to select your own choice of colors to completely reimagine any puzzle adds a unique feature and possibly a few extra hours of fun when done together with your children or nephews and nieces. 

     [*] Fitting for the season 
[/list]

[h3]Cons[/h3]
[list]
     [*] One bug: 
When you move a piece out of the deck below and then return it there (because it didn't fit), it makes the furthest piece to the right in the deck go out of view, rendering it unseen and un-selectable. Here's a demonstration. 
Hidden and unreachable: 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3104977295

Visible and selectable:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3104977769

     [*] Typos.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3105956668
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3110484901
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3112314166

[/list]

[h3] Quality of Life Suggestions [/h3]
[list]
     [*] Maybe make the stained glass pieces stick together outside of the picture?
Right now, even if the pieces fit together, they won't join unless within the frame. I understand this very well might be a game design choice.
Example: 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3112041945
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3112042130

     [*] Show the name of each book and chapter at the start of its puzzle, and feature the complete non-colored puzzle; both as a center-screen popup message of sorts. This will make for a more coherent and immersive experience for the stories.
     
    [*] Add the ability to pick which Christmas music is playing. 
I can name two indie games that I've played recently that do this (Voyager and Wound Man) and it's really helpful because we can skip to the ones we like the most or avoid a track that keeps playing too many times. 

[*] Is it possible to add vocals to the music? Can it be done without violating any copyright laws?
[/list]

[h3]Achievements[/h3]
[list]
     [*] Total: 14
     [*] Very straightforward
     [*] Perfect Game? Not yet but it certainly has all the potential in the world to give that. 
[/list]

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
Highly recommended!
This is an affordable game that fits Christmas perfectly. 
I don't believe I've played any Christmas-themed game that comes even close.

[quote]Liked this review? Please follow [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44352372/] [b]Volcanic Reviews[/b][/url] for a variety of fun and new reviews! [/quote]
[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32732116-IndieGems/] Follow [b]IndieGems[/b][/url] for more reviews like this one. [/quote]

Craving winter stories or Christmas moments? In [i]Stories in Glass: Winter[/i] piece together 40 beautiful scenes depicting the magic of the season. 

[h3]The Story[/h3]

In [i]Stories in Glass: Winter[/i] you play through five books that each tell a winter tale. The stories are The Fir Tree, The Snow Queen, Elves & the Shoemaker, Visit St. Nicholas and the beloved story The NutCracker. You can play any book in any order with each book having 8 chapters. 

[h3]Gameplay & Features[/h3]

The settings in the game are very basic, audio control and resolution options. As well as language selection. 

Game play is piecing together mosaics like a jigsaw puzzle. 

[i]Strengths[/i]

* In-game hints that recharge fast. 
* The music is festive. A collection of instrumental Christmas melodies that are relaxing and certainly suit the theme of the game. 
* Easy to obtain achievements, just play & enjoy the game. 
* The puzzles DO auto-save so you can back out and go back in with your progress saved. 

[i]Special Features[/i]

One thing that this game does have which is cool is once you complete a puzzle you can paint or recolor elements in the puzzle. Once done you can make it a wallpaper. 

[i]Shortcomings[/i]

* You can only change resolution from the main menu and not during game-play (hitting quit will bring you back to the main menu (not quit out of the game).
* The pieces do not rotate. Simply pick them up, find their spot and it will click into place. 
* No difficulty options. 
* When you're piecing together the puzzle there is no image to reference as to what the complete picture should look like.  
* The pieces are, for the most part, grouped together. Making it very easy to assemble sections. 
* Hints do not place random pieces, it always takes them from the first piece in the lineup. 

[h3]Overall Experience[/h3]

This game is certainly festive with beautiful illustrations to get you into the mood for the holidays. However what it offers is too basic and too easy for those looking for any type of challenge. The pieces are grouped together so there is no trying to ‚Äúfind‚Äù the next piece, they are next to each other. Assembly becomes very easy once you notice this. There are no difficulty options, no rotation of the pieces and no real challenge. 

I will say however this game is perfect for the young ones. They are probably not going to notice the lack of difficulty and the colorful illustrations combined with the music, re-coloring options and festive spirit will certainly delight them.

 [i]I recommend this game for a younger audience and on sale[/i].

Relaxing puzzle where you restore images while listening to Christmas tunes.

Here‚Äôs something different from Tiny Little Lion studio. After several series of old-school and casual HOG games, here comes the equally casual puzzle game where you reconstruct glass windows. As always, there‚Äôs no need to worry about quality or content because they always deliver.

The game is divided into five chapters or books, and each book has eight puzzles. Although it would be a good idea to play them in order and follow the story, you can play any puzzle you want. The story is just a one or two sentences after you finish the puzzle, so it might not be that important to you. 

Each puzzle starts with some of the pieces already placed. The rest of the pieces are found on the bar at the bottom. There‚Äôs room for only so many, but you can freely scroll between them and look for those you want. The best way to start a puzzle is to look for pieces with straight sides. This means there‚Äôs a good change they fit somewhere around the edges. Or you can look for pieces with unique shape.

Regardless of your approach, you simply need to click on the piece and drop it on the correct spot or somewhere on the playing field. When a piece is placed on the right spot, it will get ‚Äúglued‚Äù and won‚Äôt be able to move again. But if the spot is wrong, you can either click and drag it around to a new spot or drop it back at the bottom to keep the screen clean. 

Once you understand the concept, solving a puzzle is very easy. The thing is that pieces are usually placed at the bottom in such an order that allow you to fill up the image without worrying where the pieces go. In other words, the first pieces is often connected to the second piece, second to the third, and so on. 

It‚Äôs a bit shame there aren‚Äôt any extras or bonuses. The only other feature is that you can change the color of completed image or completely repaint it according to your wishes.
Puzzle game for family, mainly for children. Although as an adult I have a lot of fun. Great music! Perfect while waiting for Christmas. It would be nice to add more chapters.
A chill puzzle game with stained glass, nice sounds, and good holiday music.  This one is a win.

Nice stained glass window puzzle game. After you complete the puzzle you can repaint the window.

Recommended.

[h1]GOOD VARIETY OF CHILL GAMES[/h1]
The Just Find It series has a hodgepodge of puzzles that are easy-breezy and relaxing. However, I will say that I found some of these to be quite challenging because of the intricate designs and patterns chosen.

Several of the puzzle variations have a hidden Lion mascot available, as indicated by the Lion Emblem on the bottom corner, as well as on the puzzle's icon. They are really fun to search for because each one is slightly different.¬†¬†

There are seven categories:¬†
‚Ä¢Click To Cycle (2)-click on various shaped pieces to create the correct picture.
‚Ä¢Difference (32)-spot the differences between two or more scenes.
‚Ä¢Detail (55)-search for areas in each scene that match the swatch.
‚Ä¢Match (6)-find identical pairs of various objects. (Butterflies was my fav!)
‚Ä¢Memory (3)-flip over two cards at a time to find matching pictures (I would love more of these!)
‚Ä¢Montage(12)-find objects that match a portion of the image.
‚Ä¢Swap (3)-swap shaped pieces between images.

Collector's Edition Extras:
14 Music Soundtracks, 15 Wallpaper, 2 bonus levels of Click To Cycle, 8 bonus levels of Differences, 7 bonus levels of Detail. 2 bonus levels of Match, 1 bonus level of Memory, 4 bonus levels of Montage, and 1 bonus level of Swap.

Casual mini-games that won‚Äôt overstay their welcome.

This is a compilation of seven different kinds of mini-games. It's a shame that at least half of the mini-games feature only a handful of puzzles, but the collector's edition fixes this by adding a few more to each category.

The focus is primarily on identifying differences and matching pieces to the image. These two mini-games have a lot more puzzles. The game is casual because you can't fail and there's no penalty for randomly clicking. You also have a hint that recharges after a while.

Puzzles can be sorted by type or all. The option to filter out puzzles you've already solved is absent. Although completed puzzles are marked with a checkmark, adding an additional filter would make it much easy to find them.

Collectibles are added to puzzles to make them more interesting. These take the form of a lion, which is hidden somewhere in the puzzle. Puzzles with lions have an icon next to them so you can see if you missed it. Unfortunately, there‚Äôs no reward for finding them all.

Xonix Casual Edition is a free mobile app that's been dumped on Steam as a paid product to scam PC gamers.  As if it was a real PC game (it's not)... it's a cash grab from greedy mobile devs.  This mobile app is an unabashed, lazy ripoff of Qix (Copyright Taito Inc, 1981).  Many lazy "amateur" developers don't pay attention to their obligations under copyright law, and often steal the ideas of actual, real game developers without credit, such as the "developer" here has done.  At this stage no legal action has been taken by Taito Inc against the "developer" here, but it's never off the table, as previous copyright law cases have shown.

Putting aside the unethical intellectual bankruptcy of stealing someone else's game concept for profit, this is also breaking that unwritten law of stealing other people's game ideas... you should at least try to do better than the game you're ripping off.  Xonix Casual Edition is considerably worse than Qix.  Sure, it's 3D rendered (badly) but there's nothing new or interesting about it.  And the fact it's a ripoff is blatant.  I had to go make sure HapGames wasn't some subsidiary of Taito or something, but they're not.  In fact they branded this mobile app on the app stores as "Qix: Xonix Edition".  Yeah, they're even ripping off the trademark as well as the rest of the IP.  And that's probably our first of many reasons not to buy this... because it's blatant copyright infringement, it's likely this will get booted off Steam as soon as Taito finds out what's going on. 

From a technical perspective, as a mobile app, this doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

There's no option to change the resolution and no useful graphics tweaks.  There's no way to ensure this is running at the native resolution of your display.  There's no guarantee this game will look right on any PC as a result of this hamfisted design decision.

The mobile app features low-polygon "retro" assets with cartoony, mobile app style shader effects, making this look like a barely functional mobile app from 15 years ago.  This visual style is a method that lazy devs often use when they have a lack of interest/capabilty to create highly detailed, high poly models and instead use shader effects to disguise that shortcoming under the name of "art", or "We made it look bad on purpose", which really isn't something gamers should have to put up with.  It's unclear why the developers weren't willing to arrange high quality, high polygon count contemporary assets and high resolution textures for the mobile app.  It's far below the state of the art visuals gamers expect as a result of their decisions.

The controls can't be customised, which will be an annoyance for many, but it can also render the mobile app unplayable for differently-abled gamers, left handed gamers or gamers using AZERTY or other international keyboard layouts.  

Because this is a mobile app, it carries a number of deliberate design deficiencies.  Compromises were made to cater to the iPhones that the mobile app was designed for.  These are unfortunate handicaps and limitations that PC gamers shouldn't be forced to accept, but it's evident that PC was an afterthought for the iPhone developers who are to blame for this.  The mobile app is deficient as a result of these choices, and would have been so much better without the handicaps that designing games for mobile phones forces upon a game.  Once more, mobile devs have made gaming worse for everyone.  I didn't spend thousands on building a gaming rig just so I could pretend it's an iPhone.

These technical defects push this mobile app below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

The poor quality of this mobile app is reflected by how many people spent time with it.  At the time of this review, SteamDB shows the all-time peak player number was only 2 players.  This is a remarkably low number, and now, the only player activity occurs once or twice a month, presumably someone loading it up to see what it is then quickly uninstalling it.  Considering there's over 120 million gamers on Steam and well over 100,000 games for gamers to choose from, the overwhelming lack of interest in this low quality mobile app is to be expected.

So, should you buy this mobile app?  Is this one of the best of the 100,000+ games on Steam?

[quote][b][url=https://partner.steamgames.com/doc/marketing/profile]Profile Features Limited![/url][/b]
Valve have marked this mobile app as "Profile Features Limited" at the time of this review.  This is usually caused by poor sales figures and low community acceptance for the mobile app (to date).  Until this status changes, this mobile app will not give you +1 to your Game Collector badge count, appear in profile achievements or any other Steam meta-accomplishments, nor can it be displayed in some profile showcases.  If these factors are important to you, it may be worth holding off before buying this mobile app.[/quote]

Once more we see greedy mobile devs trying to scam PC gamers. On Steam, this is $7 USD, on app stores, it's free. Mobile devs must learn PC gamers are not here to be gouged, and can't be expected to pay a premium for a free mobile app just because it's been lazily dumped on Steam.  This is unacceptable disrespect for PC gamers.  Because this can be played free elsewhere, and because of the other defects, it's impossible to recommend.

SEVEN BUCKS FOR A FREE MOBILE APP. 

Who do they think we are?
