First off, as someone who utterly adores this game and wanted nothing more than for this DLC to be an ancient relics 2.0, it brings me great pain to say that this is genuinely the only Stellaris DLC I go out of my way to disable. The rifts are interesting, and the relics are cool, but if i'm being honest the entire thing feels like a badly made mod.

I don't say this lightly mind you, we've had our fair share of bad paradox DLCs here, but the fact that half the new relics are either game-breakingly strong and/or blatant power creep on existing relics (and not even in an interesting way) combined with the fact that "azilash" (lower case intentional unfortunately) and all the content related to it feels cheap at best and actively detrimental at worst. It leaves a sour taste in my mouth unlike any DLC paradox have put out before.

I could spend far longer here ranting about the poor decisions made when developing this DLC and I haven't even touched on the fact that it was marketed as a full blown expansion. Suffice to say, I wouldn't buy this DLC again. 

TL;DR: Play with mods, there are objectively better mods on the workshop for exactly the content this DLC was meant to provide with far less random baggage tagged on.

To be frank, I'm not sure what my money has paid for; this is a full priced expansion but it compares poorly to the smaller story packs. It's a shame, because the narrative content itself is actually quite good and I have enjoyed it - but there's so little of substance to warrant it being the most expensive full priced expansion.

The 'Astral Plane' mechanics essentially boil down to a new type of Archaological Site that require a tech to access, a series of boons that function in a similar way to Relics, and a new resource type 'Astral Thread' obtained through research stations to purchase them with... and that's it?

Outside of the mechanics, there's a new Origin, a couple of Civics, and a few new species portraits that for some reason are low resolution compared to the existing ones.

As it stands, I'd have trouble recommending this at the current price to anyone. If it were reduced in price to match the other Story Packs, then I might suggest it for the more hardcore Stellaris fan, but even then it's a bit of a stretch.

Edit: Apparently people haven't realised, but this is DLC, which is why it shows as zero hours. I have played nearly 1000 hours of Stellaris at this point and own all the DLC. I have deleted the comments calling this a 'fake review'.

[b]"Astral Planes = Archaeology 2.0"[/b]

The main feature of this DLC is a recycled, reskinned, redundant mechanic from the older Ancient Relics DLC.

Advertised as something new to explore like the L-Cluster from the Distant Stars DLC, instead the Astral Rifts are only a series of textbox events with arbitrary choices, leading to unpredictable outcomes.

Most of the time, you only gain more of a new resource, the Astral Threads. This resource has no purpose outside of a few unlockables and buffs during the early game; though eventually you find yourself startled by yet another permanent "Resource Storage Full" alert, because this resource cannot be sold or traded.



The DLC also came with a forced "free update" which ruined the few positive elements of the previous Paragon DLC, by making leaders largely useless and frustrating through changing their roles, nerfing or replacing the useful traits with useless ones.

While you can choose to simply not buy this DLC, you cannot opt out of the free update branch.
The lead development of Stellaris is not doing a good job anymore. Avoid.
Higher prices with less content. And why are the new portraits so low-res compared to existing species? Is Paradox trying to pull a CA here?

Something I sorta bite the bullet on cuz I'm the host of most of our MP campaigns, so in principle I typically buy all the DLC so my friends don't have to.

That said, the vague description of the actual DLC should have been warning enough, as well as the closing of departments and this rather strange pricing.  I love you Paradox and I love Stellaris, but just with CA and Total War, we can't encourage this practice.

Stay away.

I have some 1300 hours in Stellaris since 2020. I have all DLC and delayed buying this due to the price point mainly and being out of work :/. I play typical single player, on larger galaxies and don't move the mid or end game around and treat each game as a campaign over several sessions. My games maybe last 6-12 hours.

There's purpose in this DLC, it's not meant to show up in the early game unless you take a set origin and you might feel underwhelmed about that at first, I was. What it does do later on is give you rifts that spawn like a dig site, beautiful purple, blues, reds and pinks and you have to divert resources to know enough about the first rift to actually then do anything with it. 

After this, you can allocate a scientist. Unlike dig sites and anomalies there is no right click or automation for this(yet?). One weird aspect about this is, the leader screen to select a scientist will be empty unless a free scientist is crewing a ship. There, they will fly to it and begin exploring it and will unfurl a story and there you make actual choices of how the story goes. These stories are a bit more, in my opinion - deeper, than most most / all other sites and thats something some people will enjoy more than others.

As you finish exploring a rift, you can make use of the Discoveries screen and each successive rift explored enables you to use your growing amount of Astral Threads towards unique activations. They function like relics, some with limited uses, others with long "cool downs". A lot of those activation's are useful or even super-awesome but they are not game-upsetting either.

This DLC also comes with three new music tracks and they are nice but maybe not quite up to the same standard of Stellaris that I'm use to, there is a high bar there though.

This DLC does add more relics to the game but i can't comment on those yet; My purchase was based around more stories, a deeper aspect to the mid game and yeah, that's what I got. 

[Post-edit] Seems the AI does use rifts too, so thats cool. Also you can automate rift exploration with science ships, I either didn't notice or maybe its a dynamic menu (probably the former!).

For those that rush the game and bring down those mid / end game years and zerg the AI or even play competitive MP(which are by in large, short games too), you could be forgiven for skipping this DLC as you might find them a chore but for me, I like the flavour this adds and wets my whistle and adds to the mid game where a lot of people complain "not enough happens".

Get this on sale. This is a good DLC, but Paradox missed the mark on pricing. 

Rifts are an innovation on archaeology sites. Each features a series of branching decisions with impactful rewards, often beyond a lump of resources. It's clear Paradox saw an opportunity to flesh out existing game mechanics with this DLC and took it. That was a great decision. 

Astral Planes offers less content than an expansion, but far more than a species pack. It showcases Stellaris' storytelling capability while fleshing out some mechanics introduced in earlier updates. It's not quite worth $20, but definitely worth adding to the game.
For the price of $19.99, you get 3 civics, an origin, and a re-skin of archaeology sites. Don't waste your money on this and get some mods instead.

I'm beginning to feel as though I'm interacting an enterprise application rather than enjoying the game I once loved. The constant pop-ups completely disrupt the immersive experience. I believe Paradox should consider developing Stellaris 2, where pop-ups are replaced by advisors (or leaders) who communicate with us directly about the situation.

Astral Planes is a good story-pack, it adds intresting content, extremly powerfull new relics, astral rifts have cool lore, and the events are quite fine (great job writers). Civics and Origin are also quite cool, but nothing special. My main issue with the DLC is pricing, it's too expensive, and adds relativly little new content. That's why i can only reccomend it to people who already have most/all DLCs and have some spare money they would spend on ciggarets or booze.

TLDR. - DLC is great, but WAAAY too expensive

I‚Äôm never quite sure how to judge downloadable content, in part because I‚Äôm never sure what‚Äôs fair to expect from it. Complete overhauls with entirely new mechanics can be fun and valuable, but if every additional release had these, the game would never feel stable enough to bother mastering. Likewise, I‚Äôm happy to see updated graphics, but if a release were to include only a few new menu screens, no matter how attractive, I‚Äôd be disappointed. Reviewing Stellaris: Astral Planes is one of those times I wish Steam ratings offered more granularity than simply ‚Äúrecommended‚Äù or not. At the moment, this DLC is a 7.5/10 for me, which is passing.

Let me start with the price: the DLC was released at $19.99 and is currently $17.99. I truthfully don‚Äôt know how to think about game value vs. monetary value. I‚Äôm in the fortunate position to be able to buy games as I want them. I don‚Äôt have to make hard calls about how to spend my money. Do I know what else I could get for $20? Of course. But I also know that I‚Äôve been okay with spending well more than that on a night out. At least this downloadable content is available to me permanently, not enjoyed and then flushed away.

In a recent patch note, Stellaris‚Äôs devs referred to Astral Planes as a ‚Äúnarrative expansion.‚Äù As I‚Äôll show below, that phrasing is apt: the DLC is more story than mechanics, more exploration than challenge. Could the developers have included content? Of course. Could this release have been cheaper? Sure. But I haven‚Äôt experienced any bugs, and I‚Äôm having fun. That‚Äôs basically all I want from the games I buy. I recognize that other players have other, perhaps more demanding, desires from their purchases.

I also realize that my way of playing Stellaris isn‚Äôt the same as everyone else‚Äôs. To be clear: I‚Äôm not someone who plays Stellaris for the blobbing. I enjoy building up my borders and seeing my naval cap increase, but I find the game‚Äôs warfare unremarkable. Sure, it‚Äôs a delight to watch sparkly lasers and exploding ships, but the military side is tedious. Astral Planes doesn‚Äôt add much to the game‚Äôs combat. There are new active and passive buffs and maybe some novel technology. Fine, whatever, ho-hum, shrug.

What I love in Stellaris is the exploration. At each game‚Äôs start, there could be just about anything out there, only a little beyond sensor range. My science ships head out, undoing my ignorance with every scan, and I‚Äôm rewarded with a host of planets, resources, and pop-up events and stories. These mysteries, tales, and discoveries bring seemingly empty space to life, and though I‚Äôve seen most of them before, I still read each one in full‚Äîusually aloud. I imagine the settings, events, and characters. And the hours of play tick by.

This DLC is clearly meant for someone like me. It includes are new events, a story-driven origin, and a new exploration system. The last of these is modeled on the earlier archaeology mechanic, which allows players to discover the history of their universe. The new system, accessed through attractively bright tears in space, instead gives insight to the history and present of other universes. One advance on the earlier archaeological system is how the DLC‚Äôs astral delving stories present choices. Archaeological events happened mostly on-rails, step-wise through, with occasional hidden rolls to determine outcomes. Astral Planes' events lets the player decide: Will you help the other worldly beings? Will you run at the first sign of danger? Each of these choices comes with an explicit difficulty marker, similar to the current espionage system. They can fail, sometimes disastrously. But these decision prompts remind me of my favorite childhood books: Choose Your Own Adventure.

I‚Äôm hopeful this release heralds future DLCs with substantial narrative content. Even if they‚Äôre not everyone‚Äôs favorites, they‚Äôre mine.

Recommended.
Price way too high for so little content, wait for discount, wouldn't recommend, 1/10

Should've been a story pack at half the price tag, as it is this is probably the least worthwhile DLC released so far. Adds what is in essence reskinned excavations, with some interactions to click regularly for bonuses.

The DLC is fun and definitely a worthwhile addition to the game, but at this price point? Absolutely not. I don't know what the developers are smoking, but it must be some strong stuff. I do not recommend only at this price point, wait for a 50% off sale and you are good to go.
It's the archaeology DLC for twice the price and half the stuff.
With the release of this DLC they almost completely broke the game. The amount of content you get with this is NOT worth the price. Wait for it to go on sale if you must have it.
Fool me into buying overpriced DLC once, shame on you. Fool me into buying overpriced DLC 19 times or more, shame on me.

Offensively bad. It's just midgame archaeology sites you need to set your science ships to explore, and a set of "Astral actions" that are mostly the same as relics and constantly pop up asking you to activate them. It's annoying and just another thing to micromanage rather than something that lets you take your empire in a new direction.

This DLC was clearly not play tested properly - there are a number of obvious bugs with bonuses (e.g. reduction in costs) not actually being applied.  They've already released one hotfix to allow to to be usable (at all) for some users; I suspect there will be more, but it's disappointing to see such obvious issues.  It also doesn't really seem to add that much depth, though I keep getting frustrated by the bugs (should I give a leader this trait that doesn't work or that trait that they can't actually use) and quitting a run.

It may be much better with a patch or three, but this is a pretty frustrating release.

The mechanics are similar to archaeology sites but with a cosmic coat of a paint. Some of the actions from the new but rather simple mechanic are pretty powerful/ fun to play with and I like the different narratives you can get. The new origin and civics are also neat but calling this an expansion is a bit of a stretch. As with all the Stellaris dlcs, buy on sale but even then, you get a lot more bang for your buck with the others besides the species packs. This one is 100% not worth full price.

The only DLC I disable just so I don't have to deal with the constant pings of "your resource storage is full!" only to discover it is, once again, astral threads, with nothing useful I want to use them on because all the actions have long cool downs. I wish there were a way to selectively disable which resources being full made a ping, because this made me just completely ignore the thing and overcapped on resources I actually cared about, like minor artifacts, which I can't see on the top bar unless I click into it.

The story bits are pretty interesting (alternate timelines of the precursors!), some of the artifacts are really powerful (size 50 gaia world? pretty pog), but I feel like its really forced into your face, you can't just choose to ignore it (because once you get to repeatables, unless you manually micromanage your physics research EVERY SINGLE TIME, you WILL research astral threads and you WILL be harassed by the pings), which ends up just making it really annoying when you're trying to focus on anything else.
The content is good, but it has nowhere near enough to warrant the price. It should be 5-10 dollars max.

I‚Äôve played the new content since it was released and I think honestly there‚Äôs a lot to dig through here. This is a DLC that gives you a lot of mileage over multiple playthroughs (most of the content is not unlockable all at once like Ancient Relics or Distant Stars or Galactic Paragons) but if you want to dive straight in, choose Riftworld origin and go nuts. Besides the DLC validation hiccups and a few persistent crashes, the number of noticeable bugs introduced has been almost non-existant. There‚Äôs a few persistent bugs but those have been around before the DLC release.

Slight spoilers ahead but I feel the DLC page doesn‚Äôt really describe the sheer scale of content here so I‚Äôm gonna try to summarize it as best I can.

Basically, buy this DLC if you like:

- 33 Branching early/mid-game storylines with non-obvious choices and high risk but high rewards. The number of localization/text lines is roughly equivalent to all of Ancient Relics archeology sites  (~1200) and trades off the quantity of archeology sites for the depth, risk and reward and branching paths potential instead.

- Storylines that have alternate timelines to 2 of the precursors.

- A civic that gives the ability to play a hyper-defensive empire that can defend planets with 6 digits (100,000+) defense numbers that will take 100 years of bombardment or a planet cracker to break and guard starbases and territory super hard.

- An alternative take to the pre-FTL exploration civics in First Contact without the tech loss and challenge.

- A civic that lets you play spiritualists that worship weird space portals (l-gates, shroud tunnels, astral rifts or wormholes)

- A civic that lets you get dark matter tech without having to beat fallen empires. It also grants unique edicts that use dark matter to achieve research, espionage bonuses, alloys and energy credit bonuses. (You can also spawn this on AI empires for an alternative method of getting the dark matter tech debris without going through FEs)

- An origin that has a unique archeology site and rift, allowing you to jump start both minor artifacts/archeotechs and astral rifts at the same time. Within 40 years, I had 5 astral rifts done and hyper relays before even getting the pre-requisite tech.

- Various actions from researching astral rifts including but not limited to: Making more astral rifts so you‚Äôre guaranteed 5 (and all the actions) if you find just 1, research hyper-relays and quantum catapults, give a permanent boost to quantum catapult effectiveness, ability to instantly generate forges without rare crystals and alloys, being able to prevent wormholes and l-gates from being accessed by closed border empires, instant jumps travel to your territory, the ability to summon extradimensional fleets for a time, removing relic cooldowns, and access to astral thread edicts.

- Astral thread edicts that let you get a 10% bonus to all resource production, +5 minor artifacts per month for a consistent source of minor artifacts if you get screwed on map generation or if you‚Äôre tall, cloaking strength and a massive bonus to shield HP and hardening.

- 8 relics, which is over half of the amount in Ancient Relics including the custodian patch that added relics to precursors!

- A new vassal type that cuts the cost of physics research tech in half. (aka research physics techs twice as fast).

- A new legendary paragon leader that can give military fleets, random physics techs or a bonus against certain crisis enemies.

- 2 Physics technologies related to astral thread extraction and exploring astral rifts.

- Several new ways of gaining leader immortality without psionics or synthetic ascension.

- New scientist leader traits and bonuses.

- Some new buildings.

- Ways of accessing various technologies before you‚Äôre supposed to.

- Replayable fun and things to do during the post-expansion midgame phase for those high skill scholar scientists.

Definitely recommend this, it‚Äôs been a blast so far and the scale of what goes on in the rifts stretches well past the already weird existing in Stellaris. There‚Äôs a universe full of blood out there. Another one full of trash. Find out for yourself what happens.

PDX, don't do it. You're one of the good ones. The one I use as a good example.

You know this is a 10‚Ç¨ story pack, not a 20‚Ç¨ full expansion. It just doesn't have enough content, add it, then it might be.

In general, the content is cool, but extremely overpriced, not worth unless 50% discount.

PDX, I'm done with greedy companies. Don't be CA.

If you want to spend 20‚Ç¨ to make your game worse go right ahead, but I'd stay clear. 

The glorified excavations are ok but not 20‚Ç¨ worth, and the astral thread interactions are annoying at best and often infuriating when the AI pulls some fresh BS out of it's ass.

Bought it because I buy every stellaris content. I've played around 20-30h with this DLC and have to say, that it adds very little content. Worth maybe 5-10 bucks. I'd say it's a system like archeology with a new resource. A couple of stories, some minor quality of life features but overall, I could do without it, has pretty much 0 impact on my games.

I don't know what possessed the devs to implement the ability to pull a fleet with an average power of 500k on medium maps out of your ass as soon as the late-early game that lasts ten years, can be instantly respawned, and is abused by the AI, but it needs to be done away with. This alone gets a negative review from me.

That aside, and even if this wasn't an issue, I can't rightly recommend this. You are basically shelling out $20 for just a few mid game stories akin to excavation sites. There is nothing special here. None of the events offer anything game changing or even interesting and the abilities aside from the aforementioned one are easily ignored.

Do yourself a favor and pass on this, even if it is on sale. This is the only dlc I have disabled. Every other dlc, even ones I disliked or are way overpriced I can at least say something positive about them. I cannot say anything positive about Astral Planes.

IF YOU ARE NEW TO THIS GAME / CONSIDERING WHICH DLC TO BUY, BUY OTHER DLCs PLEASE.

Astral Planes are definitely not worth its price tag. Seems to me like dirty cashgrab from dedicated fans of this game.

REASONS
- astral rifts are not new mechanic, but rather non linear archeology
- astral actions and threads are really unecessary (just another resource to keep track and buttons that needs to be clicked)
- one ugly humanoid portrait
- only one origin with very little (but interesting) story (first time you play it thou)
- few very lousy achievments
- most important game tweaks were brought by free update (which fucked up outliner btw)

Genuinely the only stellaris dlc that I would consider bad regardless of price. Doesn't even add an origin trait and the "content" is basically less interesting dig sites that give minor research bonuses when finished. Only get this if it is in a bundle.

My problem with this DLC is the impactfulness of Astral Actions. Everything in this DLC is related to Astral Threads, generating them and using them. However, when it comes to the usefulness of it, its very minimal. 

I mean, we have fleets with hundreds of thousands and even millions of fleet power by the late game, and yet the End-Game DLC gives us an Unbidden fleet that despawns and has to be respawned every 10 years. And this is one of the "strongests" Astral Actions. By the mid-game we have the Astral Action to instantly create ONE Hyper Relay, with a very long cooldown, so you just have to do that dozens of times, for decades to fill your empire network with only Astral Actions. You can also press a button to get +10% physics research... THE most powerful perk this DLC gives us are the Relics, which were included in another DLC, and their passive/active effects are much more relevant than astral actions.

I get that its supposed to be about space exploration and travel manipulation, but come on, couldn't astral actions be more relevant?

It's like Espionage, where the concept is great but its simply not worth the trouble of getting to know and maximize the mechanics behind it. The benefits of using astral actions are very nimble.

Also, it's counter intuitive with the leader rebalance (which is part of the Free Update), since now its harder than ever to have high level leaders. Then you have the option to use this high level leader to explore an astral rift and maybe get him/her killed just for some astral threads and unlocking some useless astral actions.

Espionage was abandoned, and I'm worried that Astral Actions will also be abandoned. If Paradox improves Astral Actions or give Astral Threads more uses than I think this DLC could be worth it.

Astral Planes exists to give mid and late game some exploration content that it otherwise lacked. It does an okay job at that, basically adding super archaeology sites that are less linear, offer new rewards and mechanics.

However, paradox has released cheaper dlc in the past that has as much, if not more, content and impact on the overall game. Nothing in this dlc will change the way you play, it just gives you more buttons to click and things to read.

Astral Planes should be at the bottom of your list of dlc to buy and is safe to skip if you don't enjoy the narrative side of Stellaris.
Very little content for the price, and the update with it broke the game in many ways

Alright price aside, as I am someone who thinks the dlc's have enabled us to get the amazing QOL patches the last few dlcs. Lets talk about this mess.  
We are testing the bugs for them hard this time around as most of the bugs i've ran into would have been found in one run by someone who's put any amount of Stellaris hours in.  This whole pushing content to have the players test stuff has got to go.  I'm fresh off the coattails of star trek infinite being the buggiest thing i've touched in a while BUT THIS IS A CLOSE SECOND

As a long time and reasonable fan of Stellaris, I have enjoyed playing with this DLC. Every Rift has a unique and interesting story, and it really feels like your exploring a fantastic new 'realm.' Astral actions are on point, I just wish there was more of them, so that it was more of a choice during a playthrough about how to allocate threads. Is it worth $20? Probably not. Still a recommend for w/e it goes on sale. 

For Paradox: If y'all had cut the price in half, then it would have sold a lot more and had less negative reviews. Same profit, but with a lot less alienation. smh.

This ain't it. For 20 dollars, you get reskinned archaeology sites with worse rewards. They advertised it as having branching paths which translates to "Would you like to end the rift early? Yes? Here's some 50 astral shards after you spent 500 to open the rift." You won't even see these for years upon years (unless you sacrifice your origin to get a head start, but for what?) and if you had any hopes of playing tall, you'll get four or five at best as opposed to much more average 12+ for slightly larger empires.

Not only that, but this DLC was coupled with one of the worst updates (3.10) to date, completely botching leaders (large majority of leaders spawn with governor traits, reducing councilor slots by 1 because of a new "required" councilor, etc) but still making them necessary. With the amazing things that we've been seeing over the course of the past couple years, it's unfathomable how they could have dropped the ball so low.

I love psionics so I bought this. Unfortunately it's rather boring and I don't like the music that came with it. It might sound laughable, but the atmosphere is what makes this game so great and music is a big part of it. After getting this DLC I find the game less immersive.
Adds more clutter that does not interact or integrate well with the pre-existing game

DLC Adds:

4 New Civics
1 Origin
30-ish Astral rifts
new relics
new music

My thoughts:

Civics: They are good, but only for normal bio empires. 

Origin: It is mediocre 

Astral rifts: Astral rifts are basically upgraded archaeology sites and they generate a currency called astral threads which are the equivalent of minor artifacts. If you are lucky you can get some crazy rewards including new relics. If you are not lucky you can still spend the astral threads in a special shop that actually has some really good stuff. Some of the things you can buy in the astral thread shop include boosts to physics research, sublight speed, and getting a guaranteed research for hyper-gates/quantum catapults.  Last thing of note is the true end game for astral rifts will lead you into the center of the galaxy where you will have to fight a mini crisis and honestly is what made it worth it. 

New Relics: They are strong. 

New Music: It is good.

Price: It is not good. 

Final Verdict:

If you play spiritualist empires you should get this DLC. If you play non-spiritual normal bio-empires get this DLC if you have all the other DLC. If you play machines or hive minds you might wanna wait for a sale. If you are a sweaty well you have to buy this dlc cus you need the PvP or Tall civic. :p

If you have a lot of money i would recommend this DLC

Price: 2/10
Content: 7/10
Story/roleplay: 10/10

This has by far the worst price out of all the DLC. The new game mechanics are fun even after playing through them a few times unlike the excavation sites. My biggest problem is the price. The update it launched with also was very buggy which however most of the bugs are fixed.

I own all other Stellaris DLCs. I bought Astral Planes despite the mostly negative reviews.

In summary; Yes buy this if you are a Stellaris regular and need something new to add new flavour. But don't buy this as your first, second or even third DLC. There are better options.
It is not at all a badly made or thoughtless DLC. The stories are pretty interesting and make you think. The issue is more that the appeal / customer base for this particular DLC is certainly more narrow.

Honestly I get what people are talking about:
1) The new content in this DLC is almost purely story based, with a few extra traits and artefacts.
2) It's definitely, definitely overpriced for now.

Having done one play through with it, its given me more new stuff to explore in the mid-game.
Astral Rifts each have decision chains where you can explore different choices on different play throughs. 
Its purpose is to help keep the regulars interested. It's not one of the patches or DLCs designed to attract new customers.

Like with archaeology sites; there is a risk your choices will kill your scientist, or make them unavailable for a long time. 
Unlike with archaeology sites; interestingly Astral Rifts cannot be explored by Scientists on your Council.

'Mostly Negative'  -  Okay I admit. The pricing for what this offers is dubious. The content is hit or miss. The music slaps (Especially "Into the Astral Rift" hot damn)   

But if you can get it on Sale?  It's pretty decent. Not great, not amazing,  just decent.  That being said, I do like how the Astral Sites are interactive instead of simple  A to B to C to Win  like Archaeology Sites are.  The groundwork for something better, and I hope Modders one day make great use of it too!

So yes. Recommend, but on the Condition of  Sale.  Steam REALLY needs a  "Neutral"  option like seriously Valve, get to it already.

I got it at a discount, which I'd recommend. But I really liked the content it added, it gave my scientists more to do in the mid/late game which I enjoyed. It was enough to bring me back and I needed several games to "see it all". 

I'd highly recommend at a discount.

This is the worst DLC by far.

Fleet spawning is Overpowered as fuck.
Everybody gets physics research boni and this causes everybody to rush the same physics tech.
The astral rifts are not really something new. The events are cool... I guess... sometimes.
The lock ability is useless because you can't lock a system someone else locked, even tho it's in your system.

It adds a new archaeology system and a new resource to keep track of. The new resource can be used for lukewarm edicts.
That's it. That's your $20 DLC.
Pick up your game, Paradox.

I got it because i love stellaris. But like many people say i have to agree it it does not bring much to the table for the 20 price. I LOVE the idea of astral rifts, but the just feels lackluster. The "many" choices are boiling down to some pathsways that are not different from other things already in the game . I love the idea of finding precursors in the past of an alternate dimension but it feels like it cshould be more.

I've had Stellaris since it's release and it is, one of my favourite games. However, now I find it is seriously marred, by most of its DLC's. I have purchased every dlc for this game and now I'm finding that it is becoming impossible to enjoy playing. I play on "slower" speed, and even then I find that I get 5 or 6 Popups, almost continually. 

This  disrupts any attempt at role-playing which is the reason why I play and from an enjoyable experience has become a chore, huge headache and totally ridiculous!! From a great game with interesting story lines that emerge each time you play, it has become an endless  click/ popup fest which break any attempt at game emersion!

This dlc has only made things much worse!!  If any more content is to be added to this game, it has to be done some other way, than by adding more text and pop ups in a game that is already inundated with this means of storytelling. It is not the only way, it is just lazy and the game is no better for it.

Time to start fixing what is already there.

The astral plane (or "the Shroud") was always one of the most interesting aspects of Stellaris lore. At release our interactions with the Shroud were limited. As a spiritualist empire you got to venture into this mysterious realm through text-box interactions at regular intervals. It wasn't great, but it offered a unique playstyle and established the materialist-spiritualist dichotomy. Playing as a psychic species gave you a unique jump drive, ground forces and pop traits which weren't all that different from anything else in the game but at least felt thematic. The crowning feature was a way to ruin your own galaxy which I won't spoil here. The whole thing dripped with potential but felt stapled onto the game at the last minute but I always chalked this up to: "It's a new game. And this is Paradox. Just give them a few years to make a DLC for it".

Things that I hoped for in this potential DLC:
- Jedi/Sith inspired leaders who can use mind tricks on other NPC characters
- A full Shroud-based shipset, cityscape, and maybe an origin or two
- In-game representation of Shroud-space, or at the very least a map layer
- Shroud storms which can be manifested in the real galaxy to be wielded as weapons of mass destruction
- Finishing the base game Shroud features as part of the free update

This expansion has none of that. By now tumble weeds must float through the original Shroud from total neglect because this DLC has not detected it's existence. Instead it adds Astral Rifts, which are just archaeology sites with extra steps. And did it really need to add yet another tab to the already bloated interface? Navigating the astral plane is exactly the same gameplay as archaeology/anomaly hunting. And after 3 playthrough since getting this DLC: what the hell is even an Astral Thread? Can I sew them together to make an astral handkerchief to wipe my tears?

This is easily the least interesting DLC. Buy this only if you run out of ideas during a steam sale.

They over promised, under delivered and over charged for this DLC. I noticed a lack of good content from Paradox Interactive. After this poor launch, and Star Trek infinite. I‚Äôm no longer buying their products until they show they actually want to focus on quality. I don‚Äôt mind buying a product as long as it‚Äôs worth it. Seems like they only care about revenue,  and short sighted gains. Gross!

If this wouldn't have been advertised and sold at the price of an expansion I don't think this would have got all the negativity one encounters here. It is actually a quite nice story pack and should have been advertised as this. But before complaining get it at a discount later. Most content which was included what had the most impact comes with the free 3.10 patch which gave a huge overhaul to the leader system. But there is nothing inherently wrong with this pack.

As a chump who has every dlc and is probably the consumer Paradox orients towards when pricing a 20$ thing like this, it‚Äôs hard for me to discern what a dlc actually contributes to the game that directly enhances my experience and what is already in the game that I just enjoy already, because I do genuinely love this game. But at least with Astral Planes, I can pick out one little thing, the portrait they added which just looks‚Ä¶ awful. So lazy, complete and utter contrast with every other portrait in the game. An afterthought, rushed perhaps, something to just put a checkmark on a list and say some achievement was accomplished. Soo‚Ä¶ perhaps that‚Äôs a hint.

The game is basically governed by a system of schedules during the day, in which depending on the time you can perform different activities, such as training the girls in the dojo, buy items in the store, work as a laborer to get money, fishing to get money and special items, and other small activities.
The main objective of the game is to train the girls in a certain technique, grope them during the training to increase their lust and finally have sex with them, to achieve this it is necessary to increase the skill level of the MC, increasing his strength and technique by training in the dojo and buying technique books in the supermarket which are necessary to unlock all types of training and view all groping scenes.

üåü[h1]Overview:[/h1]
[code] In "Self Defense Dojo," players enter the life of Kotaro Morimura, a man haunted by his past ties to the yakuza. Seeking to escape, he becomes a self-defense instructor in a remote village dojo, where he embarks on morally dubious adventures. This game, intended for adults only, delves into complex themes of manipulation and betrayal under the guise of teaching judo, showcasing the protagonist's descent into exploiting his authority to corrupt his students‚Äîmostly women in committed relationships. [/code]

üéÆ[h1]Synopsis and Gameplay:[/h1]
[code]In "Self Defense Dojo," players take on the role of Kotaro Morimura, who oscillates between his duties as a dojo instructor and engaging in more clandestine activities aimed at manipulating and seducing his students, as well as the local convenience store clerk. The game features a point & click interface that allows for exploration of various locations, some of which become accessible as the storyline advances. Gameplay is governed by a day/night cycle that impacts Kotaro‚Äôs ability to perform various tasks.

Managing your stamina is crucial, as it affects Kotaro's ability to carry out daily activities such as judo training, construction work, treasure hunting, and fishing. Strategic planning is key, as players must enhance Kotaro‚Äôs martial arts skills while also engaging in mini-games that simulate both physical training and secretive tasks. These activities are essential for advancing his dual objectives, which include the gradual corruption of the three women targeted by our protagonist.[/code]

üìñ[h1]Story and Depth:[/h1]
[code] In "Self Defense Dojo," players embody Kotaro Morimura, a disciple under a dojo master with a hidden agenda as a manipulative womanizer. Kotaro's life is a balance of honing his self-defense techniques and exploiting his charm to corrupt his female students. The game intricately layers his personal quests with his duties, pushing players to influence relationships with various characters: Mayuko Hasegawa, a married woman; Aya Matsushita, an engaged athletic woman; and Yui Matsubara, a day worker at the local convenience store.

The narrative thickens with the introduction of Rika Ijuin, the intimidating granddaughter of a rival dojo master, whose formidable presence and aggressive behavior add complexity to Kotaro's challenges. She is not only physically imposing but also aggressively confrontational, which tests Kotaro's limits in unexpected ways.

Players are tasked with managing Kotaro's daily activities which include training sessions at the dojo, subtly manipulating his students, and working at construction sites to secure the funds needed for enhancing his abilities and acquiring necessary gear. Effective management of these tasks is crucial as Kotaro navigates his morally ambiguous path, making strategic choices that will define his journey's outcome. [/code]

üèÜ[h1]Verdict:[/h1]
[code] "Self Defense Dojo" distinguishes itself as a captivating simulation/RPG game, featuring point & click gameplay and sophisticated pixel art animations that resonate with fans of popular NTR games like "NTR Legend" and the eagerly anticipated "Ntraholic." In this game, players step into the shoes of Kotaro Morimura, a master manipulator and skilled womanizer, offering a fresh perspective within the NTR genre. Unlike typical NTR games where the focus is on being cuckolded, here you play the orchestrator, adeptly seducing and corrupting women while cleverly maintaining amicable ties with their partners.

This role demands more than mere deception; it requires strategic interaction management to ensure Kotaro's manipulative endeavors are successful. Players are tasked with improving Kotaro‚Äôs stats through diverse activities, navigating complex relationships that are as challenging as they are rewarding. The game's mature and provocative themes are seamlessly integrated with gameplay mechanics, making it an essential addition for any NTR genre enthusiast who relishes directing the narrative and influencing the outcomes. 

Although "Self Defense Dojo" encounters some minor technical and translation shortcomings, it offers an engaging and deeply rewarding experience.  It adeptly melds strategic gameplay with complex storytelling, making it highly appealing to players who appreciate games that challenge both their tactical skills and moral boundaries."[/code]

Train self-defense to helpless women by grinding and groping them. 

The game places you in the shoes of a young man who comes to work for the elderly judo master. If you accept the position of teacher, you are welcome to stay at the dojo. Despite receiving a daily allowance, you will still be responsible for paying the rent and the old man's training courses. The best part is that you'll be teaching gorgeous girls how to defend themselves. 

Art is incredibly great for an adult game. You get to visit several locations that are packed with small details. Camera control is not great, but it‚Äôs not required that often because of small locations that fit the screen. 

Freedom in the game is limited to hotspots and marked exits. Although some rare hotspots can be checked for a brief comment from the character, they don't offer much. You can check them out on the first day and possibly find some additional cash, but after that, you can forget about them because they don't replenish or add new comments.

Aside from the dojo, you can explore six additional locations in town. Two buildings will only unlock once you get to know the females a little better. The other locations include a construction site where you can work for a few hours for extra money (if you have enough energy), you can go fishing in the mountains, see a movie in the theater, or buy important items at the shop. Items are pricey, but they can reduce grind time, teach you new moves, and refill energy. 

Buying food seems like a waste of money. Although you can only execute a few actions per day, you aren't forced to compete with time. You are able to do whatever you want, and sleeping helps to recover your energy. Characters will always remain in their current locations. Aside from the master and girls, there are a few additional characters with whom you can converse and make happy with presents. 

When the girl first enrolls at school, you will see an information card about her. It offers a brief biography as well as some additional information, such as breast size and zodiac sign. But what matters most is the girl's desire to learn lessons and her level of lust. Lessons are simple minigames. You must either mash buttons or stop a moving target in the correct position. 

Because judo may result in inappropriate touching, your character takes advantage of whatever opportunity he can get. There is a lot of grinding and groping. By holding down the mouse button on an action, you can increase the girl's enjoyment and resistance. Resistance builds up quickly, and if you go too far, the lesson ends. The catch is to wait a few seconds for it to drop, then repeat till you've had your fill of pleasure. Once this is done, the girl's lust will increase. You will always gain some, but it will fill up much faster if you do not rush things. 

The gameplay is pretty repetitive. You'll need to repeat a lot of the same actions to build her lust level. This is the only way to reach the nasty bits. Lust levels unlock sex scenes. The harder you grind, the more opportunities you'll have. These do not take long because you can adjust the speed slider to move through them more quickly. These, too, raise the girl's lust level. Unfortunately, most of the scenes are pixelated.

In the end, the game can be considered casual. You can easily grind for money at the construction site and quickly buy the best stuff from the store. Time spent in the game will depend on how much of the sexy things you‚Äôre willing to see.

[h2] The "Art" of Judo [/h2]

Self Defense Dojo is a life sim game where you manage your time earning money, "teaching" Judo, and interacting with a handful of different women. The game offers a variety of mini-games to master and CG's to collect, all stemming from a simple yet satisfying game loop. With a soft and clean art style, you'll want to see it all on your journey as a Judo "instructor."

[b] Now I'd like to mention some things I appreciate: [/b]
The first thing you'll see is the game's art, which is one of the most important things for a game like this. The colors are nice and coherent, the cel shading and highlights are all very clean, and the shapes and colors make the characters very pleasing to look at. Overall, I find the art to have a lot of charm. Along with the art is the animation. Each interactable scene comes with its own smooth animation to complement the art of each character. The game also features various mini games, from Judo "matches," to digging for treasure, and even fishing. (I love fishing) The mini games are simple and straight forward (you wouldn't want overly difficult mini games in a game like this) and lend to a satisfying game loop. Its fun to watch your money and stats go up as you hit milestones and benchmarks to unlock new interactions with the girls. And the rewards for your efforts are [i] very nice. [/i] The game also features subtle comedic moments and not so subtle references that I quite enjoyed. (There is a Jojo reference right off the bat that I found absolutely hilarious.)

[b] Additional Notes: [/b]
Here is where I'd like to mention some issues and similar things I ran into while playing this game. The first thing to mention is that there are minor errors in the English translation of this game. Thankfully they are fairly unintrusive and never cause the meaning of a sentence to be lost. As a result, it is hardly an issue in practice. Now, the major problem with the English translation, is the formatting issues. As an example, a Japanese word that would have taken up 1 or 2 characters in Kanji, can now take up to 8 for a word like "Strength." This means that in some of the menus and UI, text will often bleed into the nearby words and numbers, overlapping each other. This doesn't make the words unreadable, but can mess with visual clarity in some menus. Thankfully this overlapping issue doesn't happen with character dialogue, instead, words will sometimes pop out of the bottom of the dialogue box in longer sentences. While I am highlighting this issue, it is worth mentioning that it never affected my experience negatively, it is simply something to be aware of, and will hopefully be fixed at some point. Other than that, I encountered no real bugs and had an overall smooth gameplay experience.

All and all, apart from some errors in the English translation, Self Defense Dojo has a chill gameplay loop, charming art and animation, with a handful of interesting women to interact with. If what I've described sounds appealing to you, then please feel free to pick up Self Defense Dojo, and check out my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44931296-VA-Views/ ]Curator Page[/url] for more reviews.

TLDR: Yui best girl because she kinda reminds me of Ubel from Frieren.

It is recommended to get the ‚ÄòYakuza Rogue 1&2 Bundle‚Äô as both games are related to each other. Self Defense Dojo should be played before Yakuza Rogue as it is considered as the prequel to it. Yes, you see it right, there is actually plot in this game.

In general, this is a time management game with mostly clicking on the stuff to do. You can play as MC to do various tasks in the game such as training the girls or yourself in the dojo, fishing, going to cinema, working part time to earn extra money, buying/selling stuffs through black market. 

There are only five girls which you can have seggs with (Milf, University student, Convenience store worker, Kappa girl and the Ugly giant boss). The seggs scenes can be triggered at various places such as inside the dojo, cinema, tent or even construction site. It can be done easily if you know what the requirement to trigger the seggs scene is and it does not feel very repetitive.

The good part about the gameplay besides seggs is of course the NTR part. You can actually NTR the girls and their husband/boyfriend. You can gain trust with the male partner and watch them fall into despair after you NTR-ing their girl. You can also do stuff that you can‚Äôt legally do in the real world such as drugging the male partner or record sex videos and sell it at black market.

However, the game is not perfect. One thing that I dislike about the game is the voice acting or should rather say the moaning sound during seggs scene. Some of the moaning sounds so ridiculous and horrible that it made me laugh during the climax scene. There is also no fully voiced scenes which can be a minus point for some people.

Also, if you are perfectionist and trying to complete all the achievements, some of the achievements require a lot of farming such as fishing 200 times. Personally I dislike this type of achievement farming so this is a minus point from me.

Overall, I would say the game is worth getting even at full price. If you do not mind to wait, you can get the bundle version whenever there is discount for better experience as the plot of both games are related to each other.

Was gifted this game as a meme, but it's actually quite good! I meant to play this game ironically but I just ended up liking it instead and 100% it lol. I don't have much experience with H-games, so I'm surprised by how much this one had to offer. (full-fleshed review because I'm bored, TL;DR at bottom)

Artwork is fully uncensored and looks nice. The character introductions and their profiles + music was really perfect. There are a LOT of different scenarios and poses you can unlock/randomly encounter with the different girls. I had quite a few scenes left in the gallery that I didn't see in my first playthrough, so you'll likely need to do a carry-over save and grind in order to get them all. The extra content is worth looking into, especially the scenes at the cinema.

I'm a huge fan of the fact that the main character has a rather charming appearance to him despite his problematic history. Having a male character actually look like somebody with some sort of backstory is nice. He even has a sleazy personality to match his appearance and sociopathic behavior revolving around sexually harassing women (great)!

There was a lot of grinding to do, especially in the earlier parts of the game that got a bit monotonous. At some point you do stop grinding for money. Once you get the drills/infrared camera and start selling video tapes it really cuts down how much you have to work for it. At the time of writing this, there are some things that looked like they were left unfinished (a fourth spot to leave a wireless camera that doesn't exist, mildly broken translations) but these are not game-breaking and didn't impede my enjoyment.

The craziest part is this game has a sequel! The sequel (Yakuza Rogue: Yokohama Massage Parlor) is much more polished than Self Defense Dojo from what I've seen so far, so if you're like me and like Kota and whatever weird bullshit he's up to, you should play it. It seems like a huge improvement from the first 30 minutes of that game alone.

TL;dr good art, lots of scenes to unlock. A lot of grinding too, but worth it. If you enjoyed this game, there is also a sequel that seems very promising.

[b]TLDR[/b]: Astounding H game with unparalleled arts, great gameplay and satisfying H scenes. I am especially fond of the art in this game; the ladies are drawn too perfectly and I am still dreaming of them when writing this review. There are a few parts that require grinding, especially if you are aiming for 100% achievement, but nonetheless, you will never feel bored when you can pound your favorite lady. Ayano is the CUTEST!

Greetings kouhai-kun, welcome to the Self Defense Dojo. My name is AV and I will introduce you to the story and mechanics of the game. First, the story... it is straightforward but its simplicity is what makes this Dojo unique and undemanding. Next... I am sorry to say the in-game tutorial is on the wrong edge of the world, so you have to explore, mess around, trial & error a bit, but one thing for sure kouhai-kun; this Dojo just requires your right hand to do the job. [i](whatever you plan to do with the left hand is entirely up to your imagination)[/i]

We have two newcomers that will be participating soon, you will do well to instruct them and if possible, make them fall heads over heels as you unlock their lustful nature. There are plenty of H activities that you can indulge in, with many different scenes as you progresses. Although there is no voice acting, the moaning, the SFX combining with the peak art is suffice to make your bottom part rival against the Wonders of the World.

Aside than working as an instructor at the Dojo; there are plenty of entertainments around town, feel free to hit up on interesting mini-games that will delight you during your stay. As our town is pretty isolated, ample of items sold is bloody expensive, so you need to grind up a lot of income... not to mention some achievements do take up a lot of time.

That's all I have kouhai-kun, now I shall make haste and escape before my butt is chopped down by YKZ. It seems they have tracked me here and I need to escape to [i]Yokohama[/i]. May you enjoy your stay at the Self Defense Dojo. And~~ Ayano is the CUTEST!!

Oh, I nearly forgot, this Dojo has plethora of NTRs (you are the one NTR-ing), if this is not your click, you may choose to instruct at a different Dojo. Overall, recommended for sure!! Sayonara~

Welcome to the fishing game you can play one-handed, which also has some fun scenes on occasion.   Do I recommend it?  Eh... if you like fishing yes.   It's not horrible, but there are better NTR games out there if that's your thing.

The story (really, do you care?)   You end up in a dojo for forgettable reasons, and to stay, you need to make yourself useful and train women in Judo.   Specifically, two women.  And scene.

The grind, I mean game play:   The women are gated behind lust.   The more you judo feel them up, the more you eventually get to do.  To make the judo easier you must build up skill (pretty easy) and strength (this is a horrible grind particularly because where my mouse stopped wasn't always where and when I clicked.   Getting better at these stats allows you to do more "judo" moves and get more scenes.  

Apart from lust, strength, and skill, there is also money and fish.   Money can be acquired by finding hidden money, working at the construction site via labor or eventually digging, and then fishing after you buy a fishing pole and upgrade it to level 3.

For the fastest progression, ignore the women and do construction/dig/fish.    Buy upgrades to digging and fishing.  Buy food to restore stamina so you can dig and fish more.  The good news is that digging and fishing are one-handed.   

Eventually, you have resources and can start working on the women.   There are two in the dojo, one at the store, and a muscle-bound girl who has the hots for you and you can try to beat or lose to.   Working strength and Stamina will help you succeed.  OH, and fish girl who has the hots for someone you can drug and then take her instead.  

The women have a number of places you can have fun with.   You have options at the dojo after you train.  You can eventually take them in their apartment at two time ranges during the day, you can also do one girl in the store and all of them at the movie theater.  The store girl is also supposed to be mobbed at the construction site but I haven't done that yet and I need to look up the trigger.

The scenes are single positions and you click a right or left mouse button and hold down until it's done.   In the dojo, you can do it three times, but elsewhere, it is a single shot.   So, no real change of positions, no covering walls with white paint or whatever.

Overall, I spent a lot more time fishing than anything else (which was probably the best fishing game I've played in these sorts of games because it was relaxing and one-handed).   I would consider this more a fishing game and an achievement game than a "fun" game.  

Would I recommend the game?   As I mentioned above there are a number of games that I like better, but it's not the worst.   For those people with a specific itch I'll say "sure" although I'd recommend  NTRaholic first.  For others, it's not the worst game, and the grind is grindy, but you don't have to button mash, which I appreciate.  So, it's all right, and I'd recommend it on sale.

[code]A review copy was provided by the developer, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/search/?developer=WAKUWAKU]WAKUWAKU[/url].[/code]

[h1]This isn‚Äôt Judo, This is Anal SEX![/h1]
Netori simulators, as I call them, have become quite popular after NTR Legend came out, blew everyone's minds, and inspired other devs to make similar games. [b]Self Defense Dojo - Secret NTR Lessons[/b] is one such game and also the current winner of the DLSite English Awards 2023. Are you curious to know how good the game is? Keep reading to find out!

[h3]Pros[/h3]
- Solid gameplay with a good variety of minigames
- Charming art style
- Serviceable plot that adds to the experience
- Plenty of animated sex scenes

[h3]Cons[/h3]
- It‚Äôs a bit grindy

[h1]Story[/h1]
The game puts you in the shoes of a fuckboy named Kota Morimura, who had to take refuge in a dojo in the countryside after banging the wrong woman and is allowed to stay under the condition that he teaches Judo to its female students. The problem? He hasn't practiced dojo for ages and barely remembers the basics, but he's more than ready to relearn everything and take advantage of the situation while he's at it. 

There isn't much focus on the story past the introduction, but it gives enough info to make characters more than simple NPCs you interact with. Moreover, it features many references and funny situations that lighten the mood, such as when the protagonist meets the overly muscular female challenger who is head over heels for him.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3221712749
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
One of the most important parts of a game like this one is its gameplay, and it doesn't disappoint at all. It consists of managing your schedule and your energy to win over all the girls of the town, and instead of having a single game mechanic, it features a variety of fun mini-games you find everywhere in the game. For example, the Judo training consists of a mini-game in which you left-click and right-click in succession fast enough to topple your opponent, followed by another one where you have to click at the right time to lock your opponent. If you succeed, you then play the ubiquitous mini-game where you touch your trainee in inappropriate places to arouse her without angering her. 

How well you do in the training depends on the MC's strength and skill level, and how do you raise them? You guessed right; you do so by playing more mini-games, such as stopping a meter at the right time to train your strength and using left or right click when prompted to train your skill, similar to what you do in the Sexing Chickens mini-game in NTR Legend and the Trash Recycling mini-game in Peeping Dorm Manager. 

There are even more of them unrelated to training. For example, there's the fishing mini-game everyone loves in which each fish you catch gives you points you can later trade for money and items that'll make your life easier, a drilling mini-game that'll make you stinkingly rich and net you some useful items, and a movie-watching mini-game in which you try to get down and dirty with one of the girls without making too much noise and getting noticed by their partner.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3221712832
Its biggest downside is that it takes a lot of grinding to max out the girls' lust and their partner's favorability to the point that it's better to focus on getting money and items that increase stat gains first so the game doesn't get repetitive after a while.

[h1]Visuals and Sexual Content[/h1]
The game features a unique and charming art style that differentiates it from the rest of the H-games, plus its characters and backgrounds are pleasing to the eye. As for its sexual content, it features a good amount of nicely animated sex scenes that you can tweak to your liking, whether you want the walls or the MC to be semi-transparent, the speed of his movements, or the X-ray bits to be visible. Moreover, later scenes also feature highly polished still shots that add some variety to the scenes. 

There's a lot of corrupting and cheating in the game, as you'd imagine given the game's genre, with some extra flavors that make things spicier, such as public sex, banging the girl with her partner next to her and unaware of what's happening, some BDSM, and gangbangs.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3230270580
[h1]Verdict: Outstanding[/h1]
[b]Self Defense Dojo - Secret NTR Lessons[/b] may have a few issues, but it's so good it's very likely to be in my Top 10 list of Steam games released in 2024, if not the top in the list. Its solid gameplay, eye-catching art, and serviceable story make it a must-play for anyone who enjoys playing hentai games, especially if they are into netori.

I got electrocuted when I first touched Nerobi.

A few moments after the beginning, you start exploring a world with brutal level design: the game has no regrets in killing you over and over.

But the beautiful graphics and sound design takes you in for another round, and as the character gains back his abilities, the story unfolds and gets clearer and far more interesting.

The characters design is quite amusing and a nod to japanese culture.

Astonishing and curious work for a duo-indie team! Surely worth 10‚Ç¨.

I'll update my review when I reach the end of the game.

Nerobi is a fun, challenging game full of secrets to discover. The hand-crafted drawings are unique and spectacular, along with music and gameplay capable of constantly engaging. It is not an easy game, so if you are looking for a relaxing experience you may want to opt for something else. It is, however, an excellent title for fans and novices alike. You will test your patience and skills with this game, but you will also find yourself traversing a world full of wonderful secrets and atmosphere.

What immediately ravishes you is the graphical compartment. The settings are simply magical, fairy-like, enchanted. The designs are made entirely by hand and are extraordinary, turning Nerobi into a fairy tale with its many sides. This game is not the classic platformer with wobbly platforms and sterile obstacles. Nerobi is pure magic, with almost blinding lights and colors so vibrant that they mesmerize from the first moments. The different scenarios constantly leave you speechless and amazed, starting from the forest with its hues to the mysterious caves with cerulean hues. Absolutely satisfied.
WOW Nerobi is so cute. I definitely love this indie game! The drawings are beautiful and the music is so relaxing. At the same time, the game is challenging and competitive. No mistake is forgiven.

The game play feels new and there are some innovative elements to it. All in all it's a fun game worth the money.

positives:
[list]
    [*]unique/experimental game mechanics
    [*]very nice camera animations
    [*]nice use of post processing effects
    [*]attention to detail is high and stuff mostly seems to be actually modeled for this game, not just taken from some asset store. Kudos for that. Also nice how there's little stoppers on the moving-tower-block thing. Really cool little detail.
    [*]feels good to get the guy locked down with taser/slowing towers
[/list]

things that could be improved IMO:
[list]
    [*]wiggly canon. Like, why are you wiggling? Let me shoot that guy already. At first I thought the wiggling causes me to miss sometimes, which - to my relieve - wasn't the case. Less wiggle would be better IMO.
    [*]guy moving lanes randomly causing you to miss shots. I know this is part of the game play and this is what makes the game challenging. I just don't like the randomness of it. If there's a pattern I couldn't find it. Guy goes up at some random time causing your slowly moving bullet to miss. Argh! It's a bit frustrating at times to be honest. Couldn't there be some indicator that the guy is about to move? Maybe a small arrow telling me that the dude is about to go left? I'm not even sure my suggestion is a good one. That's the thing with ideas isn't it. They're just ideas. You need to test them and see if they feel right. All I can say for certain is that the element of randomly changing lanes has something frustrating to it (I wish it was more of a skill based kind of thing to be able to hit the guy, not luck based).
    [*]the wind tower. I hate it. I never felt like using it helped me much. I know, I know, it's good for preventing the guy from hitting the fast-blocks. But I'm trying to hit this guy with my super slow cannon here. And having the guy move because of this wind tower isn't helping me in that regard. Also, sometimes the dude is immune to the wind? like... why? How can I tell when he is and is not immune to wind?
    [*]too many icons and no tooltips at all. I get that this way it's easier to localize (ha! No Text at all!), but this is too much. I have no idea what those gauges at the bottom are trying to tell me. There's a green gauge popping up later in the game. It looks like a special ability kind of thing? So I click it and 3 more icons pop up. I'm trying to keep this guy from advancing and simultaneously I have to figure out what all those icons are trying to tell me. I click one and the gauge is lower now, so I guess I used it up but nothing happens? Now, finally, while writing this I am thinking maybe it is to reload the towers? Could that be it? I don't know. Also the gauges on the right are a mystery to me. I thought they're the dudes life, but that doesn't seem to be it. What are they?
[*]canon laser sequence. I took me way too long to figure out that I'm supposed to be using the laser to unblock tower-positions instead of trying to shoot the guy. That's on me maybe. But there could be some sorta arrow, right?
[/list]

Edit: I played a little more. I got used to the guy moving lanes randomly. There's some pattern to it after all, he won't change lanes immediately after changing lanes for example. So all good here. It's quite challanging. Currently stuck in level 20. I still don't know what the buttons above the green gauge do. But I'm having fun. Good BGM/sound effects!

Stages are selected from a menu in a linear order. There‚Äôs no big story here, you‚Äôre just trying to reach the finish line by jumping over chasms and on insects‚Äô heads.  

Everything looks generic due to the small variety of enemies and locations. You encounter a few creatures, such as wasps and cockroaches, and the locations offer very little.

Geko's only ability is to kill foes by jumping on them and climbing up the wall. Climbing is really bad; geko always slides down when you jump on a wall and you can't recover if you get hit while climbing. If you hold the jump button while killing an enemy, you will receive a small boost that will propel you a little higher. This method is often used to traverse chasms by jumping on multiple enemies. 

The game is frustrating because the majority of the stage is made up of holes into which you can easily fall.  Even layout doesn‚Äôt help because you have very small platforms with a threat in the middle. Every jump is made even harder with enemies that knock you right over the edge. You're not safe from climbing either; wall jumping mechanic is not good and you enounter slimy surfaces on which you constantly slide down. Of course, you need to do this while avoiding enemies and a pit below.

It's fine when precision platformers provide you the tools to overcome a problem and make the experience satisfying. Nothing here, just another stage with the same cheap hits and endless holes.

Death, thankfully, is not a big deal. You simply respawn at the last checkpoint after losing all three hearts. Extra hearts can be obtained by finding them within a stage or by catching flies. This is pointless because there‚Äôs no reward for grabbing all flies. 

When it comes to achievements, some are broken, specifically the ones for finishing a few stages without taking any damage. This could be due to a bug - or is it a feature? - that does not reset the amount of hearts when you quit and start a new stage.

It's a solid follow-up to 'Geko: Entering the Pipe' delivering a well-functioning precision platforming experience. With its endearing main character, pleasant art, and fitting sound design, it maintains the gameplay's enjoyable aspects. It's a recommended choice for those who enjoy the genre.
Good thing for ur money, its a decently long game with some fun ideas. Def worth it

I have a pretty bad cold and this is just what I needed. Simple and fun. 

Would be nice to hear from the dev...
A cool platformer with levels that will allow you to play for hours

A self-admittedly solo project, made predominantly to learn how to even make a game. And that inexperience certainly shows, with a lot of rudimental graphics and UI elements, some readability woes, slightly off hit detection, and "cute" little oddities like being able to shoot once during the pause menu and such. But even with all its obvious rookie errors, Vexed Heroes is a fun little bullet heaven game. By focusing on min-maxing a single weapon (one that has to be shot and aimed, so no auto-fire) and summons, the action can get quite frantic, though the enemy variety isn't high. There's also only 2 very similar stages, but at least the progression in terms of difficulty scaling seems virtually infinite.

Anyway, it certainly isn't a masterpiece, but it's not aiming to be one. Solo dev Mint has made a fun attempt at tackling the ever-growing bullet heaven genre for his debut, and for the price of just under 1 USD/EUR in the current Steam Sales, it's a good couple hours of entertainment.

Bullet Heaven Fandom review #69. If you're looking for extensive coverage of the games in this genre, consider checking out my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43402758-Bullet-Heaven-Fandom/]Bullet Heaven Fandom[/url] curator page.

Vexed Heroes is a fun top down bird's eyes shooter with cute graphics and unlimited re-playability. There are many ways too build your selected hero through the vast different permanent stat boost and in-round skills chosen on level ups. Great game, looking forward too future projects from this creator.

For its price this is a fun, charming and solid survivor game. The gameplay is enjoyable with enough skills and passives to choose from. Interresting addition that all upgrade have a little humor quotes what made you smile or laugh sometimes. The XP gain is not traditional survivor way, as you earn XP by killing enemies like in Diablo, however you need to collect the skull currency. With these skulls you can unlock more characters and get permanent passive upgrades, so the meta progress is presented. After 100+ survivor game I played this was a nice surprise, a little friendly charming cheap game.
Recommended.

A game which very much reminds me of a classic arcade experience. While I have only played it with mouse and keyboard, it feels like it would be quite comfortable with a controller.

The runs are not too long at ~30 minutes or shorter if you are "better" at the game. The variety of game mechanics during playtime is refreshing. I personally enjoy switching between various weapons and just winging it, or rerolling all my gems to upgrade the bow as high as possible and abusing it to focus completely on bosses when they spawn.

The way an upgrade always comes with a downgrade at the same time, makes it quite interesting to think about your current build, and gives you the chance to choose up-&downgrades that fit your playstyle best.

While it isn't in early access, I am happy that the developer seems intent to keep working on the game, and I am looking forward to the unlockables and features that will be added in the future.

The game is decent enough, Cool idea but it could have been done better. There are almost no synergies, would like to see an overhaul of the games upgrade system but that might be too much work.
 
Hope to see more from the dev

Hate Me Not is a surprisingly fun game from a new indie developer. It features roguelite elements and plenty of charm. The visuals are simple but captivating, and the audio fits perfectly without ever feeling out of place. The gameplay mechanics are satisfying and offer a good challenge. I really enjoyed my time with this game and recommend everyone give it a shot. It's evident that a lot of love went into this project, and it truly deserves more recognition!

There is no option for thumbs neither up or down, so I had to give this game a thumbs up, but with reserve. The graphics of the game are nice, there is no censorship in the game, but no animations either.  The biggest problem is the card battle mechanics. You must win each round of card battle to progress the story. You may want to strategize all you want, the outcome is greatly affected by AI that makes it very hard to win battles, you may have to redo the same battle over and over again before you finally win the round.  You win the round by removing all the points before the end of the battle, you lose if your opponent still has 1 point left.  So your success in this game relies heavily on luck more than strategy.  I believe this game would be more fun (and less frustrating) if it was easier to progress.  Having the scenes animated would be a nice bonus, a better reward for winning the round. Overall, this game deserves a 5/10.

[b]"From corporate slave to sex slave in an isekai world with hot fantasy girls, improvements!!!"[/b]

[h1] Review [/h1]
An interesting mix between a deckbuilding game with the basic elements of rock-paper-scissors, in which the classic isekai story is presented, the MC is transported from him office to a alternative world where he is almost a god since he can give life force to all the girls he has sex with him and receive a creampie.

The story, due to its simplicity, remains in the background and is limited to narrate the adventures of Mc through various areas in which he meets the 4 different girls, as for the gameplay is a deckbuilding game in which you assemble your deck of 15 cards to fight against the girls before a sexual event, These fights are divided into phases attack and defense in which you have to play cards of different colors of the attacker and defender to do damage, a bit similar to rock paper scissors as there are only three colors available, and in case of being the same color damage is nullified parry style.
The first is interesting but unfortunately that's where all the gameplay is, the same cards that are at the beginning are the same at the end there is no possibility of unlocking new ones as you advance in the story, the only way to improve your deck is to upgrade the cards you already have, as this will make them do more damage or recover more health, but this aspect also has a flaw because to upgrade the cards you need two copies of the same quality to make one of higher quality, but these can only be purchased in the store at a price of 1000 coins, and another 1000 coins to refresh the store to buy another copy, in addition to the price of upgrading the cards, making a very slow system to level up and that requires a lot of grinding because the victories give you very few resources as 2000 coins or 3500 in the last levels.

As for the visual aspect the game is nice the background design is good and the female characters are varied and quite lewd, plus they have very professional Japanese voice acting that gives them a personality very consistent with its design.

üîû[b]sexual content[/b]
Undoubtedly the most detailed and highest quality aspect of the game, there are a total of 4 heroines to have sex with and each of them has 4 sexual scenes, these are with image sequences (CG) in which they have changes of clothes and expressions to represent well the sexual act, these are accompanied by their appropriate voice acting very professional with his touch lewd that help to put very well the environment for manual labor, as the moans that emit are quite exciting, in terms of fetishes there is no great variety as most are vanilla sex scenes with some services as; blowjobs, footjobs, paizuris, etc.
The game has its own gallery where you can watch the complete scenes or just the CG.

üí≠[b]Conclusion[/b]
A game with a gameplay that promised a lot with its style of gameplay but was overshadowed due to the lack of progression and how slow and tedious it is to level up the cards, some of these aspects can be improved by simply increasing the amount of rewards by x5, Also fix some cards because a lot of 3 star and 4 star cards have the same damage values making it absurd to level them up, even so the sexual content is worthy of recommendation, as it is quite pleasing to have such good voice acting and good art, so on offer is worth buying it to add it to your nightly library and enjoy those 16 good sex scenes.
