An Isekai Adventure with Mixed Gameplay! „ÉΩ(¬¥‚Ä¢ œâ ‚Ä¢`)„ÄÅ

[h1][b][1] Intro : [/b][/h1]
Bareback Reincarnation: It's Just That Easy to Brave a Different World is a game that throws players into a fantasy realm as a corporate slave turned traveler with unique powers. Developed by Ex-Erotia and published by BokiBoki Games, this title offers a combination of card battles and narrative exploration. The premise follows the protagonist's sudden transportation to an Isekai during overtime work, where he discovers his extraordinary abilities tied to "magical essence" and skill enhancement for female characters, all without causing pregnancy.

[h1][b][2] Game Experience : [/b][/h1]

The game's unique concept brings both positive and negative aspects to the forefront. On the positive side, the audio and video quality are commendable, creating an immersive experience. The interspersed card gameplay provides an extra layer of engagement and strategy, adding playability. The character design and charm of the four female characters are also highlighted, each with their distinct personalities and backgrounds. The narrative introduces Meili, Kalia, Freya, and Farr, each with their own unique attributes, adding depth to the adventure.

However, the game's gameplay mechanics have received mixed feedback from players. Some users have expressed frustration with the high luck factor in combat, making battles feel inconsistent. Additionally, the pacing of the game, especially the slow action in battles, has led to complaints about the time it takes to complete each round. The gold coin farming aspect of the game has been criticized for being tiring, affecting the overall enjoyment. While the concept of utilizing the protagonist's unique abilities is intriguing, the execution has led to gameplay difficulties for some players.

In terms of progression, the game seems to offer a reasonable playtime of around 3 hours. The initial stages are manageable, but feedback suggests that the difficulty spikes as the game progresses, posing challenges for players who may not be well-versed in such mechanics. Despite this, there is an acknowledgment that the game has potential for those who enjoy strategic and challenging gameplay. Some users appreciate the complexity and find it suitable for shrewd players with a knack for mastering game mechanics.

[h1][b][3] Verdict : [/b][/h1]
In conclusion, Bareback Reincarnation presents an Isekai adventure with a unique twist, blending card battles with a fantasy narrative. The game's strong points lie in its character design, audio-visual quality, and the intriguing abilities of the protagonist. However, the gameplay experiences some setbacks due to its luck-based combat, slow pacing, and potential grinding aspects. While the game offers an engaging experience for those who appreciate intricate mechanics, it might not be the ideal choice for players seeking a more casual and streamlined gameplay experience.

SUMMERHOUSE is a quaint and relaxing little game with an enchanting art style.
Or rather, it's about 80% of a game.

Keeping in mind that it's a one-man project, there are certain glaring things missing from it that I personally would have made sure to add before release.

- The ability to simply click to drag an object to move it is just a strange feature not to include, and makes every action twice the amount of work it should be.

- The available selection of items to decorate with is simply too small most of the time. Some strange choices were made by the designer of which item varieties there are enough of and which not - there are three parasols, but only one (strangely huge) plastic chair and one plastic table to put under them. There are several advertisement signs but only one lamp, and none of them light up at night. Even just different colour varieties of items to pick from would add loads of artistic freedom.

- The UI falls short. There is no scroll bar and scroll sensitivity is low. Items of wildly different sizes show up as the same size in the menu, so you have no idea what you're getting. Items are also highly pixelated in the menu to the point of being unrecognizable at times. Menus will frequently reset to the top half the time, and several times they bugged out completely.

- The textures of placeable items frequently clash with each other's meshes. Certain items that are supposed to be stuck to a wall can not be put at the correct depth to actually stick to the wall, either sitting inside or floating in front of it. Side scrolling reveals that the sides of any wall block or roof block are completely untextured.

So after that laundry list of problems, do I recommend the game?

Yes. It's gorgeous and meditative. It's an impressive effort for one man to have made. 
Really, my only hope is that the author continues to fix the problems above and add more items/colour options.
With these issues adressed the game would be simply excellent.

This is an extremely cute house building game. One thing however, I did find it a little frustrating if I place down an item then wanting to move it, I'd have to delete the item then go back into the item menu and select it from there. Another thing is I wish we could choose the colour of items. Certain items are one colour in menu (take example the graffiti) then it's a different colour once you place it. The tutorial is also a little lacking. It can be confusing sometimes with the popups. I think there should be a quick tutorial to show how to play the game.

Overall though, I enjoyed playing this game.

So, I bought the game the moment it released, and I think I am going to sink a lot of hours into this game. 
Its a relaxing, creative building simulator. Build your house how you want it and make it however you want!
Think townscaper, but just the house. 
During my playtime I could just feel myself relax to the music and the visuals. Even when I made something that arguably looks bad, It still has its charm in this game.
The only real feedback I would have is to have more blocks to make your house even better. Or give tools to the community so they can create more models on the workshop to be used in the game.
All in all, I can recommend it!

A very relaxing and simple straight-to-the-point sandbox game about just laying back and enjoying that warm, digital breeze while building some houses.
I can't help but love it.

It's not the type of game to keep you engaged for the "long run", instead more like a "fun run".
Sincerely, Summerhouse is best enjoyed in small, few, compact sessions with a hot cup of coffee on a hot summer evening.
Strong recommendation!

Chill.
Basic.
And super relaxing.

A little house/neighborhood builder.
No pressure, no time limits, no mobs coming to wreck what you build.
Just pixelated creativity.

Pick your map, and build your dream house or farm or row of shops.

It is basic- don't expect a million choices like massive city builders might have. But see what you can create with what is there, and what new blocks and character you can unlock to use.

[b][u]***Accessibility***[/u][/b]
Well, it can be played with one hand. So there is that.

No text or UI scaling.

No color-blindness settings, which could be an issue for people with certain forms of color-blindness. You will have to rely on your computer's system settings for color-blindness settings to adjust things.

The art may be difficult for some people with low vision to be able to easily tell the difference between different blocks or decorative items- even with pixelization toggled off.

There is no voice acting, other than the developer giving a very short "Hi!" at the beginning of the game, right after launching. Nothing that affects game-play. Should be very playable for Deaf or HoH players.

Controls are a tad awkward and not intuitive, can be a little confusing at times.
**************************************************************************************************

All that said, the game is by a solo dev, and is very new.
It runs well on my older desktop (i9 9900K/2070 RTX Super/ 16 GB DDR4 RAM/ Windows 10), but I wouldn't count on it running well on an absolute toaster (see the required system specs on the store page).

There are some guides being published for the game, some are helpful, some not so much (true for any game on Steam).

Very casual and chill creative art experience for killing time and just relaxing. I see a user-defined "city-builder" tag some gamers have applied, but it really isn't that. It is a creativity thing, not a "build and manage a city" thing.
Don't expect an AAA studio game experience, expect a cute, casual, chill indie game experience, and enjoy it for what it is. 

Definitely recommended for folks who just want something creative to relax with after a long day.
Full price is worth it, on sale, snag it right away.

It's nice for about an hour or two, but I begin to get stressed in builder-games with no goal when I start running out of block types to use. I really, really, really wish the game had more block types than it has now.
Relaxing game to pass the time with when you're feeling a bit down. Definitely worth the price - support indie developers!

SUMMERHOUSE is an Incredibly calm and relaxing game. It's open-ended design allows for a lot of creativity. Although there are a couple limitations in the game, they end up furthering the player's creativity by forcing the player to think outside the box and come up with new strategies for building their summer house. The game has beautiful graphics and a pretty nice option to change them if you aren't particularly fond of the pixelized style.

Although the game could benefit from some improvements to the UI, better explained controls, and having other controls explained at all. The ability to disable the UI by pressing 'H' now has a pop-up, which alleviates some of my problems with the UI, but there are still improvements to be made.

Overall, this game is a nice, relaxing experience that I am sure I'll return to at later dates to get a fix of that cozy juice. The first update gives me hope that we will see the issues I brought up addressed fully with time, but nevertheless this game is an immediate recommendation.

very pretty and relaxing! love the animation & visuals and it's very easy to play. 
however there are some suggestions :
- it'd be better if we can hide the tool bar so we can take a screenshot without the toolbar appears
- a scroll pad to make it easier to find an asset on search menu
- all the neon signs and lamp post also glow in night

This game is very good. I love the music and the art style, but there is only one thing i worry, dear devs please don't add content with micro transaction to purchase specific items like SIMS. 

Overall this game is TOO good, it's such a vibe for people who have stressful jobs and busy days, you can honestly unwind yourself and enjoy your time with this game. 

I love this game, I've played Elden Ring for too long.

Beautiful and soothing, tiny city builder; a very enjoyable game that lets you build anything you want in a variety of environments.

Combining different objects might unlock a new variation of one of the objects used. You can change the weather or time to see your creations in a different light. While there are no limits to what you can build, you still might run out of ideas as there aren't that many things to build with, so hopefully more will be added in the future. It would also be nice to see some different environments to build in or more weather options.

Overall, I consider this a perfect game to unwind and be creative with when you just want a break from stress, so I definitely recommend it.

[i]SUMMERHOUSE[/i] is a creative pixel game where you build small-scaled lived-in buildings without restrictions or limits to your creativity. 

[h3]Game-play, Graphics & Features[/h3]

As an artist, first and foremost games in this genre tickle my fancy. In [i]SUMMERHOUSE[/i] you craft small-sale lived-in houses, cafe‚Äôs or stores without restrictions or limits. Choose from four main environments; a lake, the city, the desert or a grassy scene. The game also has some secrets to uncover as you play and pair certain items together. 

If you're stuck on getting certain achievements or unlocking secret items browse the community guides, there are some very helpful ones to guide you! 

You can build whatever you can imagine in this game. Place objects anywhere you wish and change the depth of them to make them come forward (like 3D) or recede so parts are behind others. You can change the weather to suit the mood you're in, whether it is a moon-lit night, a sunny afternoon or a rainy day. Plant trees, grass, flowers and place rocks. There is some wildlife and insects such as butterflies, birds, a cat and even a ghost. 

There are lots of save slots (20) so you can do lots of different creative designs and not feel like you're running out of room. 

I do hope they put out some dlc in the future or add mod support for more content to allow us to build even more things or have more variety. Content such as animal packs or more lighting options. But what is included is a good selection to start with. 

My first design‚Ä¶but check out the Steam community or subreddit on Reddit for some truly epic builds. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3234826340

[h3]Overall Experience[/h3]

This game is truly relaxing and enjoyable to play. No restrictions, pure creativity and beauty. A wholesome game for everyone to enjoy at a great price with very high re-playability. üé®

[quote]Please follow our curator page, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/4680120/]Otome Lovers[/url], if you'd like to see more reviews like this one! [/quote]
Great game! It would be even better if the lamp can actually light up at night and sometimes there is bug when controlling the depth. Hope more elements will be added into this game!

It's decent, great idea, and every item has been polished. But I would say it doesn't give you a lot of creative freedom, such as being able to change the colours or having more options for lighting during night time. What you basically get as what you can access in the demo. Play the demo, and it you find yourself getting bored, I'd hold off until it is updated more.

TL:DR Beautiful aesthetic and great concept but the user interface (UI) needs a bit more work.
I played with a mouse and keyboard - not sure if it is better on a controller.

I found the UI a little frustrating - from the fact that you can only build in a line or straight up (even though blocks seem to be 3D) to the really counter-intuitive and laborious way of finding the blocks you need (you have to scroll through the whole list each time and it doesn't remember where you last were - so you can't easily get the next block in the series). This game could be absolutely wonderful with just a little more work and testing. 

I'm also confused why some blocks like doorways seem to be only place-able slightly in front of other assets, but not in them - e.g. grated doors that show the background through the gaps until you put a wall behind it- where then it just shows bricks instead of being a doorway in the wall; or graffiti only being visible on some parts of a rock formation but not on others.

I can see how this could be relaxing and I found the new blocks popping up delightful (if again feeling a bit random on what pops up and what doesn't). However, for me the UI issues were a bit of a deal-breaker as they caused stress and frustration.

I do hope the creator keeps working on it and fixing some of the bugs at least - I look forward to seeing how this evolves (if it does)

The way it is now though, I don't think I can recommend it. I hope that changes!

This was a game I was so excited to try when I first saw it previewed.  I think this is more of a creative exercise than a game, in that there are no goals - simply a blank canvas and building blocks to play with to create a cute scene.  It's so very intuitive and I think ANYONE could get in this and make a really nice looking scene easily, that's how well done this is.

I've spent an hour and a half just playing around, with no real goal - just placing blocks and seeing what the end result was.  I even built one scene entirely by hitting the "random" button and placing whatever piece it gave me.  The end result was always pleasing to look at and fun to put together.  It was also really fun to discover new "character" blocks by placing certainly blocks together.  

The art is gorgeous, colorful and a joy to look at.  I think if you are someone who enjoys being creative OR you're someone who likes to have something to mess around with while you do other things (talk on the phone, listen to something, etc) this is going to be a hit with you.  It doesn't have to be a time sink if you're looking for something short to do, or if you want to spend literal hours with this, you absolutely could.

I encountered no bugs, no issues and the game is solidly well made.  My only wish is that it will get an update or DLC with new environments and building blocks.
Lovely little game, I'd love to see an update where we can adjust the color and size of the objects! Keep up the good work Friedemann :D

More of a sandbox builder than a traditional "game", SUMMERHOUSE is perfect for winding down & relaxing. Other than the achievements for unlocking specific building elements, there is no objective to the game - you simply build to your hearts content. While I would like more variety in items to build with & perhaps environments, at the price point of $5 USD I feel like this game offers plenty.

My only complaint with the game is the difficulty navigating the menus to find the exact items I want to use. I am not sure how to make it more efficient but I often found myself looking in the incorrect category for specific items.

For anyone who needs some downtime & a game where they can chill without stress, I would absolutely recommend this one.

[b]update soon with comments on accessibility[/b]

For a game with very little rules, rails, or progression, there's a surprising amount of drive and incentive. Like other creative canvases like Such Art or Minecraft (in Creative move), goals and designs emerge from the simple act of exploration. The simple beauty of the pixel art make the achievement of what you make that much sweeter.

You could close your eyes, randomly click around and the result would still look pretty.
This game makes me feel nostalgia for things I never knew I missed.

- Hello, I really like this game, SUMMERHOUSE. It is impossible to describe how many features are already available at the moment and I really want to help it to promote the game industry. So I really hope it will reach the creator Friedemann. I want to express what is worth adding and fixing in this game. Let's start.


- Adding more

1-More items and locations. 
 Despite the fact that what buildings are created by players at the moment, it would not be enough to increase the stock of items in the various tabs, such as in the tab "Decoration Blocks". I'm not even asking to add a workshop so that players can not only add their save with buildings so still and add their own items and just increase the banal number of items, because for 4.99$ it is a shame. I would like to sprawl in the possibility of building anything. Well, and would also have more terrain and add a tab with people to be able to place them near the houses creating a sense of habitat.

2-The "Control" tab. 
 What is really not in such a cool game is just a tab with "Control" seemingly insignificant tab in the settings, but the newcomer who would like to master the game and immediately know all the "Hot Keys" this button is really not necessary. And that yourself to look in the guides in steam and try to learn the purpose of keys is not pleasant.

3-Reassign keys.
 Speaking a little earlier I talked about the "Control" tab and I would like there to be an opportunity to reassign keys. I really miss this function.
 
4-Add more features.
 I do not know how personally other players, but I would like to be able to change the size of any object / bush / wall and so on. And also to mirror them not only horizontally but also vertically, as it will be more convenient UwU. Well and it would be desirable to increase the number of layers. Oh and one more detail, I would very much like to reduce the picture so that the whole location was on one screen. It's just inconvenient that you need to take 3-4 screenshots of the whole location.


- Bug fixes
 This will be a short section, I just want to point out that I found only one bug and that is that the panels in the "Nature blocks" and "Walls blocks" tabs are shifted to the right. Because of which I can not select the item that I need and have to go to other tabs to make this bug disappear. Well, and probably will find some other bugs.


-End
 At the end of the review I would like to say "ADD WORKSHOP, ADD WORKSHOP, ADD WORKSHOP". But that's about it.



 - MineCommand
     (Translated with DeepL.com)

This game is so cute! It's a great game to just sit back, play it, and listen to the music.

The amount of items available is definitely enough to make pretty much anything you want.

If you want a game to just relax and build some houses, get it!

Alright Friedemann, have your big chai latte; I made an ugly house!

Edit: In all seriousness, this game lacks some basic QOL features.  Can the key bindings be shown/edited?  Can esc close the current window instead of bringing up the menu screen?  If you disable the "pixelation" option, can this be reflected in the build windows as well?

This will be appreciated once you're done with your large chai latte, Friedemann.

Great and relaxing game, there could be many more features to make the game more cozy tho.

Incredible game and the sound design is on point too. I would love to see some more lighting options like lamps and other decorative lights in the future. I would greatly recommend playing it if you like cozy but also creative no-pressure games.

Personally I think the game has a good premise and I really love the game, but it comes with a major flaw that I can't seem to work around. And that is that the game has very little options for how to build the different buildings. I think that if they had just added a feature like controlable length and height to roofs and walls, and maybe ability to change texture and colour, it would be amazing for the game. 

So at the moment I wouldn't recommend this game to people, but if it did get an update with new stuff and more variation I could definitely recommend it to someone.

This is such a cute game that is littered with problems. I REALLY wanted to enjoy it but the game makes it so hard.

Why do NONE of the pieces line up? You basically need to make the houses like the ones in the promotional images or cover up every single join with other bits and pieces. Did you think there would be a stone walled roof that matches the brick pattern you used for the walls? Because there isn't. Did you think the smaller wooden walls would match the pattern of the bigger walls you used for the base? Because they don't. 

There are also only a handful of pieces you can use to build. It's so limiting to have a single wooden roof, and that wooden roof doesn't match the wooden walls. It needs to be completely covered in signs and other bits to make it look at all neat. 

WHYYYYY does scrolling take SO long? It would have been simple to just make it faster but it's painful trying to scroll down the menus to do anything. Especially if you want to swap back and forth between things further down the menus. 

The trailer also seems a little disingenuous, although probably not intentionally. "You can build houses in a variety of levels, such as the sea, the mountains, the city, or the desert." Yeah you listed the only 4 locations. It really makes it sound like there are more than those 4. 

I hope this doesn't discourage the dev from making more games, It seems like they really liked this game. But it feels more like they built a game for themselves.

Summerhouse is a relaxing building program with a limited selection of building blocks, many of which have to be unlocked by placing the right combinations of blocks next to each other.
It is a very soothing experience, and you can create some really nice-looking buildings with it.
It's not a game with goals and does not pretend to be one. It does accomplish exactly what it set out to do.

Exactly as it's described. There is no real gameplay or goals, just make cute houses and buildings. If you go into it with these expectations, you'll really enjoy it! If you're expecting something more complex, it's not for you. The price is reasonable given the work put in.

All y'all creative, imaginative, and/or relaxing folks: SUMMERHOUSE will be a nice little addition to your steam library. I hope more content is added!
I got gut-punched by pure vibes for the price of a coffee. I can't imagine a better deal for a game, absolutely recommended.

Great calming experience. So tranquil. Loved the view, the music, most of all I loved the sounds of buttons and clicks, soooo satisfying. I wish I could export images/gifs without UI to set as my wallpaper
A simple, cute, and utterly charming sandbox game. Its very easy to just zone out and build and would recommend to anyone who like very chill and simplistic builder games.

Positives:
- Low cost.
- Nice art style.
- Unlocking the new objects was quite fun.

Negatives:
- Controls are really bad - to find something to place you can either right-click a dozen times to get to it (and you will probably overclick and need to go round again).
- UI is really hard to use - the objects are stored in thrown together menus that scrolls painfully slow.
- No further customisation tools like the ability to recolour.
- No convenience tools that would be expected, like the ability to move something that has been placed.
- Unlocking new objects has bugs that meant I had to spam objects to trigger them to be unlocked.

It lacks a lot of content, which isn't terrible for a low cost game, but it isn't relaxing to play because the controls are horrendous. The art is generally quite nice, but the UI, controls, gameplay, are really badly designed.

Very Summer. Very House. Very fun. 

I've spent a few hours enjoying this and crafting the most of what I can with what's given! It's a beautiful game and I would gladly pay for DLC with additional content or play the game to earn more. It's a great game!

This is not a completed game and is full of bugs! I got enough money to purchase all fishing spots (which seems to be endgame) from accidentally claiming the reward for a daily quest over and over (I thought it was stuck, but it gave me money for each click). Most of my playtime comes from when I launched the game and went to do chores. It's a very cheap game, but unfortunately I can't recommend buying in its current state.

That being said, if some more effort was put in to finish development, flesh out the NPC scripts and perhaps create more innovative game-play than just mashing F for battles and pressing F to time catches (with no variation on timings currently), this could be a great game. I adore the cat and fox, and the general art style. To the dev: please keep working on this game!

[h1]I'TS VACATION TIME AT PINECREEK HILLS NATIONAL PARK AGAIN![/h1]
Vacation Adventures games have become a cult classic over the years. There's just something about these games that keeps us fans, game after game. I've always said that playing a new Vacation Adventures: Park Ranger game is like putting on your favorite sweater every year; it always puts a smile on your face.

You can play in Casual Mode (untimed-faster hint recharge), Challenge Mode (timed-normal hint recharge), or Extreme (timed mode, all wildlife & recyclables must be found) FYI: In Extreme Mode, there are 30 Items to find versus 18. There are 21 Achievements to earn for completing various tasks such as finding Wildlife, buying souvenirs, or finishing a mini-game quickly. You can purchase Park Souvenirs with the points earned and store them in a Display Room.

Each scene has several Wildlife Animals to find that are shown as silhouettes in a box to the left of the word search bar, and when all the animals have been spotted, the doors will close. There is a Wildlife Notebook that allows you to see illustrations of all the wildlife you have found.¬†

You will also Recycle cans, bottles, corrugated boxes, and paper found in each scene, and when all recyclables have been found, the recycle Can icon will be displayed as full. Some of the trash items are located within Zoom Zones as well.

There are 16 Photo Op scenes that allow you to take a photo for your Album whenever you see the Camera Icon, so don't forget to keep an eagle eye out for those Photo Ops.

You will earn an Eagle Eye achievement if you don't use either the Hint Magnifying Glass, which shows the location of a single random item, or the Mega Hint feature, which shows the location of all available items from the list. You'll earn a Bronze Star for completing the Search, a Silver Star if you find all Wildlife OR all Recyclable Items, and a Gold Star if you find all Wildlife AND all Recyclable items. (Extreme mode requires you to find all recyclable items & wildlife.)

Words listed in Blue are Tasks that require an interaction of some type, and words in Red are hidden inside or behind things. Most of the scenes have at least one Zoom Zone (indicated by sparkling stars) that has hidden items and sometimes includes Recyclables or Wildlife. Levels can be replayed to better your time/score (timer counts up, not down) or pick up missing recyclable items or wildlife, and the items to find are different each time you replay it.

After each Search Scene, you'll play a Mini-Game such as Placing Map Shapes, Spot The Difference, Word Search, or several different types of Jigsaw Puzzles (Rotate Squares, Swap Tile Sections, Flipsaw, Slider Puzzles, etc.)

[b]Collector's Edition Extras:[/b]
30 Main Levels +8 CE Levels, 18 Wallpapers, 20 Music Soundtracks w/player (that familiar Vacation Adventures soundtrack is called Bluewaters Heaven btw) 21 Achievements, 16 Photo Op Screenshots (available in Photo Album) 16 Gift Shop Souvenirs with Display Case, 126 Wildlife Critters to find (available in a Photo Album) 48 Replayable Mini-Games.

Check out my Group/Curator page¬† at¬†https://steamcommunity.com/groups/thewoodsforum
and don't forget to stop by my nature-themed chat forum at¬†https://thewoodsforum.boards.net/
Love these games. Lovely scenery, sometimes repetitive and can be a bit unreal, but they keep my interest.

 Small Kingdoms Prologue was ok but felt very simple to me, like a casual beer and pretzel strategy game. It was nice also that they gave us some achievo's to chase without annoying grind to unlock.

 The gameplay loop wasn't that bad, build up a city, build some troops for defense and more troops to fill your armies to attack. But it felt clunky and seriously lacked any real strategy and that was very bad for a game like this calling itself a Strategic Simulation video game.

 If the full release version does not fix this issue then I do not recommend this game. I'll be honest, I feel a little bad for leaving a negative review since they gave everyone the prologue for free, but thats not the point of reviews eh.

 You can play the prologue for free for yourself, or watch a youTGube video to see if you disagree with me.
Have fun, cheers
It has easy achievements and good visual appearance, as a negative note I would say that it has poor optimization, these errors should be fixed as it is a prologue.

Sex Story - Cuckold Life - Episode 1 is a visual novel with adult content.

The game offers multiple choices, but if you don't go with what the developer had in mind, the main female character just does whatever she wants and uses 'I want to do it that way, cuck,' as an excuse quite literally. With this in mind it makes the entire game just a snooze-fest of text. The game has no animations whatsoever, the models are quite good, but gosh the poses are terrible. Also the whole plot is just bizarre, characters are taking this way too casually, some of the plot progresses way too fast, there is yet again transition to pictures of the male character 'finishing' about 20 paragraphs or so before it actually happens in the story... you get the idea.

To crown things off, the game has no settings. The text is painfully slow (and the animation used to write it on screen is aggravating to look at,) the back button backs entire sections of the story and to top it all off, the last achievement took TWO ENTIRE RUNS + 5 MINUTES OF SPAMMING AND ALT-TABBING TO UNLOCK. Way to make a disappointing game even more frustrating.

Overall, the story has/had potential, but this first iteration is not it. Poorly coded.

So I've been married along time.. like A LOT of years, and if you're in prison... I mean married like me you know how frustrating it can be.. The Wife always has a headache, the kids are little demons running around, acting like animals, breaking your stuff and always requiring more and more money.. You can do like the Turpin's, break out some chains, restrict their eating and only give out the very minimal amounts of love and caring..  Although I wouldn't recommend it as they were sentenced to 25 years to life.. OH BOY!!!!  Anyway, as a married couple sometimes things get a little slow in the bedroom.. Sometimes need to be like Owen Hart and say "enough is enough it's time for a fall!!!!"... wait that wasn't right.. Too Soon?  Anyway, being dead kind of sucks or so I've been told by the dead people who visit me at night and watch me pound the pud..  You know how hard it is to punch the one eyed clown, while you have an undead guy with half his head missing bemoaning how the afterlife sucks and he can't get tail anymore..  I'll let you know it's not easy...  So occasionally you have to find things to do to spark up the love life,, You can try dressing up, or buying a new car, or trying your hand at finding the next Julia Roberts (not the one in real life, but the one from Pretty Woman that somehow nabs the wealthy stockbroker, you know a lady of the night)  or you can try what my buddy tells me is the new yellow.. being a Cuckold..  If you can get over the thought of another guy pillaging your woman's poop deck,  it just might be the best medicine for a sorry love life.. I mean it worked for that dude who Let Dennis Rodman plow his wife, while he spent time chilling in the Worms mansion, watching his TV and crying in the closet while he choked the chicken..

The Story - 

Anyway, sad story aside, it brings me what you're all here for the main event,, the whole enchilada.. Sex Story - Cuckold life Ep 1..  The Story is what you'd expect from a game called Cuckold Life, it's the story of a married couple..  Adam and Nikki. Adam comes home early from a work trip he surprises Nikki.. After a few pointless scenes and text she decides to let her Boss give her the old Meat Rocket as a way of putting spice in their love life..  The game goes about how you'd expect from 2.99 cent visual novel.. Completely devoid of anything worth while.. and the translations are kinda lackluster..

Gameplay - 

Press the Space bar and read the REALLY slow moving text. Make some choices which have absolutely zero effect on the game..  Want your wife to wear black panties.. LOL.. no way bro she's going with Red..  If you can't figure out how to play this game in 2023, then I'm pretty certain you'd have some issues with staying alive if your body didn't' automate your breathing.. 

Pro's - 
Easy achievements
Counts toward the +1
Bewbs???

Con's - 
Broken achievement...  The one for finishing the story is broken, it took me a while to unlock it after playing through like 18 times, then it randomly unlocked in the middle of my fifth play through
no speed text or options at all
no animations (for 2.99 can't complain too much I guess) 
Weirdly worded text, probably translation issues.
Choices mean nothing....

Recommendation - 
The game has a few pros..  for starters the easy achievements..  play five minutes and finish the story (finish the story seems to be semi broken), the lack of options ANY options, is really frustrating, means sitting through the same boring story numerous times to unlock the finish the story achievement.. The fact that it's really cheap and adds a +1 to your library count is beneficial to game collectors, the fact you can get 100% completed game in under an hour is another benefit to achievement hunters.. If you're looking for a visual novel that is engaging and interesting, this isn't for you, if you're looking for a visual novel that tells a compelling story, this isn't for you.. If you want a +1 to either you're E-peen (game library) or your E-Scrot (Achievements), then by all means buy it.. if you care about any thing else,, just avoid it..  Snooch to the Booch

the lack of features missing from the basic kinetic novel is, to be frank, highly disappointing. It's a timed slideshow that you can't even click through.

Rating: 7/10
I went into this game for some achievements and ended up discovering an interesting game. The story is confusing but you can make it out in details. It's abstract minimalism and the controls are janky but they kind fit the game. Since the game is abstract ,weird and in a way broken,and the levels are presented in this smaller compact way, the controls feel right for this type of game. 
It does well in telling its story ,of escape from reality using summer season as it's backdrop. 
It feels in a way and if you play the game since it's short, you will feel it too that the entire story was centered around escape from troubles of the real world. The story takes a darker turn but in all that ,the character you meet and talk to behind a summer landscape is always there to remind you, everything will be fine and i liked that touch. The game is only 15 minutes long but it does well to portray what it was trying to go and make your mind wonder about the story and maybe piece your tale together. Despite it's flaws it ends up being an interesting experimental ,mind you adventure with abstract themes. Worth playing if you are going into it ,expecting something abstract,experimental and that something that will make you think how the story and the world besides what happens in the game really is and is it any different from our world.

Another fine and interesting title from Lu.
It suffers from the problems of their previous games, since its the same engine. Control Delay, Rough Controls, janky camera movements in 'cutscenes'.
but it also features their unique story telling and engaging art. 
I'd really like to see a FULL title from Lu, a dating sim maybe, or an adventure game with better controls.
Since this game is free, you can play it, and if you like it, you can drop cash on their previous titles which are all very similar.

[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
Mellowollem is for lack of a better way to put it a tech demo.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Game play is extremely primitive. WASD or Arrow keys to move, Z to interact, and Space to advance the conversation. None of these keys can be remapped. You start off in what looks to be a hospital corridor. You can't open any of the doors. When you walk to the far door the scene changes. You see a woman on a beach. You walk up and talk to her, then you have to walk around the map and pick up watermelons, no reason, just pick up watermelons. You bounce back between a room with bunkbeds, the hospital corridor, and areas with the woman. There is no direction, just keep trying to activate things and when you get the right object(s) you advance. There is a hide and seek game where you have to find the woman. There is also a cat, but no explanation of why.

There is a small story you discover along the way.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
This plays like an assignment in a programming class. Create a game where the player picks up objects and plays hide and seek.

Crucial Ballistix Sport AT 2666 MHz DDR4 RAM (16GB x 2)
ASUS GeForce RTX 2080 Overclocked 8G GDDR6

The problem I find here is that the prompts are WAY too repetitive. 

They're great for 1-minute games, but as soon as I pushed it to 2 minutes and further, it just never seemed to get any sort of new material at all. There were moments where we literally did the same actions for the same prompts, so it became almost trivial to stick to one or two decks in the same category without getting incredibly bored. The video game category is so... surface-level with its prompts that it almost feels insulting, but I understand if the casual folks won't get it.

Considering that they're also pushing this on the original phone version (which I did own) at the same price (all decks for $40), I only wonder if they couldn't go lower here due to price parity or they're counting on people who don't know any better to buy in for what appears to be a pretty content-rich party game.

Folks, either buy this for a significantly-reduced price or just don't bother.
Hell, if anyone else can make a better version of this, go right ahead.
I only lucked out getting this for $30 due to its launch sale, and I still feel like it's not worth it at that price.

[h2] If you are looking for a very tough word game and spatial puzzle game then this might be worth checking out but I just found it so difficult that it felt frustrating to me. [/h2]

Quadruzzle is a mixture of Crossword and spatial puzzle game where you are given four clues that each form a word, like in a crossword puzzle, but the letters are all jumbled up on a four by four grid, and you have to move the letters around to complete the word. 

Not only do you need to solve the clue to know what word to find on the grid, but then you have to arrange the letters by moving them around the grid with only one spare space, and this is so difficult. If you don't know the answer to the clue, there is the possibility of working it out from moving random letters around the grid until they change colour, and then you know it is in its correct position. 

Even if you do know the answers, putting them in their correct positions is incredibly hard as you will mess up the position of other words you have set up and it takes a certain kind of brain to be able to move the letters around successfully. 

There is only one puzzle a day, so if you complete that one, you need to wait until the next day to have a go at a new one. The grid shows the least number of moves possible, so you can aim for this if you like. 

[h1]üç≥Conclusionüç≥[/h1]
[quote][h2][b] There's nothing particularly wrong with the game as such. I haven't encountered a word game like this before so points for originality, but due to its incredible difficulty I didn't enjoy it. You will soon find out if you like it or not so do give it a try if you enjoy challenging word games, but it isn't the word part that is difficult, it is moving the letter around the grid that is the challenge. 

I think some of the achievements are a bit silly, relying on you to play on certain days of the year for example. 
[/b][/h2][/quote]

[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32732116-IndieGems/] Follow [b]IndieGems[/b] [/url] for more reviews like this one. [/quote]

This is a fun lil' game that gives your brain a workout. Figure out how to solve the puzzle using clues, discover sorting orders, and use strategy on how to get the letters where you want them to be in an efficient way. I'm a come back and keep playing!

Having sunk a solid 10+ hours into Poly Backrooms, I can confidently say this is one of the most unique and captivating multiplayer games I've played in a long while. At first glance, its cartoonish visuals and playful design might lead you to think it's just another lighthearted game, but it masterfully marries the realms of fun and fear in a way I hadn't thought possible.

Each room, despite looking similar, brings its own set of intriguing challenges and puzzles that range from delightfully simple to devilishly complex. Playing with others only amps up the fun; trying to solve the puzzles cooperatively added another layer of excitement and unpredictability to the mix. One of the standout features for me is that no two playthroughs feel the same, ensuring fresh and new experiences every time you dive in.

A true five star experience, I'll be looking forward to the updates and next levels!

If you're looking to buy a backrooms game, please for the love of god, look for something else, this game is the definition of ASS. Usually these backroom games on steam you can have fun with, either that be playing with friends, having some fun on your first playthrough, and they can be pretty fun to go back and replay/speedrun. But not Poly Backrooms, this game has some of the worst AI I've ever seen in a game, and worst of all, it's so boring and such a slog to play through. I can't even imagine playing this game by yourself, I played with a friend and we still found it super boring.

If you're looking to 100% this game, there's an achievement where you need to beat a level 20 times, and with this game being boring, it's such a slog to do that. Me and my friend could legit only do 1-2 runs a day, after that we'd just quit throughout the next run because we'd get so bored and frustrated out of our minds.

I know this game is in early access, but this game really should've been developed a lot more before releasing it to the public, especially with only three levels, and TWO enemies. I'll give the game this, the first level was pretty fun to play for the first time, but when you enter the second level, the game just goes down hill there, being the most tedious fetch quest set in a maze. And replaying the first level isn't any fun. Also the price of the game should really get cut down, even if it's already somewhat cheap.

If you are considering buying this game, I'd recommend any other backrooms game, me and my friend have played a couple backroom games, and this one is without a doubt the worst one by a landslide (that we've played mind you). There might be worst, but i highly doubt it, this game isn't even laughably bad, it's just plain garbage.

I'm sorry for the devs, but the artstyle of this game is pretty unique and I quite like it. This game really should've had much more put into it before releasing it. If the devs fix up the current levels, add some new levels, make new unique mobs, new objectives and polish the game more, I could really this see game becoming an actually really good backrooms game, but in the state it's in right now, it's far from the truth. 

I really hope to see this game evolve over time so I could come back and update my review, but for now, I'd look elsewhere for a backrooms game.

This is one of the more unique and actually cute Backrooms games I've played! It's fun to play with a group of friends to have some chaos and laughs! I am here for the takes on the Smiler and Bacteria and can't wait for more monsters and levels

In the vast landscape of internet lore, there exists a phenomenon that captures the imagination like no other - the enigmatic and mysterious realm known as the backrooms. A surreal journey through the labyrinthine corridors of this digital underworld reveals a tapestry of intrigue, fear, and fascination. As a self-proclaimed adventurer of the virtual unknown, I find myself irresistibly drawn to the uncanny allure of the backrooms.

The backrooms, a seemingly endless network of interconnected, dilapidated rooms and hallways, have become a digital subculture, with tales of exploration and eerie encounters spreading like wildfire across forums and social media. What is it about this bizarre concept that has ignited the curiosity of so many internet denizens, including myself?

First and foremost, the backrooms tap into the primal human instinct for exploration. The idea of wandering through forgotten, decaying spaces, each room with its own unique atmosphere, beckons to the inner adventurer in all of us. The sense of the unknown, the anticipation of what might be around the next corner, fuels the excitement and adrenaline of the virtual explorer.

The sheer creativity and diversity within the backrooms contribute to their captivating nature. From desolate, flickering fluorescent lights to the unmistakable aroma of aged carpet, the vivid descriptions shared by fellow enthusiasts paint a vivid picture of an otherworldly environment. It's a world where reality blurs with fiction, and every room tells a story of its own.

What sets the backrooms apart is the community's commitment to storytelling and world-building. Through collaborative efforts, contributors weave intricate narratives that expand the lore of this digital universe. Each room becomes a chapter in an ever-growing anthology of the surreal, and the collective creativity gives rise to a sense of shared ownership among its participants.

The backrooms also serve as a canvas for artists and writers to showcase their talents. Striking visual representations, haunting poetry, and gripping short stories emerge, adding layers of depth to an already multifaceted landscape. The creative outpouring within the backrooms community transforms this internet phenomenon into a genuine form of artistic expression.

Moreover, the backrooms function as a space for introspection and self-discovery. The eerie ambiance and the sense of isolation within these virtual halls prompt contemplation on the nature of existence and reality. It's a digital pilgrimage that challenges one's perceptions and invites a deeper understanding of the self.

In my personal journey through the backrooms, I've found solace in the escapism it provides. The ability to immerse oneself in a world divorced from the constraints of reality offers a therapeutic retreat from the stresses of everyday life. It's a testament to the power of the human imagination, capable of constructing entire universes within the confines of a digital construct.

The backrooms, with their haunting aesthetic and rich narrative potential, also serve as a source of inspiration for other creative endeavors. Artists, writers, and even game developers draw upon the essence of the backrooms to craft their own interpretations, contributing to the ever-expanding legacy of this internet subculture.

In conclusion, the backrooms stand as a testament to the boundless creativity and collective spirit of the online community. As a virtual adventurer, I find myself enamored by the mystique and allure of this digital labyrinth. It's a journey into the unknown, a canvas for artistic expression, and a haven for those seeking an escape from the mundane. The backrooms, with their enigmatic charm, continue to captivate the hearts and minds of internet explorers, inviting them to lose themselves in the ever-expanding corridors of imagination. Overall 6/10.

I'd argue that this game is actually for everyone, despite what it may seem.
To enjoy it, you do need to understand how to "play it". It's not a game where you actually do a lot.

The first pitfall is that you can remove mushrooms by clicking them a lot, which isn't what you want to do for a really long time. I recommend to just let them grow and click each one maybe once to see if something funny happens. Also please take in the brief tutorial.

It's like a watch grass grow simulator, so at the start you just get to watch.
The thing that makes me say it can be enjoyed by everyone is that you can just have it running in the background when you do something more interactive and switch back to this game every now and then to check in on your mushrooms.

On its own this game is purely 2 things, a relaxation game and a cute collector game.
The atmosphere is very relaxing, just the noisescape is enough to make me have it on in the background.
Collecting cute mushrooms and trying to make them interact with each other is the fun part.
I do hope that the game gets more content, since I'm almost done collecting all of them.

[b] Review After 100% Achievements [/b]

Woo! I just survived all 15 stages of the battlefield mode to obtain the final achievement needed to complete this game‚Ä¶and I have to say, Lizards Must Die is totally worth the money. There are story-based missions that you complete with your choice of four characters (unless you buy the dlc where there is one more added) and each one has their own unique weapon/move set. Then there is also a battlefield mode where you face waves of lizards and aliens! Movement and attacking can feel a little bit janky at times in crucial moments, but overall, it was a solid experience. It took me a couple deep runs in the battlefield mode for me to finally beat it but it felt awesome to finally complete. Playful and fun story combined with souls-like combat makes for a good time!

If you don't, you are missing out on the reason humans exist. Every single person should play this game. I will fight wars to make sure people can continue playing this game. I have stayed in my room since this came out, which is the day I wrote this, and I haven't talked to anyone except the NPCs in this game. I think this is the next step in human evolution. We will eventually all be plugged into a machine, like in the movie, "The Matrix", where this beautiful masterpiece will be our life. Every day, we will wake up in heaven. Every night, we will go to sleep on the copy-pasted textures on the ground. That soon will be the glorious reality, the reality we are meant to be in. Download this game right now, it should only take you a second, and play it. Enjoy it. Live it.

LIZARDS MUST DIE is an outstanding game that excels in every department, making it a standout title in the gaming industry. With its captivating audio design, top-notch performance, intriguing storyline, diverse array of foes, this game sets a new benchmark for excellence in the gaming world.

Audio Design: One of the game's most impressive features is its audio design. From the immersive soundtrack that seamlessly accompanies you throughout your journey to the lifelike sound effects that enhance the gaming experience, LIZARDS MUST DIE immerses players in a world that feels both dynamic and engaging. The audio design greatly contributes to the game's overall ambiance and emotional impact.

Performance: LIZARDS MUST DIE boasts exceptional performance, ensuring a smooth and enjoyable gaming experience. The developers have optimized the game to run flawlessly on a wide range of hardware configurations, making it accessible to a broad audience without the need for high-end gaming rigs. This optimization allows players to focus on the game's thrilling action without any performance hiccups.

Storyline: The game's storyline is a masterpiece of storytelling. It draws players in with its intricate plot, well-developed characters, and unexpected twists and turns. The narrative is rich in depth, offering players a chance to fully immerse themselves in the game's world and become emotionally invested in the outcome. LIZARDS MUST DIE is a shining example of how video game storytelling can rival that of even the most acclaimed novels and movies.

Variety of Enemies: The game impresses with its wide variety of enemies, each with unique abilities and challenges. From cunning humanoid foes to colossal, terrifying creatures, players will constantly encounter new and exciting challenges that require strategic thinking and adaptability. The diversity of adversaries keeps the gameplay fresh and exhilarating from start to finish.

No Premium Edition or In-Game Store: Unlike many modern games, LIZARDS MUST DIE takes a refreshing approach by not offering premium editions or in-game stores. This means players won't be bombarded with microtransactions or paywalls, allowing them to fully enjoy the game without any distractions or additional costs.

In conclusion, LIZARDS MUST DIE sets a new standard for excellence in gaming. With its captivating audio design, outstanding performance, gripping storyline, diverse range of enemies, and a commitment to a pure gaming experience without premium editions or in-game stores, it outshines even highly anticipated titles like "Starfield." This game is a must-play for all gaming enthusiasts and is sure to leave a lasting impression for years to come.

Game is not for me as I find the experience of playing this game to be a rancid affair--but there is charm here that I don't want to rob anyone going in with if they are looking for a brain rotting experience fighting lizards with friends. It is not however a hidden gem or a game of any quality beyond being a bizarrely successful meme game with nothing else going for it. 

It certainly does what it sets out to do for whatever that is worth, and for a storefront filled with asset flips this at least has carved an identity and weirdly large fanbase through the purity of its slav jank. I can't hate that. If I had friends to play this with I would probably appreciate it a bit more.

I don't recommend it to anyone who is looking for an actual functioning videogame with any amount of stakes.

I especially don't recommend this to anyone looking to play it with a controller--K/M controls are a bit more functional but the complete lack of impact from hits makes the whole lizard killing affair feel like I'm swinging around a wet paper towel. Also you can't rebind keys, at least from what I can tell. 

It is undeniably functional-ish and I am sure the ridiculous amount of positive reviews are in jest, but for me it fails to deliver a satisfyingly meaty monster mashing experience to recommend seriously. A modicum of effort to at least allow some keybinding could make this a bit less insufferable but even for a joke game it boggles the mind with how little effort was put into the game itself.

Not worth the dollar to anyone if they don't have friends willing to damage their brains by playing this with them.
Bretty good. A fun hack and slash. Cool soundtrack and a meme plot. Worth its price.

utter masterpiece

I was partially excited about this because it was from the same think tank of the Dr. Livesey Rom & Death Edition game. Unfortunately this game doesn't quite accomplish the same charm. I will give credit where credit is due, I did myself laughing at the intentional "so bad, it's good" production and jokes, but I was also hoping for a nice little hack and slash game. You do get multiple levels, three playable characters, and several power moves to use. Achievements are easily attainable if you're into that. There's even aliens from outer space.

The game blasts Phonk like nobodies business, but it doesn't have the musical timing that Dr. Livesey had. It's core gameplay isn't that fun either. Reason being is that there's no weight or challenge to the combat. Dr. Livesey had gunplay that matched the feel of the music. I bring up Dr. Livesey because that's an example of a meme game done right. Lizards Must Die is like a bad piece of gum that loses it's flavor way too quickly.

Don't get me wrong, I wanted to love Lizards Must Die, and I'm not averted by some jank, but I just wasn't having fun, and games like this, at bare minimum, should be fun to play. I'm welcome to updating this review if updates fix the game.

Funny little russian meme game made slightly less funny from their govt's recent casual partaking in genocide and journalist killings. Unironically has one of the most fire soundtracks I've heard out of a game in years. Do not buy for the gameplay.

It's loud (but you can adjust the volume), janky, and the 'voice acting' and translations are a crime against humanity. The story is dismal, the strategy is rather non-existent, and it is bad...gloriously bad in the most entertaining way!

It's a small-team passion project, and their love of fun shines in this game (at least the English version...the Russian version may come off quite differently).

There are several maps (Lizard Men and, my favorite, Aliens) and settings, some minimal variation to available powers, and a very linear progression through the various encounters. The soundtrack is also really good!

For the price, and for the bad 80s movie vibe, I truly can suggest it as long as you understand what you're getting and getting into.

Also, for the achievement hunters out there: this one should be easy pickings with a few sessions; I'm at 55% after my first hour of game-play.

You should play lizards must die. It is this really cool souls like game that rivals games such as elden ring and dark souls in quality and lore. The voice acting is perfect, the emotion in the main character and villagers are like no other. The combat is smooth and satisfying as you slay your war through Lizards and their bosses. Like dark souls, the difficulty is hard but rewarding and gives a real sense of accomplishment. The game keeps itself fresh with the option for classes and different moves- from a ground pound that sends enemies staggering, a lightning strike from the sky to even chickens shooting eggs, this game has it all! If you‚Äôre a fan of dark soul games I highly recommend lizards must die.

Despite controversial UNITY engine was used, game didn't exhibit no crashes or errors. 
As for playability, it took me few minutes to adapt the controls and camera POV, but since latest update, it is much better.
Lizards MUST Die is not a typical RPG, also not your everyday normal Action FPS (well, not shooter, more like axe swinger), it is something in between.

You can choose from different types (heroes), each having variety of unique skills / warcries / spells. 

Yet no matter what you chose, the game remains non-forgiving, if you can't embrace the controls, and be very nimble player. 

Cut scenes are mostly funny, and refreshing, but I hope there is a way to skip them (in case I start over) 

I like also the quite subtle message how Lizards / Lizardmen / bipedal snakes are ruthless aggressors and standing together and put a fight, is the key to victory. Everyone is full of ebil Putin narrative, but no one dares to criticize or even consider revealing lizard-like banksters, who control UK, US and also US and love starting global wars for no other reason than pure genocide and money.

This is a great game for flexing your fists on the shameful lizards and foreign herods! I drank Baikal water and shouted ‚ÄúGoyda!‚Äù when I went to do a Slavic ball clamp with Drocheslav! My ancestors are proud of this game!

An enjoyable Match 3 game which I am playing in Relaxed mode (there are 3 modes). There is a story to follow, with easy little puzzles to complete (like putting torn papers back together). The mechanics are smooth and easy, the music and ambient sounds are pleasant and there are power-ups to earn as you go. It is a nice, chill game (the way I am playing) which I recommend.

This was a great purchase !

For the price I have had a solid two hours of fun. I managed to complete the full game across all difficulties without too many problems and it was entertaining throughout. I recommend playing through from the easiest setting and then replaying at a harder difficulty after receiving all of the unlocked units.

Overall a cool little game for passing a few hours, definitely worth a go for the price.

This game isn't bad. Some of the animations are lacking but the game play is fun. The crafting and resource collection is as good as some other survival games I've played. I have enjoyed it so far. There is a surprising amount of content in the game. 

I don't know if they intended some of the animals an Nazis to humorous but I found them to be. The monkeys. LMAO. I found a little dog that follows me around and chases the monkeys up trees. 

It's also somewhat of a horror survival. Night time can be quite fun.

Graphics are decent. With some really good visual effects from the environment. 

It's worth the price of .99 cents lol. 

I think I enjoy it better than Elden Ring.

How is this less than $1?

The controls are fluid, the game-play has been glitch free, the graphics are decent enough, and the story is more than acceptable.

What surprises me is the content. This is a well thought-out game with plenty to do and a surprisingly large amount of content, maps, and villains. There is weapons crafting and upgrades, base-building, resource collection, and open world exploration. There are mutants, monsters, and Nazis to kill, and let's be honest; who doesn't love curb-stomping Nazi twatwaffles?

On a completely trivial note, it kind of reminds me (in a good way) of the 1977 Nazi-zombie film Shock Waves.

Anyway, check it out-it's more than worth the cost!

Later in the runs you'll be flying around with an array of movement abilities, swapping between multiple powerful weapons.

My only caveat is that the movement and gunplay doesn't feel quite as tight as some of the best arena shooters (at the time of this review), however it more than makes up for that for me by being a great roguelite which I haven't seen enough of in these types of games.

Along with the awesome in-run upgrades, there's both standard purchasable metaprogression and metaprogression through little quests that can be completed during the waves, which is neat and different. I look forward to playing more!

[h1]Translation team thoughts and thanks with screenshots in Sinical Network[/h1]
https://www.sinicalanimenetwork.com/post/vampires-melody-2-translation-team-thoughts-and-thanks

I recently received a beta key of this game for free from MyLifeForOliveira as a translator and beta-tester for this game.

[i]AsicxArt[/i] has returned to Steam after a 3-year hiatus to release a sequel to its previous game with [i]Vampires' Melody 2[/i]. It continues the story of the vampire couple Raylan Monroe and Yella Lester following one of the endings in [i]Vampires' Melody[/i] in which they have been banished to a deserted island for failing a routine ID check. Raylan and Yella will have to learn to survive in a hostile new environment, and come to terms with the new reality after waking up from their slumber for 300 years.

As with [i]AsicxArt's[/i] earlier titles, [i]Vampires' Melody 2[/i] retains many of the charm and highlights from its earlier releases by featuring cute well drawn artwork and having great musical compositions for its accompanying background music. The art will look very nice on any visual novel fan's Steam profile. In addition, this title features fun, casual minigames that add some interactivity and make the player feel invested in the game and characters without being too difficult.

In terms of plot, [i]Vampires' Melody 2[/i] retains many of the cute, comical moments, and fan service as Raylan and Yella work together to survive in an island adventure with a comedy, fantasy, science fiction and mystery narrative. Some players may not like the fan service and romance tropes with a female vampire domineering over a cowardly male protagonist, although I still think the way the script is handled came off as very funny, and the scriptwriter has also given the protagonist several chances to save the day over a vastly more powerful supernatural being which saw me rooting for the protagonist despite his inherently weak and cowardly nature. Many of the scenes are also brought out very well by the excellent voice acting and artwork. They help to lend immersion into the game, bringing out the tense moments during minigame challenges. There are numerous references to events in the prequel, so it is recommended to finish the earlier game first before starting on this one.

Lastly, I would also like to share that I handled the English translation for this game.  As a long-time fan of [i]AsicxArt[/i], I was motivated to work on this project after following feedback from my friends in Steam, members of my Steam group (Visual novel, JRPG, Anime), and fans of [i]AsicxArt[/i] over a weakness in [i]AsicxArt[/i] and [i]SakuraGame's[/i] earlier games. The game's excellent production quality and feedback from fans of [i]AsicxArt[/i], together with support by [i]SakuraGame[/i] and my friends in Steam helped to build up the sense of pride and excitement to bring a cute and interesting comedy to an English audience. I hope the English translation for this game is an improvement over their earlier titles that will not disappoint fans' confidence in the games by [i]AsicxArt[/i], and would like to thank all the fans for their patience and support all this while.

Thank you to all my friends and family members who have supported me, and to [i]SakuraGame[/i] for giving me the wonderful opportunity to work on the English subtitles for the game before release. It was a pleasure to work on this project and we hope you will enjoy reading this cute, funny story, along with the cheery upbeat opening theme song [i]Seaside Melody[/i] by idol group [i]Luce Twinkle Wink‚òÜ[/i] to lighten your day.

Oh god, I liked the first game.

Unfortunately the dev has no Idea how to get this story going on a deserted island setting and made a Hatchet-like narrative going on, albeit poorly executed. Dev added in some flimsy minigames to mask the lack of plot happening but man is it still too much busywork to go through. I was 2 and a half hours in of hopefully getting into some kind of conflict did I then realize that I was already halfway through the game. Oh, well there was some mystery going on I guess which tried to grab my interest but it gets cancelled out since there is also some swoon-y and cringe romance tedium.

Funny they introduced some characters late game but at this point I wanted it to end. I guess this makes an ok lengthy fandisc but man is this not it for a sequel. Let alone being as much as the same length as the first game!

I really wanted to give this a positive review but it's kind of hard. I even waited until I played the whole game and went through every part of the flowchart and got all the achievements to make sure I wasn't missing anything.

In short, it's not really worth it. The story is mostly filler or over-extended, only the very beginning and the very end has any meaning at all, most of the things that happened in the middle could've been shortened, or made to be a whole lot more interesting. And by the end of the story[spoiler]they are placed in a situation very similar to the one they were in the previous game.[/spoiler]

Choices do not matter, this is a static visual novel through and through, there's only one choice that only change a few dialogues in two or three different places but has no bigger meaning to the story, it just serves to connect this game to the previous one. And the "alternative endings" are just "you died" screens from failing a few very specific mini-games. And speaking of..

The mini-games add nothing and, imo, only take away from the experience. They are way too easy, you cannot fail most of them (game just lets you repeat it until you do what it wants you to), and they are really really simple, they are more akin to quick time events than mini-games. In my opinion, if you're going to add mini-games, you should add actual mini-games and, other than maybe the very first time, don't force them onto the player. There's a few visual novels that did this well, having mini games about table tennis (ping-pong), pool, bowling, air hockey, card games, etc. Also having achievements related to failing those mini-games 3 times brings nothing but extra frustration to the player, even more so if you ignored achievements until you completed the game once, which just makes it worse because the fast forward/skip function in this game is really really slow.

The art style is, generally speaking, good, but I feel like they over-sexualized Yella for no good reason. Maybe I'm just misremembering but the previous game was nothing like that, and neither was any of their other games released so far. I bought and played pretty much every AsicxArt game because they were cute and heartwarming, with a (mostly) lightweight story.

All in all I don't like, and I feel like I just wasted my time playing this VN. It's not [i]bad[/i], but it's not good either. If you're planning on buying this I'd recommending waiting for a sale.

It's a letdown from the first one which was great. This one has a pretty bland story, very few choices, no real alternate routes. Way too many goats. The art is still good and music is decent. I wouldn't really say it's bad but it's not good either, when you consider how many better VNs there are to spend precious time on.

Just when you thought AsicxArt stopped making VN's, out of no where they come with Vampires' Melody 2!
Let me be honest, I'm very biased here, because I'm still waiting/hoping for Fluffy Store 2.
And I'll be honest to say that I think Vampires Melody 2 is not as good as the first one.

The story is so-so. You are stranded with Yella on an island, and you need to survive the elements and aggressive goats. While there are some funny moments, it wasn't very interesting. It started to get interesting with the caves and stuff, but it doesn't go very deep.
The biggest issue I had is with Yella's behavior. I mean, she was't very nice in the first game, but now she is outright abusive. Every time she doesn't like what Raylan says she kicks him, verbally abuses him and even threatens his life. And there is nothing Raylan can do, because his life was given to him by Yella and can be as easily taken away. A classic example of a toxic and asymmetrical relationship.
The ending was kind of good on its own -the story gains pace and I liked the drawings and bits of prose-, but when putting it in the bigger picture, it's very strange. Why does Yella suddenly become so mellow?? I wish she was like that in the whole novel. The pace is also so high that it feels rushed, and things don't make much sense anymore.

The only real reasons to buy Vampires' Melody 2 is the artwork, steam achievements, maybe the music. Also, you can switch between English, Japanese, and Chinese, which is nice for reading practice. Just don't expect too much from the story.

so, Fluffy Store 2, when??

I'll be giving this game a thumbs up for now, however, It is really awesome, in my first 15 minutes, But things that I'd want in future updates to improve the game are:
- Have the ability to parry with the knife while reloading (currently you can't do that)
- Sounds option (Currently the game doesn't have any options to configure the music volume etc)
- Overhaul the UI (The Game's UI isn't the best)
- When dialogue is being played have the option to click to continue to the next dialogue text (It moves to fast)
- The voices in the game is to low and hard to understand
- And lastly It would be cool for you to add some skin to the character = ) and it'd be visible in First person aswell, for example (Red sleeves, and gloves that have lightning emitting from them) something unique

Overall, I'm going to continue to play this game more, hope it is still worked on in future updates and above in which I recommended gets added

EDIT Day 1: (I'll be adding onto this edit more things that should be updated the longer I play)
 - Also what would be good in the future is to add Skins to the Knife Aswell/Abilities
 - Photo Mode

Edit Day 2: Jesus Christ...this game is UNFORGIVING LOL... IF YOU don't like dying alot, and you rage quit, this won't be your game, it is hard, you die in 1 hit, and to the level I had to take a break on, they just threw multiple huge aliens at me all at once...lord have mercy, but more things that should be added

- Make the player able to block while reloading aswell (please lord)
- Make every level a checkpoint OR remove the dialogue if a player has already seen it once and dies Or a skip button, I can't lie, not to be mean, it's annoying and stressful to have to wait every single death and every single time for the dialogue/cutscene to finish for the 1000th time

Let me preface this its a fun game but you should wait a while as there's a decent amount of platforming bug issues and a semi rough translation and some rune balancing. 

That said once they fix those major issues, I would definitely recommend it, so be patient and allow them to fix the bugs before buying. Once they fix these issues its a gonna be a major gem.

While I had some trouble running it consistently when I first started playing, I've since had very little issues the last few times I've booted it up. The combat is satisfying, the movement upgrades make sense and are very useful and the story is mysterious and interesting. I haven't finished this game yet, but if you're a fan of metroidvanias, give this one a try; try the demo first if you're unsure, but I'm still enjoying it 9 hours in and the gameplay is very familiar to hollow knight in some ways, such as spike pogoing, a wonderful charm system and platforming challenges for rewards and upgrades. Do yourself a favor, just jump right in and get ready for a wild ride; you'll be glad you did.

To run on Steam Deck currently use Proton 8.5

This isn't as much as much a review as it's more about the Steam Deck.

When I first downloaded the game it would crash every time on the oled steam deck.  If you run into this issue change the compatibility settings to run on Proton 8.5.

When you first set the setting to 8.5, if you haven't installed it before it will automagically d/l the needed files for this.

At first you will see a black screen, but let it stay up and eventually you will see the Unity logo.

TBH there is some slow down, but the controls work fine, no issues with readability that I have come across as of yet.

you start off by creating a character pick some traits positive and negative traits or none at all, blood type "effects your character in some positive ways" and a back round "also effects in different stats" then your dropped in a world where you can make choices on how you'd like it to turn out, depending on stats and traits different random events can trigger.
there is an energy system that you use when ever you go to a new location interact with object around the world, work, or sexual acts. Your energy drains differently depending on the actions you do. can gain back energy through food, sleep, energy drinks.
Your character has a hygiene meter too, that drains depending on your actions and can be gained back through items or taking a shower.
there's a lot of areas accessible from your home, diner, slums, red-light district, park, alley, clothing store and etc, lots of ground to be covered and discovered.
Just give it a try it's literally a dollar and has lots of content for it.

"Mr. Unaware ‚Äî 08/02/2024 9:43 AM
Well, Insexsity together with Fleeting Iris were my main inspirations for the project, but none of these games went for Steam in their prime, but more like a way squeeze a bit more $$$ in their last days.
