This is an adult life sim sandbox style game with both rpg and lewd scavenger hunter mechanics with a female protaganist ... that's a mouthful!

But its so good . . .

It is currently sold for $0.99, so as long as you are in the market for an adult game with a female prot, its more than worth checking out. Overall, I was fairly impressed with the game, and it shows promise to be even better as it is further developed. Most of what you'd want in an adult, female prot life sim etc etc sort of game are checked off, and I think my only complaint was that there really wasn't enough places for the prot to work or go or have fun and some of the events became a little stale after a while ... but for $0.99, and with potential to get a lot better, its very worth it. The prot is customizable both in appearance, background, and even voice a little, the rpg mechanics are pretty sound, there is a mini dress up game, adult fetish hunters will likely be fairly pleased with various scenes in the game, and I can think of more good things ... but the prot is currently stuck working at one job where she really has no chance to not end up corrupted at some point, I think, and there is no bar, no night club, no spa, etc. etc....so lots to be added, but I have confidance that the creator will add more of those things in - so yes, I'd gladly recommend this game for those looking for an adult female prot game.

Another worthwhile addition, the new weapon is good & the bow now takes a sight, but the main feature is the caller.

While some say its too heavy, I don't find it a problem myself because I will just carry a tent with me, deploy that & then use the stash inside the tent to equip the caller, walk out to a spot, place the caller then go back to the tent & equip as many weapons as I like.

Not a problem, its part of the management of the loadout.

Somebody pointed out that it gives you a headache, I AGREE!! my first use I thought "NO WAY, this is annoying" but have a look in the sounds menu, they have conveniently added a slider to adjust or turn off the remote caller sounds.

I can see this being useful as I can call animals to a location while I sit in a treestand, there are lots of options, some say its cheating but I think they use bait IRL don't they? 

The only thing I do agree with others are the cosmetic packs, they should have been free for each reserve as we have already purchased the reserve, but at the end of the day these are all DLCs, they are not compulsory.

I think my Refund Request notes say it best!

*******

I bought this pack purely for the electronic caller:

1. Wa-ay too heavy, ridiculous! Should be 2-3 kg MAX!
2. Calling is constant and therefore unrealistic and highly irritating - this could be overcome with a 'frequency' setting and/or even a 'manual fire' button. Currently, it is a very 'blunt instrument'. Frequency should have a broad range of at least 10-60 seconds between calls.

I love the concept and I'm looking forward to new and interesting ways to hunt, but I cannot use this in it's current state. If you bring the weight down AT LEAST 1-2 kilograms and introduce a broad frequency setting, I will repurchase immediately.

The e-caller can be turned down in Audio settings! All these negative reviews about the noise... just turn it down!
The e-caller has a range of 200m. It is OP for canada geese farming. I occasionally call with my reed caller as well because it has a range of 500m. They work together.
The rifle is cool, love lever acitons.

The e-caller works well.
Remember that you can turn the volume down in settings. It doesn't change its effectiveness, just ensures you don't go mad listening to it.
It's kinda heavy at 5kg but can make life a lot more simple on reserves with lots of animals. It also takes the hassle out of switching to an individual caller every 5 seconds.
Not sure about the weapons, haven't used them, but the caller is well worth the money.

Dissapointed in the electronic caller. On Emerald coast there's no caller for kangaroos, Banteng, or Saltwater Crocodiles. The three big species that are argaubly the most fun to hunt. Yet the caller works on Alligators on other maps. After a long wait for the DLC that was a huge let down

False advertising - says all callable species can be lured with the electronic caller, but tigers cannot be called in with it. Tigers have a caller in the game, why does this device not work with them?

The electric caller is rather.. interesting to say the least
Instead of selecting one setting and calling one animal at a time, Yeah it calls every animal in the game no matter what setting, you guys really put 0 effort into this and its a disappointment, only really good thing about it is the gun.
That's all I have to say.

The rifle is really nice, it's good for class 4-8 and has a nice fire rate and reloads fast. Great choice for an all-rounder.

The electronic caller seems really good - you can select the call for almost every animal in the reserve you're on - but it's heavy and it's made for ambush hunting which isn't really my thing, I like to keep moving and use the standard callers. 
The really important thing about it is that it's remote - you can enable/disable it and change the call type from a distance which means you can lure animals into view from your stand or wherever to get a clear shot without risk of them seeing, hearing or smelling you while getting into position.

I haven't used the bow and probably won't so I don't know if that's any good.

Besides the rifle it's not much value for a player like me but if you really enjoy ambush hunting, it's probably worth it for the electronic caller.

The Ambusher Pack is fantastic! I love the Moradi Model 1894 .44 lever action rifle. The exceptional penetration (or expansion if you use the hollow points) really makes it an excellent choice for medium-sized animals, especially within 150m, though you can certainly take down larger ones, even out to 300m.

When paired with the outstanding electronic caller, you can easily set up a tree stand, blind, or tripod to position the animals where you want them. What's particularly noteworthy is that the electronic caller attracts both American alligators and raccoon dogs, for which standalone callers aren't available (although there's a Perk that works on raccoon dogs). (In response to bad reviews complaining that the caller is unrealistically 5 units of weight: like the high weight of the digital rangefinder bow sight, the caller's weight is more about game balance/limitations to prevent making stand-alone callers obsolete [try carrying all the waterfowl callers; they also have unrealistic weights].)

I'm also quite fond of the Stenberg Takedown Recurve Bow. It's lightweight, compatible with standard arrows, and, most importantly, can utilize all the available bow sights in the game. Due to its light weight and versatility, it's worth carrying as an alternative weapon, even if you're not primarily a bowhunter.

All things considered, this is one of the finest weapon and equipment packs released. I'm thoroughly enjoying it, and it's unquestionably worth the price, especially for the electronic caller.

Worth it for the electronic call. Remember that you can turn down the caller volume in the settings menu. As someone that has spent a lot of time IRL hunting coyotes behind an electronic call-- I appreciate this slider more than you can imagine. It doesn't affect the in-game volume, only the system setting for your speakers. Priceless. 
The .bow is fine but there isn't much variation in the traditional bows to begin with. I was more excited for the .44 Mag lever gun and it is solidly....okay. I frankly think it's rated too high in the game as the .44 mag in a carbine length barrel produces roughly half the numbers of a .45-70 Gov't cartridge. With a .45-70 in the game, there should be more to differentiate the two from one another. 
As a fan of lever guns though, it rounds out the collection until we get a .22LR lever gun like a Henry Rifle.

Bought it for because every item is made for me. I almost exclusively use lever action and bows and I am an ambusher style hunter.

Every single item is a minor let down in some way.

Rifle (Pass) I like have access to modern scopes on a lever action so the rifle is a pass. Though it is annoying to have to hit reload every round at the rifle range.

The Caller(FAIL) weighs a lot, which is fine I guess if it was more powerful. But it is constantly spraying out calls and gets annoying quick. So if you are looking for a hunt on the move(I am not talking long stalks, I mean moving with wind or circling a lake.) item at all it is not handy and weighs so much you cant afford to bring extra callers. Having to go back and pick it up every time I want to move a little was more of a hindrance than I thought it would be.

The Bow(FAIL) I was so excited for the bow. Can accept all modern sights which is fun. But it is just wildly inaccurate and not even consistently inaccurate. It pulls to the right super hard for me to the point where even using the high tech scope It would shoot out of circle at the 50m targets. It was so bad I thought it was a weird bug where the arrows were just not being registered.

The electronic caller is a really good idea for this game, but the frequency is so high and it stops calling by it self relatively fast, not sure if that is intended or bug, but its annoying. It is a great tool though, combine it with the scent sprays and you have a really effective trap. I don't care much for the new lever-action rifle but the recurve bow is really cool and was needed, we had no "traditional style" bow in the game of this quality, but now we do.

5kg for the caller is waayyyy too heavy. 

This thing has the same weight as ten (!) normal callers, and I never take ten callers with me. This alone renders it useless, unless 
(i) I don't take any firearm for birds/rabbits/foxes etc, or 
(ii) I take a backpack for all the the extra weight. 

Another thing they don't tell you, is that even though it weighs as much as ten normal callers, its attraction strength is on average 25% less than other callers. 

This is a massive disappointment.

The electronic caller is the best damn thing to ever be added to this game.
It doesn't take that much space (I don't know wtf some people are crying about)

You can ambush animals in any way possible with this, it's like being with another hunter but solo, it's much more fun to hunt with this.

Hard to tell if it's working, All I hear is loud calls every 2 seconds, no clue what the animals are actually doing...(aka useless). I also found animals will not go to it out in the open, they go like, around somewhere which is usually like 150 meters from the "caller"(noise box). AKA they act scared of it and hide where you can't shoot. Eh, working as intended?

The .44 magnum lever-action rifle is one of the most goated and busted firearms at the moment. It's a class 3-8 rifle which makes it a rifle that never leaves my backpack, but does suffer from pulling off longer range shots (300m+). It can easily double lung and, drop animals in literal seconds which is absolutely awesome. The electronic caller kind of sucks, but its worth it for making story missions easier. The take-down recurve is a solid choice for a 2lb weight category and thankfully does accept the EZ mode sight for quiet eliminations. I would highly recommend this DLC specifically just for the .44 mag rifle, but the other two items are kind off worthless in my opinion.

I really like this DLC except for the rifle, it looks nice and has cool animations but I haven't found a fitting place for it in my loadouts. The bow is a nice addition though. Like others have said it feels a bit inaccurate but thanks to its low weight I've been able to "squeeze" it in most of my loadouts so I always have a bow with me which is a trade off I don't mind.

The caller is very heavy but I think that most people are missing the point. The way I see it is you're supposed to put it down and camp out in a hunting stand or whatever. HOWEVER.... it still weighs the same after putting it down so the remote takes up 1/4th of your inventory (unless you've got a backpack on) I'd like it more if the weight gets reduced after putting the caller down.

I'm having a lot of fun with it and hey this pack only costs 5 eur so can't complain really.

A worthwhile addition to the game! The .44 is great, and the bow takes a sight, but I will agree with everyone else that the caller is a bit heavy! I don't mind, though. I just manage via tents.

nice new DLC. the new caller comes very handy ‚Äî place it in front of your favorite hunting stand, let it run and wait for the animal. the advantage here is you dont call it to your location than to a perfect spot to shoot at and you dont have to call all the time cause the device does it for you. like the new approach as an addition to the ‚Äûtraditionell‚Äú hunting methods.

oh, and the price is top ‚Äî you get also a powerful lever action and a nice recurve bow.

The obviously contentious part of this pack is the electronic caller, so I'll talk about that last.

The recurve bow is highly effective. It has a low draw weight but is still more than capable of skewering multiple organs, especially with the Pumping Iron perk. It's really low in terms of mass, like the traditional bows, but allows for sights, which makes it infinitely more accessible.
The 1894 is an excellent addition, too. Having a rifle capable of 3 - 8 Class harvests means it's capable of replacing one of the very common 4 - 8 Class rifles in a loadout. The default "zero" for the 1894 is definitely further than the .44 Magnum revolver with the handgun optic, but it is not the "standard" range seen with nearly every other rifle cartridge. The 1894 is also relatively low mass for a rifle and I do like its animations.

Electronic caller is highly useful, but it is annoying.
Actual electronic callers can facilitate delays between calls but theHunter's version absolutely doesn't. It's fun to hear some new calls and have selections between the different types of calls for a species.
It is also quite heavy. 5 units is big and means your loadout will have to change to facilitate it, and I'm pretty sure that it's heavier than just having every caller for a reserve on your person.
Bumping down the weight by a unit and allowing intermittent or timed calls would make this useful tool less of a burden.

Not a bad pack! No doubt worth it if you're waiting on theHunter sales.

Updating review to recommended since EW changed the e-caller stats. Now it weighs 3.5 and the attraction strength was updated to match the other callers. Also, I've tested it a lot ingame now. I can say it is at least as effective as the manual callers, likely better as it spaces the calls automatically. Well deserved thumbs up now.

Original review below.
______________________________________________________________
I'm not fond of bow hunting, so I have not much of an opinion, just test it a little at Parque's range, it can use the digital scope, that's very good, but even with that scope I never landed a single shot on the 100m target.

The Moradi, yeah, it drops small deer on the spot. A little scary to use against Moose, because they run like crazy, even when double lunged. This is, quite frankly, nearly a meme rifle - you can drop Mule deer with shots thru the backside and the ridiculous penetration will cause you to get stomach, liver, and lung. Now, nothing really bad about this. It is worst for example in "Classic", where you have the 9.3 O/U, or the .340, that will allow you to do the same but with a water buffalo, and also drop it on the spot. Mules will run a little bit at least with the Moradi.

Finally, the main "attraction", the e-caller. So far I'm getting mixed results with this caller. I used it for geese; it doesn't seem to have any advantage over decoys, it was, predictably, worse. I thought of combining it with decoys, and didn't see any advantage either. And what would be the point? This caller actually works more like a decoy in the sense that you set it up and hide preparing to shot from a distance. Then it seems to work much better with coyotes, but just barely with red deer. At this point I don't know if I'll be using it at all, as it has too many disadvantages.
This is the reason I'm saying no "at this time", with the hope that the devs will actually do something about it. I understand the need to "balance" a device like this. However, and I've seen this same feedback in several places, it is too much. They made it weigh 5 units, that is the equivalent to 10 callers, that you'll never ever will want to carry, you wouldn't need to carry that many. This would be okay, however, the problem is that they also are only giving it an effective calling range of 200 meters, and worst, they gave it an attraction strength of only 30 compared to the 40 most manual callers have. This absolutely doesn't make sense, it is an electronic/digital caller. It should have the best optimization to give you a way better attraction than a regular caller.

--EDITED after testing out Moradi--

Giving a thumbs up, but with reservations.

The electronic caller is, as others have said, extremely annoying. The high frequency of calls per minute is grating at best, and completely unbearable at worst. It works though, and can allow for changes in tactics which is a welcome thing at this point in the game.

I also like the bow. It's only 2 lbs, and can use all bow sights, including the electronic range finder sight. This is quite nice because it allows for some interesting loadouts. The bow works fine, though it does feel like the lower poundage actually has an in-game effect, notably when attempting frontal heart shots. So while it's not a mandatory addition to the game, it is a nice one, and probably my new favorite bow. That being said I AM an avid archer in RL, so any new bow is fun for me. YMMV.

I could care less about yet another rifle however, and have not even tried this new one. I'm sure it's fine, but whatever really, this game is not hurting in the rifle department. Overall, this seems like a wasted opportunity to me. You could argue that the new recurve also does not add anything new I suppose, but to me it does stand out as a more unique weapon, given that we didn't have a 'normal' take-down recurve that can mount sights (and that lower weight does come into play compared to the compounds). A rifle that can use .44 cartridges may be fun for some (and all the power to you), but I don't think this really translates into new gameplay or strategies. So great, you can use a heavier weapon with a calibre already available in a lighter weapon... IF the ballistics for the 44 projectile actually change in the 44, then I could see the point, but unless I'm mistaken, EW has not done anything like that so far (EDIT: I was wrong there, the .44 ballistics are slightly improved in the rifle, see below for my results). The Cuomo shoots EXACTLY like the 243 rifle (I've checked that out at the range, there is no difference) even though the barrel is quite short (obviously). In the case of the Cuomo however, this is an AMAZING thing, because you can carry that light pistol around to shoot any class 2 to 6, which gives a lot of freedom in loadouts...

Overall, this pack is nowhere near as interesting or necessary as some of the other packs, and the electronic caller is really a mixed-bag. I don't think I'll be using that thing myself; it's too heavy but mostly, it's just WAY too annoying. As for the weapons, I think in the end it just comes down to personal preference. But neither the bow or the rifle are really necessary upgrades, IMO.

But I am still recommending the DLC, if only because I approve of anything that can (at least theoretically) lead to new tactics and/or strategies, even if the execution is not perfect. Put another way, I'm ok with giving EW some of my money now for this sub-optimal selection, in the hopes that they put weapon packs out more frequently (which ideally means more chances of us getting really neat/different/exciting/game-changing items).

Moradi/Panther comparison
No zeroing perk
.44 is good for classes 3-8

Moradi (3 lbs) with Hyperion scope
----------------------------------
100m => shots land on cross-hair
150m => shooting at 10 ring, most shots land low on 8/9 line.
200m => shooting at 10 ring, most shots land low on 4/5 line. 

Panther with pistol scope
-------------------------
50m => shots land on cross hair
100m => shooting at 10 ring, most shots land low on 7/8 line.
150m => shooting at 10 ring, most shots land low on 2/3/4 line.

With these results, I can see a place for the Moradi in loadouts, given the in-game versatility of the .44 cartridge. Also, the rifle is pretty darn light at only 3 lbs, so it is in fact quite nice, stats-wise...

10-23-23 Review update;

Since my original review I have figured out what was keeping the dlc from working.  I removed an old mod that was no longer working after the last update and the the Ambusher Pack content was then available in the game.  So if it is not showing up in your game, that is something you might want to look into.

Now that it is working, I have to say that I like the new content very much.  The new gun which shoots .44s, is very handy because that caliber covers a lot of class range 3-8.  I also like the electronic caller, it is fun to use.  I haven't tried the bow as I'm more a gun enthusiast and not really into bow hunting.

I accidentally bought this game and I played it.
You are a top heavy women with massively jiggly boobs and has a thicc dump-truck that jumps on weird spongy cheese looking blocks in the dark for poor gaymers.

Well I mean, what you get for the pricing is okay, but in itself its just not good.

When you spawn in, theres a whole load of lore on the wall in front of you, and it goes on and on, in different languages. Everythings super dark, it took me already 5 minutes to find my way out of the "lore room," into the gameplay section, and its not much. Jump on sponges in dark areas, I have no idea how to connect this to the "post apocalyptic underworld," this more looks like a cyberpunk dungeon with sponges everywhere.
The character models shader is very out of place, and doesnt fit with the games general looks. Its like you put a cartoon character in a realistic environment. I also dont understand the characters design choice. Whys Eve so thicc? I mean, I dont mind, but why?

The platforming itself is quite alright, not too floaty, not too clunky, but thats really all the positives I have for this game.

the real frustration that came with getting over it's popularity was that it made the frustrating climbing/precision jumping games 1. popular and 2. seemingly easy to make because now we have trash like this. the probably ai generated description in she fell off's page has more effort put into it than the clipping into themselves jiggly breasts mechanics. there's no cohesion to the art direction, nor any art direction at all. the music is ambient sound and, really, this is what you play when your mom tells you that you have haydee at home.

there's also no menu whatsoever, you've got to alt tab yourself out of the game. really, don't bother with this one.

I tried to play this game, despite the negative reviews. But damn if they were right... The platforming is clunky, the animations are weird, and the "lore" is shoved down your throat in the first room. You are not "immersing yourself in an eerie mystery" you're immersing yourself in sponge-land. I wanted this game to be better, but it isn't. Eve doesn't move naturally, and she doesn't fit in the world.

If you fall, (which is all I did, considering the weird, slippery movement) you don't get re-spawned, but instead have to do MORE slippery platforming just to get back up to where you fell. This wouldn't bother me as much if there were a menu to respawn yourself in, but everytime I wanted to restart I had to alt-tab and close the game.

I hope your next works are better, and whoever is reading this plays a better game.

I've played video games for the past 40 years. This game is a throwback game with above average difficulty featuring a variety of themes on each level along with the entertaining original music. The variety offered by this game is refreshing change to most games these days. 

The game appears to be basic from the marketing but it's anything but another attempt by game developers to bait you into another "basic" and "mindless" trap to make the happy buck. This is a genuine classic development of a game that is entertaining and difficult for any level of player. 

There are a limited number of shots you can take on each level forcing the player to be frugal. Pay attention to your health as it is also a scarce resource. I liked both features of the game as so many games these days allow for unlimited ammunition and health. 

This is a game I purchased with the intent of passive interest as I'm a turn based strategy gamer. I find myself playing more often than I thought I would. It's enjoyable, relaxing, and challenging. I recommend the game.

I honestly wish there was a mobile version of the game so I could play while waiting around.

Alien Land is a bit of Chinese shovelware that seems to have been dumped on Steam as a cash grab.  Is it an asset flip? I'm not sure, but probably.  It's very badly made, whatever it is.  It's supposed to be a hybrid Tribes like city builder and TD game, although I think the TD elements are missing...  It's difficult to tell how to play because there's no tooltips, and a short, badly translated passage on how to click on stuff with your mouse (oh so helpful).  You can work it out, however, there's no point in doing so, this really is shockingly bad.

This game has been translated from into English... badly.  If this was done through Google Translate, Google Translate should feel ashamed of itself.  Regardless, the language in this game is broken and will put off a lot of gamers.

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

There's no option to change the resolution and no useful graphics tweaks.  There's no way to ensure this is running at the native resolution of your display.  There's no guarantee this game will look right on any PC as a result of this hamfisted design decision.

The game features lazy low-polygon "retro" assets, making this look like a barely functional 3D game from the 1990s.  In fact the assets are incredibly poor quality, and combined with the locked resolution, they look fuzzy and awful.  It's unclear why the developers weren't able to arrange high quality, high polygon count contemporary assets for the game, and also irrelevant... what matters is that this looks bad as a result of their decisions, a compromise PC gamers shouldn't have to put up with.

There's also some graphical distortion, some of the UI elements are broken and take up about half the screen... you can play around them, but it's a truly terribly experience trying to do so. 

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

The poor quality of this game is reflected by how many people spent time with it.  At the time of this review, SteamDB shows the all-time peak player number was only 2 players.  This is a remarkably low number, and now, the only player activity occurs once or twice a month, presumably someone loading it up to see what it is then quickly uninstalling it.  Considering there's over 120 million gamers on Steam and well over 50,000 games for gamers to choose from (over 9,000 completely free titles), the overwhelming lack of interest in this low quality game is to be expected.

Alien Land has the ridiculous, laughable price of around $5 USD, it's not worth it given the defects and shortcomings with the product, especially considering the sheer number of completely free, much higher quality games on Steam.

[b][quote][url=https://partner.steamgames.com/doc/marketing/profile]Profile Features Limited![/url][/quote][/b]Valve have marked this game as "Profile Features Limited" at the time of this review.  This is usually caused by poor sales figures and low community acceptance for the game (to date).  Until this status changes, this game will not give you +1 to your Game Collector badge count, appear in profile achievements or any other Steam meta-accomplishments, nor can it be displayed in some profile showcases.  If these factors are important to you, it may be worth holding off before buying this game.

Nobody's Home is the shortest entry in the VCRPG series, but I still thought it was a worthwhile experience. Good writing, lots to explore, and a few secret endings to discover. It's a light dose of horror, and short enough to be experienced in an hour and a half- and for the record, I don't think those are bad qualities. If you're a fan of horror games that are short and sweet, or you enjoyed developer Oates' other games, you might like this one too!

"Nobody's Home" is a VERY short survival RPG where you play a partygoer trying to escape the aftermath of a party gone wrong. The main deal here is resource management (maybe THE gameplay-schtick of "oates") and it feels fresh and rewarding (maybe because it is so short).

It only takes around 15-20 minutes to beat for the first time, but there are several endings to it! Definetly a recommendation for a short and unique fix!

Cannon Block Ball is a browser game/web app that's been dumped on Steam as if it was a fully fledged PC game (it's not)... it's a cash grab from greedy web developers.  The game is an unabashed, lazy ripoff of Angry Birds (Copyright Rovio/Sega, 2009).  Many lazy "amateur" developers don't pay attention to their obligations under copyright law, and often steal the ideas of actual, real game developers without credit, such as the "developer" here has done.  At this stage no legal action has been taken by Rovio/Sega against the "developer" here, but it's never off the table, as previous copyright law cases have shown.

Putting aside the unethical intellectual bankruptcy of stealing someone else's game concept for profit, this is also breaking that unwritten law of stealing other people's game ideas... you should at least try to do better than the game you're ripping off.  Cannon Block Ball is considerably worse than Angry Birds.

Once more this is an attempt from Nannings to scam PC gamers into paying them for a game that you can play for free in your web browser.  This is unethical and insulting to PC gamers on Steam.  Putting aside the fact this is a scam and nobody should buy it, from a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

While there are options to change the resolution for the game, all this does is scale up the simplistic 2D art assets used to make the game, which makes little or no difference to the graphics quality.  Without any other substantial graphics tweaks, it's not possible for gamers to improve the lacklustre 2D visuals.

The game features simple, cartoony 2D graphics, of the type you normally expect to see in low effort mobile apps.  3D graphics programming does require a degree of skill and competence and unfortunately not all developers have the budget or talent to deliver this, despite 3D graphics cards hitting the mainstream in the 1990's.  Considering this is being evaluated as a PC game, having the graphics phoned in like this isn't going to result in a high quality, visually impressive game that PC gamers are used to seeing.

The controls can't be customised, which will be an annoyance for many, but it can also render the game unplayable for differently-abled gamers, left handed gamers or gamers using AZERTY or other international keyboard layouts.  

The very poor quality of this game puts it squarely on-par with ancient 1990's Flash/Java games, and given it's 2024 (and this was released not so far back in 2023), gamers and the industry expect and deserve better than this kind of low effort shovelware.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

The poor quality of this game is reflected by how many people spent time with it.  At the time of this review, SteamDB shows the all-time peak player number was only 2 players.  This is a remarkably low number, and now, the only player activity occurs once or twice a month, presumably someone loading it up to see what it is then quickly uninstalling it.  Considering there's over 120 million gamers on Steam and well over 100,000 games for gamers to choose from, the overwhelming lack of interest in this low quality game is to be expected.

So, should you buy this free browser game?  Is this one of the best of the 100,000+ games on Steam?

Once more we see greedy devs trying to scam PC gamers. On Steam, this is $1 USD, but it's free to play on the web.  Web developers must learn PC gamers are not here to be gouged, and can't be expected to pay a premium for a free browser game just because it's been lazily dumped on Steam.  This is unacceptable disrespect for PC gamers.  Because this can be played free elsewhere, and because of the other defects, it's impossible to recommend.  Who do they think we are?  This is also competing with over 11,000 free games available on Steam, many of them far better than this paid product.

Until this status changes, this game will not give you +1 to your Game Collector badge count, appear in profile achievements or any other Steam meta-accomplishments, nor can it be displayed in some profile showcases.  If these factors are important to you, it may be worth holding off before buying this game.[/quote]

I also just bought this to support it, but honestly, there's a couple of my favorites that justifies this purchase. [b]Update, checked on 18 September '23: It seems that this very link now has the later-mentioned keyboard rhythms in, so this paragraph may no longer be relevant.[/b] I think the one here is a bit more bass-y (?), while the one on youtube is lighter but crunchier in a good way. But also. [u]the one here has a constant, rhythmical keyboard chord to it that Youtube's doesn't![/u]. (which goes to mean that these are 100% different versions of the track; if the youtube version will suddenly get added to the album because of this, then I hope the old one stays in the album)

I do feel like I would've loved to get "Bassy Bass (Ancient Archive variation)" though, because those play in-game and aren't available here. I know they don't sound particularly good, but, would've been nice to have!

I'm glad the default suspense music ("Uh Oh!") and the final boss fight music, are each their own separate tracks, only with a similar first-minute build up, with the latter using the former as some sort of prelude. Again, the same part plays slightly differently, so having both to listen to is nice!

Also the muffled version of "Essential Albums" (that plays during the Pop Up Shop in Hellblivion) isn't here in the album. I do love that track in its intended glory, for sure! (Minor spoiler)[spoiler]How it plays near the end is comedic gold[/spoiler]. But still, it's a different, neat variant.

In the end, I think that's pretty much all tracks accounted for. So yeah.
Other recommended tracks if you do get this: Bopstead Bop (of course), Ian's Skeletone Funk, Sid's No-Tea Party, & The Bus.

my personal favorite aircraft to fly in this game, its definitely not the best one in the game, but its a absolute blast to fly.

the main pros is in its speed, jamming, BVR, and SEAD. in those roles its a absolute beast of an aircraft due to its sweeping wings and VERY powerful afterburner, jamming pods, AIM 54's, and having TSD along with good SEAD missile options.

its cons are in its agility, flight cost, and hardpoint slots. because of its size and weight its turn radius is less then ideal, you CAN dogfight in it, although your chances of winning are reduced, so keep your distance. its flight cost is very expensive so on missions with only 100K IF your using jamming pods you probably wont be able to rearm. its limited hardpoint slots is not something that needs to be changed as its hardpoint slots are realistic, im saying its a con because the other jets in the game can hold much more.

overall, its NOT the best jet in the game by any means but it is up there due to its VERY big pros, awesome bird!!

Beautiful, fast, and versatile.  With unusually low drag with wings swept back, accelerated up to mach 1.44 in level flight at about 50 feet altitude, then climbed to about 84,000 feet in a continuous steep climb, better in this test than any other jet in this game by a significant margin.  Doesn't pull the most AOA, but great acceleration and energy retention.  I love this jet.

The only way I can put this is... Big aircraft (they called it's inspiration a 'flying cloud' for a reason) with a tail-hook the size of a postage stamp. I forgot my wrist strap, and the unfortunate controller is now somewhere across the room, I need to go see if it survived after being tossed when my arms went up in a cheer. A cheer at finally managing to catch the 2 wire in what can only be described as a controlled *crash* of a landing. If you can 3-wire consistently, I doff my hat to thee. The more I tried and failed to catch a wire, ANY wire, the more I became convinced that mastery of the EF-24 could make a man a better boyfriend, such was the hand-eye coordination and multitasking required.

Right, the difficulties I've had in my horrible carrier skills notwithstanding: it's FUN, even if I spent much of my time swearing at it. It is BIG, both in size (see above), and how it flies (even when not trying to land). You can't throw it around the air like you can the Tyro or base aircraft, so you have to make very deliberate movements to get the most out of it. The sweeping wings change a lot about how it flies. You don't notice this in the 'auto' position (forward and to the left on that lever) as much, but manually messing with it does interesting things (made finding out that there WAS an auto setting kinda nice).  If you get the right combination of altitude, airspeed, and over-G, you can do some pretty surprising turns. But doing so bleeds speed very quickly and you'll be wallowing afterward.

It's got F-45 (totally-not-an-F-35) styled touchscreens, which... honestly works for this aircraft better than you'd expect, even if it feels weird not seeing old-school gauges in a Tomcat Analogue. You have a lot more control over the RADAR than you do in the F-45 (which most folks don't even know you can use instead of the datalink/TSD) and even a bit more than the F/A-26B gives you. It's as close to DCS-level as I've seen VTOL get.

And that brings us to the back seat: The pilot *can't* fully control the RADAR. The back-seater has the ability to set altitude, pilot only has Azumith (direction) and actually selecting a target. to use the AIM-54 properly, you will *need* two people.the rear seat can also swap SOI with the left control stick. That's something that I missed comparing VTOL with any game that uses my X52. Having to let go of a control and *physically move your hand to swap sensors* takes a notable chunk of time, and you can't adjust throttle/stick while you're doing it depending on hand used. So a pair of players, one almost completely focused on flying, and one almost completely focused on weapons/systems use, is going to be a very dangerous pair indeed. The downside of this, unlike the AH-94 and T55, is that it really doesn't work great solo. That's all before we get to the electronic warfare stuff which I haven't been able to mess with.

All in all, a fantastic aircraft (which fortunately didn't kill my controller upon finding it).

Even though I'm disliking it at the moment, I don't regret buying it and it's probably worth it for many especially ones which want to dive into EW. It's beatifully modeled and you can tell that a lot of exertise and love went into creating the EF 24 but unfortunately I'm not having fun with it and am a bit dissapointed. Theoretically the plane gives you a lot of options but to me it seems like you only be left with one, which is EW.

Why I don't like it:
- Can carry only less than half as much as a FA26b, I think you can carry the least amount of weapons from any jet in VTOL. The FA26b even gives the option to carry weapons instead of extra fuel but the EF 24 can only carry the fule tanks with no option to put ammunition on them instead.
- Super sluggish to fly, doesn't want to turn and is bad at dog fights even with extended wings. Even though the 26b woul carry what feels like three times as much the EF 24 would with less load still fly much worse and generally less fun.
- Seems to be only worth for EW (which other planes now can do as well to some degree) but is not good for multi-role things like having enough stuff with you to fight air and ground targets after another. The description of the jet says its a normal jet adapted for EW but then I don't get why by that it becomes underwhelming at all other roles. 
- The roll the 24 is good at is pretty boring in the type of flying we do. While you can jamm and decoy stuff to get close to targets you then don't carry enough with you to deal damage so all you can do is a support roll and you will need others do the fun work.
- All together make the EF-24 pretty much useless for the kind of missions I fly with a friend currently because instead we are better off using two 26b, carry more, be two targets instead of one and much more agile. 

What it needs so I could have fun with it:
- A bit better maneuverbility and less sluggish to fly, when having the wings spread it should not fly like a brick and be at least halfway decent in dogfights but at the moment it just doesn't want to pull any gs. Would be cool if I could use manually spreading the wings as more of an advantage in dog fights but  it just makes it sligtly less bad.
- Higher amount of weapons to carry so we are not empty as quick and can be equipped for both air and ground targets at once. Why can I not put more bombs/rockets on one mounting point or chose weapons instead of fule tanks like on some other planes like the FA26. 

Some background info why I don't like it:
What I currently do most is flying coop missions with friends, mostly dynamic ones where it's about taking an airfield with e.g. 4 air targets and 8 ground targets or cleaning a city nearby with 10-15 ground targets and other random things. Because the EF-24 can cary only very few weapons we are constantly out of ammo and would spend most time flying back to a base for rearming. Because of the bad capacity it's also hardly possible to prepare yourself for multiple tasks like having some bombs and anti radar missiles while still having enough AIM120 and AIM9 to defend yourself against air targets. When a friend and I each fly a FA26b which carries like twice us much rockets and bombs than the EF-24 we can take out several other jets still have enough bombs left to clean ground targets or big part of a city. With the EF-24 we can either have enough for air targets or for some ground targets but by far not enough for both especially if we woul go for sharing the cockpit instead of flying each our own jet. Because of this in most missions we go back to using the FA26b again which is a shame as I think the 26 didn't age well and with its bigger sized cockpit feels much less immersive to sit in as in the T55 or EF24. I would have loved to move to a new jet but have to go back to the old one just because it's far superior in versaitlity and also maneuverability.

Edit: Now I've also tried the F45 again and its much more effective than the EW24. It can jam without the need to carry pods (just less options and maybe a bit less effective), it can carry more weapons and still pull more Gs which makes evading missiles much easier. I can dominate situations alone in the F45 where we would struggle hard sharing cockpits in the EW24 and the fact that instead of flying in the EWO seat my friend can fly another F45 in coop missions makes it 10times more effective and fun that the EW24. Currently I can't see a reason using the EW24 until it can carry a bit more and fly less like a brick.

[b]PROS AND CONS BELOW THESE WALLS OF TEXT FOR TL;DR PEOPLE[/b]

This DLC is essentially what we would've had in real life if the corrupt hack named Cheney never existed. The aircraft's body is a modernized version of the world-famous F-14 Tomcat, while the cockpit area is packed full of touchscreens similar to the F-45A to facilitate it's unique ability: [b]ELECTRONIC WARFARE[/b]. With this aircraft, you gain the ability to deceive enemy radar systems using a combination of jamming pods and decoy missiles (that can also jam enemy radar, how fun!) in order to bypass and neutralize them easier than ever before! It's primarily built for two people (who both own the DLC) much like the AH-94, with one person focusing on the EW systems while the other focuses on flying and fighting, but both can be done by a lone pilot with enough focus and willpower. 

Besides the jamming pods and decoy missiles, this plane also has access to the AIM-54 Phoenix, a long-range, heavy-payload, radar-guided air-to-air missile that was exclusively used by the Tomcat, allowing you to obliterate enemies from afar! It's also as fast as a bullet, capable of speeds of up to mach 2.6 (maybe even faster) and is the fastest aircraft in VTOL VR to date. It's not perfect (see below as to why I think so), but for the low price (and those beautiful variable-sweep wings), it's a must-buy without a doubt.

PROS:
1: Tomcat. Need I say more?
2: EW is fun, the jamming and decoys add a new layer of complexity to air combat operations.
3: This aircraft is [i]fast[/i], [b][i]really fast[/i][/b]. Perfect if you have the need... the need for [b]SPEED[/b]!!!
4: The Phoenix missile is a [i]beast[/i] in BVR engagements, capable of going far and hitting hard.
5: Seems to take quite a beating and still fly (from my experience as a missile sponge).
6: Only $12 at full price, won't break your bank.

CONS:
1: Solo players will likely struggle with utilizing the EW mechanics effectively while piloting.
2: It can't turn as much as other aircraft can in a dogfight without ripping the wings fully off, and you'll likely hear a stall warning for most of the fight. It [i]can[/i] dogfight, but it will probably take practice and skill.
3: On afterburners, it [b]DRAINS[/b] fuel. You can get like 20 minutes of constant afterburners [b]WITH EXTERNALS[/b] before fuel dries up, so you'll have to stay off of afterburners when it's not needed.
4: Can't split weapons with EWO, only one or the other can launch missiles. I'd say just to leave that job to the pilot to avoid confusion.
5: Not much space for weapons, and no cluster bombs or rocket pods are available.
6: Personally wish the pilot seat was less like the F-45A and more like the F/A-26B, I just would've preferred a more "analog" setup.
7: EWO gets no MP3 player :(

This plane is pretty spectacular. its a great multirole, but it's role as an electronic warfare/support aircraft is it's priority.

it excells in jamming and is the best in the game at jamming.
it carries mostly Anti Air munitions, filling it's secondary role very well: air superiority.

in terms of air superiority, it has an amazing loadout. it falls somewhere between the T-55 tyro and the F/a-26 wasp. it carries much more than the T-55, it has MUCH more engine power, but it has no pitch limiter and it rolls slower. In the hands of a skilled pilot, it can hold it's own, however in the hands of an equally skilled pilot, the F/a26 would beat it, even if it would be a challenge to do so.
The Ef-24G also carries the long range Aim-54 missile, which is exclusive to it.

Compared to the F-45 ghost, this plane has the upper hand in a dogfight.

in terms of ground-pounding, this plane is quite modest. you have 3 anti radar missiles, 2 cruise missiles, the dumb bombs, 2 gps bombs and 1 laser guided bomb. in other words, it is very old-timey in terms of ground-pounding and carries less than the F/26, which carries an amazing loadout... but the Ef-24G still does a great job, better than the T-55 and very slightly worse or equal to the F-45.
Absolutely amazing aircraft and I love the new Jamming feature. Thank you Boundless Dynamics for this aircraft.

Only problem is the single player missions (if you don't play those or have friends, this can be ignored). They are horribly balanced to the point where some missions are extremely difficult to straight-up impossible solo, and only marginally easier with an EWO. Mainly due to the fact that, as a support aircraft, the missions revolve around supporting AI, which are too dumb to operate effectively 

Again, if you play multiplayer most of the time, this is a non-issue.

Fantastic DLC. Truly the best jet. Awesome glass cockpit, best HOTAS.
The EW system surprised me. Unlike most other games, EW is actually effective. You can literally defeat missiles with the Jammer, no maneuvering required.

It requires active management, which is why the second seat is assigned to it. While flying solo EW can be employed, but will end up being far less effective due to the high workload. Fantastic balancing for coop multiplayer.

IMO there is only one downside: The price. It really should be higher than 12‚Ç¨.

"It's for electronic warfare? I don't think electronics can go to war."

"You mean it jams radar? What kind of jam? strawberry, raspberry, blueberry?"

"As in it interferes with the radar's functions. I mean any old plane can interfere with a radar's function if it has a weapon on it"
super cool plane I've been twice the speed of sound (M 2.14) I think even the fastest plane in the game? how do this plane also has a lot of buttons, now I have to figure out how they work

Until Heatblur makes an F-4G this is the best EW experience you'll find in a video game. This is very fun and cool, I just wish I could use my stick instead of the VR one lol.

Touch controls work great but being able to use a physical stick for precision alongside a touch controller for throttle and buttons would be a huge improvement in my opinion. I am shocked that this isn't supported.
As complicated as can be, I love it (as long as there's a manual, which the community provides!). Always happy to see 2 seaters as well, great for messing around with a friend.

Hey, it's a really cool new plane, but I have a problem with it. Landing the carrier is far too difficult because the hook is far too short for this aircraft. Normally the hook should lightly touch the ground or be slightly above the ground, but the hook end of this aircraft is about 1 meter or more above the ground, but I'll keep trying and it's still a wonderful new plane with cool new ones Features

Edit: Never mind it was just a big skill problem on my side now that I've trained properly, I can land this plane with almost no problems on the carrier

Finally! A Tomcat!

This is the one DLC I have been waiting a long time for other than the T-55. The EF-24G is my brand new main plane.
I actually printed out the manual and got a whole binder for it just because of how much i love this plane. (also to learn electronic warfare). Baha has completely blown the community away with the quality of the plane, and also the update that released with the plane. I bought it as soon as it came out, legitimately I bought it probably 2 minutes after. The swept wings are phonominal and this has pretty much been the best update for the game: tons of new features and such.
