Honestly my favorite plane in this game, Its really fast, fun to fly, EASY to fly and I absolutely love the new cockpit design for it. 

Would 100% recommend this aircraft.

very good tomcat, i believe its the fastest aircraft in the game, topping out at about 830 knots (or mph i forgot which one i use). the electronic warfare side of the aircraft seems cool but its very confusing, there is also no in-game tutorials on the systems

This aircraft is a do it all machine, it will require some work to learn and use to its potential, but that being said it raises the bar on what vtolVR aircraft can do, its speed and capability for maneuvering and payload is far above its competitors. it possesses weight and power, to balance with the wing configuration. its modernization of the f-14 body-style is a welcome and fun to fly air frame with its own personality. the EWO flight controls not being doubled is somewhat weird but there's enough to do for the team back there that makes it a welcome step up from the t-55 and f-26. price to performance? 12$ for an aircraft to use in the best VR game for aviators is insane, and Bahamuto should take a victory lap, you are missing out if you dont add this to your hangar

Feels great. Haven't taken it out for combat yet, but just free flying around with it feels fantastic, and we finally get a two-seater that doesn't fall out of the sky when it pulls G.

Surprised by the price. Should cost more.

Another awesome plane released by a great dev. A must get if you already play the game, and at $12 it can't be beat.

Oh, and for everyone complaining about lack of tutorials, there is a flight manual for the plane that got released a few days ago, shouldn't be too hard to find with a little searching.

Instant buy without question, it's an amazing aircraft with a ton of capability and it's fun in either seat.

NOTE: While there really should be an Electronic Warfare tutorial, you can find the EF24G Flight Manual on the VTOL VR discord which goes over many of the EW mechanics if you don't mind reading some.

honestly the best plane for vtol to date, i really like the cockpit design and electronic warfare is really fun, although you NEED a second person to do it (its not an option) anyway i have literally never bought something so fast in my life

Got around to learning how to use it, it's a blast to use. 
I'm usually not a huge Tomcat/Top gun guy, but the more 4.5 Gen feel of this thing sold it for me. 
And the Electronic Warfare systems give you a whole new play style to toy with.

Though sluggish in rate fights it can definitely pack a punch in terms of speed as well. 
Would recommend it highly for anyone, even if you think the movie "Top Gun" is overrated

Another fantastic addon for VTOL. The EF-24G is complex and well thought out. It adds two unique styles of play, it has versatility as a straightforward flighter, or can be used in it's very complex EW role. Long live the JamCat

This think is the peak of VTOL VR. I LOVE everything about this game but this brings it to a solid 11/10. It's gonna be hard to learn, most likely needs 2 people, but this thing is a workhorse of maneuverability and weapons/EW capability. Seriously, what are you waiting for? It's a 5th gen Tomcat.

*Highway to the danger zone intensifies!!!!!*
In all serious tho this is one of the best DLC/aircraft in the game. Carrier ops are more fun to do as you feel much like Mr Top Gun, EW is amazing and has made SEAD a lot harder(Which is something i prefer, maybe not for beginners), also you can troll friendlys with the EW pods now so enjoy free flight or any multiplayer mission with one person making your RWR beep for no reason 
Thanks Baha, for making my Christmas a lot better.

Very fun to fly and the EW is a great addition to the game. Haven't gotten a chance to fly with someone else yet but the EW is somewhat manageable flying solo. 100% worth buying.

The plane itself is VERY fast, you'll burn through your fuel in around 20 mins with the 2 fuel tanks that you can carry. The AIM-54s are great, and will win you most BVR fights you do in multiplayer. Air to ground ordinance is limited and I don't tend to engage ground targets nearly as much as with the other jets but the option is there. It also can't really dogfight since you'll rip your wings off but the AIM-54s will almost always get you a good few kills regardless (and you can carry a fair few AIM-9s or even AIM-120s as well just in case).

TLDR: good fun, super cheap, tomcat go vrooom.
The Average Game: It go zoom, fuel consume, and Aim 120 go big kaboom.

"This must be how Prez feels... except my pilot is incompetent, and I don't like him very much."
"F*** you, Ace."

But seriously this is great. Jamming is a full time job in the back seat but let's say you don't want to roll with a jammer and just want to be a Super Tomcat. Well that back seat is still useful. Take over radar management and keep the bad guys in the radar's view while the pilot steers and shoots. Still a lot of fun. Or how about doing recon for other units? Marking GPS targets for allies or yourselves to drop an entire payload of JDAMs and hit dozens of targets all at once in a display of shock and awe not seen since the Gulf War.

Simply put, this DLC is awesome.

Introduces a complicated new system to the game, that's great.

Does not include a tutorial on how to use said system, that's not great.

Also only has one unique mission included as far as I can tell (you can do free fly and the other generic missions that the other planes have). I obviously haven't been able to beat the single mission since I have no idea how the plane works . . . because there's no tutorial.

The variable wings are cool though.

This is again a game where I would like to have the option to just give a "mixed" review, and while I usually give a thumps up because others review games on minor nitpicks too harshly, I can't bring myself to it this time.
In general the game has a good atmosphere, it felt more like a horror game the two prior games, and the criticism about the game being too dark isn't invalid, but not a deal breaker since illumination is provided plenty. Also adding jumping and weapons to the game was a welcomed sight, since I missed the janky platforming in the second game. The story was also keeping me engaged enough to not feel discouraged by the presented flaws.

However, the negatives:
- The game is absolutely linear. You follow light spots to progress through a level, and that's it
- The combat didn't feel necessary. In the first game defeating an enemy opened up more recordings in the zone, here it was just there to have busy work and sometimes collect a singular voice line.
- The EVP content was almost non existent. While the first 2 games' main gameplay focus was deciphering voice lines and piecing together the story, it was now just a byproduct. You automatically collect 95% of the voice lines, they are automatically deciphered and you just need to piece together a message after a zone. The only remaining gameplay in that regard were the camera recordings that are optional content.
- To the prior point: in order to end the game you better be thorough collecting the voice lines, because otherwise you can find yourself replaying levels to even start the ending sequence.
- There were no puzzle elements, just walking through the level without any interactions with your environment and little to no environmental story telling.

So overall, the game did some things right, but lost its unique playstyle in the process. After playing the game, it confirmed to me that Sylvio 1 was by far the best entry in the series.

I had to restart this game from scratch because of a bug that makes multiple copies of the same phrase in the ghost records thing, but I finished it in the end.

The whole "phrase placement" puzzle that's very prominent and important is tough af and could be more streamlined, perhaps the same way the songs are used by isolating the correct phrase in the correct place from further movement instead of having to reconfigure ten phrases into something coherent; the idea of 100% correct only is agonizing for game play. I easily spent a good three hours additional just trying to finagle the phrases into the correct position.

The four weapons in the game could easily be reduced to two; one rifle type that can zoom and a pistol/smg type that alternates firing modes (semi/auto) depending on clicking or holding the mouse button. 

Hope this game will be patched for new players in the future though, especially with the puzzles in mind. I did like every other part of the game but the puzzles hurt me bad.

If this is the first time you've seen the name "Sylvio," then please understand that this is actually the third title in a series. Chances are, if you decide to start with BW before Sylvio 1 or 2, you'll be confused and frustrated, as the game starts immediately from the ending of the second title. I'd highly recommend at least experiencing Sylvio 1 before jumping into BW, as both games are very similar. 

For fans of Sylvio, that last sentence should probably catch your attention. I was wary when this game was first announced, I loved the atmosphere and music from Sylvio 2, but it was a huge downgrade from the preceding title. I'm happy to say that this release feels like a return to form. 

Continuing from Sylvio 2, Juliette now finds herself on a dead alien planet that looks eerily similar to our own. A strange device on the surface asks you to input an unknown code, and Juliette descends down into the depths of the planet to find it. Darkness envelopes you, strange glowing statues are scattered everywhere, and gravity defies all logic as you clamber around ruins that are illuminated by small pinpricks of light. This time around, Juliette has a companion by the name of "Lee", and unseen guide that helps her traverse the area. It's a refreshing change from the first two games, as the story is slowly revealed through the two's frequent conversations, and it requires less piecing together compared to the earlier titles. 

But how does BW compare to Sylvio 1? Hard to say. It's funny to see BW tagged with "exploration", as the game is pretty linearized. You follow set paths through the levels and you can't deviate at all. The only way through the game is forwards, and it'll drag you kicking and screaming if it has to. Linear levels aren't a huge deal breaker for me, but it can start to get old when the environments are too samey and drab. Every level that I've seen thus far can be described as "ruined buildings surrounded by trees." Even Sylvio 2 had unique levels (e.g. the hotel, the farm, the church), so it's a bummer to see BW's set pieces all blend together. That being said, I'm actually struggling to find some collectibles, so it's not linear to the point that it becomes a total snoozefest. Puzzles have also been removed, the game is now more combat focused. There's only a single enemy type, floating spirits, that you have to fend off, but you're given multiple weapons to choose from? A pneumatic pistol, a pneumatic shotgun, even a pneumatic submachine gun! I'm not exactly sure as to why they're included, as Sylvio isn't meant to be an FPS shooter. 

And yet despite the problems, I'm having so much fun. It feels like I'm replaying Sylvio 1 all over again. Sylvio has to be one of my favorite indie games of all time, and I recommend it because of its tone and atmosphere, not because it does anything innovative with its gameplay. I would recommend BW for that same reason as well: you walk through empty, desolate environments, with nothing to keep you company except for the cursed messages hiding in the static and the haunting synth chords of the soundtrack. The more you descend, the more you learn about the events that transpired here, growing that unsettling pit inside of you, the feeling that you're about to stumble across something truly evil and terrifying. We're not here to go in guns blazing, we're meant to dial back, sit tight, get lost in our own thoughts. So draw your blinds, turn off the lights, crank your volume all the way up. You've got some Sylvioing to do.

I would honestly recommend playing both Sylvio 1 and 2 before playing this.  I went out of the way to buy them before I played S:BW and while the 2nd game is a bit of a hard play I enjoyed my time getting here.

That being said, this games pretty nice.  It has this very moody vibe the entire time as you try to piece together what happened to the 18 humans and the astronauts that visited this alien planet.  There's moments of clarity that feel really emotional throughout the story and I found myself really enjoying the conversations Juliette had with Lee.  The gun returns from the first game but really isn't here to solve puzzles anymore, instead its mostly to fight the ghosts that will try to impede you.  The actual combat isn't anything too spectacular (and can be disabled) but I did find in the last two areas I found myself needing to conserve ammo or run away from enemies to survive.

Sylvio: Black Waters feels like a strange continuation of the previous two games.  There's still so many questions that need to be answered involving what or who "Sylvio" even is, and what was up with the aliens at the end of the 2nd game.  Though as a story on it's own I think it's pretty enjoyable.  It's absolutely a step up over Sylvio 2 and the story telling was fun.  The game IS very dark, though it does help give it that moody feel, and there's plenty of lights throughout the game to help navigate through the darkness.

Took me about 7hrs to beat, while completing almost all side objectives.
Good game. If the game is too dark... deal with it. Turn up your brightness, or just follow the lights that literally take you to the end of the game. Still awesome.

I was surprised they were making a 3rd Sylvio game. I really enjoyed this one. I highly recommend playing the first two before playing this one otherwise you will be confused. The game is DARK but I think I understand the developers intentions pretty easily. Just follow the lights it won't steer you wrong. The ambient music is great, the combat is an absolute dumpster fire. I may turn off enemy encounters on my next playthrough just because of how clunky and ridiculous it is.  I definitely recommend playing this game if you've played the other ones.  It's still not as good as the first game, maybe a little better than the 2nd. All in all worth a playthrough


8.1/10 will play again

About 9 years ago a very unique and underappreciated game by the name of Sylvio was released. It dealt with a really curious concept of EVP ‚Äì Electronic Voice Phenomena and made for a really cool and creepy ghost horror adventure with light combat mechanics. It had just the right amount of ambition for the one-person development team at Stroboskop, so while it was somewhat ugly looking and had lots of minor frustrating issues and bugs, the experience was unlike any other so the game was worth playing anyway. The game was to be followed up by an equally ambitious sequel that would move EVP research from audio to video, but, sadly, the Kickstarter campaign to support the development failed. Sylvio 2 that we got  two years later was simplified in most ways in comparison to the original and while it still had cool ideas (and one of its sequences with spectrograms still gives me nightmares), it was somewhat disappointing. A few years after the release of Sylvio 2, the developer decided to stop making games.

However, the rise of the ‚ÄúHaunted PS1 Demo Disc‚Äù and ‚ÄúDread X Collection‚Äù communities, releasing short form horror titles, got Stroboskop excited again and after participating in Dread X Collection 5 with the short title ‚ÄúKarao‚Äù, they‚Äôve decided to return to bigger games with this new release of Sylvio: Black Waters. Which I‚Äôm very happy about‚Ä¶ yet I can‚Äôt say that the resulting game is very good.

So, how does this game play? This is a first person action adventure that focuses mostly on story exploration with the story itself being a very bizarre mix of sci fi and folk horror. It‚Äôs difficult to explain and I can‚Äôt say it works in the end, but the idea is intriguing. The game world, just like in the first game, is divided into several linear levels, all of which are conceptually connected to a central overworld. Though in case of this game you get two overworlds ‚Äì one from which you get to revisit the linear levels (something that the original release of Sylvio didn‚Äôt allow), and one where you get to drive a‚Ä¶ bike-thing with a radio to follow the light to get to the next linear level. That last transitional type of level is, frankly, odd as it lacks the fun of exploration of the first two games (where you had a car and a boat respectively) and seems to be added just for ‚Äúcool vibes‚Äù I guess?

And you do get combat back, after it was completely absent in the second game. This time around your weapon doesn‚Äôt solve puzzles and is just used to fight ghost-like entities, but the main focus of the encounters is changed. In the original game you just had to defeat ghosts that spawned at specific parts of the exploration and that was it. In this game, all ghosts spawn from glowing human statues that you can usually see beforehand. And if you break the statue before it cracks open on its own, the ghost won‚Äôt spawn. But some of the statues do not spawn ghosts and your ammo resources are limited, so the gimmick here is basically on noticing the statues from far enough and deciding if you want to spend your resources on destroying them to potentially avoid the fight later. It‚Äôs a cute idea, that sets a very good methodic pace to your ‚Äúexploration‚Äù, but I can‚Äôt say it was that exciting.

Especially since, I did write ‚Äúexploration‚Äù in quotation marks for a reason. Sadly, for all of the cool ideas with levels changing gravity and folding onto itself and the potentially cool combat mechanics the game is aggressively linear. To avoid players accidentally landing on surfaces before the gravity is the right way around or falling between cracks, there are invisible walls everywhere and all you do is just follow the lights. Not because it‚Äôs easier to do, but because you can‚Äôt not do that. Granted, there are still plenty of spots you can fall and fly through the game potentially forever (perhaps there is a kill plane but I have not hit it when I had these bugs happen). It‚Äôs a real shame because even though Sylvio 2 was also hand-holding you constantly, it gave you plenty of choice and illusion of choice to feel more interesting than it was on a mechanical level. Whereas here, the game is the opposite to all of the cool ambitious ideas that made the original so interesting. It also contrasts heavily with something like Paradise Killer, which is more than happy to let you bunny hop through its world however you want, becoming a huge part of the fun you get from that game.

As for the EVP ‚Äì it‚Äôs still here, but so oversimplified and not interesting, it feels barely a part of the game, despite being vital to the game‚Äôs completion. You just gather the creepy voices and the big ‚Äúpuzzle‚Äù of the game isn‚Äôt about finding them, but about arranging them in order, which is often very poorly executed as there is only one correct solution, even if the lines presented can be set in any order and still be grammatically correct and mean the exact same thing. There is sound manipulation, with a video component included, in fact, but it‚Äôs not very interesting or engaging and is done for the optional stuff that doesn‚Äôt really lead into anything. In fact, most of the story here is just kinda ‚Äúvague creepy stuff‚Äù. And while the ending of the game might not be as silly as of the second title, it‚Äôs still more bizarre than good.

I am glad that Stroboskop is back into making games again. And purely in technical terms, I suppose Sylvio: Black Waters is the most competent project. But it‚Äôs also least memorable of the three and ends up feeling in some ways more disappointing even than the second game. I still enjoyed it, it has neat elements and cool atmosphere. But I can also easily see a lot of people completely dismissing this game and I won‚Äôt blame them.

Perhaps I need some story related context here, but I have absolutely no idea what's going on story wise and in my short time with the game so far I don't really feel compelled to figure it out. The game is dark yes, but it seems that was a stylistic choice based on some random plot device about the sun disappearing. However, this game is pretty boring to look at and the combat seems pointless. I'll probably play a little longer before refunding, but I don't think so. This definitely isn't worth the price because it feels like a half-baked tech demo.

I usually don't write reviews, but I just have to for this game
Just finished my first playthrough and i loved every second of it!
The atmosphere and sound design is as perfect as ever and the soundtrack is so good as well, also I loved the premise of the story and though I would recommend playing the first two games of the series to understand the story a bit better, I think it can also be played as a standalone
Absolutely fantastic game <3

[h1] Melancholic Creepy and Chill exploration [/h1] 
Great music and sound
the environments are atmospheric 
I also thought the voice acting was good.
The game is dark but uses points of light for navigation and i still found the environments to be interesting to take in. The mystery/story was compelling enough for me to finish it which is more then i can say for 80% of games in my library. 
I found the combat to be not great not terrible i found myself missing certain lines of phrases during combat encounters and i had to backtrack towards the end of the game which killed the pacing a bit. I think however that relative short length of the game was a good choice. Nothing overstays it's welcome and it does not become tedious.
Night sky radio lives rent free in my head.

I adore Dread XP games so it breaks my heart to give this game a poor review.  Dread XP games have a reputation for being good and spooky.  Sadly there is not much good here nor is there anything remotely spooky. From the beginning of the game, your entire objective is to follow lights on the ground as they lead you through different areas.  The game is dark, sure, but that's how the lights lead you. 

As you move from light to light, there will be some that have an extra sparkle, which make up the crux of the "game".  You will get a sentence or a phrase of a short story and the next sparkly spot gives another sentence.  You then need to put the story in order to get it told to you.  Since you can just hold down the button and it will tell you in what order the phrase goes, there's not much riddling to it. 

Same with tv monitors that you can pick up.  While it's a neat mechanic, it's totally optional and, as far as I can tell, serves no real purpose other than to hear a song. For these you will need to listen to a recording and then either speed it up or slow it down, backwards and forwards, to unscramble a phrase. Over and over, until you have all the lyrics  Neat, but pointless.

There are enemies, but again they are just sparkling lights that don't really seem to do much other than harass you, so much so that you can disable them in the menu.

The voice acting in the game is fantastic, Juliette is superb, but it doesn't make up for the rest of the "game". I put game in quotes because you are literally just walking, from light to light, through the entire game looking for ways to progress to the next area.

My first experience with Sylvio: Black Waters wasn't very good. It's a little rough on the edges (ugly interface, not having a loading screen etc) and it's very confusing at first. Had to see a walkthrough to discover what I was doing wrong. After that, I decided to restart and actually had a much better experience.

Sylvio: Black Waters is actually a very beautiful game, with it's dark, gloomy, surreal and mysterious landscapes. The story is kinda abstract at first but everything starts to make sense like a puzzle. Actually, it's more straight foward than the previous games, with a sad, dark and twisted sci-fi tale.

It's basically an exploration game with "words" collection that forms the lyrics of songs and stories that you have to solve.  It's not so scary like the previous games and that's actually a good thing. The atmosphere is very dense, transitioning from ominous to melancholic, but never stressful. The synth soundtrack is brilliant and could easily be a score for a good sci-fi mystery movie. Audio wise, it's near perfect. There's light gun combat which can be avoided and even turned off, but I actually found it cool. 

It really needs some fixes (like the invisible walls that make the sniper practically useless) but it still a good game, mainly because of the atmosphere, the soundtrack and the mystery. 

Tip: when you finish a Lungs stage, you return to a hub. Find the "office" and follow the tracks. Then get the bike and follow the light until you find another track to a new Lungs stage. I noticed that I wasn't the only one who got stuck in the game because I didn't understand this.
Sucks, it's too dark, it's a where do I go, what do i go game. I played for 30 mins until i fell through the map. I can't image playing it any longer than i did. sorry

Just finished playing this (link at end of the review for anyone who wants to see a gameplay sample). I was torn on whether to give this a thumbs up or a thumbs down. I‚Äôve decided to give it a tentative thumbs up just because there were aspects of the game I liked. However, this is one of those games where I wish Steam had a neutral option.

I liked Sylvio and enjoyed both previous games. Sylvio: Black Waters is the third instalment, but I felt it wasn't as good. It's... a'ight, I guess? It picks up where Sylvio 2 left off, with protagonist Juliette on another world - presumably having been taken there by the aliens. I say 'presumably', because the game doesn't make any reference to said beings or explain who or what they were, as far as I'm aware. What ensues is an exploration of this world, unravelling the story of what happened there.

Story-wise, the game's... just okay. It was engaging enough for me to stick with it, but I was hoping for something more. The story of Sylvio: BW feels like its own thing, and as far as I could tell didn't seem to have any substantial connection to the lore established in the previous games. Maybe I'm missing something here...

The sound design is good, and the graphics are fine. People have mentioned that they are very dark, which is true - but the path you need to take is typically lit, so there's little chance of you getting lost (except perhaps in the main hub area, where the game might benefit from giving you a waypoint just so you know which direction you're sometimes meant to be going).

Now let's talk about gameplay. Something new in this game is the gravity mechanic. For instance, you enter a new level and everything looks normal; then you find a ladder at a peculiar angle, and as you climb it the world around you turns and shifts, gravity begins moving in a different direction, and now the walls have become the floor, etc. It's a clever gimmick that enables the dev to take what are quite compact levels and make them seem bigger than they actually are, as well as find unique places to hide ghosts to record, etc. The only downside is that the levels are all fairly linear, whereas this sort of mechanic would benefit from level designs that are much more open and less linear (i.e. giving you multiple paths, thus giving the player more of a challenge and incentivising them to explore every corner in order to find the path they need to get that one ghost recording that is positioned in an odd location, etc).

Another thing I liked about Sylvio: BW‚Äôs gameplay was that the gun mechanic of the original Sylvio was brought back - and the dev has definitely improved on it. In fact, there are four guns in Sylvio: BW: a pistol-type; a shotgun-type; an SMG; and even a sniper. Like the gun in the original Sylvio, they take more than one type of ammo: fluid-filled cartridges for short range, or marbles for longer distances. Throughout the world of Sylvio: BW you'll find statues - the remnants of the planet's inhabitants. Many are inert, but some hide hostile spirits (which look like human shapes made of golden particles, contrasting with the smoky hostile spirits of the original Sylvio). Wander too close to a statue containing a hostile spirit, and they'll bust out to attack. Which is where the different types of ammo come into play. If a spirit busts out, then you need to use the fluid cartridges. But if you have marbles, you could alternatively try destroying a statue before you get close enough to trigger the spirit within, negating any danger. But of course, not all statues contain spirits! However, if you look hard enough, you'll never run out of marbles - search every piece of abandoned furniture you find in the ruins.

Nonetheless, I did have some criticisms of the weapons. I'm not sure the game needed as many guns as it provides - the sniper feels redundant given that your other weapons still have considerable range when loaded with marbles. Furthermore, defeating hostile spirits doesn't yield anything. In the original Sylvio, eliminating a hostile spirit would give an EVP recording (which might reveal clues, waypoints, etc). But in Sylvio: BW, this isn't the case. It would have been good for there to be a bit more of a reward to fighting off the hostile spirits.

Which brings me to the main gameplay mechanic of all Sylvio games: EVP (electronic voice phenomena). The original Sylvio had you use your ghost-recording equipment to unscramble the audio of the dead to yield clues. Sylvio 2 then brought in the video camera mechanic, where you'd also get a visual recording that you had to scan through. This enabled some great creepy moments where you would see ghostly grey figures in the footage, which helped give Sylvio 2 a horror atmosphere without any jumpscares. So how does Sylvio: BW compare?

If I'm brutally honest, the EVP mechanics felt bland by comparison. I hate to say it, but I didn't think they were as good as the first two games. Partly it's because most of the levels are linear, and the locations of all ghostly voices are marked out by a particle effect that is easy to see. In contrast, the original Sylvio did things differently: whilst some voice locations would be marked with waypoints based on clues you found in recordings, some would not - instead, you'd have to use Juliette's microphone to zero in on them (prompting more careful exploration of surroundings). Even Sylvio 2, which went more overboard on the waypoints, still had certain points that would only appear once you found particular clues. But in Sylvio: BW, neither of these are a thing. The locations where you conduct recordings are just a bit too easy to find, I guess?

What about visual recordings? Have they been brought back from Sylvio 2? Well, yes - throughout each level, you'll find cameras with footage on them, which you can unscramble to get song lyrics. But it felt like a downgrade from Sylvio 2. Firstly, the song lyrics are optional - you don't have to find them all, and they don't tell you anything you won't figure out from the standard ghost recordings. Secondly, the footage on these cameras is bland, usually just a dark close-up of something in your surroundings. Don't expect to see any ghostly figures appearing in them to creep you out. I don't recall ever seeing a single one, and I was kind of disappointed, because Sylvio 2 did it really well. What this meant was that Sylvio: BW just wasn't as creepy as its predecessors, in my eyes.

Lastly, there were technical issues. In the hub areas, my frame rate would often stutter. Adjusting graphics settings didn't seem to help, but outside of the hub areas the frame rate stabilised. Whilst my PC is getting on in age, it's still beefy - so I'm of the opinion that the frame rate jitters indicate some optimisation issues in the hub areas? Another technical issue (and this one was frustrating) was in one of the Lungs levels. After being killed by a hostile spirit, the game had to reload from the last checkpoint. But it glitched, and the level didn't load properly - it didn't remember which way the 'world' was meant to be facing (going back to the gravity mechanic mentioned earlier), leaving me stuck on a ledge. Upon falling off, I ended up falling through the world indefinitely. I'll post this on the bugs thread and hopefully the dev can patch it, but it was annoying because I was quite far into the game, and no matter how many times I tried reloading, the glitch kept occurring (which forced me to restart the whole game).

With all that said, I'm sure you can see why I had a bit of a struggle deciding whether to give Sylvio: BW a thumbs up or thumbs down. I'll go with the former just because there were certain aspects I liked, but I'll caveat that with my view that this is probably (in my opinion, at least) the weakest entry in the Sylvio franchise.

OASIS: Tokyo blends elements from big publisher games that we're familiar with into an original and engaging game for a price well below what you'll play elsewhere. The game operates on a mission system similar to the raids of Tarkov, where players will deploy to wipe out gangs of thugs, assassinate high value targets, or upload viruses in server networks.

To assist you in this there is a wealth of weapons and weapon customization, cybernetic implants, and a hacking system reminiscent of Cyperpunk. I enjoyed min-maxing different cybernetic builds for my character; I lost track of time grinding missions in order to afford a new rifle, and then lost track of time again fleshing my rifle out with scopes, stocks, grips and other attachments. Getting back to my apartment and sorting through my stash after a grueling mission was extremely satisfying and with enough work I built myself up to a tuxedo and armor-wearing John Wick eliminating gang after gang with my rifle and sidearm only to get wiped out by a Setcom tactical team and start from square one again.

As others have said the AI has room for improvement, and I'd love to see improvements to movement such as a lean and crouch/prone system. But overall the game is a blast and seems to be a real up-and-comer.

This is honestly so much fun. I've been looking for a single-player Tarkov experience and this scracthes that itch. Gunplay is solid, I don't see any issues here at all. Inventory managing works great as well. Graphics aren't anything to right home about but the music is fun and the overall atmosphere is on the cusp of cyberpunk if you like that. 

Oh and as a big fan of cyberpunk-esque stuff in general, the cyberware feature (that's part of the normal game) is awesome. The fact that you can create builds from cyberware/augmentations is *chefs kiss*. The developer also included more than one game-mode (I believe there are three: a rogue-lite mode of the endgame, a survival (think OG MW3) game, and one more). Not even a necessary addition but the dev decided to make it and I'm grateful for the above-and-beyond. Best bang for your buck on Steam in my opinion.

Although i understand it would probably mess up the current in game economy as of now. Now to the gun play it does feel like a simpler weighty version of tarkov but in a yakuza subway mafia type setting its very pleasing to be honest but every time i played a mission all I was thinking was i want to lean around corners with q and e and I want to be able to crouch the stamina mechanic also slightly doubling as a health/shield is fine but the movement just feels limited if you can polish up all those things this game has a bright future although for six bucks its still worth it as of now.

I really really want to recommend this but its an unbelievably buggy ass mess. Starting the game for the first time made it run at 4000fps and then crashed, restarted and tried the tutorial.  the first 2 enemies the tutorial showed me fell through the floor after completely ignoring me to shoot a wall. the tutorial was unbelievably dark as well and really terrible at teaching you anything. I pushed through, played my first map, went alright had enemies clip through doors constantly which almost killed me. the hub area for some reason makes my PC chug, a PC that can run Doom Eternal.  I played my second mission and i started really liking it, i found a weapon stash of an mp5, scorpion, auto shotgun, and tons of other stuff. In this time i completely lost all my stamina, which is way way way too low, even if you can restore it in the hub, its worse that old cod sprint times. Another annoyance is swapping weapons in your inventory, you cant just drag and swap them, no you must drop them entirely, then put your weapon you want in the now open slot, look down and pick up your dropped gun.
the hub despite being a square is so damn confusing since its all untextured city corridors, i spend most my time there just forgetting which way was is the level starter. The players house is a random 2nd floor room in a stairwell too which got obnoxious to find everytime.
Here is where my biggest issue comes in.  You for some reason (that at least i know) cannot remove a mag from an equipped gun, you have to put it in your inventory to do so. so i go sure ill do that, theres no enemies, and the one Im tracking is in the next room, she doesn't know Im here, doors closed Im safe.  I suddenly hear her clunky voice line activate and see a shotgun barrel stick through a wall, Dead instantly. that's absolutely wild, and frustrating. 
I went that sucks, ill load up another level then, goodbye good loot that i unjustly lost. loaded in to enemies already looking at me, in the exact same map, despite being entirely across the city map apparently, i survived somehow, tried reloading my gun, for some reason despite not making it do so it dropped out of my inventory, despite doing the proper reload, struggling to find it i hear 4 more voices activate, and every single one gormlessly clips through the closed door and guns me down. Im taking a hiatus after that.

its really frustrating cause this game mechanically is everything ive wanted, a tactical customization single player looter shooter like tarkov. when the game works its so much fun, i l o v e inventory management, and upgrading loot through instanced areas, but stamina needs reworked, and these bots need some play testing.  i will cautiously hope and wait for better patches.

OASIS: Tokyo is undeniably a diamond in the rough. Graphics are bog-standard Unity schlock. Movement, aiming, and physics are gloriously dysfunctional. Missions are repetitive. Enemy AI is bewilderingly stupid. User interface is janky. There can't be more than 3 songs and a couple dozen voice lines in the whole game. Unexplained FPS drops are unfortunately common.

And yet, it nails the looter-shooter sweetspot so hard, it's worth taking a second look despite everything. Gunplay and core game mechanics are far more developed than a first impression might imply.

Guns are fun to fiddle with and fun to shoot. Variety of weapons and attachments is decent. Ammo and inventory management are meaningfully integrated into FPS gameplay. Enemy encounters almost always pose a genuine threat. Layers of branching build progression and customization make additional playthroughs worthwhile. Difficulty settings ensure the game is accessible to practically any skill level. And gameplay never feels slow, thanks to stacking energy drink buffs cranking your character's movement up to speeds that would put Sonic the Hedgehog in the ER.

At $6.99 USD, the dollars-to-fun ratio is a no-brainer.

It's already a great and entertaining game, and it will continue to get better. That's my guarantee.

People are sleeping on this one. Was a bit put off when I realized you couldn't loot bodies, but there is enough loot scattered throughout the map that adding full loot on kills would slow the game to a crawl. Shooting feels good, and there are a wide variety of firearms. Some are better than others, and some balancing is a little weird. An UMP-45 (SMG) takes two headshots to kill while a Colt 1911 (Literal starting pistol if you skip the tutorial) takes 1 despite being the same caliber. As of writing, there is no lean or crouch function, the former being slightly more odd of an omission than the latter because of how Tarkov-esque the firearm damage and healing system is. Some of the randomly generated maps can get repetitive, but the core gameplay loop is so addictive that it doesn't matter that much after awhile. Combat in this game is quick and deadly, and sometimes you're better off fleeing with your stuff than getting caught between waves of reinforcements. Still plenty of room for this game to grow, but for $7USD, this is an easy recommendation.

A fun little single player shooter that takes the inventory/economy management from an extraction shooter, and applies it to a mission based structure. You won't be getting huge open levels you can loot and 'quest' to your hearts content here, but much smaller, levels generated specifically around an objective, which you will have to complete before extracting. You can extract without the objective but you'll take a reputation hit, but sometimes its worth it if you're low on supplies and don't want to lose your gear.
The combat feels good enough, It's not the best shooter I've ever played mechanically but it does the job (what I wouldn't give for a lean function! or even just a crouch to better loot low items).
There's a nice bit of mission type variety, and the locations get more varied as you progress in the reputation system.
Overall, I definitely recommend, the game is fun in its current state, and there's room for it to get even better.

Review: 7.2/10

I got stuck and refunded, but engaged the Dev who kindly wrote the following when I asked what to do upon completing the tutorial. (see below).

Originally posted by PavelLeksinCG:
Click on the places marked with a small golden triangle. There you can buy things, take orders.
Always check the book in the upper left corner of the screen when you select an order. There you can see what you need to complete the order.
1) Finish the ladder and the door orders.
2) Buy the owl feathers and the leather belt.
3) Complete the bow order, buy the horns.
4) Look at the axe order - get a message that you need to upgrade your forge. Go to your house/forge. Upgrade the forge. Put the Grinding Stone in a vacant slot in the forge.
5) Go back and complete the axe order.
6) Buy the leather

Now you have a new location, new orders, etc. You can always repeat an order if you failed to fulfill it. All materials regenerate, you don't need to restock or buy again. There are repeatable orders in the game, so you can earn money as much as you want. These are marked with a double box. You'll find them when you complete the Tavern location. Use the "Help" menu to read tips on each of the tools.

I was able to continue and enjoy this (very) nice and unique game, for the responsiveness of the developer alone, I recommend you future blacksmiths give this game a try.

Really neat concept, but instructions are sorely lacking leaving little room for error. I understand maintaining some sense of reality but there are better ways to control a hammer and the physics on the saws are utterly infuriating

Really janky controls, buggy as hell, menus dont work properly, ive been locked out of completing a task as the metal saw doesnt work anymore, i cant upgrade my workshop even though i have the funds and have no idea how much it costs to upgrade my house as this doesnt show either, very janky buggy game for the price. feels like a late 2000's free to play flash game.

The interface is a bit janky. The audio balancing is wacky at times - my cats got scared when an audio sample of "angry cat meowing" blasted at full volume, disproportionately louder than music or other sounds. The rare voiceovers are done using text-to-speech, and not of the latest advanced interations clearly. The turorial is overbearing, so I skipped it after a while and started a new game without it. Fortunately it wasn't too difficult to figure out what to do. The game could use some minor polish here and there.

HOWEVER! Despite all that, [b]I'm absolutely loving[/b] the gameplay! It's probably one of the best blacksmith games out there, with the focus on making items, rather than managing the forge or economics.
This is more of a puzzle game, where players have to use various tools and materials to assemble an item as close to the blueprint as possible. You can saw wood or bone, hammer and bend metals into various shapes, use sharpening stone, pin components together, add ropes, leather straps, belts, buckles, spikes and many many more things and available tools.
Progressing through the story unlocks new unique orders with gradually increasing complexity, which in turn does a great job at teaching the player new techniques that will come in handy later.

My first axe that I made was a real piece of garbage. It looked hilariously bad. But over time I became better at hammering metals into shapes that I want. And it's SOOOO satisfying to complete an order with 99% accuracy!

If you like involved gameplay that consists of meticulous tinkering, measuring and experimenting - Blacksmith Song of two Kings will be right up your valley!

Good concept, badly explained. Like the trash bin being beneath the material drawer on the left side. Or the hammer and rivets is only limited to 13. Makes my blood boil whenever you've come that far, and can't finish the creation.

So because of this, thumbs down from me so far. Explain more, make things more intuitive and let us come back to whatever wee were working on after going out to get materials, or more materials. I don't know how to even get more than 13 rivets for the grid-gate.

Blacksmith. Song of two Kings is a unique blacksmithing title and the answer is yes, I'm the best blacksmith this side of town.

Since writing this review I'm 93 hours in and still thoroughly enjoying it. I play it on and off, and it's also super great if multitasking to background audio or listening to your gf. Nonetheless, it's still a difficult game to master and I had to look the game creator's owl blacksmith video to get some tips. Originally, I thought it was only about shaping items, but the game, strangely enough, has a lot more going for it than I originally thought. As the best blacksmith in town, I need to manage what tools I will take to the smithy with me, what guests can stay at the house (to help improve the business and/or smithing) and what current items and bonuses to use as well, which supplement guests (each with their own story) and their relative items. It doesn't just end there. There's a progression system, an interesting story, a map with fog of war, and gold to earn for your business (upgrading the buildings, buying materials and taking on certain jobs). Later, there's magic and morality (like cursed/blessed properties) you can later imbue in your craft with the help of guest witches and necromancers. Yes, being a good blacksmith requires a whole range of skills.

I cannot find much fault to the game, but it does have its own set of problems. However, the art style and crafting physics are really enjoyable, so for me they are easily overlooked. I thoroughly recommend Blacksmith. Song of two Kings to anyone who enjoys a bit of a challenge but at their own pace and to people who really appreciate this kind of immersive art style, and especially to those blacksmiths that have a talkative partner. Currently at 93 hours and judging by the map, I think I have another 30-40 hours before I complete the campaign.

[h2]PROs[/h2] 

+ Fantastic art - everything is drawn
+ satisfying skill based crafting system, especially the shaping of metal
+ Great music and atmospheric sounds
+ Intriguing and indepth story, even though I was not too interested
+ House, item management and business management of blacksmithing
+ Allows for creativity to solve many problems
+ Take your time and relax
+ You can cheese the % recognition marker for crafting of items (sometimes makes unnecessarily difficult items easier to craft) 
+ Great and quick support from the creator of the game with any help, including bugs
+ Tons of jobs, and many repeatable jobs
+ High difficulty - without thorough preparation for the material the order needs, you may need to restart or make the item again later and many jobs have extra optional requirements for extra rewards
+ Fantastic crafting effects, especially the magical side

[h2]CONs[/h2]

- Since everything is drawn, cutting and shaping materials can cause the item to lose its depth so it does not look as good anymore
- Overly stretching and bending metal can cause some odd properties 
- Items are not built for utility or practicality but rather to complete certain criteria (-immersion)
- You can cheese the % recognition marker for crafting of items (- immersion) 
- Occasional bugs
- Low replayability
- All information needed is available in-game but initially knowing where to look is sometimes unclear


This title reminds me of passionate and love projects like Papers, Please, Hammerfight, Delta V : Rings of Saturn, and Highfleet. I definitely recommend Blacksmith. Song of two Kings. Get your blacksmithing on!

Only option was to close the tab, which its frustrating when you're almost done making something."

I'm really loving this game so far! The control scheme is incredibly unique, and while a little rough around the edges (UI prompts and general explanation for things could also use a little work) it's nothing that a bit of experimentation and a whole lot of practice can't fix. 

This game really allows you to express pride in your work: sure, you can trick that little number in the corner into thinking you did a good job, but when the time comes to hand it in and you're forced to look at the misshapen monstrosity you created, it really does make you feel a little guilty for not trying a bit harder. 

The feeling of finally perfecting a sword edge and comparing it to past attempts - seeing how much I've actually improved - is something I've not yet seen in other games. It's a charming little indie game and I'm enjoying it quite a bit!

this is a really good game, i only wish for a blacksmith game that had the same mechanic but it would just be you selling commissions like doing work, from that money buying supplies, upgrading and keep it going, while it still has some of this. I just still wish it would scratch this itch of mine. Hopefully one day it will come, but i fully recommend this.
Big flash game vibes, very chill game to play with a video in the background. The dialogues are pretty rough (maybe just bad translation or written by AI) but the game-play is good enough to cover.

This game is awesome! It's like the game Potion Craft but for blacksmithing. Its super satisfying as well. The only real critique I have is that it is somewhat buggy when it comes to hammering and forging items. Also the saw tools collide with items and that's super annoying to work around. Other than that, this is a great concept and executed beautifully!

Its got some rough/bugyness to some of the mechanics, but Ive been waiting for this kind of hands-on crafting sim for a long time!  Hammer, metal into shape with "realistic" physics.  Cut wood.  bend rods in your vice.  Do whatever you can to match your blue-prints.

This is an excellent "chill-out" title in a similar fashion to Potion Craft.

The game is not perfect. The execution can be improved, especially the UI and the controls. It needs A LOT of QOL changes (can I have zoom please?). Regardless, I love it. I believe there is no other crafting/ smithing game with this approach. 

I'm really bad with my hands (I blame my lack of dexterity) but I love crafting and tinkering in real life. This game reflects that accurately - as what I craft looks very bad or I spend too much time in one craft just to make it acceptable. LOL. But that's the beauty of it. I've been pretty stressed lately and going to the forge late at night helps me relax and unwind.

I recommend the game because I wanted to support its development. Despite being a "finished" game, it lacks polishing and can sometimes feel like Early Access. Regardless, I wanted others to try the DEMO first and judge the game for itself. I believe it will be a lot better after a few updates. You never know, the game might just 'click' with you, as it did to me.

EDIT: +10 recommendations because the developers are lit. God bless them.

Great game few hick ups an quirks that are QoL & control sensitivity but an awesome blacksmith game you can guild an feel the metal move not perfect but a nice start and it has free creation an "mission" builds easily guide an build your skill progression an ideas of what to build over all a awesome cozyish game

I do not recommend this game in its current state.  The frustrating controls and the many mechanics that are not explained, prevent me from getting further in the game.  I had to reset multiple jobs because the materials would disappear or the crafted item would not register as complete.

Great and fun simulation, although it feels cheaty sometimes (i. e. in the bending state, the game does not simulate forging). But this is not fun as a game. I often find at the end of the creation process, that I've missed something. And thus I am required to abandon my work and start again.

Loved the game, pretty fun

Especially liked the part where it crashed, sent me back roughly 30 minutes in progress, crashed again while I was redoing the candle stand two times in a row and now I'm too scared to open it up again because I have 6 minutes left before being able to refund it.
The controls are a disaster (can't see all items in inventory), and the tutorial dos not teach you anything (click here, click that).

So this is really fun.

I'm using legit blacksmithing techniques to solve real blacksmithing problems. Like, how do I get an even curve on a metal rod? A vice, a hammer, consistency and patience.

This ain't cooking mama. You're mostly using the same raw materials and the same tools to make different objects, which is the most 'feels like crafting' experience I've had in a game. And, like, games that try to simulate crafting are my entire jam.

The 'overworld' 'you are running a shop' economic sim part is barely there, but just there *enough* to make me feel like I'm playing a crafting game, not a puzzle game, if that makes sense. Very welcome, very good use of limited dev resources.

The whole project is really tightly put together, gorgeous, small-but-with-a-lot-of-gameplay, and does a unique physicsy thing, reminding me of Hammerfight by Konstantin Koshutin.

I see quite a few comments talking about how bad the physics and control can be. 

That's true, honestly. Like a tool meant to let you bend metal where the metal can easily get stuck in it. That's been a fairly minor irritant so far though, as have all the others. It's sometimes incredibly hard to get metal in the shape you want it, also, in extreme cases to the point of feeling impossible.

But then, I didn't come here for perfection, I came here for Swinging Hammer. And let me tell ya if you're as obsessed with smithing as I am, this is a good one. Annoyances or no, it does capture the feeling of carefully hammering something out, carving, nailing, etc, and there's satisfaction in getting something that [i]looks good[/i]. Take some time, get used to the controls. It mostly became second nature to me after the first half hour or so, and by that point I'd forgotten I had only intended to give it a quick try before switching to another game. So yes, I recommend.

Do you enjoy messing with unintuitive controls? Do you like QWOP? Because if QWOP made a blacksmithing game, it'd probably be a lot like this. Trying to line things up to bend in this game is ridiculous. The hammer rotation mechanics are awful as you try to angle it just right in this 2D environment where you bump into everything. And then when you try to clamp onto the anvil, it gets jammed and you can't use the horn to bend your metal at all. A great concept, but overall incredibly frustrating controls.

While this game is far from perfect, it does more than many other similar item creation games manage: actually creating the items yourself.
Most crafting mechanics require you to simply gather the raw materials into a single area and then it becomes a predefined shape. I never really feel satisfied with these sorts of mechanics because I don't have any control over what the result actually looks like.
In this game, you need to actually deform and arrange the raw materials into the shape you need, and it's the deformation forging that really got me hooked. You can customize an order to look how you would like it, and there's even a "free play" option to make literally anything.
My only real complaint is that it sounds like voice acting (there's not a lot of it, but it's there sometimes) is AI generated, but it looks like this is just one single person's passion project, so from one indie game dev to another I understand why.

Developer is fairly responsive and pays attention to the bugs and issues. So thats a major plus already.

The game is kinda a puzzle crafting game where you have to do your best to work out how to move metal with the tools you have on a 2D plane, which can be conceptually difficult until you practice a bit.
The controls can be a bit janky and it absolutely feels like its been designed to play on a tablet, which is not a negative in itself, but does lend itself as a reason to the odd controls.

I have almost 11 hours on record so far and will be continuing to play through as its probably the best crafting game, and singularly best blacksmithing game, I have ever played.

If you are into blacksmithing and medieval craft, this game is a must buy

I think I've encountered a numerical glitch in the game. On the first project to do for the thugs in the northeast part of the kingdom to the northeast, it requires a pretty simple dagger to be made. However when I go to select the order its saying I have to pay 99650 gold as a fee in order to take it on. Has anyone else had this issue?
Just not good enough physics mechanics for the game, materials constantly getting stuck on objects that are supposed to be used together. Unclear instructions from tutorial also.

Really cool game with cool mechanics.

The start is a bit rough and could be more streamlined. 

Else its pretty cool

6e... that s the appropriate price for that game in this current state.
It s an early access at best, with bad audio. 

I played the demo for about 6h, so that s my review after 13h of gameplay.
DON'T BUY.

--- for more details ---
When I played this game, what was passing through my mind was "I m sure it would be easier to do it in real life..." (then that's this game offers).
- The space where I crafted was cramped. It s difficult to move things around without hitting other pieces.
- You have the list of materials needed for the recipe only before crafting, never during.
- You have no way to trace the schematics on your plank of woods. So cutting angles on planks is a nigthmare.
- You have no way to mark a line on iron. So making angles at the right spot is a guessing game.
- The rail on the grinding wheel can be adjusted, but not horizontally. Moving a piece through the rail to have a straight edge is unecessary difficult.

The voices have static. All of them. And it s an AI reading a script monotously.

Otherwise the game has good art, the story was okay and the world building was actually really nice.
I would have enjoyed discovering more of this imaginary world if it wasn t such a chore.

Complete.

Great game about forging, but to be almost perfect it would need some UI/UX quality life improvements: 
-When choosing what items to bring, the highlighted items are almost identical as the non highlighted
-Once you are in the forge, you dont know exactly what items you need to use to forge, so for example you dont know if the base of a weapon is a wood or metal base
-When created an intermediate item, it stays there, you can't store it for later, so it can be annoying because it collides with the other collider items and tools
-If you make a big mistake and add something by error to a weapon (which hapenned to me), you can't undo it, so it could cause you to fail and you would need to restart everything again, frustrating
-Ropes physics are frustrating too, sometimes they go crazy
-...

way to many glitches literally had to retry a level 5 time cuz the protection was to low even tho i did everything right. and you can so easily get soft locked cuz you spent your money on the wrong things and you cant do any contracts because they cost to much

Has it's quirks. Control of the hammer could be better, but skill comes with practice. The only way to save the game is to exit via the menu, so I've lost progress before assuming that there was an autosave and Alt+F4ing. Sometimes the ingots get a bit wonky if worked too much. BUT, it's also the best blacksmithing game I've played thus far. Hope the dev sees this as positive encouragement to keep plugging away at projects like this.

Great therapeutic blacksmithing game! Start out crafting ladders and tavern signs, work you way up to magical artifacts for the kingdom's greatest knights, and have a lot of fun the whole time! While some interface elements could use some refining, the crafting is mostly intuitive and satisfying. Highly recommended if the premise appeals to you!

Great game! After finding your way to use the controls, it`s a relaxing crafting game.

The new game of Blacksmith: Song of two Kings has positively surprised me. 
The gaming process is captivating from the very first minute. What particularly pleased me was the tutorial ‚Äì straightforward yet detailed, without unnecessary information.
The game immediately draws you in. The thrill of completing each task is great. You can feel the difficulty level increasing, but it only adds to the game's excitement. The satisfaction from each stage completed is gripping, urging you to tackle more challenging tasks. You immerse yourself in it and lose track of time.
Blacksmith: Song of two Kings has the potential to be one of those games that linger in your memory. I recommend it to everyone who appreciates quality gaming. Even veterans in this genre will find much fun.

I am not one to comment on games but I feel like this dev deserves it! 
This is one incredible little big game. Extremely cozy but at the same it gets me hooked with the story bits and overall world. The forge system takes a while to understand and get the hang of, but once you do it's very magical. So far I have been having a blast albeit not having much time to play. And the developer is very kind listening to the community's opinion. 
Be prepared to learn how to bend metal, cut wood in circles and all that. But one nice thing is that you can always do some workarounds and still make it work. For example, I failed in bending a metal so I cut in 3 shapes, fixed them all and still got 100% accuracy (since the shape was there I just used 3 more screws), which I really like : )
If you want a true blacksmith simulator, with nice physics and all the mechanics I truly recommend this game. 
So far my only gripe is the screw animation could be a little bit faster (maybe there is an upgrade in the game which I still haven't found).
Edit: yes there is a way to speed it up haha (now I am getting destroyed by the curved daggers)
good but saws are a bit janky but still pretty good
First blacksmithing game I have found that feels like an actual blacksmithing game.
One of the best carpal tunnel simulator I've ever played

I am thoroughly enjoying this game.
Yeah, the interface and the controls can get quirky at times, like with every physics-based games, but nothing game breaking.
The gameplay is very unique and the story mode is very well put together and has a nice addictive reward loop going (fulfil crafting order > make money > buy advanced crafting tools and components > upgrade your forge > fulfil more complex order > etc etc).
I grabbed this on sale but it is easily worth the full price!

I found this game by accident but it is just a really fun crafting simulator??? It has a similar vibe to potioncraft in that when you work out the best way of doing things it feels rewarding. There is a story and plot too but the crafting is definitely the focal point. I've been treating it as a game to pop into when I need some chill time and it's great.
i really like the game... but it is a bit Overpriced for what it is..

This game really does give you a satisfying blacksmith experience with a fun variety of orders to complete. I recommend anyone interested even a little to give the demo a try like I had, your progress in the demo will transfer into the full game. I was hooked after the 3rd order and all progress was still there and I was even prepared to start over if need be. Finding creative ways to fulfill the orders and problem solving builds truly feels like becoming a more competent blacksmith and I found myself developing my own work flow, where it once took many tens of minutes to finish a meager knife I was now pounding out flawless longswords in 15 minutes with little to no hick-ups.

Only complaint I have is a minor one that is a non-issue to me because I tend to watch videos while I play games would be the voice lines from the companions and the soundtrack. Companion lines sound like they came off an old floppy disc point click adventure from the 90's, like come on you can find door bells with better recording quality. Soundtrack I found to be alright for all of the 3 minutes it didn't feel like a loop. 

Everything else about the game I can say I enjoy or at least see the reasoning behind, easy recommendation to anyone who likes to get creative and enjoys challenging themselves to develop strategies.
Awesome with more songs! Looking forward to more releases ^^
Good songs. Would buy more.

Neat little physics game with mind-boggling controls. Description is apt: easy to learn hard to master. Similar to other rage games, prepare to have your progress destroyed due to your own incompetence.

It's fun! Worth the purchase.

For a free demo I will say this was a lot of fun and the progression feels rewarding while also adding to the challenge of having to travel further out from the tree in the middle. 
The physics are a fun addition and adds a lot to the aesthetic, however this does have you tripping over every residual rock and tree root left from mining/cutting trees.

Overall a positive experience, I only wish there was a way of marking each 'island' with a resource symbol or note, as after you mine an area its quite hard to remember what resource was there after clearing it.

While the water totem is a nice additional extra, it would be nice if you could manually regrow a resource with an item like a watering can, as often I found myself waiting for yellow flowers to grow (with the water totem) just to make fuel for the resource replenishing fire to make some progression.

9/10 would recommend

How collectibles work:
I thought I lost 2 of my e8 shermans but turns out if you assign them to one regiment, you cannot assign them to another. So with that in mind I had put 2 of them into my 1st tank regiment, moved onto the medium regiment and thought they were 'consumed'. They are not consumable they are permanent, and you can buy as many as you want with supplies earned in game in order to spread them across multiple regiments, they are also not overpowered as they are just reskins of default vehicles like the regular e8. That said the flamethrower sherman is pretty cool and good for anti-infantry would recommend unlocking that fairly quickly.

Wish there was somewhere that actually gave you the full rundown of how collectibles work but trial and error is fine ;)

Despite being a VR to PC port, this is probably the best way you could do it. Controls feel responsive, it's challenging but not annoying, immersive but not pretentious. All-in-all a very terrifying fun experience.

Oh and of course for those who have seen the movie "Das Boot" this is a dream come true.

In my short time playing and lack of people to play with (and horrible internet connection reliability overall), I've rather enjoyed myself in this desktop experience and am strongly considering grabbing the main game for use in VR, and outside of VR. I've turned on all the assists and was still left with the challenge of not tunneling on one task and overall navigating the submarine through minefield peppered waters. Don't think I'll be getting the gold medals very often, but managing to multi-task the submarine into a silver or even bronze time is still a feel-good moment. I especially like how there's no geometry involved in making torpedo runs and that the gunnery is very intuitive even outside VR, just straightforward tasks to be done.

I have had a mild gripe on the mouse interaction in regards to fast-acting with gunnery though, I'll stand myself off to the "corner" so as to have quick access to shells and quick load them into the gun and pull the trigger, all in one semi-smooth operation. The gripe comes in where sometimes the little green status/menu screen will sometimes overlap with the trigger depending on where I'm standing, but this is largely resolved with just changing up position a little bit and carrying on.

Another small thing is that I don't believe the sonar station or the hydroplanes have been covered in the tutorial, nor any mention of the player having a compass, spyglass, or little map/speed/depth tool in their inventory spheres, but I was able to quickly figure those out. I do especially like the little pocket chart that gives quick orders for surface/periscope depths, speeds, and being able to pick out a direction. Functionally I could sit in the weapons station, check the hydrophones for a quick scan for targets, peek up with periscope, adjust course, manage torpedo locks, all in one convenient location and makes singleplayer usage quite a bit more smooth.

Noteable experience: I did get tunnel vision in sinking merchants in mission 3 and have ran into a mine which caused three leaks whilst I was at periscope depth, I was in the weapons room at the time where all the leaks were. I went to the helm, set the hydroplanes to full ascend, went back to the other room and welded a leak shut. Realizing stopping would be a good idea to prevent another mine hit, I went back to helm to stop/slow the sub before going back to fix the other two leaks. As I was putting the welder away in my room traversals, I noticed an odd toolbox-looking object in one of my inventories, checking it out and discovering that it was the aforementioned map/control thing. Wound up finishing the mission, took about 14 minutes to get done as I was navigating mines and running subsurface to avoid planes, but will definitely have to give it some more goes later on.

Overall, yeah I'm gonna put the main game on the wishlist. Cheers~

Cold Waters could take a lesson from Iron Wolf in sub controls, but Iron Wolf could take a lesson from Cold waters in user Interface and commands.
Cold Waters gives ability to see targets that could not otherwise be seen, a failure on their part as that is not how subs work. This is not a review of Cold Waters though.

Maybe the non free version is better but this is not a bad review. While the interface and how one has to manipulate it is lacking in my opinion, Iron Wolf does a fine job of Sub control and Mechanics. As one reviewer put it, it was an exciting time of seeing nothing. That is submarine combat. A tactical solution in a graphical void.
Me and my 2 vegetable friends got qualified to pilot a submarine (we have 30 minutes of experience).

While the game does function well enough, it is still a far better option to opt for the VR option. The only reason I would recommend the game would be more of a "demo" as to what features would be available in VR. 

The other issue between the games is the speed at which different actions occur. The locomotion of actions, such as loading torpedoes manually, are vastly different in speed. Additionally, the interactions measures often are difficult to manage between adjacent ones. For example: Opening a latch on a door vs pulling on the door are often difficult to differentiate. 

However, the true negative to the game is the lack of free-roam. This is the real bread and butter of the game, and is a key piece missing in the current form. While my opinion might improve slightly if it were added, I would still only suggest getting the game as more of a test/demo. 

The other point to consider is the online community for the game. While the game is clearly meant to be enjoyed with multiple people, you will often find it to be rather "empty". While the Non-VR game is new, the VR counterpart is not. Both have, at best, a fledgling online community, making multiplayer a rare encounter. Unless you have friends joining to play, I would caution expectations on that regard, instead viewing it more a solo-game.

Marionette Eden Breakers? A Mixed Fantasy Adventure with Sensual Twists! (‡∏Ö'œâ'‡∏Ö)

[h1][b][1] Intro : [/b][/h1]

Marionette Eden Breakers is a hack-and-slash action title revolves around the premise of defeating monsters to become more powerful, a concept that initially piques interest. As you progress, you can acquire a variety of weapons, and the more monsters you vanquish, the more powerful your arsenal becomes, enabling you to deliver overwhelming attacks. Additionally, the inclusion of H-animations adds a unique aspect to the game, catering to a specific niche.

[h1][b][2] Game Experience : [/b][/h1]

However, the game is not without its shortcomings. Some players have voiced their disappointment in the lack of a compelling narrative, as Marionette Eden Breakers seems to lean heavily on its predecessor, Marionette Eden. Furthermore, the H-scenes, a significant selling point for some players, are notably brief and lack voiceovers, detracting from their impact. The battles themselves have also come under scrutiny, with some players finding them less engaging than the standards typically seen in the hack-and-slash genre.

One aspect that particularly stands out as a drawback is the absence of character reactions during battles. Players have noted that clothing doesn't sustain damage, and there's a lack of representation of the characters' struggles as their health depletes, which ultimately impacts the game's immersion.

[h1][b][3] Verdict : [/b][/h1]

In summary, Marionette Eden Breakers offers an interesting mix of action and adult content, but it falls short in some critical areas. While the concept of powering up through monster-slaying and the inclusion of H-animations have their merits, the underwhelming narrative, uninspiring battles, and short H-scenes without voiceovers leave room for improvement. Gamers seeking a more fulfilling hack-and-slash experience may find more satisfying options elsewhere. However, those interested in a unique combination of cute heroines and adult content at an affordable price might still discover something to enjoy in Marionette Eden Breakers.

[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
Hentai Abigail is a Unity based swap puzzle game. Select a piece and swap it with another piece, continue until the picture is complete.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You are shown what the completed puzzle looks like, prior to the pieces being rearranged. Select a piece and then select a second piece to swap. If you are in a hurry you can expand the hamburger menu and select the heart icon to auto complete the puzzle.

There are ten puzzles. All of the puzzles only have eight pieces. I was able to complete all ten in less than five minutes.

All of the images, except for the last one, are just woman by herself.

[h1]The Gallery[/h1]
There is no Gallery. You need to replay the puzzle in order to view the completed image again.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
An inexpensive swap puzzle game with 10 images and 10 achievements.
