[h1]CyberLink PowerDirector 2024 Ultra: An Ice Wolf's Masterpiece Review[/h1]

[i]By Kiba Snowpaw, Furry Alpha Male Ice Wolf of HowlStrom[/i]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Introduction[/h2]

Greetings, my fellow furries and tech enthusiasts! I am Kiba Snowpaw, an experienced Ice Wolf from the frosty lands of HowlStrom. Today, I'm diving into the depths of CyberLink PowerDirector 2024 Ultra, a software that promises to elevate your video editing skills to new heights. With 37+ years of expertise and countless software trials, this Ice Wolf is here to give you the lowdown on all the highs and lows of this powerful tool.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Basic Overview[/h2]

CyberLink PowerDirector 2024 Ultra is a professional-grade video editing software designed to cater to both novices and experienced editors. From stunning visual effects to seamless transitions, this software packs a punch with its AI-enhanced features and user-friendly interface.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Originality[/h2]

PowerDirector 2024 Ultra brings a unique blend of advanced AI tools and intuitive design, setting it apart from other video editing software. The inclusion of AI Body Effects, Motion Tracking, and AI Sky Replacement showcases its innovative approach to video editing.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]The Studio: CyberLink and Deep Silver[/h2]

Developed by CyberLink and published by Deep Silver, PowerDirector 2024 Ultra reflects the expertise and commitment of these industry giants. CyberLink's continuous innovations and Deep Silver's publishing prowess ensure that users receive top-notch software backed by reliable support.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Analysis/Evaluation[/h2]

[b]Key Features[/b]
[list]
[*][b]AI Body Effects:[/b] Automatically wraps stunning visual effects to the contours of moving bodies.
[*][b]Video Outros:[/b] Create high-quality, engaging sign-offs for your videos.
[*][b]Enhanced Transitions and Visual Effects:[/b] Seamlessly connect shots and transform scenes with drag-and-drop ease.
[*][b]AI Motion Tracking:[/b] Add text and effects that follow the motion of objects with frame-by-frame precision.
[*][b]Video Intro Designer:[/b] Craft attention-grabbing intros with customizable templates.
[/list]

[b]System Requirements[/b]
[code]
Minimum:
- Requires a 64-bit processor and operating system
- OS: Microsoft Windows 11, 10
- Processor: Intel Core i-series and above
- Memory: 4 GB RAM
- Graphics: DirectX 11 compatible
- Disk Space: 7 GB available space

Recommended:
- Requires a 64-bit processor and operating system
[/code]

[b]Implementation and Impact[/b]
The implementation of AI features is seamless, providing a smooth editing experience. The impact of these features is profound, significantly reducing the time and effort required to produce professional-quality videos.

[b]Hook and Thesis[/b]
PowerDirector 2024 Ultra hooks users with its powerful AI capabilities and intuitive design. Its thesis is clear: to bridge the gap between professional editing and consumer-friendliness, making high-quality video editing accessible to everyone.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Praise and Critique[/h2]

[b]Personal Opinion[/b]
As an Ice Wolf who has navigated countless video editing terrains, I find PowerDirector 2024 Ultra to be a game-changer. The AI tools are particularly impressive, allowing for creative freedom without the steep learning curve. However, the software's resource demands can be hefty, which might be a drawback for users with older systems.

[b]Highlights and Drawbacks[/b]
[olist]
[*][b]Highlights:[/b] Advanced AI features, intuitive interface, customizable templates, and seamless transitions.
[*][b]Drawbacks:[/b] High system requirements, occasional performance hiccups on older hardware.
[/olist]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Character Development and Relatability[/h2]

While video editing software might not have characters in the traditional sense, PowerDirector 2024 Ultra's development is akin to a character arc. The software has evolved significantly, adding new features and refining existing ones, making it more relatable and user-friendly for editors of all levels.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Structure and Mechanics[/h2]

The software's structure is well-organized, with a user-friendly interface that allows easy navigation. The mechanics of editing, from applying effects to rendering, are smooth and intuitive, ensuring a hassle-free editing experience.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Comparison with Similar Software[/h2]

Compared to other video editing software like Adobe Premiere Pro and Final Cut Pro, PowerDirector 2024 Ultra holds its ground with its unique AI features and consumer-friendly approach. While it may lack some of the advanced features of its competitors, its ease of use and innovative tools make it a strong contender.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]

In conclusion, CyberLink PowerDirector 2024 Ultra is a robust video editing software that combines professional-grade features with user-friendly design. It's perfect for both novice and experienced editors looking to create stunning videos effortlessly. As Kiba Snowpaw, I wholeheartedly recommend this software to my fellow furries and tech enthusiasts. Dive into the world of video editing and unleash your creativity with PowerDirector 2024 Ultra!

This game is overflowing with personality and that unique Sui Arts touch!
If you haven't played his older games you might be a little surprised though. The game doesn't take itself very seriously and there's lots of fourth wall-breaking (the game even points out that the joke is getting overused in the beginning). If you don't enjoy the humor, you're probably not going to enjoy your time with the game.
However, I do recommend that everyone at least tries the game. There's a free demo, so nothing will be lost if you don't like it. You're not going to experience anything like this anywhere else (except in Sui Arts other games then obviously).
But I'll keep following Sui Arts and I'm already looking forward to the next episode. Keep up the good work!

[strike]The only thing I can see as a negative is that this is very obviously a mobile-first kind of game and that includes the big on-screen buttons. It would be nice to have a setting that removes some of those (for example the interact button in the bottom right) so it looks closer to a game made for the computer. It's obvously not needed and doesn't change how good this game is, but it would be nice to at have the option there. [/strike]
(Edit: The amazing developer listened and updated the game, so you can now hide the buttons through the settings)

The game is also released on Google Play and Apples App Store. I‚Äôve played his other games on mobile and only bought this on Steam so that I could enjoy the new pixel-art on a bigger screen.

In short: Buy this and when you've played this, play all other Sui Arts games if you haven't already.

We DIDN'T PAY for a game that offered a specific experience. The product we got for has been irreversibly changed to the point it's no longer even the same game. Of course we're going to be upset about it. We were promised - and delivered -  a game that has tons of features including many worlds, unique monsters, shops and even many party modes. It includes survival mode, you can play alone or you can play with your friend. Get as many skins, profile pictures and make your profile as cool as possible.The difficulty of the game is medium. rather than the "pay money to receive a meaningless skin" experience the game has turned into, with each character becoming increasingly less unique and boring.

The community that entered the game from the beginning should not be forced to pay money for a few skins of the game they once loved in order to try and cobble together something that represents the game they were initially promised. DLCs should be a fun way to add extra content; not a poor and cheap way to make a quick buck.

Fruit Conflict is probably the most intense game you'll ever play. The action is non-stop and will keep you on the edge of your seat. Plus, the fruit characters are hilarious and fun. I'm totally addicted!‚Äç

A very challenging game with deep and rich storytelling that rewards the player for their determination and vigor. After completing the game for the 5th time I shed a single tear as I knew that this is the peak of gaming.
Great game, not for the light-hearted. It starts off very simple, getting harder with every level. This makes the "Victory" screen that appears when you complete the level ever so rewarding.

Ladies and gentlemen, gather 'round because we've got a game on our hands that's not just great, it's paradigm-shifting, genre-defying, and a downright masterpiece. I mean, when I say it's one of the best of all time, you better believe I'm not blowing smoke.

Now, this game doesn't mess around when it comes to levels. Each one is a revelation, an experience that hits you like a ton of bricks. They're not just levels; they're immersive worlds, and every single one of them is a crucial piece of this gaming masterpiece. You might be wondering, "Does it have any duds, any levels that make you question your life choices?" Short answer: No! This game is in a league of its own.

Let's talk about the soundtrack for a moment. You know how Kendrick Lamar dropped "To Pimp A Butterfly" and Radiohead came through with "OK Computer"? Well, move over because this game's OST is something else entirely. It's a musical journey that deserves more accolades than it already has. Hans Zimmer himself gave it a standing ovation, and for a good reason; this soundtrack is next level.

Now, we can't just ignore the visual feast this game serves up. The art direction and sprites? Immaculate! I heard they were crafted by every artist on Twitter ‚Äì and it shows. This game doesn't just look great; it's a visual spectacle that pushes the boundaries of what we thought was possible.

But hold on, there's more. The gameplay here is a revelation. Fruits changing locations ‚Äì I mean, come on! Who would've thought that gaming could take such a groundbreaking turn? It's innovation like this that makes you question if you've been living in a cave because no other game even comes close.

Graphics? Don't even get me started. This game's visuals are on a whole new plane of existence. They're so sharp and breathtaking that it feels like you're gazing into another dimension.

I could go on and on about this game, but let's cut to the chase. It's a 10/10, and you can bet your bottom dollar on it. This game isn't just great; it's a work of art, a testament to what the gaming industry can achieve when it dares to dream big. If you haven't played it yet, what are you even doing with your life? This is gaming history in the making.

Disclaimer: I received a key from the develops to play and release a video of their game. With that out of the way, here are my thoughts on the game. The game is still in alpha, so be mindful of changes or bugs (I haven't encountered any bugs yet). The game is fun, if you don't mind a bit of a grind and some learning curve. The dungeons are hard, but have all the ores necessary for progression. The puzzles aren't too complex (subject to change with harder dungeons), but give really good loot. There's always something to do, mine, gather, or kill. The character move speed is very slow in the beginning, but the level-ups give good stat boosts (towards the start, I put my points in speed and it made a big difference). Overall, the game is fun, a bit grindy, and I'm excited to see what kinds of other things the developers have in store for this game!

This game is great fun.  I love a simulation game which uses skill trees, allows you to talk and build relationships with NPC's and is quite free roam.  It's fun that you can make your own decisions, explore and use your income to buy things.  I think the game is fair and balanced, meaning you don't have to grind to make enough money to progress.  Although I am a guitarist myself, I enjoy that the game isn't fully orientated around the guitar and also incorporates different aspects of the character's life.  I've put a few consecutive hours into this and am now at the point where I've played at most venues and have the most expensive clothes and cars.  I recently bought the studio which has allowed me to recruit more members into the band and to record music for other artists -  in this current version, the money earned from the studio doesn't seem like the best source of income and is also very difficult to achieve, however Rock Star Life Simulator is a free roam game and the studio is not something that you have to buy.  I think this is a great game and I am really looking forward to the future updates and what can be added next! Well done developers!

Rock Star Life Simulator has an interesting premise: start off as a nobody playing guitar on the street and work your way up to becoming a world famous rockstar. Unfortunately, the game's execution is so poor that it's almost unplayable.

The graphics are incredibly outdated, lacks of polish, and the gameplay is clunky and repetitive. There are also a number of bugs and glitches that make the game even more frustrating to play.

If you're looking for a fun and challenging rockstar simulator, I'm afraid Rock Star Life Simulator is not the game for you. However, if you're just looking for a laugh, you might get a kick out of how bad this game is.

Overall, I would not recommend Rock Star Life Simulator to anyone. There are much better games out there that you could be playing instead.

First and foremost, this game has the potential to be something truly unique and amazing! That being said, it's definitely far from finished and unpolished.

Pros:
-Starting from the bottom and working your way up is a fun concept.
- The AI chat system is absolutely amazing! It isn't perfect, but it works very well!
- The beginning progression is good.
- A lot of the initial concepts are intriguing.

Cons:
-Fighting feels like something just thrown in. Is very clunky and pointless.
-Same with as above when it comes to driving. Much easier and more efficient just to use the fast travel bus stops.
-Limiting the amount of chats with the AI really slows progression, especially since love is important to progression.
-Time goes by too fast when performing. A 6 song set can literally take over 10 in game hours and needs to be adjusted.


Those are just a few things in the 6 hours I've put in. I can't wait to put in more time and to see how this game grows!

A huge shout out to the Dev, @cet, for responding to my original review and dumbing down the game for me.

The latest update allows you to set the difficulty for each song between normal and easy. This really helps a lot, as the easy mode allows you to advance when the dexterity challenge becomes too great. I currently have 6 songs written. The first 3 were easy to play on normal because it only required 2 fingers, but when it expanded to 3 fingers I was struggling. The 6th song required 4 and I was lost.

It's truly become a simulation game. I haven't seen a simulation game in the music genre that draws you in like this. It funly makes you feel like you're progressing step by step on the rockstar path. From the character creation screen to many different contents in the game, it promises many things beyond ordinary simulation games.

This game is so nostalgic for me... I love everything about it!! I am having so much fun with performing aka guitar hero/rock band-like format and playing the notes using keys on the keyboard. It's not too easy and not too hard. It's just enough to be challenging in a game-like way and not too much where it would be annoying, it's just RIGHT. I also love gradually increasing popularity and growing relationships. My goal is to eventually ask the bartender out lol I think if you loved playing guitar hero or rock band and you also enjoy simulation games like my summer car or cooking simulator then you'll definitely enjoy this game.

First of all, well done to everyone who contributed to the game, I hope you will be rewarded abundantly for your efforts. The game is very nice, I didn't even notice that 2 hours passed while I was trying to understand the game :) I think it will be among the best simulation games. GLHF

Game is really shallow atm, the Song playing is quite boring would need some improvements to be anywhere near the levels of say Guitar Hero. Not much to do in the game. I unlocked the studio and played at the best stage that's all the content for now.
Boring game play, soon after starting a new game there is nothing left to do. The AI chat feature is a nightmare and hardly works making the NPCs in the game useless.

First of all, GREAT GAMEPLAY for a game that is still pretty new. Tons of content that will keep you busy for over 4 hours. 5 hours playtime and I'm not even halfway done. Weirdly, tasks are repetitive but don't get boring cause they are just challenging enough to keep you on your toes. Good dialogue with NPC characters. Overall smooth gameplay mechanics. Also, funny as fuck that you can run over peds and hit people's car and no one cares. If you lose a shit ton of money at the casino, I recommend driving out and running over like 30 people. It's therapeutic in a way.

Second, and more importantly,
SUCH A GREAT FUCKING SUPPORT TEAM!
They have a Discord for this game and the devs are on there like 24/7. I left a comment at 5 in the morning and assumed I'd get a response in a couple of hours. Nope, in less than 2 min a dev hops in and says I can personally DM him. He then proceeds to write out full on paragraphs to help me with all of my problems. I kept DMing him after with like small problems but he was on top of it everytime. Such a nice and helpful dude and timely ass responses. 100/10. 

All in all, GOATED fucking game, GOATED dev team. Can't wait to see what they have in store for the future of this game. A lot of Steam sims games are clear money-grabs and unfinished projects that people use to just get money. This game truly seems like the devs and overall team had a true passion for creating a game that can be genuinely enjoyed by all sorts of different people. Really screams collaborative passion project indie vibes for a sims game which is hard to find on Steam.

pretty fun game and cool idea, but the AI chat system needs to be ran client-side somehow, requiring a constant stable internet connection for a game mechanic is silly and unreliable, people get constant connection errors.

The game is great, but we definitely need more than one slot to save the game, because I would record one for youtube and the other one I would switch, so I would switch in several different ways as well. I can't wait for new updates.

I got an angry cop on my back cuz I accidentally peed through the wall of an outdoors toilet. So yeah, the game is yank. But to me that is part of the fun. Flirting is fun, the AI is very fun to chat to. The rhythm game is fun but too easy at first with the small amount of buttons. Hope someday we will get 6 key mode too. The simulation part is okay. It's definitely got that way too big and empty world feel though, but that in and of itself is very simulation indie game like which despite being objectively bad is somehow kind of nostalgic already to me as so many indie simulation games share in that, so it has sort of this weird cheap charm to it. Still in EA with many things still being announced that I do hope won't remain empty promises.

Rock Star Life Simulator is an engaging and amusing dive into the chaotic world of rock stardom. The game brilliantly captures the wild and unpredictable journey of becoming a rock legend, complete with hilarious moments.
However, while the game is undeniably fun, it could benefit from a bit more refinement. Some mechanics feel slightly clunky, and a few bugs might interrupt the otherwise smooth gameplay. With a bit more polish, Rock Star Life Simulator could truly shine as a top-tier simulation game.
Despite these minor issues, I wholeheartedly recommend giving Rock Star Life Simulator a try. It's a great game to kick off your gaming session, offering a lighthearted and engaging experience that promises plenty of laughs and a good time.

- I love the AI chat, really makes you think and be creative.

- Odd jobs in between trying to pick up chicks, great way to pass the time
- Social media elements are funny and feel very current

If the devs read these, some thing that should be added at some point:
- Look customization: more clothes, hats, tattoos etc. Also being able to change your hair style in-game.
- More places to pick up dates, 1-2 more bars would be great.
- More homes, maybe a penthouse?
- Basically more of everything (cars, guitars etc.) 
- Consider making an 'easy' mode for the actual playing, some people aren't good with these things. I admit once you get to 4 buttons for the songs I had some trouble.
- Add tiredness to hunger & bathroom so we'll be forced to end the day at some point, otherwise the only incentive to go to bed is next day's gig/money.

What the actual hell is this!! It's absolutely AMAZING! It's a little rough around the edges but the core game play is great. The driving feels a little Roblox but the life sim mixed with a rhythm game like guitar hero is great! 6/10 easy! can't wait to see what they bring to the game!

I played the early access version of the game, then I loved the game so much I bought it here and I don't regret it at all. There is a learning curve to learning the songs but that's the fun part. Each song, you have to practice it to get better at playing it like a real song. This seems like a pretty small simple game right now, but it's surprisingly immersive and a whole lot of fun! You can date girls, drink beer, buy houses, a studio and cars and of course ROCK HARD! Oh, and you can make your own custom guitars and but them and they add to your charisma. It's really awesome! The Devs have more intentions in the future with this game so I'm excited to see what's next! Definitely worth the money!

Visually I think it was very satisfying for a first version.  

I am Feeling like a rockstar!!!

I played the game for a while. If I were to comment on the game I played, it is a very fun game with a good main idea. In addition to the main story of being a rock star, the side mechanics are also very well handled. It's great fun to wander around the city and advance the game by playing on the streets. Besides, it is also well thought out to advance the game by interacting with other NPCs in the cafe.

I will add the good things I see later as I progress through the game. It will be fun right now. I definitely recommend it to those who want to play.

The game has a fun and vast story that can be played for days from the very beginning. The mechanics are very easy, and one feels very happy while playing. After all, you can't always be a Rock Star. I found the amount of money I paid to be insufficient; I recommend it to everyone.

I'm giving this game a thumbs up because it does a pretty good job of what it set out to do.

Upon first appearances you'd look at this like just another throwaway game cobbled together to make a quick buck. Well if it is, they did a good job of hiding that fact.

Keep in mind this game is early access and incomplete and it does have it's issues. Not a whole lot to do right now besides play music and whenever you're not playing music the game does get a bit boring. Also there's no real point in doing anything either. 

However the songs are awesome, the gameplay mechanic QTE for the music playing and song writing are interesting, engaging and fun and even a lot of the other aspects of this game are interesting as well. Like talking with the AI chat bot. That's fun...and terrifying.

It's gameplay components are solid, as its ideas and the general development mechanics of the game. Plus it's a cheap price. At the very least it'd entertain you during a long weekend.

But if you'd like a more in-depth look at the game please check out the video on my YouTube Channel (link below).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BOoOwMv4G7U

Otherwise, thanks so much for reading and I hope I managed to help some of you out there spend your money wisely.

This simulation game is one of the best I've ever played.
It has excellent mechanics and gameplay. If you're a fan of simulation games, this is a must-have. The artificial intelligence integration is impressive, making it feel like you're talking to a human.  Even the AI alone is worth the purchase. Despite being in early access, the game already offers a substantial amount of content. It is expected to improve even further with future updates.

(sigh) Twenty one years ago in 2003, Electronic Arts did a much better job with the release of their Superstar expansion for The Sims. The graphics, the action, the songs, the animation, the content -- all of it was far superior to this effort, despite the passage of time with other inspired works such as The Sims 3, Guitar hero, Rock Band -- well, that's it for me, but all of these (including The Sims Superstar from 2003) were incomparably superior in making me feel like a rock star. I think it is reasonable to expect these influences to inspire anything following to be much better than this.

Frankly, I suspect this title and theme are far too ambitious for the apparent skill level of the development team. First of all, If you're going to attempt to simulate rock star lifestyle, the graphics should be amazing. Everything should look gorgeous -- not clunky. The graphics are nowhere near the level they need to be to provide an immersive experience simulating the glamour of a rock star existence. I mean, 1,000% improvement would not be enough. A whole new graphic style of presentation is what is needed, and I can't imagine that happening.

The AI chat available with a very limited number of NPC's is briefly impressive, but it's not that much fun making innocent small talk with a chatbot to maintain a relationship, and opportunity for such interaction is severely limited anyway. The reward for your effort is also quite unsatisfactory. Soon, I found it to be a very not-fun daily chore to maintain a numerically scored relationship level which drops daily for no reason, and drops precipitously if you choose to "make love" (I guess the character is exceptionally lousy at that!) The fulfillment of this action is presumed, and not shown. Considering the lack of any reward to the player for doing it, I soon stopped doing that so that I would not have to work so hard to recover the relationship level afterward. Most NPC's you see you cannot even interact with at all. It's all pointless, anyway. Again, in The Sims 3 (2005) NPC reactions to your rock star character were far better. In this implementation, fan recognition is often rude, even hostile.

There are side jobs you can do, and some of the minigame tasks associated with them (like tuning a guitar) are a bit clever in their implementation, but it's not enough. They've introduced a music studio for the player to buy and this is one rare instance where their focus is on track to make you feel like a rock star, or maybe just a record producer, but at least it's in the right ballpark, thematically. Nevertheless, there is little reason to do it. If you can afford to buy the studio, then you don't need the pittance of a reward that you get for completing these activities. Additionally, the music produced at the studio is awful and the performer animation is elementary. Otherwise, most of the other rudimentary content (casino games, aiming a stream of urine, fist-fighting rivals, driving a car, keeping yourself fed, etc) is missing the point, doing nothing to make you feel like a rock star, EXCEPT --

The main activity in the game is writing and performing songs. The developers have some good ideas in implementing mini-games to represent song-writing, and the songs are mostly somewhat musically pleasing, apparently original works but without lyrics. When performing the songs, the action is similar to Guitar Hero or Rock Band, but unlike those titles, this title hasn't bothered with animation of your band rocking out on stage. Unfortunately, the number of songs is very limited, and if this is all you want, Guitar Hero even on a PS2 is a much more immersive experience and a lot more satisfying.

In summary, this game is almost certain to disappoint. I paid $10 on sale and in retrospect, I wouldn't waste a buck on it. I'm sorry my review must be so harsh, because I know this game is in early development, but honestly, I don't see any promise in it. The design team does not seem to know what kind of content is relevant, but worse, the entire production is far too crude to simulate rock star life and would need a complete do-over from the beginning to succeed. The most noteworthy talent demonstrated by the development team is their creativity in making mini-games to represent tasks, but unfortunately it is not enough, and everything else is sub-par.
To be honest the game is pretty fun, but they should keep updating this game because if not, it is going to be a dead game real fast

[b]solitaire quest: garden story[/b] is yet another generic +1/-1 card game that doesn't offer anything new but it was supposed to be a welcome change after the endless lazy suricate (jewel match) and 8floor reskins, if they even bother to change the skin at all. the garden theme is not really for me but I'll take anything over atlantis for the billionth time. I thought the dev would be a welcome change too. boy, was I wrong.

I found a bunch of issues outlined below, but instead of fixing them (shouldn't take long in competent hands), they told me of their 15-year experience and intentional design decisions based on all sorts of player feedback. no idea who would think some of these are in any way convenient, acceptable or should be a standard, [b]making games for a casual audience shouldn't mean throwing common sense out the window[/b]. no wonder you can't tell these games apart, it's as if they were all made by the same hivemind (or probably [i]for[/i] the same hivemind). I thought these guys were new on the scene, would explain a lot, but they're just as bad as suricate. call themselves playzzy, the 'p' must be silent.

[b]200 levels[/b], a good amount, doesn't overstay its welcome. one level unlocked at a time but besides the stars themselves, [b]a different color should indicate imperfect levels[/b] so they're easier to find on level select. [b]4 ways to play[/b] to please everybody, with optional per-turn or per-level timer or untimed with extra cards. it can be changed anytime. the optional in-game help explains what you already know. grab crystals hidden under cards, some are frozen, locked, etc. they [b]really went overboard with the annoying 'face changes after x turns' nonsense[/b]. grabbing the crystals is enough for 3 stars most of the time, except when it's not. it must be based on the number of cards left, not mentioned anywhere of course, nor is there an on-screen star progress.

there's an [b]illustrated diary[/b] and some dialog with a paper-thin narrative and a [b]garden to decorate[/b] with the crystals. they're 'upgrades' and have to be bought in order, can't go straight for the one you actually want to see. [b]endless mode[/b] unlocks after about 30 levels and not only is it endless but also pointless. unlimited deck, no undo, no shop, a tiny bit of extra cash. as soon as the board starts to clear, more cards appear, enjoy if you can.

[b]power-ups are fucked up.[/b] shuffle, turn cards up, etc. bought from the shop, only accessible from a level, as they're all per-level and used instantly, except [b]jokers and wildcards, which are lost at the end of the level[/b] whether you used them or not. also, [b]can't use the spade to remove a card if there's only one left[/b], last altogether or the others locked, defeating the very purpose of that power-up. shuffle is very conditional as well, even if there are plenty of cards to mix up, 5 is apparently not enough. and they went even further: [b]everything gets more and more expensive with each purchase throughout the game[/b]. instant consumables with an ever-increasing price tag, genius.

but wait, there's more. offering [b]5 extra cards for 100 gold at the end of an incomplete level[/b] is a very mobiley but potentially helpful thing to do, except [b]there's no confirmation and the button is right under the last card[/b], in the upper half. another example of stellar game design, a misclick losing you a bunch of money.

I've lost count by now but here's another never-before-seen idiocy: [b]undo changes the next card[/b]. missed matching the 7, you see the next is a king, undo, match the 7, draw next card and it won't be the king again. are you serious? [b]achievements are bugged[/b] as well. don't care personally but the one for completing 50 levels with 3 stars popped after 35. and they only appear outside levels, not when conditions are actually met (or not met, as it were).

[b]navigation is awkward but still nowhere near the nonsense one has to deal with in jewel match solitaire.[/b] game mode selection comes up when starting a new game but there's no confirm button, gotta close the window to continue. there are [b]single screens of text with a skip button when it should say continue[/b], there's nothing to skip. and the level complete screen should have more buttons (menu, map, garden) and [b]continue shouldn't lead to the garden every fucking time[/b], whether you can upgrade something or not, but load the next level.

as you'd expect, the game is very pleasing to the eye, except for the very basic main font. there are a few card customization options, separate volumes, a non-resizable but much smaller windowed mode, game cursor toggle, in-game representation of achievements and multiple player profiles. unfortunately, [b]settings aren't accessible from the pause menu[/b], gotta go back to the main menu to adjust volumes, and [b]progress is stored in the registry, the worst possible place[/b]. don't even dream about cloud saves. and esc doesn't bring up the pause menu because why would it?

all things and questionable decisions considered, it's [b]a whole lot worse than most other games in the genre and the bar isn't exactly high[/b]. since it evidently won't get the extra attention it badly needs, not even basic grammar fixes, it's not something to recommend. not sure why loading a level takes so long either. my pc is ancient but not as much as the system requirements and come on, it's a very basic card game that should work on a broken toaster. tried it on more recent hardware, no problem there (except for [b]deliberately slow animations when levels get laid out[/b]), but it still gets the award for [b]worst performance in a solitaire ever[/b]. 15 years of 'extensive experience' my ass.

"Solitaire Quest: Garden Story" is a solitaire card game with extra features. While it doesn't innovate the genre, it's a fine addition, if you like such games, especially considering its price. Pretty graphics, cute animations and relaxing sounds are there to accompany you on your quest to restore the pretty garden!

You can expect powers-ups and minigames to make your gameplay easier and more entertaining on those 200 levels. While you are playing the game, you will earn coins to spend on power-ups, help actions and, most importantly, buying decorations to restore the garden. There is a story to give flavor to the game! On top of that, you get the endless mode after a few levels into the game, in addition to those we already have (normal, timed, relax and challenge). You'll see various mechanics used such as unlock a card by finding the key, unfreeze cards, put the fire out, etc.

For more reviews, follow my curator https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44864435-Mewesome-Reviews/

[b]Note:[/b] An awesome friend gifted me a copy of this game. ^^

[i]Solitaire Quest: Garden Story[/i] is a card solitaire game developed and published by Playzzy Games.  You take on the role of an unnamed female character who has just inherited her Aunt Diana's garden, as her aunt has retired from gardening and is now traveling.  As you attempt to improve your aunt's rundown garden, Steve, a rival gardener who has lost gardening contests to Aunt Diana, approaches you, sneering your efforts and offering to buy the garden.  However, you refuse to rise to the bait, continuing your efforts, and even get encouragement from Amanda, Aunt Diana's close friend who also happens to be a yearly judge of the gardening contests.  What will happen?  I know I'm leaving this on a cliffhanger, but I don't wish to reveal spoilers and all that. XD

As for the gameplay, there are a total of 200 levels in story mode, and you can choose from among four game modes: normal, timed, relax, or challenge.  (For review purposes, I chose to play in normal mode.)  Endless mode is unlocked after you complete a certain number of levels.  You can choose from among various card designs and such.  When you start a level, you're given a layout of cards on the board, and the objective is to obtain the required number of flowers, which you obtain by clearing the board of cards.  There's a store where you can purchase boosters, such as jokers and the ability to randomly eliminate a card, to help you complete the levels easier.  You purchase boosters using coins, which you can earn as you complete levels.  The flowers are used to purchase decorations for the garden, and as you purchase a certain number of decorations, part of the story gets unlocked.  Also, Steam/in-game achievements are present although they won't count towards a user's global total until the game is out of "Steam is learning about this game".

Now that I've gone over the story and gameplay, I'll move onto my thoughts.  Every once in a while, I enjoy a relaxing game of solitaire, and [i]Solitaire Quest: Garden Story[/i] delivers that.  The story is pretty basic, but it's enough to move the game along.  There's the typical villain as well as moral support for the MC.  However, the main crux of the game is the gameplay.  I had no trouble completing most of the levels although those last three levels proved to be a bit challenging, as I had to replay them a few times before I was finally able to obtain all of the required flowers.  Although there are no mini-games, unlike some solitaire games, I was never bored while playing through the levels.  It's nice getting to play a simple game of solitaire.  All of the achievements unlocked for me without any problems.

As for the art, it is quite beautiful to gaze at.  The cards and backgrounds are lovely, and I especially liked the garden.  It was great to witness how purchasing upgrades improved the garden's appearance, and it's fun to customize what decorations you want.  In regards to the soundtrack, there's only one track, so I wish that there had been more variety.  Regardless, the instrumental track that was present is very relaxing and soothing to listen to, perfect as you play through the levels.

Overall, would I recommend [i]Solitaire Quest: Garden Story[/i]?  If you're looking for a fun, simple, relaxing game of solitaire, then this is worth taking a look.  It's pretty doable to complete and earn all of the achievements.  For the asking price, I'd say that it's definitely worth it, as it took me about 11 hours to finish the game and such. ^^

[h1]I ENJOYED IT SO MUCH I'M PLAYZZYing IT A SECOND TIMEüÉè[/h1]
I'm actually kind of picky about Solitaire games because they have to have specific features. Most importantly, it has to allow me to remove all cards (not just special cards) and it has to have the option to replay levels as often as I deem necessary.
¬†
Solitaire Quest: Garden Story has 200 levels that can be played in a Relaxed, Normal, Timed, or Challenge Mode. It also has an Endless Mode that allows you to play a never-ending game with infinite deck cards.
¬†
I don't enjoy Timed Modes in a Solitaire game, and I would have loved it if they offered a Hard Mode, which was more challenging than the normal mode but either didn't have a timer or had a way to disable the timer.
¬†
There are several Obstacles available, such as Frozen Cards that need to be played twice, Ivy Cards that require Garden Shear Cards, Root Covered Cards that require playing Axe Cards, Padlocked Cards that require Key Cards, Fire Cards that require Watering Can Cards, and Wax Seal Cards & Wax Seal Cards of Specific Suits that require you to play red & black or suit specific Cards to remove the seals. As you progress, a whole slew of obstacles are thrown into levels to make them quite challenging!
¬†

If you enjoy Solitaire and are looking for a cute story to go along with it, I would suggest getting this game. I found myself saying "just one more level" and then be ten more levels in. For $5, definitely worth the price IMO.

Susan has a problem.  No, it's not drug addiction.  A little something to get her through the day isn't that unusual, and she can stop any time she wants.  She said so herself.

No, Susan's problem is her aunt.  You see, Susan's aunt needs help with her run down garden, which has been neglected for a long time since Susan's uncle passed, and Susan's aunt began self-medicating with various substances.

Guide Susan as she restores the garden to it's former morning glory, through the magic of solitaire.  This is her quest.  This is her story.


[b]Solitaire Quest: Garden Story[/b] 


If you like the Jewel Match series of solitaire, this might be of interest to you, and if you are the developer, you might feel a bit confused, and are rethinking how you choose to which curators you send games.

I guess it's just like solitaire.  Sometimes you flip the next card over and it's the ace you were hoping for, and sometimes it's just a packet of instant oatmeal.  Maybe it's Quaker¬Æ Instant Oatmeal, 100% whole grains, and packed with flavor in every bite.
So if you can't get enough solitaire or oatmeal, why not make Solitaire Quest: Garden Story part of your morning routine.

[b]Personal Comment[/b] The Creature Zone VR: Nightfall delivers a highly immersive and spooky VR experience with its detailed environments and tense sound design. The interactive gameplay adds to the sense of immersion, making it engaging for horror fans.

However, performance issues and technical glitches can disrupt the experience, and the predictable gameplay and sparse storyline may limit the overall enjoyment. Outdated visuals also detract from the overall polish of the game.

Overall, The Creature Zone VR: Nightfall is a decent horror VR game with strong atmospheric elements but is hampered by technical issues and a lack of depth in certain areas.

Cyber Prison Management is a really badly made, well, I guess it could be called a tycoon/management game/hybrid action game (?) where you take on the role of a prisoner or the prison system itself and manage various aspects of prison life... as a prisoner your goal is not just to survive but escape, and of course as the AI your goal is to stop all that nonsense.  This might all work if the implementation was fine, but the implementation here is frankly, well, comically bad. 

Gameplay involves clicking through various cameras to see the prison, interacting with stuff, sneaking around... the game design itself is quite convoluted and doesn't stick to clean lines and clear gameplay.  It's hard to tell what's going on at all, in fact.  This isn't close to games like Prison Architect. 

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

The artwork here is terrible, it's all just amateurish "My First Wacom Tablet" style drawings used instead professional looking game assets.  It's unclear if this is due to lack of budget to arrange someone who can create graphical assets properly, or lack of talent, regardless, the overall visual quality of the game is extremely low, enough on its own to deter gamers.

There's no option to change the resolution and no useful graphics tweaks.  There's no way to ensure this is running at the native resolution of your display.  There's no guarantee this game will look right on any PC as a result of this hamfisted design decision.

The implementation here is of such poor quality, the developer couldn't work out how to make the game display in fullscreen, it only runs in a window.

The controls can't be customised because the game has such a dumbed down, simplified interface that it's just point and click stuff like a browser/Flash game.  The fact that the interface is this dumbed down might be seen as a problem in itself, however... this is a fairly shallow experience if you're the kind of gamer that likes to play games with deep, rich control schemes and interaction.  You'll get none of that here.

Some of the defects in the game can be attributed to the choice of using the video game library/engine, GDevelop's Electron, which is really a container for HTML5 like browser/mobile apps.  It's rarely used, because it's arguably worse than construction kits like GameMaker Studio, RPGMaker and Clickteam Fusion, but it's also much harder to work with.  Despite this, it also has very limited capabilities, which go some way to explaining the poor quality of the game.  Just as you can't make a silk purse out of a sows ear, you can't make a great video game if you use a terrible engine.

The very poor quality of this game puts it squarely on-par with ancient 1990's Flash/Java games, and given it's 2024 (and this was released not so far back in 2023), gamers and the industry expect and deserve better than this kind of low effort shovelware.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

The poor quality of this game is reflected by how many people spent time with it.  At the time of this review, SteamDB shows the game all-time peak player count was only ONE player.  That's right, only one person ever played this at a time.  When I played this for the purposes of reviewing it, I equalled the peak player count for the game.  OUCH.  The only player activity occurs once or twice a month, presumably someone loading it up to see what it is then quickly uninstalling it.  Considering there's over 120 million gamers on Steam and well over 100,000 games for gamers to choose from, the overwhelming lack of interest in this low quality game is to be expected.

So, should you buy this game?  Is this one of the best of the 100,000+ games on Steam?

Cyber Prison Management has the comically over-optimistic price of $10 USD, for which you could easily get any number of older AAA games.  Given the defects and quality issues with the game, coupled with the unrealistic price, this is impossible to recommend.

For comparison, the $10 asking price for this game could get you games like "Europa Universalis IV", "Subnautica" or "Mass Effect Andromeda".  Quality, professionally made games like those are frequently on sale cheaper than this.

[quote][b][url=https://partner.steamgames.com/doc/marketing/profile]Profile Features Limited![/url][/b]
Valve have marked this game as "Profile Features Limited" at the time of this review.  This is usually caused by poor sales figures and low community acceptance for the game (to date).  Until this status changes, this game will not give you +1 to your Game Collector badge count, appear in profile achievements or any other Steam meta-accomplishments, nor can it be displayed in some profile showcases.  If these factors are important to you, it may be worth holding off before buying this game.[/quote]

Very short game, like 10 to 20 minutes. The renders are not bad, but the story is not engaging enough. I still like the idea or premise, but it could use some more work. This is an extremely short VN. It will take you no more than 45 minutes to finish the story and that's if you bother to read it and not just click through. The translation isn't great and the story isn't either. It's very bland. There are choices to make in the chapters and if you pick the wrong one you fail the mission. Then you are kicked back to the beginning of the story, because it doesn't auto save your progress after each chapter, which is extremely annoying. I got to chapter 4, made the wrong choice, failed the mission, and had to start the game all over. NOT FUN!!! The renders are very basic, static, nice, but nothing to write home about. The mini game modes are so awful they aren't worth your time. The Secret Mission mode is particularly bad. The hit box is so off I found myself shooting through the zombies body and head and nothing registered despite the shot clearly going through the target on screen. Yes Horny Spy: Secret Mission is only $4.99 and that's not a lot of money, but no I don't think you should buy it. Take your money elsewhere.

A remastered version of a unique RTS game.
  The graphics and sound were polished for the new generation of hardware. This is helepd by strong psychedelic stylization of the game's world. Everything was running smoothly.
  The story is unedited this time, which makes it even stranger and more convoluted. It uses original Russian voices with new English translation.
  Gameplay is still original take on RTS with terrain modification instead of resource gathering and transforming units, Beware that you have to treat some missions more like a puzzle than classic RTS, because they require certain specific approach to survive their beginning.

Original release of the game back in 2004 was buggy and multiplayer had de-syncs, and this was only fixed with patches much later on. Hence why it didnt become popular back then, despite all its good points.
This edition has all those problems fixed, and had many improvements on top of that.

Oh, and if anyone's wondering why i reviewing this with zero play hours, its because game engine is open-source, and its source code is available on github :). So it can be used with game resources of older editions, although they may miss some things.
it is working, both First campaign and Emperors testament are present. really nice to play it again.

It's a remastered classic RTS with unique gameplay, lore and story. If you want something new and refreshing, try it.
It's best played in Russian if you know the language, because the voicing is great, and in the official English translation a lot of the lore is missed. This version, however, comes with "True English Translation", which I guess is acceptable compromise - uncut lore, but mission briefings are with English text and Russian voice, and these are very worth not skipping through, because they're really good.

I'm really surprised to see the updated textures. I've read that they done it, but was skeptical because the screenshots look pretty much the same. But I've made a comparison of the same things in original and this. The changes are subtle, but noticeable. Which is perfect in my opinion.

The movies are widescreen, which is a nice touch too.

It's very nice to have content from both games in skirmish, maps and sides. In originals, there's only selection of default frames, but here, no content from campaign is wasted.

The "community" option in the menu also has some goodies. For example, a link to GitHub with source code.

Soundtracks from both games are in the game's directory, which is nice, but it would be l33t to have them also as Steam soundtracks.

Do you enjoy fighting man-made horrors within our comprehension? (they are a result of our inner sponge, after all) Well then boy do I have the RTS game for you.  In this game you will battle a variety of different opponents from many different classes, but by far the most unique aspect of your troops is that they are all of the classes and none of the classes. You see, when you want a rocket troop, you don't order for a rocketer to be made, you order the entire squad to reform their matter into rocketers. You don't just build a transporter for your troops, your troops are the transporter. And this isn't just some mechanic, you see this happen to the troops, as each one liquifies right before your eyes, and reforms itself into whatever you choose. 

There is also probably one of the main draws to this game, at least for me, and that is the fact that you can reform the entire map as you please, void some special exceptions. You watch as the comparatively small drones move the earth around, redefining the landscape in the will of the Legate. 

PERIMETER: Legate Edition is everything I was hoping for in a a light remaster of the original. The texture and engine updates may sound small but I assure you they make quite the difference. 

I love this game and the minds behind it. The universe they have created is truly a wonder.

Amazing Classic game, altering land heights, combing units etc.

[h1]As if you've ordered "Mirror's Edge" on wish[/h1]
Okay let's pretend you really want to play this game decently. First of all - the default settings are not very helpful. Just deactivate the FOV jump visuals and set your FOV up to 120%. Now you can see around and don't get distracted by annoying motion blur (or whatever realistic bs graphics was intended by the dev). 

Next is the setting: You are trapped in a cave probably somewhere in SEA. Sometimes at the beginning you can follow the paintings on the walls but later on in the game they will fade out and you'll find yourself in a mf HOG, like guessing which wall is the next climbable, where to jump safely or is there not a trampoline below which can be used once or twice. 

Now my main point this game deserves a total downvote - they messed up the ladders. 
1.by default you climb down on ladders not rest on the step you are on. 
2.to reach the upper step you always have to glitch while looking to your shoes. Otherwise you won't be able to jump off from top of the ladder. 
3.because ladders are curved steel hooks in the wall you can be attached to them from 3 different sides while you would only need to climb them up from the middle side. There is no way to climb around sideways.

Ladders are probably not the most important lack of the game, but to reach out  the last achievement (after the finished stage2) there is an extremely hard ladder placed which seems almost as unclimbable.

To round up my negative first impression they added some bs language with lots of "pak" and needed subtitles which supposed to be funny I guess?

Wouldn't buy the full game, because I know the difference between "challenging" and "non-functional"

Well... it's nice to have a download of this music, especially as FLACs, but this is bizarrely put together.

Tower World's theme is very [i]very[/i] clearly an old mix. It sounds as it did in [url=https://youtu.be/PEhTOuiDwFc?t=2003]the original upload of the soundtrack[/url] on youtube back in 2021, rather than the version in-game which matches the [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nQjw3USYfak]extended youtube upload.[/url]

There are also some odd flubs in a few of the tracks - Mist World's theme seems to have a weird little artifact of some sort at one part, Gogi's theme might have a bad loop although it could just be how the song sounds because it's a little weird generally (and it seems to start fading before the loop happens, which is sloppy but not that bad), the Dream Nexus theme isn't as egregious as Tower World but it's also a worse mix than the extended upload. There are likely some other issues I haven't listed, too, but even if it's just these that's still pretty bad... It doesn't [i]ruin[/i] the soundtrack or anything, but I know I would have put in more care than this, and I already have for far less consequential projects like a Spelunky music mod.

Also... the Nowhere theme seems to be the same mix as the extended upload, but. it starts out mono. If you split the stereo tracks into two mono tracks, then invert one of them, that [i]should[/i] completely cancel out all noise and result in nothing at all. ...but instead you hear compression artifacts, meaning that it wasn't rendered out as a FLAC originally, it was instead converted to a FLAC from a lossy format, defeating the entire point of a FLAC. Best case scenario that's the only song that wasn't rendered as a FLAC, worst case [i]none[/i] of the files are truly losslessly compressed.

There's a chance that this was a weird set of mishaps out of the control of the person who compiled this. And if so... fair enough (and sorry, maybe this is a bit harsh). Still not ideal though...

First of all the big question: Is the translation good? Yes it is.

The game is simple yet beautiful. Don't be deceived by how it looks like yet another Slay The Spire clone. The gameplay is very different and engaging. The dice system adds randomness, some of which you can mitigate by your skill choices and equipment. The start feels railroady because it is essentially a tutorial baked into the first run don't be alarmed.

The story seems good. As explained on the store page it is based on Ancient Chinese mythology/history with the creator's interpretation and imagination thrown in.

Gameplay Loop:
1 - On the main map you chose which location to go. This part is linear.
2 - In each location there are story elements, which you access by clicking on their cards.
3 - Each Story Element(which can be a person, a location with people/shops/questgivers, enemy etc...) has its own small story. This part actually is reminiscent of Erannorth Games.
4 - Each Story Element can be solved by making choices, making skill checks, or combat.
5 - After completing a Story Element you gain experience, sometimes you also gain some loot. You gain skill points as you level up.
6 - You can spend these skill points on your character screen to create your own build. My favourite part: You can actually completely change the initial skills, don't like one? Just set it to 0 and regain its point investment. As you spend skill points your passive abilities also get unlocked(Don't be like me and wait 3 levels so that you can buy that +1 dice)

Skill Checks: In this game skill checks are done via throwing dice. There are 6 faces on dice: Yin, Yang, Azure Dragon, White Tiger, Vermilion Bird, Black Tortoise. Yang Dices can be used as substitutes for any other dice except Yin. You have 1 chance to match the required dice type to pass the check. Basically Yin is 1, Yang is 6. Yin is normally unusable but the skills that can use Yin are usually very strong.

Combat: At the start of combat rounds you roll your dice. Each round you also have 3 reroll options and you can use/lock the dices you like before rerolling. You have all your skills available to you. However to use them you must pay their dice cost. This part is similar to Immortal Way of Life's combat. As you level up(or equip related items) you gain extra dice throws or dices of one type so that tutorial episode dice starvation will soon be going away don't worry.

For 5$ this game is a 10/10 buy. 

Note: The game sometimes feels like it is stuck during the start but after a minute or so the menu appears. They probably forgot adding a loading bar at the very start. Don't let this discourage you. It might also simply a me problem but just writing it here in case someone else encounters it.
Cool gameplay, never seen using dice as stamina before. The story is pretty good so far. It feels a bit like Hand of Fate. Worth a try.

Only just started but all around loving it. The dice as your mana/points per turn is cool as heck and not to hard to pick up on. The translation is good so far. The subtitles cut off a bit on the screen when the pretty white haired man speaks to you, but other than that the game explains the mechs pretty well. You are told you can always go back to settings to find the help/tips again. The art work is so amazing!!!!

I honestly didn't expect too much from this game, the whole play dice on cards intrigued me but then I played the demo and what actually grabbed my real attention is that the story is amazing which more or less plays out as a visual novel with choices, deaths and failure states.
I haven't really played (or consumed much Chinese media) to begin with, but all this mythology I have never heard about just makes everything so interesting to me. The commentary from the Fisherman (the DM in the background) is also quite funny.

Also do have to say the story itself gets quite brutal (Ch.2 spoiler) 
[spoiler]R.I.P. Ji Yun, Ji Yu and Ji Feng :'([/spoiler] made me cry for an hour and also has quite some other dark moments but that definetly just adds to the fascination of wanting to see what's next. The failure states are also really intricate and detailed sometimes. Not just "you died" but several paragraphs of horrible things playing out.
The English translation - even though it's noted Alpha in the menu - is absolutely good, some obscure choices of words sometimes, but perfectly understandable.

The card art looks beautiful, and there is so many of it, even scenery you only see for like two paragraphs or so. I also haven't checked the artbook yet due to risk of spoilers.

The game itself does feel a bit janky with some effects, saving inside dungeons seems to run into issues and some of the effect text is really tiny but like those are the biggest issues I've came across.

Completion Edit: I have finished the game at this point, Dungeon saving no longer has issues. Missing text is barely a problem anymore.
The story was stunningly emotional, invoked feelings of happiness, grief, anger, so many tears and a desire to see everything through. Thank you so much for translating this and sharing your culture and mythology. The art is stunning and going into my wallpaper rotation. I learned so many new things too! ([spoiler]Metal[/spoiler] is an element!?)

Bai Chi <3

Fatermyth is a great game if you know what you're getting into. 

This includes:
‚Ä¢ Interesting, but rarely challenging dice TTRPG gameplay (Every character has a cheese strat- there are few fights that challenge or circumvent it)
‚Ä¢ A story that splits between seven protagonists. You go through everyone once, then go through 4 of them twice, then go back to the start to finish it off
‚Ä¢ Said protagonists barely meeting up in their own stories. 5 of those images up there ^ on the page only happen in the last ~4 hours of the game, and this includes the art and gameplay of the protags interacting with each other.
‚Ä¢ Stiff and passive English translation 
‚Ä¢ You (as a playable character) having to beat and charm a man in combat to have an "intimate" scene with him

I really don't think this is a bad game, hence the positive review, but it's certainly rough around the edges. There are still some untranslated "pages" of the story here and there (thankfully you usually don't lose much), and the overall English translation is written in a way I (personally) found severely unengaging and detached. There are exceptions to this- and the game is wonderfully written when it drops this, but it's not very often. I can tell there's a good story here, with every individual protag and overall, but it was hard to connect to. So, in a way, it's kind of a perfect representation of sitting on a boat while a guy tells you why you should care about all of these people. 

I would best describe this game as a severely railroaded D&D campaign with simpler mechanics. There are choices in this game for sure, but they barely ever matter. If you don't pick what the game wants, it tends to just kill you instantly. There are some situations in which this makes sense, but I got sort of sick of getting fail-states for menial decisions after awhile. The game wants to tell its story, and all you need to do is play the right moves and press the right buttons. 

My biggest active criticism of the game lies with my last bulletpoint. If you don't want to do that (and you have to play through that incident twice on both sides, same result), I wouldn't recommend the game. That incident [spoiler] becomes the basis of Teal Guy and Fox's (using simpler names for identification) relationship, and their second-half stories are about their blooming romance and fated destiny together. The game likes to call their initial incident passionate impulse, but the fact that Teal Guy had to be charmed and defeated for it to happen is... certainly something. I tried to avoid Fox throughout the entire rest of the game for this, to no avail. Gifting her the skinned corpse of her kin gives me a fail-state, and you can't progress to the last section of the game without grabbing her spirit... I just need my boy Bai Chi to find a better girl... [/spoiler]

A real hidden gem. Anyone who is a little bit interested in a good story and simple yet quite unique card battle system should try this game.
It has its unique charm not many other game had, and I've played a lot of them. 

Story is split into different characters and you experience their journey one by one. 
And each and every one of them are powerful enough to make your heart beat faster. You can feel how much passion went into this small project

Just give it a try. If you can enjoy the battle system, you will absolutely love this game
Super fun game with great story as well as art and game play, highly recomend!
A card game rpg, with the genshin TCG dice system, which is cool. The interface is a bit weird, but intuitive. The translation is ok.

UPDATED:

Finished the game, found all collectibles, unlocked & completed the bonus mini-game as well.

If you enjoy slasher flicks or yearn for games like Friday the 13th on the NES and Clock Tower 1 and 2 on the SNES and PSOne, then look no further.  Terror at Oakheart will most definitely quench your...  appetite.  

The story is very well presented for a game that is comprised of 2D Pixel Art and animation.  The pacing seems to be right on the money.  There are Lite Puzzle elements with classic action/adventure horror game vibes.  I haven't completed the game yet, but I can confirm that the atmosphere is completely engrossing and will leave players thrilled & chilled during and between scary events.

I must also mention the music and sound effects as they are top notch!  I truly did not expect such an unsuspecting game to have such great music and sound.  

Terror at Oakheart should take approximately 2.5 hours to complete for your average gamer.  I think the price point is just right, given that the experience is well crafted, engaging, and oozing with the appropriate atmosphere.  I'm looking forward to seeing how things churn-out in Oakheart.

Lastly, and this would be my only major gripe, is that there is no Full Controller Support.  There is however, a rudimentary level of controller support.   I've played both the demo and the full game now.  The Demo does have a bug or two when using a controller or gamepad, however, I didn't come across any bugs during my time with the Full Game release.  It is unfortunate that we don't have full gamepad support yet, though it looks like the developer is working on it since there is placeholder artwork in the options menu showing a Controller and what each button on the controller does.  However, once again, this placeholder art does not show the correct controls for the game (yet).

I have been able to figure out the controls very easily using an Xbox One Gamepad.  The 'Y' button seems to interact with objects, while the left analog handles the movement, the right trigger fires weapons, and the 'A' button dodges.  The "Select" button brings up the inventory menu, and the Start Button toggles the Options Menu (in-game).  There is one tiny section in the game where you must crouch and that, unfortunately, is not mapped to the gamepad in any way shape or form.  The only way to crouch right now is by pressing 'C' on the keyboard (unless you go through the trouble of mapping new controls through Steam's Controller Profiler).  Also, if you've forgotten your objective during a particular chapter, just press and hold the 'Q' key on the keyboard.  I don't know why these two actions were never mapped to the controller or gamepad.  Thankfully, you only need to use crouch in one small section of the game and most of the time the objectives are very straight forward.

I sincerely hope gamepad support is fully implemented in the near future because this is a banger of a game.  If you enjoy campy horror fun with classic Splatterhouse atmosphere (circa TurboGrafx-16 and Sega Genesis), then you'll enjoy this fun little adventure horror game with it's engaging story, eerie environments, and chilling soundscape.
A fun horror game with lots of brutal executions and multi-character gameplay where nobody is safe!

It's sadly not really scary as the title implies. It's a decent retro game with good graphics though. Doesn't take too long to complete. There are no choices, it's 100% linear. You do need to run around and find items though. Overall it's enjoyable.

A pixelated tromp through classic horror movies. I wish I could give this a thumbs up but it's so basic. I wish I had done more research before I bought it. That said this is not a bad game but besides "go here" and "press F" there isn't much to do or play here. Honesty, I think this would be better as a mini film or something because the graphics and music are great. But the gameplay leaves a lot to desire.

So the game is great and as a horror fan I get the references and it really is a treat for any gore hound. Very nice setup which leads to a pretty solid finale. However I can't in good conscience recommend it due to the final boss and that level in general. So I get that the developers felt the need to do some kind of elaborate final fight in order to prolong the game/give some gameplay value but here it just doesn't work (at least for me) Combat is super clunky to begin with and the fact that you have to go through the same dialogue lines over and over when you lose made me quit after getting to phase 4 only 2 times.
So TLDR game is actually very good, an 8/10 from me especially since it's fairly cheap and you can tell a lot of love was poured into it, however the final fight just breaks it for me and thus I have to thumb it down.

Loved it! Great nod to classic slashers. The tone and vibe is great. Music very much NES-inspired and it works so well. There's even a DODGE yooooo. 9/10 because of the doggie killing otherwise it'd be a 10.

TL: DR - TERROR AT OAKHEART is a love letter to 80‚Äôs slasher flicks. Toss in some cosmic and body horror as well and you have fun, well animated and looking Retro side scroller slasher.  Though it has a few flaws I 100% recommend this game to those who want something unique in horror games.  8/10

The TO LONG. DID READ.

TERROR AT OAKHEART at its core is a love letter to 80‚Äôs slashers like Friday the 13th and more.  This game you get to see all sides of the story. From playing as TEDDY as he hunts down his victims to feed the flesh god.  Too playing those who are doomed to not survive the night. 

Graphics ‚Äì
As you can see the focus is on retro pixel-based game play.  Each chapter looks create and the animations play out very well. You can see that time and care went into creating how things look and move. Even more so when you get to the kills in the game.  For fans of 80‚Äôs Slasher flicks that had to cut out most of every kill to keep an R rating.  In here you get to see some of the iconic kills from slasher flicks recreated in pixelated bloody mayhem.   From the to the over the top.  

Game Play ‚Äì 
The gameplay in this game is very simple.  It‚Äôs move left or right. Dodge roll, attack and reload, then lastly interact.  The two main flaws in game play this game suffer from a ‚ÄúOrder of operations‚Äù and lack of I-Frames.   Though you can find out with ease the rhythm of combat for each monster.  The biggest issue is you can still be damaged, and killed, in moments that you have no way to fight back.   EXAMPLE:  if you are transitioning between doors in the game.  You are not safe. You can take 1 to 2 hits trying to leave an area if you are not far enough away.  I feel the gameplay would be greatly improved If you have some I-Frame moments when the Transition starts.   The other is the ODER OF OPERATIONS.  This is double edged.  You must do things in the order the game wants you to. There is no real wiggle room for this.   You always must do part A before you even try part B.  First play through is not that bad but on your moments where you replay parts after death. It can be a bit annoying.  I do understand WHY it‚Äôs here, but it can still be a bother to deal with. 

Story
The story of the game is what you would expect of a 80‚Äôs slasher.  Don‚Äôt come here looking for depth and world changing ideas that make you question your own humanity. This is a SLAHSER.  Sit back and enjoy the mayhem with a smile as mayhem unfolds. 

Replay ability ‚Äì
This game sadly has very little reason to replay the game once you beat it.  There are collectables that if you just do a little bit of exploration as you play, you will find ALL on your first run.   There is a reward for beating the game that calls back to one of their past games that came out before TERROR AT OAKHEART.  But outside of that.  This is very much a ONE AND DONE game. 

OVERALL ‚Äì

TERROR AT OAKHEART is a unique gameplay and take on a horror game that really does embrace the slasher aesthetics and feel of 80‚Äôs slasher flicks.  Though little replay is in this game. At the price of $8 (at time of review) This is a short and fun game that very much should be checked out for fans for horror.  It will make up jump, smile, and squirm as any good horror game should

8/10 Bloody hands from me.   Some flaws can make you get Amad and rage at it. But you hopefully will still enjoy the bloody path and story this game gives you. I for one hope for a TERROR AT OAKHEAT 2

[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/6142328/][b] With 1,400+ reviews, make sure to follow The Cpt Froggy Club Curator Page for plenty more![/b][/url][/quote]

Terror At Oakheart:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 

The town of Oakheart has been on edge for quite some time; Teddy is on a killing rampage. He targets couples, and his killing methods are never the same but always gruesome. Teddy was always an odd fellow, working as an ice cream vendor dressed in a clown outfit with a strange mask, and walking awkwardly. But then something extraordinary corrupted his already weak mind; you know, the usual horrible extraterrestrial monster shooting some sort of membrane that sticks onto faces. It‚Äôs scary stuff. Is there more murder in sight, or will Teddy be stopped? If you want to know, then don't miss Terror At Oakheart.

Terror At Oakheart is a pixelated side-scroller survival horror game with a light puzzle element developed by Tainted Pact and published by Assemble Entertainment on the 24th of February 2024 on the Steam platform.

The game consists of nine chapters, including a prologue, and will take around three hours of gameplay to complete. Yes, it might be short, but what you get for the price point is excellent. As advertised, the game is heavily inspired by the horror movies of the 80s and 90s, and while playing the game, a few titles, such as Friday the 13th and Aliens, came to my mind. 
What impressed me in this game is the way the story is told, and the fact that you play every character. Yes, you'll play murderous Teddy, and you‚Äôll kill a few characters in his eccentric ways. But most of the time, you'll be playing characters who are about to die. For a couple of characters, you'll have to avoid being killed or it will be game over. Ultimately, the character you play the most will be the Sheriff of Oakheart. Most of the combat phases occur as the Sheriff.

Each chapter is based in specific locations, and the story will flow cleverly as you go along. The chapters/level are designed as corridors with doors that you have to explore. Some rooms will have items to collect, such as keys to open locked doors, ladders to reach a house's second floor, and various items you can use during your gameplay. The puzzles are straightforward and provide a bit of necessary variation in the gameplay, 

The combat phase is simplistic and suits the game very well. You‚Äôll experience most of the fighting as the sheriff, facing characters who have died and become pretty fun mutants, as well as a few different monsters created by the strange alien. They are not hard to kill - if they are too close to you and you need to reload your weapon, try exiting the room, reloading your weapon, and re-entering. The enemy will reappear on the other side of the screen, giving you plenty of time to shoot at them. The last boss is not hard to kill - it might take you a couple of goes until you understand its pattern, but when you get it, it will be straightforward. When you finish the game, you'll gain access to Mr. Top‚Äôs Killing Spree Mini-Game, which is fun and an additional bonus.  

The game runs well, and I like the eerie atmosphere it provides throughout the chapters with its dark areas and scary soundtracks. As the game is quite short and has one storyline, Terror at Oakheart doesn't offer much replayability, but it is really worth playing. 

Positives:
~~~~~~~ 

+	Great pixel artwork and eerie soundtrack
+	An excellent story with nine chapters
+	The ability to play each character within the story
+	Good, simple combat phases
+	Simple puzzles to give more variety throughout your playthrough
+	Good price point
+	Achievements 

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~ 

-	No trading cards as yet
-	A bit short

Although quite short, Terror At Oakheart is an excellent pixelated indie horror game that perfectly emulates the 80s and 90s movies of the genre.

7/10 

Key provided by the developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!
