This game is awesome! It is a love letter to slayers from the '80s and the '90s, especially Friday the 13th, The Thing, Halloween, and the Blob. It is a sci-fi/horror flick.

In gaming words, this is an action/adventure, horror game, side scroller. It has a couple of puzzles, but those are easy to solve, they don't require a lot of thinking, but the shooting does from time to time, because of the dodge mechanic and the relentless enemies you will face.

All in all, it is a fun indie game, buy it if you want to enjoy a good story like if you were back at the end of the XX century. Also, game time is around 2 hours, but those are a good couple of hours :)

Very good pixel slasher here. I played up to chapter 2. Very solid gameplay. The animations are nice and story elements while cliche still keep ya on ur toes. The atmosphere really sells it all. It's unfortunate that there is no voice acting. A common occurence with indie horror games. Despite this, the game is to be checked out. 

Gameplay Impressions: https://youtu.be/vLJsN1ve8nI

"I don't think I'm making it out of here. But I can at least leave a note for whoever comes here next."

There's a lot to like about this game. The pixel graphics are very nicely done and the soundtrack is excellent. However, it suffers from very uneven pacing, confusion about what it wants to be, and some of the most godawful combat I've ever come across in a sidescroller - especially in the final "boss" segment of the game. 

Initially, the game appears to want to be a 2D walking sim type game with nods to slasher horror movies like Friday the 13th; you do a segment as the killer looking for your victims, then you play as the victims for a bit and wander around fetching items cluelessly until you meet the killer, who promptly butchers you in a comically excessive and grotesque death animation. You'll get cut in half, beheaded, crushed, hurled into a woodchipper - all the staples of b-movie murders - then the cycle repeats. The setting is classic horror fare - house during a power cut, isolated police station, and the ever-popular summer camp in the woods. The game wears its influences on its sleeve and that's totally fine. I didn't mind this part at all, though I could imagine some objecting that there are no choices to be made or much in the way of gameplay to be had - you just go left or right through doors until the bloody death scene happens. Personally I thought that this section was done competently enough if you're into that kind of thing; it looks and sounds good enough that if it'd had continued this way I'd have given a positive review.

Unfortunately, about 2/3 of the way in, suddenly the game has an identity crisis and wants to be a sidescrolling horror shooter instead with disastrous results. The atmosphere and pacing of the first hour are thrown out completely in favour of poorly-executed combat encounters. Your gunshots (and later your flamethrower) do little or no damage so you'll be running around left and right trying to create enough distance to get a shot off or reload constantly, even on basic enemies. The dodge doesn't work very well and unless your timing is absolutely perfect you'll take damage in most exchanges, even when you feel like you should be out of range or have gone in the opposite direction to the attack. It's clumsy and pads out the game excessively, with fights prolonged to about twice the length you'd actually want them to be. Despite these irritations, I thought I'd press on and see the story out, only to have things decline further. The final section is infuriatingly bad. You get two prolonged boss fights back to back with no checkpoint between them, lots of annoying added enemies all over the place snapping at your ankles while you're trying to concentrate, and not enough room to really fight back effectively. The difficulty spike here demands a level of mechanical mastery that no other part of the game requires with no build-up to speak of. I did beat it but it just feels so horribly out of place that it soured my already-shaky time spent with the game. I don't mind tough bosses in a combat-focused game with decent mechanics but this was just a messy and inappropriate ending to a game I previously felt well-disposed to. A shame.

So, while this is a game that I am recommending, it comes with the Caveat that the actual gameplay isn't that great. The main reason that you want to play it i because of the fact that it is basically a B horror movie in game form, and for that it is excellent. It is cheesy, it has some fun kills, some actually tense moments, and the plot is perfectly predictable in the way that if you watch a lot of horror movies you will know by the back of your hand. And if you play it looking for that, you'll probably have a good time.

However, if you're looking for puzzles, or for the survival horror sections you will not. Puzzles are basically just going around to find the thing that you need and the survival horror sections are plagued with clunky reloading mechanics, weird hitboxes that are just as exploitable as they are unpredictable, and enemies that are such bullet sponges that the fact that they are easy will not stop you from dying to them because you thought that your dodge had just one more I frame than you thought that it did. These sections, while they can be fun are also a pain to play as whenever you get forced into a fight and only offer you slightly faster movement but only if you get the movement right when not in combat.

All this isn't to say that the game isn't enjoyable, but it's short and about a third of the three hours I have comes from a combination of rough fights, and getting lost on a certain level in the game. I did enjoy it as a horror experience, but the game aspects need a lot of sanding off the rough edges. I do think that it is worth playing, but plenty of people will not and even for those who do it is probably better to pick it up on sale. I did enjoy looking for the plushies though, so take from that what you will.

It's been a slow season for good indie horror, and this was an absolute breath of fresh air during this time. 
The pixel art is fantastic, the gameplay is fun, and the story is fantastic. Really enjoyed basically every aspect of Terror at Oakheart.
Highly recommend for indie game lovers.

Short game that make you fell like you playing a slasher movie, interesting concept, worth it.

Absolutely loved this game. I'm a huge fan of classic horror films and this does a great job of paying homage to it. The music and story gave me total slasher vibes the entire time. not much gameplay, not much puzzles, not much combat, not much dialogue, no much story, not much music, not much playtime, not much content.

a not much game.

A nice little sidescroll horror story game with with a bit of action and adventure mechanics. But on a very small grade.
I feel about 8 bucks is a bit high for the very short time and the gameplay is not very deep. It's more like a 2D walking sim.
The story is also not very deep BUT it's art style and atmosphere is great. I would wait for a sale due to the lack of content and the fact that it is a linear story. But if you like unique atmosphere and want to support indie devs, go for it.
PS: The minigame that you unlock after the main story is kinda interesting but it feels very pointless. It would have been much better adding a bunch of different story path and decisions to make instead of creating a minigame where you have a clunky combat system and also just walk a linear path to the end.

I loved every aspect of this game, the 2D side scroller was right up my alley, I loved the story that unfolded as you played the game! This indie game is a true delight for all horror fans and I had a blast playing through it.  It's got your classic tropes, your awesome kills and a body count to die for!  I loved the pixel art style and the storytelling was awesome and played out as if you were watching an old 80's horror flick.  The music was on point and really helped to give it that perfect horror atmosphere.  One small suggestion would be to perhaps include some checkpoints so that if you need to leave the game for some reason that you don't have to then restart the entire chapter.

Highly recommend checking this one out if you're a fan of 80's slashers.  I'm sure you'll love all the little nods to your fav movies that the developer included.  I'm looking forward to seeing more from Tainted Pact in the future (keep up the great work)! ‚ô•

An excellent tribute to classic slasher films. A great story you would expect out of a game inspired by 80s films with hilariously over the top death scenes, retro art and amazing music. Definitely recommended if you enjoy those kinds of movies.

Clowns. Tentacles. Moist. Meaty. Gore.
All my favorite things wrapped neatly in a package of pixels and tied off with a lovely bow of gory kills. :)
Tainted Pact games did a fantastic job bringing us a 80's slasher retro nightmare with good storyline, captivating nostalgic graphics and A KILLER SOUNDTRACK.
I enjoyed the campy yet menacing feeling of the game and the characters were perfectly cliche. The gameplay was intriguing as you get to play as each character and witness them meet their fate at Teddy's hands! (Still mad about Max.) I also respect the homages to notable horror films and creative kills! I personally found the game only a bit dialogue heavy but I appreciate it was necessary for the game, I just get tired reading out loud >_<
Combat in game is pretty straight forward but still quite challenging (I don't wanna talk about how many tries it took me lol), be prepared for plenty of dodging, reloading and weapon cycling to beat these eldritch beings! Plenty of viscera and squishy Lovecraftian aesthetic. Watch out for tentacles!
Overall, I recommend that YOU PLAY THIS NOW. Honestly, I enjoyed the heck out of this game and the dev's work in general is top tier.
Also...I didn't break anything. 10/10!

(I received a free copy of this game from the devs)

A really well made game with little to no complaints on my end. The complaints I do have are not enough to warrant a bad review or things that should trigger buyer's remorse.

+Fantastic music that myself and viewers thoroughly enjoyed. It was genuinely great and several people had picked up on the 80s/90s vibe without knowing the game's description at all, so the aesthetic was fantastically transparent through art, concept, and music. 

+Decent story, nothing to absolutely write home about, but was still entertaining

+Enough puzzles, story, and other elements tied in that it's a good balance of mechanics

-Playing as the killer felt too comical and took away from the horror aspect, but the kills were really brutal and fun to watch.

-There's a few grammatical errors within the game, namely within the beginning. 

-Combat mechanics can feel clunky and unfair at times, but nothing game breaking or impossible to move past. It offered a nice challenge to myself, personally. 

Overall, the game is well worth the asking price and is something to actually play and enjoy without things being overly complicated and long-winded.

Everything good until the [spoiler] final chapter. I completed the first mini boss, then went to the next. After a couple tries  I got all the tentacles and turned the valve or whatever, then it wanted me to repeat the process. I died, did it again, died around the same spot, did it again, kept on dying. Then I accidentally returned to main menu instead of reload to checkpoint. From the main menu you can only select which chapter, and not continue from last checkpoint. Not even going to try to repeat that chapter. Watched the ending on YouTube. [/spoiler] Additionally, I didn't like how often you play as the killer. It's not scary at all when you do the killing, it still is cool but, you can still better experience that when you are the person being killed. I would give this game a thumbs down because of the [spoiler] final chapter [/spoiler] but the rest of the game is great. Some things are similar to suffer the night.
Really dull, moving from left-to-right, trying to find the right door to progress through the story and if you take the wrong path, you die, reload and then do the right path.

I had a lot of fun with this game right up until the final 'boss' fight which took me FAR longer than I'm willing to admit to beat and which felt like such a departure from how the game had played out before. It just didn't fit with the story-telling/narrative driven nature of the game up until then. All of a sudden it turned into an intense shooter/combat game?! And I swear the AI cheats. Yes, I'm still salty. Anyway, if you disregard all of that which was in reality a very small portion of the game, I loved it. The art style was great and allowed for more gory, gruesome deaths which a horror/slasher fan like myself loves. The nods to classic slasher horror movies was appreciated. The story-line was predictable but fun - I always enjoy deciding if I like a character or not and trying to figure out how they'll die in slasher films. If you're a fan of the 90's slasher horror flicks I guarantee you'll have a good time with this game. You can watch my full play-through and review over on my YouTube channel: https://youtu.be/pZvG5_aS42U. Thanks to the dev for the key and the opportunity to play this game for my audience!
Amazing game highly recommend for any slasher fan man really loved it ! really hope they make a sequel .

Short fun and murderous game. I wish it was longer but I am content with my purchase. I enjoy the mechanics of playing different characters. I truly got a little stress and anxiety from fear a couple times which is great for a horror based game. Still very reminiscent of OG pixel point and click adventure games. Do not expect this to be some outrageous masterpiece, however, it is good for its genre and niche.

Disappointing. Story lacks creativity and the gameplay consists mostly of walking with your current character down their linear path, maybe pick up an item on your way, until Teddy kills them. Sometimes it's reversed and you walk Teddy down his linear path until he kills them instead. It's always very obvious and offers no surprises. It doesn't get scary, because for that you'd need the feeling you could do something wrong or at least a bit of hope for survival. Here, you get "guess we'll kill this person I've never seen before off now", next.

That's until you get to one of the characters who can actually use a weapon to defend himself at which point the game turns into bothersome run and gun, except you're not running. Combat is tedious and cumbersome and becomes annoying really quickly. When you've had enough and think you'll stop for today and play on later ... think again, because you cannot continue from checkpoints when you leave the game, only restart whole chapters. Poor.

The music and visuals are good, though. The actual game not so much.

As though this game feels and has visuals like a Super Nintendo Console, it feels very linear when it comes to gameplay. Story is straightforward where you play as a serial killer, who is a clown, working with an evil entity to feed it flesh. It has simple puzzles to do in order to progress to the next parts of the game. It does have a cheesy classical horror theme going for it, yet it doesn't help from its linear gameplay. Though the game did have some enjoyable death animations, which are the only interesting visuals that made this appealing. There is some combat, but its not too difficult and some of the hit boxes from dodging requires a bit of timing. Overall, its a horror game with the SNES theme going for it just not highly recommended.

I love the game but I didn't finish it because of the worst part at the end, which is soooo long and does not really fit into the game. I don't want to spoiler what happens, but the last chapter is really bad, for me personally and I this is why I would give the game a neutral if this would have been possible.
Apart from this it feels like a horrormovie and I had a good time until this point of the game.

I really liked this game after watching Insym stream this, I was 100% interested.

The Story is your typical 80s slasher movie but you see the killer side of things aswell. The gameplay is very simple but however there is more to it then you might think. For it's price, I think it's a good price point for how short the game is.

Really fun and charming, bursting with great nods to classic slashers all over the place in superb pixel art form. The music gets a little bit repetetive for my taste though, and there's a significant difficulty spike by the final chapter. I'm still struggling with it. I'm not a huge fan of the placement of the save points, especially considering how tough some of the later fights are, and the fact the collected inventory items such as med kits vanishes by chapter progression was a frustrating realisation. It's a great game though full of love for the genre.

Short little slasher horror game. Obviously an homage to 80's and 90's slashers, which I like.

The combat is functional but lackluster and can get on your nerve as the game progresses. The story is just that of a slasher, and doesn't really innovate too much. The kills are great (and if you know your horror movies, you can see some really on-point callbacks).

I enjoyed it for what it was.
A Jason-esque eldritch slashing experience. Glory kills, giant tentacles, and challenging end bosses that let you play out an 80s horror flick to a T.

This game was very fun. I loved the music, atmosphere, pixel graphics. Had me laughing and also disturbed at some parts haha Great slasher horror game. If you love 80s horror movies, you'll enjoy this game.

One of my absolute favorite games ever made!
The whole game is homage to old school slasher films which to me, that's fantastic,
Especially once you start to get the movie correlations!
Its mostly a relaxed and scary game but as each level that goes by, it becomes more challenging and involved.
The whole environment is super immersive as well, especially for a retro style game.

Don't think too hard about purchasing this game, if you liked the trailer, you'll like this game. 
4.8/5 rating (imo)

Absolutely worth a buy.  A fun little horror story with very good pixel art.  It's not a huge amount of puzzle solving or combat but kind of just rolls along.  A few collectibles and another game mode to keep you busy if you want something more after the games over.  This dev is great at making digestible horror experiences, I notoriously don't finish games but theirs always hit the sweet spot of keeping me engaged till the conclusion..  Very much enjoyed one of their other games Suffer the Night.

Very odd nitpick, some of the people (I believe it was mostly male chars) have a weird jump in the light area on the lower half of their shirt.  The highlighted area jumps from 2px to 3px from an eyeballs glance, it causes a kind of visual stutter.  Overall artistically loved the setpieces otherwise.

So, I LOVED Suffer The Night. I think it was one of my favorite games from last year and I played ALOT of them. This one, doesn't fit that same mold but really did scratch that retro style 80s horror itch I've been craving. The story is barebones basic but nothing wrong with that being inspired by the good old slashers of the time. 

Fits right in with what it was going for. I enjoyed it especially the story.

Excellent game! 

Gorgeous aesthetic and pixel art, the story is very interesting, the music is good, straight forward gameplay, easy to play.

Definitely recommended, gonna check out other projects by the devs.

Overall I recommend this game.

The atmosphere is great and reminds of old SNES games. Graphics, sound, gameplay, controls...all of it has the retro vibe. Horror fans should try it out in my opinion. It isn't too innovative, but that is not necessary or bad. Horror fans with a spleen for gore probably enjoy it exactly like this.

I liked the boss fights as well. They had a bit of a Secret of Evermore touch (boss is not directly attackable, so work around).

The only negative thing I want to point out: I played for 2.7 hours and basically unlocked all achievements including finishing the bonus minigame. So the content is not too much and some people might think the price is a bit too high for this.

For me personally the price was ok, I had good fun for roughly 3 hours. Others might think different.

Very cool little sidescroller horror game. Its gameplay is rather simple, at first consisting of merely walking and interacting, but gradually combat comes into focus. It's solidly executed mechanics-wise, however the real stars are the visuals, sound design and atmosphere. It's a neat concept and story turned into a treat for fans of retro and throwback horror. If you enjoyed Happyhills Homicide, for example, this one will be right up your alley.

this was a fun game, and with great story! I also loved how it was short and sweet as well.

my only gripes were this, and they're very minor

A} no health bar
B} no ammo count

This game is the perfect blend of 16 bit retro side-scrollers, classic slasher films, and eldritch horror. The story is entertaining and interesting, the pacing is good, there's just enough room to explore and find goodies without it feeling tedious, the dialogue is light and fun but every character is distinct, and the combat is challenging but not overwhelming. I highly recommend this game to horror fans, retro fans, and anyone who just enjoys fun. 
Tainted Pact continues to deliver quality, unique, interesting, entertaining and accessible indie horror games.

It's Terrifier meets Thimbleweed Park. 

A couple levels in I thought it was "just" a sidescroller, but then I got to shoot things! Very straightforward levels with just the right amount of horror movie references. 

I love it, especially the soundtrack.

If you're looking for a fun, short, campy NES style horror game then this is good choice. The combat can be very frustrating at times because of the inability to dodge while reloading and sometimes unfair feeling hitboxes. Though maybe it's just a throwback to a more frustrating age of gaming!

Buy it on sale if you want but 10 bucks isn't too bad.

I loved the pixel graphics, 80‚Äôs slasher vibe, and very exciting gameplay! The story was great! I hope there is a sequel.

 My only gripes would be to make the checkpoints a little closer together, and the option to skip the cutscenes after you seen them, so if you die, you don‚Äôt have to repeat the same cutscene over and over. 

But overall, I think it was a great experience, and it‚Äôs the first time I‚Äôve been excited about playing a game in a long time. I was counting the days to its release!

Played today and absolutely loved it!

I feel like if the Friday the 13th movie and The Thing movie had a baby, it would be this game.

Style was fantastic, soundtrack was awesome, story was so much fun and the gameplay was great!

A health icon would be nice but apart from that, it blew my expectations away!

"Fish on the Desktop" is not just a game; it's a transformative experience that has undeniably enriched my life. From the moment I first launched the game, I was captivated by its simplicity and charm. The serene underwater world that my desktop screen is able to create with the fish living on it is a testament to the game's ability to transport players to a tranquil realm, providing a much-needed escape from the stresses of everyday life. As I navigated through the virtual aquatic environment, I found myself immersed in the calming ambiance, surrounded by vibrant marine life and soothing fish swimming on my desktop. The game's intuitive mechanics and engaging "gameplay" allowed me to unwind and embrace a sense of mindfulness. "Fish on the Desktop" became my sanctuary, a place where I could momentarily detach from the hustle and bustle of the real world. Beyond its entertainment value, the game subtly instilled a sense of responsibility and environmental awareness. Caring for the virtual fish in their habitat mirrored the importance of nurturing and preserving our own planet. This newfound perspective translated into my daily life, encouraging me to be more conscious of my ecological footprint. In essence, "Fish on the Desktop" transcended the boundaries of a mere game, becoming a catalyst for positive change in my life. It serves as a reminder that even in the virtual realms, simple pleasures and mindful interactions can have a profound impact, ultimately contributing to a better, more balanced existence. (this game made my mother come back and made me ascend to a new level of being)
genuinely a very delightful little thing. look at my fishies swim on my desktop! so joyous! yay! fish time!

One of the best games I've ever had the pleasure of purchasing and buying. Genuinely life changing, the game play is phenomenal, and the Chinese really put the cherry on top. As a long term gamer, this is by far the best game. I can write a whole essay, but i'll stop myself. Just buy it for yourself (it's only 99 cents) and experience the joys of fish on desktop.

holy fuck this game is life-changing. the perspectives this game has provided to me have proved invaluable, both in game and in life as a whole. do you pursue a career as a cutthroat businessman, selling stock as soon as they decrease in value? or do you retain your empathy, holding these aquatic creatures close to your heart and granting them a spot in your aquarium as long as financially possible. i can't remember the last time any piece of media touched me so dearly, and i would recommend this game to any and everyone. Thank you.

best game ever, the immersive experience of fish swimming on the desktop is like no other. I would never have known the experience of true love if not for the fish I care for on my desktop. fish on the desktop. œµ( 'Œò' )œ∂

Marvelous. Truly breathtaking. One cannot simply describe just how intricately crafted this experience of a game is. One must purchase and play this masterpiece to truly understand the deeper meaning and message behind such a project with such a deep meaning behind it. The graphics alone will tell you such a brilliantly written story that most triple AAA games shall be put to shame.

I feel truly enlightened by this wonderful addition to my games collection, and I shall cherish each and every single moment that I get to play this fine wine of a game.

This... is not just a recommendation, no, this is a plea, for you, dear Steam User, to buy and play this game. For there is simply no other experience that could possibly gift you the same rollercoaster of emotions as this.

Truly... magnificent.

To call this a game would be a gross understatement. Fish on the desktop is not a game, but an experience. My life has not been the same since the day I downloaded this work of art onto my computer. These fish have made me a better man. A kinder and gentler person. They've brought me closer to God. I love each individual fish like a child. Watching these beautiful creatures swim around my computer, I feel as though everything will be alright. I feel like maybe, just maybe, there's a way out of all the madness of modern life. In a word, I feel at peace. There are no downsides to installing this beautiful breath of life into an otherwise dull world.

Thank you, Fish on the desktop. I am better because of you. I hope and pray that more fish will be added in the future, and I hope everyone who reads this will buy Fish on the desktop for $0.99. I promise you will not regret it.

love these fish. make me so happy. i like enabling always on top so that they can always be with me and always provide me joy and love and company. best money ever spent in my life. these fish truly are on the desktop. im a whole different man because of this game. my life is changed entirely for the better

There is really a lot to say about this game. I was gifted this a few months back, however did not launch it until about a month after that initial date. At the time I was naive. The fish were amusing! Fun! Entertaining! Trying to complete schoolwork and other things with these fish was great. However, the achievements changed me. After I reached that sweet 100% completion, I searched for other goals. The leader board. That damned leader board. I wanted to know how far it went. How deep the rabbit hole would go. 

It was fun at first, trying to figure out that optimal strategy to get the absolute most out of these fish. After a week it became my life. Taking care of hundreds of sharks just to gain a bit more on the leader board. 

One thing i'm annoyed about is the lack of anti cheat, or any purging of the leader boards. While this game is fine without it, everyone past rank 8 on the leader board has cheated. Why? Wheres the fun in cheating your way to the top, never experiencing what fish on your desktop really does to you. The sharks. The barracudas. They speak in riddles. To all who consider hacking on this game, I hope whatever fish god lies above curses you to an eternity of fish hell. 

Overall a pretty fun timekiller! would buy again.

Enigma Code: Prologue‚Ä¶ well, it's the prologue for something that doesn't exist yet.
---

I'm going to quote the store page and then respond to each bullet point; this is what's advertised:
[list]
Game features:
[*]Unusual visual style
[*]Mysterious story
[*]Short duration (10-15 minutes)
[/list]
[list]
[*][i]Unusual visual style[/i] Is it though? You can watch for yourself in the video on the store page, it's not that unusual just old. (which would be fine, I don't care that it looks like it's from 1999, but it's not unusual)
[*][i]Mysterious story[/i] Did you watch the video on the store page? Because that's it, that's the entire mystery. You've watched the entire mystery ~ there is no ending within "this" game, that would be the next one (that doesn't exist) after this "prologue"
[*][i]Short duration (10-15 minutes)[/i] ~ They claim 10-15 minutes, personally it took me 6 and that includes solving the "puzzle" that gets you the achievement. I suppose if you read really, really slow and have a difficult time clicking on 1 of 6 boxes it might take you substantially longer than 6 minutes.
[/list]
More to the point let me make it clear this game doesn't innovate or have any deep game play. It's a very straight forward visual novel that you read and make a couple of "choose your own adventure" style choices that have no effect on the outcome. Aside from clicking on a couple of folders to "solve" a puzzle (that is so easy I have a hard time calling it a puzzle‚Ä¶) you're just reading/listening to dialogue and answering a couple of irrelevant questions before being told "this is a mystery" which I suppose is the hook to get you to buy their next game? (which doesn't exist yet? if ever?)

Look, the game isn't even long enough for me to hate it. If this was free I'd be telling everyone to download it and get a free achievement while maybe being mildly curious what their next game would be.

But it's $1 and it has basically no content aside from a few minute long commercial for another product that doesn't even exist yet.

How am I supposed to recommend this?

Watch the video on the store page, it's 1 minute long. If you want to see 5 more minutes of that same screen while that character keeps talking and gives you no additional information, then go ahead and donate $1 to this developer by buying it.
---

Bottom line: This wants to set itself up as a mystery, but there's not enough content to even engage with.
---

This is not worth a dollar. It's basically a demo for a possibly much longer game. The audio sounds are grating. The voice is AI. This could be fleshed out into a game, but it's not worth money at this point. I would not recommend paying for it. It feels like less than a demo.

Really not a lot to say here, as it is incredibly short, but still intriguing. What it offers is good. 
You are an AI that seemingly lost its memories, theres a lot of bugs, lost data, and broken files, digging deeper it looks like all of it wasnt an accident. The visuals are crunchy and nice, the character is animated, which I didnt expect, (only looked at the screenshots.)

Nothing bad to say here, Im interested and look forward to see more of it, given this is only the prologue.

Thank you C-14, for providing me with a copy, much appreciated!

[b] Horror/Surrealist centered Curator: [url=store.steampowered.com/curator/43071910/] KuriKuration[/url] [/b]

Story wise, I can't piece very much, but on the other hand, the theme, the overall aesthetic it was aiming for is somewhat well executed. Creepy and mysterious vibes complemented by a rather simplistic layout of things. Not half bad for a short point and click game, definitely would like to know more about the story.

Short visual novel that would be worth expanding.

The presentation is what draws you in. You assume the role of an AI in charge of keeping everything in order. But then something unusual happens, and the boss wants to know what happened. 

Everything happens on a computer screen, however the gameplay is extremely constrained. When the boss asks a question, you're able to respond by selecting one of the options. The three desktop icons might suggest freedom, but they only function when the boss instructs you to click on them. In any case, there's not much to see in there because most of it displays an error message.

The whole game can be finished during your lunch break.

Non-branching visual novel followed by the laziest Windows 95 interactive facsimile ever.  The game screenshots above literally show ever single bit of "gameplay" that this offers. I'm not sure how I got this game, probably as part of bundle, but the remote possibility that I paid 99 cents for this garbage makes me feel slightly ill. I love retro gaming and retro styled gaming and yet could find zero redeeming content here.

[b]I'd be disappointed if I paid for this as it stands. [/b]It's *very* short, but I was actually hooked by the end of the 14 minutes.  I liked the old-school graphics.

It kind of thrusts you into the hot seat of a story that's already in motion.  That threw me off at first, but I felt like it just started getting good when the prologue ends! It's a bittersweet feeling. 

This review is somewhat given in good faith:  I genuinely think this could be a cool project if it's as intriguing as the last 30 seconds were.  Don't buy the prologue at $0.99 though.  It's too short.

One QoL thing that I'd like to see is the dialogue immediately progressing when you choose what to say: As it is, you click a dialogue option and then have to click again to hear the next line. I'm not sure if that's intended, but I found it strange.

I will preface this by saying that this game is complete trash.  It's not playable by any means. 
I will also state that being a fellow game developer, using assets that you did not purchase the rights to is illegal to do. I saw assets used in other war games as well as music that is not copyright (or royalty) free.

The game's current reviews are fake and do not actually reflect the game itself or its gameplay.  They are reviews from the artists and generally fake to help bolster its overall score. 

So, onto the review of the game itself...

The game is made using Unity (A free version) as the intro slate suggests.

The menu is not properly play-tested and broken from the get-go.  If I navigate to an exit window, and decide to hit "cancel", I am brought back to the main menu but now no longer able to proceed forward into the game, it just stuck in a loop forever.

Okay, so I close and re-open the game.  I go to start to play the game, I keep trying to click to start the game, it errors out over and over again, after about 20 clicks I'm finally able to proceed into the next menu which allows to (once again play the game, or play a tutorial.  I go to click on to play the game, I am then FORCED to consume a tutorial which is nothing more than a huge "power point" style presentation about "how awesome this game will be" and doesn't provide any sustenance as to what the game actually is!

And this leads me to another big point.  I checked out this game also on youtube as well as its incredibly failed kickstarter and nowhere anywhere in any social media platform does the creator of this game actually TELL you what this game is about in a concise way.  The creator just goes on and on and on and on about things.  Things that don't hook up or make sense or tell about what the game is or the game's actual gameplay or the point or objective.  That is a crucial game design mechanic.  You can't have a game if you don't know what it is, or could tell someone what it is.  For example, take StarCraft, in one sentence I can tell you what it is: "It's a realtime strategy game about three opposing forces all wanting the same goal."  However "WARZOOM" I have absolutely NO idea what it's about but apparently the creator says there's expansions (which you have to pay for?)

So when I finally get to playing the game, guess what? I can't play it after all BECAUSE IT'S NOT DONE.  So this entire "Game" is just one big presentation thing? I don't think this qualifies as Steam content, let alone a game.

I just don't get why this exists and why the creator reveres this mess? Apparently as he quotes, "WARZOOM created in 1987 became a hit board game. WARZOOM is now coming to PC, Laptop, Tablet and Smart Phone." I have literally found nothing about that.  Anywhere. Warzoom doesn't exist in the real world other than in this guy's head and maybe a friend or two he might know.  Where's the hit? where's the awards? Where actual GAME. There's absolutely nothing. That's called lying sir, it's deceitful and it's scummy.

The fact that this game is offering in-game payments for content that doesn't exist is a huge violation of Steam standards. On top of the stolen assets.  On top of the lying.  On top of the fake reviews.  On top of it not even being a playable game.

You sir need to really re-evaluate yourself and your efforts if you think this is some "BIG HIT" with nothing to show for it.

I'll be following up with Steam to flag this content as fake / scam content.

As an avid strategy gamer I was looking for something new and casual to play and I cam across Warzoom.

It's hard to even call this a game. What it actually seems to be is a power point presentation explaining the rules and how exciting and cool this game is and a vehicle to sell skins from 99c to $2.99

It talks about being a conversion from the hit board game warzoom. I'm an avid board game collector (and nerd) Warzoom was a French made WW2 skirmish rule set for miniatures released by Aron Clement in 2012. This is not that game, and the actual game called warzoom was far far from being a hit. 

The splash screens appear to be artwork from other games . After a quick google search the images used on all of the splash screens are taken directly from War Thunder. 

I'm not surprised that the artist who supposedly worked on this project has disabled comments to their game review and put their profile on private. I would imagine if Gaijin Entertainment somehow find this it will be copyright struck immediately. 

There is no solo mode, apparently its "coming soon"

The game lobby is empty so no multiplayer

This just seems to be a vehicle to sell skins for 99 cents to $2.99 each. 

I read the positive reviews and I'm not sure how they could have written anything positive at all - there is nothing to play.


The characters and skins you can "play" appear to be pre made assests

I'm just confused as to how and why this is even on steam, all that seems to work is the buy a skin option.

Don't even waste your bandwidth or disk space to download this, its completely pointless. Unless you want to buy skins for a game that appears not to exist.

The publisher / dev team have used assets ripped directly from a popular video game. Used a name from a game they obviously do not own. Then claimed that warzoom is from the hit board game. 

I don't know for sure if this game is a purposeful scam or a game made by kids who don't know any better.

Fun game, wish it was more popular. Chickens rule everything around me! I'm completely hooked on this game now - I love amassing a large hoard of chickens armed to the teeth and parading around the map like a god. Foxes fear me. Raccoons fear me. I fear me. 

I truly haven't played an arcade-style game this fun in a while. The mechanic is really easy to grasp, and the power-ups add a whole other level of mischief and total chaos. I've played a few rounds and I just want to keep replaying and seeing how far I can go. I can't wait for this game to grow and evolve too, it's already so much fun.

Simple game where you save chickens from predators.

You begin by selecting your guardian. While gorillas have more health and geese have greater speed, cats provide the most balanced gaming because all of their stats are equal. The gathering radius, which attracts chickens towards you, is roughly the same for everyone.

Then you pick the stage you want to play. Only woodlands is available at first, the rest are unlocked as you beat stages. These are fun, and contain elements to make them unique. Stages are the most interesting feature because the main gameplay doesn't change much and can become repetitive.

The goal is to run around and gather chickens that spawn at random spots. They will begin to follow you as you get closer, and there is no limit to how many you can have. Chickens come in three sizes. The largest is the slowest, but you can carry one in your mouth. There are chicken coops on both sides of the map. When a chicken is delivered there, you earn both money and time. Time is always running out, and you must continue to acquire chicks in order to survive.

Other animals such as foxes and wolves will hunt you. If you have chickens, they will stop rushing after you and eat one of them. You can get rid of predators by purchasing powerups. The most entertaining is the one where you give each of your chickens a rifle or laser. The shop can be opened at any moment, and money transfers between runs, so you don't have to spend everything in a single run. 

Dead predators drop a golden egg. This feature is currently broken; the game crashes when you grab two eggs.
Such an addictive game! Stay away unless you want to fill your dreams with endless chickens dominating the world!

For the price of a meal deal, this game is huge value if you like Crossy Road style graphics and want to have a mindless blast.

Yes, use your pussy to save the birds from the wolves and all kinds of other minions of destruction.

Game's pretty cool, though really simple, I hope there's plans to flesh this out in further updates.
Basically, it's another one of those bullet heaven games, but there's a roguelite map progression mechanic for some reason (though TBH it doesn't really add much to the game.)

The transformation potions mentioned in the game's store page are basically "classes" you advance by drinking more of said potion, and the more you drink, the more active and passive skills you can unlock.
Big breasts- explosions and AoE
Small breasts- single target attacks and speed
Corruption- IDK, there's a bunch of damage over time stuff?
Muscles- physical/melee + crit. (Kinda jack of all trades, I wish it was a tank build or that there was more of a focus on close range or something.)
"Beast" (catgirl)- summons
Hips- ...more AoE, I guess?

Anyway, each potion DOES affect the character's appearance a bit, though most are WAY too subtle until the meter maxes out and you evolve.
Kinda grumpy how little the BE potion changes her size until the meter maxes out in particular, and even her maxed size isn't THAT much bigger. The beast potion adds a tail and little cat ears as the meter fills, and the corruption potion gets horns.
Basically what I'm getting at here is the breast potions, the hip and muscle potions, they're all super weak visually, the dev/artist barely touched the character, probably didn't want to have to redraw anything, I guess.

Still, it's a pretty generic bullet heaven / action-roguelite / Vampire-like / horde battler, and the transformation mechanic isn't really enough to make the game particularly unique, though the price helps.
The game's short too, out of the 2 hours I played this so far, I only really actively played it for about an hour, I left my PC running, and in that hour I've beaten two of the three difficulties and only failed three times, two due to terrible RNG and once due to me disliking my build.

IDK, the game's okay, but pretty middling, my feelings for the game are so-so and will entirely depend on when/if the dev does some balancing and content updates.

7/10
Don‚Äôt be fooled by the screenshots, this is not in fact a H-game. It does contain some suggestive art, but it‚Äôs there for the purpose of giving the game some flavour, instead of being the whole point of it.

What you are actually dealing with here is an entertaining little entry of the auto shooter genre spearheaded originally by Vampire Survivors. The core gameplay in Wedding Witch doesn‚Äôt differ that much from other games of the genre, but it does make some changes to spice up the usual formulae.
In my opinion the most interesting change is splitting a run into multiple shorter sequences. After each level you are able to select a body upgrade which will extend the number options in the weapon/upgrade pool. This helps somewhat limit the annoying RNG factor often plaguing the genre, and allows the player to plan ahead their build in the beginning of the run based on how the upgrades are scattered across the levels.

If I had to criticise one thing about the game, it would be the lack of polish which is holding the game back in some areas. A prime example of the rough edges is the build balance, which could definitely use some improvements. One of the available build types is unfortunately so underpowered that it‚Äôs borderline unplayable. 

I must admit that I originally bought the game to laugh at some anime t*ddies, but ended up staying for the gameplay. I have played quite a few games of the genre, and gameplay wise this one is far from the worst ones I have tried. The movement and hitboxes are tight enough to make the action and projectile dodging feel satisfying for hours.

Regarding the art I feel obligated to reinstate that it‚Äôs good, but not all that lewd, nor is there that much of it actually in the game (I wish there was more). But I‚Äôd wager that as long as you are not expecting to get a full blown H-game and have at least a little interest in the auto shooter genre, you are bound to have a decent time with this one. Beating the available content and grabbing all the achievements takes around 7-10 hours in total, which to me felt like the ideal completion time for this particular game.

-----------------------------------------

[h1]--- Overview ---[/h1]
A Vampire Survivors-like game containing a cute Witch preparing for her wedding with a normal human male by taking it upon herself to prepare for her first night with him by altering herself so that mayhaps he will like her more! With three difficulties to take on and several end-cards to see, there is a lot of replayability here!

[h1]--- The LEWDS ---[/h1]
As your witch consumes potions, she gains minor traits related to that potion. When she maxes out any transformation bar, she will take on traits heavily associated with that potion and her body will change appropriately. Note that if you max out any bar after you've maxed out your first, it will not change anything.

After you complete the game, you get an image of the girl in her end-game state (whether she is normal from never maxing out a potion or she has maxed out a potion and is transformed). Unfortunately, there is no gallery associated with this, so if you want to get a screenshot of a transformation you missed, you'll have to replay about 15-20 minutes to get to that point again.

There is no nudity of any kind, only erotic designs associated with her appearance. Aside from that, there is also no lewd element to the gameplay of any kind, the only erotic element of the game is in the appearance of the witch.

[h1]--- Gameplay Overview ---[/h1]
You run around with arrow keys/WASD controls with an auto-attack going that auto-homes onto an enemy and that enemy will drop experience points. Collecting those allows you to level up mid-fight, enabling you to become stronger or unlock certain abilities. At the end of each stage, you're given the ability to consume a certain potion. That potion not only changes the appearance of the witch slightly, but also unlocks the ability to obtain new skills when you further level up.

Dying at any point means you start over from 0, but this also means that if the game crashes (as it did for me a few times) or if you need to leave for any reason, the game doesn't save your progress as it doesn't distinguish between death or game closing, so you lose your progress in that current session.

Around the maps are also pumpkins that can contain a variety of items such as a one-hit kill item that kills every enemy on screen, an item that pulls items in towards you, additional coins for use in the shop, and more!

Failing a match doesn't mean you are left in the same state as you were before. Unlocking achievements and finding coins in-game provides you with a currency you can use to further upgrade your witch, giving you more of an edge right out the gate. The unfortunate aspect of this is that the game definitely expects you to be grinding to get to your 'ultimate state,' but there is a level of progression with it that is satisfying. I'd say it definitely expects you to grind too much, but not an unreasonable amount, just a mildly irritating amount.

The audio and sound design is fairly forgettable overall, but not jarring or inappropriate for what is being shown.

Despite having high replay value, there is very little in between that besides unlocking new abilities. It's satisfying to see if you killed 10,000 enemies in one run, sure, but the higher difficulties don't unlock new endings, just higher chances of getting Strong potions that up your transformation meter in a category by 2 instead of 1. 

[h1]--- Issues / Bugs ---[/h1]
¬∑ I had about 3 crashes during my time playing.

[h1]--- Final Thoughts ---[/h1]
Belonging more in the field of being softcore and tame, it's hard to really put Wedding Witch into a category-- being not lewd enough to warrant being a NSFW title and not tame enough to truly be considered SFW. I think I recommend it to anyone who simply likes the cute witch attached to a Vampire Survivor-style game, but not if you're expecting anything more than that.

Wedding Witch is a rogue lite game that feels like a cute twist on Vampire Survivors. The main draw is an injection of lewd energy, and a slay the spire type of level selection. 

The slay the spire type level selection highlights one of the major sour points of this game however, as levels are too short for you to actually enjoy playing with your build. I find myself often running against the clock, or trying to avoid boss fights so that I can find revealed treasures on the map. 

As difficulty progresses through the games 3 options you'll find that damage seems to be more homogenized between everything, making the balance tip in the favor of abilities that attack at more frequent intervals and at greater range. 

All in all there are some really interesting ideas going on with this game, and the price isn't offensive for what it is, but I'd like to see this game with a little more development and thought put into the game play side of things.

Edit: Lack of mouse support in any way shape or form is also a huge annoyance in this game and feels like a lazy omission.

Before I say anything else, I just want to state what many other reviews have noted- there is no nudity in this game. Suggestive themes and provocative images, yes. but it never goes farther than that.

Wedding Witch is a game I didn't expect to like as much as I did. Being a descendant of Vampire Survivors, it makes sense. But I usually come in to these games with very low expectations- some lewd themes and not much else- so having just a little bit of substance made it a bit more interesting.

The basic gameplay is pretty bland, all things said. If you've played an hour of Vampire Survivors, this is just that but with small "stage objectives" to move on to the next round. A round based system is interesting, but there is basically no variety. Your options are either:
A. Kill a set number of monsters
B. Kill one specific boss monster (With nets additional rewards, making it the best hands-down)
C. Wait out a timer
D. "Break a seal" which is just waiting out a timer but an invincible enemy drops aoes on you the whole time.
A novelty at first, these game modes end up being not very interesting. As opposed to the 20-30 minute timers of most VS clones, you can finish a whole set of 7 stages in about 30 minutes, which I think breaks up the action a little too much.

Last bit about the actual gameplay, the skills are "okay" but ultimately not very interesting either. They all seem to work well enough, but they are often not explained properly (Some don't even have descriptions at all) and the level-up tooltips do not reflect the total gains you're getting across all levels in that skill. The method of acquiring skills through the potions is a good idea, but I do think we need the ability to re-roll level ups as a way to maintain a good build.

The potions system is probably the most interesting part of the whole game. The idea of "building your waifu" through body mod potions at the end of each level is pretty cool, and the fact that some potions have direct effects on the character even before the final transformation is pretty neat. It can be frustrating when the potions you want don't spawn, and the fact that your ideal waifu won't always be the most powerful (Small chest my beloved, you're at least half decent), but I really like the concept. I would love to see it fleshed out over a longer period of time, and maybe more options in the potion types.

The art is all decent, it's nice to not be worried about stolen assets. The enemies are kind of uninspired and the lack of zone variety is a disappointing, but it all still works I suppose. 
My biggest criticism in the art department is the initial state of the main character. She's a bombshell right out the gate. While I know that's probably a way to sell more copies, I do think it kind of defeats the purpose of the narrative. She has huge breasts already, why would she want to go out and drink potions to make them even bigger (And the small chest potions don't even really make them small...)? The more niche ones fit okay I suppose, but I think it would be more interesting to have a much more plain main character that you transform into a bombshell with said potions, rather than being hot right out the gate. 

There is also the issue of the translation, it's not very good. The English is often broken and horrifically clunky. It needs another pass over an actual English speaking editor. Not that the story is anything interesting, but even the menus and tooltips are difficult to understand at times. 

Lastly, the music- dull. Sounds royalty free to me. I'm sorry if it's an original track or something, but it does not add anything. Sound effects are not great either, monsters are standard and the main character makes funny sex noises.

All in all, Wedding Witch is alright. Definitely something I would love to see the team expand on and learn from. I think I would love a refined version of this with a bigger budget. Maybe some day.

Definitely not a Hentai game btw, not even really NSFW or Mature imo. But it's one of the best Bullet Heaven games I've played thus far, and I've played a lot. Would definitely recommend it for anyone who likes games like Halls of Torment, Vampire Survivors and/or Yet Another Zombie Survivors.

At its core, the game has good ideas. This much, it deserves. It's a cute little experience and I like that. And, for the record, the the rating is not a result of the game being bad, it certainly works and is functional...it's just that it also feels incomplete. Since the context within which Wedding Witch exists really help illustrate just how lacking the game is. And, in turn, help illustrate just how much work went into games that Wedding Witch walks in the footsteps of. Because, here's the thing. For the same price as Wedding Witch, you can get far superior experiences in Vampire Survivors, Boneraiser Minions, or even Elemental Survivors with infinitely more depth, polish, and charm. Or, if it's a lewd Survivors-like you fancy, there are games out there that deliver a better playing experience with better sexual content out there as well. 

The most obvious problem that Wedding Witch has is a general lack of polish that almost feel like they get taken for granted in other games in the genre. And, this manifests in many ways. 
Sure, every Survivors-like will have variability in effectiveness of its various weapons and skills, the good ones generally don't have upgrades that you make sure to avoid. There's also a general visibility problem. Be it literally seeing what's happening on the screen with certain attack types. A lack of information with a lack of tooltips. There are also basics that could have been slightly altered to make the game feel significantly better, so you don't have to unlock upgrades to reach what feels like should have been the base starting values. And, of course, there's the game's stability as a whole. The game crashed on me multiple times in my fairly limited playtime. 

A lot of the game also just feels unfinished. For instance, after you complete a run with a maxed out type, you unlock that version of the witch to start the run with. But, as far as I can tell, this is purely a cosmetic choice as the witch reverts to the stock version right away. It's also a shame that the routes have no other interactions other than whichever one you get six hearts in first. It would have been really nice to have the potions transform the witch based on how many of each potion you drank, which in turn could have affected the story in some way. Or, better yet, create infinitely more replayability and fun by having the powers in use be augmented by the potions (e.g. This explosion power now spawns projectiles after detonation). Even what's arguably the best part of the game, the flowers upgrades, feel like they are a good baseline, but could have been so much more extreme in what they can bring to the table. There's also an Extras menu entry that feels like might have been a gallery before the game was scaled down to just two cutscenes and seven stock pieces of art. 

Don't get me wrong, what's there is a really good start...but, it's a start that feels more fitting of an initial release in Early Access, not as a finished product. As, just looking at the game, you can see where the gaps are where if you filled in the missing pieces, the game could have been so much more. Even if that more came with a higher price tag, it would have made the experience feel way more worthwhile.

Here is my review of Wedding Witch after completing 100% achievements.

Graphics:
The graphics are charming but lack consistency. Some areas and characters are well-designed and vibrant, while others feel rushed and lack the same level of detail. This inconsistency can be jarring and detracts from the overall visual experience.

Monster Variety:
The game's monster variety is disappointingly stagnant. After a few hours, it becomes clear that the same types of enemies repeat with little variation, making the combat encounters feel monotonous and uninspired.

Content and Completion:
Despite being marketed as a complete game, "Wedding Witch" feels more like an early access demo. The game is notably short, and it feels like significant portions of content are missing. The world lacks depth, and there are few areas to explore, which makes the game feel unfinished and leaves players wanting more.

Adult Content:
Contrary to its marketing, there is no actual adult content in the game. While some might see this as a neutral point, it‚Äôs worth mentioning to set correct expectations for those who might be influenced by the game's promotional materials.

Gameplay and Build Mechanics:
The gameplay concept is interesting, particularly the idea of various build types. However, the execution falls short. Mixing builds often results in a significantly underpowered character compared to sticking with a pure build. This imbalance can be frustrating and limits the player's strategic options.

Game Length:
The game length is excessively short, making it feel more like a brief distraction than a full-fledged game. Even with its low price point, the content offered feels insufficient, and players are likely to be left unsatisfied.

Overall Value:
While it's hard to be overly critical given the low price, "Wedding Witch" comes across as an attempt to mimic the success of games like "Vampire Survivors," but it fails to capture the same level of engagement and depth. It feels like the developers lost interest before fully fleshing out the game. Despite its potential, the game falls flat and struggles to justify even its modest price tag.

Conclusion:
"Wedding Witch" offers a few hours of diversion, but its lack of content, variety, and polish makes it difficult to recommend, even at the low cost of five dollars. It has the potential to be a fun game, but as it stands, it feels incomplete and underwhelming.

Yet another lewd bullet heaven, but aside from some slightly suggestive character art and a questionable upgrade mechanic involving increasing breast, hip size and such... it's very solid actually. If there's one thing I can criticize of the gameplay itself, is perhaps the relatively slow speed of player and enemies alike, which never truly becomes high even towards the end of the run.

As of now, the game's content variety isn't too high, as there's no real stage variety aside from the different objectives and bosses. There's 6 classes to unlock, but that's about it. Still, a promising start for a game that is already quite a lot of fun, and frankly not even that lewd.

[h1] Wedding Witch is a fun game if you give it the chance. [/h1]

First and foremost let's get this out of the way. There is no nudity or h-scenes in this game, do not go into this game expecting that. If you are looking for nudity or h-scenes in a Vampire Survivors style game, I recommend Kagura Survivors and get the free patch for that game. With that out of the way, let's talk about what Wedding Witch does do.

Wedding Witch is a Vampire Survivor like game but instead of going to a stage and trying to survive for the time limit, you instead pick a stage to go to on the map with the goal of progressing to the end to beat the succubus in the final stage. You have three difficulties of maps to choose from being Normal, Hard and Nightmare. Each stage can have a different objective on how to complete it such as defeat a certain amount of enemies, defeat a boss, etc. As you level up you can choose to pick a skill or magic from the four options presented to you in order to power Belle up. These upgrades carry over to the next stage you go to so you are always starting a new stage stronger than you were at the start of the previous stage.

It is important to note that there is no rerolling or banishing here, you get four options and you have to pick one. This could be seen as a let down for some but I think it adds to the challenge of the game. It makes you pay more attention to what skills or magic you choose instead of just blindly choosing and hoping everything works out. This leads into what I think is an interesting mechanic.

As you beat stages you get the choice to take one potion out of a selection of three. This is where an interesting mechanic and fanservice mix. The potion you take will indeed change Belle's appearance but it also is what determines which types of magic she will have better access to. For example if you want projectile magic, you would want to take the potion which makes the breasts smaller. If you want explosion magic you would choose the potion that makes the breasts bigger and so on you get the idea. 

This is interesting as it poses the question to the player, are you more interested in changing Belle's appearance purely for fanservice or do you choose a potion because the magic and skills it gives you access to better compliments your playstyle or works better for your build? Yes there is fanservice here which could cater to a player's interests but at the same time it does work as an interesting mechanic. The way you choose to shape Belle's appearance will also impact what kind of skills and magic you can use. While you could win by making Belle's hips to the maximum level for example, it does not mean you will have the best, or most fun build gameplay wise. The choices you make for fanservice could actually make the game more challenging. 

That is the thing with this game though, if you look past the fanservice of the game, you have an enjoyable game that can provide the player with some challenge and also make the choices you make to strengthen Belle actually fell like they matter. You could choose just willy nilly fire and forget style, and you will most likely feel it in the later stages, especially on Nightmare difficulty. 

The game also has flowers you can find in the stages to add to your bouquet which is your main weapon of attack. When you find the flower you get the option to pick one of three flowers to add to your bouquet which will each have a different effect. Some of these will work great with your build while others not so much. Just like the skills and magic, you do not have a reroll option. What is offered is what you get, make the best choice for what you are working with or plan to work with.

This game is a lot of fun and honestly I think it is worth playing especially if you like Vampire Survivor style games, even if you are not a fan of anime like witches or fanservice. There is actual fun gameplay to be had here if you give it a chance.

As of now, I can't recommend this game.  It's not a bad game, but it's also not great.  There are tons of Survivors clones out there, and this just doesn't stand out.  

1. To get this aside, no matter what the tags say, there is no true sexual content in this game.  Some mild cheesecake, but that's it.  It's cute, but it's not going to be a reason to buy the game.
2. The mechanics aren't bad, but they don't bring enough new to the table.  
3. Enemies are pretty generic.  Even Beautiful Mystic Survivors has better boss fights.
4. Crash bugs with no resuming a run.  If it was one or the other, I could live with it, but it's both.  You crash, you lose the whole run, and it doesn't look like much expectation of updates (note, bought this near release. If you see patch updates when you read this, ignore this complaint)
5. Clearly and sloppily cut content.  There is an Extras button.  It doesn't do anything.  Doesn't even let you replay the simple closing animations.

Okay, this is a very good bullet heaven game, like, really good.

Everything really works well, the reviews saying only the bouquet deals damage and the spells are useless? Don't listen to them, this people got totally filtered. In fact I have completed several runs with different magic schools and 0 upgrades on the bouquet which is your basic attack, it can be upgraded to deal more damage, have more range and attack faster, but it is only broken when playing on lower difficulties which are unlocked once you clear the previous one.

I have played the game at the same time as one of my friends who also is a Vampire Survivors completionist and we unlocked Nightmare Difficulty (max difficulty at the moment) in just three or four runs. And Nightmare difficulty is what allows you to do even more flashy and broken builds (the bouquet here only works in the first two stages, fully maxed, beyond those two initial stages the bouquet is... just not good enough).

The balancing of the different schools is pretty decent with only one exception being the Familiars (summons) which suffer from attack delays due to them having to look for a new target after killing the previous one, it is not terrible but it would be nice to have more responsive summons.

For the price I loved what I got and I'm a bit frustrated at the same time because the game could be so much better if dual school effects or interactions were added, more illustrations for the endings if you maxed two different magic schools, and more control and customization options for the runs (like more stages, rerolls, banish spells, more control on what type of build you want to do like in Vampire Survivors for example).

I know the game is pretty much an artist's love project (love your art Chowbie), so I believe the game is complete and done, but I REALLY want to see some more updates because the game has tremendous potential. If the devs decide to make good paid DLCs with new stuff I'm 100% willing to pay for them.

Oh right, I also have experienced 0 bugs and the game is NOT NSFW, it is just tasteful spicy art.

So, this is a nice solitaire game but it's not a game with progression, it's like windows solitaire - you win or you don't win and then you play again. But there is an achievement for playing 10 games.

The game is much more strategy than luck but you can sometimes be unlucky since you need a matching suit to be drawn to dismiss a royal.

100% Achievements completed in 90 minutes, I feel like I'd figured most of the strategies in that time. Easy Achievements IMO.

Some value-add would be to have daily / weekly / monthly high score tables - The highest score for one match that is.

No regrets buying this, I enjoyed playing it so it's a recommend for the price of ¬£2.24 (~ $2.86)

Short, sweet fun to scratch that solitaire itch.  Doesn't reinvent the wheel, but does it just different enough to have a good time.  My only suggestion is once you reach the highest difficulty, it should unlock a table of all the cards you've been through.  Otherwise, have a notepad handy.

[h1] A Card Game KING review [/h1]

Royal Card Clash is a VERY simple game with charming graphics and one amazing soundtrack. Each turn you draw 3 cards where each card deals it's value in damage to enemy cards with the goal of destroying all royals (Hey!). The trick is that royals can only be killed by the card of the same suit. That's it! There are no active or passive powers, not different stages, no story, no bossess, just 3 difficulty levels.

And that's perfectly fine, it's still a very well designed and fun. Not every game needs a ton of extra stuff...but it wouldn't hurt. The issue is that, while the game is fun, you would have seen it all in the first 5 minutes, and by the end of the first hour, there is not much else left to do. 

The strategies are simple, the variety-non existing, but a coffee-break game, perhaps, doesn't need it. It's exactly that, a game that is meant to be played every now and then to kill some time. If that's what you are looking for then it fits the bill perfectly. If, however, you are looking for something you can spend hours on at a time, then this isn't the game that can provide it.

[h1][b]The positive[/b] [/h1] 
+ Lovely graphics and animations

+ Excellent soundtrack

+ Solid gameplay (even if it lacks longevity).


[h1][b]The neutral[/b][/h1] 
* Lacks some quality of life features - like a reset button and overview of cards killed and left in the deck. Not knowing the latter will often lead to games where you have already lost, but don't know it yet and reduces the number of tactical choices one can make.


[h1][b]The negative[/b][/h1] 
- At the highest difficulty RNG is a much greater factor than skill.

[h1][b]Conclusion:[/b] [/h1] 
Coffee-break style game with simple but solid gameplay, great soundtrack and visuals but lacks depth and variety needed to support longer play sessions. Recommended.

[i] My Experience [/i]

I had a good time with [b]Royal Card Clash[/b]. It reminded me of another lightweight solitaire-style card game I played last year, [b]Deck 'Em![/b]. I played [b]Royal Card Clash[/b] until I'd  beaten the game on every difficulty at least once, and then continued until I'd accumulated 10 wins (which nets you all of the game's achievements).

It's fairly simple, and has you attempting to attack and defeat all of the royals (face cards) in a deck by attacking them with the numbered cards and aces. Royals are arranged in three stacks with four cards in each. You're dealt three cards at a time, and can put one in a holding slot if you want to save it for later. A 2 card would do 2 points of damage to a royal (and so on), with the caveat that a royal can only be finished by attacking them with a card of the same suit. Aces can either knock a royal down to 1 HP, or finish a royal that has already been reduced to 1 HP. Something that it took me a while to realize (and hopefully this was intentional on the part of developer Gearhead Games) is that if you use an ace to finish a royal that is at 1 HP, the ace goes back into your hand. This is the only time you're able to use a card twice, and this played a substantial role in helping me conquer the highest difficulty.

If you can appreciate a quick-playing, easy-to-learn solitaire game, I think [b]Royal Card Clash[/b] could be just the thing. It's cheap, and I don't regret any of the time I spent with it.

Royal Card Clash is a delightfully innovative take on classic Solitaire, combining strategic elements with the familiar gameplay that we all know and love. As you embark on a journey to defeat royal cards, you'll find yourself captivated by the game's unique mechanics and challenging gameplay.

There are three modes of difficulty: Easy, Standard, and Extreme. The core gameplay is simple: you must use your deck of number cards to attack and defeat the royal cards before your deck runs out. This creates a sense of urgency and encourages thoughtful decision-making. As you progress, you'll unlock achievements and compete on leaderboards, adding a layer of excitement and competition to the game. 

One of Royal Card Clash's strongest features is its easy-to-learn but hard-to-master nature. You'll quickly pick up the basics, but mastering the strategies required to defeat the royals provides a satisfying and rewarding experience. With its intuitive design, the game caters to both casual players and those seeking a challenge.

The game's visuals are clean and appealing, with a minimalist design that allows you to focus on the gameplay. The cards are easy to distinguish, and the game's interface is user-friendly, making it a joy to play on both mobile devices and PC. 

In conclusion, Royal Card Clash is a breath of fresh air in the world of card games. Its unique blend of strategy and classic Solitaire gameplay offers an entertaining experience that will keep you coming back for more. Whether you're a fan of Solitaire or simply on the lookout for something entirely new, Royal Card Clash is an excellent choice.

I loved this. This is a gorgeous immersive artwork right down to the smallest details. I'm a fan of Bryn Oh's work and her stories are so rich and thought-provoking that it's a wonderful experience to see The Brittle Epoch brought to life in this format. Whether enjoying the narrative, pondering The Singularity, or just standing and watching the snow fall- this is a gorgeous and important work accessible on many levels.

Bryn Oh's latest title is a remarkable achievement in art and storytelling, an immersive experience that remains faithful to the original story and long-term art project.

Visually, it‚Äôs a treat, meticulously crafted and captivating. Bryn Oh's style and artistic talents shine through in every detail.

The story telling is where this title truly excels. It takes players on a poignant journey. The emotional depth and intensity of the narrative are genuinely heart-wrenching and have a lasting impact.
To me, what sets this version of The Brittle Epoch apart is its ability to provide deeper insights and explanations. Both new and seasoned Bryn Oh admirers will find the storytelling more accessible and engrossing, allowing players to connect with the characters and their struggles on a profound level.

Looking forward to more from Bryn Oh.
