This is a very mixed review, very close to a negative one, but it just made it over the edge.
The concept is fun, a hidden object type game where you search a large picture for clues.
On the down side, you can only find them in order, and I find a lot of them before they are called for, which is irritating. 
Also there is a strange, annoying timer, which is not only irritating, but very stingy. Luckily it doesn't seem to end the investigation, but just give you fewer stars. Why? Usually games with the stars-per-level mechanism have some replay value, but once you have found the clues, replay is kind of silly.
And stars are need for achievements, as well as opening night time missions, so they also become annoyingly mandatory. 
The missions themselves are okay, though you are led my the nose by the police telling you what to look for next. In fact the game is so simplistic you might think it is for children, except for the murder, the mentions of pornography, and what I assume is going to be a perverted Santa Claus.
Still, I expect to keep playing, and it is tough to give a negative review to a game I want to keep playing. 
One very tepid thumb up.
ADDENDUM: Kind of difficult when the things you are looking for are hidden, and only clicking the clue button reveals it. Geez.

Imagine complaining about a game being too difficult when there are easier difficulty settings and you can unlock all the content by playing on the easier difficulties.

This game is fun and unique. A roguelike tower defense game where you can only place towers within your signal range, and placing towers will increase that range. You cannot be afraid to use towers as disposable shields sometimes just to gain ground, and you must be willing to waste resources placing towers you know will be replaced by better ones. Levels have different rewards and you get better rewards for more challenging levels. Some unique level challenges could be mining resources, or saving energy to build a mission goal. The rewards consists of currency to unlock upgrades for your towers, and artifacts that give you passive buffs for the rest of the game. It looks as though there are over 100 artifacts in the game as of now, and the meta progression to unlock new content is as simple as trying out different artifacts.

When you first start the game, there are 2 difficulties unlocked, and beating the hardest available difficulty unlocks your next difficulty. The difficulties have their own names like officer and captain, so I'm not sure what the "standard" difficulty is, but I think it's safe to say the "standard" difficulty would be one of the default ones unlocked, in which case the game is not nearly as difficult or intimidating as other reviews make it sound. If you decide to increase the difficulty, yes it gets more difficult, and you will probably lose, and perhaps you even need to get lucky with what artifacts you find in order to win. That's kinda normal for a lot of games and idk why people are upset about it. I would be upset if you had to beat the hardest difficulty to unlock things, but to the best of my knowledge, you don't. In other words, this game is accessible. It's not just a brutal game that punishes you. It's easy for people who want it to be easy, and challenging for those who want a challenge.

Not to mention, this game is relatively cheap, and it's well polished as far as I can tell. No bugs, doesn't feel incomplete, it's intuitive and easy to understand. If you like roguelike. strategy, or tower defense games, give this one a try. I will surely play more when I have time.

I've quite enjoyed the demo back in the day and found the gameplay very appealing. I am happy with how the end game evolved since the demo with new mission effects, new towers, more artifacts, etc.

I've played for over 10 hours and discovered around one-third of all the artifacts. I haven't tried many other builds you can choose, so the replayability and variety of runs are very decent.

For the price asked its a nice little tower defense basebuilding game.
Its relatively simple and i feel like its fun comes from the random upgrades (artifacts) you get after each mission.

Its fun, looks nice, sounds nice.

What i wished for, were some more in depth systems that increased replayability like customization of loadouts, stuff i can take from a previous run to the next one to tackle higher difficulties, some more modes, like endless mode (if there is one, i havent seen it, due to short playtime), maybe even finding persistent artifacts i can use to customize my run with (maybe with downsides too).

Furthermore, i think the upgrading paths are a bit limited in choice. Basically every structure has 2 paths to choose from and thats it.
Abilities like laser or the bomb, dont even get an upgrade path although they should and personally i wished there were more artifacts in total.

All in all, for a low price you get a good game that will entertain you for some hours with enough initial depth to keep you hooked, but it lacks some expanded features that could keep you firing it up (like highscores, endless, customization and run mutators) and ultimatively hold it back from its potential.

The dev should keep investing some time adding a few more systems and features, as the basis is there for it to be expanded in any direction he/she wanted.

But outside of that, the enemies can be somewhat fun to go up against. I do wish we got resources a bit faster, because scaling the upgrade trees can be a bit more difficult than I like. The artifacts do make the game more fun and can change your playstyle! I think a change I'd really like is the ability to completely change what buildings you have access to, like either having a balance to spend to decide which ones to use, or just filling out X amount of slots with which ever buildings you'd like. Maybe even a random button! I definitely think the game has good potential, and even with everything I've said I am still enjoying it. I can't wait to see the future of this game!

Very fun and engaging strategy game with much careful thought in its design. Extremely underrated compared to others in its genre. Highly recommend to planning/strategy fans who enjoy facing tough enemies and optimizing heavily to beat them, and those who enjoy being continually challenged/engaged.

There is an excellent balance of structures and instant abilities, where using both is indispensable to beating higher difficulties. Moreover, all the structures and abilities serve a purpose, not only as a whole but within a run - you almost never reach a point where a button gets obsoleted and the best strategy becomes just spamming a few specific buttons every fight until the run ends. 

The enemies and challenges are varied enough to not just repeat the same build order each fight, and similarly the relics are varied enough to enable different strategies each run. Moreover, taking individual hard fights will cost you health but is rewarded with relatively minor rewards (that still add to a significant amount over a course of a run), which significantly mitigates the "taking elites is always the right play unless you are literally about to die" non-choice overly prevalent in similar games.

TLDR: the greatest strength of this game is that it keeps you thinking and itself engaging, unlike much of the dross in its genre.

[hr][/hr] 

One nitpick: the second half of the run is less interesting than the first half. If a run can beat the midboss, the run's strength is too often enough that "hard" fights are beatable with nearly no risk until the end boss, and currently for the second half of the run the focus is on the best reward with little risk-reward analysis. In my opinion, after the midboss on higher difficulties, the hard fights should scale way faster and be way harder, while providing at least a couple easy options so you still have a choice if you decide you can't handle the hard fights; basically it shouldn't be a complete no-brainer to pick hard fights. (Addressing this would also mitigate the matter generator's OP-ness...)

I love to play roguelike and roguelite style games and this game is quite good at what it provides. The early difficulties help to ease the player in and teach about all the mechanics of the game. Whereas the latter difficulties provide a real challenge to beat.

The game is not without flaws though, as the starting faction is in my opinion by far the weakest. The turrets don't do enough, they struggle to get a good economy going and there buildings are quite lack luster compared with the other 2 factions. I do hope the developer gives the first faction some love with the base turrets so they can have an easier time setting up a defense like the other factions. E.g. increasing the turrets attack range so multiple turrets can attack past a wall.

13/15

nice tower defense game. Hard starting off but it's fine when you have a system set up. Getting legendary artifacts is fun but repetitive after a long while. Same gameplay but more/harder enemies. Still worth the price.

Yes there is a difficulty curve at difficulty 3 but it feels to rewarding to beat it, especially when it wasn't just rng. There are hand few of generally broken artifacts but the good ones require you to actually build around them. Forcing a build in this game isn't recommended later on and incentives heavily to go with what you're given with. 

Don't over look some relics, for example: getting 10 defense (temporary health) at the start of each mission seems kinda like it's helping noob players but it actually allows you to ignore the 1st wave and build generators immediately.

If you want dumb/easy fun stick to the 2nd or especially 1st difficulty. If you want to learn from mistakes until you form a strategy then try to get to legend and beat it like im trying. Best of both worlds 8/10.

Edit: Beat Legend but I had a busted run. I had lasers give rad, free lasers every so often, + Rad damage, etc. 
Legend is one of those hard for the sake of being hard difficulties, like A20 in StS, not designed (for 95-99% of players) to win-streak or to play consistently but rather for the challenge and to prove that even if you have a broken run (in any rogue-like) that there's a difficulty that can punch down on you.

One of the best tower defense games in awhile for players looking for a tough challenge. Very well balanced overall where every decision matters and almost every option has a purpose. The game also is such where it feels very fair and you never feel cheated into death.

The first two difficulties are very easy where pretty much anything will work. The game actually starts once once you get to the 3rd difficulty and up.

What I like about the game is the variety of units and how they can change with upgrades, and the advantages of combined arms. For instance, the mortars initially left me cold. Then I realized that with an upgrade I could turn then into bombers. Walls are fairly useless until they are backed up with the device that pushes enemies back. Rockets are great for defending the base. The bosses at the end levels are the only time I use the lasers and the bombers and then I buy mass quantities. I am still feeling my way, so I assume at the higher levels I would probably see things that I am missing right now, or aren‚Äôt important because the challenge is less. I like the fact that there is a choice of the next mission until the end of the level. I have always been a sucker for games that I can play quickly over my lunch hour and this fits that category nicely for me. Generating energy and mining are almost a sub game. I have found the pinned game hints in the discussion thread to be useful as a starting point for developing my own tactics and strategy.

It's a no from me my man. 

The game has a lot of potential, but even on Adventurer, I was getting slapped around after round 3. Enemies are too tanky, too fast, and too strong. 

There also needs to be some RPG aspect that allows you to upgrade things permanently that you can carry into each mission.  

Will probably give it another try in a few weeks or months once there's been some proper balancing, but for now I'd save your money.

Edit #2: Changing my review back to positive, after talking to the dev there's some synergies in the game that make it easier. However, this isn't communicated well and I think it's mostly a UI/Tutorial issue. If FiveHead improves on those, I think a lot of us that felt the game is too difficult, will have some better luck with our runs.

The game could also use a little more in the way of meta progress. There's not much to unlock after a couple of hours. But that's a longer issue to solve.
----

Edit: I gave a quick positive review to support the dev. I've since put 10 hours in, and some post patch and boy is the game extremely difficult, and not in a "get better" kind of way. I truly think the higher difficulties are not humanly possible to complete as I've had times where I'm losing on the second level on an easier difficulty and there's nothing I could have done to do better.

The core of the game has a lot of potential, and I hope Fivehead can keep at it and make the game the best it could be. But it's not at that point right now. I don't think it's worth the $10 currently as it's not even playable imo.
----
Great little tower defense game. Got like 30 hours out of the free demo, I suspect I'll get twice that from the full game. Not bad for $9-10

Please do not listen to the people saying the game is too hard, it was easy to clear missions before the nerf patch, this is a rogue-like tower defense game, in the vein of Dome Keeper (Also a Godot game), it is supposed to be hard, but it is not punishingly so. After you get a few artifacts and unlocks, and learn how the systems work. You'll be clearing harder difficulties in no time (My only criticism is I wish there was a way to see in game what Artifact's you have and haven't already collected.)
We need more thing to beat!!!! The game right now very good with combination of Artifact, but still need some more challenge that dont seem to be repetitive....

This game is simply great. Any complaints about difficulty are unwarranted as once you understand which strategies are effective and which aren't, the game becomes far less of a challenge. The difficulty remains fairly constant as you gain more experience whilst attempting further difficulties. The premise of the game is very entertaining and once you find one of many effective strategies that suit your playstyle this game proves to be satisfying and fun.

very very repetitive, you start with a loadout(about 7 or 8 weapon 3 abilities) which removes a lot of the roguelike aspect of the game, i feel like the game would be way better if you started with one weapon and build your loadout while you play, every game feels the same.

Game is short, repetitive , and hard.  Its only made harder by the fact that if you die, it restarts you from the beginning and theres no healing between missions.  My main complaint is that you cant really enjoy game play because its like you are barely hanging on by the skin of your teeth, then the second you become slightly comfortable, all other paths close and you are forced to end the game with a boss fight. waste of ten bucks tbh

[strike]the balance is so screwed up. havent even unlocked higher difficulties because they throw impossible missions at you regularly enough that getting a run which happens to be lucky enough to push past all the bosses isnt possible in the 5 hours ive played. even the easiest difficulty, whose description makes you think it is for children, is just too difficult. if you lose a single mission, you need to abandon the run because the loss of upgrade materials is enough to fail you, on the EASIEST difficulty. if failing a single mission is meant to be a run killer, then the escape pod mechanic should be removed entirely, instead of wasting the players time soldiering through a dead run.i personally think in all but the harder difficulties the scaling should be forgiving enough to use the escape pod, lose the upgrade materials, and be okay. thats just not how the game is balanced right now.

also the pause button doesnt work, but the game does pause if you tab out. the game reeks of lack of polish like this. sometimes upgrades or artifacts will reference a weapon name that isn't in the game, so you're looking through all of your gear wondering what item it effects, for example. the enemies will sometimes get stuck on regenerating energy walls, where they will damage the building behind the wall despite the wall holding them back. i could go on, but i didn't take notes while i was playing.[/strike]

edit for new update:
still too hard, but the developer seems to be listening to feedback, and the difficulty is now a little more reasonable. my primary issue now is that some of the armored enemies (particularly the one that looks like a partially hatched egg) just have too much health. officer difficulty is still left up to chance, because if you arent given artifacts that allow you to focus an incredible amount of damage on these already armored enemies they will destroy all of your buildings. 

i have a hard time believing any amount of internal playtesting would miss this. but im not in the room and maybe there's some obvious mechanic ive totally missed. so i'll switch the review to recommended. the game isnt that expensive and if they continue making balancing changes it's worth the money. also, the pause button works now, which is nice.
Fun game for about an hour. Probably wont play again if I'm being honest. There's nothing inherently wrong with it, it's just super simple and doesnt have stay power for me personally.

The game is really good, it lacks a bit of depth to improve replayability but the general concept is nice. I really enjoyed playing it.
worth the price

Wouldn't recommend until difficulty balancing changed. As others have said, most of the difficulty is in the first wave of each round. This makes the game extremely binary. If you can quickly get a build online to survive the first wave, the game becomes trivial. If you can't, then at the higher difficulties you will be wiped out almost immediately. This basically turns the game into Speedrun Reset Simulator and if you play at any difficulty higher than officer you will be abandoning games at round 2 over and over and over to get a good run. 

I like difficulty, but if it was shifted from front-loaded to back-loaded, you could see more viable runs and less boredom on the good runs. Dying instantly because you can't deal with a multi Tank first wave is not fun. Watching the clock as you wait to win your run with a good setup is not fun. I appreciate the efforts of the dev and will come back to retry this one after more patches.

Small Update: The dev has made 3 patches since the main part of this review (see below). It seems a lot more balanced and doable but i have yet to find the time to play it a lot more. That being said the hard difficulties are (surprise!) still hard but more fair. 

Main Review:
I dont ever make reviews but I have some concerns that need to be addressed before this can be a game. I love strategy games like this, Im also very good at them.
That being said I beat the first difficulty (out of five total) on my first run, I beat the second difficulty in a few runs and the third difficulty after trying and failing for almost 6 hours. I was only able to beat the third difficulty because of a cheese which has already been removed from the game.
I have tried the fourth difficulty a dozen times and have yet to make it past the 3rd level alive. It is physically impossible to beat. The monster scaling is so high that the only slightly viable method is stunning/delaying the enemies in some way. This isnt a matter of me not being good (see that I play these types of games a ton, i intuitively know how to play well) or even bad rng with artifact rolls. You simply dont ever have enough money to build an economy and defend, the waves start too soon and by the time it starts youll barely have a single building turret down which can only stop 1 out of the 3 or 4 initial enemies that rush you. Ive tried other starts with a stall tower but even then you lose at minimum, with perfect play and a good starting artifact, 9 life, meaning with that start and no other life loss, youd lose within 7 levels. 
This game has only been balanced for the first and second difficulties, the third is barely doable with good rng and some cheese and the final two arent even remotely possible. There is no way the later difficulties were play tested before release and if they were then id like to see a detailed video showcasing how to beat them, and a video that is repeatable. 

All in all i recommend waiting until the game is balanced before buying it.
TLDR: Game is unbalanced for later difficulties and isnt actually possible to beat.

Great game! Hereby an overview and first impression: https://youtu.be/mPfHo8B_VvU But just buy it. It's very cool. It has waaay more debt than you think it is because you also need to keep in mind how long it takes for the tower to be there. Combined with the range and upgrades. The combinations go very far.

Really like how much your gameplan can change over the course of a run. I don't think any other roguelike I've played has this much swing, where you can look at the artifact options, check your bank and immediately go 'alright, gunner turret spam in the front can defend against all the small enemies now, I'm speccing the laser turrets into single-target damage'. Even within each stage it's pretty interesting. Gunner turret as first drop is almost always going to happen, but for the second drop gunner turret, wave generator, wall, and generator are all solid options depending on what enemies are coming.

Definitely worth the price if you enjoy that sort of strategising. Artwork is good and UI is nicely designed too.
Very fun game with numerous ways to defend. Loving the latest update of the drones, very fun to focus on for boss runs.

Simple game with good core loop.
Steal at less than 5 bucks, but worth the full price.

I bought it because I heard it was hard and had a blast unlocking and beating the hardest difficulty.

A fresh take on classic game mechanics. Extremely interesting mechanics that I kept exploring more and more, even finding out that relics and upgrades that seemed bad were actually good in different situations creating entirely different builds. Early game is indeed very rough and I find myself prioritizing early game upgrades and relics throughout the entire game (early game is hard and an early advantage snowballs a lot). I think it's good the way it is as it kept me at the edge of my seat.
Really fun and challenging Game. If you like tower defense type games, give it a try!!

I am not a huge fan of Stellar Initiative, but it is if you are a fan of tower defense games and roguelikes I think that you could have fun.

Stellar Initiative is a barebones tower defense relying on a singular dimension to act as the path to the base that you are defending. It varies from others in the genre by being a roguelike and offering a flexible (though quite short) campaign path. There are a variety of mission types which is something that I found quite creative for a game like this and adds some much-needed variety for how simple the main gameplay loop is. That loop is Start mission, build generators for power, build towers and walls for your defense, use abilities to help when you need it, finish missions to get upgrades and artifacts then rinse and repeat until you beat the bosses. So how good is this gameplay? It‚Äôs passable. I don‚Äôt think there is a ton to write home about here. The upgrade paths are simple but good, artifacts are unique, replayability exists with trying to get all the artifacts and playing with the different factions, different mission types mix things up, mission modifiers add some extra challenge in the mid-game, and the bosses are acceptable. The shortness of the runs is both a benefit and a curse, I never felt like I was either getting to my full potential or having to stay for too long; but I think if there was more variety in enemies, the strategies you need to fight them, and if upgrades were a bit easier to come by the length could be extended and it would make things better. I felt like there was one central strategy that was best as far as gameplay went in my runs (just amass turrets and generators and only add other things if absolutely necessary), so I never was enticed to do otherwise especially when you only ever get enough resources to upgrade two things to their fullest so that made the game feel a lot less strategy oriented. I also felt that weapons should have been separated from buildings in the creation queue, it just felt awkward and made doing quick defenses an absolute annoyance that cost me health and towers that felt like they were lost undeservedly. Also, mining missions should give you the option to leave once you get the minerals (there are reasons not to force end it, so the option is best), I sat in a mining mission and twiddled my thumbs for far too long on occasion and I hate it when a game wastes my time. Overall, the game is fine to play, but I think pacing is a central issue. As a final note on gameplay, I initially was going to just thrash this game and say how boring it was when I first started this review, but decided to go back and it clicked with me more. I don‚Äôt think that it is a good sign when you have to play for 1 and ¬Ω hours to get a game like this to click and I think that is why a lot of people complain about the difficulty, it isn‚Äôt hard, it just likely hasn‚Äôt clicked for them I think. So, your mileage may vary on this one, but I found myself enjoying it by the end.

No story is available and I think that even a barebones one would have been nice, moving on.

The sound design is not great. Although the weapon and combat sounds are fitting for the visual style given, they are still simplistic and limited in their number. What bothers me the most out of anything else in the game though is that there is only one song. Honestly, I cannot think of a single game that I have played with just one song besides this one. This game could have easily had 5 songs (menu, mission, ship, Boss 1, Boss 2) and I probably still would have griped, but this is a low I have not seen before. The song is not even that good either, it lacks any sort of energy that makes me want to keep playing, and not only is it the only song, but the song itself is repetitive. Is it thematically fitting? Eh, vaguely, but that hardly matters in this case. While writing this portion I actually went back and tried to prove myself wrong. Nope! The closest thing to a second song is literal silence when you are doing stuff on your ship. This just made the game some much harder to enjoy and I cannot say I have ever been so disappointed in a soundtrack for a game before in my life.

I think my favorite part of this game is the art style. Its muted and simplistic color palette combined with the silhouette style pixel art is very appealing to me. All the menus, units, and interfaces match thematically. The colors are used to create clear visual representations of useful information (you‚Äôre black, their red, shields are orange, artifact qualities are colored, that kind of stuff). And the model work fits into the game well. Honestly, I can‚Äôt think of a single complaint. Some may prefer more color in the game, others will want more variety in models, maybe some unit shading for depth or something silly like that, but for me, the game has a particular style that looks good and is consistent plus it is 100% functional, for a game like this it is perfect. Simplicity can be bliss if you know what you are doing.

I am pretty mixed on this one, but in the end, I had fun and think it is worth recommending to those who are fans of tower defenses and roguelikes. Is it worth $10? No. I wouldn‚Äôt spend anything more than $5 on this game as it currently stands and I think that it is probably actually worth $3 to most people. Humble Bundle is where I got this one, and it wasn‚Äôt a bad game to get. It is short, simple, has an abysmal soundtrack, and is moderately fun. Stellar Initiative is a completely average game built for a specific audience and that is okay.

Fun, fresh entry to the rogue-like genre.

The consensus of Stellar Initiative being hard is fair, but I think people aren't considering that there is a learning curve. The first 10 or so runs I was pretty bad. After losing and learning how to win, the difficulty felt reasonable.

I thought runs might get stale with the few number of buildings available, but I was constantly surprised at the unique strategies I would put together to create a strong build. One of my favorites was when I was unlocking the win without upgrading achievement. My strategy was lining up walls with a dense stack of war robots on top, and three rocket launchers behind. With a good economy I was able to replenish walls and war robots as they were destroyed. Assuming you are upgrading, there are a surprising amount of synergies between the buildings depending on the path you take on the upgrades. I do think that strategies to beat the two bosses are much more limited though, and the game would benefit from new bosses with different weaknesses.

Maybe a hot take but the game is not too RNG heavy on the easier difficulties. I have found the game to be pretty generous with decent artifacts early on, and if you can adapt to what is given to you well you should be able to win. On star lord and legend difficulty the first few waves are the hardest, and getting artifacts helping you in the early game ASAP are necessary to win. Those difficulties are RNG heavy for this reason, but its a hard difficulty on a rogue-like game, so I didn't mind resetting most of the time.

Now I have won on every difficulty level and about ready to put this game away. To me it was worth $10 for the 30+ hours of content
hard game but very fun.,,,,,,,,,, runs take awhile but  rare roguelike game with a save feature (please roguelikes add save features i don't wnat to play a single run for 2 hours straight)
very fun, the leveling and progression is very satisfying. upgrades skipping the queue is kind of op.
An amazing game that has a lot of content. The difficulty may be offputting to some, but it provides an intense strategy experience that has me thinking at every moment. 10/10 would buy again!

I am a fan of this game! Took me a little to get the hang of how everything worked, but once I did, I was stuck playing for as long as I had people to play against! The art style is stunning, as I've come to expect from Halfie Studios. I am always a huge fan of the game intros this guy does!

The game itself is like a more intricate faster-paced battleship, where the organs you choose (which function like the ships in battleship) give you power-ups that impact how you play the game. Definitely worth a try if you are looking for a party game to play with friends! 

I do wish there was a larger fan-base though, so I could climb those leaderboards aha!

Interview and play with the game developer here: https://youtu.be/3QwJEb646Uw

Obviously I'm biased, but I really enjoyed the game it's neat seeing how the different abilities work and having an active component of charging with the space bar while trying to figure out where your opponent put his organs keeps the game pretty exciting as you try to full on base race.

too many references to nicole kidman throughout but fun game

Since the demo they also added a VR mode, which worked well on my Index. Intuitive controls, but I wish there was a way to move the world in front of me, so I could look at it more comfortably.
I enjoy the game both in VR (for shorter sessions) and non-VR.

Do not expect a city building simulator from this game. It's much more of a lite game. Meditative. Relaxing. Just build your own little Babylon.

A great relaxing game in which we will have to build a miniature city with the help of unusual architectural monuments on a mysterious green island. Each successful construction will be noticed by a special Tower, located in the center of the island and will add nice bonuses when building our structures.
Unusual visual style, time of day change and mediative music will immerse us in the mystical world and allow us to see ordinary objects in an unusual way.

A lot of the tags are misleading.
I wouldn't call this a "clicker" or "idle" game at all.
It's an easy to learn, mobile style puzzle game, simmilar to 2048 or other "merge 3 or more of the same number" games.
If thats what you are looking for, then go for it, but don't expect a Stategy - Base Building - Idle game like the tags say.

I want to say that the white color was chosen in the theme, because it does not cause any irritation and so the gameplay was measured. My inner perfectionist was happy that I was able to set the towers straight
A great meditative, soothing and eye-pleasing puzzle game. Considering it's also free, it's just what you need on a Friday night after a busy work week.

Not really sure about the negative or positive, but maybe it is just not my type of game. The game is beautiful and very well made, the mechanics are simple, but the 'strategy' and 'base building' elements aren‚Äôt as important as I had hoped.

Throughout my first playthrough, I started to understand that merging buildings from lower levels to higher levels is not really how the game is played best. It is much better to just get a combo to get some cards, which gives you higher level placeable buildings and allow to move buildings around the map freely. So, if you just reserve some space to make a 5-9 combination of level 1 or 2 buildings, the game is pretty easy. I got all achievements in about half an hour, which isn‚Äôt that challenging.

It's free, so it‚Äôs not a bad shout to see whether the game is for you, but I just think that after this playthrough, I‚Äôm not really interested in setting some high score, playing it again or buying the full game.
Relaxing and easy to understand strategy puzzler. I prefer the nightsky sceneries, really helps to wind down after a long day.
This game is so calm and the most relaxing game ive played in a while slightly more relaxing than playing elder ring.

[h3] Achievement Hunting Rating 5/5 [/h3]
A pleasant little puzzle that requires some intention and focus to complete all achievements but not impossible. Can be done in about an hour.

Good idea, but boring.
I hoped the game would offer buildings of different shapes and that combining could be done in several ways with varying results.
Also i hoped it would be possible to combine buildings far more often.
But turned out you can only upgrade to level 8. I assumed it would go further, and combined 3 lvl 8 but it just didnt do anything.
Would have at least imagined some effect or bonus score by doing so. Lets say a combo o 3 lvl8 towers would provide extra score to any upgrade done next to them or something.

The game is a good example of a solid and fun idea not developed enough to live up to its potential.
Sadly.

[h1] Interesting [/h1]
The game grabbed my attention right away with its pleasant graphics, the ability to change the time of day, zoom in and out, and switch camera angles. You can move a house, swap it with another, or even build a new one.I play without VR mode since I don‚Äôt have VR goggles, but even so, the graphics are excellent. With VR, I imagine it would be absolutely amazing. The game is free.
P.S. My high score is 56352 point. Can you beat my record?
Not too difficult puzzle game with very realxing music and astahtic. Also, it is free so really there is nothing to complain about
a fun enjoyable puzzle game that weirdo ate alot of my time for a demo.  Helps you relax and think logically, even for just a little bit in the crazy messed up world!

URBO: Dream One captivated me with its meditative city-building on a serene island. Constructing a harmonious town amidst lush landscapes was a serene escape. The Tower's mysteries and enchanting monuments added intrigue, while blending architecture seamlessly with nature. An immersive experience of crafting a thriving city in tranquil beauty.
Excellent puzzle game that allows you to distract well from the daily hustle and bustle. The game is well optimized, play interesting, you can play together with children.

A Freegame? there's had Achievements? And count as a Perfect game?
NICE!
Thank you to the Devs
Good Chill , Easy Base Merger, Way better than those Fake Freemium Mobiles game

It's pretty easy thanks to the "Card system"
The only hard part is to get the X4 n Pro achievements if you don't have any idea on what to get them

Quite fun and relaxing for short playthrough. Although since it's only demo, it start getting boring after some plays. Hopefully the fully version have tons of variation to prevent that.

2048, but with buildings and a couple more mechanics. It's pretty and meditative, but ultimately shallow. I'm not sure where the full game will go with this, but I don't think there is much here to build from. 

Maybe this would be nice as a mobile game on a boring commute.
Its fine, its essentially a mobile. You place things and they combine. It's not special and I feel like it being called a Clicker is misleading
A game that will allow you to relax after a hard day's work. Interesting puzzles. Only positive emotions from this game. If you like puzzles you should definitely try to play this game.
A simple game and very exciting with puzzle elements. If you want to spend time, you can play))

This is the free version of Urbo I believe. I love Urbo but this seems to be a bit of advertising. It's really easy, have only played one game, played till I was double my top score in Urbo and then shut the game down. I just couldn't loose and as a result it became boring quite quickly. Honestly I found this very disappointing but I will recommend it as its free. And also do yourselves a massive favour and go buy the paid for version, it really is worth the price.
nice short time puzzle merging game. like how the combos work. nice little relaxing game.

Cool graphics, nice music, great gameplay.
Well done, developers: among so many games with very mediocre graphics, music and gameplay it's a real gem! :D

Spending 90 minutes on my town just to have to let it go was the most humiliating experience I've had in a while. Truly feeling how fragile things are, realising that all beauty in life will disappear unappreciated if one does not cherish it. Realising, there is only one chance in life. Not taking an opportunity, a chance to great joy will make it pass away, and it won't ever come back. building a town for 50000 people gave me enough time to rethink my own existence. How I used to be an asshole here and there. Probably too often. Most likely too often. No. It was already too often. Others do not get more chances at life either. Ruining this very unique experience for someone is the worst a human could do. We truly should appreciate everything he have in this very moment. Who knows for how long we get to enjoy it?
I want to express my gratitude. Not just to this game which made me realize how wrong this approach to life is, but also to everyone around me for being there, I could not ask for this, let alone more.
(Except Remi.)
A city builder where 3 similar tier buildings will combine into the last placed spot to form a higher tier. Quite simple but overly enjoyable.

This is a free demo of the game. Worth playing if you have a couple hours to kill.

Thoughts: 
Short game about city building, similar math puzzle games for mobile.

My Strategy:
Basic strategy for higher population. (don't read if you want to figure it out for yourself)
- place smallest building near the top, and place larger buildings near the bottom/edge
- try to combine building so the end up closer to the bottom or edge
- save as many cards as possible for the very end
its a good chill game, really like the music and simplistic visuals. Quite simple to understand as well. The only based thing i can say about this  game is that is gets repetitive really fast

7.5/10 Classic merging puzzle in meditative city building setting.

TLDR: A classic merging puzzle with pleasant looks and audio. Great if you have a VR set

Good:
- it's a well-known puzzle type where you need to put groups of 3 or more elements of the same tier for them to merge into a single element of the next tier. But there are boosts here like moving and element to an empty spot or swapping with another element is you make more than 1 match in a single turn. 
- music is top-notch, very relaxing
- the pieces on the board look like houses, and there are far more variations of them in the full game. Overall, the graphics are very pleasant here
- stylish UI design
- free (prologue)

So-so:
- it's somewhat unclear from the looks of the elements what tier they are until you've played this for a while. I guess games of this type would be clearer if they just used plain numbers, though certainly it wouldn't look as nice
- well, it's not original, and you can find thousands of games of this type (maybe with minor differences in rules) on mobile, for free. So I guess, at its modest full price of about $5 it's worth it if you value aesthetics

Bad:
- nothing

This is a very cute and relaxing game. I never played these types of games but decided to give this one a chance, and I am glad I did. Nowadays, I always have something to turn to when all of my other games get too boring or repetitive.

strangely addictive, simple idea of aligning three building types to upgrade. It's priced well and definitively value for money. Graphically very pleasing and audio is very atmospheric relaxing and chilled game, no hesitation in recommending

This game is absolutely fantastic!!!  It is simple, but engaging.  It is also very relaxing.  The concept is amazing yet simple to figure out, and to put you in the mood the game has relaxing music. The aesthetics seem soft and relaxing at first, but it begins to feel dull, lifeless, gray and boxy after a while. I'd like to see trees and citizens wandering about to feel like its a town. Still, it's a nice game to have in the background.

7:45AM. I rip out of my driveway in dad's old Ford F-150 and hit the corner hard, tearing through a group of three joggers on the sidewalk. They flip through the air like confetti. I flick the wipers on. Doesn't matter. I've got a date at Storage Steve's on Fourth and Hell.

Tripling my kill count along the way, I roar through the chain-link fence surrounding ol' Steve's. A few veterans of the storage-vulture trade recognize the truck as it pulls in. Some flee. I skid to a stop, fishtailing into a grandmother.

"Opening bid's $300," the auctioneer calls out to the crowd as I step out of the truck.

"Eight million," I shout as I stride into the fray of would-be buyers. The crowd disperses.

The auctioneer smiles and hands me the key to the storage unit. The moment he lets go of the key, he's gone, like an almost-remembered gap in the memory or a "spot the difference" game with only one picture. I pay the concept no mind. That's just how auctioneers are.

Crunching my hand into the sheet metal and tearing the door free, I blink in surprise. Guns. Guns! It looks like an armory in here, stocked by somebody with a fear of shelves. Had anybody else outbid me, they could have armed a small militia and finally put an end to my truck's rampage through the sleepy suburb. Tough luck, you clowns: I'd been playing online blackjack for sixteen hours straight.

7:45PM. After unceremoniously backing my flatbed full of AK-47s through the front door of my home, I crack open my laptop and start posting listings on my shop site at the speed of light: 
"COOL NERF GUN FOR CHILD BUY NOW"
"EASY MAGIC WAND **LEARN FIREBALL IMMEDIATELY**"
"AK-48 THE SEQUEL!! NEW KIND OF WEAPON FOR ANY FUTURE SOLDIER"
"TWO GUNS AT THE SAME TIME (CANT DUAL WIELD WITHOUT THIS AUCTION!!)"

[i]Ping! Ping ping ping![/i] Here they come. The customers. My life force.

"I'm $35,000 short for this listing- Would you take a $5,000 bid?" one asks.
"No. In fact, my new offer is $90,000," I reply.

They consider it.

They agree.

This game is exactly what you think it is. I don't recommend it for the price, even on sale. The storage containers when I played were low quality, even the higher end ones at the luxury storage facility. The pattern for negotiation is easy to find to get the most out of your items and after seeing "Legendary" items at 80% of garage sales, it's easy to see where to make money. All of that being said, it is rather cathartic to drive around and pick up items for cheap and sell them online after you "fix" them. Leveling up is easy and to get to the end game content took less than 4 hours. Is it worth the money? I don't think so at this stage, but in the future it could be really good. 3/10

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]

5/10: Very amateurish, but the developer seems to be staying on top of bug spraying, and great fun with all things considering. (And to think ol' Il Pallino normally only likes simulation games involving cops, crooks, and big, mean-lookin' American trucks.)

[h1]Overview[/h1]

Think American Pickers, only you don't get a cutie like Danielle to point you in the direction of where to look for old junk, and the items that the player finds can be repaired before sale. Starting with a home, a hammer, an object scanner, and a pick-up truck, the player goes about acquiring objects from abandoned storage units and yard sales through buying low and selling high. More money allows for the player to upgrade their hammer and object scanner so they can make greater improvements to objects below perfect condition and use their scanner to find the value of greater valued items to which they sell on the internet. Earning XP flips the difficulty curve and allows for more effective haggling with buyers and sellers, along with discounts at winning auctions on storage units.

[h1]Graphics and Sound[/h1]

The graphics are on the lower end of what a player would expect from a simulation game. Not too bad but also not great.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3074007167

The sounds, however, are a bit limited, and several actions have redundant sounds. The auction sounds are humorous, but there was a stranger who complained to ol' Il Pallino at a coffee house about the invalid action sound being "creepy." (The sound was certainly annoying.)

[h1]Positives[/h1]

Perhaps the most positive aspect of [i]Storage Hustle[/i] is that item names and descriptions can be changed before listing said objects for sale on the internet, which is good fun, and can make for fun screenshots.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3075450203

If anyone thinks that the idea of buying old crap, fixing it up, and selling it is fun, then you can say that you've found your game. (However amateurish.) And to ol' Il Pallino, [i]Storage Hustle[/i] is pretty fun for what the game primarily entails.

[i]Storage Hustle[/i] has plenty of fun items available, even if the garage sales are mostly the same objects, but the player will start to see plenty of  new-old objects when they unlock higher level storage unit auctions.

[h1]Negatives[/h1]

Bugs, bugs, bugs, and bugs. The bug rating has been downgraded from [i]Roach Motel[/i] to [i]Newberry's Backyard Barbecue's second owner[/i] since the developer has stayed on top of bugs before release. (Note to aspiring curators: Curation is not for the faint of heart, and the depending on the price of the game, the player better claim their free copy knowing that they're going to be the guinea pig.)

If the player is the sort of player that can only enjoy high quality games, then the player should best stick to their AAA games, because this is an indie game, and with it, the player can expect some audio glitches, and driving is somehow even worse than the driving on I-95 in Miami-Dade County, Florida. (At least the cars stay in their appropriate lane, which is more than what Frandiber Santana can say.)

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Without knowing the regular price of [i]Storage Hustle[/i], the player would do well to wait for a sale, but because the amateurish nature of [i]Storage Hustle[/i] at full price is liable to drive the player crazier than a laughing hyena on crack rock. At least there are no genuine competitors to [i]Storage Hustle[/i], so the player really has no alternative... At least the developer doesn't seem to be anything like Posh from [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198246234164/recommended/750520/]Arcade Tycoon[/url] and is actually doing something about bugs as opposed to whining about how criticisms are unfair.

[h1]The honest word of Il Pallino... OR ELSE![/h1]

This game gives me nostalgic feelings from when I was a kid, I would often sit in the living room and watch Storage wars on TV, followed by Pawn Stars. This game is Storage wars, it's bidding it's haggling, it's what we all want and expect from a game like this. However it has a few bugs, but the Devs are actively listening and paying attention to everything. 

for their first ever game they've hit the mark, a bit more polish however to make it truly shine, but this is their passion, their project and I truly believe it's a game worth getting behind. Keep up the great work devs!
Came to the game to chill and buy storage units then i found blackjack and now im a recovering gambling addict

[b]4 and a half hours. [/b]

That's what it took me to complete the game, get all the upgrades and the tools available, even bought a new car and a house for money sink. (I got a plus 1 h in the game because i left it open when i went to dinner)

Don't get me wrong, this game isn't easy but either hard, it's in the spot where you don't need a lot of brain power to do stuff and at the same time doesn't present any difficulty. It's a weird spot. And after you unlocked everything there is nothing left to do.

I encounter only a handfull of bugs, like 3, where the control didn't respond very properly and once my iten that i just bought disapeared.

The graphics are not very pretty, but they are ok. 
There is funny stuff in there, like when [spoiler] i got an ak-47 and the description said "With this you got 100% discount in any shop" [/spoiler]. There are some stuff in there that are very much enjoyable.

The mechanichs for the bidding are chaotic, wich is good, because bidding with people is chaotic. Another funny moment [spoiler] i won a bidding and a guy named "BiddingMaster" just dropped dead on the floor [/spoiler].

Overall this game is quite enjoyable, not a precious gem, not a brain bluster, but is good. In the spot where it pass it but with some *.

The game is worth in the sale, above 30% i would say, but no the full price.
I'm eager to see te continuation of this game and the full potential.

Side note: the car control physics are way too good for this game, wich is kind of funny, but is only that, the acceleration is just 0-100 in 1s, the turn is pretty open, but you get that feeling "man this game is not ment to have this". It's weird.

Resume: This game is weird, is neither terrible or excelent, is just ok.

I really like storage auction concept and i think this game captured the essence of it. There is a lot of content that can be done, I believe that more content will be added with the new updates. There are some bugs in the game, but I believe they will be fixed in time.
unplayable....crashes after 30 mins max ...known problem since release but never fixed. shame because is a good game but only for like 30 mins until it crashes your pc

Storage Hustle is a fun little game made by a solo dev so it's well worth supporting. It's in early access at the moment and there is more content to come. You bid on storage lockers and then try to make a profit on the contents. You can also visit yard sales to pick up some bargains. The gameplay is pretty nice, as you gain experience you can unlock perks to make the hustle easier. You can also upgrade your tools (a price scanner and repair hammer) to make them more efficient. You can buy new houses and cars with your hard earned profits, and do a little gambling on slots and blackjack if you feel like it!

At the moment there are some optimisation issues and crashes but the dev is actively working on these issues and seems to be very hands on with players in his Discord server. He welcomes and responds to player feedback and bug reports which is really great to see. He seems like a genuinely nice guy, so I really hope this game goes great for him - it's off to a good start and i'm looking forward to seeing how it develops ‚ô•

[h1]Half-Baked in one afternoon[/h1]
It feels like someone threw together a bunch of assets in one afternoon. This game could have been decent if the developers had actually tried to make it good. It has an interesting hook, but absolutely everything about this game feels completely generic, and no effort was put into it.
[b]My recommendation is to avoid this game, with a capital "A".[/b]

To make matters worse, the game has been released for almost a year. If this is its state now, I have little hope it will be enjoyable at full release.

Not worth $11, BUT, pay attention to the obvious jank present in even the promo video and you probably understand what you're getting into. So, the review is based off of you already seeing and accepting that.

I've got 4h in this game and see no reason to go back until something game changing has been added. Owning all the vehicles, homes, and basically having enough money to just quickbuy every acution at the highest tier storage place is easy. As lon as you're within about $50 up or down of the price, there is someone who will give you an offer within about 10s of you putting it up. Once you get the repair tools, everything is always perfect quality for zero cost.

About all you're hunting for at that point is the legendary items so you're making the most bang for your buck.

Honestly, if they gave some tradeoff for repairing items or actually made you have to put forward some effort to keep your stuff moving then it may hold attention longer ... but until then, its okay for what it is, just wait for the sale.

It's in early access, so play at your own peril I guess.  The game is buggy, especially when it comes to graphics and item physics.  That's to be expected.  But there are a lot of other things that are just too much of a barrier for me to want to keep playing the game at this point.  

The biggest issue by far is the save game mechanism.  You have to transport all of your items back to your house and store them in your garage or they just disappear and you lose everything.  This means that I can't just save and stop playing when I want/need to go do something else.  No, I have to go through the time consuming process of transporting and unloading every single item I've purchased first.

And that doesn't even always work!  There's a bug that seems to just randomly occur where the game upon loading resets to some earlier autosave instead of your most recent save and so all the items in your garage are gone.  I've lost literally hundreds of thousands of in-game dollars on this!  That was the final straw for me.

Until they change the save mechanism, I can't say I'd recommend this game and I don't even know if I'll be playing again myself.
Great concept. Enjoyed it. But constantly crashing and locking up entire PC. Not fit for sale yet.

This game is really well done but suffers from some problems.

It needs better optimisation since it can get pretty choppy especially when driving, even on a high end gaming rig.  The game can freeze and crash, but it doesn't seem to happen very frequently, maybe once every 3 times you play.  The first time I bought the van and sold my truck, the game crashed and my van was completely gone when I reloaded the game, leaving me without a vehicle so I had to restart from the beginning.

There are a few other small issues, but this game has some serious potential and I'm looking forward to seeing where it goes.

Some cool things about the game:
- You can buy a few houses
- The auctions are fun
- Discovering new items and their prices are fun
- Being able to repair items so they make a bit more money is cool
- Seems to be a pretty decent list of items to obtain so far
- There is a fair with some fun and challenging games you can drive to
- It's open world (even though it's a bit tiny)
- You can buy cars, trucks and vans (only a few, not many)
- You can haggle for better prices

Things that would be great if they were added to the game
- More vehicles - ex. a moving truck, luxury cars
- A bigger map
- More items in each store since most seem pretty empty
- New storage locations
- Item visuals get better as they are repaired
- More items to find
- Better optimisation

Is the game worth buying?  Yes, this game has it's issues, but it's addictive, and adds a great game to your collection of simulators.

Definitely is satisfying to my storage battle type craving. I have to limit myself on a few things to keep it enjoyable. I don't gamble in case I win too much, and I don't auto buy storage bids. Having a balance between garage sales for mild profit and the gamble of storage units for larger profit/loss keeps things feeling just right. The only goals that fuel the game for me are tool upgrades, maybe a bigger garage, and a vehicle that can haul a lot more back at once. The bugs are few to none that I've had to encounter. Sure some NPC audios could be more updated but the captioned lines aren't terrible. It's amusing to hear men make a womanly call out and vise versa. Then again, the call outs NPCs make don't feel in character to a bid battle. Usually people say "Here" or something and these guys are going "YAHOO" like aight buddy I know you're excited but it aint over yet lol. Idk. You can tell it's unique and luckily unique is what helps keep loyalty. I even like some of the buyer personalities. keep adding those unique touches dev! Like the gorilla haha and the funny af names of the competitive buyers. Keep that up and I really hope to see this game flesh out!!!

Storage Hustle, my current go-to for that Storage Wars thrill, comes with its fair share of quirks. In the vast expanse of Early Access, the price tag aligns with the potential, especially if you're knee-deep into the storage unit hustle.

Bidding has that authentic feel, even if some folks seriously lowball their loot. Haggling offers its own kind of joy, but tread carefully ‚Äì push too hard, and you might earn someone's lasting annoyance. Skee-yee! Now, the physics dance on a thin line between predictability and chaos. Ever wonder if your digital haul would randomly explode off your truck? It's a bit like contemplating dinner plans mid-game. stomach growls

Speaking of which, I've been navigating Storage Hustle's world with the perpetual curiosity about my next meal. Skee-yee! This isn't just about lunch or dinner; it's a wandering thought ‚Äì could Cesar's culinary wizardry conjure up something delightful tonight? Ah, the enigma of gastronomic exploration.

But, back to the game. Skee-yee! A glaring gripe here ‚Äì the absence of a skills tutorial. "i" for skills? It took me a digital eternity to unravel that mystery. A small on-screen hint or an initial tutorial could have spared me some button-mashing frustration. Skee-yee! Perhaps Cesar has a recipe for gaming enlightenment?

And let's not forget the Mercy mains of Storage Hustle ‚Äì quirky, a tad frustrating, but not without their unique charm. Skee-yee! It's a shared sentiment, not animosity. Anyway, I'm thinking about dinner plans now... maybe Cesar has a suggestion. In a nutshell, Storage Hustle, with its hiccups and quirks, is a virtual journey into the chaotic world of storage wars, all while contemplating the profound mysteries of both digital adventures and culinary delights. Skee-yee! stomach growls louder

Its honestly a fun game, Some bugs here and there but the devs are constantly patching the game! Recommend if your looking for a chill game to play!

Too many bugs. Game crashes all the time, frames drop constantly. Some items you can't repair or price scan, even with maxed tools. I've also now lost 3 separate days of sales because the game refuses to save or crashes while saving.

I wish this was a positive review because it has a lot of potential. I get it is an early access game, yet, I should atleast be able to play it. I've never, since i have had this steam account, requested a refund until now. I'm very disappointed, especially with the potential this game has. Maybe one day, when it is complete, will i try it again. Until then, this was a disappointment.

Like a typical early access game, doesn't run smoothly even on a powerful system, I will say though this runs terribly. Very glitchy and just runs awful. A good attempt at a game and at least got it on sale. Game constantly crashes, have all drivers up to date, RTX 4070 super with a 14th gen i7, plently enough computer to run and it is just laggy with everything. Game mentions gender stuff, it isn't something to put into games simple as that, instant review for that.

Great Game! A few suggestions...when tipping over cardboard box, things should fall out. When hitting pedestrians, lose money over lawsuit. More homes for sale. More vehicles for sale. Restore vehicles from bad to perfect. Restoration should cost money.
Just a few ideas...it is addicting to play though, for those of us who like games where we "make money".

So i totally understand that is early access and i am curious to see where this is ending. But right now I can not recommend and will refund.

The game crashes on me frequently while driving back to my garage after Auctions as if the stuff in the back is bugging out and then the game shuts down. Here we go same day starting again. But I think that the Experience is not reset so atleast you got that going.

The auctions are really annoying:
-Weird noises from the NPC buyers
-Waiting for 8 Seconds between each bid is to long for me

Selling the stuff works really well, kinda like that part. 
Driving is weird, should be reworked

But the game is just not enjoyable for me the way it is now.

game crashes frequently when trying to sleep to the next day. didn't happen until i started collecting items to decorate my house, i think theres an issue with how many items are in the world and being loaded the next day. or its just poorly optimized and im overthinking it.

This Game was alright gets boring you found ever item in the storage units than just feels like an endless repeat. Also be aware that if you‚Äôre using anything other than a keyboard and mouse you‚Äôll have to map your own keys.
reminds me a lot like the tv show storage wars and very similar. It's an alright game for a couple of hours

If you like the series Storage Wars,I believe you are gonna like this.Go to auctions,bring back your new items,scan and repair them then sell them for a profit.I wish we had a store or something instead of a garage but it's a good casual game.

Storage Hustle offers a realistic experience in storage management.
Establish your own business, transport goods intelligently, and delve into the intricacies of storage management in the business world.
Start expanding your business and become an expert in the world of salesmanship!

Start out living in a garage, and old truck.
Buy storage units, and try to make a profit selling on the internet.

Please carefully research the products in the storage units you purchased with your scan tool.
Repair damaged items with your hammer, and increase their value.
Don't let any valuable items go unnoticed, be cautious!

Work your way up to buy a larger vehicle to hold more items.
Move out of the garage in search of your dream home.

Visit yard sales, or have some fun at the fair.
Run your internet business, showcase your negotiation skills by buying/selling cars, and master the art of the haggle.

A fun game for someone who liked watching storage wars. It may not crash like some people write in their reviews, but when it comes to optimization, the game can indeed stutter, so it's very weak at this aspect. More trade mechanics and interesting things would be more fun. When it comes to gameplay, I noticed that it's not worth buying in the last garage auctions, only in the third at the most and then the profit is big.

An alright jigsaw game with cute cats with color splashes (as the title implies) as the images. There is 50 different jigsaws ranging from 9 to 49 pieces.

I encountered 2 issues with it:
- The sound mute button only mutes the music, you can still hear the sound effects
- The sensitivity as to when it detects a piece in the correct location is way too low, so sometimes you will find yourself spam placing a piece 5 pixels up and down till the game will finally register it as correct.

It work without any issues on Linux with Proton (8.0-3)

Color Splash Jigsaw is a decent jigsaw puzzle game featuring cat images with color splashes, as the title suggests. With 50 different jigsaws ranging from 9 to 49 pieces, there's a good variety of puzzles to solve.

However, my main gripe with the game is that the sound mute button only silences the music, while the sound effects continue to play.

Took me nearly 100 minutes to finish all of the puzzles.
Sadly doesn't give a lot of replayability, but its some puzzle fun for a short time, if you are bored.
The rising difficult level is pretty nice.
Perhaps a randomizer (either randomizing the background image or being able to set the amount of pieces per puzzle) would benefit the game.

Note: This is a generic review for the jigsaw puzzle games of this indie developer.
This is a traditional style jigsaw puzzle game with cute pictures. I am honestly not a big fan of indie games for various reasons, but I actually enjoyed playing this game. It has very beautiful artwork. The music is nice. And the gameplay is relaxing, straightforward and especially not buggy. I think it is worth its price for a 1-hour puzzle game from an indie developer. 7/10.
Fun puzzle games where the puzzles have more pieces the further you go. 50 levels of puzzle with good background music. I enjoyed it a lot!

This is lovely. I'm enamoured by the gorgeous cats covered in vibrant colours. The overall design is well made, with the puzzle inside a picture frame,  the colourful background, even the mouse is colourful!

I liked the warped shapes of the puzzle pieces and the gradual increase in size. Starts off small with 9 pieces, then 25, then 49, so far. I'm currently on level 41 and looking forward to seeing if the final puzzle is going to be an even bigger size. Aren't I greedy!

I also enjoy spending time in the gallery. Here you can sit back and admire all your beautiful cats. 

Overall, the game is a great stress buster!
I do not recommend

KINDA recommend (depending what kind of game you're after). Not bad if you like Tetris-type games. It is a bit more relaxed, because the blocks aren't falling. Also, this is not a flashy, fancy Tetris game.

You basically have what I'll call "city blocks," all of which are mini Tetris boards. But instead of filling in a line, you fill in the "city block." You can drop the pieces anywhere you rotate and set them, and you have 30 seconds to position the piece and set it, which isn't hard at all if you have played much Tetris. You can get "caught" because if you drop a piece on one board, and it is sticking into another "city block," it will drop the spare piece there. But that is also part of how you play, so it's not bad or good to do that, but it can trip you up.

I would say only get the game if you want a relaxing Tetris-y puzzler. I will play it more if I remember, but I have too many games to play, and I gotta be in a "Tetris mood" to really get into these types.

TBH, reminds me of a "classicy board game" phone game. I play Reversi and Checkers a ton on my phone because it's pretty easy and occupies my brain. This game doesn't play like Reversi, but it has that same "I can let my brain do other stuff while I occupy myself" kind of feel. I was gonna play for like 5 minutes on the tutorial and ended up playing half an hour, but I didn't feel the need to play for 5 hours either. So kinda like Reversi or Checkers in that regard.

Anyway, if you want a slower "old man game," give it a go. If not, stay clear, because you're not gonna get Godzilla coming to tear down your city, or an epic quest or anything like that. You just move blocks. That's it.
It's a really fun and chill game. It can entertained you for longer than you think.
Super fun addictive game.  If you have enjoyed Tetris you will like this game.

Straightforward first-person shooter that delivers some mindless fun for an hour or two.

The plot is somewhat weird and revolves around the cryptocurrency topic, a generic booze-guzzling badass and a Russian bear general. After being attacked by space pirates, the guys decide to take matters into his own hands and eradicate them.

The game employs the old-school structure. This involves a stage loaded with enemies in each room and the occasional keycard that must be found in order to access the colored doors. There‚Äôs also money you can grab but there appears to be no purpose behind it.

The enemy variety is limited and lacks excitement. They're all very mindless. You have big spacesuit guys who die in one shot, thin soldiers with glowing eyes and jumping soldiers whose behavior remind me of people in multiplayer games. It‚Äôs hard to hit them because they keep jumping around and moving. They're also bullet sponges, meaning they don't respond when shot. Headshots do not exist in this game, and the only indication that your bullets hit is some kind of liquid erupting from enemies.

You have three weapons to take out the enemy: a powerful pistol, a machine gun, and a scoped rifle. Limited ammo is never an issue because you‚Äôll die before you get to waste all of it. However, the game is almost casual because you simply can‚Äôt lose. When you die, you respawn with all of your ammo and health at the last checkpoint. Dead foes remain dead, and you may simply pick up where you left off.

The biggest criticism is that the game must be completed in a single sitting. You are unable to save or continue. The game isn't long because there are around six stages, which takes around 1-2 hours, however it crashed twice and caused me to restart.

Solid game right here. Off the bat I dont like how ya can't adjust the music volume..it's a bit too loud. Other than that, the gunplay is solid when you aren't dealin' with jumpy enemies. The story seems to be parodying crypto concept and the mining that comes with it perhaps. I appreciate that it features voice actin'. Plus points for that. Not bad for the price. 

Gameplay here: https://youtu.be/fUmWTyY9K1U

Not very good. No impact on the shooting. Enemies don't react till they die. Power ups don't seem to work at all. Not sure what picking up money was used for. Enemy variety boils down to 3 types. No boss battles. Can be beaten in an hour though my game crashed twice on my playthrough when transitioning between levels.

My only positive is that story wise I thought it was pretty funny because of how incoherent and purposley stupid it is.

I have been eagerly anticipating this title, and I can confidently say it has not disappointed me in the slightest. Allow me to share my experience with you in this thrilling game.
Graphics and Visual Design (5/5): The visual retro aspect of Revenge of ILCOIN  is simply stunning. The details in the environments, weapons, and characters are amazing. Every corner of the battlefield feels authentic, from the war-torn wreckage to the sunlight streaming through the trees. The visual effects in gunfire and explosions are so realistic that I sometimes found myself in awe of the beauty amidst the chaos.
Gameplay (4.5/5): The gameplay  is its strong suit. The controls are precise and responsive, allowing you to fully immerse yourself in the action without feeling any disconnect between what you're trying to do and what happens on the screen. The maps are varied and strategic, encouraging dynamic gameplay and keeping you on your toes at all times. 
Story and Campaign Mode (4/5): The story in the campaign mode is intriguing. Although it may not be the game's standout feature, it offers a solid narrative and interesting characters that keep you engaged. If you're a fan of storytelling in FPS games, you will definitely enjoy the experience.
Sound and Soundtrack (4.5/5): The soundtrack fits the action perfectly and creates an intense atmosphere. The sound effects are realistic and further immerse you in the experience. The sound of weapons, and character voices are of high quality and add significant value to the game.
In summary, Revenge of ILCOIN  is a triumph in the first-person shooter genre. With its stunning graphics, solid gameplay, and a well-constructed world, this game is a gem for action enthusiasts. While no game is not perfect, it comes remarkably close to perfection and offers what all we wanted ‚Ä¶ fun. So, join the battle and get ready to experience an epic journey on the battlefield!

For real though, the game is awesome. It's crazy to see something like this made by one guy. Support this developer, so they can keep making awesome games!
Really enjoying this so far! Reminds me of worms. Landing those bombs was challenging but lot of fun. Sometimes i feel like enemies survived standing on single pixel though :D

The game is tough, but it's fun. I had a blast playing it. You gotta be smart about where you put your towers, or else you'll lose. It's not a game where you can just slap down towers and expect to win. It's awesome, but it's more for people who like to think things through and pay attention to the details.

Game is still too hard for the idea being sold. If it was called Brutal Tower Defense or Very Specific Strategy Tower Defense, maybe... But "cozy" implies a somewhat low stress experience. Happy to change my rating if further balancing is done. Graphics, sound, vibes are on point. Gameplay is frustrating here, and I own and play plenty of TD games. Would also be nice to speed up waves, if that function is present, it isn't obvious.

The game is extremely hard. The developer made the mistake that he built the difficulty around his knowledge of the game mechanics and since he knows his game well, it's not difficult him to beat any level. Because of this the even the very first level is hard to beat. I cannot recommend the game to anyone until the difficulty won't be ironed out.

A really great game in which you sink into. You have to think carefully about which towers and buildings you build so that you don't stand there without money or material. The music and the graphic style live up to the name "cozy." Great pastime 10/10

The resource system is not easy to understand at first. But as soon as you understand in which order and where you have to build your buildings, it's fun to develop strategies for the next rounds. After about four hours, I played through the initial four levels.

For beginners, I would recommend playing each level and unlocking perks. This makes it easier to defeat the bosses on each level.

I would love to see more levels, enemies and defenses in the future.
This game is literally unplayable. An hour in and I haven't been able to get pass the easiest level on round 2. Its literally impossible.

I really feel at peace playing this game. Thank you so much for this game, sure it takes for strategic thinking but that makes it even better cause you can just dive into the game and not think about anything else :))

pretty fun game only have 2 complaints
1. this may just be me having a game journalist moment but in the tutorial it didn't make it apparent that to get the text that lets you know how to play was to press W.

despite those minor nitpicks the game is  fun!
For the first game from this developer, it's got a great atmosphere and concept behind it. Can't wait to see what the Dev does next :)

I enjoyed the game, would be cool to have a challenge mode or some such though. Lvl 18 was my favorite for this reason as well as those with map elements that encouraged speed. All in all it was pretty nice and chill. Def good for an hour or so.

Pretty cool game! Its giving me similar vibes to fire boy and water girl, in a good way.
There were a few sections that felt tricky playing as a solo player. 
I really like the secretive theme around the final level, but I almost didn't even play it! I went into the chapter select only to finish the last collectible I missed, but the ending of level 17 wouldn't have led me to believe there was anything left to do.
Overall, I had a good time with it and it was refreshing to play a simple puzzle game that didn't get bogged down with ads or unneeded complexity c:
I'm excited to see what else you work on!

The game is cute, fun and simple. Other games attempt to make it a challenge or video game logic to beat the game. It's 
a simple game meant to be enjoyed. The designs are bright and fun. I really hope the developer continues with this project because it a refreshing to play a game. Games are meant to be fun. This game simplistic fun at its finest. ^.^
I've been following the development of this game for a while now, and it's great to finally get to play it! It's a really enjoyable experience with some satisfying puzzles and a great atmosphere.
i LOVED this game!!! it both challenging and so fun! btw spoiler, but i loved especially the ''secret" boss battle. Great game would definitely recommend it !!!

Really fun! There's a lot more to the levels than I initially expected, and the attachments are getting more and more interesting as I've been going along. Fantastic job!
