Excellent DLC, the first one in a long time where i actually want to use all of the new wrestlers in my Universe mode.

If you have blood turned on in the settings during Sandman's entrance he will bust himself open on the way to the ring like in RL, what a train wreck of a human being. I love that they thought to add this detail.
No Enter Sandman entrance theme music though sadly.
Just expected a couple of characters for this update/dlc, very much pleased to have also the inclusion of new weapons! Hope the other dlcs include added features!

Only have it because I have the Wrestlemania edition. Personally, this pack is worth it whether you just want actual CM Punk or love classic ECW. Only downside is no Tommy Dreamer. How could you have the Sandman and not Tommy Dreamer?

Would've got it, even if it was not included in my purchase.

Is it worth 10 dollars? Debatable, but out of all the first few packs for this game, this is definitely the one that's most worth that price regardless. You've got your classic hardcore icons, several new weapons you can have under the ring like a door or a tube light, you can now add Cult Of Personality to the songs that play when you're navigating through menus. Hell, The Dudley Boys even have a specific unique tag team champs entrance made for them. Regardless of what mode I'm playing, it feels like having these additions to the roster actually spice up gameplay choices in a fun way.

Now, if only they'd done this with the two packs that followed this and things would be okay right now, but that's just not how it worked out, was it?

It's a great expansion pack. 
I compared the old entrance scenes of the characters in the DLC with their new entrance scenes. 
This can give you an idea of what has changed: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gpInltyp5nA

Overall, this game is a unique and intense experience, especially for me given my megalophobia, and for the price its definitely worth it. But, it does have some flaws. 
For starters, the game is very dark with no way to brighten it, which makes it very hard to navigate, even with the sonar. A better flashlight of some sort would be nice, just for interior spaces at the very least, as the one you do get is very weak and kinda easy to miss.
It's very hard to actually get started, and some of the objectives are a little hard to actually do when you get them, given how little oxygen you get (Plus I still don't know how to get zinc) The oxygen recycler didn't seem to help at all either, even with two of them. The sonar can also be a little buggy with the rangefinder at times.

The main draw of the game, the black hole itself, is very nice and absolutely terrifying. I was frozen in fear when I first noticed "Hey, that black hole looks a lot bigger than it did before."
Overall, neat little game with a few hours of fun

Normally I have a really hard time giving a bad rating to a game that I didn't pay anything for. And in this case, I'm somehow even more sorry since it's the developer's very first game.

But, as much as I'm sorry, no, I can't recommend the game under any circumstances. Not only for the following reasons but also because of the price, which in my opinion is significantly too high. I may be the first to write a bad review for the game, but I can well imagine that there will be one or two buyers who, after purchasing it, will see it as a ‚Äúrip-off‚Äù for what it offers.

When I received the game, I looked at it briefly on an office notebook and I thought, OK, it looks pretty nice, even though it took forever to load the game and I wasn't able to use the game because of performance issues kept getting stuck and jerking. I didn't think anything of it and blamed it more or less on the notebook, even though it's not a bad one and other games work on it without any problems.

Today, on my main gaming computer, with which I can play any AAA game in the best graphics quality in 4k without any problems, things were similar with loading and area changes. After starting the game, I was afraid that my graphics card was broken because the picture was so crooked and it seemed like there were color errors. I didn't take a screenshot because, if I'm honest, I didn't want to post a screenshot like that.
You can see what I mean in the following screenshot and if you look closely, then you might know or understand what I mean.
[url] https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3074144904[/url]
[url] https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3074145072[/url]
It may be that this is intentional, but I find it really terrible and incredibly tiring to look at such pictures all the time and I can't do anything with it.

I've made the effort to actually watch and play through the entire game from start to finish but I can't find anything where I can say, well done. The pictures remind me a little of a toddler who can't paint yet. Sure, it can be a style that can be quite interesting, but then something is missing in the implementation and these disturbing color errors or whatever you want to call them shouldn't be there in my opinion. And I think, as someone else also wrote, the cats are kind of ugly. Well, they are cats that were turned into stones and you have to turn them back with a click, but after that a pretty, cute or whatever cat would have been nicer and not a cat stone. Sure, it somehow fits with the overall picture, but still...

Some of the puzzles contained in the game are not that easy and you don't always immediately understand what you are supposed to do. Since I wasn't very happy with the game anyway, I looked for a guide, which luckily exists. The guide itself is written by the developer. I find that very commendable and it is also very helpful, but I also wonder whether it is good to offer a complete solution and also with a map to find your way around. If you can't find the solution after x attempts, you'll probably use a guide to help you, but it's kind of difficult because it seems to me like you're trying to prevent people from not finishing the game and possibly getting upset about it excite. A guide with tips without a concrete solution might have been a little better. If you use the guide it is not difficult to unlock the achievements. Otherwise, things could get a little tricky.

The menu offers a few settings intended for the comfort of the game and you can choose between windowed and full-screen mode. You can also adjust the sound and effects separately. The background music is actually quite relaxed, but like everything, it's purely a matter of taste. I personally find the effects and the meowing terrible.
Unfortunately there are no settings for display or quality. The operation itself works quite well, but the view or movement of the image is a bit strange. Static but somehow shifted by the ‚Äúcamera angle‚Äù. I don't know how to explain this exactly. It may be that I'm now spoiled by really good HOG games and their functions.

The idea behind it and the basic concept is not bad, even if it is reminiscent of existing and well-known games in many ways.

Unfortunately, I don't have enough to be positive about it and I specifically asked a few people around me what they thought of this game. And to put it briefly and simply, the answer was unanimous: nothing. I'm really sorry.

You can find a different and definitely positive perspective on this game for example [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198161853963/recommended/2528710/]here[/url]

Review date: November 14, 2023

I want to start by saying thank you so much to the dev (who worked solo on this game!) for the free copy for me to review!  I appreciate it so much!

That being said, I do recommend this game but I also have some caveats and suggestions for how it could be improved!

THE GOOD STUFF:

- I am a big fan of indie games, of cat games and of hidden object games so this was like a wonderful trifecta of those things for me.  I think this is a very impressive first game, truly. When I went to check out the devs other stuff, I was a little surprised to find that this is all they had done so far because, while Meowing Point isn't perfect and still needs a bit of polish, it feels a bit more experienced than a first (solo!!) game.

- I spent a little over an hour in this game and while I didn't 100% it, and I don't know how close I got to finding every single cat (more on that later) I feel satisfied with my experience in the game.

- The cats are not "hidden" in the traditional way.  In fact, they are more or less right out in the open but they are presented as blank 3d models in a 3d space you can move around in and when you click on the blank model, it "fills it in".  This is deceptively easy at first. You start happily clicking away and revealing cat after cat.  But it's not long before you realize you're having to struggle a little to find more.  And when you think you've clicked on them all but it doesn't give you the area complete message....you really have to start keeping your eyes peeled.  Some of them were really very challenging to find.  And the fact that I did NOT find every single cat in my run, is proof that it isn't that easy.

- There were multiple different areas to work in, and you can travel easily back and forth between them, should you decide that you'd like to move on to another space before finishing the one you're at.

- The style is simple, but cute enough! 

- While I initially thought I'd find this entirely too easy, it ended up being a decent challenge as mentioned above.

- It plays some really fantastic throw back music (reminded me a lot of very early Final Fantasy music) and I love that it displays on the screen what the track is!

- There are some pleasant surprises here in the form of unexpected "side quests".  I discovered rather randomly some items by clicking on them and realized eventually there was a use for those items.  One item leads to another, and I won't spoil anything but it was a nice addition to this game.

- Every single cat had a name.  Adds nothing to the gameplay, but I loved it :)


THE NOT SO GOOD STUFF/SUGGESTIONS FOR IMPROVEMENT:

- The font for the title/logo of this game is so hard to read and definitely needs a change

- The price point of this game is too high.  There's an argument to be had regarding what indie devs DESERVE to make vs what we want to spend as gamers, but the truth is that for an experience that will land many people in the 1-2 hour time frame, the current price point of 6.66 is way beyond what most of us would justify.  For a lot of games like this, we're looking more in the 99cents-2.99 range.

- I have no idea what the "ending" of this game was.  It went from hidden cat game to weird clicker for a brief moment and I didn't care for that part of it

- There's nothing wrong with the black cats in the game, the model is very cute.  However, it would be cool to see other kitties!  Some variation in the cats would be nice.

- There is no hint in this game.  That's not necessarily a bad thing, but hints can be useful and do tend to be a staple in the hidden object genre.  On that same note, I'd like to see a counter maybe at the top of each area denoting how many cats I've found vs how many there are, rather than a sum total of cats found in the game so far, which is what is currently displayed.


TLDR - overall I recommend Meowing Point if you like relaxing hidden object games but only if you can get it at a much lower price point.  This is a good first game for the dev and I think it was a fun entry into the casual indie game genre.

If you liked this review from me and you'd like to see more of my reviews, check out my curator page at https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41107206/

Another "find cats" game that tries to add a personal touch. 

You move around by using a mouse. Although you can travel between screens, you are not allowed to freely explore them because of a fixed camera. The only thing you can do is pan the screen by clicking and dragging. It is also possible to zoom in for a closer look, however this does not work around screen borders.

The objective is to locate all cats in all locations. Unlike in other similar games, the cats are prominent in this one. The environment does not conceal certain strange shapes that make you wonder if it's a cat at all. They've all been turned to stone, so they're simple to spot. Each cat has a name.

Some cats are better at hiding than others. This is why you should click on suspicious things like garbage cans and windows. You never know what you might see. You are also going to encounter tiny components of adventure games, such as picking up items and using them in the appropriate location. 

There are no hotspots, which is a pain, and you must hop through adventure nonsense. For example, a rock requires a specific pickaxe and not the ones laying near to the rock. When you find all of the cats on a location, you get a star and can move on. But since there are no hints, finding that one last cat is always frustrating. 

One nitpicking issue is that available exits should be marked more clearly. While it‚Äôs true that cursor changes when you point at it and there are traffic cones that mark end of the road, it‚Äôs still easy to miss a path or get lost.

Short, but entertaining hidden objects game in a 3D world where you need to find cats, complete quests and ... battle an evil tree in the lighthouse? That last part didn't really make sense to me either, so don't worry about it lol.

You move around the world with your mouse, you can zoom in and out, but you can't really turn the camera. The camera is mostly fixed angle that sometimes made it difficult to find all the cats. There also was no hint option, which was a little disappointing, but the cats were not all that difficult to find.

Every cat has a name and you can pet them! The story is almost non-existent and quite confusing, but honestly I don't really think this game even needed a story to begin with, but it is there, for what it's worth anyhow.

I really liked this hidden objects game, and will recommend it. The price of the game isn't really worth it imo, so wait for a sale for this one!

An fun and unusual 3D exploration game where you have to find a load of petrified, yes petrified cats, you can pet them, but they are petrified, get it. Okay maybe not. Collect the stone cats, but be on the lookout for hidden cats, poke at things that look like they might have been put there, to unlock areas and doors Collect plastic bottles to recycle, and well to end the game, that would be a spoiler. Nothing too special, just the sudden end.

But it's a very short game.

[b]Meowing Point[/b] is a cute 3D hidden cat game from solo developer Yofransico. It is the creator‚Äôs first project and was originally made for a friend. Players must find and rescue hundreds of hidden cats that have been turned to stone.

It is an ambitious but enjoyable game, and very impressive as the developer‚Äôs first solo project. The hidden object aspect is well implemented and a lot of fun though more direction or hints would be a nice addition to the other activities rather than just have the player stumble across them. The aesthetic is unique and has a subtle retro feel to it and the visuals suit the style of the game well. The music is very nice, though some tracks fit better than others and there was some repetition. The clunkiness of the controls and navigation is probably the game‚Äôs weakest area and does put a bit of a dampener on an otherwise enjoyable experience. Currently, this game needs a bit more polish to justify its price tag. That being said, it is a cute, fun game with a decent amount of potential. On the game‚Äôs store page, the developer talks about working on additional areas, secrets, and polishing which is highly promising and certainly means that this is one to keep an eye on and I will tentatively recommend it with that in mind.

[b]WANT TO KNOW MORE?[/b]
My full review of this game where I go into detail about gameplay, narrative, and styling is available on [url=https://indie-hive.com/meowing-point/[/url].

Meowing Point by Developer yofrancisco, a solo developer with his first game  

A short Point and Click exploration game, with hints and references to the developer's hometown in Australia. It has some slight puzzling with extra hidden objects. The developer, yofrancisco states he is working on additional free areas, secrets, and more polishing. If you're stuck, a story & achievement guide made by the developer can be found in the community section. The developer decided to give this a slightly moody color scheme.

You move around the world using your mouse, you can zoom in and out, but you can't move the camera. There are no hints but the cats are usually not too difficult to find. Pet these kitties and you will find they have names. Yes, they each have a name! There are also some random side quests too, so be sure to pick up any suspicious objects that might be used later. You can click on suspicious things like garbage cans and windows. Some things might even unlock new areas and doors. You never know what you might find. There are a few riddles in this game and they can be somewhat challenging at times. Sometimes a rock requires a specific pickaxe and not the ones laying near the rock. When you find all of the cats on a location, you get a star and can move on. But since there are no hints, finding that one last cat (or last few) can be challenging and frustrating at times. I did get lost even though I tried following the map. It's probably just me, like usual. Cats are more on the ugly side (sorry) and very clever at hiding sometimes.

Looks like no one has reviewed this game recently so here goes:

For a first game by a solo dev, I say good job! It's a casual little point and click game where you find hidden cats that have turned to stone. They meow when you click them, and you can click them again to pet them (and it will tell you that cat's name which is cute). The cats can be tricky to find, which I appreciated as it didn't make it feel like I was wasting money by it being "easy". If you complete an area 100% it tells you in the upper left hand corner that you found all the cats, the most cats I've ever found was 634. And that was with me basically finding all cats in all areas except by the lighthouse! There are some neat references to actual places in Australia, which I enjoyed. You're able to change the window size, make it full screen, and adjust audio which I appreciate. There are achievements, which is pretty dope. Oh, and the dev published a guide themselves, can't say I've seen that before! It's not super thorough, but it helps if you get a bit stuck. 

Yes, there are some things that are a little finicky. I still say it's worth the money. Examples of fiddly bits: when you are about to glide your mouse over the entrance to a new area, the mouse and game lag a bit trying to load the animation of the cat walking/the light lighting up. No biggie. After the initial lag it doesn't seem to happen again. There are only a few songs, so they loop and I guess it could get annoying that they repeat (I still liked the music, it even tells you what song is playing as it changes). 

Overall, I got plenty of hours of play time in with this game. I'm happy with it, I look forward to seeing if the dev comes out with new content :)

Good:
- free

- writing is pretty good and natural

So-so:
- the models of the girl look older than 18, more like 24-25, this mismatch was a bit irritating
- from the start, I didn't feel like I can't hit on this girl. I mean, according to the story, she is "almost like my daughter" but that's not really felt because the protagonist's actual (40+ year old) girlfriend isn't in the picture and there is no player's attachment to her. So, the initial daddy-like tone felt unnecessarily limiting. Thankfully, since I kept selecting the most "sexy" replies, I got to ending 4 which is where the protagonist has sex with the girl. I'd say, the story should have maybe had a message exchange with the girl's mom as well, to make the "love triangle" more real, so that it would matter to the player (?)

Bad:
- well, nothing... except it's short. However, it would get boring if it were any longer because this raw exchange of messages, even if there are a few erotic renders of 3D models in-between, can hold attention only for so long. I think I was starting to lose patience and more like skimming through text just about 50 messages  before the end of the game, so the pacing is about fine. Could still be shortened, to speed up tempo and be certain that it doesn't get boring before it ends.

Overall, it's an interesting mix of a VN and a texting simulator that's relatively novel. I recall 1 game from Nutaku that used the same technique but this game just has far better writing, so it's much better.

A visual novel that tells an adult story in a unique way.

You play the role of a boss who is responsible for introducing a new intern to the company. Sophie is her name, and it turns out she's really adept at her job. After a few work-related talks, you become more friendly, share personal information, and possibly something else.

The game tells a story in an interesting way. Everything is done via an app in which you exchange text messages and perhaps occasional photo. Instead of distracting you with boring gameplay, the entire product concentrates on delivering a story.

At various points, you will be able to respond to Sophie by selecting one of three options. Each option raises one of the three stats, which ultimately lead to different endings. You have three options: love, lust, or creep. Although there are two difficulty levels, it is recommended that you choose easy, which uses colors to match responses to stats. This allows you to go for the desired ending. 

The only explicit content in found in the endings. Until then, text messages are clean and the only risqu√© thing you see is a girl in sexy lingerie.

When you turn around, you can see right through walls since the camera is too near to the main characters. The most of the objects are solid, but a billiard table was most likely overlocked because you can walk directly through it. Furthermore, the view from the balcony is a clear 2D image slapped on the horizon.

It's a shame you can only interact with your computer. Even still, you have no control other than hiring the four girls and changing their clothes. The only other thing in the office are the staff with whom you can speak. However, they will all simply ignore you and claim to be working. 

The most important characters are the main girls. You need to talk to them constantly because they give you tasks. It doesn‚Äôt matter which one you go for because they all want the same thing. While nudity is completely absent from the game, you will see them in a swimsuit or sexy lingerie. 

Unfortunately, there isn't much of a game or content here. The only other options are the beach and your house, neither of which has any interaction points. You boost the value of your firm by fulfilling tasks for girls. This allows you to hire more assistants, but because there are only a few girls, you can do this in ten minutes.

I played a bit of this game yesterday and I know I'm going to love it. Rust Bucket is one of my all time favorite games, also designed by St33d, and this game features the same core systems. One consequence of the minimalist aesthetic is that some of the enemies can be hard to read, but over time I expect to build an intuition for them. So far I've been enjoying puzzle mode, but I expect to dig into some of the proc gen modes eventually as well.
Really cool grid-based puzzle game. Very unique mechanics, great aesthetics, and the dev keeps updating it with new and interesting twists and modes.

Unending is a really beautifully designed puzzle game! It reminds me strongly of Patrick's Parabox, but with less brain melting physics. There's both a mostly linear set of puzzles (where I've spent most of my time) and a more "roguelike" set of dungeons. It's really a no brainer for the price!

If you've ever played or st33d's Ending and Nitrome's Rust Bucket (also designed by Aaron Steed), you know what you're in for.

The game's whole gimmick is that it's a roguelite turn based, tile based combat puzzle game with the twist that you can't move or attack diagonally and most importantly, you can't use a turn to sit still. This creates a lot of awkward situations where you have to find creative ways to waste turns without putting yourself at a disadvantage in order to allow enemies to put themselves in disadvantageous positions themselves. Most things die in one hit with enemies dying in 2 hits or being invincible being special gimmicks and enemy behaviour and the outcome of attacks are completely deterministic and very predictable. All the enemies are unique and the graphical style allows you to easily tell them apart and know how they behave and what their gimmicks are by just looking at them. This isn't without a bit of trial and error, however as you'll have to understand the visual design language the game uses through experience. 

Speaking of trial and error, the game in general is full of it. Thankfully, you can make as many mistakes as you want, including those that put you into a checkmate situation and undo your way all the way to the very first turn if you wish. Only some dungeons have limited/no undos as a special gimmick. It's a great way to allow the player to learn without frustration getting in the way as all mistakes you make just disappear at the press of a button. Though, if you've played turn based puzzle games with unlimited undos you'll know that this doesn't diminish their challenge. The puzzle levels show how each of the many interesting mechanics you'll encounter throughout the randomly generated dungeons can be used in devious ways and even with unlimited undos you might still struggle to figure out how to finish a lot of them.

As of the time of this review there are a lot of puzzles that show and teach you the breadth and depth of the game's mechanics and several randomly generated dungeons each with their own gimmick, including one that's endless. Plenty of fun to be had especially for the low price.

st33d says that an Android version may come in the future (Rust Bucket and Ending both have mobile versions) and I'm really excited for it as I think it's the perfect platform for such a pick up and play and put down any time kind of game like this. Even if it's not 'mindless' fun it's pretty relaxing to play while being very engaging.

This game is kinda like Sokoban crossed with a traditional roguelike, no block pushing though. Needs more exposure. I played the original Ending years ago on my phone, happy to have it on my Deck now.
loved Ending, loving Unending

[h1]Experienced on the Meta Quest 2 & 3[/h1]

You can view my gameplay & early impressions here: https://youtu.be/KgruPpt0nv0

I would not pay full price for this game ($24.99 USD). However, in the current Steam Winter Sale at 60% off ($10 USD), this is an easy recommend for anyone looking for a chill, cozy game. This game is a VR port of a mobile game, so keep your expectations in check. If you're just looking for simple gameplay that is easy and relaxing, then this may be for you.

The game has a nice, linear progression. You start off in London and just renovate all the houses. Once you're done, you'll have enough money to unlock the next city (Dubai). Each house you renovate will have variations of mini-game like "home restoration." You'll have this game where you swing a blade around and it'll act like a lawnmower. Or you'll mortar the bricks together. Or you'll fix the hole in the wall by plastering it then coloring the wall with different tools available. You'll also add home furnishings to make either the cheapo house of your dreams or the luxury house of your dreams. The choices are limited, but it keeps the game feeling cozy throughout.

Game is running on the Unity Engine. On my RTX 3080, I was getting mostly 90 fps, but I did notice some frame rate drops / stutters at time, especially in the hub area. The only serious bug I encountered (I think) is that I couldn't change the colors of the bought decorations. You do have full locomotion, along with snap turning. I recommend turning off the blinder in settings. You can play comfortably seated.

I didn't think I would like this game at all, especially after the first few houses. But the more I played this game, the more I was enjoying it because the game introduced new things to do as you progressed. I hope that is the case for all the cities.

It is simply ASTONISHING how unfinished this addon is.

First let me say that the core bus is actually really nice.  That's what makes the decision to release it in this state so frustrating.  The sounds are nice, the gearboxes are improved over the poorly shifting usual versions from Kescrole, and are finally getting to feel like the transmissions on other addons.  (Kescrole just cannot do gearboxes and should have gone externally for help a long time ago).   Even what people in some reviews are describing are "poor textures" - are not poor textures - Kescrole have finally made the effort to make the dashboards, that are shared across all their products, look a little different from each other.    The bus depicted here is an older (2006-2011) version of the Evadys and the dashboard has been textured with lots of wear and tear; which I think has been done really well.

So what's the problem?

-- No tablet --

Every Kescrole payware addon so far has come with the tablet, to make setvar changes dynamically. This addon is the same premium price as his other buses, so why on Earth should we expect to have such a huge downgrade, by not having this tablet functionality??  I use his other addon buses a lot, and use the tablet in every single session, to customize the bus how I want it for each trip.  Not having this tablet makes this package around the same functionality level as the default OMSI buses.   Unacceptable

-- Function to change ticket machine language to anything except French, is BROKEN! --

In every other Kescrole addon, you can change the ticket machine language to German and English. In the case of this addon, it is stuck on French.  (This is the case with the machines that come with the Urbanway addon - it seems this collection of French developers all work together, and whoever created the ticket machine... well, it's broken!)

-- Only a GERMAN manual is provided. No English and no French --

No addon sold on Steam should be coming without a manual in English.  More surprising - considering this develop is French - is the lack of a French manual even!

-- External model animations are missing --

Again, every other Kescrole addon has opening engine hood, fuel and AdBlue caps.  This one has no external animations or features.

-- The "Schoolbus" sign on the front is disgusting (seems to have blood and gunshots on it), and BECAUSE THERE IS NO TABLET, cannot be removed --


This could have been a fantastic addon, but it feels like Kescrole was about 75% finished, then just gave up and released it in this terribly unfinished state.

I strongly recommend that you do not  buy this addon, until it receives a huge update, to bring it up to the same standard as Kescrole's other premium-priced, OMSI addons.

EDIT: In fact they included setvars (list) but only in a pdf file found in Addons folder.

"The Detective Reaper Invites" is a puzzle roguelike that challenges players to solve randomly generated murder cases. As a detective reaper, your task is to gather testimonies from suspects, deduce the culprit, and execute them.

The game is a unique blend of strategy and resource management. Cards can be used to acquire vital testimonies, but they come at a cost, so maintaining your finances is important. Money can be earned by successfully solving cases, and you can spend your earnings on items and cards at the shop, but beware of cursed items and detrimental cards.

The board game layout adds a layer of depth to the gameplay. Players must navigate through various tiles, such as Crime Scenes, Shops, Treasures, and Random Events, to progress. With three levels of difficulty ‚Äì Normal, Difficult, and Arduous ‚Äì the game will test your deduction skills to the limit.

Overall, this deduction game is ideal for players who enjoy logical puzzles and resource management. It draws inspiration from "Mimic Logic", that's available for less than half the price.

However, I hesitate to recommend this game in its current state, due to the barely legible font. It's a puzzle in itself to read the faint squiggly text. In particular, the letter 'Z' is almost identical to the letter 'X', which can lead you to identify the wrong culprit.

A big drawback is the absence of mouse support, limiting players to use either a keyboard or a game controller, which feels unusual for a puzzle game. 

Another concern is the balance of solving the cases.  Early levels can be guessed without the use of any cards and later puzzles lack the necessary clues or have suspects who refuse to provide any information. This combination forces the player to guess who the culprit is, potentially risking a significant loss to their health.

Finally, the game would benefit from an option to disable the time limit, as it's unclear why players are being rushed through puzzles in a genre that usually encourages thoughtful consideration. 

Addressing these issues would significantly improve the game's playability and make it easier to recommend.

I was going to give this game a good review with happy smiles and good tips, but I'm mixed, now.

The game does not understand what constitutes a "lie" when it comes to locations, specifically when time is not a factor (only 01).

I've seen multiple culprits *honestly admit* their location in their opening message. I have to completely disregard location.

Play Gnosia if you want an interesting puzzler type game like this but with more elements of social deduction and argumentation.

If you still want to give this game a shot, here's how to break it: Max out on Culprit cards, SKIP everything else. The AI does not consider what has been said previously.

If there is 1 killer, and they accuse 2 people? Murderer. If there is 1 innocent, and they say 2 people are innocent? Murderers. The AI is incapable of throwing its ally under the bus. This applies to ANY uneven group, but it is harder to pull off.

Remember: if someone says someone else is innocent, they are always on a team with that person.

If someone says someone is guilty, they are always the opposite alignment.

The strategy is incredibly simple: Determine teams as fast as possible. When you're forced to kill someone, if you don't feel confident, kill the decisive testimony for grouping people up. If the result is unexpected, invert your qssumptions.

Once you determine the group that told you the truth, if you've grouped everyone up effectively, you win.

Remember that location, eyewitness, and all that other shit are next to useless unless the outcome is impossible. "I was with E", Z? But literally none of you were together. Murderer, spotted.

The only other useful eyewitness pairing was "I was with (other person)" with both corroborating each other.

The only time location/eyewitness work is when another person corroborates. You want to seek contradictions. Locations and eyewitness statements have way more variables than culprit choices. Make everyone declare culprits and see where it leads you.

A really great repayable murder mystery rogue-lite where you solve murder after murder with really nice graphics and feel, it is clear a lot of care went into the game.

The core murder mystery puzzles are like liar puzzles (similar to mimic logic) where the culprits lie & the innocent tell the truth and you must deduce the murderer from this. Each mystery has a very cool little map showing where people were at different times (although it doesn't tell you who is who). 
This map is great and unique, it is very cool to see the murder play out in motion, sometimes with the murderers lying in wait and victim entering the room, or sometimes following them in in a later part of the sequence.
The map is an integral part of the game which sets it apart, with layers people being in different locations at different times adding a lot of things for the characters to talk and lie about, and it causes some very great difficult logic puzzle with very satisfying solutions.

You can only get a few statements out of each character and you also have finite cards to ask questions with which really makes you think about which type of question to ask people. Should you ask F about the location they were in or who else they saw there? Playing these question cards also costs currency which pushes you to solve mysteries with as few questions as possible.

The roguelite part of the game plays out like slay the spire with as you cross a grid of mystery puzzles and random events and shops where you can buy new cards and modifiers which impact health and currency. At the end each level, there is a tougher mystery like a miniboss. A full successful run can take about an hour, but the game is infinitely repayable with different mysteries every time.

When you beat the game the first time [spoiler] you get to play as a 2nd detective character who limits the number of cards you play before you accuse someone, this really makes the decision making about which questions to ask much more important. [/spoiler]

Presentation is very nice and stylised, and gives a great feel to the game.


The negatives of the game are minor for me and may be ironed out in time;

The UI of witness statements can sometimes cover the map showing where people were during the crime.
The Z in the english translation has a cross through it making it look like an X which makes it hard to read the first time.
There are some 50/50 situations, particularly with [spoiler] the 2nd detective where you can sometimes only play 2 cards. The final puzzle of that run was a 50/50 "he said she said" situation which I lost & felt unsatisfying to lose an hour long run to chance. [/spoiler]


But overall, this game is a massive gem for me, some of the puzzles become very complex in a great way and are incredibly satisfying to solve and really scratch that murder mystery itch. So many murder mystery games are a one and done experience but I see myself playing this again and again.

Having heard about this game when it was first announced I was interested in checking it out as soon as it was released. Unfortunately the final product was nothing like the expectation I had in the lead up to release day.

Cases can go from immediately solvable due in part to the opening statements (X: D is the culprit, D: X is the culprit, Y: D and myself are not the culprits) to a coinflip because of pointless testimonies causing you to waste cards thinking you can get helpful information out of some uncooperative suspects. The penalty system for executing the wrong person is also weirdly unbalanced, as you can have a max HP value of 80 but a wrong answer does 75 damage. You can find or buy cards that raise your max HP and reduce penalty damage but it's all still random.

The cards you can pick up during a run either after successfully solving a case or purchasing in the shop don't offer much variety (you can have a choice between a 5-cost card that gets a testimony out of a suspect or a 3-cost card that does the same thing, or even another 5-cost card that has the same effect but with different artwork and name). At first you would think there would be plenty of cards that offer a wide range of useful effects based on the number of encyclopedia entries but they are mostly duplicates and some entries reserved for cards that impose a negative effect.

The UI during cases is also rough. Gathered testimonies would end up covering portions of the map that make it difficult to reference when making your deductions and in cases with a fifth suspect their portrait outright covers a chunk of the map. Narrower rooms that get generated in the middle of a map also make it hard to tell what room a suspect was in as their map marker overlaps the room borders and makes it seem like they were in an adjacent room.

Overall The Detective Reaper Invites has an interesting premise but fails to deliver in some key areas that make it hard to come back to for repeat playthroughs.

Mostly a bad game, but fixable, as it is not intentionally bad, and it already has the groundwork to being great.

The random setups are either too easy or a random guessing game, and the punishment for randomly guessing wrong is too hard.
All suspects will only give 3 replies, a VERY dumb limit, as they may even be a nonsensical space waster declaration, that is just adds to bad randomness.
At random times you have to guess, and this is usually an instant-lose-scenario.
The economy is WAY too hard+expensive+random, too often getting you into the random insta-kill scenario.

how to fix this:
- never have anyone make no statement from the start. that is a random resource  waster.
- never have anyone say "i am innocent", as this is a space waster.
- never have anyone say anything, that NEVER helps the case. (shocked, weather) 
- - alternative solution to the above, anyone who ever declares a space waster can be executed without penalty but then will no longer declare anything.
. . . maybe the fail-state itself is just silly. why is there no "bad/greedy cop" ending being played straight for what it is, this simply needs a secondary "currency" that is more or less a "rating system with no failure or different fail states".
- all declarations must be a logical-AND statement, we already have this, but too rarely, as "A and B are innocent"
an AND statement makes the game harder while it also significantly more likely exposes a liar, and once exposed because all sides of the statements are a lie, this usually exposes 2 culprits at once. 
- more cards and cheaper cards.
- compared to similar deduction games, mostly mimic-chest-themed, you have the advantage of a timeline, but fail to utilize it properly (game economy is too constrained for no good reason)

The aftermath of a murder is ignored for no good reason, different weapons leave different traces, to be hidden/disposed only by murderers.
Add more token that potentially aid in exposing a liar, while they may also be a red-herring, played by a culprit.
Culprits have professions and outfits, that match their profession, but the murderer always lies who has what costume AND profession.
Some rooms have a security camera, that never lies, unless the murderer has a profession that can disable it.
Differences between murder weapons matter, some can be concealed easily, some make more noise, they all leave different traces on use and murderers make attempts at hiding traces/weapons after the murder.
A murderer will always use the murder weapon that matches its true profession, and not all murder weapons exist in all rooms, but may be transported between rooms.

"I was in the kitchen AND B is the Cook with a knife"
"I was not in the room when the security camera got destroyed AND A is a hunter"
A murderer may have to dispose of the murder weapon and remove traces of the murder, and that may add hints to who is lying.

Nice little game.
I hope the devs will continu to develop it and add cards and game mecanics.

I got to the end of the run but [spoiler] sadly, in chapter two, innocent started lying and culprit started to tell the truth and I hope it will get patched quick. [/spoiler]

I already played an hour worth of this game and genuinely, I'm conflicted by what I really feel about this game, but then I see the price tag and in all honesty?  It's a really neat execution.

The idea is simple, using simple deduction, using cards in your deck, you need to be able to sort out whodunnit in quick mysteries via testimonies, time, and location. At first, and in some cases, it's very obvious as killers lie and innocents are truthful, matching statements making it easier to detect, but then when you have 4-5 people and 2-3 killers, suddenly you have a bit more of a troublesome situation making you needing to pay close attention while on a time limit.

For $10, if you want a solid roguelike to experience?  Pick this up.  Slay the Spire is one of my all time fave games and, admittedly, Balatro didn't click with me (but I'm still playing it since it's still fun in the end) but this is cheap and pretty solid.  I'm very curious about Natalie's story as there's an underlying story to it all too.

So while it's not expansive (at this time), there's plenty of complexity to be had that makes this easy to get sucked into.

I hate being negative on a small indie game, this has clear passion behind it and a very good idea under its belt, but this is a very flawed game on a fundamental level. Even if all the weird jank and bugs was fixed in its entirety, the foundation this game builds upon isn't engaging for a roguelike, this isn't the kind of game you want to replay and see how things change between runs, the only big difference between runs is how much you get screwed over by random chance, sometimes you get a case where 2 people say "X is the killer" and it's a sweep, other times you get no testimony at all and when you ask questions, they give you "I can't believe this" or "I'm Thirsty". This is where the cards are supposed to come into play, but there will be times when you try to use them optimally and because the witnesses just choose to not be helpful, you get stuck with barely any more info than before. This wouldn't be too bad if you could more easily opt out of runs and start again, but there's no reset mid run aside from dying or closing the game, so if your up a creek without a paddle, you just have to wait until you die or reopen the game, it makes a already slow experience feel slower.

The concept here is really brilliant, a deckbuilder rougelike murder mystery is a idea that can be so fun, but this execution does not do the idea justice, If it gets more fixes and updates later, I hope it does go about fixing some of the issues the game has, but the issues are so deep rooted in its very foundation that I just can't imagine that happening.
A solid music for someone who is not a musician or has knowledge of sheet music. Made with the GarageBand app and inspired by epic soundtracks of any kind.

Cleared this game on my first try. It's light on moveset and build variety, but you can also beat the game with bad/no gear. In my opinion I prefer this kind of skill-based roguelike over ones where luck is the most important factor in winning. Combat is responsive and fast while still making attacks feel impactful. The just dodge and guard feel great, even if you wish the moveset was a bit larger so there were more ways to style on enemies.

Persistent elements so far are pretty basic; mostly just stat boosts and new super attacks, along with two unlockable characters. The game mentions new weapons but I'm unsure if that means there's a weapon switch mechanic or just a result of inaccurate translation. At $17 I think the game is a steal, but you have to know what you're getting into. It's an unorthodox blend of musou enemy fights and melee boss fights you might see in things like Nioh, and there might not be a lot to keep you playing if you want run variety above all else. Will update this review when I get farther, but so far I'm impressed.

Game holds 120FPS on medium with a 3070 and an i9-12900k so I'd say optimization is good too.

Truth be told I still enjoy the game even after the 2.0 update, however, I will admit that two changes from that version in comparison to 1.0 should be reverted.  Number one why, did you remove the multiple choice options from the shield parry,  the purpose of a combo based game like this is that the player has multiple options to approach an enemy.  Secondly, the making it so that only certain ground and air skills can only be slotted in a specific spot really kills the move variety, again going back to multiple options argument.  I will also admit that I kind of like the idea of the awakener skills from 1.0 and would kind of like to see those come back to make each class a bit more unique and increase the move pool a bit more.  Despite these gripes, I will still admit that this game is a pretty fun take on a DMC rougelike. The moves nicely combo into each other with smooth movement and the fights are pretty nicely balanced in terms of difficulty based upon player skill.  The runs are kept to a reasonable length and don't feel dragged out making the replayability much better than some other rougelike's I've played in the past.  I will say that if the two changes I mentioned earlier were to happen, then I think this game would reach an even greater point then it is at right now.  Keep it up devs, looking forward to what you have in the future.
New update feels like it removed a good amount of the fun systems, although it brought in new ones, the game feels worse off.

first of all ignore the playtime, accidentally left the game on pause when i did stuff and forgot about it a few times, actual play time is more along the lines of 10h

now that thats out of the way, the gameplay is fun enough but it gets very repetitive without much variation, you might say thats because going for the most effective option all the time will make things boring, and to that i say, theres really nothing else, elements are mostly just apply stacks with this relic, pop it with another relic, none of the relics really build into anything more than that, theres not like more complicated relics you need other prerequisites to get, which just makes every run feel the same to me, and other than that all you get is just stats, which just leads to doing the same combos

its not a bad game per se, just not what im looking for in these kinds of games(replayability with at least some variability), it was like $10 for me due to regional pricing so i guess its okay that i got 10hours out of it but wouldnt really recommend it, get it on a sale or something i guess

So at first I was a little conflicted. Not too sure if I should give this a thumbs up or a thumbs down.

But eventually I decided on giving it a thumbs up and here's why.

Is this game next gen? Is it epic? Is it awesome?

No.

It's average.

But the reason why I'm giving it a thumbs up is because technically it does what it sets out to do. Plus it's at a very reasonable price. Despite how good the game looks, or how well it plays, or how stable it is, it's still only charging 17 dollars.

Gotta give it credit for that.

But is it a must-have game? Nah.

It's okay. It's average. Let me put it to you this way, if you always wanted to play Dark Souls or Elden Ring but found them too hard, then I encourage you to try this game. It's like those but on super easy mode. I'm terrible at those games and almost cleared this one in one sitting. Which brings another possible problem. I think this game is only a few hours long. 

Again...making it not worth more than 17 dollars.

Overal it's not an awful game or an awful experience but it's nothing super awesome or must-have either. Basically if you like the look and style of games like this and you're bored one day, then sure maybe pick it up and play it. But if you're not sure, then just move on. K?

If you'd like more information with gameplay please check out the video I posted on my YouTube Channel (link below).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=irwbyXwXBLc

Otherwise thanks so much for reading and I hope I managed to help some of you out there spend your money wisely.

This game is fun, a good deal for $15.

The first run is pretty easy but I'm definitely getting my ass kicked more on the 2nd run as they add more enemy types and the mini-boss encounters get spicier.

Wow, this is actually incredible! Addicting action combat, super satisfying combos and sweet graphics. 3 Discinct Classes. Deep and fun Roguelike. BIG SURPRISE I massively underestimated this game. Just Easy Fun and an actually good game, system-wise aswell as mechanically. Animations also insane. The Rogue class is NUTS! Highly Recommended. Dont even wait for Sale. trust.

[h1] TL;DR [/h1]
The game is pretty bare-bones and lacks the complexity of it's bigger AAA action game brothers like the DMC or Bayonetta series' but it's a solid foundation especially for an indie game. Honestly, it feels a lot more like a Dynesty Warriors experience in its current state which is pretty good for its reasonable price point. Worth it in my eyes but if you're on the edge watch for updates and pick it up during a sale.

[h1] The Review [/h1]
If you've played any rouge-likes before the gameplay loop will be pretty familiar. Same bosses at the end of the tunnel but random room structure in between. However, instead of just being thrown from one random place to the next you have a choice between three room structures with different rewards or enemy types in between. Currently, there are 3 characters and it won't take very long at all to unlock them. 

Again, I should mention ahead of time that if you're expecting a lot of complexity in it you'll be pretty disappointed. I should also be upfront in saying that I'm not a combo god. Other people can surely elaborate further on this games lacking aspects than me so take this an an average players account. I came in looking for a Devil May Cry type experience but got more of a Dynasty Warriors feel. 

On the offence, every character is locked to 3 moves mainly. A launcher, (Which is also your helm-breaker type move in the air) a charging attack, (As in you run forward to close distance) and your standard hits (Usually a 4-6 hit combo). I'll give a brief summary of each character but all of them only have one weapon, only one of them have a gimmick without upgrades, none of them have ranged attacks (Which is really something they should add, would definitely help the game-feel a bit more), and the "devil trigger"-esque (DT going forward) mechanic isn't character specific. (Meaning, while it is useful, all of them are simple enough that they're either kind of boring or don't mesh with some characters as well as others.) 

Every character in this game feels like you've just booted up a new savefile in DMC. Outside of being able to toggle sprint, a couple of pause combos, (I mean that, I've only found one or two for each character.) and a helm-breaker-esque combo ender, you have basically nothing and the few unlockable moves you can get aren't actually added to your characters moveset and instead are optional replacements for your launcher or charge moves. The only thing that can spice up this formula are the "artifacts" you can pick up during runs but again these are not character specific. This means they're plagued by the same issues as the games DT mechanic I mentioned earlier with the added downside that they're used constantly in your gameplay so feeling boring or not meshing with each character is far more impactful. Now we'll be moving on to:

[h1] The Characters [/h1]
[b] Knight [/b]: This game has a perfect parry system that seems to be geared towards the knight. I mentioned earlier that only one character has a gimmick and this isn't what I was talking about. There's a souls-style dodge roll and a parry which are introduced in the tutorial, where you're playing as the knight. It's pretty easy to perfect dodge and perfect parry and there's not much of a meaningful difference between the two outside of the flair. There are 4 options of attack out of the perfect parry as the knight and only one for dodging but the damage and stun is about the same. Now the reason I'm not calling this a gimmick is because I can't tell if I'm just bad or it's character-specific. I land parries pretty easy as the knight but I tried it as the other two a couple times and just didn't land it so I just went back to rolling. Outside of that there's not much to say here, his tools aren't much but it's a simple loop that's pretty satisfying. The TTK is fine but it's mainly his defensive aspects that make him fun, not because of the damage but because it just makes you feel pretty cool. 

[b] Assassin [/b]: Has the most to his combo game compared to the other two. Has a [Just] timing system kind of similar Assault Spy if you've played that game. Long story short, perfectly timing together attacks give a huge power boost and this can be made far better during your run. Definitely the character with the most to him if you're looking for complexity but still feels pretty hollow to me. If you're still really on the fence about getting this game you'll definitely get him within the first 20-ish minutes so honestly just playing it to try him out and just refunding it if you dont like the feel before the 2 hr mark would be my recommendation.

[b]Spear Woman [/b]: This is the easiest character in the game and the last one you unlock. You knock people up and can just kind of sit in the air forever. You still have to think fighting bosses since their hitboxes are wide enough you'll just be sent flat on your ass if you mess around. It's entertaining and her unlockable attacks keep her fun to play but probably the one that needs the most work between the three. You can infinitely pretty much infinitely loop the same two attacks to the point where the only thing stopping you from hitting the skybox is your foes HP.

[h1] Fin. [/h1]

It didn't really need its own category or anything since overall they're pretty serviceable obstacles but here's a brief bit about the-

[b] Enemies [/b]: Some of the enemies have kind of wonky animations that make the game feel harder than it really is. I've gotten used to it now but on an initial run it can definitely throw you off. This includes the bosses and mini-bosses. Since it's a rouge-like I'm alright with a little bit of trial and error here.

That about wraps my thoughts, sorry if it's a little unorganized but that about summarizes my view of this game. For a smaller indie project it's a worth the price I guess but it wouldn't hurt to either wait till more nuance is added to the gameplay or a sale if it doesn't sound worth it to you.

The indie scene is rife with choices when it comes to the Roguelite and Roguelike genres.  Be it on genre staples of 2.5D Metroidvanias like Rogue Legacy and Dead Cells to more outlandish entrees like The Binding of Isaac or Darkest Dungeon: you‚Äôll be hard pressed to go a month without another new one hitting your recommended store of choice.  So it‚Äôs that time of the month, and in front of me stands a Dark Souls-esque Roguelite promising fancy combos, plentiful enemies, and colossal bosses.  Alright, let's see what we got.

The Awakener: Forgotten Oath summons you to the world of Sylvalong, notably to the land of Lucatia, where disasters spread amongst the area and threaten life in and around it.  To keep the land from succumbing to the horrors that plague it, the Gods have pulled the world into another dimension known as Nothingness.  These Gods have tasked chosen warriors, deemed the Awakened, to eliminate the demons once and for all to save Sylvalong: no matter how many lives it takes for you to complete your task.

Forgotten Oath‚Äôs initial vibe feels like if you took Devil May Cry‚Äôs combat with Dark Souls aesthetic and Rogue Legacy‚Äôs rouge-lite systems and slapped it all together in a Unreal Engine For Dummies game-engine.  The biggest draw going into the story will be the combat, which easily stands as the best parts of the game.  You‚Äôll have your choice of three Awakeners, each clad with a specific moveset that caters to different playstyles: I‚Äôm a sword-and-board kind of guy so I went with the starting character.  Movesets start with a basic combo but can be extended using Launchers, Dashes, and Smashes.  These extra moves do exactly as intended, with the launchers popping enemies up for extra hits, Smashes adding a firm end to any combo, and Dashes which can be done on the ground or in the air being a flashy continuation against your enemies.

These movesets can be tinkered with before each run with different styles of attacks, but after trying all of them, I very quickly found the bread-and-butter combos and stuck to it.  While flashy, the combos will become notably repetitive: a recurring theme going forward.  You‚Äôll face enemies in a 30-floor gauntlet, with boss battles on every 10th floor.  Each room will only last you about 1-2 minutes depending on the difficulty of the area chosen after beating the previous room.  Rooms with harder enemies grant better results, which come in a variety of lootable options.

Your main power ups come through Relics, a 7 element card system that helps shape the style of your character during your current run.  Each element has a specific ability: fire does damage over time, wind will make enemies easier to crit, ice freezes enemies over time, and these cards will be your benefactor to being an absolute damage monster.  You can also grab Void Crystals and Soul Echoes, which allow you passive upgrades to your character to take to future runs and to unlock new moves and characters respectively.  Awakeners can collect coins which are good to buy current-run-only items and Relics to help aid in completing the build you want or to cash out for more crystals and echoes if you want to add more power to your next run.

Relics will work in a number of ways such as activating by doing a Launch/Smash/Dash, on a passive timer, during a dodge, or on Perfect Defense (parrying) and Just Dodges to name a few.  Relics of multiple elements can be stacked on the same action so later runs can have you activating multiple elements on one move and doing an abnormal amount of damage through one button press.  It gets bonkers keeping up with the amount of damage you can do and a simpleton like me does like doing a big move and seeing the big numbers.

But while the game expects you to run multiple times to gather knowledge of enemy patterns and to progress the overarching narrative, the stink of repetitiveness will inevitably work its way into your nostrils.  Forgotten Oath‚Äôs story arc requires you to traverse through the 30 floors multiple times (I needed 4 complete runs to finish) to collect story-related items, and in doing so shows you just how thin the content really is.  The fancy and enjoyable combat soon becomes a min-max study as later floors require you to find the best combo and abuse it to perfection.  While hitting an air smash on several enemies triggering several elements to do a waterfall of damage is enjoyable, you‚Äôll be doing it so many times it will become second nature and the allure wears out well before the credits roll.

Floors lack diversity and in some cases, explanations (why are there lasers shooting out of every angle in this castle???), and you will see the same room multiple times even though the rooms change aesthetics every 10 floors.  I think there are maybe 3-4 variants of each biome that you are asked to run 10 times a piece to power up your character and none of them are very memorable.  Since the game does not really provide you with a reason as to why you are in these specific areas, you are just meant to fill in the blanks as to why this asset-friendly arena is where you need to be and these enemies that are given no roots to the plot are necessary to be defeated.  The bosses are not much better.

Forgotten Oath has three bosses that, again, feel like placeholders within the created biomes but don‚Äôt really provide details as to why these enemies are our enemies.  The first boss, the Skull Knight, is the only boss given some plot context and that‚Äôs given on a few lines of text before and after your fight.  The movesets for each boss are pretty limited and are easy to handle and counter, leaving these fights longer due to a higher HP but not harder due to inherited difficulty.  Once you do get a completed run under your belt, returning for another run will only spawn additional higher-rank enemies to make the game more difficult, but in turn only increases the time of each run, which is not doing the game any favors.  You can add Curses to your runs to provide a boost in difficulty as well netting you more rewards for each run, but the amount of Void Crystals and Soul Echoes are collected at such a respectable level that these Curse runs feel provided for personal enjoyment rather than story necessity.

Lastly, the localization team for Forgotten Oath could‚Äôve used some more time polishing their work as there are multiple typos and grammatical errors strewn throughout the title.  Font choice looks like a preset default was used and doesn‚Äôt mesh well with the aesthetic of the game, giving the UI a very rushed looking finish and can cause some confusion when explaining Relics and navigating around the menus.  Using the term ‚ÄúUsually‚Äù and ‚ÄúSeemingly‚Äù when defining a card that does damage on a certain move is a very odd choice that makes me wonder if some of these cards were really working as intended if the text isn‚Äôt even quite sure of its intended powers.

What sullens the mood the most with Forgotten Oath is that it does not feel like there is a full game presented to its audience.  The combat system feels fleshed out to the point of working and then everything else is rushed around it to mirror the allure of a complete experience: the plot is non-existent, the locales are paint-by-number, and the enemy selection are cardboard to stop you from speedrunning the game by accident.  As much as the combat tries to mask the incompleteness of its surroundings, there‚Äôs very little redeeming qualities and even less to grip you to seeing The Awakener: Forgotten Oath to its end.

Very Well Creative Game, Rogue-like Type game. Fighting is smooth dodging is beautiful, perk lv ups and ability perks are very well understanding and detailed.  dungeon stage base progression , this game has tremendous potential honestly. Already beat the game doesn't take long to beat, enjoyable.  highly recommended if interested in trying something new. 10/10. still give a 10 even tho its single player only.
Surprised at how this can run on Deck. Graphics are great, gameplay can be a bit repetitive, but overall fun. Recommended for Hack N slash deckers!

I recommend this game BUT it really needs a lot of love when it comes to control mapping, immersion when it comes to dialogue, spelling etc. I understand English is not their first language I get it. 

But surely it's not hard to get someone who is a linguist (Or even just a English speaker that's a Grammar Nazi) Hell I would do it for very little.

Why? Because This game shines when it comes to combat I feel the amount of effort that has been put into hit detection and graphical effects. It needs voice acting, correction of errors such as spelling and other scenes I can't fill in this box of text.

I see the potential of this game, and Controls and spelling should not hinder such a game.

It's honestly a very mid game and I mostly bought it to satisfy my Bloodborne Chalice Dungeon craving I've had for years, but strangely enough this game's combat ended up being more like.. a Dynasty Warriors or ultra simple DMC game mixed with your standard roguelite. It's also pretty easy. I beat the full run and unlocked all characters within 2.5 hours of buying the game. The powerups are mostly just elemental buffs to your existing combos or percentage gains, but it still feels really good (and cool) once you get upgraded and have a million effects going off during your combos. I guess I'd recommend to anyone who's bored and wants this specific genre since it's not like we have any other options LOL. It won't hurt to wait for more updates/patches though

EDIT: New update was a step in the right direction but two steps back. Build diversity is more interesting and possible with the addition of a 2nd artifact slot (artifacts are your special attacks). They also added quite a few artifacts that I really like. They also removed your start loadout and just incorporated the abilities you could choose from as floor upgrades. I personally think that was a good idea, since previously you would just pick the best abilities and never really look back. Now i find myself experimenting or excited when I see the abilities I like. They merged the currencies which was also a good idea. I hated having an obscure currency purely for buying characters. They removed your ultimate ability and I find that to be a shame. I'd love a devil trigger or spartan rage mode. They also removed some of the cool counterattacks you could do with the Fighter class. Now it's just a regular counterattack when you parry rather than a few options. They also buffed enemy health by a LOT. Everything is a damage sponge, or it might just be a side effect of removing so many abilities/buffs from before... but enemies take a very long time to die and I often find myself air juggling them for waaaaay too long or even just backing off and waiting for my artifact to come off cooldown since it just didn't feel worth it to attack them normally. This results in the combat feeling slower/clunkier than it previously did and I don't really find myself wanting to do another run. That being said, I still recommend since the devs are actively listening to the community and updating the game. This game has huge potential if they can find the right balance.

The game is cool and I think that the updates are really helping, however I feel like there are certain abilities and upgrades that outperform the other ones that it creates a power gap. The amount of grinding you have to do for upgrades also feels a bit excessive.

This game has a solid foundation, a truly fun core gameplay loop. It is however lacking in build variety, the skill based combat will keep you somewhat interested but overall your choices are limited. I look forward to updates cause this could a be truly great game. Think Hades meets DMC.

its pretty good. need more air combat tweaks... after 2.01 i thought you guy were cooking with the movelist and then you remove it? kinda breaks the entire loop of making combo strings ill be back when i can be a dragoon again.
Fun combat and great feel. Localization has some errors that make it difficult to understand what a skill does sometimes, but not enough to seriously affect the game.

Got to the credits in about 7 or 8 hours into the game. Not a whole lot of content, but it's worth the price (IMO). 

Something worth mentioning is that the balance feels quite off. What's weird is that a big damage increase comes from upgrading the damage from the main base, instead of getting buffs from a run (though many of them are strong too). Without the base damage upgrades, enemies can feel like a sponge, but after they're maxed, it's incredibly easy to stunlock and delete the bosses in less than a minute.

For the price honestly a steal, just wish it would have bossrush mode, more bosses n characters. But hey for a 1.0 release at that price. Enjoyable.

I'm 20 minutes in, I know what to expect for any further playtime. I'm happy for the solid combat system I've so far experienced. Nothing feels clunky or forced, I can only expect more and varied systems to learn. I'm going to play as much as I can around my family needs. 

I get to game in either 10-15 minute blocks around my family, or I get a single day where I game til my eyes bleed. I've been happily amused for the 2x 10 minute blocks so far.

Some might see a fluted helm and immediately compare this to Dark Souls. Don't. If you must, this is a DMC-style combat in a rogue-lite form.

The characters' combat styles are varied enough to pick a favorite based on your preference. You have the tough, grounded heavy hitter, the sleak aerial-focused spear lady (VERY fun) and the really fast, lower damage but insane elemental stacker rogue-type combo-based guy.

In Monster Hunter terms:
Knight - SnS
Spear Maiden - IG (on crack)
Rogue - DBs

The combat has all the bells and whistles of a proper action game that wants you to improve and just nail down sections with fast reactions. You have a perfect block, perfect dodge, aerial combos and aerial dodge. 

It can be slow or fast depending on your character choice. They all gradually get faster and faster. The aerial chick really opens up a whole new way to play. Imagine you were playing a dragoon in FF, but like they do in the cutscenes XD or if Monster Hunter IG didn't have stamina. Healing's a slightly shorter DS3 estus.

The audio's acceptable, but not memorable by any means. Hopefully they revisit that portion.

Audio: 5/10

Overall, it's definitely super worth 20$ and if they patch onto it, I'm in to try out the new content every time. For now, I'll be playing this for sure! It's quick, pick up and play, just go go go!

Mkay, yeah, this game is definitely cool and worth the playthrough. The combat is obviously what was focused on the most and it still feels sorta bare-bones-ish at times like getting locked in certain animations or dealing with funny hitboxes from the bosses. It feels like an asset game where they fully fleshed out the combat. And the combat is REALLY fun, I don't want to understate that. Once I unlocked all the characters and found which one best suited me, the combat is extremely gratifying and can certainly scratch those power fantasy itches. I can't wait to see how this game improves over time. This is a special rogue, for sure.

UPDATE:
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The update more or less ruined the game. They took out all of the elemental skills you'd usually get and replaced them with two or three, it seems. There's not as many unlockables anymore. They added some artifacts, which was cool, but the original version did it so much better. By the end of the run, you don't feel like a powerhouse like you did in the original version. All around, just less fun.

VERY VERY fun rougelike. among one of my favs of the genre so far. a fast paced mix between dmc and dark souls meets hades.  from my play though, you got three characters to play as that all vary between styles. dual sword, sword and shield, and a spare holder. the game runs smooth even at 4k on my system. It is on the short end of the stick but unlike cod mw2023. the cost of the game is 1000% worth it.  you got combos and counter attacks that can be pulled off easily once mastered. The mixed score is BS. this is one of those games i bought and played the moment it was released that i can't put down. so maybe give it a shot and judge it for yourself! a solid thumbs up

Edit: I'd like to redo my review now that I've played it much longer. Overall I'm still rather positive towards the game and feel satisfied with my purchase. Just so you know, the game is very clearly low budget and seems to just reuse assets from the devs main game, The Awakener: Risen. This in itself isn't an issue but you will notice some lack luster amateurish animations and rough translations. 

Combat:
The game's combat feels really good; the controls feel responsive, you're able to cancel the early frames of your attacks into a dodge, and for one character into a guard, perfect dodges and guards feel extremely satisfying to pull off and to follow up with a counter attack, which will always stagger the boss and give you some free damage. The game really does reward skill and makes you feel excited for pulling off shit. 

However despite how good the game's combat feels, it can also just feel really repetitive. While you're able to free customize your move set and change it around with the random moves you can earn while doing a run, you do end up feeling like you're doing the same few combo's over and over. The artifacts are a nice way to add further diversity to your moveset but the fact all of the artifacts, including the buffs, can only be executed while on the ground feels very limiting. In addition to the artifacts, the level 4 attacks, all of your attacks have levels up to 4 that drop during runs, are really cool as they add elementally effects to that corresponding move. The issue is that you're not likely to get more than 1 or 2 of those moves during a complete run, in my experience, so you don't get to really get to enjoy them much before the run ends and due to the increased strength the games ends up pushing you to use those moves far more. 

I would really like to see some artifacts changed to be executable while airborne and for maybe elemental effects to be added a level sooner.

Enemies:
Basic enemies are far too basic and boring. Like straight up they lack a lot of complexity, they'll stand still a bit before throwing out an attack and most have one or two attacks at most. Their attacks a clearly telegraphed, which is good, and during an attack they're uninterruptible. All enemies can be launched and combo'd in the air and prior to being attack frames they're staggered by all attacks. Elites, mini-bosses, are a bit more interesting and have more complete movesets. They're still nothing really too interesting but they're fine. The bosses are about the same for me. There's a total of four bosses and of the four only Skull Knight fight 1 and fight 2 are the best the game offers, especially fight 2. The other two are just fine, Lava Golem is more enjoyable than the Orc boss to me.

I would like to see more enemy diversity in the game and for enemies to have more attacks they can do.

Sound: 
I'm not gonna lie the music is fucking mediocre. I think this is first game I've ever turned off the music to and played my own in the background. The sound effects are fine, nothing special. I don't have much else to say

Visuals: 
They're serviceable. Graphics are nothing impressive and the environmental design is uninteresting. The design of the playable characters I find really cool, enemies however are also just serviceable. 

Think that covers all of my thoughts about the game. It's a very mediocre game but for what it is and the price point I think it's worth the money. I got my time out of it and enjoy the games combat enough to keep playing. I hope the devs keep putting time and effort into and continues to work on this game.
fun hack and slash mechanics that are fun to learn
