Awakener: Forgotten Oath is a 3d rogue-like dungeon stormer. Calling it a diamond in the rough would be an overstatement, unfortunately. 
My play time is low, but I feel confident in my assessment enough to even forego formatting my text.

Currently, the game feels like a 0.5 Early Access release - though the game's 1.0 launch was just over a month ago. This game has a strong, solid foundation to build upon but it falls completely short. It's as if the developer's finally got through to the meat and decided they were full. Shortly after launching the game a vague tutorial message displays about changing your class. Then you notice the two other NPC's nearby, both adorning a warrior's gear set, and realize that's what it's referring to.
Unless one of them is just holding their sword for a friend, I wouldn't consider growing a chest and longer hair a class change. That's something else entirely.

The grammar and spelling in the game resembles something created by a pre-teen and didn't give the impression of it just being a language barrier issue, The game had a rocky development spiral and what should have been a grand, open-world souls-like adventure turned into a boring rogue-like that anyone who mains Garen could clear on their first try.

At best, I'd say this is a $5 moblie game, but most phones couldn't run it. On the lowest settings this put a heavy demand on my Lenovo Legion 5 pro, more than any game I've ever played. When my temps reached 90c, I turned it off and refunded the game.

New update made many systems that worked perfectly fine, worse when nobody asked for it. At current state I don't recommend. 
Also new update removed my old save game and I have to start from scratch if I want to beat the game again and unlock the other characters :).
This game is enough to fulfill my hack and slash urges.

This game is pretty fun so far and for the price it's fantastic. One tip, not sure if it was mentioned in the tutorial and I skipped it or what, but your primary attack combo has at least two options. At least it does for the dual blade character, haven't tried it on the others yet but I noticed I did a weird backflip kick that I hadn't seen before and eventually found out it was from waiting to continue the combo after you see a white flash at the end of the animation for your first attack. Try messing around with different attack timings and throwing in your launch and dash attacks at different points in your combo, you may find some cool combos you didn't know you could do. If you like parries, the starting character is built for it. Every time you perfect block with the sword and shield guy you get 4 options for a counter attack and they're all pretty sick imo. I'm excited to see how this game evolves and hopefully we'll get some more characters down the line.

I think The Awakener has a cool aesthetic of something more like Dark Souls and combat mechanics like Black Desert with a good parry system for the most part it does have some flaws and some ways the developers could improve the game!

Main Nice Things ( Much more rushed as I started on the flaws and it was a little late )

1. The combo-ing your character can do is very very fun to as it can be awesome to make a build that heals and does massive damage at the same time but the flaw about this mechanic is that it can turn into a game of smashing one key over and over as with no upgrades I got to the end by just mashing Q but an idea that could help is more emphasis on some upgrades you've already implemented like doing an upward slash skills makes you do more damage but maybe you implement skills which proc new stuff after you do different skills instead of spamming Q.

2. The Gods within the skills are a cool mechanic when having multiple gods you can gain skills that proc chain attacks or benefit one another but something that can boost this is taking some influence from Hades and adding Duo God Skills or when having multiple Igni skills for example you gain an option to obtain a legendary skill in the card hands.

3. (Idea) This isn't a feature I see being utilized as much as it should be but the addition to card hands should be a rework to picking your abilities, like in a game called Deepwoken where when you get your abilities you can freeze or burn your cards allowing you to either get the same card next card roll - Freeze or banishing the card forever - Burn instead of implementing a reroll.

4. (Idea I thought of just to add some cool features) Variations to the heroes to play slightly differently and add more replayability but the idea is that you keep the move-sets but tweak the character where instead of the characters like Warrior being an all-around character, it could rely more on crits while being much weaker where when paired with elements like wind and no attunement you could do lots of damage.

Main Flaws & Advice

1. I think implementing invulnerability frames during a rag-doll from an attack could be good because of the way the combat flows, it's not a game where you are allowed to make a lot of mistakes and you aren't extremely tanky so when being rag-dolled the main problem is being chained into another attack, mainly seen when in boss fights, this might be skill issue but there were times when I get hit at 40 HP so about -20 HP but I get rag-dolled causing me to lose 40 HP instead.

2. This flaw is another problem mainly seen with bosses and elites that have follow-up attacks, when they do attacks and you're up close attacking them and they have one of these multi-hit attacks, the second hit is not as visible with camera not being able to capture the full hit without you having to look away for that short amount of time which would've been when you parried, which also can be easily fixed with two ideas off the top of my head being the implementation of either a quiet sound queue to indicate parrying while keeping your eyes on the enemy or the addition of follow-up attacks to be a bit more visible either a larger size/brighter parry indicator.

3. This one isn't a flaw but more of a nitpick but I think the addition of clicking to continue people talking and any parts of the game where you would need to press space.

4. (This isn't a flaw but the game is promising so I wanted to say this) With my past experiences with Rogue-Like games I think the ones most popular are not the ones with a few classes and the classic upgrade system being the main progression but ones where there is more depth to the game like quests and NPCs you can find, stuff that draws the player, for example, an alternative upgrade system which maybe upgrades the hub in a way where you could start with an item or two like in Dead Cells, or implementation of smaller game modes like boss rushes, my point is that the game has potential but all yall need is the hook for people to stay after beating this game because what you have right now isn't going to cut it.

5. Please add a bit more room variation as during the game it can end up feeling like you are playing the same run over and over again through the same rooms, not a lot to be said about this but more variety would be good!

Right now the game is cool but I would be iffy about recommending it to someone who isn't as avid about roguelikes as it is a bit barebones, the developers do seem keen on trying to make the game as good as they can so I think people should still support the game and see where the game ends up hopefully the game has a good run. Hopefully, some of this review is constructive to the developers and can help! :)

When they said "Through Time," the creator wasn't kidding, because getting the achievement called "Game Duration" that stated the game needs to stay online for 360 minutes (3 hours), but felt like 6 hours or less in real life instead. Also, BEFORE YOU START THE GAME BY ANYTHING (no matter what language it's on), make sure you hit the the keyboard "K+C" to help finish the game with an update. Because if you don't do this, you'll be playing the game with 5 stories & only 5 puzzles (Didn't do this), rather than 10 stories & 50 puzzles (After Doing This). Yeah, VERY BIG DIFFERENCE, I had to learn that the hard way at first, but hey, I guess that's what makes us game players, right? Anyways, if you enjoy the simple types of puzzle solving games, it's truly worth it, it's free of charge, & it's fun to play. Happy Puzzle Solving!

Solid fun game, with some tricky platforming and fun exploration. Finding secrets, extra power ups was really the best part of the game for me and finding new pieces of lore. The combat might be the weakest link here, unfortunately some enemies only seemed to be able to attack me me once then they just stood there and we hugged each other, I think a few tweaks could make the combat solid. Personally I would have liked to see a bit faster Stamina regen allowing me to stay in combat constantly instead of having to go in and out of combat. And allowing me to roll behind enemies would also give the player more strategy during combat, but maybe this would be OP?

Personally I would have liked checkpoints, or going of the edge not killing you (pretty fun that it killed the enemies as well). But I can definitely see this being what people are looking for. More in the vane of jump king, where if you die you go back all the way to the beginning  and I respect that vision for the game. 

There seemed to be a lot of lore pieces that built up the world around you and then there we're others that in the same swoop also told a short story. Sometimes it was about the boss right before you faced them, or it was a thief stealing money.

In the end, the game i worth the money if you like difficult games with punishing platforming and fun exploration!

PS. super cute doggo dev art <3

This is the Flappy Bird of soulslike platformers.

It's a little rough around the edges. But the difficult platforming, unforgiving deaths, and unexpectedly immersive lore create a very addicting experience!

I quite like it and I see a lot of potential in this game. It is much appreciated how smooth it feels for how new it is. For I find that new, especially indie games seem to be very rough around the edges. There are two things that i feel would make the game a lot more convenient to play. One thing being the ability to hold on to the edge of cliffs and pull yourself up. The other being adding a save at the end of each boss fight. Other than that, keep up the good work Jubei!

I can't get past a boss, but the game is still really fun. I absolutely love the platforming. There's no checkpoints from what I can see which can be annoying from time to time. I'd recommend it if u have nothing else do like me and just want to mess around.

I found this game through posts on r/BisexualTeens and I was hooked immediately, it is a very cool concept, and I really liked the gameplay, however, when you die on Level 2, there aren't exactly checkpoints and you just start over, I am fine with this, as I can just get back, but it's still a tad bit annoying, I will play more later and update my review, though!
Its a cute and nice game, Its fun to figure out, although its a bit frustating at points. But all in all a nice game and an intresting challenge to firgure out :)

I would say the top review summed things up pretty well, but to reiterate:

This is a cool game. The things that stand out to me the most are the pixel art (really quite beautiful) and the soundtrack, and of course the fact that this was made by a single high school student! The platforming is decent, and so is the combat, although getting hit by enemies doesn't have much weight behind it, so its hard to tell if you've taken damage unless you're constantly looking at your health. I would say the combat is the weakest part of the design here. I would love to go more in-depth, but unfortunately this game did not run very well on my laptop, so I could not really play very much of it. But for just 99 cents, this is worth checking out!
Pretty cool for a first game. If you're into Soulslikes and pixel art platformers give it a try.

[h1]I WAS SOOOO BORED[/h1]
I love searching games like Hidden Cats in Town and the Find All series, so I bought this game as soon as it was released. It looked bright and colorful and claimed to be geared toward animal lovers.
¬†
Those colorful graphics that caught my eye quickly lost their curb appeal because there were only a few different scenes that were repetitively used by cropping different sections of the same overall scene.¬†
¬†
You are tasked with finding 3-5 clipart objects, such as 5 Trumpets, 3 Unicorns, 3 Bulldogs, or 5 Blue Balloons. Some of the levels are covered with nothing but childish stickers like Unicorns and Rainbows.¬†¬†
¬†
As you find an object, you have to sit there and watch a giant hand circle the item with a giant piece of chalk before continuing your search while listening to canned laughter & clapping. You are rewarded with new Crayons, Markers, and Chalk to circle these objects on the next level...oh goodie!
¬†
I'm not sure who the targeted audience is here. Some of the scenes are crammed full of older adults at a concert or dog park, certainly not appealing to a younger audience. The next scene may be a collage of clipart dogs and bones or the before-mentioned Unicorn & Rainbow stickers, which are certainly not appealing to adults. Hmmm???
¬†
The most annoying feature in this game is constantly having to hear a "Dong" and seeing a giant Red X appear on the screen every time you hold the mouse to drag the scene around as you search for the items. You literally have to make a conscious decision as to where you place the mouse before clicking and dragging the scene around; otherwise, the game thinks you are making a wrong selection.
¬†
I made it through 16 levels before calling it quits, so it's not like I didn't hang around to give it a chance to improve. That says a lot because I am really OCD about completing games I started, especially when I haven't earned all my achievements...sorry devs, I think it needs to be more appealing to either adults or children; right now, I don't think either will be impressed.
¬†
Check out my Group/Curator page¬† at¬†https://steamcommunity.com/groups/thewoodsforum
and don't forget to stop by my nature-themed chat forum at¬†https://thewoodsforum.boards.net/

I've played a large number of hidden object games (150+) and overall this one felt fairly average. Sometimes the objects were a little on the easy side, but others blended in quite well with the background and took a bit of hunting. 

A number of the scenes were repeated for a second level, but spaced out far enough it didn't really matter. The art style seemed to vary a lot between levels making it feel a bit disjointedness at times. And there was an annoying trumpet sound which would play at the end of each section despite the fact sound was disabled via the menu. 

It's certainly not the best hidden object game out there, and perhaps felt a bit overpriced. But if you are a fan of the genre and want to add it to your collection, it's perfectly fine.

This vehicle is marketed as the in-game equivalent of a License Plate Reader (LPR). In real life, an LPR reads license plates and will alert an officer if the vehicle comes back stolen, the owner has a warrant, the insurance/registration is invalid, etc. In game, however, all it does is alert you (after following a vehicle) if the driver didn't use a turn signal, has a loud engine, has tinted windows, ran a stop sign, etc. All of these are observable violations that you can see by UI pop-ups automatically or if you use the "focus" button in-game. There really is no reason to buy this DLC unless you hate holding down mouse-click to see a pop-up if a vehicle is committing a violation.

What I thought this DLC was, was a vehicle that would automatically see information about a vehicle/driver that you could only see if you opened the police computer AFTER focusing on a vehicle (open warrant, no valid insurance, expired ID, stolen vehicle, etc). There is literally no reason to spend money on this when you can use the focus UI and see this information unless you really hate all the extra effort that comes with holding down left-click and looking at a vehicle.
A fun DLC. It adds a cool new car with new engine sounds and more options for vehicle related traffic enforcement. Overall I recommend this DLC if you have a few bucks and want a cool car.

This DLC is a must-have if you ask me. This car functions like the standard police car, but has a scanner on the roof. This scanner is extremely handy for scanning any violations of the car in front of you. I use this car as my main patrol car from now on, it is so good.

Would absolutely recommend this one, is my favorite car so far. The handling on it is pretty good, ELS package on it is nice, is quite quick and nimble, overall feels very good to drive. The observation scanner make it the best car to take out if you like driving around pulling people over.

Also helped a lot getting the "Don't ever Drink and Drive" achievement. If that's something you are still missing definitely consider picking this one up.

I expected this to scan for ALL violations including invalid ID, Open warrant, and stolen vehicle which was the reason I bought it so I didn't have to stop and then look at the computer. DO NOT buy this if this is also what you were expecting

A really good purchase you can make! This vehicle is amazing for those who want to experience simulation gameplay but still have the helping hand of identifying vehicle issues. (obviously you tend to know how to pickup on most things by that time but it's still a very neat feature.)

Its a cool vehicle DLC, the vehicle gives you notifications if a NPV committed a traffic violation. Its more of an extra vehicle and not an essential vehicle to carry out your duties as a police officer in PS:PO. I recommend this vehicle DLC.
One of my favorite vehicles in terms of Looks and convenient function/ handling

This is my current favorite vehicle to use in game. I love that it can ping cars and mark them as:
DUI suspicious
Red Light Runner
No Turn Signal
Wanted
Expired Plates
And a few others that currently slip my ageing mind!
Don't worry if you want all the skins the devs will soon release another paid dlc for this car that you can then unlock all the skins with for another small price
Do not buy this! I did not revive the car but nothing then a badge do not buy its a scam!!
Great car

Seems much more detailed than the other vehicles that have been added so far. The lights on this car are great and i don't just meant the emergency lights. The headlight, taillight and brake lights are very visible unlike in most of the other DLC vehicles. I quite like it.

Some people don't like the design and think it is ugly, I think the design is great. It drives and handles well and the info sign on the top is helpful if you need to stop traffic for an accident, the Do Not Pass is the main one I use to stop all traffic from driving on my side of the road while I'm out on foot at an accident, But keeping the flow of traffic in the other direction going. I'm looking forward to using it when the highway expansion comes out, making it safer to sort out accidents on the highway.
Don't worry if you want all the skins the devs will soon release another paid dlc for this car that you can then unlock all the skins with for another small price

This game is proper good n' all i'm going to be real. But of course, aside from its good aspects I only made this just to note the cons of the game, hoping someone who works on the game sees this and takes this into mind.

Anyways, there are very few issues but these are major ones for me, I'll only state these in quick advance. The game is unneccessarily laggy on Carnage & Spoilance, I dunno why, I tried lowering the resolution, nothing helps. Another big issue for me, is when I die and i go back to the menu, the whole game freezes and breaks. I have no idea whats causing this, and I hope someone can bring this to attention. bit of a learning curve but when you get past it this game is incredible. i cant wait for the full release and im really hoping there will be large scale battles with 100 men on each team. i think that would be epic. although i do think that the weapons in the demo work better than in the playtest, idk if you guys changed anything about it but it felt weird to me. still tho, great game.

Saying I'm impressed would be an understatement.

Half Sword's demo already has one of the best gore system I've ever seen in a video game. There are so many choppable pieces, if you slice a guy's stomach his intestines fall out, a scythe can slice a dude in half with one swoop. Your weapon might get stuck in some guy's body if it has a long sharp end. The AI reactivity is also insane, the enemies react to the strikes and blows they receive so realistically. You slice a guys throat and he holds the area as he slowly falls down, a guy missing an arm crawls on the ground using only one arm while scaredly looking back at you. 

The playtest version sadly doesn't have the gore and blood enabled because it's a test version for cons. The arena mode is a cool idea, but I have mixed feelings about the full plate armor. It's almost impossible to kill someone who has it on, the player included. If I have it on and I fall down, instead of dying I just get stuck as the enemy keeps on attacking me infinitely without being able to kill me. Trying to kill other enemies on the ground in plate armor is also impossible, I continue slashing or smashing them all over the place but nothing happens. There should be some big weak points in the armor, or it should get significantly nerfed overall.

My main issue with this playtest as of now is it feels like the npcs were given much better control of themselves than the player making the game feel overall balanced against you. The demo felt a lot better when it game to player control.

Very Fun Historical Fencing game. The attention to the arms and armor are really good. As this game strives to be 1430-1480 Central Europe. This games combat is very good, some weapons kinda need some work but other than that I think it's fantastic. the voice, lines the music, The Ui Really makes this game feel unique to other medieval games as it has a really perfect art style for a game like this, furthermore The gore not being on the game does hold some things back but that doesn't really matter since its coming on the 0.4 update. [As they are showcasing it to the tokyo game show] Andd that's it. I love what you guys are doing and I hope the best. I will thoroughly look forward to your game.

Combat feels better than the demo, it is a great amount of fun. Switching between thrust mode and slash mode is really smooth, and overall the combat feels pretty good. 

Dying and returning to the main menu crashes my game which might be a 'me' issue, some characters in various tiers straight up crash the game. Returning to the main menu at all crashes the game, which means anytime I want to switch my loadout I have to restart the game. 

Overall, I am impressed with the development so far. I'm really excited to see how you guys keep developing the game and fleshing it out. Despite the bugs, the core gameplay is really fun and satisfying. I can already see myself sinking many hours into the game once it releases.

The playtest is amazing and I have not experienced any bugs so far. If the playtest is this great then I can't wait for the full release or early access.

it may say only 78 minutes but i played the demo for 10 hours today, 10/10 would recommend. it definitly  need work, but it is still in very early early beta. but i think this game has great bones and im excited to see where the devs take it. 100% will be buying the full game when it release. its simple but so much fun

Great game, one of the most innovative games I have ever played, graphics are great and fit perfectly with your surroundings, some things they need to fix is this clipping, sometimes if your fighting someone your sword will kind of clip through their armor, which kind of makes it unsatisfying, but other then that the game is great and never gets old for the most part, the difference from the playtest and the demo is insane, I thought the game would be just like the demo. But just knowing the idea that this game will have a story, and a working prestige system makes me want to buy it.

It is an awesome game, I wish there was gore and blood like the experemental version but it an all around awesome and fun game. This shows a LOT of potential. Between the variety of weapons and armor, the mouse-controlled combat and the impressive body physics, this is teetering on the edge of a combat simulation compared to a game. I can't wait for the full release with the added blood and gore shown in the demo.

The demo was better and funner the playtest, you can't seem to hit anyone at all, idk i prefer the demo. Also playtest has a glitch where when you start a round it says you lost and asks you to play another round but you can't since you're still in it.
Absolutely love this. Takes some adjusting to the mouse controls but so much fun even when swinging wildly. Can't wait to see further progress!

Very great game so far! I would like to report that I have had two rounds so far where I lost on the same exact frame I loaded in, before an enemy had even started walking towards me. But that has been my only problem so far, keep up the great work!

The game is a perfect and fun mix of hard and easy, and I do know that it requires some more work, but everything about the game: the graphics, the cloth physics, the ragdoll physics, and every aspect is great.

Half sword is a medieval PVE game that covers just about everything you`d expect in a game like this. what i personaly like is the  physics because of how realistic it is sometimes.There are some minor bugs i would like to address,When you start a match i noticed in the first second of it when you load in your character is unable to move while the enemy can.Minor bug but still slightly annoying. Clipping, The game clips alot whether its the weapon bugging out in the enemy or just trying to pick it up it just starts flying around alot. i have also noticed that it sometimes lauches the enemy and maybe even the player( in the demo also). But this is still a fun game and adds a wacky feel to it. The graphics arent the best but still very good and its not what you might get out of most games for being so early in development. I love this game  i look forward into hopefully helping the creation of this game ( i have like 20 hours in the game rn)
Love the gameplay, and all of the preset classes. didn't notice any bugs or anything

Half Sword is GREAT so far! The game is essentially the next step towards full immersion in medieval fighting games, ahead of Kingdom Come: Deliverance (KDC). Combat took me about 5 minutes to adjust to, and even then it was a challenge. I appreciate the stamina system and simultaneous lack of health/energy indicators. I also love how some fights are over in seconds, and others can drag on for minutes. 
One thing the game lacks is clarification on how to stab, switch weapons, and get up. I think I figured these out after 15 minutes or so, but I'm not sure if I'm just leveraging the physics system to accomplish this or actually pressing the right command key. 
A scoring system would be pretty neat too, tracking streaks of wins (again, thinking of KCD's arena system). 
Overall, amazing demo. I'll keep playing until the full version comes out! Thank you, devs!!!

Really fun, and brutal. Even without the blood headshots with bludgeons and swords is extremely brutal. My favorite weapon is the Goedendag, which is just a gigantic stick with spikes at the end. But can snag onto an opponent and ensnare them with spikes as they struggle. I've gotten much better with other weapons, like the spear, sword, and blunt. I can't wait for this game to come out, can only imagine what work in progress sections are gonna be like.

Sometimes I find myself in the wrong place. Life can be long and grueling. You can strike yourself against the flint and hope to make fire, but it doesn't always work. 

Life can be funny like that. There's times I enjoy being myself and sometimes I feel like I'm in the wrong place. Like I've made a wrong landing. 

Self love is the most challenging game of survival.

It's not awful, I can clearly see the influence of the Forest and similar games. Its kind of wonky and confusing, and I managed to get trapped behind invisible walls a few times, But a free game with achievements is alright in my book.

And to make this so young is pretty impressive, its more than I could do even now. Its a good start, you gotta keep up the work!

cool game!! the puzzles are awesome, the background music is great :D love the simple mechanic of the platform gun
It's a neat little game with really cool mechanics. The graphics are terrible, sure, but the core mechanics are fun.

interesting. from the title, i was expecting a platformer, but this is more like a stealth 2d shooter. also, based on the cutscene at the beginning, i was expecting more of a story. the platform gun is almost really fun but the jankyness of the platforms definitely detracts from that. also i wish that the platforms sped up more slowly or at least had a lower max speed because it definitely goes too fast. i had to restart the game because i wanted the achievement for beating the boss under 45 seconds there is no way to restart the boss fight after you beat it. i wish the money system was more interesting, enemies drop pitiful amounts of money and the best way to get it is to reenter a room you've already beaten because the money respawns but the enemies dont. but you dont even need money because armor pickups also respawn. when i first saw a vending machine, it caught my interest, but they ended up being pretty boring. overall, the game could be better certainly.

A fairly good concept that‚Äôs pretty well executed. The ride and speeding up bullets mechanic is used in a lot of different ways. There are a couple balance issues though, the health stations take needlessly long to recharge, the turrets kill you way too quick and the room with the acid floor is way too punishing. Overall, it's a fairly solid game.

The movement is really fun, it's a bit rough around the edges with the puzzles being more about remember a network of gates and batteries (timed buttons) rather than solving an actual puzzle and the mechanics and level design can be improved (you sometimes fall through platforms for seemingly no reason, very steep ones are especially buggy and some spot are really awkward where you need just a bit more than a full jump height of vertical movement) but the concept has a lot of potential and leaves you wanting more.

I was initially interested in this VN because of the gorgeous artwork, seemingly high production values, and the promise of a historical horror story based on a Japanese urban legend. I was especially interested since the artist from the popular Nekopara series, Sayori, woked on this project, and I thought it‚Äôd be fun to see her produce a story with themes more mature than ‚Äòcute catgirls want to go on cute dates with their master‚Äô.

Well, as another reviewer astutely pointed out, this visual novel is a very different beast from Nekopara, but I don't necessarily think that's a good thing‚Ä¶

Though this is a negative review, my first impressions of this VN were actually pretty favourable. The art, as you can tell from the screenshots, are gorgeous, the OST is very atmospheric, and the story does a good job grabbing your attention. The story moves at a pretty fast clip, and every scene felt streamlined.

The main meat (ha, ha) of this story is set on a relatively isolated Japanese island that‚Äôs ruled by seven important houses. The heads of these houses are involved in a power struggle, and several of the houses hope to usurp the others to gain more land and more money. We‚Äôre introduced to the heads of these houses and their relatives in a rapidfire way near the very start, which does a great job at setting the stage and building intrigue.

The real stars of this VN, however, are the main couple, Kurou and Kyouko. Kurou is a relative outsider, being raised as an inhuman killing machine by the mysterious mistress of the ostracised eighth house on the island, while Kyouko is a demure maiden from the ruling house who has been betrothed to Kurou.

Though their marriage is an arranged one, Kyouko falls for Kurou instantly. She spends the early portion of the story fawning over her hubby-to-be and trying to make him return her feelings: something Kurou is (initially) bemused about.

It's sweet watching Kyouko awkwardly flirting with Kurou until he eventually warms up to her. It's a classic case of opposites attract, and I liked seeing a male lead in a visual novel going through some actual character growth. A lot of male MCs in VNs are pretty bland and one-note, but Kurou actually has a personality (and a sprite... and a voice!), and he has a fun dynamic with Kyouko.

The writing does suffer a bit in the first half by being a bit too 'nukige-coded' (Kyouko is really insistent about making babies with Kurou, and some of her attempts to seduce him are over the top enough to be eyeroll-worthy), but this seemed like a pretty minor nitpick when I liked everything else well enough.

Then, the story jumpcuts to Kyouko and Kurou's wedding day, and the story collapses in on itself.

The rest of this review is pretty spoilery, so I'll hide it. The spoilers contain some discussion of dark topics like rape and abuse, so only check out the spoilers if you're alright with reading about such topics.

[spoiler]All of the development between Kyouko and Kurou, and all of the ominous build-up with the seven families, is thrown out of the window as the story takes a hard swerve into being a torture porn revenge fantasy, where Kyouko and Kurou work together to murder all the important men on the island, and rape and murder all of the important women after Kyouko was humiliated and abused by them on her wedding day.

Kyouko encourages Kurou to greater and greater heights of depravity, taking orgasmic glee in her partner violating every named female character he encounters. I thought Kyouko‚Äôs tendency to talk in nukige-isms was off-putting in the first half of the story, but in the latter half, she has long speeches where she tries to encourage her hubby to rape and murder literal children to avenge her. Kurou, meanwhile, is content enough to go along with Kyouko‚Äôs insane decisions because he‚Äôs decided he loves her: thus, the batshittery commences.

I tried to slog through the latter half of this story, since the initial set-up was interesting enough I wanted to see how it ended, but I had to dip out after getting to a particularly nasty scene where an abused housewife is repeatedly kicked and punched in the stomach by her husband (complete with a lovingly detailed illustration showcasing all of her bruises), until she's rescued by Kurou, who murders her husband‚Ä¶

And then proceeds to rape her, while Kyouko feeds her bits of little sister, who was also raped and murdered in an earlier scene. Inexplicably, the abused housewife gets off on cannibalising her little sister, which results in A+++ dialogue to the tune of, ‚ÄúOoh, I‚Äôm eating my little sister‚Äôs meat‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm eating my little sister‚Äôs meat while taking your man meat‚Ä¶ This is so hot, I‚Äôm so turned on, ooooooooooh‚Äù (insert hentai moaning noises here).

This would be Pretty Extreme as it is, but (as if THAT WASN‚ÄôT ENOUGH), the housewife‚Äôs adopted son and daughter are watching this Utter Insanity unfold ‚Äì and of course, the son gets aroused by this, then starts entertaining thoughts of raping his sister, because why not??? Who even knows. At this point, I started to feel like the writer was just throwing darts on a board with various messed up fetishes on it, in an attempt to come up with the most deranged sex scenes they could.

A lot of the supposedly 'dark' scenes in this VN are so out there I don't think they work as being properly horrific; they read as being unnecessarily edgy. The story might revel in dark content, but all feels gratuitious and porny, and the sex scenes slow the pacing down an agonising crawl where Nothing Happens for hours at a time. It's dire.

I feel like this review might encourage people to pick this VN up to see how off the rails it goes, but I can't recommend that you do that. A lot of the content in this visual novel is genuinely disgusting, and I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs worth paying for this game if you think it would upset you. I'm not particularly fond of guro myself, and if I'd realised what sort of story this was before buying it, I probably wouldn't have spent any money on it. I realise this will bias my opinion somewhat, as I'm predisposed to disliking this sort of content, but I've read some VNs which featured dark and gory scenes which still managed to have interesting stories and characters which made up for my discomfort. This story is so extreme, however, I doubt there'll be any salvaging it in my eyes, regardless of how it wraps up.[/spoiler]

TLDR; If you want to read about anime women being abused in increasingly ridiculous, nonsensical ways, maybe you‚Äôll like this, but be warned: you have to sit through about 6-8 hours of this VN masquerading as an interesting story before getting to your torture porn.

Final edit: Looking at the mixed reviews, it‚Äôs pretty obnoxious how people downvote an indie game just because it‚Äôs not their type of genre. Getting upset over the edgy or extreme content in a guro game is like being mad at the gratuitous violence in Elden Ring or Diablo. And if you think the story goes "off the rails" (like the current top review says), that just means you weren‚Äôt paying attention to the first half. You didn‚Äôt take it seriously when the characters showed their inhumane sides early on. This is a tale of very bad, broken people doing very bad things to other very bad, broken people, because life threw them curveballs. Don't expect a story about heroes here.

edit: Jesus, this is hardcore... definitely not for the faint of heart.

Nekopara‚Äôs sister company really dropped a banger with this one. This is what a horror visual novel should be. The story beats are incredibly satisfying, with twists and turns you won‚Äôt see coming. There are no choices, but there are "routes" and multiple heroines... just go in blind, and you‚Äôll get what I mean.

It delivers on the trailer. If the trailer grabs you, don‚Äôt hesitate to get this game, it‚Äôs worth full price. Make sure to get the Steam patch or buy the uncensored version elsewhere‚ÄîI can‚Äôt imagine playing a censored horror game (thanks for nothing, Steam). Ignore my playtime; I originally bought this from a different uncensored store. I only got it on Steam because I liked it so much that I wanted to support the developer and leave a positive review. My only complaint is the somewhat slow start; some of that could‚Äôve been trimmed. Strong recommend, 8/10.

You've heard all about the gory details. Granted, that's the majority of the game that others have already talked about, but there are also more aspects to it. When not showing scenarios of spine-crushing and disembowelment, [i]Nie no Hakoniwa[/i] details a story centered on politics, corruption, depravity, and the primal descent into dark instincts. Each character is a caricature with insanity levels dialed by 999x. When progressing through the story, you might be able to point out qualities of characters that exist in reality.

The character and art style is exquisite and the sound design is immersive. The BGM is based on traditional Japanese music which evokes a sense of tranquility in peaceful moments and an atmosphere of foreboding during tense moments. All of the voice acting is *chef's kiss*, with special acknowledgment to the protagonist's seiyuu, Yotsuba You, for his outstanding performance. 

The world of Nie no Hakoniwa is set in a time period wherein women were marginalized, a theme present in 95% of the plot. It's a realm of political intrigue, where leaders are consistently racing to have the upper hand. The treatment of women during this era is disheartening. The young Kyouko's monologue, in particular, resonates deeply, illustrating her dehumanization within her own family.

Character development may seem minimal, with characters exhibiting linear growth, but their established personalities and conversations are really what make them bounce off each other to propel the story forward. The characters' backstories just make their personalities make sense. Others make you cry and feel for them while others display such vile behaviour that you just want them to disappear. Others will leave you scratching your head in confusion while others will make you nod in contemplation.

Regarding replay value, unless you're keen on uncovering missed hints or analyzing subtle details, the game may not offer much incentive for multiple playthroughs. If you're a big fan of psychoanalyzing almost anything, then you're in for a treat.

This game is first and foremost a horror visual novel, exploring a myriad of body horror elements. Mutilation, cannibalism... It's not for the faint of heart, so caution is advised. However, I will say, it's not the worst thing you can see. There are a whole lot of other VNs that show worse things. The violent and gory scenes from a horror perspective are only there to provide shock factor. Compared to other VN titles, I consider Nie no Hakoniwa as one of the weakest or tamest in the genre. 
If you are looking for the "other type" of content, then I'd like to caution you that there is only a small portion of wholesome vanilla scenes and those pretty much only involve the protagonist's wife, Kyouko-- who is the best girl. 

The best part of this visual novel for me (and why I played through this visual novel in the first place) is the relationship between Yasaka Kurou and Shiki Kyouko. They seemingly mesh well with each other and complement each other. They both hold extreme devotion to each other and only each other. Despite being incomplete beings, together, they are one unit. In insanity and brokenness. 

But what made Nie no Hakoniwa - Nie no Hakoniwa, is the tragedy and realization that no matter what type of love you act on, sometimes the consequences and actions you do aren't always in your love's best interests.

In summary, Nie no Hakoniwa delves into the deep ugly facets of human nature as well as displays that even the most beautiful of emotions, "Love", can turn into something that creates and yet deforms society and the self.

Okay, I'm having a hard time collecting my thoughts. I haven't finished the game yet, I don't even know where I am at, but the game has started to become what it should be.

First of all, I'm playing with the DLC and no matter how it sounds, I recommend playing with it, despite the shocking erotic scenes. After all, it's eroguro. I would compare playing with DLC to playing Saya no Uta with 18+ patch too, where erotic scenes play some "important role" in the overall plot, even if they seem unnecessary.

At first I was a bit bored. Kyouko (whom I only started liking after [spoiler] her "death" [although she's still a bit annoying] [/spoiler] ) was incredibly irritating, but Nozomi pissed me off even more...

No matter how you look at it, this game is a guro game, so obviously ""a bit"" grotesque, but I think that if someone has done minimal research, they won't be traumatized by the gameplay. It's not an extremely shocking game, but it may shock people who bought it just because it has nice graphics.

The game (with DLC) contains scenes of grape and murder etc. I think that a large part of the audience are just perverts who want to relieve themselves with a game that includes murder and erotic scenes at the same time........, but everytime I play it I'm trying to take my mind off it and look at the game a bit more psychologically. After all, games of this type are supposed to outrage and disgust us, right? If anyone is new to this genre - this game nails it! For people who have played similar games before, it may seem just... Kinda edgy. Because you know, for example [spoiler] woman spasms with pleasure when a guy crushes her lungs...?  [/spoiler] Like get some help. Nevertheless, history is worth such excesses. I guess...

I can't give a full rating yet because I haven't finished the game and I still have some left, but to sum up - it's not a game for everyone of course, although it is interesting game. It has a lot of boring moments, but when [spoiler] Kurou returns to Kyouko [/spoiler] game finally starts to be dynamic and more shocking. 

It cannot be ignored that it is mainly based on violence against women, so if you are a woman - it may shock you even more, which is at the same time a huge advantage of the game (because after all, games of this type are supposed to do that...), but also a disadvantage (because it is simply sad and distasteful). Sometimes I felt really bad (as a woman) because of the way the story described how women want to be humiliated... I wouldn't call it a horror though, it's just gore meant to disgust us. And excite sick people. That's it.

After finishing this game I have a lot of thoughts running trough my mind. 
First I need to say I sticked to the sfw-Version of Steam without purchasing the 18+ DLC, but I was aware of the Rape contend the DLC contains. On that note I just want to say this game would have been great if it had been a sole gory revenge plot. I don't regret sticking to the sfw version even if you need to pay attention and read a lot between the lines, or else there are major story holes. I wished they would have edited the sfw Version at least so that you get a gruesome death scene as an alternative to the "original" scenes that are cutted. 
So...you may ask yourself why I don't give it a negative review then. Simple.
Despite all that, the Artwork is gorgeous and was what drew my attention in the first place. The voiceacting is pretty great as well - even if everyone is kinda allready beyond saving on that Island. 
Overall the Game has a lot of interesting points that keept my Interest on a high level, it didn't get boring as the story progressed. 
Here is a big "but" - there is a lot of sensible content even in the sfw Version, such as canibalism, violation, abuse, human trafficking, gore and so on. So if you are triggered by/ or sensible to some Themes please look up the CW for this game. 

If you want my honest opinion? Stick to the sfw Version instead of the nsfw one, that only gives you a major Ick (and ruins the characters)

You've probably read this review a few times.

Great story that devolves in to straight up torture porn that completely defeats and destroys any meaningful buildup from the first half of the story.. Any care or empathy you felt towards any character, even the main protagonist just disappears, I couldn't finish it, the main character just devolves in to a one dimensional being despite having some nice development to get you interested in to the first half.

Don't buy it, it's not worth the money.

Shits all over nekopara, genuinely one of the best vns Sekai/Denpa have ever localised, translation was excellent guro was delicious, sex was intense. Genuinely this game is incredible if you can handle the content. 1 thing tho there's a really bad bug with this that will wipe your gallery after finishing the game if you restart. apart from that tho 9/10

While going in i knew this was not going to flowers and sunshines i can def say i did not expect the story to take this turn....
Errr yeah! Art, music and presentation is amazing so far but def can't recommend if you're easily unsettled...

From the sister brand of NEKO WORKs, creator of Nekopara, comes a VN masterpiece by Sayori that leaves all the innocence of her previous works at the front door. 

The supernatural aspect, while being the main driving force for the events of the game, takes a backseat to a Romance/Revenge story ultimately about how far one will go to bring happiness and peace of mind to their loved ones after their sense of worth has been stolen from them, and how desperate others are to intervene in those attempts purely for their own satisfaction.

"Oh yes, there will be blood." I would highly recommend you stay away from this title if you can not deal with themes of Blood/Gore, Sexual Assault/Rape, and other intense themes.

This game is incredibly based, especially towards the female characters. I laughed hard at a lot of the remarks some of the characters were making, they do not pull punches based on what was the social norm back then in Japan. The game itself will gate-keep the tourists fortunately.

My only minor complaint is that the game's dialogue leans toward Nukige quality at times, I was expecting more in the writing. The heroines so far are constantly horny as soon as they're introduced to the point of being a bit annoying. For example, the love interest in the first part will tell the MC that she wants to get preggo, usually in detail.

Overall, solid game you will enjoy if you like horror/gore.

Edit:
I have now finished the story, and I believe the mystery reveal was well executed. Overall it was an enjoyable experience, despite my minor gripe of the dialogue being repetitive some of the time.
This VN is as messed up as it is entertaining. The art is super high quality too.

I "played" this until you meet two main characters and was whole heartily bored as hell. ... This should just be labeled a book lol. I dont know but for 30 bucks this is just paying for a book not a game. very boring.

Quite an elaborate take on retelling the popular Japanese Urban Legends 'Kotoribako'

This one is not for the faint of heart. 
It seemingly introduced us to a political/ rural governance power struggles with a slice of true love romance plots at first but when the real plot pick ups, the VN reveals itself to the faithfulness of the original urban legend story.

What an atrociously bad visual novel. At least, at the beginning, I felt lukewarm about the story‚Äîit could possibly go somewhere interesting, but moment-to-moment, I wasn't engaged. However, Nie no Hakoniwa only got worse with each hour I invested into it. For nearly the whole runtime, I was wondering when it would finally become interesting, only for it to never do that. Even worse, it ended up going down one of the most nonsensical routes it could have taken from its setup.

The novel ostensibly tries to present a story in which all the characters are morally grey. "Sure, the protagonist isn't the best person, but his enemies are bad, too, so I want to root for him," the scenario director seems to want you to think. However, what Nie no Hakoniwa actually does is fail at telling a morally grey story. Rather, it's closer to morally black: every character is such a horrible person that I don't care to root for either the protagonist or the antagonists. In fact, I ended up not really caring what happened at all. The ending seems to present the protagonist and main heroine in a sympathetic light‚Äîthe tone of the writing wants you to feel bad for what happens to them‚Äîbut they were so irredeemably disgusting for the majority of the story that this presentation seems completely unjustified.

Additionally, the protagonist is supposed to be this ripped, badass assassin who can kill anyone without making a sound, but in reality he comes across as weak-willed because he simply goes along with whatever the main heroine wants. And it's a miracle he falls in love with her (although he himself is not even sure that he is because, again, he's supposed to be an emotionless badass), because from the first second she shows up, she comes off as incredibly irritating, incessantly begging the protagonist to get her pregnant.

At the very least, Nie no Hakoniwa does have some themes about how, under a patriarchy, the only value women are thought to have is as childrearers, but those themes are so infrequently explored and so painfully unrealized that it in no way is worth trudging through the slop that is the remaining 99.9% of the story to get to them. Nie no Hakoniwa is, at this point in time, the worst visual novel I have ever read.

2/10

BEFORE you purchase Nie No Hakoniwa you need to know that there is gore, necrophilia & cannibalism involved. If you want to purchase the NSFW DLC content you'll need to pay an extra 10$ on DL-Site. Nie No Hakoniwa is a story centered around the mysterious yet horrifying Kotoribako. Yasaka Kurou is a stoic assassin of the sorts who is to be wedded to the beautiful yet eccentric Kyouko Shiki. You'll go through a roller coaster of emotions as you progress deeper into the story.

So far so good, story is interesting and the characters are likable

Art, sound, music, interface and everything feel polished, as does the translation. 
I'm a slow reader so i'm looking forward to how it pans out, but so far I recommend.

Only negative is the uncensor patch is paid,  I recommend getting it on dlsite as it's cheaper then denpasoft with the perpetual 15% off coupon

Bonus points for full steam deck compat, even the op works

Solid and clever scares.

Fun concept and great atmospheric horror, but at the moment too difficult imo. It's a bit like playing a spot the difference game, but you have to remember how everything looked - which is especially difficult when first starting. The more you play, the better you get at spotting things, but my first few playthroughs were very frustrating when I couldn't see anything amiss at all. Since there doesn't appear to be a limit on reporting, my best bet tended to be reporting randomly whenever I'd gone too long without an anomaly. 

I think all of that could be fixed with a tutorial or 'easy' level, where you can see the type of anomaly you mean. Or, maybe you could increase difficulty by increasing the types of anomaly for each map (as in, the house would have 6 things you could report, hotel could have 8, factory 10) to build the player up slowly to learn what to look out for. 

But despite getting a bit frustrated, I really enjoyed playing. Wonderfully spooky and made me incredibly paranoid!

I have a bit of a Backrooms addiction, and this is the 28th Backrooms game that I've purchased. I am stunned at how solid it is for the price it is being sold for!

There was a game-breaking glitch the very first time that I played (I picked up the key, explored the house, and when I went to leave, the key was no longer in my inventory, so I was trapped in the initial room. I rebooted the game, and it has been fine since). There is also some issues with color blending at the edges of the screen, and one entity that cannot attack you if you're crouching, but those and the initial glitch are the only issues that I've had. One hasn't resurfaced, one is very minor, and the other should be an easy fix.

The controls are smooth (No head-bob. Thank you!), the scenery gorgeous, the maps are challenging, and there is plenty to explore (and to run from). There is a solid 'save' system (as a busy gamer, I thank you for that), and you can choose your levels. That can be a plus or minus, depending on if you feel that progression needs to be earned. I, however, really enjoy that option and see it as a definite plus!

The story is a bit weak, and I am not awed by the soundtrack, but that is getting pretty darn nit-picky about a game for under $1.

This would have been worth it for $4.99, so I can only say that if you are a Backrooms fan, this one is a must-own for the collection!

Wow guys, not bad at all! Sure, the game is very short, and several models are not placed very well in the environment, BUT, speaking of pure gameplay, this game is indeed very fun and entertaining, with plenty of different entities and puzzles that will keep you engaged till the very end. Every new level is a surprise, you won't see any recycled mechanics here. For its price, this game is even too good in my opinion, I expected MUCH less. If you are interested in the backrooms universe, try this without second thought, I don't think you will be disappointed!
Cheers guys!

I had a lot of fun playing Wiki's Wild Ride - the game has a simple premise but that doesn't make it easy. I was definitely infected with the "i'll just have one more try" when trying to beat the first level!

I have a weakness for cat games and this one really does it for me. I completed normal mode and am now challenging myself to finish both hard and very hard mode. The premise is simple but the execution becomes harder and harder as you progress. I love games like this to warm up my brain and reactions, The music definitely puts me into the zoomies and suddenly I'm howling as soon as I hit an obstacle. But I start over and try the level again. and again. and AGAIN.

A relatively simple (but not necessarily easy) game. You are moving through each level and avoiding obstacles which slow down or eventually stop you, while collecting coins and treats for power ups which are arranged in a tree.

Nice, chill and chaotic game with cats, dogs and evil printers and vacuum cleaners! 

Very easy to get lost in time with the "Oh just one more" 

Oh and don't let its cute looks trick you the game is hard O_O
If you love cats, hate vacuums, and have two thumbs; you will turn them both up! Simple fun game the whole family can enjoy.

This game is deceptive in its depth. At first glance it is simple (not to say boring) in interface and gameplay. The basic 6 vial mode is almost trivial in difficulty with puzzles that I can solve in half a minute to a minute with fifteen to twenty moves. It becomes a game of optimization for me in how many moves can I shave off and how fast can I do it. As more vials/colors to be sorted are added solving the puzzle without clicking in a tiny placeholder vial becomes nightmarish. 

I was glad to have the color optimization feature because one of the default colors was nearly indistinguishable from the background on my screen with my eyes. Color acuity varies greatly and what screen is used can have a big impact as well.

A fun puzzle game akin to solitaire with some twists! The game is simple enough to figure out, but I'm sure difficult to master... especially when adding extra colors. Music is eclectic, energizing and enjoyable. Overall, I can see myself playing this when I need a moment to relax and catch my breath. Nice work!

This is a type of game that is popular on mobile and I've played multiple versions.

I like this type of game but this isn't a good execution of it. For one, there is no animation of the pouring between vials. For another there isn't really any sense of progress. You just pick a color count and go. Normally there is a progression of difficulty as well as color count (usually by reducing the vials) and ways to earn powerups for more difficult games.

Calling all organization enthusiasts and puzzle aficionados! Chemical Sort is a hidden gem on Steam, offering a delightful blend of logic and relaxation at a fantastic price point (especially with the current 50% discount!). This seemingly simple game quickly transforms into a captivating challenge that will test your strategic thinking and color coordination skills.

At its core, Chemical Sort is a digital test tube experiment gone awry. The game presents you with a series of vials filled with colorful liquids. Your mission? To sort the chaos by strategically transferring liquids between vials until each vial contains only one color. Sounds simple, right? Well, the catch lies in the transfer mechanic. You can only transfer liquid on top of another liquid if the colors are the same, and there's enough empty space in the destination vial. This seemingly straightforward rule quickly evolves into a complex web of colorful logic as the number of vials and colors increase.

The beauty of Chemical Sort lies in its accessibility. The basic mechanics are easy to grasp, making it perfect for casual gamers or those new to puzzle games. However, beneath this simple facade lies a surprisingly deep well of strategic thinking. As you progress, the puzzles become increasingly challenging, demanding careful planning and foresight. Each move needs to be meticulously considered, ensuring you don't create an unsolvable mess in the process.

But Chemical Sort isn't just about solving puzzles ‚Äì it's about the journey. The game boasts a calming and visually appealing aesthetic. The vibrant colors of the liquids pop against the clean background, creating a visually satisfying experience. The gentle soundtrack adds to the relaxing atmosphere, making it a perfect game to unwind after a long day.

Chemical Sort boasts a surprising amount of content for its price, especially with the current discount. With hundreds of levels to conquer, there's enough gameplay here to keep you entertained for hours. Additionally, the game offers a variety of difficulty settings, catering to both casual players and hardcore puzzlers.

Whether you're looking for a quick and relaxing mental break or a deep dive into strategic color sorting, Chemical Sort delivers an exceptional experience at an unbeatable price. So, if you're craving a game that's both visually appealing and intellectually stimulating, don't miss out on this hidden gem!

Update: Instead of responding and working on the game, the developer revoked my key. Anyway, the game might not be available for much longer due to assets from other games.

The game is a weird mix of assets from elsewhere, but the biggest culprit are empty stages and no map.

At its core, the game combines action and metroidvania components. You find yourself on a map with obstacles that cannot be conquered with your basic abilities. By exploring the map, you obtain skills such as double leap and slide, which allow you to push further. The game starts encouraging, but it quickly ruins everything with bad design.

While there is a small mini-map in the lower corner, you don‚Äôt have a full map that would fill out as you progress through the game. This is a problem because the game is made of filler content that doesn‚Äôt add anything. This shows up in the form of long and empty stretches that just waste your time. Also, you have no way of knowing if you found every secret. Even if you find a key for a locked door somewhere behind, you won‚Äôt even remember where it is.

Your character carries a sword and a gun with limited ammunition. The sword is not particularly useful because it has limited reach and some enemies are resistant to its attacks. You can even jump on some, but this is risky because you never know if the enemy will attack you back. The things enemies drop are money, health, and ammo. Since they also respawn as you go away, you can use this to grind for stuff.

The map is littered with money and secret locations that conceal a permanent upgrade. You can find a variety of stuff, such as the ability to see the enemy's health bar or a larger bag to carry more apples. At first, your hero can only take three hits, so keep an eye on that. The game uses a life system; you respawn right on the spot you die. However, once all lives are used, you will have to restart from the last save point. 

Coins are used to improve the attack power of all weapons or buy some other goodies. To prevent you from grinding and buying the best stuff right away, the purchases are locked behind levels. If you don‚Äôt find the upgrade for the next level, you won‚Äôt be able to buy new stuff.

The big elephant in the room are the game‚Äôs borrowed assets. The main character, for example, will be familiar to everyone who has played a popular run-and-gun game. Most of it is inconsistent with the general appearance, since you will continually notice parts that don't match. You will see one enemy in one style and another in an entirely another one.  There are also a number of strange bits poking out that cause your character to become stuck.

This game reminded me a lot of the time I played Super Nintendo in 1993, it made me remember those nostalgic plataform games from that time.

It starts a little slowly and teaches you how to play in an intuitive way, because without learning a certain function of the game, you won't be able to progress to new places.

The game has many coins scattered around the scenes, and when you kill enemies they drop coins, ammunition, food, one time it even dropped 1 life.

I found the shooting a little slow, but I saw that you can increase its speed as you progress by purchasing from the game's store. The coins you pick up throughout the scene are to be spent in these stores, to recharge life or buy information from what I saw.

I saw that you also have the freedom to go anywhere, there are many paths to explore, it's like an open world without forcing you to follow a logical path, there's always something hidden in these places.

The background music is very pleasant.

the player starts the game with 5 lives and can only receive 3 damage per life, but from what I saw you can increase the damage resistance found in a kind of heart on the map, I found it a little difficult at the beginning but once you get the hang of it you will although.

There is also the option to save the game, when you die you will return to the point where you saved in the same way you were with your lives.

It isn't much, like at all. I've played for .1 hours as of this review and I don't see myself playing this for hours on end, but it's a nice bit of fun. I don't see how the whole "interstellar guardians" comes into it, but it's a nice quick free game that you might as well give a try, might be your thing.

There isn't much right now, I'd love to see more enemy variety, as (as of round 8, which is where i got to before failing) there were only 4 enemy types. I can see there are others, but when there's only 15 rounds per game, I'd like to see more variety sooner.
Also, different difficulties, adjusting quantity of enemies and their health, would be nice to see, and some more weapons especially, as the gunplay felt very limited and restricted.
I would also like to see more in the way of tutorials than what is currently present. You can see your controls but beyond that there is little explanation on how the different abilities work. It would be nice to have a tutorial section on the menu where you can get an explanation/demo as to how each ability works, and how to manage them (as i unintentionally sold one and had no clue what happened)

Basically, it's a quick arcadey wave shooter that's nice enough for a week into early access to get a positive review. The Early Access notes look great but I don't know how to feel about the releasing fully in 2023, I'm not sure how complete it could be by that point and it feels like the game will either be smaller than it has the potential to be or that it'll feel like it's still in early access upon release.

I'll definitely come back to this from time to time and I'm excited to see how it goes, I'll probably edit the review down the line after playing some more

[b]My Playtime:[/b] 25.3h (100% achievement, finished the game)
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (~2 achievements).
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (10 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]Juna - The Dreamwalker[/b] is an action-adventure game that focuses on exploration and puzzles. You are armed with a wand that can morph you into anything, both monster and object, and use their ability. It's a game that tests your creative thinking skills, figuring out what you can do with the abilities to clear the area.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- 16+2 dungeons
- Unique bosses that require the use of a specific ability to beat
- Huge area to explore

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Sometimes it's hard to figure out where to go next with the numerous backtracking
- It's easy to get soft-locked
- Bombs' area and damage are too big

[b]Specs[/b]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you enjoy playing Zelda-likes and want one that doesn't have the same ability as other similar games, this game is for you.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
[b]Juna - The Dreamwalker[/b] offers 2 kinds of display: 16-bit and 32-bit color. The 16-bit looks simpler and has a low pixel density, while the 32-bit one doesn't look pixelated at all. Both displays can take some time to get used to, but I ended up getting more comfortable with the 32-bit one. However, there is no way to switch the visuals in the game. You can only do so through the main menu.

[h3]Story[/h3]
The story serves more as a way to progress the game. There isn't much depth and the dialogues are boring. Luckily, the game is quite straightforward, and there is a quest log that you can use to figure out where to go next. Sadly, the same quest log was bugged during my playthrough and showed me quests from the next few objectives in the future.

[h3]The Game[/h3]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
Aside from the classic sword and shield, you are armed with a wand that can morph you into anything, both objects and monsters alike. There isn't much use in morphing into objects, but morphing into monsters will grant you their ability. Some are useless, some are especially important for your progression.

The game is highly explorable. There are just a lot of areas to explore and there are some areas that can be locked and meant to be progressed later. And this gives me a challenge; I would try to figure out how to reach some of the areas and it turns out that I could reach most of them this way, even if it took a long time to move the monster to the required area. And this brings us to the next problem.

[b]The Softlock[/b]
It's easy to get softlocked. Some locked areas are reachable by using monsters' abilities, even though you are not supposed to go there yet. These areas were supposed to be unlocked after you got a certain item, which was only available after you progressed with the game. Since you access the area with monster abilities, you won't be able to find a way back if you undo your transformation. I got stuck a lot this way, although luckily, the dev is quick enough to fix them after you report them.

You can get softlocked in dungeons too, though. Sometimes the game has a bug that either prevents you from progressing or locks you in one place. The occurrence for these ones is more random and can be resolved by resetting the game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3297524254 

[b]Abilities[/b]
I like the monster's abilities. They are unique, and they don't look similar to the ones introduced in other games. Other Zelda-like games feel easy to beat since the key items are similar, but not in this one. Although there are still some items that are similar to other games like a bow and bombs, you won't use them that often. You'll have to use the unusual monster abilities and items that have a similar function to progress. That being said, since you need to learn how to use them, it's easy to get stuck if you are not creative enough.

Bombs give some issues to me. They have a huge range and deal high damage. I had to be very careful to disarm them in a way that wouldn't harm me, and getting hit by it depleted so much of my HP. I think I got damage more often to these rather than the enemies' attacks.

That being said, I like how big the sword range is. It can cover almost everything in front of you, making it easy to clear grass or hit the monsters.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3297525152 

[b]Dungeons[/b]
The game requires a lot of backtracking, and you need to remember where they are to progress. This is especially true in dungeons. You will be forced to backtrack a lot, to the point that you might even have explored the whole dungeon several times by the time you finish it. I don't have any issues with it in the first few dungeons due to the small length, but some of the later dungeons can be a chore and confusing.

Bosses are varied. The early ones can be cheesed and very easy to beat. There is a difficulty spike starting from the middle half on the bosses, making them twice as tough and hit harder. They all have different weaknesses, which you need to figure out. Although the early bosses are straightforward, the latter ones aren't, forcing you to use more than one item in a certain order to damage them. And you need to be patient since the damage will be minimal. I prefer the boss fights this way since you need to be creative and think about how to use your items, although the drawback will be that you might not be able to figure out how to beat some of them if you have no idea what you are doing.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3297523614 

[b]Length and Difficulty[/b]
I finished the game in 24h. The rest of my playtime was spent getting the achievements. There is a lot of content in the game, and although some bosses are challenging, they are still not at the level that is hard to beat.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]Juna - The Dreamwalker[/b] is a game with a unique concept. I like how you can morph into enemies and use their abilities, and how unique the abilities are compared to other games. With a lot of Zelda-like games, it felt as if I was playing the same game, but this game doesn't have that same feeling. Progression might not be obvious because of this, although it was not something that I have an issue with. If you like Zelda-like games, you'll definitely like this one.

This zelda-like is incredible. It invokes a feeling in me I didn't even know I could still feel. Its like links awakening mixed with minish cap and it somehow works incredible well. The mechanics are very unique as well (you can become literally anything using a magic rod). It has 8 regular dungeons and 8 "dream" areas and even a large zelda "field". This game is worth it easily at full price and I cannot recommend it enough (even with some of the crashing issues).

If you like Links Awakening, you must play this game.

Dev. is very responsive and has made numerous tweaks, usually same day, based on user feedback.  I also feel this game would be great for speedrunning as there are some fun sequence breaks possible.  It has the look and feel of a good Amiga game but much more responsive and fast paced.

You can transform into almost any other object or creature in the game and there are loads of hidden mechanics and interesting physics puzzles, much more so than Links Awakening.  The game is big, and depending on your problem solving abilities could easily take 50 hours or more for a first completionist playthru.

Juna The Dreamwalker is a game that wears it's inspiration clearly on it's sleeve. If you enjoy the 2D Zelda formula then you'll enjoy what's on display here. It's not a masterpiece by any means but it's good enough to keep most players satisfied. I wish there was a rating between recommend and not recommend as there were enough issues here to hinder my enjoyment by quite a bit. For my full video review please see here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Yl0kxr0w6I

I've been playing this on my stream and it's definitely a lot of fun.  As others have said, it reminds me of the original Link's Awakening.  There are times when it's confusing, but there's a guide available for if you get stuck.  It's the Zelda game I've been looking for for years! I definitely recommend it.

I did initially get frustrated when dying because Continue sent me back to the start of the game, but if you choose Load instead then you'll get sent back to the last checkpoint.  I feel like they should be "Continue from House" or "Continue from Last Checkpoint" for clarity, but that's it.
