How about a modern "Links Awakening" with some "Alundra" thrown in? Another reviewer stated this and it fits nicely. It seems like this is a "custom-everything" Gamemaker project. The love and detail on display shines through despite the game's faults (are these subjective? I can never tell anymore...) The music is orchestral and uplifting though I can't decipher if it's Gamemaker stock or not... doesn't matter as long as it sounds great!
	
          In the World of Juna, the quantum foundation of existence is clearly skittles. This can be seen in the tasty rainbow scatter that rips apart your foes. As to whether or not Juna is herself made of skittles I cannot determine... perhaps it is only the force she is opposing?
	
          I'll confess that I started out loving this game and gushing over its aesthetic, visuals, charm, creativity and puzzle-logic. I greatly enjoyed at least half of what I played. By the time I threw in the towel I was cursing it. This doesn't mean the game is bad but rather that it needs more time to be perfected. I think the potential here is enormous and the developer's forthright responses to bugs is very appreciated. Whats more, they are working on a higher resolution version of the game with redrawn graphics throughout. 
	
          Bugs and crashes are numerous and I encountered one that corrupted my save file. Many of these have been fixed as of writing this. I would caution those playing to make save backups in a separate folder with dates or whatnot in the event of a corruption. 
	
          Performance suffers major slowdown on certain screens despite the pixel graphics. Perhaps this is a Gamemaker engine problem, or it may be my bogged down 2017 laptop (which chugged on these frequent screens). These aren't exactly modern graphics so I suspect that something is handled very inefficiently in Gamemaker (this is not a criticism of the deliberate graphics). 
	
          Without spoiling anything: In one particular dream sequence there is a jumping mechanic that is required to progress. This jumping mechanic is "speedrun-glitch-skip" logic in my opinion so I consider it unreasonable to expect the player to do this. This same mechanic is used in a later dungeon in any even more frustrating way.
	
          I made it to the seventh dungeon and had to call it quits. I could have consulted the developers walkthrough again but I am stubborn about these things on principle (to a fault) and don't consider progress worth it if a walkthrough has to be consulted more than a few times to continue... guess I won't ever be playing the La Mulana games then! ;) 
	
          For those more flexible regarding guides and who are more patient than I, there is a lot of creativity and ingenuity on display in this game! It is clearly a labor of love from the developer and I think it is worth ironing out whats here... I just hope they consider making the game a little bit more accessible with its cryptic sections. Perhaps portions of the walkt-hrough could be incorporated into the game as collectible pages that keep pace with whichever part of the game the player is in?
	
          Go try it out if you are like me and are craving more Zelda-Likes on steam. This game needs more attention, it could become one of the best with some ironing (just my opinion).
Thanks!

Very similar game in vibes to Alundra from PSX. It is good - I love Alundra. Exploration is similar, vibes are similar, dreamwalking is similar but slightly less detailed. 

BUT

The game is hard. Not in a combat meaning. But the puzzles and exploration is hard. In Alundra, exploration was like: "Do something. Now, walk around and talk with everybody, until you find new dialogue. Then do something, then walk and talk some more." Here - exploration is similar, but also - gimmick with changing form opens a lot of ways to solve puzzles and often I don't know if I don't have some kind of new power to move forward and have to keep exploring, or I don't see a way to solve my position with changing form. Like - to move super heavy crystal pillar, you have to be a raccoon.

In Alundra, there was a story teller, where you could spend some coins and get some tip of where you should go. I think, it would be great if something like this would appear in this game. Right now - I love it, but for now - I'm just in dungeon 2 after 2 hours of playing, and I was already checking solution for about 5 times to move forward.

The dlc has everything I hoped for in a long time. I loved the smaller scenarios in the older games (that are now published as Strategic Command Classic). It is perfect to have now all the innovations and improvements the series made so far also in the smaller scenarios. That hugely improves the variety. It also is great when you have only couple of hours on the weekend and want still finish a game. 
The two recent dlcs (Wars in America for American Civil War) and this one are a perfect addition and one can only hope there will be yet another dlc for Strategic Command War in Euopre and/or World at War.

This DLC brings some new and interesting scenarios for the game.

The minus that I found so far is that in the Russian Civil War scenario I was expecting all Russia from Europe to the Mongolian borders and even the Japanese (and Entente) intervention in Vladivostok. The scenario ends in the Urals.

I've purchased every version of Strategic Command, right from the original that I spotted in EB Games (before Steam was even invented). Every one has been magnificent and this one is no different. You owe it to yourself to buy it.

Nice package of small missions. Much faster AI turns, a scenario can be finished in about one hour. I found the two missions I've tried so far to be pretty easy on veteran difficulty. May need some balance adjustments, but I'd recommend the DLC.
Great pre and post ww1 scenarios, still caries the great Feel of the Main Campaign and it's mechanics!

Otherwise, it's a good DLC that add some interesting campaigns.

A speedrun game with fluent and smooth controls, clear and useful tutorials, great soundtrack, fun mechanics, and a few hours of playtime. 100% worth the price, as you can play levels over and over trying to beat your record each and every time.

What an interesting little game. As I understand it, everything from game programming and art design to soundtrack design and writing was done by one person. That is very impressive.

Although, that being said, the game is not perfect. At the time that I played I encountered a few bugs and the game overall felt a little janky. But, in fairness, I think the developer will fix those bugs soon, if he didn't fix them already. For now the most persistent and annoying "bug" (perhaps feature) that I noticed is that your character will sometimes miss when he's shooting.

Don't want to spoil the story, so all I can say is that the story doesn't seem like anything special up until about the middle of the game. And then it grabs you.

Also, I was surprised by some novel gameplay (even though it appeared only for a short time) close to the middle of the game.

Overall, I would recommend playing it if you want to play something short and interesting made by an indie developer.
thoroughly enjoyed it. the music is immersive, the combat is tough and forces you to act strategically, the story is a mix of interesting horror and mystery. the creators did a great job! i had fun.

Good thing I can say about the game - it brings back memories of Flashback game from 1992. Narrative in the game may be good but the game doesn't allow me to enjoy it.

Unfortunately the game is empty and hard.
- Fight mechanics is unforgiving. Zombies kill you from the first bite and you only have small window when you can land a bat swing at them.
- Levels are empty. You can wander around, look into empty rooms but there isn't anything that reward the exploration.
- There are no highlights on active areas or items. This means you have to spam "Interact" button while walking. It feels like pixel hunting.
- Control layout allows you to play with your left hand. Game expects you to quickly move fingers and not to miss the keys because zombies give you little time to react.

And finally I got stuck after about 1 hour of gameplay: https://youtu.be/3MLmatRbsE4

Overall I think the game may be way better if it won't be as hard.
Crashes my whole pc when i try to play it it worked for 50 minutes but the kaboot

[h2] Graphics [/h2]
Right away I'd tell you that the visual style might push you away and may seem cheaply made (like in old flash games), but you get used to it quickly and you can even notice that in some places the game is fairly well made and detailed (decorations and interior). Animations are simple and there are not a lot of them, but they are passable.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]
The main gameplay consists of finding items and fighting zombies. You're exploring different locations which differ in scale and look for the needed items to pass through to the next level, and sometimes you solve puzzles. Enemies can be killed with a baseball bat or a firearm. There's few ammo, and zombies can appear suddenly and kill you with one shot (bite). Beside that the game has a few surprises which can please you and add variety to the gameplay.

[h2] Story(no spoilers) [/h2] 
The premise of the game is fairly simple, but with each new level the plot gets more and more interesting and it makes you want to follow it. The story develops gradually and has a few unexpected moments. You see the development of the main character and his relationship with his family which helps to empathize with him much more. The writing and dialogues are good, thanks to which a lot of the characters are perceived as real people despite their appearances.

[h2] Music [/h2]
I liked the music. The compositions are fairly different and the fact that they were all played only with an acoustic guitar adds to the atmosphere.

[h2] Technical notes  [/h2]
I haven't noticed any serious bugs or errors. Everything works well.

[h2] What about the negatives? [/h2] 
Personally, I find the fact that the main character can miss while shooting to be the only major negative. It doesn't happen always, but sometimes it really pisses you off. It's a weird lottery. Thankfully, there are not that many enemies in the game, or rather in some levels there're few enemies and in some there's many and in some there's not a single enemy. And additionally, the pistol is not the only way to defend yourself, you can always choose to use melee combat.

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]
In the end you get a decent game with an interesting story and dark atmosphere. The levels are diverse and at times the game can surprise you. There are memorable and sincere moments that can draw emotions out.

The game challenges you and that's good, otherwise it would be a lot more boring. In some places you need to apply attentiveness and in other places you need to be quick and reactive. What I personally enjoyed is that the game doesn't lead you by hand and rewards curiosity and desire to explore every location. For example, you can find additional ammo or secrets and Easter eggs in some places. Talking about the latter, I also liked the vast number of references to the famous (and no so much) movies about zombies, and some of them are cleverly integrated to the main plot.

You can tell that the game was made will love and effort. For a solo developer that's a pretty well done job. Hope of Bion can be finished in 2-3 hours and I think it is worth its money and time.

The Lord of the Night: Pombero Reborn embarks on an ambitious journey, tapping into folklore that promises an eerie and engaging gameplay. The visuals are intriguing, especially when experienced in 4K. However, this game seems to struggle under its own weight.

The major bug encountered during the resolution change from standard to 4K renders the menu persistent, which becomes more of an obstruction than a tool. It's disappointing to see such a fundamental oversight in a title that aims high in terms of graphics.

As for gameplay, the experience is a mixed bag. While the atmosphere is charged and the setting deeply immersive, navigation and progression can be frustratingly non-intuitive. Getting trapped in the living room, for instance, without any clear directives or logical cues is an exercise in patience and, occasionally, exasperation.

In conclusion, The Lord of the Night: Pombero Reborn is a game with a lot of potential that is unfortunately marred by some glaring bugs and ambiguous gameplay. While it has its moments of brilliance, players should be prepared for a few bumps in the road. Hopefully, future patches will rectify these issues, bringing the game closer to its true potential.

The first thing about Athos that caught my attention is that it's a hilariously blatant ripoff of ARK: Survival Evolved. The second thing is the screenshots I saw of their surprisingly accurate Spinosaurus model--my favorite dinosaur. I knew I had to check this game out. Because this game has a long way to go to compete with the actual ARK franchise in any way, shape, or form, I don't mind recommending it despite some of its lazy and stolen implementation of ARK mechanics.

Athos is clearly in the very earliest of Early Access stages and it shows, but after playing for a couple of hours I can at least say it is a fully-playable game which is more than can be said for most of Steam's new Early Access titles. So far I've only encountered a couple of bugs and they are not necessarily game-breaking. Although the player's character can swim and dive, the wildlife does not seem to have any water interaction coded yet and so they just walk across lake bottoms as though they were on dry land. I also discovered that, when building structures, certain unplaced structures such as the bed will interact with the player character if that structure's silhouette is moved directly underneath the character; this will cause the structure to "wig out" and send the character twirling around in the sky to no apparent detriment--but it is dizzying for the player. (EDIT 10/16/23: since posting this review the so-called "flying bed" issue has apparently been fixed.)

Many of the character's interactions are painfully slow, such as eating and resource gathering; not to mention the animations are awful, especially that of the eating animation which makes it look like the character is pulling the food right out of their butt. The last thing I'll say about the characters themselves is that there's currently no option to play a female, but in general the character creation is clearly still very much a work-in-progress and hopefully improvements to it are implemented soon. (EDIT 10/22/23: character creation has been overhauled and females are now an option!)

The wildlife models and animations are very hit-and-miss, with the current roster that I've encountered so far feeling a lot like early-game ARK with the standard parasaurs, dilophosaurs, raptors, rexes, and sarcos. I'm guessing the models themselves are all stock assets because they vary wildly from pristinely scientifically accurate (the parasaurs and Spinosaurus) to hideously inaccurate (the Sarcosuchus and Velociraptor). Most of their animations are not convincing either, for example the parasaurs look like they're tip-toeing everywhere and the rexes feel like they have no weight to them whatsoever.

The game itself could also be presented better, currently held back by the usage of obvious and cheap AI "art" and an embarrassingly cliche "alien planet with dinosaurs" lore. Hopefully as development continues they put some resources into actual artists and writers.

Despite its flaws as an Early Access title with lots of clear placeholders, Athos has a lot going for it too. The weather and lighting effects are really good--especially the thunderstorms and sunsets--the dinosaurs generally have good patterns and color varieties, the bed offers a Minecraft-like sleep mechanic which is something ARK actually lacks as far as I know, and in some respects there is good attention to detail such as the character holding a blueprint when in construction mode.

Aside from improving on the criticisms described above, what Athos really needs to do is stand out from ARK. As long as they don't get in legal trouble for it, I think initially ripping ARK off is a funny meme that gets people talking about it. I certainly wouldn't have heard of this game if the ARK content creators I watch hadn't mentioned it, and to that end I respect this business tactic. I am all for more ARK-like survival simulators, especially with the ARK franchise itself going in a more Souls-like direction with ARK 2, but I want other ARK-inspired games to deliver an experience that ARK doesn't. As the development of Athos continues, I don't want to see the same wildlife roster that ARK has. I don't want to see a ripped-off Scorched Earth, etc. I want to encounter new creatures and explore new landscapes that ARK doesn't have. If Athos doesn't achieve that, then it may risk falling into obscurity if not worse (legal trouble from Snail, Inc.).

Game is full of bugs. Haven't seen any fixes or updates in over 2 months. The last one didn't even address any issues. I read from someone that the developer posted another game before this in early access only to abandon it later on. I hope that this isn't the case here, although it is starting to look that way. Save your cash  until this game gets some of the needed attention it requires. At the current state it is not very playable, just frustrating.

I can't in good conscience give this game a positive review.  It's not ready for EA yet as it's very unfinished, in fact it feels like something was rushed to market, with the view to make it something the community wants?  I'm sorry but that's pretty lazy development.  I'm all for listening to the community and shaping it based on what the majority suggests, but you should also have some idea of a road-map in your own head as well rather than being totally reliant on community input.  At least that's how it comes across.

I get the point of EA.  To shape and polish a 'nearly finished' product.  This is not 'nearly finished', more like 'barely started'.

I won't be asking for a refund ... yet, and depending on how frequent the updates are and what they bring to the table, my review may yet be turned around.

I can see the potential in a game like this, and the idea is a fun one.  I'll reserve judgement until I see more patches and updates released.  I'm sorry, but as it stands it's definitely not worth the price, even on sale.  Let's see what the future holds, though.  Maybe it'll become worth it as time goes on.

Sorry, I know this is pretty scathing, but hopefully there's some useful advice in here as well.  Best of luck developing this.  As I said, I can see it's potential.

This game is in a very early access stage, and there are several points to consider for a better understanding. While I'll give it a thumbs up, it's contingent on the developers' commitment to adding content and continuous updates. The game currently feels somewhat like a 'been there, done that' experience, reminiscent of Ark. However, there is promise here.

Should you buy it? Not just yet. I would recommend adding it to your wishlist and keeping an eye out for substantial updates.  As of this review, the game is on sale.

Athos EA Preview [Single Player]

[Stability]
FPS under 100 @ 1440 EPIC: Looks good.
FPS above 100 @ 1440 HIGH: Looks good.
FPS above 100 @ 1440 HIGH: Looks good; shadows not too great.
NO crashing or lag so far.

[Character]
Player animations are stiff, not many animations.
Camera angle is high.
No First Person View.
Not much in character creation [Still buggy].
Combat is sluggish (lack in animation overall)

[Environment]
Colorful and vibrant.
Lacks real immersion.
No real-world interaction animations with objects like chopping trees or mining.
No real threat [BIG PLUS FROM ARK].
Lack of Dino's (Feels empty)

[Sound]
Lacks immersion, feels looped.
Sound effects are dull.
Add character grunts while jumping, fighting, or interacting.

[Overall]
Can't say much as I just started playing and noticed all these things. It doesn't seem too dynamic and feels like more of just a basic start to early access. Looks promising if the Devs continue to update and add content. It's a much better experience compared to when I first played Ark.

Absolute trash.  Save your money and sanity by avoiding this quickly assembled mess of Unreal Marketplace assets.

https://youtu.be/G2x58vR_-CA

This developer launched his first asset cobbled together mess of a game (Junk Survivor) in early access less than six months ago and stated that it would be completed by the end of this year.  Instead of finishing that game, now he launches this game also in early access and is likely to quickly abandon this one as well.  ..This is NOT a good or promising pattern and basically shows that he is only launching these early access games to try and make a quick profit.  He makes lot of empty promises in the early access write up but it's pretty obvious that he never intends to actually finish or fix all of the bugs and problems.  

Anyone can buy assets and cobble them together on a map and hit the export button.. that is NOT impressive or something that people should pay their hard earned money for.  That is NOT a "game".. it's just more lazy trash cluttering the already terribly infested Steam platform.  


NOT RECOMMENDED.  ..Refunded and I only wish that I could refund my time to get that back as well.  *sighs*

I have been watching this game grow and progress for many weeks in discord. I just installed it after the latest patch and it is simply epic! It is visually stunning and so fun to play. The dev is very responsive, active, helpful and works very hard to get the patches out. Bravo! Woot!

I understand very well it is an "early access" game so there will be some changes to take place and it seems the developer is onto it and I really appreciate his quick feed back and response. One hardly get that from developers now.  I will give it another go and try to be patient :).  I just do not like the thought of restarting the grind to get split stat points.

The game has potential but is riddled with bugs right now.  Some dino's are frozen with nothing close to them (can just walk up and melee them to death without getting hit back), dinos get stuck on rocks/trees, taming does not always work (at least didn't for me), random deaths from very small step downs (or jumping up) - just a few bugs that I have personally experienced.  Response to bug posts on Discord is hit and miss (still waiting for responses for a few I have posted).  

Based on what I have read, I do think the devs are working to remedy issues but at this point this game is not ready for any meaningful game play - feels like a pre-alpha release that should have been limited to testers to address some of these very basic bugs.  Yes it's early but has more bugs than other EA games I have tried.  At this point, I'll put on hold and revisit in a few months.

At first I really liked this game, but as it progresses and changes through development, it is looking more and more like an ARK remake. If that is your thing, great. As for me, I am disappointed that the only way to advance skills will be through trader buys after you reach level 28. It appears there will be no advancement in level past the level 28 cap to progress naturally instead of being forced to hunt down and grind for trader bought advancements. Not exactly the primitive survival game it first started as. Kind of regret buying this as early access as it came out and not waiting to see where it would go. Yes, it is still changing, but every new update so far has made it more and more like ARK and less like a unique game. It is great, if this is what you are into, just not to my liking anymore as it progresses into a copy of another game and not really it's own thing.

Athos is still pretty early in its development but I can really see the potential here! This game has ARK vibes, but in my opinion there's a lot of things more improved here, ine uncludingnthe smoother graphics, and it seems to be optimized well. From what I've played so far some of the game movements and animations are rough, but they are smooth enough that I don't really pay much mind to them.

I absolutely love that you can host your own server, no extra charge, to play with your friends. Downside is that the server isn't up while the host is offline. But then again everyone can have their own server and you can just join in on their server to continue playing (albeit you have to start over but not really a setback in my opinion). This option allows for friends to play together. There is a bit of a set back with this feature, as that anyone can join your server, there's no option to add a password or to make it private. Something I hope they add in the future as it would help.

The animations I mentioned earlier that were rough are just Dino movements, movements past resources already farmed are a bit glitchy, and the fire animation is very old school game, all of these could be improved. Again this is still early access and I see so much potential here, so I have hope for improvements!

Things I would love to see: More cosmetic options in character creation (changing tattoos, height to name a few), more options for your hosted world/single player (ability to increase time resources spawn, increase Dino spawn rates, creative mode for builders?), more building options (walls, doors, decor items, etc), holiday event items possibly dropping from dinos, torches auto turning off at sunrise would be helpful, mass eating and drinking of water (so you can fill the food and water up faster). These are just suggestions but things that I think would improve the overall game. 

Something I had to discover too: You can split stacks by shift+left clicking and dragging, just a tip!

I will definitely keep playing this and see how it develops, it's also something I recommend!

Athos" is an early-development game that shows tremendous promise, thanks to the dedicated team at Neojac Entertainment Inc. While there are some noticeable bugs, the active commitment of the developers to address and resolve issues is commendable.

One of the standout features of this game is the developer's attentiveness to player feedback. Neojac Entertainment Inc. is actively listening to their player community, taking into account their needs and wants. This level of engagement ensures that the game is evolving in a direction that resonates with its player base. It's a refreshing approach that's often missing in the gaming industry.

However, it's important to note that "Athos" is still in early development, which means it comes with its share of bugs and imperfections. The game world might have a few rough edges, and players might encounter some technical hiccups along the way. But, it's crucial to appreciate the transparency of the development team in acknowledging these issues and their evident hard work to find and fix them.

For players who enjoy being a part of a game's growth from the ground up, "Athos" offers a unique opportunity. The potential of this game is undeniable, and with the dedicated team's continuous efforts, it's likely to become an even more impressive and polished experience as development progresses.

In conclusion, "Athos" is an early-development game that shows tremendous promise, thanks to the dedicated team at Neojac Entertainment Inc. While there are some noticeable bugs, the active commitment of the developers to address and resolve issues is commendable.

i honestly do not understand a lot of the hate this game gets. is every racing game a blatant ripoff off the first, whatever that is? is every shooter?

yes, it is heavily inspired by ark but who cares? if you do care about that you have some serious issues, this is actually making me mad, like the children that fight each other over xbox vs playstation.

the game is clearly in *VERY* early access and that is made clear by the dev, who seems to be quite active fixing things which is the most important thing to me.
yes, it does require some refinement, but that's being worked on, if you can't take it if a game is in early access, don't buy games that are in early access, it's really that simple. people would be a lot more helpful if they told the dev if they found bugs rather than come here and complain about something that was obviously going to be an unfinished product.


i would like to see athos going somewhere and in the meantime i'm fine with some bugs, as i said... early access, if that doesn't ring a bell... look it up. ark still has quite a few bugs that were there from the very beginning and have never been adressed so... give the dev some time to work on it, early access is not just the 'i want to make money asap' option, it also gives devs the chance to find not only more bugs to fix, but to find them faster, granted people actually give them a heads up rather than go on a rant about the state the game is *currently* in.


long story short, if you can live with a game that is still in very early access i would recommend giving it a try, but not be discouraged if it isn't perfect - as it won't be. dev seems to be actively working on the game and that should be the most important thing in early access, not a perfect result - which would ultimately take away any reason for early access anyway.

So far the game is great, the mechanics have been flawless for me, from harvesting resources, crafting system, leveling up skills, unlocking blueprints and more. 

The building is very clean, snaps easily, rotates smoothly, placing objects you make like the campfire, bed and such place with ease and are allowed just about anywhere reasonable (note placing bed down into a 1x1 can be buggy as it cant figure where your placing when standing inside)

The AI dinosaurs fight each other and seem to display passive and aggressive detection to you, as some just mosey on by, while others more predator like will began to chase you, trying to hunt you down. Did notice tho, that if you can get distance from them, they will just give up and move along elsewhere, so i like that your not forced to fight.

The combat with the dinosaurs is simple, not a lot other then you hitting them and them biting you. Your able to stand under some larger ones at their feet and just whoop them till you win as they cant attack you and don't know how to counter it. Still they look pretty cool visually, with their unique colors and differences in appearances, but need a bit more in depth animations, pathing, combat and such will need to be worked on. Which i'm sure the dev or devs will more then get up and going.

Your stats: the depletion is very good, fair 100% imo, and the nutrients gained from berries (stamina berries, food berries, water berries...not their names but what they help with) and meats gained from dinosaurs give you a decent and fair amount tbh. I do not think this needs any work as it seems perfect to me.

The durability of tools & weapons: The durability is great, lasts for a decent amount of time on just the basic tools and weapons. Plus the crafting costs for these is completely 100% feasible and done well.

As for the graphics: I am running all the graphics on epic, highest settings, vsync on and have smooth game play, recording and all. Looks stunning to top it off, as the atmosphere just seems so nice. The sun going up and down, casts some odd shadows tho which seem like ur lagging but just move and you will see the game play is smooth still, its just the simply weird shadows casting lol

When harvesting resources, its an auto collect when chopping trees, and rocks, while others like fiber, single stones, wood logs and stuff like this are manual pickup, but done so with ease. Enjoyed every bit of gaining resources.

The keybindings were a huge thing for me as their simple but fully customizable, and not just bind to new keys, they even display the proper keys you bound in game when interacting with things. (Example: picking up a single stone, by default prompts E key, i changed to F key, then did the same thing and it now prompts to pickup with the F key.... with other keys as well. (I did this just to test the feature)

When launching the game, you have the choice to join a game, host your own or through the hosted tab you can set to play single player, which i love tbh, i enjoy playing solo and occasionally i can host a game and allow others to join my game. Your also able to adjust game settings and multipliers for the game as well before loading into it, and this applies whether you host or single play the game. I love the fact i can customize the game to my preference.

The devs are so commutative and quick to tend to comments, feedback and such already. There have been some bugs and things needing fix or added to the game, and the devs been on point to addressing and fixing them right away, 100% to the dev team.

All around i'm loving the game, and would highly recommend to anyone, especially if they like a Ark style game, or even just dinosaurs and survival, plus the added twist to taming is neat. Game def is an A+ to me, keep up the amazing work yall :)

Will continue to update my review as I progress in my YouTube series, https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCecUPxk7lgb0U1_dGqhihow

I got this "game" for free and it immediately gave asset-flip vibes, and boy was I right. This isn't even a game; there is no gameplay. If for whatever insane reason you're actually considering buying this just know that you can not; jump, crouch, prone, loot enemies, craft, or really ANYTHING besides walk around a stock world and shoot AI-less, motionless zombies. It's just another example of 3 different asset packs flipped to scam people, disguised as an "early access survival" DayZ reskin. This isn't even a game and I highly doubt it ever will be, here's some "gameplay" from my review/first impressions to serve as proof of exactly what I'm talking about: https://youtu.be/UofKx6SmZYs

Don't ever buy this.

The game, as it is, is a big map where the trees and buildings pop in as you approach. They are filled with mostly nothing, but there are some random bullets and cleaning supplies placed in the middle of empty rooms. The zombies barely notice that you are there and drop in two punches, making getting firearms superfluous. The hunger and thirst meter drops so quickly that I died after playing for 10 minutes. That's not how humans work, not even a little. This needs to come off steam and have the 2-3 years of development the dev says in the early access section done before it returns. 

https://youtu.be/uZMhKkd7n4U

At least with those things will be better experience.

Deadpoint is a fun and well-developed game that offers a massive map, loads of guns, and impressive gunplay. While it does have some rough edges, there's nothing game-breaking that ruins the experience. The game features both scavs and zombies, meaning that you're not just constantly shooting at mindless zombies the entire time. The gunfights are exciting, thanks to the solid gunplay.

You might be wondering, "Why wouldn't I just buy DayZ?" First of all, DayZ is 70 AUD, whereas Deadpoint is only 7 AUD. Despite the price difference, I can easily argue that Deadpoint can keep you more entertained.

Even if you aren't a fan of zombie games, Deadpoint is still very enjoyable. I personally am not a huge fan of zombie games, having only completed The Last of Us, but I still find Deadpoint very fun. The combination of scavenging, battling both scavs and zombies, and the overall dynamic gameplay makes it a game worth trying, especially considering its affordable price.
the price is quite cheap, and the gameplay is also good, I highly recommend this game

For a 2 dollar Pre-Alpha build, this is not bad. It has some of the basics of the open world survival, like looting, hunger/thirst, zombies, enemy scavs, gunplay and clothing, vehicles, and even a rudimentary trader. They definitely need some refining, but they are there. The gunplay was honestly feeling pretty good if I were to highlight anything. I purchased this as more of an investment into the future of the game, as I can tell that the devs clearly have some vision with this game that they are trying to go through with. 

BUGS/ISSUES I NOTICED:
When you kill an enemy scav, their torso disappears.
When aiming down sights, the third person crosshair stays on screen, blocking the iron sights. 
Different ammo types are all called 'Ammo'.
Bears are way too weak, and disappear when killed.
Too many bushes in the forest area. Hard to see anything.
Third person camera needs to be more right of the character to see better.
When attempting to discard your equipped weapon, the 'discard' button appears off screen and is unreachable. 
You can hear zombie sounds from almost everywhere, yet barely see any zombies. 
Switching backpacks is almost impossible. 

FOR THE DEVELOPERS:
What you have here is a good start. You can turn this into something REALLY good, but I think right now you need to focus on refining the gameplay rather than adding new guns and locations. Refine the movement, refine the inventory, refine the shooting and the AI, add more mechanics and features rather than content. Base building/barricading, more crafting, more hunting, vehicle upgrading, even maybe a leveling system. You can add more guns when the gameplay is solid. I think you can make a really great game out of this if you just focus on good and interesting features and mechanics. That is what will get people to play.

The game in it's current state you play the man with the world's fastest metabolism. Food and thirst burn down quick. so fast that moments after hitting zero your character will drop dead on the spot. So get your running shoes on cause it's a constant race to find the two resources that will kill you quickest if they hit zero. 

Initial humor aside let me get the bad out of the way.  At the time of posting I'm nearing two hours into the game, not quite there.  It's glitchy, you occasionally fall through things, zombies clip partly but do not travel through walls. The buildings fell randomly plopped and some are repeated.  

HOWEVER, that's to be expected in an alpha build of a game. it's not a bad framework so far. I've only fallen through the world once. Character can sort of swim, the weapons feel/sound decent, the zombies move ok. It's..more functional that many alpha builds I've played on steam. 

All that AND the best part? The dev does seem to be accepting criticism pretty well.  I know, I know supposed to be talking about the game not the creator  but hear me out. I've played games in similar states of progress and design and a lot of the creators (not all) don't know how to accept input. So it's nice to see someone noting issues and being friendly as they  get  the game's issues sent in to them. Hard not to appreciate it. 

Should you get it? Well, if you can accept it's alpha with a loooonngg ways to go and want to chuckle and silly bugs and growing pains, go for it. If not? then maybe wait till later on this one.

Its a pretty fun and cheap game. It does have quite a few bugs, but its to be expected from an early access game, and i hope most of the issues will be fixed in the future. Overall 7/10, would recommend, and its pretty decent for its price.

there is also an in depth building system though i haven't tried that out yet.

For $5 which is actually $2.5 because of regional pricing i highly recommend this game.

I love that there's a reward system that allows you to choose area's of the hub to open up and explore. There's a solid foundation here just like I knew there would be, and its been taken a step up beyond any of my expectations. 

One of my favorite idea's here is being able to load in 3D models externally in-game to clean, either by you choosing or it being randomized which lends to a very large pull of potential. It feels as satisfying as it looks and I hope that this title will continue to build upon its strengths. 

One of my hopes is that one day, though quite the undertaking I'm sure, players will be able to load or create custom environments and maps that can be shared, as while it is fun to clean items and objects, the idea of cleaning larger area's by the community would truly set this ahead of any other power washing VR title I can think of. Cheers and thanks for the fun~

Under Pressure is a VR pressure washer sim. It is currently in a very early stages of EA, but already has a solid gameplay loop and plenty of content, thanks to Sketchfab integration. I am not a fan of chore simulating games, but  still enjoyed playing it for an hour.

Pressure washing mechanics are superb: from realistic changes of textures during cleaning to a responsive controller rumble. Main gameplay loop is simple: you clean stuff and get coins for it, that can be used for unlocking new areas and upgrading the pressure. And the game has some additional multiplayer minigames and even water propelled flight mode. 

On the minus side: it currently seams to launch in "always online" mode, making offline single player impossible.

For it being completely free it's a great VR game. It definitely scratches that itch to play something like Powerwash Simulator in VR, but since they didn't put it on steam for some reason this is a great alternative. Decent amount of stuff to clean, fun lil minigames to play with friends, and seemingly infinite amount of content with the workshop.

This is a really nice wind-down-after-a-long-day game. Bonus points if you chat with a buddy while you pressure wash. Thanks for sharing your game for free, OP. Saw you talk about it on reddit and tried it out. It's a nice game.

Honestly, it doesn't have much content and lacks graphics.
There are also near-constant FPS issues.

However, I do think it is worth it for about an hour so if you have a friend or couple to mess around with for a while. It is a really fun concept with a couple small extra things that aren't just cleaning which can keep you and your friends entertained for a bit.

I really hope this game improves over time and becomes a proper game, which, honestly, once the issues (mainly the FPS issues) are fixed, I would even want to pay money for :D
Fantastic game, only real complaint I have is that there is no smooth camera option. Can't wait to watch this game get better!

[b]Summary:[/b] At the time of this writing, this is a game you should skip. The content / adult scenes are just not good. Compounded by basic skins, bad camera control, and  a disappointing ending.

[b]Technology:[/b] This is a unity engine game. So at least a decently powerful baseline to work with. If only Unity didn't cause new problems via their garbage licence agreement.

[b]Visuals:[/b] Very basic. All of the characters are anime - like. This part is acceptable. While the skins for those you interact with could use some more detail, that is more a neutral than a negative. You can squeeze pretty good smut out of pixel art if done well. The partners / antagonists are still pretty generic. Rooms and objects are the same or are slightly color shifted. Static NPCs are scattered about. They may move / or not, but they are not interactive. The draw distance of a room is intentionally hobbled no matter what quality setting you select. You can see effectively 3-4 steps in front of you in a permanent 'Superman Fog'.

[b]Audio:[/b] Also very basic. there are some audio queues that you need to listen for in the game loop. There are also jumpscare noises that occasionally occur.

[b]Game Loop:[/b] This is effectively a 'walking simulator' where you need to travel through 500 rooms total to get to the end. There is a checkpoint every 25 rooms. The checkpoint is a 'lounge room' with a side door that sometimes opens to show a scene. There's bunny suit girl who at least talks to you, and a save station next to her. There is also a notepad you can find and read in this room. There are other people here. They do nothing. Between checkpoints you look for the unlocked door. Not all doors are unlocked and you have to find them to proceed to the next room. Occasionally you will find Static NPCs and there will be occasional jumpscares from a sign that has a picture of one of the pursuing girls. If you are being chased, you'll get a very obvious clue and you want to keep moving to the next room as quickly as possible. You take damage from the pursuing girl and losing is just a back to title screen. After 100 rooms you can do a scene with one of the pursuing girls at the checkpoint by talking to her. After you clear 500 rooms you wind up in the 'ending room'. You will claim your prize: [spoiler] a couch that dubs you as owner of the hotel. [/spoiler] There is no end scene or interactive NPCs that I could find other than one you can talk to.

[b]The good stuff:[/b] All of the above I might be able to give this a 5 or 6 out of 10, it was okay review if the scenes were good. They are not. The models all pose and move in the same way. The camera controls are fixed locations and zooming in does not appear to be an option. The poses are equally basic, and the female models seem censored or underwear only in some cases. Your character is a blue outline - which I could forgive, provided the scenes were actually good. The camera limitation also applies in the game as you move around you are moving as if on a grid. There is no fine resolution to your movement so you could look at the simple models at certain angles or crouch, or anything to make viewing them better.

[b]How to improve this:[/b] I'm not a fan of "Game bad. lol!" so I want to point out some constructive things for the devs to put their effort towards if they want this game to be better and ultimately more interesting to play for the gameplay and lewd reasons.
- Improve interactivity: This includes more NPCs to talk with or heck, even lewd with. It's a light content game, but that content needs to be heavier than air. Fix timing for captions so that they persist long enough to read. Longer responses tend to zip by too fast.
- improve character skins / skin variety. You get to the 'seen em all' threshold way too quick. Some palette swaps and clothing mods will easily improve the variety. Coupled with the above, that's a good improvement.
- A better draw distance. I'm not sure if the choice was made to allow potato class PCs to run this or what, but it is an artificial difficulty and it was overall annoying. Changing some of the room surface textures / adding more textures would also be a visual improvement.
- Make the scenes worth the bother. I feel like the music is for a Daytime TV Judge and while the starting pose is all right, the bad camera, below average textures, and almost mechanical response movement did not inspire anything of value. I can accept blue outline dude, but make the model and model movement interesting.
- Some kind of interactive ending. I did the last 25 rooms twice because I thought I missed a detail. It's especially disappointing because you do finally get bunny girl looking available, but instead it's just a tease.

I successfully finished the main and bonus game in 6 hours. 
And hooray.......I did not encountered annoying or game-stopping bugs. 
The CE-edition of the game without the dlc plays as a normal complete game. There are no unfinishable games scenes or story lines.

This game was a good with an enjoyable, entertaining fantasy story.  It has a lot of puzzles. I love this... Although I do not like the arcade-based puzzles. Fortunately for me, there are plenty of logical based puzzles left to enjoy. 

The adventure part of the game was much improved, compared to the older Domino Games (Do Games Limites). They have listened to their players!!! 
- More logical actions. Little to no repetitive actions. For example : Items for inventory puzzles don‚Äôt need to be obtain again and again, but can be used multiple times during the game. 
- They also improved the puzzles for seasoned hog players. Now, the hard mode puzzles are really more difficult and has challenging puzzle-mechanisms compared to the easy mode, instead of just more time-consuming.
- The hidden object puzzles has now both easy and difficult items to find. I used the match-3 game options in these puzzles to find the too well hidden items instead of having to use hints üòâ

There are also things that has remained the same. 
The same achievements and easy to find collectables and morphs. 
Wallpapers, music and room to decorate with collected points of the collectables. 

There are 24 replay able hog and mini-puzzles, but only 20 of them are accessible. 
I assume you have to buy the dlc  to play for this.

I powered through to the end, but it was boring.  There was no logic to things you needed to use to get past obstacles so it turned into "try everything in inventory to see if something works".  Don't waste your money.

have to admit i got frustrated at times, and i didn't like playing with checkpoints at all while still having to conserve lives. i had more fun with the "restart from position" option enabled. the game is really difficult, and the scoring doesn't feel very rewarding. thankfully, there is (probably an oversight which i kinda felt bad about exploiting but hey the game's hard enough and it doesn't work that well on 1.5 difficulty) a way to max out lives and score, simply by sticking to the back of the stage 1 boss and following it around (which will make your score skyrocket in the millions if you're patient enough, and in any case will dwarf any legitimate scoring from the stages). it also seems that scores aren't conserved between game starts, so if you close the game your scores will be gone. wasn't a big fan of that but it doesn't matter that much after all, especially with my previous points.

with the negatives out of the way......

the soundtrack is EXCELLENT, and i think the game looks awesome. i may have had some trouble following the action with the colors and sizes but overall it is very aesthetically pleasing. also the game is FREE?? and it's clearly a huge passion project, and i did have fun with the game overall and i was pleasantly surprised. for all the things i disliked, it's still a whole lot better than a fair bunch of shmups i've paid for on steam lol....
i'm mainly leaving this review to support the dev since i think the game is quite cool, and i hope they get to make more games in the future.

EDIT: i feel like my review sounds too negative on the gameplay side, i'm also going to mention that on one of my runs i randomly was sent into a secret stage with awesome music and i thought that was really cool, the game's handling feels pretty neat and the whole gameplay is quite tight. most of my negative feelings are also in part due to me not being THAT into more old-school shmups (i am a danmaku baby), and i'm not personally fond of mechanics that revolve around you spending a lot of time right next to enemies, at least not without bombs or other screen clearing effects. also the level layouts are very varied and the endgame was pretty hype with all the minibosses and stuff. just a cool game all around

As someone who has seen this game a lot, it is definitely one of the best experiences of time. 
- Sun Tzu

Here are some tips for players, as well as strengths and growths for the game

Tips for players:
- Use WASD to move, k to bomb, l to shoot and enter to select in menu get settings/pause ( in the settings you can change to arrow keys to move, x to bomb, and z to shoot)
- Get all the collectables you can (they really help)
- Shoot all the enemies you can to reduce the count so it doesn‚Äôt get overwhelming EXCEPT for the non violent enemies that when you destroy release a bullet at you (Ex: the moving squares)
- You can destroy the flashing target seeking bullets but not any other kind of bullet
- If the game is too hard you could, change the difficulty, change it to start in last position vs checkpoint, or skip sections using the training mode in main menu


Strengths:

Top three strengths are:
         - The music is a Bop. It is really catchy which I don‚Äôt really think of as retro music being but I really have been enjoying the sound track. 4-5 star retro music.
         - This game isn‚Äôt just a retro themed game. It FEELS like a retro game. It IS a retro game. (at least from my experience of playing some retro arcade games). The aesthetics, the music, the AI and game design all combines into a game that could of been in the arcade room in the 70s or 80s (except with better music :) )
         - It is free, there is nothing that you have to pay to play this high quality retro game

There is accessibility in this game which allows for:
         -The difficulty can be changed from 0.5-1.5x the difficulty
         -Settings allows for starting at checkpoint or starting and last position (depending on who wants to play)
         -Settings allow for accessibility by changing the amount of starting lives (which I really like) in each game as well for left handed controls (the arrow keys instead of the awsd)
         -Training mode (allows you to explore more content without needing to stay alive from the beginning)

- Can clearly tell what symbols mean what (due to the key on the left) and you know what to shoot because all enemies are 
clearly red (you also know you can‚Äôt shoot asteroids since they are purple)
- A large variety of enemies are in the game which really makes the game play fresh and entertaining
- There are variety of bosses across the different stages which have amazing design
- This game was very engaging to me. I spent more time than I initially thought I would spend on this game
- I can resize my window to however I want it (I am really happy with this, I get annoyed when games automatically full screen the game)
-Haven't found any bugs from 40 minutes of playing
-The controls feel nice and are fluid

Growths:

- Especially on harder difficulties the purple comments are annoying and can come out of nowhere and kill you. I would like them to still be in the game, but maybe a warning sign could indicate the direction they are coming from or path they follow
- I know you can kill the target seeking bullets but I personally would want to be able to do damage to all types of bullets in the game (this might be hard to balance but it is just my preference)
- This game is just very hard. For me it takes to be on an easier difficulty and use start at position to even beat the first stage of the game. Yet this is not as big of a con as it could be because I am able to beat at least the first boss on a lower difficulty and can progress as far as I would compared to other retro games. It might even be a strength to have for some people who really likes challenging retro games.

Conclusion:

	In summary, if you are looking for an free entertaining side scrolling retro game that gives you a challenge, a wide range of different enemies to blow up, allows for a variety of player types (casual to hardcore), and that has stellar music and sounds ‚ÄúThe Rush‚Äù is a game for you.

Although I do think a continue option would be very beneficial for this game.

The reviews showed "Very Positive" and I tried to like this game. I bought it and tried it out. The navigation is wonky but each game has it's little quirks. The game's dialogue, however, was clearly not written or translated by someone who speaks fluent English.

I'm pretty forgiving about that, normally. You can give some latitude given that you are engaging in what is basically a digital adult picture book. If the pictures were good, it might have boosted my tolerance for the terrible writing.

The developer needs to improve.  This is another unfinished bug-ridden title.
I will admit, compared to their other titles, this one is LESS buggy, and does not seem to have a lot of translation mistakes and typo's.  So that's good.  But that does not mean that it is without serious bugs.
The biggest of these is the animation/cut-scenes.  Whenever you unlock or view a cut-scene, the first animation of the cut-scene becomes the master-file and blocks all other cut-scenes, so they only show up as black screen.  (ie. if you have a cutscene that has say, 5 animations in sequence.. you'll only actually be able to view the 1st, the rest will be blackscreen.)  .. The only resolution is to completely stop the game, and re-launch it, then  you can view 1 animation again.  and then you'll have to repeat and stop the game and re-launch it again, for any additional animations you want to see, for each one.  Otherwise, if you continue on the game without closing it and re-launching it, when you get to another scene, since it is holding the previous animation as master-file, it will go to black screen and lockup so you can't exit and have to alt+tab out and then close it from the outside and re-launch again anyway.  Really annoying.

To their benefit and credit, the developer did much better on this than on 3 of their other titles which were COMPLETE GARBAGE and a waste of money.   This title should be considered early access and needs a lot of improvement, but at least it's not as bad as the others.   I could see paying a low price for this one, but that having to re-launch for every single animation is just crazy stupid and annoying.   That is NOT how you leave a game for people to play.  

So, they did better than some of their others.  But is better than terrible good enough to recommend?  Not with the current bugs and lack of depth.  Game still needs much work.  At the very least it needs to be flagged as early access or beta, and they need to work on improving it.

No climaxing, you just watch the same reps till you click "x close" and the story continues. Paid 6 for this game. Felt like should've been 2 or 3. I think the only redeeming factor is the washing machine scene, since it's an adult movie classic and I've not seem it before in a game.

[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
My Lovely Stepsister is a Unity based visual novel, in a point and click adventure format.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Your stepsister, Tracy, who you haven't seen since she was 13, just went through a bad breakup with her boyfriend and has asked to move in with you.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You start off by setting the main character's name, Leo by default. There is no way to roll back the text, or view the history.

After your first quest, buy a lasagna for your stepsister. Active quests show in the upper left of the screen. While the game may seem like you can go anywhere and do things, you are really limited to the quest. For example, if you don't have anything you need in the store, you can only go to the store, there is no additional interactions available.

Mini Games: After you get the lasagna, you have to come home and cook it. To find out about the objective of the mini game press the question mark on the game screen. The games are all very similar, but have different nuances. For the cooking mini game, there is a spinning wheel with green sections. You have to click in the green sections to successfully cook the lasagna. There is a progress bar on the right, you need to fill the bar. If you click outside of the green the bar goes down. The second mini game appears if you choose to peek on your stepsister in the shower. While it looks similar to the cooking game, it is different, you have to prevent the white ball from being hit by the black bars as they spin around the circle. Pressing the mouse button moves the track the ball is on. The difficulty of the mini games increases as the game goes on.

Money: As you walk around you'll see hot spots to search. Some of these spots will reward you with money. However, you can also work, on the laptop in your bedroom. Work is another mini game. You have to click in the highlighted area to increase the amount of money that you will earn. Money doesn't really play a large part in the game and a couple of hundred dollars (or whatever currency) is all you'll need.

Scenes: The scenes are comprised of short movies. On the sides of the screen are arrows. Clicking the arrows will show you a different video of the scene, a different angle or position. Close the scene by clicking close in the upper left. If you switch active windows the action, and audio, stop.

If the text box isn't on screen you can press the ESC button to bring up the option to Save, or Load.

While the English starts off very good, it falls off later in the game. There are a few oddities along the way. Day 1, after Tracy eats the lasagna she tells you the best neighbor she's ever had, so many better word choices available, brother, stepbrother, or roommate, for example. When you go to the University the it is shown as Univercity on the map.

There was an instance later in the game where all of the navigation arrows disappeared and I had no quest. I used the phone a couple of times and the navigation arrows came back. However, without a quest there was no way to continue the game, this caused me to be able to get all of the achievements, except the negative relationships, but none of the endings. This is a fatal flaw. I save and save often, so it is a flaw in the game logic as I reloaded my last save, after a restart, and had the same issue. I went to every location available, my home was not, and every phone contact. There was no way to continue the story.

[h1]The Gallery[/h1]
There are two Galleries, the CG Gallery for stills and the Video Gallery for, duh, videos. There are 40 stills and 42 videos. I was able to unlock all but six stills and three videos, which I assume have to do with the bad relationships or the different endings.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
There are supposed to be three different endings, unfortunately I'll never know as the game logic prevented me from getting any ending. The scene videos are excellent, but you'll never get closure.

[h1]System Specs[/h1]

Nightstands are those tables next to the bed--you use them primarily at night. Hence the term "nightstand." They are not found in the kitchen--those are called "cabinets." They hold things like food, or pots and pans. 
The choices are there, but they have no consequences. Some jackass wants to trade me a beer for a girl's notebook. I chose "That's ridiculous!" (which means "no deal") but guess what? Absolutely the worst indie horror game I have played this year.

The game plays at around 18-23 FPS on a 2060. Zero graphics settings, not even a menu.

The game is 5 minutes long if you die.

All of the doors are broken, the house is populated with the bare minimum of stock assets (and not even the right ones, this guy has an industrial fridge and a foodservice sink in his kitchen. The downstairs bathroom also has a port-a-potty door with no handle.)

All of the other houses on the street are empty shells, and the "store" is a featureless cube with an elevator for a front door.

You don't interact with anything; you move near it and your character "jumps" into a new position as the game loads into a changed state.

The antagonist is literally staring out the window at you when you get home, but the main character is apparently too utterly blind to notice this even though you can stand and stare straight at him.

There is one jumpscare; but you have to manually trigger it by entering the room with the antagonist.

After you go back to bed and wake up, you hear the sound of a crash from downstairs. But there's nothing breakable at all downstairs other than the TV which hasn't moved; and if you enter the room upstairs that the antagonist was in, he's still there and the jumpscare sends you back to the point after you left the store.

The police station is... down the road somewhere I guess? I looked away for a literal second while walking along the sidewalk, and when I looked back, I was in the police station.

And then the game ends with a line of text that just says that the police told you that the guy from the store had a knife and went to your house to wait for you. Nothing else.

I purchased this game with the primary intention of supporting the Gamker Youtube channel. However, I cannot currently endorse this game due to its poor "gaming" experience. This current condition of release is hard to use nor enjoy.  The graphics fall in the mid-range, instructions and tooltips are noticeably absent, no control shortcuts, a limited selection of furniture, and an overall dearth of customization options. Comparable applications are readily available on platforms such as Windows or the Apple Store, offering a more refined user experience if you are intent to do interior design. I sincerely hope that Gamker will fulfill their commitment to enhancing this game/application continuously, even if the purpose of the release is to prioritize quick financial gain.  Purchase this game if you are supporting Gamker, but don't buy it if you want to play/use it.

[i] My Experience [/i]

Unless it just looks awful from the jump, my co-op partner and I try most free cooperative games that release on Steam. [b]Embers[/b] seemed interesting enough - sort of a fantasy top-down shooter, featuring dragons. Although some of the reviews criticized the game's control scheme, we both used controllers and found the game to control fine. We played enough to retrieve one of the dragon eggs, but after we were defeated we didn't feel the urge to try again. The game is a little rough around the edges, from the inadequately signposted shrine where players can purchase skills to the ludicrous purple bat swarm that covers the whole screen and seems to take about 30 seconds to put down. For reference, this is much, much more time than any other enemy we faced.

If you're looking for a fun, free top-down shooter to play with a friend, I'd recommend SAS: Zombie Assault 4 instead.

I am so glad Mattel is bringing some of Acceleracers back for us fans. The cars are amazingly detailed, right down to UKET on Chicane. I understand that  Ã∂RÃ∂eÃ∂vÃ∂eÃ∂rÃ∂bÃ∂ Vert's was renamed due to Mattel not trademarking it, but it still feels a little weird seeing that name. Environment is top notch and I love the little easter eggs hidden around. Overall this expansion is well worth $10 even if you are not an Acceleracers fan. Please support this to show Mattel us fans are still here and have interest in this IP.
I still can not believe this is an ACTUAL AcceleRacers EXPANSION; not just some cars which are cool nontheless but honestly i dreamed of this for such a long time jesus thank you for this so much

I love you Milestone and Mattel for not forgetting about the AcceleRacers fandom.

Chicane, Spine Buster, Rat-ified and [strike]Vert's[/strike] Reverb are great additions to the game and are faithful to their toy versions (I used to have Reverb myself). The Acceledrome is a fairly faithful recreation of what we saw in the movies back then and it still holds a special place in my heart. 

However there is one thing that is bothering me. In Hot Wheels Unleashed 1, the Expansion DLCs have at least one Track Module related to their respective expansion and the AcceleRacers DLC gets... none. It's mildly disappointing that no new modules are introduced, would have loved to see the Swamp Realm Monster again. Is it going to peg it down to me giving it a thumbs down? No, 10 bucks for 4 highly-popular cars and an Environment is fair.

They recreated everything pretty well. I love the detail they put into the new environment. This expansion gave me tons of nostalgia, and i could recognize pretty much everything, especially the references they used for the course names.

Thank you, Milestone for making my childhood dreams come to life in this expansion.
Even if you're not into Acceleracers, this is worth it. The enviroment is great, the new cars are great, the icons are great, pretty much this is great.

New map is great. Seeing AcceleRacers again after so long is wild. For $10 I'd say this is an excellent DLC. I just have one issue in that the ultimate time trial is unbeatable right now. With a time of 1:01 as the goal on a map that takes around 2 minutes to finish there just aren't any shortcuts that would make a time like that possible. Hopefully it gets patched soon
Cars and level are great! Though Reverb being renamed "Vert's" was an interesting choice....

wish the campaign map was bigger and it had realms but this is really well done, its not just some low quality room that was made to crash grab off fans stuff like the wheel of power in the middle is given nice detail and lightning. i had given up hope that this would happen but it did and its not crap. for $10 i say its worth more then most car games dlc and if your like me and grow up watching the movies then this is amazing.

Although I wish they added some of the classic sound effects from the movies (The Wheel of Power doesnt feel the same being so silent. And the old Nitrox would've been so amazing as a boost sound, and more interactive elements like the realm alarm system would've been cool), the amount of detail that has been added in the Acceledrome is pretty amazing. 
Being able to explore the Acceledrome in full 3D is a dream come true ever since I first saw the movies as a kid. And having even more Acceleracer cars added is always a plus!

As an owner of all these cars in real life, they are extremely well detailed and faithfully modeled to the real diecasts; even down to the community-adorned "ukeT" decal that appears on Chicane's livery in real life. The people reviewing/buying this DLC are Acceleracers/HW35 superfans, but I'm happy to report that this expansion is in-depth in terms of content too. The cars are the standout point for this DLC, but the AcceleDrome map is grandiose in scale and has the Wheel of Power boasting its gorgeous glow in the center of the map. The Acceleracers expansion comes with a mini-roadmap of events to do, just like the regular campaign. It also includes some profile stuff (profile pictures, card backgrounds, etc) for both Teku and Metal Maniac fans (no Silencerz or Racing Drones unfortunately). The events have famous quotes from the movies in their descriptions that pay homage to the franchise in a quirky and loving way too. This DLC expansion is absolutely worth the $9.99 in my opinion, but I'm certainly biased and should acknowledge that. My only gripe comes down to the fact that Reverb is renamed to "Vert's" in this game, which grammatically confuses me, and makes me groan as a pedantic Acceleracers superfan. They officially confirmed this is due to legal reasons, and thankfully the model remains accurate to the movie and IRL diecast anyways, so it's absolutely forgivable. 

This DLC is meant for the vocal minority of dedicated Acceleracers/HW35 fans who have been asking for new content over the past two decades, but I do think this DLC holds its value even despite that. Huge props to the developers and team behind this game for making it happen!

A very short hidden object game with really bad camera. Get it only at a huge discount.

The aim of the game is to select items from a list. There are only six little locations that may be finished in a few minutes, so you won't need much time to complete this. 

Stages are miniature, nicely detailed dioramas. Sadly, due to a camera that is fixed in the middle of the screen, the most of it will be overlooked. Despite being able to spin around, the camera cannot be moved around or rotated up and down. Since they are not transparent, you cannot see through walls to the other side. Zooming in and out is another pointless feature because it works only in the middle of the screen. 

As a result, finding stuff becomes incredibly challenging because you are unable to get a closer look. This may be possible in some stages if you click the magnifying glass symbol, but it only applies to certain areas, such as a drawer. This forces you to click at every tiny suspicious thing and hope it‚Äôs one of the items on the list.

Stages are not very interactive. The most you see are little objects that can be pushed around. This can create a problem because you might push something over an item and not even see it. However, clicking on everything is encouraged because you never know where you might find what you're looking for.

The vision of what this game could be is brilliant and i liked the way you could rotate and zoom in a little bit. Aside from that it falls short of what the game could be. The lighting sucks big time and i found myself clicking in dark areas hoping to come across one of the objects. I spent a lot of time just clicking blindly due to the terrible lighting. The camera functionality still needs some work too.

Very rough, but still enjoyable and some good mechanics for a hidden object game.

Had fun. More levels please. Thanks.

Worth the cheap price if you like these kind of "Hidden item" games

This game has potential to be a good backrooms game however there are many bugs that need to be fixed in order for it to be playable experience. I am giving this game a thumbs up since it has only just released and I feel like it get better with some fixes and tweaks to certain levels. I played with 2 friends and the experience was decent however there are some issues which I will list below.

1. The parkour level (level 7) is way too difficult especially for people who are not the host since you just clip through the platforms. I noticed that when you get to the lava spiral, the bottom few platforms prevent you from jumping half of the time and it is quite annoying (especially with how weird the jump mechanic is).

2. Level 8 is completely broken as I mentioned in the discussion that I posted and I just end up dying from sanity. Myself and my friend looked everywhere to try and find what we were suppose to do but we didn't find anything which leads me to believe that the level is bugged (in multiplayer at least). 

Other than these 2 major issues, I feel like the game is quite fun and is reasonably priced for the experience. I will also note that I did get a cheevo that was suppose to be given on level 10 randomly on level 8 while running on the road.
This game is fun to play with friends, and with all these unique levels, it's a whole new journey to play through. I recommend this if you like other backroom themed games! 4/5

As much as I want to give this indie developer a positive review and a recommend here, I can't do that if I'm being genuine and honest about the game state itself.  It's simply not worth the price with the performance issues, lack of basic sound effects, and game breaking bugs I've witnessed just on level 1 alone.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kGPQ2uNn2ko

The problems I experienced preventing my recommend of this game:

- When playing with friends co-op and you die and start spectating, you see 100x more sway that whoever you are spectating, making for an almost miserable spectating experience.  Ugh.  Fix this ASAP!

- When searching level one, one part of the level tanked my in game FPS to less than 10 fps, where other areas of the map I was getting over 70 fps.  I don't know what is causing this massive performance drop, but this is another major reason that I cannot recommend this game in its current state.  This is game breaking, especially if you're in a chase.. it absolutely DESTROYS the immersion and fun!  (I show this clearly in the video review)

- This game is missing basic sound effects that you'd expect in a game of this type.  No foot step sounds, no basic clicks and clanks when collecting or using items etc.  Adding tension music when in danger would also add a LOT to this game, and it's simply missing.  This isn't game breaking,  but it definitely hurts the overall experience.

- No UI to see the status of other players when playing co-op.  Why cant we not see the health and thirst levels of our friends in a small UI somewhere?  Again, this isn't game breaking, but why TF isn't this in the game?!?

I DO love that this developer has created completely unique puzzles and levels for this game that I have not seen in any of the other Backrooms games.  Do understand that because of this alone, I REALLY want to give this game a recommend and support this game and developer.  But I'd be dishonest to the developer if I recommended it with the massive game breaking problems that I've already experienced, and that's just one the first level. ..I can only imagine how many more game breaking problems there likely is on all the other 9 levels.

Dev.. *pats you on the back*.  I LOVE what you are trying to do here and I LOVE the potential here but you GOT to do a lot more work on this game to make it all that it truly can and deserves to be!  Get to it man, you have my support!  ..I'll be happy to re-review this game if you address the problems I've noted above.


NOT RECOMMENDED... even though it breaks my heart to do it.  It just needs some more work and I hope this developer or developer(s) get it all fixed up because this could be a HELLA FUN little indie game once it's in a better state.
It's a decent game with a reasonable price, I would recommend to check it out :)
