Self-Portrait is a game in which you consume yourself: You eat the chicken; you become one with the hatching eggs; you walk among every season of chicken; you explore the chicken island shaped like a chicken while you, yourself, are transformed into a chicken; you cross the road, leap, and die - full circle - a fried chicken. What you make and interpret from the game is your own self-portrait. 3.5/10

After all the time it took me to complete this game (9 minutes) 

I can tell you with certainty...

This is a ride. From birth, to death, to rebirth. I was just an egg floating through a river... then I was a grown chicken, flying towards the unknown. 
My friends did karate on trees, walked up fiery mountains, and danced by the fire
10/10

The audio settings doesn't save when you go into the actual game. The cut scenes need a skip button because they are way to long and you can't pause in the middle of one. There are random invisible barriers when walking around in the water and going up the mountain after the fire pit. It is amusing that the walk sfx of the chickens is a kick and snare drum beat. But that doesn't attain to much when i am busy fighting poor colliders and barriers. The amount of times i have clipped through the world or randomly teleported on top of the mountain that overlooks the starting water, just to fall back into the water. What trigggered this, exploring the map. Why would i be punished for doing what the game claims it is, an exploration game. I'd say the only good thing about this game is that it is short.

Never in my life has a gaem moved me as deeply as Self Portrait. I played it wiht my friends and they all madde fun of it the entire time. but they didn't experience it like I did. Just wqatching a play thoruhg isn't enouhg you must experience this game, truly experience it. To understand the life and soul and essence of chicken you need to take your time. The fire, the climb, the inevitable eath. All culminating in an existential experience of true bliss. 11 leprechauns out of 4 rainbows

What the fugg was this lmao
Someone must've played the brilliant "Pineapple on Pizza" and thought to himself "Man I can do this, too!", so they crafted this feverishly nightmarish asset-ripping abomination of a dreamlike world populated by levitating, horrifying kirby-esque chickens that shriek around with a obnoxiously high-pitched voice; leading the player to the very same punchline; just less poignant or polished in every conceivable way.

Paired with the endearingly terrible intro, the worst sound design and footstep sounds I've ever heard and random quotes from Picasso (!), this shidpost bad trip camouflaging as walking simulator confused, flabberghasted but ultimately entertained me in a so-bad-it's-good "trash" way, especially with it's overbearingly loud ending. Only lasted 15 minutes because I got reset twice (!) after falling through the map or getting launched high up in the sky.

It was a complete waste of time. It has the exploration tag but there is nothing to explore. There is nothing to do aside from follow the path. I have never regretted downloading a game this much before. At least it was free

This game alternates between point and click style rooms, rpg combat and minion management. The sex scenes are great, and the main character is definitely still an evil conqueror, but he has relatable problems like dealing with idiots, small town politics run by said idiots, and entertaining people who desperately want to part our dear Pleasuremancer with his hard earned gold. I'm still in the midgame section, the village section, but I'm almost finished with the main quest for this part. Your actions do have consequences, and nowhere is this more apparent than the introduction, where you can completely remove one of the main antagonists from play within the first ten minutes of gameplay. I would consider this a good thing, especially for a first play through. Combat is difficult in ways that can be equally frustrating to struggle through and rewarding to figure out the secrets of.
Ultimately, for a game still in development, it's great. But obviously, there's going to be some nitpicks, although most of them are quality of life perks. For example, when you buy the skeleton key for the baker's quest, it doesn't actually show up in your inventory, so the only reason you know that you have it is because the quest updated. My biggest issue here is that Guild quests are only available under certain circumstances, and disappear if you have saved or quicksaved the game recently. This isn't mentioned to you very clearly, if at all, and you only figure this out when you save before taking on said quest.
The English translation is evidently incomplete even at the beginning of the game, and starts breaking down about when you try to become mayor, but it is especially apparent during Autumn's quest. I wouldn't say it is immersion breaking though. In fact, I wouldn't mind if some of the alchemy recipes, wine names, or magic spells remained in French. The Early Access announcement said that this might be fixed soon, though.

[h1]Overview[/h1]
Having reached the peak of your craft, you've decided to banish yourself, wishing for better challengers in the future. As luck, or lack thereof, would have it, you find yourself summoned by goblins with a severe lack of intellect. As a result of their failed summonning, you now find yourself relieved of your powers and needing to re-establish yourself.

[h1]Review[/h1]
The most important thing first, this game is in Early Access, and as such will have problems here and there, but I want to underscore that this game oozes of love for the game, so clearly the creator has been pouring his or her heart into this one. It does have a few bugs, one that I kept triggering was when fighting paladins during the starting section. This can easily be bypassed with some save scumming, so at most an annoyance.

With that out of the way, the humor in this game is, while subjective, quite good, and has managed to coax a few smiles out of my soulforsaken face here and there. The game itself is mostly a nostalgia trip to point and click adventures of years passed, could absolutely see lucas games doing something like this if they decided that full on adult content were fine.

The looping BGM is quite degrading to the experience, and would appreciate a bit clearer early game goals explanation, just kinda pressing around and doing whatever lights up. While servicable as a point and click, it could really do with a bit more direction for the player.

One to keep an eye at.

English: 
Ah, my noble companions of the gaming adventure, allow me to recount my humble journey through this captivating universe‚Äîan RPG as complete as it is exhilarating, where every moment spent exploring its depths has stirred in me a fervor worthy of the chivalrous quests of old.

I have spent many an hour within its world, my fingers deft upon the keys, my thoughts devoted to finding the best path, restarting countless times to refine my strategies like a knight sharpening his sword. This game does not yield easily, my friends! No, its difficulty is a welcome surprise in a time where, alas, too many games simply guide us by the hand. Here, every decision bears weight, and every action must be carefully considered. Oh, let me tell you: save often, for a misstep could steer you away from certain rewards as precious as they are unexpected!

As for the more carnal delights the game offers, ah! They are a feast for the mind and heart, a gentle favor bestowed by the creator, in their generosity, as a gift to those who persevere through the adventure. These scenes, my friends, are of rare elegance, and I shall say no more, for they are treasures to be uncovered by your own efforts, hidden like gems within a labyrinth.

In short, this game is already quite complete even before its final release, and I assure you that both my gamer's heart and my more sensual inclinations have found all they could desire within. My companions, if you are among those who cherish strategy as much as passion, this RPG will surely fulfill your every expectation.

Save, strategize, and embark on the adventure! But remember, in this game, your "main" weapon isn‚Äôt just your sword‚Äîit‚Äôs the wisdom in your hands.

Don't bother if you're getting this for the extra story. The DEMO is complete garbage and just infuriating to get through. Honestly I'm glad I never played this "demo" before buying the actual game or I would have never touched it.

After digging into the first quarter patch, it still feels very badly balanced. Improvements came in the increased need to utilize items, but this came at the cost of inventory feeling overstuffed just to carry a viable loadout beyond 2 skull missions. Enemies become far too common to contend with in any quasimorphosis zone at higher rating because you will run out of food, medical supplies, ammo, or trigger quasimorphosis before you even reach the third floor unless you get lucky on the layout, as early as the beginnings of the mid-game once you've gotten a few unlocks.

Armor is still 'pass/fail', though the hp pool means a fail isn't always an instant kill. This could be improved but is at least workable, though most armors are useless because they don't cover the 'big three' of blunt/pierce/cut.

Weapons seem to really depend on special ammunition once enemies get armor which is fine but it's very RNG as to whether or not you get a useful ammunition you can make. There is some 'rock paper scissors' here but not much, especially since the more bloated inventory limits what you can carry as a backup.

Inventory is the last major hitch, there's just so much bloat. The economy is an interesting change but there is SO MUCH that is useless or niche, and little/no way to combine things in an approachable way, if you don't get the right chips you're basically SOL, and my attempts at farming chips for blueprints basically resulted in a lot of food items and no chips, despite many corps having high chip drop rates. Could be bad RNG, but I also wasn't finding any in the missions and was careful to avoid causing fires. Inventory bloat is the biggest issue r/n to me.

Play a game of chess with the troll and his own rules.

The game starts with a simple goal of crossing the bridge. However, you won't get too far because a troll is in your way. You can only get to the other side by playing a little chess game. There's no need to panic if you're unfamiliar with the rules. The troll will lend you his rulebook, which includes all you need to know.

Some of the pages are blank, but you can fill them in as you make mistakes. For instance, if you try to move the bishop in a straight line, you'll fail and obtain a new entry in the rulebook for appropriate movement. Also, this is not a real chess match. When the troll puts a bait that you can take with your pawn, you'll be surprised to fail because it's not how pawns behave in this game.

You use a mouse to move pieces around the board. You can pick up anything and position it anywhere, including your opponent's pieces, but this results in an automatic failure. That's why precision is essential. 

Every illegal move is considered cheating. Of course, the troll will try to win by making up some amusing rules. So the pawn may travel backwards, or the troll can move your queen. As long as the regulation is in the rulebook, it is valid.

The goal of the game is to play a normal round of chess while calling out the troll whenever he cheats. You accomplish this by selecting the chess piece and the rule that the troll violated. If you succeed, you can cheat yourself on the following turn. This allows you to go straight for the king.

However, there‚Äôs a catch. The troll plays with black chess pieces that have a special rule: once a king (the troll) is taken, another black piece can become the new king. This means the game will continue until no more black pieces remain on the board. 

Since it doesn‚Äôt take long to beat the troll, the game adds loads of achievements that need special steps to complete. Some of them are funny and might even lead to different endings.

Imagine playing chess against a 6-year old who changed a bunch of the rules without telling you, and cheats, but is bound by honor to reward you any time to catch them cheating. Now move to a bridge, turn the kid green and give them horns, and BAM: you're playing King of the Bridge.

Short. Feel like I'm done with it after 1h.

But at the same time pretty good.

It's basically about playing chess against someone who's made up some dumb rules on the spot and occasionally cheats but also sucks bad so you can beat him without cheating at all.

Decent enough, but I think it's currently overrated.

If the game's gimmick catches your eye, then it might be worth the low asking price for a couple hours' amusement.
If you have only a passing interest in the concept, then price aside, it may just not be worth your time.

[hr][/hr]
[b]My Experience[/b]

I beat the troll on my first attempt and achieved the bad ending - it turns out that if even if you only "cheat legally" as payback after correctly accusing the troll of cheating, you are still considered to be a cheater in general.

I lost my second game after cheating by misclicking - the punishment for this is the immediate loss of your king.

I got the good ending on my third attempt.

I played a few more games for achievements, and I now have the majority of those currently available. However, for reasons explained later, I've lost interest in seeking the rest.

[hr][/hr]
[b]Complaints, Opportunities, Other Thoughts[/b]

The rulebook never changes. Some rules are obscured until the troll reveals them via his own moves, but the rules are always the same under those mysterious dust clouds on the rulebook pages.

I was hoping that the advertised "Intelligent Troll AI" meant that there was a (partially) randomized set of rules, and that the troll might sneakily choose to reveal rules from that set only when it's to his benefit, even though his past moves may have violated the rule while it was hidden. In reality, the rules are constant and the troll obeys them all until he randomly picks a turn to cheat, once every handful of turns.

The troll's AI is actually quite rudimentary. The challenge primarily comes from the need to capture [i]all[/i] of his pieces, as the black crown has a very inclusive line of succession.

To cheat means to freely move a single existing piece, be that yours or the troll's. You cannot swap, promote, or reintroduce captured pieces, nor can the troll. The troll's payback cheat is always to take your king and end the game. Otherwise, his "unprovoked" cheats appear to be limited to moving a single piece [i]slightly illegally[/i]. Usually this means a diagonal pawn, a two-step king, a B/R/Q hop, or moving one of your pieces (in a way that would still be legal for you). I have never seen him attempt to move a rook diagonally, a bishop orthogonally, or a knight in a non-L pattern.

(There's another review complaining that it's impossible to win without payback cheating, but you just need to learn the troll's unprovoked cheating limitations. I'm not even good at chess and I won cheat-free on my second-and-a-half try. Global achievement stats show that right now, over a quarter of players have managed it as well.)

You apparently can never get away with your own unprovoked cheating. Whether you cheat subtlety or egregiously, you'll get caught and lose your king every time. There's no mechanic, for example, to track the troll's building suspicion. He interrupts every so often to warn you not to act while he's looking away, but this - like all his commentary - is just flavor text and isn't represented in the actual gameplay. (The troll king piece sadly does not somersault when he discusses somersaulting.)

The silly goose featured in the trailer never interacts with the game. You may summon him to witness your grand victory or embarrassing defeat, but he cannot serve as an ace up your sleeve (or a queen on your board) to turn the tables against dire odds. He is only ever a silly goose.
(Note: There is a... goose-based comedic event, but it's sort of outside the actual gameplay. The goose may as well be a lily pad, a leaf, or a bubble in this scenario.)

Once you unveil the last rule, that's it. There's some replayability if you're hunting achievements, but beware:
[olist]
    [*]When you win a game, there's an unskippable ending "cutscene" before credits roll. If you exit the game before the credits, it puts you back at the beginning of this tedious cutscene.
    [*]The troll cheats frequently, and by cheating he can preclude many of the achievements. Setting up the right conditions for certain achievements thus becomes a matter of endurance - how many times are you willing to restart?
[/olist]

[hr][/hr]
All in all, this feels like an incomplete exploration of an otherwise promising game concept. At the price point, I don't feel [strike]cheated[/strike] ripped off (I feel very cheated), though knowing what I know now, my advice for my past self would be:

This is literally just chess against someone who thinks they know how chess works and then they got to add like 15 rules for flavor without thinking about game balance whatsoever. Perfect game

A fun chess based game with a great twist!
The game is fast paces, quick, frustrating but fun anyway. I know some other games that are 'Chess but with a twist'. But this game is one of the best ones. It comes with a fun gimmick that allows you to really enjoy the game. Either as someone who tries to follow the rules, or someone who wants to break the rules.

For this low price, I can only recommend this game!

Game is relatively simple once you get all the rule entries figured out, and for the most part, you unlock them by moving that respective piece a lot, or losing due to "cheating", because it doesn't move the way you think it does. 

From a strategy perspective: 
-Pawn has the biggest changes. You can't promote them, they move/capture similar to a rook but only 1 square at a time. This also implies that you can't "en passant" or move 2 squares/capture diagonally, and you'll want to advance them at least in a "buddy system", where you keep 2 or more close together, no longer forming diagonal rows for protection like in regular chess.
-Knight behaves identically to regular chess, except it's severely less flexible due to how pawns move.
-Rooks mustn't touch, lest they become a useless piece. They can also "eat" your own pieces, though that's hardly useful.
-Bishops leave "landmines" in the squares they visited, so it's not very practical to keep them inside the game board (yes they can leave the game board now...). They are VERY annoying to capture, especially in cheatless runs, so you can either make sure to prioritize killing them whenever possible, or kill all other pieces, then repeatedly kill the enemy king so the bishops on the outside turn into new kings.
-Queens are less useful, due to 2 new rules added to them, which I won't spoil, but their best use case is to try to snipe enemy pieces.

What I noticed: 
-The troll will never cheat-kill your king, if he kills your king, it's because you left it hanging (there are no checks in this game). 
-He does, however, love to cheat rule 9 and snipe your queen from its' starting position, with his own queen, so make sure to move it diagonally as soon as possible to the 2nd or 3rd rank. If he does this, since your king is now in danger, you can't really benefit from accusing him of cheating, because you WILL have to kill the queen immediately anyway.
-He also often snipes your rooks with his own, but if he does that, you can just kill it with your rook pawn, or accuse him of cheating, grab his rook and drag it ontop of the knight or pawn (if unmoved) beside his other rook. This is probably the biggest advantage you can get by reverse-cheating in this game.
-Apart from blatantly breaking rule 9 with almost every single opportunity he gets, the troll also likes to move things other than bishops out of bounds, move your own pieces, move his pawns diagonally, move his knights diagonally(mostly when capturing), stack pieces ontop of eachother, and when left with few options, his king also sometimes moves 2 tiles. I haven't noticed him using any other cheats in the ~4.5 hours it took me to beat the game.

Thoroughly enjoyed this game. The funny spin on chess and multiple endings are cool, but I really liked the personality put into the game itself. The witty Troll, the rules, and the torn out pages laying around (Would have been a rule against that the evil one if he kept it in).

For those who want the full Rule Book for this game I made a guide [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3198178425]here[/url]. NOTE* IT CONTAINS A LITTLE BIT OF SPOILERS, as these pages are unlocked as you play or accidentally make illegal moves.

I am happy the author/developer of the game is seeing success with their game and the fact it has exploded. I personally have been showing friends and spreading awareness of this game because its cheap and entertaining for the price.

I would like to recommend if there were to be a small update the ability to skip the credits after you win a couple times if possible.
It's like playing chess with a little kid who doesn't quite understand how to play. 10/10

This review is specially made for those who like to get all the achievements in games (minor spoilers ahead).

[b]Description:[/b]
King of the Bridge is a short indie, low budget chess game where you play against a troll that makes his own chess rules and each rule page is only revealed after the rule is used or broken. Besides the ‚Äúcustom‚Äù rules the troll also cheats, and if you catch him and point out which rule he broke you cheat to cheat yourself. Cheating or simply breaking a rule you didn‚Äôt know will make you lose the game and restart the match, so prepare to lose a lot of games in the first hours of the game.

There isn‚Äôt a very elaborate story, you‚Äôre trying to cross the bridge and the troll is there challenging you and depending on what you do during the chess match you will unlock one of the four different endings the game has.

The graphics are very simple and basic, made with pixel art and a color scheme that reminds me of the first gameboys with the tones of green and the low screen resolution, but this isn‚Äôt a deal breaker because the gameplay is what the game is all about.

The game is fun to play but until you know the more important rules it can be frustrating at first. After a few hours you‚Äôll start winning your first games and then you can try to get the most difficult achievements. But if you're not going for the achievements the game doesn‚Äôt offer much more than this. There aren‚Äôt new, more difficult enemies, and no new boards, only a few speed chess game modes in the options. It might not justify the 3 EUR price tag but it can still be worth it if you can purchase it with a discount.

[b]Achievements:[/b]  
[b]How many:[/b] 37 Achievements.
[b]How much time:[/b] Around 4 to 6 hours, depending on luck and skill.
[b]Game difficulty:[/b] Easy, once you get used to the new rules.
[b]Achievements‚Äô Difficulty:[/b] Medium. Most of the achievements will pop up after you play a few games and keep trying new things with the chess pieces, but a few will require wiping the save file or adapting your play style, like the juggler, overkill, the great beyond and happy ever after. Still, most aren‚Äôt very hard to get, and here are a few tips to help you, after you have already played a few games:[spoiler]
1 - The best cheat move is to move a rook over another piece next to the other rook, this way they‚Äôll get a castle and effectively lose 3 pieces (this will also get you an achievement). If you can‚Äôt do this just move the rook over a queen or the queen (or another piece) into the holes that the bishops leave.  
2 - The horses are the best pieces to get the stray pawns without vertical or horizontal support. 
3 - You can move your bishops outside the board to attack the rooks if the troll moves the pawn that protects them.
4 - There is no point in attacking the troll too early in the game, just wait until you can capture it without having to sacrifice a piece.
5 - For the speed achievements, set the game mode to the fastest and keep restarting until you finish the game in less than 10 minutes to get all 4 or 5 achievements at once.[/spoiler]


[b]Overall opinion:[/b]  
King of the Bridge is a short indie, low budget chess game with simple graphics but that has a creative and original gameplay. It‚Äôs fun to play but that doesn‚Äôt offer much content besides getting all the endings and achievements.

Short game, but great value for the price tag. The twist on chess is fairly unique and fun enough to want to play a few games of it. It was also pretty fun hunting all the achievements

First game I've rated, and man does it deserve it. Best played as blind as possible, this game very much captures how it feels to play chess for the first time. I'm flabbergasted that this game is as poorly known about as it is. An absurdly good deal for it's $3 pricetag, the game's only flaw is it's relative lack of content. However this chess parody has a lot of potential to be expanded upon, both in rules, dialogue, endings (why is there no ending for covering every tile with knowledge?), and with a few minor tweaks, maybe even online multiplayer. I look forward to seeing where this game's development process takes it.

A good game, takes normal Chess rules and breaks a couple of them in some fun ways that change the game, but it's still Chess at heart. Even does a decent job of teaching you how to think about Chess moves since the bad guy mainly only cheats when you do something that you should avoid doing in real Chess, but when the bad guy cheats you get to call him on it and cheat right back. So it creates a fun back and forth of your bad moves will let you do a really great move also.

Once you want to try to win without cheating you have to really think the game through like a real game of Chess, so it can still scratch that itch of feeling like you're good at Chess.

I learned after finally starting Iris off on her own that standing in the back row and summoning your spirit directly in front of you to tank every attack for the first few fights is *the bomb*. After that, it was more a question of building around her spirits taking hits than anything else, and I finally got my first win that way.

Here's the skinny: Iris has several character-specific events to complete in order to unlock new spirits as she goes, and you'll need to start figuring out your strategy (like moving her to the back row so you can summon in front of her) from basically the word go in order to get the most out of her. Until you do, the mid game is going to be pretty tough. I'm still learning strategies, but even more so than the other DLC Characters I believe she's worth checking out and playing around with. I don't know if she's capable of randomly showing up in other campaigns, but based on how the game shifts around her I strongly suspect not.

At this price she's worth getting, ESPECIALLY considering what other companies seem to think is worth charging for paid DLC, and I doubt you'll regret picking her up even if you don't end up playing her long enough to max out her experience bar. I'm happy to have played her campaign, and will again soon!

In the DLC's current state I cannot recommend it. The character seems cool and the design is interesting but the
starting deck is intolerably bad. With the inclusion of the basic deck's blocking cards and the hero specific blocking cards it is
very difficult to deal any damage to the opponents. Leading to multiple turns just having to sit there and slowly die as you cannot deal any damage. This is especially true with status dealing bosses and enemies such as Spitter who I have lost several runs to as I was unable to deal any damage over multiple turns due to the excess of blocking cards in the deck. The character would be a lot more fun if the basic blocking cards were replaced by the character specific ones.

Update: With the adjustment having made with the blocks the character now plays significantly better than before and I would now recommend it.
Insanely strong (and really fun to use) character with cool and interesting scenarios. If you liked the base game, but want some more - give Iris a try.
Definitely the most creative addition to the cast yet. Using spirits on their own or to possess party members is a lot of fun.

Iris is hands down the best DLC character ... and probably the best character in the game. Period.

You start off with +1 companion (if you want, but I think you should) and 1 spirit. At first this is pretty slow, but depending on a bit of luck and intelligent pathing, you will soon get more spirits with even more powerful effects. Iris's spirits can basically take up the entire battlefield if you want them to.

At the end I just had my trusty Weasel (the 2nd strongest character, but kinda required, since Iris herself isn't damage heavy) and a mouse for some additional support and just breezed through the final fights with Warden, Spymaster and Prince. Her spirits are so overwhelming when used correctly that there is almost no danger, unless enemies move you or attack through your spirits, which is very rare.

Also the only character I've bothered using Ruin centric cards with, since by unlocking spirits you automatically get Ruin cards you can't get rid of anyway.

And she's just a ton of fun to play, the new scenarios are nice as well. Good job on this one!

The new character is fun, I purchased all DLC to support the developer, but please make the hero from DLC be able to change weapons and armors like normal character. Forbit that just took away a lot of the fun.

id recommend for ppl that play the game regularly. its better than the powdermaster DLC which i didnt like since it didnt allow you to party with other team members right away.

Nevertheless, I really enjoyed the game and can only recommend it to players that liked the game base  - especially given the fair price!

An Exciting Preview of Fatalzone: Outbreak

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ

I had the privilege of getting an early look at the upcoming auto shooter, Fatalzone: Outbreak, and I must say, it's shaping up to be a promising addition to the world of gaming. While I can't provide a final verdict, here's a preview of what I've experienced so far.

First off, the graphics in Fatalzone: Outbreak are nothing short of impressive. The attention to detail in the game's post-apocalyptic setting is commendable. The environments are richly textured, and the character models look realistic. The lighting effects and animations contribute to the immersive experience, creating a world that feels truly lived-in and post-apocalyptic.

Gameplay-wise, the auto shooter mechanics add a unique twist to the traditional shooter genre. The controls are intuitive and easy to grasp, making it accessible for both casual gamers and seasoned shooters. The auto-aim feature simplifies aiming, allowing players to focus more on tactics and strategy. However, it's worth noting that this mechanic might not appeal to hardcore shooter fans who prefer manual aiming for precision.

The variety of weapons and gear available in Fatalzone: Outbreak is promising. Customization options for your character and weapons appear to be robust, adding depth to the gameplay. Experimenting with different loadouts and strategies keeps the experience engaging and enjoyable.

The storyline, from what I've seen, has potential. It sets up an intriguing post-apocalyptic world with its own unique lore, and I'm looking forward to seeing how it unfolds as the game develops further. The characters, while not deeply explored in the preview, have the potential to become engaging figures in the narrative.

One thing to keep in mind is that the preview build I experienced had a few bugs and optimization issues, which is common for early access or pre-release versions. However, I'm confident that the development team will address these issues before the final release.

In summary, Fatalzone: Outbreak shows a lot of promise as an auto shooter. Its stunning graphics, accessible gameplay, cooperative multiplayer, and potential for deep customization make it worth keeping an eye on. While it's not without its early issues, I'm excited to see how the game evolves and whether it lives up to its potential upon release. If you're a fan of shooters and post-apocalyptic settings, Fatalzone: Outbreak is definitely one to watch.

An excellent game in the spirit of Vampire Survivor and Brotato! Cool evacuation mechanics, great combat gameplay and the fun of being able to lose everything when your character dies! Cool! A perfect example of a Bullet Hell game!

The game is pretty fun to play. I loved it more than other vampire-like games thanks to its fresh (to the genre) setting and the base progression. Also, there is a real risk factor which is - if you lose during the raid, you lose the character completely - with all of their progress. So you have to be careful and plan your actions as you can only leave in one piece during evacuation sequences which are pretty rare. There are lots of perks and classes available to make the replayability much better. The style is a combo between comic book style and something like oil painting. I can recommend this over the other similar games of this genre!

ultimately the decent setting and art doesn't compensate for the frustrating gameplay imo.

Alright, I am flabbergasted at the negatives reviews so far for this nice little demo/prelude to the upcoming full game.

- Someone complains that the game only offers 30 to 40 minutes, but it has a high replay value and there are several unlocks with this FREE demo here.  I'd guess there are actually many hours here in this.  Even still, if the game looks good, what is wrong with 30 or 40 minutes in a FREE demo and how does that constitute a negative review?  God, people are stupid.

- Someone else complains that the game doesn't tell you where the helicopter is and leaves a negative review for that.  Uhhh, the game makes it BLATANTLY OBVIOUS where the evacuation helicopter is with a big arrow on the screen and a timer of how long you have before it leaves.  Again, people are STUPID.. and leaving negative reviews based on their own obvious game ignorance rather than the game itself.  Geezes.

- And again, someone else just left a negative review because every unlockable wasn't available here in this FREE DEMO.  Yet again, STUPIDITY.  Reeeeeeee, why would you ever want or buy their upcoming full game if they gave you everything for "free" in this demo!?!?  Ugh, sometimes I am embarrassed to witness the absolutely stupidity other people display in their ridiculously unfair reviews.

------- What I Like about this Demo: --------

- The zombies and enemies have a good variety and speed keeping you on your toes and keeping the game interesting and engaging.

- Very responsive controls and no FPS slowdown no matter how many enemies are on the screen 

- Great variety of pick-up options

- I love the different resources that you collect like components, food, and gold that all help you buy new upgrades from your base

- The base screen is very nice and unique main screen that does will in this particular zombie VS game.  Each building has it's own purpose and upgrades

- LOTS of stats about your gameplay after each wave and every game.  

- LOTS of specs always showing you all abut your current character you are playing and exactly what you're at for damage, protection, movement speed, and much more.


 -------  WHAT I'D LIKE TO SEE IN THE FULL GAME:  -------

I'd like to see the ability to turn off auto attack and control where you are shooting with your mouse cursor.  Maybe tie this to the right mouse button or the space bar?  ..Sometimes I might want to turn on manual shoot direction control to focus on bosses or faster moving enemies.  More control to the player is ALWAYS a good option in these kinds of games.



THIS DEMO IS SOLID AF..  If you are a fan of VS like games, this is free.  Give it a try and make up your own mind.  I just cannot understand why this demo at this point on its launch day has 3 out of 4 negative reviews that are so unfair and based more on the reviewers own stupidity rather than the quality of what's here now.

I like it and look forward to the full game launching.  ..But then again, I'm not a blithering idiot like the current bashers now.

FatalZone: Outbreak Steam Review #122 By HyPo Jeanuary von Messerschmitt
Rating: 4/10
I read some of the reviews and i agree this should have been a demo on the Storefront and NOT as a prologue and have a separate Steam store page. What is here is quite decent. Combat is fun, unlocking new stuff is fun. 
Mutation and infection and balancing between different classes is nice in terms of adding variety.
The only map this game has is quite basic in terms of design and art direction. The game in my view lacks enemy variety and has a couple of generic enemies which is fine. I don't know why but everything felt done right but empty, like there is something missing everywhere, i get and understand this is a demo version but it's a yikes from me. If this is meant to be like a first impression of sorts. I enjoyed playing the game but can't really see myself spending full price on the game from what i played. Evacuation feature is kinda neat.  So fellas, this feels like a mobile game but in a good rather then a bad way. I don't know what else to say if i am being honest. I think the demo version is quite barren for a demo and lacks enough content to be fun. I am sorry if my opinion is a bit terrible and i hope when i play the full game ,the issues i have are resolved and the pacing of the game and progression save it from it being out right average like this demo version presents the game as. Average and empty. Enough said fellas.

Day 1: First character had a uzi...wait why is he missing every single shot?
Day 2: I underestimated the crafty zombies, they've gotten to the dev team who are now gibbering giblets on a random studio apartments floor...
Day 3: I left a negative review as my final sign of resistance and will be returning to playing ai generated games as at least they tend to work on a fundamental level.

P.S. Not being able to aim is normal in this genre, the automatic aiming and gunning not trying to hit anything is not. Requiring several levels of mobility, which you might skip or not get, to extract was also puzzling.
Everyone starts with armour that makes them attack slower, and the attack speed was slow to begin with...why?
The few "innovations" are mashing it with delaying tactics that gate progress from pay2win mobile games, which actively get in the way of an already tedious and annoying gameplay loop.

Play anything else, including the ai generated slop, it is very much fun to play 98% of these.

Incredibly satisfying bullet-hell game!

Its a well made zombie version of vampire survivors with some more options gameplay-wise

I think this game has a lot of potential, but right now it feels like zombie-flavoured Vampire Survivors. I would love t see the base-building mechanic expanded and possibly something added to the maps. Rather than having random lootboxes I think it'd be cool to have looting locations, such as houses or cabins set up instead. These would create a need for exploration and create risk/reward kill-zones to add some spice to an otherwise relatively... aimless experience. The achievements unlocking new weapons and items also seems a bit off. We have a base-building mechanic, so it'd be great if that was implemented instead of the achievement-unlocks. Perhaps with building certain buildings or "tech" (kind of XCom-style maybe?). For now it's definitely not a BAD game, but it feels a lot like "just a Vampire Survivors reskin" and I think it has the potential to be so much more and bring something new to this genre.

EDIT: a lot of the upgrades also fall into the Vampire Survivors-philosophy of just increment stat-ups. But there's a grenade launcher, a frag grenade and shock grenades, perhaps these could be combined into a single upgrade-tree. Start off with the frag grenade and as it maxes out allow the player to pick between the launcher for extra distance or the shock grenades for the stun. Lastly a positive note: I love the extraction mechanic. It allows me to choose how long my run is going to be and bail early if I screwed up.

EDIT EDIT: okay I just got the spear weapon as my primary... and please for the love of god let me aim it

I am giving it a recommend based purely on the overall feel of it. The character dialog is pretty cute, the level design is kinda neat in town (though very basic), the dungeon design was kinda average-but-different. I don't know what they will eventually make out of the game, but it has potential. If nothing else, it's a pretty good example of "up front coolness." With the dialog and characters, the vibe reminds me of Maniac Mansion kind of (even though you're only playing one character). If they end up adding more unique dialog/interactions for the individual townspeople and their houses, could be a cult classic. But I still like the vibe.

I should mention that the combat is very very very VERY picky early. Basically, you gotta wait until there in one square between you and the enemy, the you gotta jump the last square so you're right next to them and attack right away, then you gotta jump away if you don't want to get hit. Not so hard with one enemy, but get a few around you and it gets to be a chore.

Dunno if it changes later, since I am only playing this every once in awhile, but it's not horrible so long as you follow the pattern. At least one enemy has had a different movement pattern as well, which makes it tricky.

You can also just run past stuff, but then you lose out on drops. Combat also feels like more of a puzzle, which is better or worse depending what you like. It does not feel like a Zelda clone, since you basically get your butt kicked if you just jump on enemies. That could be a positive or a negative, depending how you want to view it.

To do well, I recommend playing it, getting the pattern down, and then watching the preview video for the game on the store page. You'll be like "AHHH so that's how I don't die."

A friend told me about this game because it has a story that's pretty similar to what happened with my family. I lost my sister almost 10 years ago, and it still affects us today. I got really emotional playing Adam's Diary. I totally recommend it. The game is awesome.

I'm not much of a computer gamer, but I read The Midnight Town book and totally fell in love with the story. When I heard they dropped this spin-off, I got super intrigued and curious. I couldn't wait for a Playstation version. 

Loved the game's storyline, as always, well-written and makes you think about your own life/family/choices. The game is immersive, and I was hooked for hours on end, couldn't stop until I finished. I lost a page along the way, but I'm definitely playing it again to snag that missed page. The puzzles are straightforward and all you have is to pay attention to the details and you will be able to solve everything. The zombies added an action vibe to the game. The standout is definitely the narrative.

I'm a game developer too so I know how tough it is to create a game from start to finish. Especially when your learning to code from scratch. I found the game very consistent, with a sad but good story well-crafted environments and a perfect atmosphere for the  horror genre. Not too many jump scares and a tense atmosphere. 10/10 here.

However, I suggest you to optimize the game a bit more in the next updates. 15GB is a lot. I also think the page collection system could be improved, as well as the options and inventory. Also support to other languages would be great and would increase the sales significantly. 

Other than that, it's an excellent game. Totally worth the price. I recommend it and I'm excited to see what you guys have planned for the future.

The game's story had me hooked from start to finish especially because its based on real events. You can tell the developers put a lot of heart and effort into it. I checked out some YouTube videos before buying the game and in every one the developers make sure to thank the YouTubers who played the game. Solid 10 for the hard work, dedication, love, and the great end result.

This is a great game. I was impressed that this is the first game made by just 3 people who recently started studying development. 

Pros: The graphics are beautiful. Seriously. There are loads of Easter Eggs everywhere so make sure you check all the interactions. The gameplay flows well, and the story is based on real events, which piqued my curiosity and made me play the game TWICE as I lost two pages in the first playthrough. The environment is rich and every piece of the scenery brings a memory to Adam. The devs putted everything together really well.

Cons: The achievement system isn't working correctly. In my first playthrough I only got 2 achievements. Two pages was missing so I decided to replay it today because I was curious to know more about Adams life and to my surprise the achievements that should have appeared in my first gameplay showed up in my second lol. The flashlight's light is irritating when you reload the weapon it shines too much. Sometimes the sound of picking up ammo is sooooo low that we can't hear it. The game's music could have been a bit more crafted to create a scarier atmosphere with more jump scares. These are minor details that don't ruin the experience, but since I see the devs update the game regularly, here's my tips for future updates.

I recommend this game to everyone who likes history and escape rooms. If you enjoy exploring the scenery to find an exit, this game is for you.
This game is really good and worth the price. It lasts about an hour and a half and is perfect for those who love stories and paying attention to details.
I saw this game on the YouTube channel HGH Horror Games House and I got really into the story. Graphics are awesome for an indie game.

Its crazy that just a few peeps made this game and there aint no bugs. Makes you think big rich companies gotta get their shit together. The story was awesome hit me right in the gut cause Ive dealt with some serious bullying myself. Still messes with me even nowdays. Game looks sick had a blast playing it.
Couple of things though: The flashlights kinda annoying when your reloading the gun  and sometimes the sounds off like you cant hear when you pick up ammo or when Adams already speaking and you pick up something like a page its like hes talking over himself saying two things at once which can get pretty confusing. But other than that the games pretty solid.

Immersive, challenging and scary experience. You have to do a good search for clues in order to solve the puzzles, but definitely rewarding to make a door open.
I recommend this game for those escape room fans with eagle sight.

A Chilling Experience - A Must-Play for Horror Fans!

Rating: 9/10

I've just had the pleasure of playing this excellent horror game, and I must say it's been a wild ride! While I haven't finished the game yet, I couldn't help but take a moment to share my thoughts on what I've experienced so far.

The gameplay is incredibly well-designed, with a keen sense of tension and fear expertly crafted by the developers. The jump scares are expertly timed, making me shriek with surprise more than once! The atmosphere is tense and foreboding, with an eerie soundtrack that perfectly complements the on-screen action.

The sound design is particularly noteworthy. The pounding on the windows, the creaking of doors, and the distant echoes of unknown sounds all come together to create a sense of unease and dread. It's amazing how effectively these sound effects can manipulate your emotions and make you feel like you're right there in the midst of the horror.

The storyline is also well-written, tackling modern-day issues that resonate with contemporary audiences. The game's narrative is thoughtful and thought-provoking, exploring themes that are relevant to our world today. It's a refreshing change from the usual horror tropes and clich√©s, and it keeps me engaged and eager to find out what happens next.

If you're a fan of horror games, do not hesitate to pick this one up. It's a masterclass in building tension and suspense, and it's sure to keep you on the edge of your seat. Even though I haven't finished the game yet, I'm already eager to see how it concludes.

Recommendation: If you enjoy horror games with a strong focus on storytelling, atmospheric sound design, and modern themes, this game is a must-play.

The Midnight Town Stories: Adam's Diary" is an immersive blend of Escape Room, Visual Novel and Horror genres. Not very comfortable shooting and I didn‚Äôt like it, but it has a cool horror atmosphere, good story and simple but interesting puzzles.

The game is packed with clever puzzles, intriguing characters, and a gripping storyline that kept me hooked from start to finish! The haunting atmosphere and eerie soundtrack added to the overall experience, making it a must-play for fans of mystery and adventure games.

For their first game this is excellent and being developed by just two people (with the third being the sound designer) the game is excellent. The story is based on real events and very well structured. The background music is really good. The only thing that falls a bit short is the shooting system ‚Äì when you reload the gun the light gets in the way a bit and it would be nice marking the zombies when we hit them with shots. Besides that, it's a great game. I'm curious to see what comes next.

The Midnight Town Stories: Adam's Diary" is an exciting adventure in a gloomy city where mysterious forces and mysterious events await the hero at every turn. The game has a fascinating plot, deep characters and an exciting atmosphere that seems to envelop you, not letting you tear yourself away from the screen.

The main character, Adam, finds himself embroiled in a complicated conspiracy, and his diary becomes the key to solving the mysteries he will face. From meeting mysterious characters to solving complex puzzles, players will embark on an exciting journey full of unexpected plot twists.

So the concept of this game is neat, but the execution leaves much to be desired. The game is designed around the idea of making your way up an obstacle course full of difficult jump puzzles and punishing you by effectively restarting you if you mess up, which can be rather frustrating if you are a ways in and happen to make a mistake. Fine, whatever, people are into that.

The issue with this game is that, despite clearly being put together with a bunch of pre-made assets (no hate on folks that choose to do that - it's more than I've done), there are a number of frustrating bugs that can effectively ruin a person's run. Having played for a number of hours, slowly progressing through the game, My fellow players and I have noticed a number of issues, most notably:

-Improperly placed assets make it so your character doesn't grip a ledge they are supposed to, or instead decides to kick off the asset instead of climbing it.

-Character randomly slides left or right when climbing, occasionally leading the player to ultimately stand on open air, 
 or on a tilted ledge, resulting in a fall

-Inconsistent player controls. Occasionally, your character will overrun instead of stopping, though it is not consistent. Sometimes they do, sometimes they don't. Sometimes the character stops after a jump, sometimes, they kick off the surface into a second jump. Sometimes, you have pretty full control of your character in the air, other times, your character simply will not move while in the air.

-Character not responding to commands. For example, sometimes (okay, a bit more often than sometimes), upon attempting to jump, your character simply forgets how to jump.

-Player gripping inside of objects, instead of the surface of those objects.

-Invisible walls, particularly toward the later portions of the game. At one point, I came across an arcade, and seeing quite clearly where I was supposed to go, my character just kept getting stopped by invisible walls. There was no proceeding straight toward my destination; I had to move back and forth around an invisible obstacle course just to reach the end of the sidewalk, where upon jumping on a bed, my character was forced into another invisible wall that felt like a cage I was forced to push myself out the side of to try again, only for the same result - and yes, this is where I was supposed to go. I was not out of bounds. The assets simply haven't been refined.

-And finally, the most frustrating of all, which we've seen a number of times; the character getting stuck in an endless jump animation, unable to move at all, forcing the player to have to go into the game's  menu and "restart," placing you at the beginning.

Look, I'm all for games that choose to punish the player for their mistakes, but when it's been fine-tuned to the point where it doesn't feel like the player's mistake was simply paying to own a copy of the game. Until the bugs are worked out, there should at least be a mode that allows the player to reset back to a saved point.

And what I find the most ridiculous here is that the game's "training mode" is locked behind completion of the game itself. What?

So again, I understand and appreciate the concept, but there's a lot to be desired as far as the execution goes before I could personally recommend folks buy this title. I'm sure I'll get through it eventually (I'm simply happy my brother managed it after 13+ hours), but one should not have to work around a series of bugs and glitches screwing them and rely on a hope and a prayer in order to actually finish the game.

At the very least, until they either open access to training or offer a mode that allows save points, I cannot and will not recommend it.

This game has truly amazing visuals and sounds.  The characters are well-developed/realistic and their expressions are expressive not limited to just a few expressions either.  This game scared the living crap out of me.  I got a mediocre ending after getting a slightly happy one.  The backgrounds and the monsters are truly amazing.  The story is really scary and really fascinating.  The story is very unique.  The price is wonderful.  It is about 2 to 3 hours for under four dollars and it's a great buy.  I was immersed but not obsessed - I've been playing games for so long I can't really get immersed but I was invested.  I recommend Steam games Stella of the End, Akyths, Ceiba, the anime Here and There Then and Now, and Slay the Princess game.  This game is a true gem.  The plot alone is compelling enough but the truly outstanding visuals and extraordinarily immersive sound effects make for a true horror VN masterpiece with no puzzles (I like it that way - I am a VN lover).  Oh I can't figure out the Happy End yet but I'll try again tommorrow because I am emotionally drained from the rollercoaster of emotional turmoil.   It's extremely scary so be warned.  The hero is a sweetheart, a true hero, before the story begins, in the middle, and at the end.  I liked the Native American characters - that made it more interesting to me - horror should have diverse characters like any other genre.  Also, try Entropic Float - this is like that too just spiritually but Entropic Float is more realistic and moderate horror but this game are spiritual horror game cousins.

From the captions, I thought Deep Under would be all about cultists full of murderous mole people with purple tentacles on their noses, worshipping an elder god beneath us. After finishing this game it surpasses my expectations with many original ideas, bringing something new to the table and not relying on tropes and clich√© we're used to to seeing. Making the whole playthrough a horror game compact with mystery and suspenseful moments thanks to the audio design making realistic sounds like heart beating and deep breathing to help make the situation tense.

My 2 main requests to make this game better are to have more save files (maybe 3 extra), and more sound audio variation as it started to become noticeable those that were being reused often. Other than that, this was a solid game you should play for something imaginative and rooted in making the players expose multiple choices to undercover some answers to a question lurking around.

[quote][b][url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asset_flip]Warning: Asset Flip![/url][/b]
"Music Man 2: New land" is a Digital Homicide style asset flip, or what Valve calls a "Fake Game". The "developer" paid for/pirated a few Unreal Marketplace packs, dumped them all in a blender, and submitted it to Valve as if they're real game developers.[/quote]

Two notable criteria for what makes an asset flip instead of legitimate use of stock assets are whether those assets comprise the majority of the game, and whether the "developer" properly credited the people who created most of the assets in the game.  This game fails both of those tests.  The "developers" here didn't credit any of the artists and real, actual game developers who created the assets here, so this is plagiarism, as well as cash grab shovelware.

In this case, the asset flipper took a bunch of random assets from the Unreal Marketplace and dumped them onto a basic Unreal platformer blueprint with next to no other effort expended.  It's a fake game like all of Tero's other asset flip scams polluting the Steam store and giving indie devs a bad name.  It has no value or merit as a real game.

Tero Lunkka/Valkeala Software have shown a repeat pattern of unethically dumping other people's work onto Steam as a cheap, nasty cash grab, through this account or through closely linked/alt accounts.  Here's some examples so you can see for yourself:
[list]
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/581200]Nash Racing[/url]" = [url=https://www.unrealengine.com/marketplace/en-US/product/advanced-tuning-cars]Advanced Tuning Cars[/url] developed by James Novih
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/713580]Nash Racing 2[/url]" = [url=https://www.unrealengine.com/marketplace/en-US/product/advanced-tuning-cars]Advanced Tuning Cars[/url] developed by James Novih
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/768060]The Warrior Of Treasures[/url]" = [url=https://www.unrealengine.com/marketplace/en-US/product/dynamic-combat-system]Dynamic Combat System[/url] developed by Grzegorz Szewczyk
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1639090]Survival Isolation[/url]" = [url=https://www.unrealengine.com/marketplace/en-US/product/easy-survival-rpg]Easy Survival RPG v3[/url] developed by Easy Systems
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1776540]Lawnmower Game: Pinball[/url]" = [url=https://github.com/freezy/pinball-construction-kit]Pinball Construction Kit[/url] developed by Epic Games
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1643280]Fancy the Frog[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/2d/characters/pixel-adventure-1-155360]Pixel Adventure 1[/url] developed by Pixel Frog
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/723830]Cyborg Invasion Shooter[/url]" = [url=https://www.unrealengine.com/marketplace/en-US/product/third-person-shooter-kit]Third Person Shooter Kit[/url] developed by Epic Games
[/list]

Taking this shovelware seriously as if it was a genuine attempt to make a game, it doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

There's no option to change the resolution and no useful graphics tweaks.  There's no way to ensure this is running at the native resolution of your display.  There's no guarantee this game will look right on any PC as a result of this hamfisted design decision.

The game features lazy low-polygon "retro" assets, making this look like a barely functional 3D game from the 1990s.  It's unclear why the developers weren't able to arrange high quality, high polygon count contemporary assets for the game, and also irrelevant... what matters is that this looks bad as a result of their decisions, a compromise PC gamers shouldn't have to put up with.

The controls can't be customised, which will be an annoyance for many, but it can also render the game unplayable for differently-abled gamers, left handed gamers or gamers using AZERTY or other international keyboard layouts.  

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

"Music Man 2: New land" didn't appeal much to the people who own a copy of the game, either.  It has achievements, and they show us a very clear picture that the game didn't really capture any interest from gamers.  The most commonly and easily attained achievement is for going through the first "level" of this asset flip, trivial to get, but less than 35 percent of players bothered to get that far before uninstalling the game.  Hardly a success story, gamers just weren't all that interested in the game.

The poor quality of this game is also reflected by how many people spent time with it.  At the time of this review, SteamDB shows the all-time peak player number was only 3 players.  This is a remarkably low number, and now, the only player activity occurs once or twice a month, presumably someone loading it up to see what it is then quickly uninstalling it.  Considering there's over 120 million gamers on Steam and well over 100,000 games for gamers to choose from, the overwhelming lack of interest in this low quality game is to be expected.

It's also important to note the "developer" here has connections to a number of shady Russian asset flippers and review manipulators who show an organised pattern to scam and defraud gamers with fake reviews and asset flipping the work of others for profit.  While reviews are about the games, gamers should be informed when developers act unethically.   Whether these connections are the same developer using multiple accounts, or just working closely with other unethical developers, gamers should be warned about the harm to gamers by this developer and their associates.  Buying games from unethical developers puts your money at risk.

This game features a small number of fake positive reviews from accounts known to be in the business of review manipulation/paid reviews.  They're all written in either Russian or broken English, appear at almost exactly the same time, very shortly after the game launched on Steam, all have a direct Steam purchase of the game, and the accounts are used consistently to write fake reviews for asset flips and other cash grabs/scams.  The "Positive" review score on this game should be disregarded due to this blatant, unethical review manipulation.  This is done to deceive and scam gamers into paying for a bad product.[/quote]

This kind of asset flipping isn't harmless.  It makes it harder for gamers to find genuinely made games from ethical developers.  It makes it harder for genuine indie developers, who put hard work into trying to make real games, to find an audience for their products.  It gives indie developers a bad name.

So, should you buy this game?  Is this one of the best of the 100,000+ games on Steam?

"Music Man 2: New land" is relatively cheap at $3 USD, but it's not worth it. Given the defects and quality issues with the game, coupled with the unrealistic price, and the questionable ethical nature of the developer and/or their associates (as outlined above), this is impossible to recommend.  Remember that if you buy a game from an unethical developer, you're putting your money at risk.

[quote][b][url=https://partner.steamgames.com/doc/marketing/profile]Profile Features Limited![/url][/b]
Valve have marked this game as "Profile Features Limited" at the time of this review.  This is usually caused by poor sales figures and low community acceptance for the game (to date).  Until this status changes, this game will not give you +1 to your Game Collector badge count, appear in profile achievements or any other Steam meta-accomplishments, nor can it be displayed in some profile showcases.  If these factors are important to you, it may be worth holding off before buying this game.[/quote]

Square Word: Back to Work! is developed by CCS (Cold Coffee Studio)

A colorful word game in a Wordle type environment, where the player will be searching for appropriate words according to the category. At the bottom of the grid are several blank squares of varying amounts. It's up to you to figure out individual words related to the current category. The tricky part is that some words may have different directional possibilities so even though the word may be correct, it's possible that you have chosen the wrong directional path and it may leave letters that can't be connected. 

The player will go through 4 difficulty levels in the course of the game, beginning with Easy to Very Hard. Each of the 4 categories (Sports, Jobs, Places, Autumn) include the following puzzles:

* Easy 3x3 puzzle-5 Levels
* Medium 4x4 puzzle-4 Levels
* Hard 5x5 puzzle-3 Levels
* Very hard 6x6 puzzle 4 Levels

As the player progresses through the game, they will be rewarded with in game Stamps which can be redeemed for Hints. There is an option of 2 kinds of Hints-First Letter or the entire Word. Earn 1 Hint for every objective completed or earn 1 word Hint for every 3 objectives. If more hints are required, there is an envelope that drops down from the top of the main menu, and if clicked, will grant the player 1 Hint. The difficulty level progresses the further you go.

There is also a daily challenge (with a timer) to complete, and if successful, will grant you 1 Hint.

Pros:
* 140+ Words to find
* Handcrafted grids
* Music complements the game
* Daily challenge
* Hints
* 12 Achievements

Cons:
* The sporadic drop of the envelope in the main menu to grab 1 Hint in an effort to proceed takes sometime to drop
* No trading cards

Final Thoughts:
Would be a great game for co-op if developer decides to implement it in the future. This is kind of a difficult game and quicker hints would be nice. Or it could just be me. The price is reasonable for what you get and is currently on sale, so even better value.

Rating: 7/10

This review was submitted for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/elitegives]Elite Giveaways[/url], where every game deserves a review.
Follow our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/11978515/]Curator for lots more honest reviews[/url].

[h1]WAY MORE CHALLENGING THAN ITS PREDECESSORS[/h1]¬†
Square Words is a game that requires you to make themed words from various-sized grids of letters. You can create words horizontally, vertically, and diagonally, and in most cases, it's a combination of all 3 directions.

There are four categories: Sports, Jobs, Places, and Autumn. Each category has three Easy 3x3 grids, three Medium 4x4 grids, and three Hard 5x5 grids. (The words do seem to change each time you replay.) There is also a Daily Game and a Mixed 6x6 category in a Very Hard mode.¬†¬†

At the bottom of the grid are several blank squares of varying amounts. It's up to you to figure out individual words related to the current category. The tricky part is that some words may have different directional possibilities, so even though the word may be correct, it's possible that you chose the wrong directional path because it may leave letters on the outer edges that can't be connected, and you'll have to restart the level.

There are two different Hint types. The Letter Hint fills in the first letter of one word. The Word Hint gives you the answer to the word, but it's still up to you to figure out the directional path. Additional Hints can be earned by playing the Daily Game, completing an entire category, or completing Achievement Stamp objectives. You will earn 1 hint per objective, such as completing one Daily Grid game. Word Hints are earned when you complete three of these objectives. You can also "catch" a hint by clicking on the Envelope that drops down from the top of the main screen (which is also an achievement x5)

I did find this game to be more challenging than the last two games. In my opinion, it was more challenging to figure out the correct words in some of the categories because the words didn't seem to fit the category, were slang words, or incomplete words.

[h1][b]POSSIBLE SPOILERS[/b][/h1] For example:

Under the category [b]JOBS[/b], a Nun is considered a job (I consider it a "calling" or a "community service") Cop is used in one puzzle and Police in another, which is inconsistent at the very least. A "Star" is considered to be a job. I understand that you can be a star employee, but that seems more like a status than a job to me?¬†

Under the category [b]PLACES[/b], "Sun" is considered to be a place, which seems a bit of a stretch.

Under the category [b]SPORTS[/b], apparently, "Volley," (not Volleyball) is a sport. I Googled "Is Volley a sport?" and the closest I came to connecting Volley to a sport was a definition for Tennis: [i]The flight of the ball before it hits the ground. The return of the ball before it hits the ground.[/i] I also encountered the word "Summerset," which is an acrobatic feat in which the feet roll over the head (either forward or backward) and return. Technically, these words [i]are related[/i] to sports, but they are technical terms, and I don't think the average Joe would be able to make these connections...but I could be wrong.
¬†
The bottom line is that I still enjoyed the game, just not as much as the previous two games, because I had to use all of my hints when I couldn't figure out these vaguely related words. I even had to grab extra hints on the main menu just to get through the Sports category, and that took away from the enjoyment of the game overall.

Check out my Group/Curator page¬† at¬†https://steamcommunity.com/groups/thewoodsforum

Stacks:Jungle is the latest release from the developer of Stacks:Space. It is a card-based strategy village builder with exploration and crafting. It is similar to Stacklands and Card Survival Tropical Island in style and game play, but Stacks:Jungle brings more variety and complexity to it's crafting recipes and greater detail and maturity to its visual motif. If you are a fan of card-based games I recommend Stacks:Jungle and if you see it on sale then don't hesitate. If you would like to take a closer look then check out my let's play series on YouTube: https://youtu.be/0pzH_L6kow4?si=pQ9l_zbyf27ihwRZ

Initially I liked it, and thought it just needs some balancing/polishing. 
But right now I have a savegame-breaking but when going from on place to the next. So probably will refund.

Some thoughts, comparing it to Stackland:
- Timing seems of. I only played with speed 1, and paused frequently, because speed 1 felt to fast to micromanage everything that is needed
- Cards produced land everywhere around, instead of stacking on an existing stack of the same card right next to them
- unlocking the research stuff feels chaotic (because it is to easy/fast)
- You overproduce coins in some places, and then just burn through them in other places -> needs better balancing
- You never "scale up" your people , you go from 1 person to 2 pretty soon, plus a parot who can one tiny thing
- Drops of leaves, which you need to increase your card limit, seem pre-scripted to stop?
- On the positive side: I like not fighting enemies.

Stacks: Jungle! is not just a game; it's a journey into a world of endless possibilities, where the thrill of stacking cards transforms into an adventure through the vibrant, untamed landscapes of the jungle. For a card-stacking experience that seamlessly blends simplicity, strategy, and creativity, "Stacks: Jungle!" is a must-have addition to your Steam library.

5 hours simply melted away as I worked my way through the first three areas. I'm almost done with them, and looking forward to finding the next 20-odd places.  There's MANY hours of game play here, and an enjoyable change of pace from FPS and RPGs.

(I was gifted this steam key in a Reddit giveaway, no additional compensation was given for reviewing)
Its a fun little game but too peacefull unlike the rest of stacks games. Would like to see more of stacks games with diffrent themes and challenges.

pretty chill and nice game to play if you like crafting and exploring with many good ideas.
i think it needs some QoL features :)

Ignoring the complains the game got for removing a single line of text that appears in an optional, out of the way, fake twitter app, this update and DLC isn't really that good. 
     The DLC feels a lot more tacked on than I would have expected and really sticks out as it essentially derails itself from the main plot that every other route follows. It slaps in a whole new villain completely unrelated from the current plot and just runs with it. 

     The DLC also comes with questionable bugs and glitches, for starters an audio bug that would occur if you alt-tabbed from the game is still present and is somehow even worse, as a majority of the game audio will now just cut unprovoked. This was just my experience but the fact it happened on two different setups isn't a good sign. Another frustrating bug that comes up is that during side quests, cutscenes play when the fight on the map ends, normally you would just fight one or two people and then the cutscene plays. But for some reason in just about every side mission in the DLC it keeps spawning random pedestrians who will become aggressive and prolong the fight forever. I genuinely mean this could last forever, I attempted multiple times to fight off the random aggressive pedestrians, the highest I managed to fight was 30 just trying and failing to progress a side quest that should have ended already. I have no clue how a prevalent issue like this fits through the cracks.

     Another issue relating to balancing. One main issue I had with the remaster of the first game was how often you would get swarmed by enemies, and this got taken way out of proportions here. There are multiple fights where you face 4 or more enemies by yourself, sometimes in cramp places. This makes it quite easy for enemies to combo you into each other, managing to kill you without any possibility for your inputs. The final boss is just you fighting 13 enemies at once. These enemies can easily surround you and god help you if they use a move with knock back as they will almost certainly knock you into another enemy as you're pushed around like you're a pinball.

     As for the story I didn't pay that much attention to it but as i mentioned before, it has a main villain almost completely unrelated to the previous story, a magical demon that possessed a family for generations, that is going to be harvested for its evil powers as apparently everyone knows the powers of this random demon that has been locked way for generations. There are also a few notable jumps in logic that violate the idea of common sense say for instance [spoiler] You deciding it would be better off to flee from you friends and get into multiple fights with them, rather than tell them that Kati is possessed by a demon and that she needs help. [/spoiler] or [spoiler] this magic demon created purely by hate, rage, and violence against humanity, suddenly wants to be good and learn to love humans after you beat it twice [/spoiler] 

     Ultimately I have no reason for why this DLC exists, it barely fits in with the main plot, is centered around one of the previously least important characters in the story, and it remains buggy and unbalanced for a game that is now 10 years old. If you liked the normal game then this DLC is worth a shot, but this will not make your experience that much better, all truth it might make it just a little worse.

If your buying Akiba's Trip new, this would fit into the experience well. You wouldn't be missing much if you skipped it but I believe online this is seen as the "cannon" ending. What I think it had good arc for a side character
