It's good BUT it's pushing away some potential playerbase due to a swarm of info dump way too fast.

I play Yu-Gi-OH and Magic and various other card games with a lot of text and complicated interactions but this game despite having less information dump than the other 2 specific card games mentioned, has a massive information on par with a TCG Rulebook while not including decent information that can cause confusion all because everything important and key to the game is info slammed in a poor raw text format all at once.

What can be done to improve this?
Easy. Just slow down the info injection mind flaying. Ease the information to when we encounter it rather than throw it all at us before we even can actually care about it.

Dismantling stuff? don't care until I actually need to.

Forge and signs? Why are these even being shown to new people when we should't/can't do anything about it yet?
Just make it hidden until necessary like greying it out and replacing it with the text of when we can/should access it. That would give the player less info dump at the very start and give them something to look forward to o new players get a feeling to work to earn something to increase their first play session of the game.

The tiny some-what hidden encyclopedia icon at the top left?
Hide all information in it until we need to care about it and have the information on it show up "WHEN" we encounter it for the first time. At which time, the information of that should pop-up mid-game.
Makes the book a "Reminder" menu.

Small Information isn't even provided as well which can confuse people only because the game drops a fat load of important information way too fast which causes the rather minor details that aren't really needing a info mention to overwhelm people before they give it a proper try causing a pointless barrier to entree that most new card game devs tend to overlook specifically because card game devs tend to have a basic understanding of card game logic. However, slowing down how much information is given at once and slowing it down a little bit helps a lot wit getting new players into the game especially in a world where currently people don't really give much time to try anything and tend to quit forever after 5-10 minutes at most usually.

In short, slowing down on the info dump and preventing people from seeing certain information when it isn't yet necessary nor even seen yet will greatly improve how long new players, including those not used to in-depth card games or card games in general will stay active playing the game while also increasing the playtime of their first session if forge, signs and info in the Manual were hidden as to give them a sense of early-meta progression all from a single first run.

In the current state, I can't recommend this game. 
The game is pretty that's for sure but I don't really care too much about that..
The gameplay feels like it's all over the place. It's perfectly fine to add a lot of different mechanics, it's even needed in order to reach a nice depth and replayability but the current mechanics don't play well with each other so it just feels like a messy patchwork.
There is way too much meta progression - which is arguably a personal preference so maybe it's your thing.
Also, hopefully only an EA issue but the balance is off, I didn't lost a single hit point in my run until I got obliterated by the boss.

Great game, a steal for less than 10‚Ç¨ ! 
It's the roguelike deckbuilder of my dreams, no other deckbuilder I know (and I tried most) allows you to customize/change every single card this deeply. 
You can have up to 4 runes in each card, each rune can add damage/defense/buffs/debuffs or some other effects, making the same base card do completely different things in the end. Depending on the champions class and element the available runes and cards to put them into differ. 
Add Equipment and Artifacts for bonus effects (e.g. one gave my warrior block for each burn applied, making him tanky by being a dot machine), rune and card upgrades and meta progression into the mix and you got your monkey brain hooked.  
I sometimes spent hours between fights, just crafting the perfect cards for each of my 5 champions to combo into each other. 
Each fight also lets you choose one of many additional challenges for bonus rewards, making each fight a bit different.   
  
The game even has a demo, just try it!   
  
Edit: I feel like I need to add that the game is still rough around the edges with bugs, I had one Artifact not even work at all, which made me stop playing for now, because it still feels like early access (which it isn't) with lots of QoL/bugfixing needed. Still had over 50h of fun for little money, because the gameplay is unique, so worth it.
Like the game, but healing can be difficult especially in tough fights. A nice game to chill and relax too.

I'm sorry to interrupt you, Elizabeth.
If you still even remember that name.
But I'm afraid you've been misinformed.
You are not here to receive a gift.
Nor, have you been called here by the individual you assume.
Although, you have indeed been called.
You have all been called here.
Into a labyrinth of sounds and smells, misdirection and misfortune.
A labyrinth with no exit, a maze with no prize.
You don't even realize that you are trapped.
Your lust of blood has driven you in endless circles.
Chasing the cries of children in some unseen chamber.
Always seeming so near, yet somehow out of reach.
But, you will never find them, none of you will.
This is where your story ends.

And to you, my brave volunteer.
Who somehow found this job listing not intended for you.
Although, there was a way out planned for you,
I have a feeling that's not what you want.
I have a feeling that you are right where you want to be.

I am remaining as well. I am nearby.
This place will not be remembered.
And the memory of everything that started this.
Can finally begin to fade away.
As the agony of every tragedy should.
And to you monsters trapped in the corridors.
Be still, and give up your spirits.
They don't belong to you.
For most of you, I believe there is peace and perhaps, warm.
Waiting for you after the smoke clears.
Although, for one of you.
The darkest pit of Hell has opened to swallow you whole.
So, don't keep the Devil waiting, old friend.
My daughter, if you can hear me.
I knew you would return as well.
It's in your nature to protect the innocent.
I'm sorry that on that day.
The day you were shut out and left to die.
No one was there to lift you up in their arms.
The way you lifted others into yours.
And then, what became of you?
I should have known, you wouldn't be content to disappear.
Not my daughter. I couldn't save you then, so let me save you now.
It's time to rest, for you, and for those you have carried in your arms.

This ends.
For all of us.
End communication.
It really makes you *feel* like a car crash victim.

[b][quote][url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asset_flip]Warning: Asset Flip![/url][/quote][/b]

Call of Farming is a Unity Asset flip, what Valve calls a "fake game".  The "developer", Mavi Game Studios, took the [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/systems/survival-engine-crafting-building-farming-178160]Survival Engine[/url] Unity Store tutorial/demo/game asset pack from the real developers, Indie Marc, changed the name, and dumped the result onto Steam.  They're attempting to scam people into buying this, so they can get your money for someone else's work.

It gets worse... "Survival Engine" has also been shamelessly dumped on Steam by other asset flippers apart from Mavi Game Studios:
[list]
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1625800]Hentai in the Forest[/url]", asset flipped by Boom Games/Sweet Games
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1543820]PaperCraft[/url]", asset flipped by Cinnamancer Studios
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1623320]Little Big Guy[/url]", asset flipped by Albatross Idea
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1507910]Survival Engine[/url]", asset flipped by Indie Marc (yes, he put his own asset pack on Steam as if it was a real game... ugh). 
[/list]
Take a look for yourself... these are all [i]exactly the same game![/i]

Because this is an almost exact 1:1 copy + paste of the original Unity asset, it's in violation of the [url=https://unity.com/legal/as-terms]Unity Asset Store Terms of Service and EULA[/url].  Specifically, Section 2, Subsection 2.2.1a:

[quote][i]Subject to the restrictions set forth in this EULA, Licensor hereby grants to the END-USER a non-exclusive, non-transferable, worldwide, and perpetual license to the Asset solely:(a) to incorporate the Asset, [b]together with substantial, original content not obtained through the Unity Asset Store[/b], into an electronic application or digital media that has a purpose, features, and functions beyond the display, performance, distribution, or use of Assets ("Licensed Product") as an embedded component of that Licensed Product, [b]such that the Asset does not comprise a substantial portion of the Licensed Product[/b][/i][/quote]

Because the developer misused the asset pack such that it comprises the vast majority of this "game", the developer has unethically and deliberately breached the license agreement.  Worse, this intellectual property violation was done in an attempt to profit from their illicit actions.  Why is this permitted on Steam?

The products that result from asset flips aren't "real" games.  They lack depth and content, because they're just simplistic copies of demos or tutorials.  In this case, "Survival Engine" is just a demo/tutorial pack to teach people how to make a simple top down 3D survival game in Unity, and doesn't have any merit as a proper, fully fledged PC game, so this copy+paste of it can't be recommended.

Asset flips don't involve any professional game development.  Sure, sometimes they may change a few cosmetic things, swap out different assets etc, but at heart it's functionally identical to the asset they're ripping off.

Asset flips like this are harmful to the gaming industry and to Steam because they reduce the visibility that sincerely made indie games should have, and make it harder for gamers to find real games from genuine developers.

Now, Mavi Studios have made this "free" for now, so they're no longer trying to scam people out of money for someone else's game, but it doesn't change the fact that their original plan was exactly that... to run an asset flip scam on Steam, to scam you out of money for Indie Marc's Unity asset pack.  Don't reward this morally bankrupt, unethical behaviour from Mavi Game Studios.

[quote][b][url=https://partner.steamgames.com/doc/marketing/profile]Profile Features Limited![/url][/b]
Valve have marked this game as "Profile Features Limited" at the time of this review.  This is usually caused by poor sales figures and low community acceptance for the game (to date).  Until this status changes, this game will not give you +1 to your Game Collector badge count, appear in profile achievements or any other Steam meta-accomplishments, nor can it be displayed in some profile showcases.  If these factors are important to you, it may be worth holding off before buying this game.[/quote]

[quote][url=https://partner.steamgames.com/doc/store/reviews]Developer Response![/url][/quote]The developer has weighed in to inform everyone they didn't read the [url=https://partner.steamgames.com/doc/store/reviews]Developer Usage Rules[/url] for Steam "partners", or they deliberately ignored the part where Valve says:
[quote]Though it may be tempting, not every review needs to be responded to.  A developer response will frequently draw more attention than the original statement, potentially turning a small issue into a much larger community discussion. It's also not a good idea to use this feature to refute customer opinions. Your direct attention can be seen as validation or a defensive attempt to silence your customers.[/quote]

So this is insane... the developer breached Valve guidelines just to brazenly acknowledge [b]this is an asset flip[/b].  They don't see that's a problem, instead, they decided to argue with me, a reviewer, about what the Unity Terms of Service says.  You know, the one that they agreed to and then immediately breached, so they can profit from dumping asset flip trash on the Steam store.  I'm gonna repost the section of the commercial agreement that they violated for profit: 

[quote][i]Subject to the restrictions set forth in this EULA, Licensor hereby grants to the END-USER a non-exclusive, non-transferable, worldwide, and perpetual license to the Asset solely:(a) to incorporate the Asset, [b]together with substantial, original content not obtained through the Unity Asset Store[/b], into an electronic application or digital media that has a purpose, features, and functions beyond the display, performance, distribution, or use of Assets ("Licensed Product") as an embedded component of that Licensed Product, [b]such that the Asset does not comprise a substantial portion of the Licensed Product[/b][/i][/quote]

Emphasis mine, but you can clearly see: 

1) There is no substantial content not obtained through the Unity Asset Store.
2) The asset from Indie Marc absolutely comprises the vast majority of this product. 

Womp womp.  And yes, Indie Marc is distributing this asset under that license on the Unity store, I checked. 

The developer seems to think that not reading the agreement they signed gives them some kind of legal immunity?  Like I said, insane. 

Good luck defending that one in court whenever Unity decides to sue. 

People should be aware that as soon as Unity does take legal action, this asset flip will be GONE.

Edit: The developer fails their IQ test massively and continues to ignore the parts of the license that require they include substantial content not obtained through the Unity Asset Store, and fail to understand that the resultant product (Game) cannot be majority composed of the asset they bought.   The license is right there, I've linked it and quoted it twice.  If the developer wants to keep pretending they didn't breach the commercial license, that's on them.

The FACTS of my review are not baseless, you can see the developers game, and see the asset, and see they're identical.  PROOF is included in my review.

I can give them this: it is a better game than I could write.

For now, anyway.

the final verdict, so i did watch a lore video on the first game because the reviews were not good for it, so i didn't want to take the chances if im being honest. i saw this game before i even knew about that one and i was hesitant to buy it because it was kinda one of those games were it doesn't look so bad but there's not a lot going on in the trailer or people talking about it...however i can say i did enjoy this game. it was scary, immersive with ultra audio design and the graphics are actually really solid. the areas are put together tightly crafted and well. the gameplay is eh, clunky gunplay but it's not a huge thing within the game. the areas were nice to explore and i would argue the low budget AI is actually scary as hell when they jump out and start charging at you LOL. either way for $12 it isn't too bad honestly. survival horror fans should check that one out if they are in search for one and/or burnt out from mainstream titles.

FINAL SCORE: 4/10

Darker Skies Remastered, the PC edition of this post-War of the Worlds survival horror game, boasts new graphical features and gameplay enhancements for what should be the definitive experience. However, my experience with the game left me with mixed feelings.

Graphically, the game is a bit of a paradox. On one hand, it looks pretty good, with well-designed lighting and character models. However, it also comes across as very bare bones, lacking the depth and detail that could truly immerse players in its post-apocalyptic world.

The gameplay, unfortunately, is where Darker Skies Remastered stumbles the most. The gunplay feels stiff and lacks the fluidity needed for an enjoyable experience. The absence of sensitivity options adds to the frustration, making precise aiming a cumbersome task. Movement speed is another issue, with walking being too slow and running excessively fast, creating a jarring contrast.

Voice acting, while not exceptional, falls within an acceptable range. However, the overall performance of the game is a significant drawback. Stuttering, low FPS, and poor optimization mar the experience, even on high-end hardware, such as the 7900 XTX.

Mechanically, Darker Skies Remastered is overly simplistic. With limited gameplay elements and a lack of depth, it feels more like a proof of concept or prototype rather than a fully-fledged game. The story is another sore point, as it lacks coherence and fails to provide answers to essential questions about the protagonist and the world they inhabit.

The audio design is subpar, with some sounds being too loud or mismatched. A peculiar addition of a tablet to the backpack, while initially intriguing, lacks any meaningful impact on gameplay, raising questions about its purpose.

There are moments that shine, such as a cool battle against a smaller mech and the introduction of mutants or aliens in one section, though the latter feels like a missed opportunity. However, these glimpses of potential are overshadowed by the game's overall shortcomings.

Darker Skies Remastered markets itself as a "Survival Horror" game, but it falls short of delivering on both fronts. The survival mechanics are minimal, and the horror aspect is barely present, resulting in a game that feels more like a walking simulator with basic combat and crafting elements. Had it embraced its narrative strengths, it could have been a compelling exploration of the post-apocalyptic aftermath. Unfortunately, it falls short of its ambitions.

Overall Rating: 4/10

This is the sequel to "Grey Skies: A War of the Worlds Story", remastered for PC after it was only available on console.  Unlike its predecessor, it takes place AFTER the war and not during.  You play as Jack, a secondary character from the first game, who in the aftermath scavenges through the rubble and debris for components to built a working heat ray weapon.  Jack operates from a home base (a central hub) from where he can access the various areas of the game.
I liked the game and really did enjoy it.
I want to be clear though that players are in general negative when it comes to this dev's work.  The first game was not received well at all and negative criticism has spilt over to this sequel as a result.  Personally, I feel that this indie dev, still honing his skills, did a good job.  While the first game was focused primarily on stealth, the player here has a choice between stealth and combat - the player wields a pistol almost from the start.  The amount of ammo pick-ups is totally sufficient in this regard.  The amount of red weed pick-ups to upgrade one's character and throwables also is enough to upgrade fully in one playthrough; just explore to find it all.
There is absolutely no need to want to run around like a lunatic and finish the game in under two hours or less.  I fully explored every nook and cranny during my seven hours of play time, taking it slow, soaking in the environment and atmosphere.
I foresee complaints about the movement being clunky and some other frustrations, like there being (mostly) zombies.  However, I feel that much of the negativity towards this game and its predecessor are somewhat exaggerated, unwarranted and even lazy.  Don't enter into an indie game like this and expect a triple A production with epic battles, spectacular stunts and a Hollywood plot.
This is my honest opinion.
The graphics are good and so is the story line.

I personally think that this is a pretty decent game with a great concept, but like the majority of new games, it needs work. A few issues that I have noticed is slight stuttering and slight frame drops (That could just be my computer), no sensitivity options (The aim sensitivity was too slow for my liking), no motion blur setting, and the enemies... I personally wish we were dealing with Tripods and Martians instead of brain washed people, the idea of using stealth to avoid Tripods and Martians just seems so much more captivating for me, I kind of hope that will be implemented into the Grey Skies: Remastered. 

As stated earlier, I recognise it is newly released and will most likely have bugs and other issues, but it has potential.

This a low-budget janky third person shooter with terrible optimization. I experienced constant major stutter and frame rate drops down into the 30s using an RTX3080 and i9 processor no matter what I changed in the graphic options. This is most likely due to the Unreal Engine shader compilation stutter that will probably never get fixed by the developer. There is also no manual save and checkpoints are far away. Clicking "continue" in the main menu also does nothing. So you must click "new game" to be taken back to the last checkpoint. Control settings also do not save and must be remapped every time you start the game. Voice acting also does not fit the lead character, there are too many loading screens, the flashlight runs out of batteries within seconds, and there is also an extreme lack of ammo. The whole experience just feels cheap, janky, and low-budget and I therefore cannot recommend it.

Weird field of view with no option to increase it for ultrawide displays, no native support for UWA monitors either, performance on an RTX 4090 is lacking, to get acceptable performance you have to use render scale 75 and that was at standard 1440P on Ultra preset.

This game has no ray tracing, so there's no reason why performance should be this bad. No stutters just poor rendering performance and mouse camera motion.

Very indie space shooter with some nice ideas and too many technical issues.

Update: The latest patch fixed both the "freeze" issue and non-working gamepad. The game works as intended now so I'm changing the review to "recommended".  However, this is still a very problematic game with many issues. Get it at a heavy discount.

Unfortunately, the game's theme revolves around technical issues. Before I could play the game, I had to complete a benchmark, which crashed my game. Although everything worked properly the second time, the first impression wasn't great. 

Even worse, the game's gamepad compatibility is utterly broken, or it is simply incompatible with my gamepad. When you first enter the game and pick the gamepad as your primary device, the game freezes and displays the message "Gamepad not found."

Furthermore, it says to press a key to play without the gamepad, but that doesn‚Äôt do anything. To make matters even stranger, the fire button on the gamepad functions because you can hear the firing sound in the background. Because you can't even get back to the main menu, the only way to fix it is to force-quit the game and play with the keyboard. And that's not fun.

Anyway, the game begins with a brief tutorial in which you pilot a spacecraft with maximum firearms. Shortly later, you're attacked by a shockwave that destroys everything. Only you and your miserable escape pod are able to escape. Although there is an arcade mode, the campaign has much more to offer. This includes voice acting with a thick accent and a less-than-professional tone. 

The objective of the game is to go on missions to collect resources, fix your base, and fly away in a rocket. Everything you need can be found by destroying enemies and objects. Things you can acquire are divided as temporary power-ups or bonuses for your spacecraft and various types of materials.

The base contains four buildings that need to be repaired. Each unlocks additional benefits that can help you become more efficient. The landing platform, for example, allows you to collect additional resources during missions, while the weapon factory allows you to create new weaponry. 

The controls and gameplay are simple: you move your ship around and fire at enemies. Aside from the shield and health bar, you should keep an eye on the energy bar, which allows you to shoot. The more weapons you have, the faster it depletes. Another challenging mechanic is that some weapons may malfunction. All you can do in this situation is wait and try to survive by dodging until it is fixed. 

The game's interesting feature is that it can be played in either side-scrolling or top-down mode. The experience may differ, but the gameplay remains rather similar. If you prefer an old-school mood, you may choose the retro look that makes everything grainy. Overall, the graphics are fine. There are some visually appealing moments, but the game won't blow you away with intricate textures. Sadly, the game can‚Äôt handle some of the textures. One enemy, for instance, causes the game to lag each time it enter the screen.

The number of missions or planets is huge. The first few missions will be boring because your pod is slow and very useless. All you‚Äôll be able to do is grind the first mission for resources until you can afford better things. Luckily, it doesn‚Äôt take long before you can make yourself a proper ship, and missions can be repeated as much as you want. Each mission has four objectives, but there are only important if you want to do everything the game has to offer. 

Unfortunately, the technical troubles persist during gameplay. Some are minor, such as power-ups flying through textures or your energy level dropping when holding the fire button in the pause menu or with a broken weapon. Other problems, however, render the game unplayable. There are several issues that occur frequently and suck the fun out of it. 

The first occurs when you press "esc" during normal play to pause the game. This causes the game to freeze completely. The same thing happens during a mission when you acquire a prototype and the camera moves closer to the ship to indicate that you discovered something important. Both issues require you to return to the main menu, losing whatever progress or resources you've discovered.

In the end, despite the slow gameplay, the game can give you a couple of hours of fun. However, random freezing issues and lags are just too much. If this is somehow fixed, I will change the review.

Zen with a Pen is quite a misleading name for a game that becomes very challenging, very fast. I'm not easily frustrated after years of playing Super Hexagon, Boson X and other fail-or-finish games; however,  this little fun right here made for a very infuriating Sunday morning, which I find very enjoyable.

The premise is easy to understand and execute: Guide a small ball through an increasingly difficult path of obstacles, with your mouse working as a fountain pen. Left click to apply ink, right click to remove it but be aware that the ink itself vanishes on its own. Physics are active and a constant stream of air pushes you forward, most of the time right into a spiky ending. I admit in all honesty that this is a pretty hard game, at least for me. I had to take a break in level 4 because I was stuck at the final checkpoint. In order to overcome a couple of corners, it was mandatory to apply the force of a certain power-up. Couple this with a slight degree of randomness, you'll always get when a ball hits a plane, and suddenly it feels like a game of chance rather than of skill.

Speaking of power-ups: there are four of them, with varying effects. One makes the ball very small, the other gives a shield to survive one spiky hit and the one I was talking about before gave a huge boost but only on the first contact with any object. Difficulties range from Easy to Zen but don't get fooled: Zen is by far the hardest, without even having any checkpoints in between. Easy provides more ink and power-ups and yet I still struggled.
[hr][/hr]
If I had to suggest some minor improvements, especially for long-term replayability, two things come to my mind. Firstly, remove the need to finish a level to unlock the next. As of right now, every time I get back to Zen with a Pen, I either have the choice to replay a course in higher difficulty or that one level I'm currently stuck in. I rather enjoy playing level 5 until I hit a wall ‚îÄ or a spike, figuratively speaking ‚îÄ and move over to level 6 until I'm stuck again. Maybe unlock the next level after finishing 50% of the prior course, to give players something to look forward to, even if they fail. This might be personal preference though.

Secondly, the music. I think many tracks are very well done and kind of remove some of the frustration that's building up. However, to restart from a checkpoint, you have two choices: Wait until the camera has settled in again, which, like everything in game can be sped up via holding the space bar, or press a rewind button in the top right corner. The latter is much quicker but causes the music to restart, which can be annoying after repeated attempts. It would be great to have the option to instantly restart without the music resetting.
[hr][/hr]
In summary, Zen with a Pen is great little time-killer that fits perfectly into a lunch-break, a morning routine or whenever you want something that's easy to pick up but hard to finish. It's not a big game, only offering 8 levels so far but I'm sure that it will take some time to finish these, even on lowest difficulties. If there was something I dislike it's the occasional randomness of the ball. This of course can't be avoided entirely but it's unnecessarily adding up on the already  difficult game design.
If you still can't decide, give the free demo a try!

Very simple yet effective concept, and executed incredibly well!

   Essentially, you choose a card every few stages that usually gives you a positive and negative effect. While this may seem rather frustrating, I'd say that Punkcake did an incredible job at balancing out all cards, as almost all of them synergise with each other. In one run you may be rampaging recklessly through any and every enemy with your insane movement and attack speed, while in another you'd be cautelous with hazards with a glass cannon build

   There aren't many levels to go through in a single run, and sometimes you may reach the final one with ease, but the real challenge in Damocles Gaze is its achievements, where you must unlock and complete a run with each individual card since the beggining of a run. I'd actually go as far as to say that the achievements are an integral part in the game's replayability factor, as it has only a handful of incredibly refined weapons, similarly to Nuclear Throne, but with a lower scale and experimentation (asie from the cards)

   You will only ever play a run to upwards of a hard cap of 12 minutes, as the game only allows you to actually die once that timer reaches zero, two minutes after the bss of the current stage you're in spawns. "Deaths" throughout each level instead send you back to the beginning of it, and while this may seem counter intuitive, it is sometimes incredibly useful to strategize your approach with the level's layout, as sometimes enemy placement may be akward/harsh to comeby depending on your current card loadout

   Overall, I believe that Damocles Gaze is a pretty good game, despite what negative comments I've had previously! I'd possibly reccomend you the game when it's at least on any sale, as the current pricetag maaayyy be a little more than what I think it's worth. That is not to say that it's been badly made, the gameplay is fair while also challenging and there's an amazing amount of polish put into it.

   So play it, It's great!

[h2] Few games are as fun as Furious Farm! [/h2]

A really, really fun game. Simple as it should be, with delightful gameplay and cool soundtrack. Addctive in a good way.

The main concept (a chalenge between harvester machines ‚Äì each one with its specific characteristics ‚Äì to see who collect more wheat) is taken at its most enjoyable and challenging way. There are power-ups through the levels to increase competitivity. You can put your wheat in a silo (but it takes time, and a time during which you can't collect wheat) or you can carry all in your truck (but if someone hits your truck, you lose a percentage of the collected wheat). Simple mechanics, but extremely well applied.

This game has huge potential to become very popular! I hope this little gem gets the attention it deserves!

Take a competitive item racing game, and mix it with a farming simulator. Works quite well, and I love it. I'd love to see more content added to this game, but even how it is it is quite fun playing. Has some slight rng for stat upgrades, but that adds to the challenge!

Overall 8/10

While simple, this game is noticeably unique as it gets, & genuinely really really well executed, I cannot recommend it enough, has surprisingly large replay value as well, and extremely fun local multiplayer. (This game not having thousands of reviews is criminal)

The devs get extra credit for the perfect arcade music, obnoxious yet still full of irresistible earworms.  Go into the game settings and crank up the screen curve to make your monitor (or tv!) look like a crappy old arcade cabinet screen.

Literally STAR-dew vally. 10/10 would recommend to any stardew vally, innocent life, etc fans. I hope the developers are as great as Concerned Ape is and continue to add and add. 

My ONLY issue so far is that as a legally blind person who still has sight, the text is just a little to small for me, but the average person will NOT have this issue.

The art style and feel of the game is wonderful. However, the game is incredibly grindy and progression bottlenecks because there is no skill progression. While there is a lot to do each day cycle, most of it cannot be achieved because time moves at warp speed. More frustrating is how dated the mechanics feel.

Okay, that is the review, below is really a rant:

Most of the mechanics are copy and pasted. Tools take days to upgrade leaving you unable to do certain tasks. You can only purchase items when shopkeepers are at their kiosk during working hours. The progression on planets is the familiar "harvest resources until you randomly unlock a portal to further area". 

However, the most frustrating aspect is how many ways the game prevents you from having fun. In order to plant one crop you need the resources to build a plot, the resources to build a battery to allow the plot to work, then the money to buy a seed. After that, the seed needs to be watered daily and the most beneficial crops take 10+ days to grow and provide $80. If you want to turn that into juice, you need to expend more resources to build a juicer (will also mention, that it needs to be unlocked based on unseen stats), build more power, then place a crop in there and wait 45 hours in game! 2 days to produce 1 juice box is silly.

I nitpick because these are the 30 second gameplay loops that players do and they are fundamentally broken. Stamina has always been an issue in these games, but there isn't a reliable way to increase it. Again with the lack of leveling up stats, items become the primary driver of replenishing health and stamina. Yet, as I mentioned earlier, producing things takes too much time.

I'll end with a mention of economy. Most games require a few patches to seriously iron out economies, but the cost of upgrades and the price you get for selling things is comically skewed. Again, items have extreme value in this game yet with production taking forever and the cost of those items returning low values, the grind becomes too real. 

Fortunately, the core gameplay is fun. The economy needs to get heavily tweaked or a system needs to be added to get more stamina consistently or to make the day longer.

TRDR: Loved it, hope multiplayer is introduced

I stumbled upon Little Known Galaxy thanks to TikTok, and let me tell you, it‚Äôs been a game-changer for my partner and me. We were knee-deep in a Stardew Valley multiplayer escapade when this gem came along, and it completely hijacked our gaming schedule ‚Äì in the best possible way.

At first glance, you might roll your eyes and think, "Oh great, another Stardew knockoff," but let me assure you, Little Known Galaxy is in a league of its own. While it shares some similarities with our beloved farming sims, it manages to carve out its own niche brilliantly.

One thing that immediately grabbed my attention was how it made me genuinely care about the characters and restoring the ship, which is something Stardew always missed the mark for me with restoration of the community centre. 

I will acknowledge some of the lower scoring reviews here as well, and say that I do wish that I had the ability to extend how long a day is, or that I had a little more energy to work with as collecting some materials can be a bit of a grind. [EDIT: Regarding the grind, after a bit more game-play and upgrading my laser gun once (was easy enough to achieve this) the grind dissipated and I now feel like the pacing is spot on. I feel like the people whop reviewed negatively based on this, gave up well before that point, the grind is no different to Stardew's early game grind.]
I saw a few complaints about the difficulty of the microbe system, which after trying I was a little shocked by. I found the microbe catching system a touch easier than Stardew Valley's fishing, which is also notorious for being a tricky mini-game for new players. That said I noticed that the creators (a husband & Wife duo) are incredibly responsive to feedback, having already implemented some brilliant improvements, including more alien hair/skin colours, faster walk speed, NPC locator and ability to rename your Tav, the ship etc. With so many great QOL updates already made, I hope that Carbon & Kay hear the constructive feedback and make the necessary adjustments to keep the game challenging and fun.

It doesn't have a multiplayer mode at this stage and I couldn't find any indication that this was something planned for the game. My partner and I would LOVE if a multiplayer mode could be introduced, whereby Captain and vice/co/assistant to the captain work together to rebuild the community and explore space. 

Whether it's nurturing crops, exploring the vastness of space, or fostering relationships with the diverse cast of characters, there's never a dull moment in Little Known Galaxy. It's the perfect blend of familiarity and innovation that keeps you hooked from start to finish.

It is... different!

- slow paced
- progressive grinding
- quite repetitious
- sweet pixel art
- but relaxing too

The Devs believed in "copy n paste" when it come to the "chapter" design.

"Credits" is all you get when finishing quests (most of the time)

Wouldn't buy it for 20 bucks - just wait until it's on discount for 5 bucks again!

The bones are good. Cute art. Fun set of characters. I love that instead of "seasons" you have different planets to go to. I love that you're a rookie captain trying to prove yourself for captain points rather than just some guy taking over a farm. I wish it was less grindy, but honestly I don't think it's any more grindy than most games in this genre.

The problem is... there's nothing really here. It's basically JUST grind. You advance the "plot", grind some more, advance the "plot", grind some more... The characters don't say much and don't get much more interesting over time, and the plot is basically nonexistent: you are looking for pieces of the mcguffin. There are some flashes of something more in here (I love that you have to save the sea people from landsickness), but just flashes. Adding more character development and story would help this game SO much. Also, I really think it would help cut down on the "grind" feeling if a) you could recycle old creations and b) you could see the whole list of possible buildings in advance (just greyed out, or "needs recipe" or something). I see a lot of people complaining in reviews about things that get better, but they didn't make it that far. Making it clear to players that there are goals out there beyond "get to next planet" would help a lot with the grindy feeling imo.

So far I‚Äôd say it needs more QoL for me to enjoy. I was falling asleep playing. I think the game itself is good so far but it starts off a total slog. Tentative recommend but I will be waiting to continue to see if they add more QoL.

Stardew Valley in space, but with less time in post-release development so less content.

There's some differences.  There's no seasons in space, and you replace the mine levels with planet exploring maps.  And it's easier to get around town because it's a 7-floor spaceship with an elevator.  If there's a fishing minigame, I haven't found it.  Things like that.

Aside from that, surprisingly similar, albeit slightly cutesier.  Hard to complain, it plays smooth as silk.

I'm not usually one to leave a review but the devs have put so much love and care into this game that I wanted to share my own adoration. I did play the demo beforehand, so my playtime is around +7 hours from that - about 11hrs total at time of review. 

Put shortly, LKG just makes me feel cosy inside. The  dialogue is quite uplifting, and humorous at times; the music is upbeat and incredibly well done; the audio feedback in game feels good; the game is bright and colourful, and just very cute visually.

I appreciate so much that the game was made with controller in mind, as someone that has to play games with a controller due to chronic pain. The gameplay feels incredibly smooth. I love the space theme and the fact that it is a story driven game.  The beginning is a bit slow, but it really picks up after a few in game weeks. 

The combat is simple but well done, with a variety of enemy attacks from the first planet visited. If the combat is a struggle for you, you can farm the materials needed for an upgraded Laser Blaster within the first explorable area of the planet (no enemies) by resetting that level to gather the materials needed and the combat becomes a lot more manageable.  

After an in game month, my only gripe with the game is that the movement does feel a slow. There is something available that I haven't gotten around to getting yet that should improve this for navigating the ship  (and it is available within the first month of gameplay). I don't think the base movement speed could be adjusted too much more without massively affecting the combat though, so I'm happy enough with how it is, though if this is a sticking point for you then this might not be the game for you. 

Overall, I've been really enjoying the game and I hope other's decide to give it a try too ^-^

In most ways I don't think this beats Stardew Valley, but it's a good entry into the genre. The demo will give you a good glimpse of the game up to the 10 day mark, and if you enjoy it you can keep playing with the same save.

The art is cute, the characters are nice, and it's mostly fun to play. The days move in 15 minute intervals instead of 10 and your movement speed is a little slow, so it feels like you can't get as much done in 1 day as you can in others. It's an endless game with no time limits, but sometimes you just want to do a bunch in 1 game day. The planet exploration starts out very slow, and with the limited inventory size at the start you can't carry much and the trips don't feel very fruitful. Then the resource and money costs of upgrades is daunting at first (but they have already adjusted some things based on feedback). You can't grow crops that quickly because you also need solar panels to power the planets. The microbe capture minigame, sort of this game's analog to fishing, has a very short tutorial that leaves some people very confused, but the devs added options to make it easier or completely skip it.

But it does hit a groove during the 2nd planet and the issues start getting resolved. The devs are still looking to improve the game but it's definitely ready for a full release.

Lovely game to play if you like Stardew Valley, but you probably already knew that from reading the description. 

I really liked the pixel art, and the fact that I do not need to go hunting for NPCs to gift them items. 

Not the greatest dialogue with NPCs and little variation to fetch quests and combat, but then again I sank 70 hours into this game in two weeks, so overall a win for me.

It's a cute game, I love the theme and the characters are nice. Needs more content. I agree with the other reviews that it's basically a less good Stardew valley, but as someone who loves Stardew valley, that's a high bar so a less good SDV is fine by me.

However. The game is way, way too grindy and it needs rebalancing. Every recipe is ridiculously expensive and you have to keep going back to the planet to grind. The spawn rate for the marker to take you to the next planet zone is also way too low so it can be frustratingly tedious to get to the next checkpoint within the space of a day / without running out of energy and needing to use a lot of items.

Also, stealing the idea of a fake rock becoming an enemy from Stardew is one thing, but making every single rock get up and chase you while you try to finish your grinding is just annoying.

It has potential but needs more tweaking, I'm equal parts enjoying it and frustrated with it as it is, and I'm a big fan of farming sims.

On balance, I recommend it but I wouldn't rave about it. I'd recommend playing Coral Island, Sun Haven, Roots of Pacha or Research Story before playing this.

Nice game, but too outdated. Inventory management is so 1990-s, nobody spends their playtime juggling items between chests and cupboards because the inventory is too small! Also grindy. Example: you need to assemble a quest item that requires 10 aluminium. For this you need a machine that produces aluminium. You need 100 stone to assemble this machine. You can get stone by scavenging, but something like 10 units per in-game day, if u are lucky. So about 10-15 in-game days to just get enough stone for that aluminium-making machine. When u assemble it, u realize it can only make 1 piece of aluminium at a time, and even this will take about half an in-game day. And here's the most not-fun part: aluminium is not the only thing required for that quest item, and stone is not the only thing required for that aluminium-making machine. Dizzy already? And it's just tip of the Boredom Iceberg. Surely you get more resources and better machines later in the game, but you'd probably lose all hope much sooner.

Fairly enjoable little game with a cute colourfull artstyle. It plays alot like a Harvestmoon/Stardewvalley game but on a spaceship.

One big issue I have, is that the gameplay feels very slow to me.

It is decent for its type of game but not great. If you are a Fan of the Genre you will definiteley enjoy this, but if you think these 'cosy' games are just OK, maybe look elswhere or only buy it on a discount.

Stardew Valley IN SPACE!!!  Enough said.
In comparison, the only minor con (for me) is the soundtrack is not as well-implemented as in Stardew.
I don't like that if I stay in one place for an extended period of time, the music stops playing.
I want the music to be on a continuous never ending loop, so I can get lost in this game and just completely forget about the world.

I can't recommend this game as the grind for materials and money is incredibly unrewarding. Currency is very hard to come by as the cost for items and upgrades are very high compared to how little can be made by selling produce, foraged material and quests. Microbe research is the best option to make money at the time but requires a fair bit of effort looking for said microbes and catching them requires a minigame that isn't very accessible-friendly (pretty tightly timed minigame) and becomes tedious almost immediately. Building requires prohibitive amounts of materials considering how much energy needs to be consumed in order to obtain just a fraction of what recipes call for.

Edit: supposedly, the drop rate of resources and amount of energy available have been buffed but I couldn't really notice any difference.

Super cute and cozy, albeit a little grindy and doesn't have enough aliens to romance. Why make a space game with aliens but then make almost all the romance candidates human? QwQ

Though still a solid farming game, having a lot of fun. Definitely recommend!

Way too grindy to be enjoyable.  You got collect ore or rocks for 30 minutes, and come back with enough to [i]maybe[/i] make one item.  I played with a mod that let me ignore stamina and doubled my speed (thanks Nexusmods) which I'd have likely quit much sooner without.

This is not a bad game, in fact with some tweaks I could actually see this game being quite enjoyable.  However, on my 300th trip back to the planet surface to collect enough rocks to make 1 thing, I just stopped booting it back up.  D+

I get that people always are always comparing new farming games to stardew valley, but it's not necessary a bad thing as SDV has become a symbol of the genre's standard. If a new game is on par with SDV, it means the game is good! It's that simple!

Little known galaxy meets the standard of a quality farming game, but it's not an exact clone. It has its own charm and it's what you'd be looking for in the farming simulation genre.

Familiar in the sense of common tropes but fresh enough in terms of how the game is executed to keep you engaged for a long time.

Things I would like in the future:
1. Have children with spouse
2. Day length slider
3. More alien romance options

I think everything else about the game scratch the itch for a new farm life simulation

Recommending but with a big asterisk attached. I like the game a lot, the art style is cute but it needs some serious improvements. For one thing, the energy levels feel unbalanced and deplete faster than seems fair. The tools take energy even if you use them on accident outside of their purpose, things are expensive, there's nothing to do while the ship is traveling, and biggest of all YOU CAN'T HOOK UP WITH PILOT.

I like the game don't get me wrong but I don't think I'd spend $20 on it again.

what an absolute GEM. the creators have really set themselves up well with the planet mechanic being the alternative to the usual mining dungeons that accompany farming/life sims. it feels like a complete game but also is rife with opportunity for future updates and DLC. so glad I bought this and can't wait to see  how it grows.

This is one of the best farming sim games I've played since Stardew Valley. It's rare I get so into a game that I am "addicted" to playing it, but this is one of those times.

The concept is so cute - you're a captain on a spaceship, exploring the galaxy, uncovering the mystery of the relic and visiting other planets along the way. This is a great idea for future content/DLC also because there could be way more story lines from exploring the galaxy.

Like most other farming sims, money is slow at the start and there is a grind element. My advice is: [spoiler]farm lots & get on the juicers as soon as they're available! Also, xenos are ADORABLE and give you lots of good resources to put into machines and sell.[/spoiler]

The community is great and welcoming and the wiki is really informative and helpful.

I'd recommend this to anyone who likes cosy games / farming sims :)

This game is so underrated and deserves more love! Lots of people say it's similar to Stardew Valley but in space, but I think it deserves its own standing. The story line and concepts are different along with the art style. In the beginning, I feel that the game is less of a grind and not as time-sensitive compared to other farming/life sims, but as the game progress and you unlock more planets and resources you can definitely grind more. If you love the mining aspect in farming sims, you will love this game! I love how many different area there are to explore and the added science aspect to this galaxy exploration game. I can't wait to discover more!

Very fun game reminiscent of Stardew in space. I played the demo for 5 hours which ported to the full version, so I have 12 hours in game as of this writing and I'm only on the second planet. Plenty of content and the devs are super active on their discord. Highly recommend.

If you want to play a realistic farming-sim, you play "Farming Simulator 20XX"
If you want to play a farming-sim with a bit of fantasy, you play "Stardew Valley"
If you want to play a prehistoric farming-sim, you play "Roots of Pacha"
If you want to play a faming-sim in space, you play "Little-Known Galaxy"

Absolutely brilliant game! I have played over 1500 hours of Stardew Valley, and despite that, this game still feels like a completely new experience. The graphics, the sounds design and the writing of the dialogue is all of the highest order. Thanks devs for such a pleasent surprise and keep up the good work!
It's spacedew. No skill progression or fishing but it scratches that itch. More updates are promising, worth the price of admission for sure.

This game was fun at first and has many good aspects to it. But after playing for a while, I felt it was too grindy to the point that it is a continuous struggle to get money to do anything in the game. This is the first game I've ever played where I felt real genuine frustration afterwards, and not even in a rewarding kind of way. It genuinely made me mad and feel worse after playing it.

It's an ok game. Like Stardew Valley, but in space, and not as good. It does have some neat unique mechanics, but it's just not as charming as SDV and feels more monotonous. I've not noticed any bugs, and the graphics are reasonably nice. Characters feel a little flat. I like the map functionality. 

I probably wouldn't advise buying it at its current price of ¬£16.75, but might be worth it if it was on sale and you've absolutely rinsed SDV of play-ability but have an itch to scratch. If you've not played Stardew Valley yet, play that, it's better and also cheaper.

While this game is definitely relaxing, I have issues with the amount of time and resources it takes to get basic facilities established. The power mechanic results in a lot of grinding to get solar power to power a machine you had grind to get the 60 rocks for, getting 1-2 rocks a node on the starting planet. You lose energy quickly, time goes by quickly, and the starting quest don't give you a lot of options to do in between but to sleep until your crops are grown. The planet exploration somewhat mirrors Stardew Valley's mine mechanics with the checkpoint system, however, you could tackle the first mine with the base amount of energy 5 levels at a time to about level 60 out 120 with no preparation. Little-Known Galaxy, with the way to progress planet exploration by breaking rocks or digging up dirt, you most likely will not reach the next major checkpoint, even with generous space food spawns from dirt, with out first buying food. While I still enjoy the game, and have found it charming and bug free, these issues, which have been resolved by Stardew and games like it, seem out of place. Combine these issues with little information on the game existing, I find it difficult to stay engaged with LKG in its current state. Many of the crew members don't really stand out or seem like people, however I like Pilot and Doc12. Another issue being a lot of the dialogue you get from talking to crew mates everyday repeats. These compounding factors results in a less engaging experience than other contemporary farming sims and seems like a step back even compared to older sims like Friends of Mineral Town on the GBA. Most my issues could be fixed in a patch or mod and many of my points are subjective and stem from spending 2 hours to achieve something I could've done in 30 minutes in contemporary games. Also I probably need to get good or something.

TL;DR: The days go by quickly with the 15 minute intervals being non-adjustable, you have very little energy and the animation when you run out is uninterruptible, too long, and annoying, the random quests with NPC's usually fail because the time frame is too short for a crop to grow, they ask for too much of an item or enemy to be exterminated for example killing six rocks creatures in 3 days and I've only seen 2. As well as needing 64 rocks for a furnace, taking about an in game week to gather what you get in a day in other contemporary sims. Also needs more mini games to kill time for days where all you have to do is water crops, talk to crew mates, and wait.

Overall fun and cute game that I will probably change the review of upon more updates to the game, but as it stands, be ready to grind. It's honestly a 7 or 8 so far but these issues are more likely to be seen by others being cautious if this review is among the dearth of negative reviews instead of the abundance of positive.

To start, I wish I could give this game a neutral recommendation. It's not a good good game, but it's not a bad game. It's a neutral-good game. I played it, I had fun, I liked it, but I have gripes lol

Some good points: 
1. I like the concept of the game: a cozy farming game set in space and you travel to other planets. That's neat, nouveau, fun. And travelling to other planets for the different seed varieties is a cool mechanic, essentially allowing you to "change the season" in terms of seed variety at will. 
2. I didn't feel rushed to do anything. So many games these days place a sense of urgency on the main quest, but this one they're like "We've been orbiting the gray planet for a while now, we're okay, but bored of it" which is great to me! I'm totally fine with just chilling, I much prefer to take things slowly and absorb the atmosphere of a game. High key a great thing for me, especially concerning how long it takes for some things. 
3. The bonuses you get as you raise up the captain rank is such a windfall! Or after donating so much to the museum too. I really appreciated that
4. I wasn't punished for staying up late or getting tanked by mobs. Except for a slight stamina hit, nothing was lost, which thank The Light was so good. It reminded me of My Time at Portia. I kinda wish the game told me how many times I had to be carried to the medical bay like in MTaP lol

The points I wasn't fond of: 
1. I can't marry Kaida. Honestly a crime in my book. üò≠ I get it the main character is a spry 21 year old, and so are all the romanceables, but another game gatekeeping the ship mommy? Damn..
2. The economic (and other) grind. Holy cow that got pretty tedious fast. I spent 2 quarters in the game growing corn bc it had the best price-per-day for me, and even then it helped only so far. Crops don't give a lot of money, and everything costs a lot. I looked at the money I earned at the end of the game, and I had 20k in my pocket, and earned a total of like 230k. Wild. That and everything costs a good amount of resources if you want to be able to finally be successful was tedious too. I felt like I couldn't spend money on extra stuff for my character such as decorations bc I needed so much for everything else, esp when I got tired of grinding and decided to just buy certain things to help speed the process along. 
3. The artifact/gem grind was the worst tho, imo. High key I really didn't like it. I naturally found all of them for the first 3 planets somehow, but by the end I had to use spooksies shop (which was quite expensive) to get the last 2-3 planets worth of gems bc the drop rate is way too low. Way too low. A 10th of a percentage? Whew, lad. Esp since there are 5 of each per planet. 
4. This is a small gripe bc I understand the reason why not, but I did find I missed the seasons. There was no change except on planet-side between the quarters. Except 1 had valentine's day, and another new years day. But on a climate controlled spaceship there would be no weather effects lol. But the planets were okay in variety. A hot desert. A hot lava planet. A water planet. A frozen water planet. It's like, "oh. okay." I get it, I just found I missed a sort of variety. There's no autumn planet (makes sense), and the spring planet is end-game.


Overall, the game was fun, but it felt like a very slow grind at times. There were other things I liked about the game, and other things I didn't. But I feel like this list is long enough lol

It's not bad. It's just not good enough to recommend as it is. It seems like it's trying to be Stardew Valley in space, but it's just not robust enough to compare.

The pacing is pretty slow, at least starting out. Having to wait 2 full days for a tool upgrade before receiving it on the 3rd day feels pretty terrible. This is especially true when the tool in question is the blaster, which is used for both mining and combat. With no way to mine or defend yourself, all you can planet-side is dig and hope monsters don't kill you. And there's definitely not enough other ways to pass the time on the ship while you wait.

I'd go so far as to say there's not really enough to do in general. The options at day 17 in game appear to be the following:
1. Tend crops. Watering and harvesting are both pretty quick and cannot fill a day at this point.
2. Talk to the crew. Pretty quick, as there are only about a dozen crew members. Again not enough to fill a day.
3. Fix up the ship. You probably could spend a whole day doing this, assuming you have something to eat to restore energy and your repair tool isn't in the shop. Because everything uses that single tool, this gets pretty monotonous, and eventually you'll run out of things you can fix.
4. Explore the planet. On the planet, you can mine, dig, and shoot monsters. If your blaster is in the shop, that only leaves digging. With only a shovel, it's very difficult to harvest resources or progress through the area, and you're defenseless.

It appears to be a lot of waiting because you lack either resources or a tool. I think I saw a few skills on the menu, but at day 17 I still haven't gotten a notification that I've gained a level in any of them. If I've gained a level without noticing, it doesn't seem to have improved my efficiency or unlocked any new items or crafting recipes. Without that sense of growth that lets you access things you couldn't before, it's not very fulfilling.

I love space and Stardew Valley, and have been looking to find a game that combines the two. I'm sad to say this isn't that game. It just doesn't match up in terms of pacing, content, or mechanics.

Little known Galaxy is a farming sim similar to Stardew Valley but taking place aboard your very own space ship.
The story is just okay but all the characters are fun and enjoyable. The gameplay is fantastic! The graphics are cute and all match a theme which is very very important. 
As of writing this review, im 40 hours in and I still have stuff to collect. I still have some story to do. 
Although, the market is a bit saturated with these kind of farming sims, Little Known Galaxy has proven itself worthy to be considered one of the top games in the genre.
8.5/10

Temporary review while I take a break after my first session; I do think I would recommend this as it shows a ton of promise and could be one of the best SD-likes I've seen. However, there's an issue in time management and time wasting. Too many separated rooms you need to walk through to get from one fast travel point to another, too slow of walking speed, days moving too fast. You need to have your mental map of how to get to your destination thoroughly understood in your mind and remember which rooms to walk into to get to the travel points. Walking is a slog, the sprint button moves you to walk. Just a short play-session shows that the game promises a lot of content and a lot of fun upgrading, and the devs have QoL in mind as your crafting bench accesses your storage, but the basic traversal is just a huge pain for now. I may pick back up in a day or two, or might wait a few weeks to see if changes on this get made. 

Thumbs sideways, possibly way up in the future.

I love Stardew Valley and this is definitely a straight replication of a lot of that game.  Except for some key points that make it hard to get excited about it.  The music and art style fall far short.  Which is easily forgivable.  The key point is that the game is on rails.  I've only played to the second planet but the game makes it hard to explore things on your own.  It plays like a very long tutorial for itself.  You can't do anything unless the game decides it's time.  In Stardew Valley you could set your own goals and decide what you were going to do with your time.  There are VERY few choices in this game that are your own.  Combine that with the clunky controls, make it genuinely difficult to relax and just play the game.

[code][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33025671-Missi-the-Achievement-Huntress/] Please see my curator page for more games that are well worth your time[/url][/code]

[b]Approximate amount of time to 100%:[/b] 75h+
