[b]Minimum number of playthroughs needed:[/b] 1
[b]Is there a good guide available:[/b] Not yet, but you don't need a guide. On the Steam forum, there is a topic with favorite gifts, that can help out a lot. 
[b]Multiplayer achievements:[/b] No
[b]Missable achievements:[/b] No
[b]Grinding Achievements:[/b] Maybe the complete collection of gems/artifacts but in the end game you get a way to complete those in a much easier way
[b]DLC-Only achievements:[/b] No
[b]Speedrun achievements:[/b] No
[b]Time-gated achievements:[/b] No
[b]RNG-achievements:[/b] No
[b]Does difficulty affect achievements:[/b] No difficulty setting
[b]Unobtainable/glitched achievements:[/b] No

I'm blown away by LKG! It has so many little awesome details in the artwork. The artwork hanging on walls, how the scene behind the windows changes when you move your ship. The items in people's houses tell you a lot about them.  I'm equally impressed with the different kinds and types of people, from shy to social butterflies, from morning to evening people, from human to robot all different kinds of personalities. Also, the events in the game are so lovely and wholesome. There are 2 main annual events (Friendsday & New Year), and there are short cutscenes between the people that live on your ship. 

The gameplay is so addictive, there is always so much to do. There are times it can be overwhelming but if you follow the quests you unlock new stuff to make it all easier. What I didn't do right was not make multiple machines and tons of planters. I felt like that just cost so much resources, but later on in the game, I could see that by not doing that and trying to get by with the bare minimum, I only made it harder for myself. So I highly recommend taking the time in the beginning to build multiple machines and many planting spots, so you can grow crops quicker, which will help with the quests but also would allow you to make so much more money, and money felt real tide during the storyline when you have to buy things for the quests, but also want to upgrade the ship and your equipment. 

There was this moment at the 5th planet, where I just felt overwhelmed by the quest requirements. It was so much that I needed to take a short break from the game. However, now that I'm on the other side (and even finished the game) I can see I was stressed out for nothing. I should have done what I have done the whole game, first do the quests of my crew members, so I get the items/machinery to make quests easier, and after that go for the quests from the current planet. 

The developers of LKG, Carbon & Kay, are super responsive here on Steam as well as on their discord server and are working hard to make LKG the best game it can be. I really want to highlight that it is so unique to play a game for 70h+ and I haven't encountered any bug at all. At the same time, they also work so hard and brainstorm how to make the game even better, like working on the mini-game to catch microbes and also figuring out how to make it more clear that people should build a bunch of machinery and not just 1 of any type. 

The achievements in Little-Known Galaxy are what you expect from a farming simulator kinda game. Befriend a bunch of people, grow every crop, finish the main storyline, and find every microbe type, artifact, and gem for the museum collection. I would recommend keeping one of each in your storage until the museum unlocks. However, it isn't a problem if you don't keep them as later on it might be easier to get them again. and for the artifacts and gems, in the end game, there unlocks a shop to make it so much easier to collect them. 

I give Little-Known Galaxy 4,5 out of 5 stars.

This game is such a wonderful little gem!! I've only been playing for a few hours and already gotten so invested and lost in the coziness and cuteness of the characters,the exploring, the farming is so unique and i cant wait to see what all this game has in store! Such a new and refreshing take on a farming type sim/space exploration. i recommmend picking this one up if you are into these types of games for a totally new feel. it wont disappoint! to be a 2 person dev team they have done a spectacular job! Loving it!!!

Welcome to [Enter Your Ship Name], we've got: Grumpy Loot[strike]bug[/strike]crab, impossibly cute googly-eyed rocks, and Groot but with a full vocabulary! Oh, and also clones, cats, critters, cooking, character customization, collecting, cutscenes, crustaceans.... 

This is a game that will fill wholesome-cozy-lifesim holes in peoples' hearts. The artstyle is yummy, for a lack of better words. Coming from someone who played and loved Harvest Moon, My Time at Portia, and other gems, I instantly fell in love with Little Known Galaxy during my stint as a beta tester. Now of course, while LKG shares similarities with these games and can be called a "Stardew Valley in Space," that alone doesn't do it justice. The backstories between the crewmates are unique to themselves, detailed and deep, intentionally woven together to create a canvas of one giant story: The story of a giant family aboard a spaceship, and a mystery that piques everyone's interest. 

Your story begins as a novice captain aboard a ... uh, less than state-of-the-art Space Alliance ship, learning the ropes in real-time and putting your prior Captain Training to good use. From there, it's up to you whether to dive head-first into the storyline, or to go gung-ho with collecting resources, producing better resources and kicking space-critter butt. Some of you will no doubt start off the bat with a beautiful living space as your top priority. I've gotten to experience it all, and am so astonished at what this crew of 2 lovely devs have built together.

It fills me with such a specific joy to see my crew members live their own lives on my ship. They have fun with each other, get work done, and let me know their thoughts after something eventful just went down. Getting to Best Friend territory with them all is so, so rewarding. These peoples' lives are diverse and interesting. 

There's so much more I can say about my hopes for the future, or gush over my many favorite details; ultimately I will say that in every aspect of this game, I have found very compelling reasons to pull all-nighters (in-game of course...only in-game...) and play for hours on end to reach goals such as: a well-furnished deck, an efficient garden/production pipeline, a complete artifact collection for a certain crabby someone, a fully unlocked kitchen, amenities for the entire ship, more xenos for my many xeno pods, exploration rewards, and so on and so forth. 

So go forth, and don't be afraid to make mistakes. There's no such thing as a perfect captain, but a captain that does their very best. Take your time and enjoy the journey.

If you enjoy farm games this is a really good one: tons of contents, around 100hrs of entertainment, and bold changes to the formula of the genre.

Just to experience these new ways to make a farm game this is valuable.

However, may feel a little bit slower sometimes: don‚Äôt worry, they are balancing that with each update and they listen the community a lot.

I loved the characters, the story, the art, and the gameplay. 100% family friendly.

I love the relaxed element of the game. Its the Stardew Valley of the stars. Building friendships and exploring new planets all while crafting farming and cooking. Definitely recommend if you love games like Stardew valley.

i want to like this game SO badly :(. the characters are fun, the setting is interesting, and the game play is engaging. but i just cannot get past the level of grind this game has. the amount of time and resources needed to upgrade/progress is way too high, and it's clear that this aspect of the game was not properly play tested.

As Captain of the USS Stardew, my first mission will be to boldly farm where no one has farmed before!

[spoiler]With more than 50+ hours of content, I suspect my first mission will last quite a while.[/spoiler]

[hr][/hr]
[h2]Initial Observations[/h2]
I'm nearly 10 hours into the game and have very much enjoyed the experience.  It's been quite a while since I've played a non-Early Access game in this genre and it's certainly a welcome change of pace.

If you've played the pixel art cozy farming games before you'll see a lot in Little Known Galaxy that's familiar.  The two main things that set it apart for me are the space setting and injection of an overarching main story that appears to span multiple planets and a variety of alien NPCs.  It's not your typical "relative X left you this rundown property to turn into a farming paradise", but rather a sort of space adventure to uncover the mystery of a relic you found on a nearby planet.  As such, it somewhat gives off Starbound vibes when it comes to the questing, lore and setting but with a bit less focus on combat and more on crew interactions and other NPC relationships.

As far as progression goes, getting access to new gadgets and crafting/refining stations is largely governed by story and quests from your crew rather than a more sandbox tech tree approach.  This is probably fine for some, but I can certainly see how this makes the game feel "slow" at the start for others.  Next it's on the player to clear checkpoints on the planet surface (a lot like the mine + open areas in most farming games) to collect the necessary resources and refine them as needed to craft stations, items, and pay for tool upgrades.

The pacing of income is actually quite well controlled in the beginning.  Usually in these types of games there's a handful of easily obtainable drops or refined/crafted goods that you can sell for significantly more money than others and use this to bankroll faster progression.  So far I haven't found anything like this.  Crafting and refining resources and components doesn't add nearly as much markup as some other games.  Many upgrades and construction options cost several hundred to a few thousand in currency, so there's definitely some grinding to be done!

When it comes to the combat, you're essentially using a ranged laser weapon.  However, I was pleasantly surprised at the variety of enemies and their move sets for having only made it to two planets so far.  There's melee as you'd expect (some even camo as a resource node), but some charge and others explode.  I did find one ranged enemy type as well.  The visual design and animations are crisp for the player and hostile alien creatures.  I hope the variety holds true further into the game as well.

Overall from what I've seen so far, if this game really is at least 50 hours long at a normal pace, for roughly $20 USD that's a great value for sure.
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Observations after 20 Hours[/h2]
Having played for over 20 hours at this point, Little-Known Galaxy continues to deliver a satisfying experience.  While I do periodically get the feeling that the pacing can be a little slow, shortly afterwards through some quest or interaction a faster method opens up and the pace improves.

While most of my initial observations still hold true based on all I've seen up through the 20 hour mark, I've described below some additional aspects that I had time to experience a little more thoroughly:

[h3]Thoughts on Time Passing[/h3]
The rate at which time passes seems fine for me so far. Depending on how you approach talking to most of the crew each day, there's enough time to spend roughly 300 energy (either on ship or planet surface), tend to a garden of about 10 crops, and talk/gift at least 10-15 crew.  This is before I got the hoverboard.  After, the above becomes even easier.

[h3]Thoughts on Traversal[/h3]
Ship traversal without the hoverboard also seems fine.  Sure you have to spend some time traveling to the elevator but I haven't found it too tiresome wandering around the ship because a lot of the key areas are pretty close to the elevator.

The hoverboard isn't as fast as I thought it was going to be, however, because you can get on and off the board near instantly, overall it's a great time saver.  You also don't need to be right next to it in order to mount it and you can go through most doors while still on it.

[h3]Thoughts on Non-Energy Activities[/h3]
It's nice that there are things you can do for progress and currency on the ship and on the planet surface when you've run out of energy for the day.

[b][i]On the ship[/i][/b] the microbe detector is the go to way to spend time when you are out of energy and not yet ready to sleep for the day.

[b][i]On the planet[/i][/b] you can cycle through saved checkpoints and dodge aliens to farm the collectable objects (i.e. flowers and seaweed) that don't require a harvesting action and as a result cost no energy to acquire.  These objects sell for a decent amount of currency and some can be eaten for energy/health.  Unlike a lot of farming games, you can navigate to a previous "level" and the entire area will have respawned (even on the same day!).  So this can be a good method to spend spare in-game hours for the day when you don't feel like collecting microbes or talking/gifting with the crew.

For the current price, I cannot recommend the game. Buy it at a deep discount ... maybe. But frankly, I'd advise against it since there are plenty other games of the same genre that are much better.

Pros:
- looks cute
- main story line is kinda sorta okay
- I didn't run into many bugs

Cons
- lack of depth (e.g. in regards to in-game upgrades)
- feels rushed and unfinished towards endgame
- extremely repetitive; planets all feel the same (find x amount of pick up resources, find x amount of minerals etc)
- farming is unnecessarily cumbersome and you are forced to do it (for quests); same goes for your xenos and while that is voluntary, it is just so repetitive with no way to avoid all of the tediousness
- making money is horribly unbalanced; you are stuck grinding away farming for relatively measly sums - it feels like the game is trying to plump up its gametime  this way
- most of the NPC's are generic stereotypes; ironically, the one that you are probably not supposed to connect to comes across as being the most authentic and relatable 
- the way the main story is told fails to build suspension; there is not real emotional payout at the end

Before anyone says if I don't like grinding, I shouldn't be playing this type of game ... I absolutely love the right kind of grind. The  kind that rewards me and pats me on the shoulder. This game just fails to do that for me.

I finished the main story line and can't find the motivation to keep playing beyond that. Will uninstall and I doubt I'll ever play this game again (unless devs drop some amazing updates).

I love space and I've been waiting so long for a farming or life sim with a space theme that scratched my Stardew Valley itch and I think I've finally found it! 

Little-Known Galaxy is a incredible farming game and it's really embraced its space setting and made it part of the gameplay. You can travel from planet to planet, there are different life forms to meet, and cool new tech to play around with. 

If you'd like to see an overview of the gameplay, I've put together a video showcasing my first 50 days in game to give you a taste of what to expect: https://youtu.be/4961TazMpOQ

EDIT: I've also tested it on Steam Deck and it worked great!

I found this game beautiful, easy to navigate, well thought out and so cute! It is very satisfying to play and accomplish tasks. As someone who hasn't found anything I love nearly as much as Stardew Valley until this game - it comes pretty close. I love the small sci-fi nods (I can order earl grey tea!) and live my best starship captain life, while still farming blueberries and digging for artifacts and farming fluffy space puff creatures!

I want to love this game desperately. The music and art style are beautiful, characters are enjoyable, and the overall aesthetic is everything I love about cozy life/farming sims. The walking speed is abrasive and the spaceboard barely helps. What did me in ultimately was the crafting/upgrade system. Unlocked the watering robots, made 4 of them. Feeling pretty good about making some hard won progress. Then, I finish a quest and unlock the upgraded watering bots. Rather than allowing me to upgrade the bots I already have, the game tells me that I have to re-grind all the base mats + extras all over again. And of course everything requires processed materials, so you need to farm 25 ores or scrap metal to get 5 metals or condensed metal cubes. I tried sleeping through the crafting grind through about 2 weeks but then I hit a point where I needed more silver ore and I just lost all joy and finally stopped. If the crafting/upgrades are re-balanced to be less grindy, I might try again.

Too grindy and gets boring fast.  It was fun at first but then quickly became very frustrating.  It's so hard to get money to do anything, and everything costs so much!.  The microbe mini game just annoys me.  And if I'm waiting the three days to travel to a planet, or to craft something for an upgrade I find myself getting up in the mornings, watering my plants and then going right back to sleep to progress because you can only walk around the same ship so many times.  I play cozy games as a way to unwind and relax and this one just doesn't make me feel all warm and fuzzy inside.  The idea of this game is great, but I think I personally have to put this one down for now :(

Poor Sproud - I will never get his mission cleared

[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
Forgotten Lectures - Fall of a Dynasty - The Beginning is a Unity based railroad visual novel.

[h1]Story[/h1]
You are Faron Taggert. Your father, Marius, has agreed to a strategic marriage between you and Sorsha Tolwyn. You last saw Sorsha when you were both children as your father was visiting on business. Now you are betrothed to her.

The main issue you will need to overcome is the differences in culture of your two societies. You come from a less technologically advanced, and more prudish society. Sorsha's world is military conquest and carnal victory celebrations.

You have been informed, by both your family and hers, that your only duty is to create an heir. You can have as many concubines as you desire.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
There is only one resolution, 1920 x 1080, or the drop down to change resolution doesn't work. You have the option to play Windowed, Full Screen Window, or Full Screen. If your monitors are higher resolution than 1920 x 1080 you'll want to play Full Screen Window if you have more than one monitor.

There is a slight lag when you go from one screen of text to the next, especially if the image changes. This initially caused me to advance more than one screen at a time. You can use the Log option at the bottom of the screen to see any text you missed. I found when I was traveling in space I needed to click multiple times to advance, unless there was a story scene playing.

Day 2 is a bit confusing to start. You're show a cityscape and clicking the screen doesn't bring up the next screen of text. That's because you have to select a location to go to, and there is only one. This continues, where you need to find the location you can go to, again there is only one. The building you need to go to is highlighted, but it is easy to miss due to the lighting. It isn't until Day 9 when you start to have multiple options available on the map.

Being a Unity visual novel, you cannot normally save when the choice selection screen is up, only before or after.

While there is some nudity, there are no proper scenes. Think R rated movie, where you see the characters in bed and then the screen fades to black.

There are some grammar issues, but not major ones.

The Cara Becken character is terrible. There is no way someone that incompetent would be selected to be a military liaison.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
This is like an R-rated movie. There is some nudity, but no actual scenes. The story is okay, but feels like a rush to the finish at the end. It isn't until the end of the game that you understand what the title of the game refers to.

Came here from the WAN show sponsor spot and this feels like a product that's still firmly in alpha rather than a polished beta.

The biggest problem is that MetaDock is not user friendly. The provided tutorial videos are not helpful in illustrating advanced features. It's helpful the dev is willing to answer questions in Discord, but having better user documentation guides would be preferable. Changing the theme to anything other than the default risks making the text color completely unreadable. The ability to dock native apps is completely borked (this is noted in the app, but I can't even get confirmed apps to work). It also doesn't help that the app looks like it was stuck in 2005 rather than something modern. I can understand a function over form philosophy, but better design would have been preferable.

The biggest question is what real purpose does MetaDock have? Most operating systems have some sort of available tool to tile windows. It works great when there's a lot of floating windows as I am currently using it as a Twitch Dashboard, but it took a ton of work to get there and the actual dashboard from Twitch would work good enough. I guess it's nice to have multiple accounts in one instance, but Chrome profiles can do something similar and any use cases feels more geared towards cryp/o and finance, and I can't help but feel there are less scuffed options and the crypto stuff just makes it feel shadier than it is.

It does what is says on the tin and it works in specific use cases, but this really needs a lot more work and polish.

[b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2520820/MetaDock/]MetaDock[/url][/b] is an excellent tool!

I use MetaDock primarily as a web browser to view up to 8 stocks at once on my small HD screen.  It has a feature that allows you to save the loaded pages as a group, so you can create other groups of pages to load, then easily switch between groups of saved pages.  You can also easily re-arrange the size and position of all the tiles to make certian windows more prominent than others.  Before MetaDock, I used to spend 20m every day to load many browser windows, go to the pages, and re-arrange the multiple browser windows so they looked tiled on my screen.  Metadock cut that process out completely, and I can be up and running in 20s.  I believe if I upgrade to an ultra-wide monitor I could have groupings of 16-24 stocks at a time.

I discovered that MetaDock can also load any application into a tile, like a game, or a text document, so you can use an application inside MetaDock!  It's a very versatile tool, and I can see this being a big hit with stock/crypto users, managers who want to keep an eye on a lot of things, or presenters who might desire a nice limited interface to show their audience.

It's so nice to have tiled browsing instead of tabbed browsing.  Until I came across MetaDock I didn't realize how much I needed this, and with screen sizes getting bigger and bigger, this is a much needed feature for the future.  It's pointless to have 1 big screen with tabbed browsing, when the pages have so much white space these days.  Tabbed browsing is so 1999, and tiled browsing is the way of the future!

I beta tested this application.  Still, I would reccomend it to anyone who wants to take full advantage of their screen space.  MetaDock is still a first release, and there are things that could be improved on, so it's not a perfect score yet, but I'm hoping the dev keeps improving it and I'm looking forward to see how much further MetaDock can take its features and polish!

Coming from the wan show, I really tried to give this a shot, but the video tutorial is already outdated and shows an interface that is different than mine, it also was not capable of docking the steam app into it, which was the main reason I decided to try out metadock, you can technically dock or pin apps with standard Windows tools, however, i thought metadock would be a good option as not only can i not fullscreen a youtube video with standard Windows tools, and the Steam window can only be resized so small, so it won't "snap" to standard Windows sizes, and i hoped metadock would be a solution to these problems. I even tried running Steam inside a web browser since metadock could not recognize the Steam app, but if i full sized the screen, it was too big and cut off almost half the screen, but if it was not fullsized, it was tiny and took up maybe a quarter of the "docking window" with no way to drag to resize like a standard window. I understand this project has mostly been undertaken by one dev, and i like the concept of what is trying to be done here, but i also agree with another review posted here that this feels like it is in an alpha stage, not a beta, I don't mean this to discourage the dev, but in its current state, i would not say this software is usable yet, at least for my intended use case scenario. If this changes, I'll update this review, but between the outdated tutorial and the current lack of functionality, i can't currently recommend this program.

Having been a MetaDock user for nearly two years it's great to see it now go live on steam. MetaDock is my absolute go to application and I simply could't do without it. Having the ability to have all of my work-spaces organised exactly how I want, in a way that was practically unachievable before, is of huge benefit to me. I have multiple work-spaces ranging from one instance to six instances. I use a three screen setup but am able to switch between the six instances with ease. The innovative and intuitive design allows me to create any number of windows within windows, so I can group my applications exactly how I want and they remain there every time I boot up. I experimented recently with how much time that saves me using just one screen and four windows within it using windows docking feature as the comparison. What took nearly a minute in windows took three seconds in MetaDock. I then scaled that up to the six screens that I usually use and that equated to a minimum of six minutes in windows {probably longer tbh} but less than ten seconds in MetaDock. This would mean that if you booted up just once a day using MetaDock compared to organising your workspace in windows you would save over 30 hours of time a year! 

There is a ton of other stuff I could go on about but while this is free just download it and give it a go. The Dev is a top guy and always on hand to help if needed and happy to chat about any feedback or ideas you may have to make MetaDock even better.

For me its a solid 9/10 for now as there is always room for improvement so come join the gang and help us push for the 10!

Brilliant software. Main use case for me is the ability to resize windows that can't usually be resized or have limitations with resizing.

I'm able to do almost as much on 2 monitors now as I could on 3 monitors, as most of my open windows can't be resized to fit all onscreen.

My personal use is to have discord and OBS open, while also having my music player and a 13 band equaliser up. I personally didn't see much use in using it as a browser, since modern browsers and some windows 11 features get you most of the way to what this software does.

Stability is fine, though I probably wouldn't trust it with a word document unless autosave was on.

I'm reviewing this product while it is free, but I've seen in other reviews that this will be temporary:
How much would I pay for it?
Depends really, to streamline browsing... absolutely nothing. You can group your tabs in most modern browsers, and you can snap windows in many different ways in W11 (Which you realistically should be using if your device supports it).
To do what I currently do with it... I'd pay maybe ¬£15-20 as a one off. I couldn't justify paying any more just to save me 2 clicks, especially since I can plug in another monitor and save those clicks for free (mileage may vary).
To use in other ways... I'm unsure honestly. This software certainly has its uses, but even I (a chronic multi-tasker) don't really have any other reasons to use it over the snapping features of windows 11. If you were a huge stocks / crypto trader or writer and need lots of news articles or financial sites open to reference then this could be useful, but if you can keep track on more than the 4 things that windows 11 will let you snap to a single screen at once you should really consider buying more displays or making better use of virtual desktops. If you are a broadcaster you might find use in running multiple OBS instances in groups for each scene in your production or something, but I'm kind of grasping at straws here.

One shortcoming of Windows 11 snapping that this software helps with is the fact that after I shut down / sleep / display off my computer my windows won't always remember their positions, or will be slightly resized for no apparent reason. This software allows you to lock windows into position and save workspaces similar to virtual desktops that you can swap between quickly.
My only complaint with workspace swapping is that I'd prefer if windows would minimise once you swapped a workspace instead of appearing on the corner of my primary display 

Overall: Good enough product, but the average person (and even some more serious multi-taskers) probably won't have a need for it (Especially if the price tag ends up being high). Virtual desktops and windows 11 in general do most of the things this software will do, but there are certainly some niches that might find tons of use from this.

A short puzzle game with very little to get excited about. 

The plot revolves around a young woman who is kidnapped by an unknown organization. She is now compelled to go through a series of challenges with a kinky twist. All in the name of science.

Trials are completed by moving around the playing field to reach the exit and shooting at enemies. This just temporarily incapacitates them, and there is no way to get rid of them. Fortunately, they follow a predetermined path. The other gameplay aspect is avoiding traps.

This is where the naughty bits come in. When your heroine is captured, you are taken to a separate screen where you must mash the button to escape. It's essentially a sexy scene in which you are tortured by various mechanical enemies and gadgets. It doesn't go too far because of the "innocent" art, but it can ruin your day if this is your first exposure to the theme.

Energy serves as both your health and ammunition. It gradually recharges, ensuring that you are never left vulnerable. It even works when you are depleted of energy due to traps and enemies. When you run out of energy, the game is over. This can happen quickly if you shoot all over the place and move around with little energy.

You will be taken through three different settings. The appearance may change, but the fundamental mechanics remain the same: simply move across the stage and activate objects to open the exit door. Each location includes five stages that must be completed in a specific order.

There is a basic upgrade system. Some stages contain canisters that can be used to improve three energy-related stats: recharge speed, energy amount, and burst. Burst is a limited ability that allows you to save yourself from enemies without having to press buttons. 

One big issue is that there is are no options or even a main menu that would allow you to quit. The only way out of the game is to force quit or click the X. The lack of full-screen is also irritating because you are forced to play on a small window that cannot be expanded.

The game is only hard if you care about achievements. There‚Äôs one for each stage, and you get it for completing a stage without taking any damage. The game can be completed in a couple of hours. When you consider how much stuff you get for the money, the game is a bit pricey.

The unfortunate part is that‚Äôs what I‚Äôd have to recommend most about the game. The game is a competent enough, albeit it pretty straightforward and a bit boring, of a puzzle game. Really nice animations, but I can‚Äôt recommend much else about it. I‚Äôd wait for it to go on sale.

The story takes a backseat to the gameplay, focusing primarily on Turqu-chan's journey to overcome the tests and escape from the laboratory. These scenes are integrated into the gameplay, with pixel animations that are fluid and a variety of outfits, positions, and accompanying moans to enhance the experience. It's worth noting that these scenes feature non-consensual sex acts, often with tentacle, robotic, slime, or fleshy themes.

In terms of pros, the game shines with its visuals, level design, variety of enemies, and setting traps. The pixel sex scenes are a highlight, and the inclusion of a gallery allows players to revisit these moments at their leisure. Additionally, the game supports cloud saves and offers achievements, which can add replay value. The price-to-quality ratio is reasonable for those who appreciate this niche genre.

On the flip side, the game does have its shortcomings. The lack of a substantial story and voice acting may disappoint players seeking a more immersive narrative experience. Turqu-chan's adventure is relatively short, and players can complete the game in under an hour, particularly if speedrunning. The price point may be a concern for some, given the game's brevity.

[h1][b][3] Verdict : [/b][/h1]

In conclusion, Turqu-chan in the Hentai Laboratory is a unique gaming experience that caters to a specific audience. It offers engaging gameplay, high-quality pixel art, and a robust selection of adult content. While the game may not be for everyone, those interested in this genre will find it an enjoyable and well-crafted experience. However, the lack of a compelling story and the relatively short gameplay might deter some potential players. Ultimately, it's a game that knows its niche and caters to it effectively, providing a balance of pros and cons that will undoubtedly appeal to its target audience.

[h1]Moved from Vegas Pro 17 ‚Üí to Vegas Pro 21[/h1]
(MOCHA IS NOT INCLUDED IN EDIT)

There's no need to switch between versions every year, so it took me three to finally get enough value to upgrade. I will focus mostly on NEW features, but will also spend some time on ones that changed since VP17.
[list]
    [*]The playback is way faster even for 4K videos with effects
    [*]Drag and drop nearly anything and just edit it (no need to convert)
    [*]More RAW formats support (even I'm rarely using it)
    [*]Adjustment events are amazing time-saver to mass-apply effects
    [*]AI features are not perfect, but fast and suitable for social media
    [*]Color correction is finally there (usable, predictable)
    [*]Steam version is limited (no cloud, no MOCHA), but still has AI tools
    [*]Text tools are questionable
    [*]Compositing is another app (not available on Steam), but it exists (if needed)
    [*]AI slow-motion would be great to have, but there's only a conventional one
    [*]There's a VST3 support, so certain featurs can be achieved with plugins
[/list]
[b]Overall it's still VEGAS Pro:[/b] quickest tool to edit videos for web, that also allow you to drag and drop nearly any video into the timeline without conversion. There are outdated UI elements and tools here and there, but nothing crucial. It also hasn't crashed during the first hour even though I tried to overload it with a variety of video formats, effects, transitions, etc.

[b]Adjustment events[/b] are the most important part of this version that everyone will be able to use. You can finally "cut first and apply effects later" (and not lose any speed on it). Events are set on any track and will be applied to anything below them. There are even transitions and the ability to fade in and out for these events (separately from each video or other track).

i wasn't sure at first, but i'm overall happy with this software.
i have used cyber link, Microsoft built in stuffs, and recently Movavi pro, but they all lacked features i needed.
many other software require work around or just compromises that this software just has available.

i will admit, the ui scared me a little initially, and it wasn't exactly intuitive at first, but with a couple of generalised tutorials, and some prodding around myself i learnt enough to get some renders and whatnot.

i have a few friends who use this software for more professional reasons, and i see why this is deemed as such high software!
it is by far the most valuable video editing software i have ever gotten my hands on!
I have barely scratched even a little of the surface of what this tool can offer but i am extremely happy with my purchase so far.

for those wondering about the refund thing, i would recommend looking up one or two tutorials first, then set your usual 2hr timer, you should be able to get a vague idea of whether or not this software is for you by then! 
around an hr in i knew this was going to be my main go to software!

i got it on offer and opted for the cheapest upgrade version (18 to 21) it just gives you both software versions, but obv i have only used pro 21 so far!

i haven't not done much, but i will also note that compared to other cheaper software (oki movavi is literally half the price, but with not even half the functionality) but probably one of the coolest things this software can do is actually utilise your GPU (unlike others that run entirely off of CPU for some reason)
so finally my 3090 is getting used! 

TLDR: finally i guess i would say, if you just want to edit your holiday footage into something for your friends/family to enjoy, you really do not want to get this software at all!  (go for the cheaper/free options out there and run away from here lol)
but if you do any kind of social media, and don't mind a bit of a learning curve (yes there are tutorials on YT etc but i think you really have to prod at it yourself tbh, then i think from my perspective at least this software is highly valuable!
that being said, i have a feeling ill be flicking between both movavi and vegas pro, at least for the time being (i haven't tried using the editor in Virtual reality yet, (i sometimes like to edit things quickly on the fly while still hanging out in the digital realm!)
i haven't yet found out if there is a GIF rendering option either, so i guess it cant do everything everything (but there's like ten million render output formats, its probably in there somewhere)
but if you feel like reinventing the wheel (who doesn't right?) it looks like you can go nuts with this and a photo editor! (i like krita personally)
in conclusion this software is amazing fun!

edit 2: after around 140 hrs of use, this has become my daily driver, its amazingly powerful, and does almost everything i want it to. (ai tools are unavailable in steam version afaik?) 
i hate to say it but friends have told me about Davinci resolve and its AI tools, which happens to be free... 
ig you could get this product from a website instead and get the included ai tools. but i digress.

for what i have been using this for i am very very happy with the software, i did have one software breaking crash once, but it was fixed with a couple hrs of searching thru tutorials.
(turns out i had to change a setting within the editor itself)
my advice if you do run across any bugs, when you search for tutorials via either search engine or YouTube, try looking at the ones aimed at older versions of this software too! its all compatible with each other to a degree tutorial wise, so thats cool!

This is not a review, but rather a helping hand for whoever might need it.
If you experience crashes, sudden stops when pressing spacebar and so on, go to bios on your pc and disable any RAM memory overclocking.
In my case, the memory has a base speed of 4800mhz and I was running it at 6000mhz, getting all these random crashes in Vegas.
It worked for me, so it might work for you too...

What I wish the next update's changelog looks like:

+ The server default is now WITHOUT bots.
+ the Rifleman now uses your Steam username instead of your Epic Games username.
+ Added bullet penetration through players and objects
+ Added killfeed icons for no-scope and penetration kills, with corresponding experience rewards.
+ Better networking so players don't get knifed from shooting distance.
+ The players crosshair now doesn't move and is now a more orthodox crosshair in the middle of the screen.
+ Player's ping is now noted in numbers instead of the signal graph
+ Ping for servers
+ Host migration always chooses the player with the most stable internet connection.
+ Players with a bad connection don't teleport and flicker around. Added animation and location insertion.
+ Added a clear way of distinguishing bots from players by means of a different name colour.
+ The spawn protection indication is now based on team colour instead of blue.
+ Improved hitboxes for many objects, especially trees.
- Removed the "take revenge x times" missions. Some players never get dominated so this mission forced you to lose.
+ Nerfed knives.
+ AI Nerf: Bots now sometimes miss on close range.
+ AI Nerf: Bots don't pull their knife as often as before.
+ AI Improvement: Bots don't all move in the same direction and walk in chains.
+ AI Improvement: Bots don't look through, and try to shoot through walls anymore.
+ Blurred the background slightly of the sniper scope when zooming in.
+ Rename the game Riflemen, without the 'the'.
+ Added unicode and font support for non-alphabet languages
+ Various bug fixes and improvements.

Planned for the future:

More content
More achievements
Add Steam Trading cards
Make the in-game weapon skins into Steam items instead of unlockables.
Make the Premium DLC into a Prime status like CS:GO.

I looked at the dates and this is older than Cum & Climb, but I'd dare say the level design is better. It felt more structured with not silly amounts of repeated objects to climb along. It also had beds, which I felt like I didn't see in the early stages of Cum & Climb (Admittedly I have to go back and play that now that I have some extra time).

But the flaws are pretty obvious. You only get one path, while good climbing up games are littered with plenty of alternative paths. These alternative paths also add up to a chance to save yourself when falling. In this game you better play on easy mode to handle falling, or you are on the bottom since few sections are as on top as a fall can be saved.

There is room for improvements, and I'm not sure I saw any of them in Cum & Climb sadly. But if someone put some work into the level design these games wouldn't be bad alterantives for people who want better motivation to grind.

Gallery felt like a joke since it was available from the start, but you can't really enlarge any pictures so they are tiny. The sex you get on the way up does not seem to be viewable in the gallary, which kind of makes sense if they are there to motivate you to climb.

Additionally, the controls in that mode are finnicky and its nearly impossible to get anything even resembling what you want to do.

Oh, you're here for gameplay? It... mostly sucks, honestly? And there's no tutorial either, despite the first level being named tutorial. Doesn't tell you what the buttons are, and the upgrades have tiny """lore""" tidbits instead of a description saying what they do. Oh and you can't scroll that either.

Hoe tof het concept van een virtuele omgeving van een historisch significante plek in Nederland ook is en hoewel ik achter het idee sta van het digitaliseren van dit soort plekken, kan ik niet zeggen dat ik aanraad om deze "game" te spelen. Ik was er met 5 minuten doorheen en de verschillende omgevingen bieden weinig bewegingsvrijheid en zeer beperkte informatie. op het moment dat de bewegingsvrijheid uitgebreider was en je op meer plekken verschillende stukken informatie kan krijgen had dit een veel interessantere ervaring geweest. Daarnaast is dit stuk software 1.5 GB. voor 5 minuten aan leestekst en rondlopen op 2 vierkante meter per "gebied". Ik zou grappig kunnen zijn en kunnen zeggen "ik wil mijn gratis terug" maar ik vind het oprecht erg jammer dat deze software zo beperkt is en slecht geoptimaliseerd is, terwijl in het concept zelf veel potentie zit voor meerdere delen als deze goed uitgevoerd worden.

Wat een fantastisch spel. zoals de trailer ook al laat zien. Ik kan niet wachten tot de DLC van het louisedal.

Ik hoop dat er ook een vervolg komt.

mooi. ik ga weer Rome total war spelen nu.

dank dank dank

Sadly, no.

The whole concept of the game (being able to recruit your own guys) is let entirely down by the fact they are not at all survivable. They will either get mobbed by enemies, or will get shot to pieces while standing still and shooting back. Add to the fact that the upgrades system is clearly not thought about at all, because all of your unit and army upgrades are both boring and extremely incremental in both the in game level ups and after game currency spending, the game is more of a chore to play than is fun.

The translations here are pretty bad too, frankly. Alot of them have clearly either been misspelled, translated correctly but extremely directly, or use such odd sentence structure that i had to re-read them once or twice.

It's a shame, because the idea of the game is fun. The execution is where it fails.

EDIT: Having played some more, i have noticed a few other issues. The biggest is that your health has no way to recover unless you choose to do so on the upgrade screen, unless i'm missing something. This then sends you down a cascade failure in a run if you get hit (Which again, is hard not to do, esp when enemies who all have guns come in the circle pattren!). With some upgrades to your troops, grenades and the ability to heal them has made the game more enjoyable in the last update, the translation is still very poor and the healing issue is my current biggest one. Others include some rather janky animations when reloading, running animation in general being poor, and other various fiddly bits.

I have to rate this down.

It runs ok, but the progression and unlocks are terrible. Both outside and during runs, you get abilities that improve stats by 1%-10% and the most exciting upgrades are the +10 flat damage and the +15% damage for army. There is nothing that creates effects, just tiny stats increases.

You can only unlock infantry no vehicles for both you and the enemy.

Your soldiers have basic AI and will stand to shot or follow you if you're too far, they'll group up doing so and get cleaned up by enemies AOE or own grouped enemies mowing them down. You can't keep them alive, and you have to pay money to buy more.

You can raise your small income during a run, it takes 30-40 cycles for the investment to be pay back, at which point you're nearly done with the run (or dead).

The game could work but need a complete overhaul of abilities and upgrade, so there is meaningful way to spend levels ups and units upgrades.

An interesting change in the Survivors genre where the bullets are the main thing to evade.

You play a hero and can command a squad of your making (units can be upgraded too) to find your own strategy, which gives you a lot of imagination on what kind of team you want to build. There's also an upgrade panel that affects your whole game which is a nice break from having to individually upgrade every hero so you can try new heroes and don't have such a backlash from not having it leveled it up.

Overall a nice and good addition to the genre to play on your free time!

For $4 this is an easy time killer. Never upgraded past the first hero, quickly realized the heavy trooper was the best (high ROF, Armor, Health) and went from there. You have to min-max the game a bit to be fully optimal (Bring two unit types to the field, but only use the heavy troop, if you bring only one unit type you get generic 'army' upgrades only, but if you bring two or more troop types you can get upgrades for a specific unit and they are always higher than the whole army upgrades)

I've done several 30 minute games on endless, but since the amount of points (warbonds) you get per mission is capped I quickly realized it was way more effective to only run 15 minute games. 

I already managed to survive a rank 5 (highest difficulty) of the last level 'campaign' but maybe I'll max out my hero, army and heavy trooper upgrades and see how long I can ultimately last.
This game is undervalued compared to quality. There are good art designs and a variety of weapons. The main character is really cute. Thank you to Humbara Studio developers!

With its eye-catching 2D graphics and captivating art style, this game plunged me into a deep rogue-like adventure. Each character and enemy feels meticulously crafted, showcasing the dedication of the game's creative team. The mechanics of the game keep each playthrough fresh and exhilarating, offering a different experience every time.

Particularly, the immersive atmosphere and striking visual style of the game provide a unique experience unlike anything else. Each level is like a brushstroke: distinct, vibrant, and full of character. It truly feels like more than just a game; it's a work of art.

One of the aspects that impressed me the most about the game is how the gameplay always feels fair and balanced. Every death presents an opportunity to learn and improve for the next game. This allows players to continually evolve and experiment with new strategies.

In conclusion, this game has managed to captivate me with its appealing visuals and enjoyable gameplay.I highly recommend this game to anyone

The variety of weapons is great, and each one feels satisfying to use. I especially loved using the katana ‚Äì it added a cool, stylish edge to the combat. The controls are smooth, and the game's design is visually impressive.

If you‚Äôre looking for an exciting, high-energy game, give Penguru a try. It's a fantastic mix of action and fun that I highly recommend bro.

Dragon Legacy is a re-branded Day Of Dragons. They just put it into a "new stage" which means they replaced Day Of Dragons for this  which "resets" every ones playtime back to 0.0 hours  which I was expecting them to have a huge mark on improving the game. 

 Some people like it and fair play to those enjoying the simplicity of flying around as a dragon or running around as a dragon and hanging out talking to one another and doing some pvp but that is all there is to it  if you want to fly, find a water and food source fast as a baby and keep hidden until you've grown to fly properly.

Other than that there is not much to it, exploring is not interesting and finding food is a chore with populated servers. People are friendly on most servers but many PVP servers still attack fresh spawn that can't put up a fight.

- Be land or sky dragon
-PVPVE
-Talk to people
-Explore 
-wait to become adult to fly and explore long distances.  

Not my cup of tea still.

Since they made a decision to  Re-brand themselves this normally indicates a huge milestone in development but I can not see a big enough difference to recommend this game. It is still bare bones and I was hoping for a fleshed out game compared to day 1 of Day Of Dragons on Steam.    If they done this to wipe the bad marks then shame on them, but if this is an innocent move,  I am expecting for bigger updates coming faster that will transform the game.  

I didn't play this version long but quickly found it is the very same bare bones game from last fews of playing this game on and off.  Wait till sale OR keep eyes on youtube gameplays that show you the game in action as it is.

They basically made a new game store for a new version instead of keeping their current one which indicates to me they've responded to the negetive feedback over the years poorly.

Its still a broken mess, nothing was fixed for this, they just tossed this out to save their asses after their "release update" rendered the main game unplayable for ~60% of the player base. Its not worth it, don't give them a cent.

** For Authenticity please check my review on the Day of Dragons page - I have over 800+hrs on the original gaming branch **
This game is yet another attempt at them to make a cash grab to anyone looking for a "cool dragon, survival game" and what better way to do that than erasing all the old negative comments on it! 
I would never recommend this game (either version) to anyone even at the low, low price of 4.99USD and this is coming from someone who got the game for FREE.
** Here is my review of the original game as this game provides nothing extra and has currently no updates since my last review. **

Reasons to purchase Day of Dragons:
- You enjoy buying DLC for content that should be included in the game
- You enjoy a Dev team that is more interested in banning anyone with a negative opinion or who has any sort of criticism about their game than making any QoL or actual updates to the game.
- You enjoy getting e-mails and sneak peaks about updates coming "soon" to the game only for them to be continuously pushed back.
- You enjoy having their merchandise pushed onto their kickstarters and labeled "opportunities" and "gifts" to throw more money into the game than the KS have already done.
- You enjoy a Lead Dev who's more interested in pushing his religious views than any substantial updates into the game.
- You enjoy a ridiculously difficult flight system that - once mastered - is guaranteed to still have you face planting into the ground because of the obscene amount of animation bugs and lag.
- You enjoy throwing your money into a void.
- You enjoy seeing crash reports every couple of minutes.

If any of these things appeal to you please purchase this game! It's guaranteed to meet all your criteria. Be sure to subscribe to their newsletter so you can get the same generic email every single week filled with updates you can't feel or see in the game itself.
If you aren't involved in this game just yet count your lucky stars you weren't suckered into the Kickstarter like so many others with the false advertising of this game only to have what you backed become the dragon that looks like Play-Doh and Neopets decided to make a baby and your backed dragon gets the least amount of detail and work involved. With the added detail that it can't cause any sort of damage or obtain any sort of usefulness or attack except.. making things glow! How exciting!
**Keep in mind a lot of communities with rules also include the rule "Don't make dinosaurs glow that don't want to" so your one-and-only ability turns into a bannable offense! **

Please look at the Dev's responses to other people's reviews if you have further questions on regarding whether or not this person listens to their community as they take no accountability and only try to sow mistrust among anyone with a negative review than theirs. Some of the POSITIVE reviews have been left by staff as well - unreliable opinions.

Look I know it only says thirteen hours but that's just how long I've played since they made the beta branch into its own game. For me this came free after they had it 'full released' for a bit over a month, if there's even an option to buy this game without the full release version don't do it. This is the beta branch - very incomplete with a lot of poor mechanics, only three options for playable dragons and glitches. It will likely never be fixed or improved on, this is pretty much just so people can enjoy the mechanics that haven't been fully ported into the full release yet.
That said it is fun to be able to play as all of the backer-exclusive and other paid skins for free over here. That's pretty much the only draw to this branch.

The game lacks mechanics... Like a lot of mechanics... Basically there are 3 pillars for this game:
- Evolve (just over time) to adult, then eat mushrooms to become elder. PVP servers are empty, on PVE you just breed to receive better stats. Boooooooooooring. Srsly, that is it since 2019?
- Eat
- Fly (very crooked mechanic)

Graphics - like a game from 2012...

Overall, I cannot recommend it. There is a gameplay for 4 hours, maybe. Sad that I cannot refund it.

It's relaxing to hop in, be a dragon, and fly into the sunset.  Could there be some changes, yeah, but for what's its worth, I'm really enjoying the game.  <3

Dragons Legacy is Day of dragons Legacy Branch that they gave everyone who got the game before this for free. This review is for EVERYONE else. dont waste your money on this. its not being updated. its not going to have dev support. its a legacy version.

Dev this edit is for you, its a waste of money because this version is no longer being updated. You wasted time making this into a pointless side game when it should of stayed as the legacy branch its not that big a deal to switch between branches. Wasting time on this small cash grab instead of working on a already late update. For only 4.99 you the buyer can buy a game that wasn't even planned, a branch of a game that is in early access.

-- [h3] BEFORE YOU BUY [/h3] --

[b] NOTE: "DRAGONS LEGACY" AND "DAY OF DRAGONS" ARE  2 *VERSIONS* OF THE SAME GAME, BUT STILL SOLD AS DIFFERENT/SEPARATE GAMES!! [/b]
Differences:
"Dragons Legacy" (5$, old version, no longer updated)
"Day of Dragons" (20$, new version, currently in EA/development, will give you the game "Dragons Legacy" for free)

-- [h3] "DRAGON'S LEGACY" VS "DAY OF DRAGONS" [/h3] --

As of writing this, the legacy version ("Dragons Legacy") has more content than the newer/EA/1.0 ("Day of Dragons") XDD. 
+More skins and easier upstatting
+10x better performance
+Fewer bugs
+Decent hitboxes 
+Actually launches/playable (XD)
+Elder system
+More food (important bc this game is literally a caseOh simulator)
+Etc.

BUT It does have an outdated map, smaller roster, and has been abandon by the devs (isn't receiving updates anymore). If you want to buy the full release/updated game, search for "Day of Dragons" (It's 20$ TwT). By buying that game, you'll receive the updated version PLUS this one ("Dragons Legacy") for free. 


-- [h3] "DRAGONS LEGACY" GAMEPLAY [/h3] --

Literally a [strike]walking[/strike] sitting simulator. (Still better than Day of Dragons/1.0 tho XD)


Otherwise, the game features:
+A nice movement/flight system 
(nothing insane but still better than most games)

+Basic to decent PvP
 (Air battles can be REALLY cool-even just to watch-and different dragons each have their own abilities they can use to their advantage. However, ground/"bite fights" are very lacking, it's literally just spinning in circles TwT)

+A small roster of playables
(The SS (Shadow Scale), FS (Flame Stalker), and ASD (Acid Spitter Drake). The roster may be small however each dragon offers a unique play style, and it's pretty well balanced for the most part imo.)

+Nesting 
(Players can nest together for stats and skins. If nesting for skins, parents can pass their rare or even exclusive (KS/Patreon) skins to their children/hatchies. And if for stats, it can give you insane advantages in PvP.)

+Large map 
(It's very barren tho)

+Groups and clans 
(group up with friends/other solos, or make/join your own clan! Clans can have up to hundreds of players each, and you can find the list of recruiting clans in DoD's official discord. Clans can be very fun, with wars, nesting parties, training sessions, etc.)

+Elder system
(After reaching adult, you will continue to grow/elder very slowly overtime. If you manage to reach full elder, you'll be twice as strong as the normal adult of your species.)

+Other features I'm too lazy to mention
(A few different types of small AI, scenting, etc.)

Hi there I do know I got low hours but on the main day of dragons I got easily over 1k hours, I am an official DOD Senior Admin. We host the Official PvEs here and there's some community servers on as well. I've been here close to day one as a Kickstarter Supporter. 

I HIGHLY recommend joining Day of Dragon's Official Discord server to follow the game's updates, new concepts, and just generally have a fun time also see all the updates, different communities around DoD, and events. If you ever have questions to ask, mods, admins and even kickstarters will try to inform you on what you asked (if I'm around I always love helping anyone out). Also, twitter, youtube, and patreon are great for updates as well as here on steam news if you wanna see what's coming up for updates again the trello in #links will tell you what they plan if they edit/update anything it is updated manually like other things. If you do decide to join their patreon (official's), they have different rewards listed on patreon but also in the discord (#patreon-proclamations) once the bot updates your role once you add discord to your patreon account it may take up to three days or so to update.

The community itself on discord and in game are extremely helpful, on day one launch I saw all kickstarter players help out the new people to the game with basic mechanics to watch them thrive and become into their own awesome dragon and even now people who have tons of hours in helping out newbies. I've been in it since I've backed it, and I don't regret it a single bit. The people I've talked to are kind, helpful and they're funny too. I feel like they've become my second family. I've had a blast with them and will continue being in their community and playing this game.  

Note: Dragons Legacy is basically the Old Legacy Branch of Day of Dragons. You don't have to swap branches to play with friends who may have been left behind due to requirements. If you already have Day of Dragons this game is free for you or it should be so if there is any issues there please let the team know. Also keep an eye out on the main game Day of Dragons <3

Making a review even tho i'm usually not the one to do so, I played DoD for a long time, since 2019 alpha, and this legacy version it's something i loved with all my heart, runs good enough even on steam deck (you can play 1.0 on steam deck too!!), the map even if old holds many memories, events, and games, it is a game where i come back from time to time even just for nostalgia or for helping players who can't play 1.0 yet!

Should you play DoD Legacy in 2024? YES, specially if you are new and not sure of everything, or can't run 1.0 for now, it's great to start learning the basics, like flying, hunting as a hatchling, learn how to nest with other players, test out skins that aren't in 1.0 at the current time, and also relax and chat if you wish
Note that some things are different in the newer version of the game! that is expected, but things like upstatting and eldering are completely different!
So enjoy the old map and dragons, and I hope to see yall on 1.0 a day!

Separately, I want to highlight the soundtrack. Although it is made in a retro style, it sounds modern at the same time. Each of the soundtrack complements the locations with a unique atmosphere and makes them unique.
If you are a fan of hardcore and retro games, then you will definitely like this game.

The game wants to be extremely difficult, it is, and totally overshoots it.
It is so old-school that you wish for at least the simplest quality of life improvements. But there are no such things here.
And that's either exactly what you're looking for or it's not!

But the slowdowns (or was it the adaptive difficulty mode?) made it impossible for me to like this game. Because it got so slow that it suddenly became way too easy.

I'm writing this review on my son's account, i bought him the game. On my account i have 40+ Killon hours and building, and i did not want to taint my original review of this cult classic by an edit.

Now then, we are shmup aficionados and hold dear brands like Cave, Taito, Henteko Doujin, Triangle, Psikyo, EastAsiaSoft, Zun Stuff, Moss, Siter Skain, Chohou Joutai guy, and to name a few favorite specifics Red Death, AWA, Trouble Witches, Wolflame, Battle Garegga Rev. 2016, Crisis Wing, Gun Wings, Neon Aileron, R-Types, Varth, Progear, Andro Dunos, etc. If it's a decent shmup we want it in our collection. That said, what makes all the above games great besides their original concept would be things like art, music, developer choice of gameplay functionality, difficulty, ship operation, controller option, things like this. It has come across our desk that this Killon game stands alone as a future cult classic in its own right and i will try to list why as specifically as possible below seeing that i have thoroughly enjoyed 40 hours of gameplay and intend on much more:

Ok so it's a difficult game, that's what I noticed at first. I realized almost immediately that enemies were really hunting you down as opposed to generic bullet patterns that are built into many games. I believe i read somewhere that there's an a.i. element to the enemies in this game and that really makes for a challenge as it becomes more realistic if you will. The enemies seem to have maybe 5 different methods of attack at any given time based on where you are on the screen and what your move choices are, and the enemies and various bullet configurations are abounding to begin with. Hard mode is preferred here. The difference between hard and regular mode is not that much as only maybe 20% of the enemies are removed from hard mode to make regular. I believe the game originally only existed on hard mode at first so this is the mode we play. Regular mode doesn't really prepare you for a hard launch mode seeing that new enemies awaiting you will need to be learned just the same. My strategy is slow and methodical, learn by failing. Luckily, there is a practice mode where you can access the stages before you actually attempt them in order to learn a strategy first. The gameplay itself though is a 1cc system which we consider great because it provides an extra feeling of accomplishment and forces everybody to Get Gud or cry. Example, you start with 3 lives but you can only carry over to level 2 what you keep from level 1, and once you're dead you're dead so trust me you must Kill On. That is a huge element of the game also is killing those enemies so you aren't as barraged by whatever they have for you - this will be needed. Strategies seem like they could be easily diverse. I saw whoever it was playing on the store page video and that person is actually a master obviously. I am more lover of the shmup but lovers can become masters eventually, it happens.


Now then,

Ship movement: Impeccable, fast, responsive, properly balanced against the enemies. Enables you to get where you need to be in order to be correctly strategic. 

Gun: Perfect in operation and powerful and multi-directional off the bat, fires where your ship goes which is very helpful,  and is upgrade-able as the game progresses. Available to set in single button mode which fires a constant missile forward while your multi-directional laser does its work, or dual-button mode where pulse laser and missile are separated. I prefer single button because i need all the help i can get. Single button can also be assigned to either X or A with weapon switch option. The power cannon is easy to operate seeing that all you have to do is release your gun when charged (roughly 7 seconds) and it fires. It is crucial to use this at the right time in order to advance through the level. Also I like how when you die you lose bomb access as with many shmups you die and are auto-granted 1 - 3 bombs this is so cheat. Killon is like a more realistic shmup this is to its credit. 


Soundtrack and sounds: Excellent and Perfect soundtrack which captures the essence of the game as a tribute to the old days but brought up to speed with artistic integrity throughout. The Sounds themselves to me are really important to this game (or any other game for that matter) being really good or just good, or bad etc. The sounds in the game are definitely a perfect fit. The levels are perfect and some sounds jump out at you while others decorate the background, providing for a true ambience as if you're in world Killon. Very good. 

Art: 90s style but doesn't feel old. Feels new as when you were in the 90s and it was new. Can also be considered new by 2023 standards so covers all bases good job.


Concept: Excellent. Game plays with a smooth flow. No hesitation for action here. 


Addiction level: High in my opinion. The game is challenging but with each death you feel like you almost know what you could have done better and want another go at it. The sounds again, make it addictive almost like a vegas slot machine or a psychological reward system is somehow built in. I skipped even many bathroom breaks to continue playing this game and i didn't even care. I really like how the game starts and starts over quickly as i guess this has something to do with the addiction level. Good call - by the time you might have quit you're already playing again, but ok because game is fun.


Let's compare: A game like Red Death which i consider very valuable and difficult, and could go for more than $5 on Xbox and $1 on Steam, but this is just fun because of its vibe and Because it's hard. Very Difficult because of the genius bullet patterns composed by the developers. But i think that can be learned if one had the will, whereas with Killon the enemies are more interactive and the music is better, the game is more polished and immersive, and very much again brings that 80s/90s style to the current age with innovation not simply imitation. 


Developer is receptive and polite and we hope to see much more from this company soon on the Steam Market!

The game is an exciting retro shooter that features vibrant combat dynamics, constant enemy attacks, and a loaded cannon that can be unleashed at any time.
The game offers different modes to choose from, including a practice mode to hone your skills, a Boss Rush mode to challenge the main bosses, and a secret Arcade mode. It's worth noting that there are local and online leaderboards, which add a competitive element to the game.
In addition to its addictive gameplay, Killon is a delight to the eye with its retro game styling, reproducing classic graphical effects such as retro sideways art and scan lines, giving the game a special charm and nostalgic appeal.

"Gumbowl's Adventure" isn't just a game; it's a journey through emotions, memories, and challenges that etch themselves into your soul. Developed by the talented minds at hoodeeGG, this action platformer transcends the boundaries of mere entertainment, delving deep into the human experience.

From the moment you embark on Gumbowl's quest, you're swept away by a tidal wave of emotions. The vibrant visuals paint a world brimming with life and wonder, each pixel pulsating with a story waiting to be uncovered. The soundtrack, oh, the soundtrack! It's a symphony of emotions, perfectly orchestrated to tug at your heartstrings and transport you to realms unknown.

But it's not just the aesthetics that make "Gumbowl's Adventure" a masterpiece; it's the journey itself. As you guide Gumbowl through perilous landscapes and daunting challenges, you're not just playing a game; you're confronting your fears, overcoming obstacles, and discovering the strength within yourself.

Every jump, every dodge, every victory is a testament to your resilience and determination. And oh, the defeats! They hit hard, like a punch to the gut, but they also teach invaluable lessons about perseverance and growth.

Beyond the gameplay mechanics lies a narrative that resonates on a profound level. Gumbowl's story is one of hope, loss, friendship, and redemption. It's a story that mirrors our own struggles and triumphs, reminding us that no matter how dark the night may seem, there's always a glimmer of light on the horizon.

Over 500 hours spent in the world of "Gumbowl's Adventure" may seem like a lot, but every minute was worth it. Each hour was an investment in my own personal growth, a journey of self-discovery that I wouldn't trade for anything in the world.

In conclusion, "Gumbowl's Adventure" isn't just a game; it's a masterpiece of emotion, storytelling, and gameplay. It's a testament to the power of video games to touch our hearts and change our lives forever. Thank you, hoodeeGG, for creating something truly special.

Feels like a slapped together cash grab. UI has some really strange bugs that are clearly a result of poorly thought out programming logic. Physics are terribly inconsistent and clunky. The jump gives almost no verticality yet feels like low gravity - a harsh contrast that makes you feel really heavy. Air strafing is non existent on smaller leaps which simply makes it feel like my movements are out of my control and inconsistent in how far I jump - not something you want in a parkour game. The courses themselves give a pretty low quality "just took some random assets and made an obby out of them" vibe.

The game can be funny at times, and I imagine with more players the chaos could be amusing, but the game itself is just really strange and does not feel intuitive to play at all.

Well after 30 hours I can safely say this game is for the freaks. I like the wide variety of experiences in the game and I don't feel forced to go to npcs that go too far for my tastes. This game is definitely easier the lower you are willing to go and can you can reach a stable point around day 50 if you play it right But that isn't really the point of the game. The game is a bit grindy, however, that feature is good in that it fits the theme for the game. I remember when I first played the game and i did not nothing but worked at aprils to finally earn enough money to pay rent and then i got robbed. I wish that this game had more late game content I recently beat Rhonda's hard difficulty and there is nothing really past that yet. There seems to be more to the story that hasn't been added in yet. There is potential for more content such as more teachers available for counseling such as ms. Viola. Or even after a set number of days say 100 entering year 2 with the upstairs portion of the university building unlocked and more classes such as chemistry. Overall the game is good and polished up to the point  of late game.

This is a pretty remarkable game, though not one for the faint of heart or who take themselves too seriously. I might make a more in depth review in the future, but for now here is my boiled down opinion on what I've played. 

This game is a misery simulator. It conveys a disturbingly potent feeling of being a marginalized person in a incredibly unfair world. The presentation has a sense of humor, absurdity, and fun about it, but it is still HEAVY DUTY stuff.  If you are easily squicked out by other people's fetishes, you may want to steer clear.

On the other hand, If you want a very well executed RPG maker game with unique visuals that may be CRUELER then Fear and Hunger. A game that may legitimately traumatize you, then I say check it out. At the very least you will have an interesting time.

i'm giving it a thumbs-up but with a big caveat. If you've already played the developer's other game "Hentai Femdom Simulator: Femdom University" then there's really not much that's new here.

The game has changed from a 3D game (which i prefered, to be honest) to a top-down adventure-style game. Although this is a prequel to the prior game, it has a very similar beat, largely the same characters and so on. There's less content than the previous game too, although that's not necessarily a bad thing.

On the plus side though:

[list]
[*] Unlike most titles in this genre, this is an actual game, not a visual novel. It's essentially a resource management game with a (very) deviant twist.
[*] Caters to a broad range of fetishes, including some pretty extreme ones if that's your thing (although you can give them a miss if they aren't your thing). There's a bit too much focus on smelly feet for my liking, but enough other things to pique my interest.
[*] There's a lot less content than Hentai Femdom Simulator but that's probably a good thing on balance. Whereas the other game went off into tangents with monster girls, etc. this focuses on the university side of things and is better for it in my opinion. However, it's disappointing that you can't get into the Skullgirls House (as far as i can tell)
[/list]

Quite a few people are complaining about the price. While they do have a point, the developer has got a track record of putting updates out and given how niche this sort of game is, it's only to be expected. There's simply not going to be a huge audience for this, so it's nice that someone caters to us.
the original IS less good, however not by much. it's essentially the same game but they've worked more on playability and smoothness of gameplay rather than making it look all pretty.

I'm a cross-dressing femboy, I really enjoy the degradation humiliation femdoming in this game. Hope to see more content added in the future. All in all, I enjoy the game. 8/10 would recommend to a fellow masochist.

You cannot avoid or stand against many humiliating scenes because you are thrash and can be easily expelled from the school (e.g scene with biology teacher). You cannot say no.
