[quote][i]This is the [b]45th[/b] review of the Steam Redlight series, a series where I purposely seek out negatively or controversially rated games on Steam to see if they're as bad as the Internet says they are. It's accompanied by a video review that can be found [b][url=https://youtu.be/Hf_C9G0rc8k]here[/url][/b].[/i][/quote]

[b]In summary, I can recommend this game, and as a numerical score I‚Äôd give it a 7/10[/b]. The game is visually consistent and there‚Äôs a lot of small details in its sound design that give the game a complete and holistic feeling. Backed by an intuitive and engaging gameplay experience with minimal problems makes this game a pleasure to experience. The game has some minor setbacks with how vulnerable it is to some in-game exploits, some controls and interactions that could be minorly improved on, and one achievement that just [i]keeps[/i] getting away from me in a very frustrating way.

[h2]Introduction[/h2]

In Game Time Glizzys, you play as a reputable hot-dog stand operator that has come back from vacation to find your rink-side restaurant in disrepair after entrusting to some lad named Ace. Your appliances are busted and are in-need of repair, your stand‚Äôs reputation has been dragged through the mud by reviewers, and the bank [i]really[/i] wants all $1,000 it loaned you some years back in seven days.

The gameplay is really straightforward, and because over half your shop is busted up you can only deliver basic hot dogs on warmed bread, or a hot dog on a bun with ketchup and mustard. Once a day, you can opt to repair / re-enable one of your appliances to expand your shops‚Äô offerings including more toppings, drinks, and a side. All-in-all, this is likely to over-complicate your workflow since now the orders will get way more diverse, but in turn you‚Äôll end up making more money. If you want to bust your back, you can enable the second register to take twice as many orders and that turns this game from a casual cooking simulator into a hyper-focused, precision-point, clicking cookery since you‚Äôre a one-person gig.

Each playthrough (of seven days) takes about ~45 minutes, and after four and a half hours I got six out of the seven available achievements. We‚Äôll talk about that seventh one later. Other than the sixth achievement, the game was a joy to play, and I‚Äôll tell you why.

[h2]The Good[/h2]

The game has a lot of good things going for it, and I don‚Äôt think any element is any better than the other because they‚Äôre all so high-up. To start with the visual design, we‚Äôve got models and assets that are fitting and appropriate, from the ingredients, to the kitchen, to the patrons, to the hockey rink your glizzy stand resides in. There‚Äôs some great small details such as the change in color for warmed glizzys, or the hockey puck that appears for a quick second if it damages any of your appliances.

In the realm of the audio design, the game has a lot of care put into it in this category as well. I think the voice acting is all sound for the limited performances that were demanded, from the phone calls to the overhead announcer to the sound effects that play at each gameplay element‚Äôs appearance. The varying announcements from the overhead announcer about scoring, fights, which team wins or loses all add a considerable amount of liveliness to the game. 

Then lastly, I wanted to commend the gameplay. It‚Äôs highly intuitive, but there‚Äôs a quick little tutorial that comes up to make sure you get rolling. There‚Äôs a lot of things to engage with which will cause your shifts to go quickly ‚Äî you might not even notice that they can get up to six to eight minutes long! If you‚Äôre feeling a little [i]shady[/i], you can use the same tablet you‚Äôd use to order appliance repairs to send Ace to do some bidding on your behalf. You can send him to the competitors in the rink to cause a power outage, break their equipment, or even commit a robbery. Your competitors are capable of the same and if they see you succeed, well, they‚Äôll do what they can to make sure you suffer from success. Who knows if that hockey puck that slammed your fully-loaded glizzy-grill was [i]actually[/i] an accident? There‚Äôs little time to think about, just yoink those wieners off the floor and throw ‚Äòem back on before anybody notices. Not like anybody cares, but you know‚Ä¶ for posterity.

[h2]The Questionable[/h2]

The smallest of the offenders is that this game has two exploits that will aid in the players‚Äô favor ‚Äî one should come with context that this game gives you twenty seconds to prep your stand at the start of every shift before the orders roll in. If you‚Äôre receiving a phone call that day, you can just [i]not[/i] answer the phone, and you‚Äôll have as long to prep as you‚Äôd like. I found myself using this because otherwise the prep times do not feel long enough and it boiled down to a simple setup of me going in the walk-in, take a step out, throw hot dogs or buns onto the floor in front of the grill for reloading mid-shift. The second is that you don‚Äôt actually have to warm or cook the glizzys ‚Äî as long as you have a warm bun, you can put them directly from the package into the bun and your customers do not exercise any restraint and will ask for three more plain dogs.

After the exploits, there‚Äôs only some minor inconveniences caused by controls ‚Äî I‚Äôll pick on the tablet first; it‚Äôs kind of rough that you [b]have[/b] to use keyboard keys to go back to the home screen or put the tablet down. It‚Äôd be great if these were clickable buttons, or if at the very least Escape puts down the tablet since it has no functionality when the tablet is up. Another one is that there isn‚Äôt a [b]Restart[/b] button in the pause menu. This button would be helpful because otherwise you‚Äôre closing and starting the game back up to start another run. On the smaller side, if you want to pay your loan in one go you‚Äôre stuck holding the (+) button for a minute or two since you can‚Äôt type in numbers and there‚Äôs no ‚Äòpay in full‚Äô option. Then lastly there‚Äôs the serving bell ‚Äî you can hit this bell a [b]bunch[/b] of times and it‚Äôll cause a ‚ÄúFailed Order‚Äù on each press, even if your shop is closed This isn‚Äôt really a big deal, but it‚Äôd be nice if the bell was inactive when there‚Äôs no customers active so it doesn‚Äôt accidentally ruin a Perfect Game run.

Then lastly, my biggest point of contention was based around the perfect game run. I tried several times to get this achievement but something [i]always[/i] went wrong. Sometimes it was a [i]really[/i] impatient customer, sometimes I‚Äôd be working [i]too[/i] fast and send the order early, but there was this one time where I did not know what happened. I didn‚Äôt notice the failed order until I got to the shift summary screen but I got my reasoning several hours later. While editing my review video, I found that at the end of Day 6, while I was paying off the loan [b]after the shop closed[/b], someone came to the stand without me noticing, and since I was holding that (+) button for a minute or two, they left before I could notice ‚Äòem.

[h2]The End[/h2]

Anywhoo, that‚Äôs it. This game was a blast, and I hope this review helped tip the scales out there. There‚Äôs a great amount of care put into a game that‚Äôs priced at $5 USD, and despite the frustrations I still think it was worth the time I put into it. Now that I have some understanding of how I failed that last run, I‚Äôll probably come back for that seventh achievement sometime soon. I just [i]won‚Äôt[/i] pay off my loan this time because the bank can stuff it. I‚Äôll take the $1,000 I should‚Äôve given them and open up a baked potato stand next.

A surprisingly fun, if not slightly flawed little game that was obviously made with one thing in mind: memes. 

However, beyond the questionable layer of skin that a glizzy may contain is a different number of meats, which also flows into the gameplay. Sure, you may have the option to just sling glizzy's to your customers, or you could go the strategic route and set up your workbench and make sure that every glizzy a customer puts into their mouth is made with the utmost care. 

The sabotage aspect is one of the more unique parts, giving you and your competition a chance to mess with one another. No matter if you get hit with a blackout during a rush, or you find a hockey puck slamming into your dog roller, you'll always need to be on your toes. 

There are some technical issues, mainly condiments going MIA if you grab something else while it's in your hand, or horrifying chugging in full-screen (that could be a me issue, though), but overall, Game Time Glizzys is a surprisingly fun little game that is obviously made with passion and love for the medium. 

Is it anything award-winning? Not entirely, but if you're looking for a great way to keep yourself occupied for a few hours, and want to spend less than you would buying a real glizzy from a food truck and support a Dev who obviously loves what they do, then pick this one up for you and a friend. 

It's a solid 7.5 out of 10. It's no Oscar Meyer, but it's better than the store brand.

Luckily there's also a pipe you can swing, and it comes in handy if you can figure out how to flail and jump back just right. There's a little bit of platforming (which I will be calling OSHA about), and some trial and error is necessary to figure out how not to become dead at a few points.

Game's not that long though, and that's perfect because I already work long hours at the pork processing plant and can't spend forever "grinding late-game content", as I've already ground hundreds of pounds of meat today and am very tired.




Recommended, especially if you know what kind of horror-action stuff you're into - this will fit right into your collection.

This game is surprisingly very good for a short game with a blend of FPS action and horror where the pigs were the ones butchering the humans in the slaughter house.   You play as a human trying to escape the slaughterhouse with your wits and stamina against the murderous pigs armed with circular saws to try and kill you.

Not a lot to it, but an ok way to spend an hour or so. It's a simple 'war' like card battler, with you and your ai opponent taking turns picking cards out of what you chose to bring to your cardfight that day. Cards get stronger over time, disinsentivizng you from changing too much.

[i] My Experience [/i]

I'm a sucker for non-roguelike deckbuilding games, and so it was a given that I would try [b]Creature Rumble[/b] at the cost of...nothing. I was surprised by the card art, which I found to be excellent. I would imagine that developer Rhinosaur Gamez used AI to create it, but even so there's an art to inputting the precise terms to receive what you're looking for. The "war-like" matches were pleasant enough, but the sound effects during combat were rather unexciting and there wasn't much of anything resembling a story arc to the campaign.

Even so, the game only lost me after I'd opened a few of the "booster packs." I've always disliked booster packs, since I began playing Magic the Gathering over 20 years ago. I built many, many Magic decks, but only bought cards from secondary markets and resellers. It was cheaper for a budget player like me, and I could ensure that I got a playset of the cards most important to my deck. I'd much prefer to gain currency in [b]Creature Rumble[/b] that I could spend in a store that includes all of the cards in the game, even if the cards were priced according to their power. I understand the monetary benefits for Wizards of the Coast in selling their product this way, but [b]Creature Rumble[/b] is a free game.

Perhaps those who find it exciting to open boosters will enjoy the game, seeing what rare they might discover, but I personally just want to get the specific cards I need to create the synergy that I want in my deck. Regardless, Rhinosaur Gamez seems to be a fairly competent developer, so I'm curious what he will release next.

Developer Okyakusama has released an admirable number of idle rpgs of late, admirable in number, and admirable in that each title is far deeper than would appear at first, and each employs unique game mechanics seperating it from it's siblings.

For me, Idle Build RPG is currently the most alluring of the bunch.  In fact, I've never seen so many nuanced systems, so much number crunching, in an RPG.

Loot drops are specific to the selected character, so switching classes out is key to their development.  Chests can be crafted from monster drops.  There are four tiers of skills, with eight freely selectable per tier.  Inscriptions of verying quality can be equiped to enhance specific skills.  Three attack and three defense gems, and class specific imprints can be set to a wheel to further define your builds.  Relics are acquired at set levels and grant passive skills and abilities.

Mercenaries can be used upon reaching level fifty, and can choose from forty skills taken from the main classes.  At level one hundred, each class can choose from two Job changes, for instance, the Knight can become a Heavy Cavalry, or a Paladin.  At level one thousand, two more job changes are available, The Knight can choose from Dragon Rider, or Black Knight.  And there are even more job changes further down the line. 

It should be noted that increased options appear into the long game.  Accent on 'long.'  Artifacts, peak points and the like.  Upon reaching a base level of one hundred, one begins acquiring 'peak levels' which at certain milestones further broaden an already burgeoning build palette.

Some upgrades evolve naturally, and some can be upgraded with in-game currency.  Boosts to XP, power, and currency can be purchased, last a limited time, but do stack.  Note, all currency is earned in-game.

The game keeps track of statistics for all classes, along with a general stat tab.

Basic game loop consists of entering a map location, and attempting to reach it's highest levels, while opening more locations on the world map.

As you might expect, this is an enormous time sink, which from your perspective could be good or bad, considering the asking price, I think it's a net good.  

One typical caveat about these Okyakusama games, there is no sound other than the click of your pointer, and no music whatsoever.  You get used to it.  If you play windowed, you can listen to your favorite content creator at the same time.

A surprisingly robust entry into the genre!

I really enjoy the game and it was a bit hard to figure things out at first because there is no tutorial (I still have no clue what Tenacity does), but it is easy to reason through stuff. I have made glass cannons, and poison is your friend! The debuffs persist even when you are dead and your mercenary can use debuffs while you are dead. When your hero dies, it will revive in 30 to 25 seconds. No need to worry about getting hosed all of the time then.

The game is also going to have some depth to it because of the quick change hero system. I haven't really messed with that system much yet because it's going to take time to get all of my hero's equipment at the same level. I suggest doing what I did and focus on the poison hero and the first world till it it slows down. Then, I moved to the other worlds and helped my DoT and poison damage with gems. I also turned off all of the generating items except for the first three. That way I now have tons of equipment chests and will open them with my other heroes to get higher gear for them easily. 

I can tell there are many different ways you can play the game so I hope this helps you if you are on the fence thinking about buying it. I'd love to learn about new ways to progress that I haven't thought about.

What I would like to see in future games:
[list]
    [*] more varied sex scenes so they dont all feel like copy and paste
    [*] smoother animations
    [*] improved character models if possible
    [*] fun dialogue, so that even if the game is short its still fun to read through
[/list]

Otherwise if you are okay with the game only being around 20min long and mainly just being about the sex scenes then it might be an okay pickup.

[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
Cats in Heat - Convenience Coworkers is a RenPy railroad visual novel.

[h1]Story[/h1]
You're the manager of three Neko girls: Lucy, Daisy, and Sophie, at a grocery store.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
While there are 40 choice options they only have a minor impact on the story, such as how the conversation goes, you're getting some no matter what you select. There are three Neko girls and there are two scenes with each girl. Once you have experienced both scenes with a girl they are no longer available to select.

I was a bit shocked at how forward the girls were, but hey they are in heat.

The animated scenes have less detail than that stills and all of the action is animated.

[h1]The Gallery[/h1]
There is no Gallery. However, the game is very short and you should have no issue getting to your favorite scene. Plus you can use the save game slots to get there even faster.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
A short, quick visual novel with Neko girls. Six scenes, two with each girl.

[b]Cats in Heat: Convenience Coworkers[/b] is Artoonu's latest entry in the "Cats in Heat" franchise and adds some changes here and there.

It's as silly as the other two games were. Here, you're in the shoes of a convenience store manager who has to handle his three catgirl subordinates: a burnout girl, a shy girl, and an energetic one. Things take a turn for the lewd when they get in heat and have intense sexual urges to take care of. As usual, the visual novel takes less than an hour to finish, but unlike the other games, the many options in the game don't affect the story or dialogue in any way.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3016438650

As for the visuals, I liked the characters' design and that the dev animated their movements during the dialogue and the sex scenes, even though it takes a bit to be used to it. So yeah, it's an ok VN whose duration makes it perfect to read during a break. Give it a shot if you're looking for something short with more PLOT than plot; you'll like it.

Cats in Heat: Convenience Coworkers is an NSFW VN by artoonu which has the twist of 3D models for the three girls, Sophie, Lucy and Daisy (alongside the NSFW scenes being fully 3d). The girls have the typical 2 NSFW Scenes each as expected by artoonu, having 6 total NSFW scenes. Unlike some of artoonu's work, this game does not have any togglable depth, speed or when to finish, being more linear and only giving the option of where to finish. The story of this game is better than some previous, (being a spin-off of Cats in Heat, this is expected) having the main plot for everyone about store performance and getting a raise, with it being a main plot point between all of the girls, with all the NSFW scenes being based off that it's mating season for the catgirls and they have heighted sexual needs/are under tension. 
 
Now to address the main issue point of the game, the 3d models. I personally don't really mind these models, their movements are choppy and some of the models in the NSFW scenes look a bit odd (not bad, just odd) but I think it adds to the charm of the game. The only thing I will say that I dislike with these 3d models is the semen, as it looks very globby and unnatural (almost like glue). 

The music from the game doesnt detract nor the rest of the artwork. The writing is quite standard to artoonu's other works, having three differing personality girls, one bubbly, one moody and one shy and their writing reflects this. 

Overall, I can understand if you don't want to purchase this visual novel based on the 3d models, although for me - I can't recommend it at full price although I think it's a decent pickup when it's on a sale or part of the "games by artoonu" bundle.

Overall I still feel that this dev is progressing well and improves their work with every new entry.

Sadly I cannot recommend this game to anybody. It¬¥s a simple 90¬¥s point and click game and it would probably be enjoyable, if it was playable... The developers implemented a bunch of mechanics but decided to not implement any of them correctly. So there are multiple times where you miss an object because you used the wrong commands. Most of the commands are also useless 90% of the time so it¬¥s never clear what or when you should use something.

Another thing is the mapping of these commands. Left click is almost always walk, even if pointed at an object, which is weird. It usually becomes walk to and do "x", but not in this game. Same thing with right click, its almost always "look at" which is almost always useless, and it changed randomly. The open and close commands are worthless and dumb, you should have open as walk to and do "x" (open when on door etc) and close should not be a thing. 

There is a bug with books which stalls your game for multiple seconds after you have read one. The save system is also extremely stupid as there are achievements/systems which kill your player and closes your game upon death. Which resets your game back to your latest manual save as there are no auto saves (to my knowledge).

Worst of all is the achievement which you can only obtain by buying their soundtrack so you cannot get 100%. Make it content DLC or put a price on the game. NEVER place 100% behind a cosmetic paywall.

That¬¥s all I came up with in my 30 min of playtime, because I realized I was wasting my time...

Edit: After speaking with Illiterate Code games over Email, we have realised that I may have found some bugs, so I¬¥m very happy that those were found. I will certainly look into playing the game again and most likely changing this review after bugfixes/updates have come through. Cheers!

Pretty good as an adventure game. Although in this case in fact very well done I am personally not an enormous fan of retro pixel art; would've loved this game in its store page title artwork style. And for it to have a more modern interface. And it being a large open-world action-adventure. And...

Oh never  mind. Recommended. Sound and music are also quite good. Well worth its 5 or so hours.

- One achievement is literally buying the soundtrack with real money

- Many solutions are not at all intuitive or even noticeable or conflict with prior information

- The 9 action grid could be avoided completely and only serves to overwhelm a player with meaningless options. I believe I used push and pull once each. Used "give" only once because the energy bar item is arbitrarily eaten if you click it normally. 

- Many items seem to have no use, further contributing to confusion over what you are actually able or meant to do

Specific annoyances:

Arbitrarily can't pick up shirt until end of the game

I genuinely don't know where the recipe solution was meant to come from, I followed a guide out of annoyance. Maybe it was in one of the 100 pixel-perfect books on the shelves.

The pencil is burned in order to use its lead, but the bad pencil can't for no reason, even though it would make more sense since you wouldn't want to ruin the good one.

A few items I completed the game without using: magnifying glass, tongs, bread, salami, sock, cheese

There are very few items the slingshot will work on, but only the horn can be hit with the beans.

The hockey stick must be used under the bed more than once.

Mothballs are used to feed a person, a person who is sleeping.

Once the beans are combined with the slingshot you shouldn't really need to combine them again after every use.

Actions like using the anvil should be skipped when using the torch, as it's implied it is going to be used as a step as that the entire reason it is placed there.

Perfect rendition of point-and-click adventure classics like King's Quest, Monkey Island, and Sam & Max.

Only advice is a hint system- I'm too dumb for some of these puzzles so I had to go through a YouTube walkthrough for a few.  And I'm not sure how the "cup portions" thing even made sense, I just copied the walkthrough.
Classic P&C game, fun story.

A heartfelt love letter to old school masterpieces like Monkey Island, Indiana Jones & the Fate of Atlantis, Simon the Sorcerer and so on, with plenty of references to them.

Art, music, jokes and speech register are carefully designed to give you that "early 90s point-and-click culture" vibes; puzzles are entertaining and not so obvious, with the exception of a couple of them being quite difficult to spot.

Be aware that there are A LOT of red herrings that, despite prolonging the playtime a bit, can be slightly frustrating at times.

TLDR;
A free point and click adventure you really should play if you love the genre, that Will hopefully have a longer sequel coming in the future.
Flash back to the good old days of P&C games.  Well done.

Before I start I want to say that these are just my personal feelings and opinions on this matter. I understand that not everyone may share the same concerns, and some might not even see this as an issue. However, for me, it's a significant turnoff, and it's disheartening to see practices like this within the indie gaming community. Developers need to find a balance between monetization and player satisfaction, without resorting to tactics that could potentially alienate their audience.

With that out of the way, as I was scrolling through the achievements list for this game, one of them immediately caught my eye: "[Supporter] Buy the Extended Soundtrack to support our work :)". This seemed like an odd addition, veering more towards monetization than rewarding in-game accomplishments. Now, to achieve a "Perfect Game" status, players are essentially required to support the developers by buying their soundtrack. It raises questions about whether such costs should be bundled into the game's initial price.

The implementation feels somewhat coercive, potentially pressuring players into purchasing something they may not necessarily want or use. Achievements should be based on actual gameplay, not monetary transactions. While supporting the game is commendable, making the soundtrack a compulsory purchase feels rather heavy-handed.

Moreover, this approach somewhat diminishes any positive sentiments I might have had towards the developers. Had they opted not to include this feature, I might have considered supporting their project postgame by purchasing the soundtrack. However, as it stands, this mandatory inclusion detracts from the overall experience. It's disheartening to witness such tactics overshadowing the core enjoyment of the game.

Initially, I was genuinely excited to dive into the game. However, upon realizing what was happening with the achievement system, I felt compelled to voice my concerns. It's disappointing when promising experiences are tarnished by questionable practices.

A kind friend gifted me this game, but I've had to ask for a refund.  The cats are absolutely tiny and difficult to see.  The game has an in house magnifying glass, but there is no facility to zoom in at all.
There are hidden cats which are difficult to find and you need to be very precise in your clicking.  I gave up when I had a hint and could not find the cat in the hint circle.
Not suitable for those with bad eyesight or poor motor skills.  There is a moving train and 2 cats to click on it. Possibly not suitable for those using a laptop like myself.  I decided not to give myself further eye strain although I love cats.

Sadly, I cannot recommend this game. 

It doesn't have mouse wheel zoom which is characteristic of major Hidden Object games. Instead, the HO items are too small and there is a magnifying glass for particular areas that doesn't zoom in properly as required for all HO games. 

Above all, the font in the game is atrocious. It makes understanding uneasy and literally confuses the players. 

Laush (the dev), after all the ordeal, you still haven't learned anything? If you create a zoom in (mouse wheel) and change the fonts, and the way the story is written, then you're all set!

I like HOG games, and have played several hidden cats games.
Only this one I made a refund request.
2 reasons: a) there is only this little magnifying glass..and it is a real hassle to search a whole screen with it;
b) the secret hidden cats....there is no sign that a cat is maybe hidden...so you [b]MUST[/b] click on everything in the hope 
to find them...and sometimes you even must click on the right spot.
No, sorry, there are better hidden/find cats around!!!

Cute, free, short find cats point&click game. The cat's are kinda small, which mades it a tiny bit harder than other similar - I didn't mind it tbh. I enjoyed the mini levels hidden in building and having to click stuff other than cats to get achievements. There were some cats hidden very well - to the point of having to click on tiny speck to unveil them.

I have played a lot of hidden item games and have to say that Cat City was one of the more challenging (borderline frustrating) ones that I have played. One of issues I had with the game was that some of the cats were very VERY small, even when using the in game magnifying glass- making them incredibly difficult to find. The second, more prominent, problem for me was that the points that you need to click on to interact with the scene or to find the cats is INCREDIBLY precise. This led to some occasions when the hint showed I had been clicking on the right item but the wrong part of it, or even situations where I found it very hard to find the cat even WITH the hint. Frequently, I ended up giving up and relying on the hint function (although I must admit that it was very good that hints were so readily available!)
I did however find the controls intuitive and easy to use, enjoyed the level structures (with the bonus items on each level) and liked the story aspect. If you want a challenging hidden object game then there's a good chance you would really enjoy this game, as I personally don't like them at this level of challenging, I didn't enjoy it as much.
I finished the entire game in about an hour however of course if you didn't use any hints it could take you much longer. Overall, I will say that I recommend it *if* you like challenging hidden object games but if you prefer an easier one then I'd look elsewhere.

I feel like this game is just a bad wannabe Dev Cats game. Yes there is a lot of content, and the cats aren't really easy to find.
But that's all the pros I can think about
- Not accessible to at least visually impaired people, as the contrast for the text is VERY VERY LOW. I can see just fine, and I had a really hard time deciphering what the cat was saying (white font, very light blue and purple text background)
- Talking about the cat, most of what she's saying makes no sense. There is a lot of repetitions, grammar and punctuation errors that makes the reading not really enjoyable. But I wouldn't mind as much, if only what she was saying had any sense at all! I got a very basic understanding of what the story was about, but it was only the case after reading the same thing paraphrased around 8 times total

[spoiler] Yes the message is good, it's important for people to know that black cats don't bring bad luck, but I don't believe it is necessary in a "find cats" game to repeat that you need to find cats in every new scene [/spoiler]

The sound settings should have a much bigger range of notches, the planes and other flying objects should fly less often, and the magnifying glass instead of an actual zoom is a good idea in theory but not in practice, as you have not only a very small area where you can search, but also because there is a big ahh stick in the middle of your screen

I almost regret paying 0.55‚Ç¨ for this game, as even in sale I am left with a bitter taste

[h1]IT COULD USE A FEW TWEAKS, OTHERWISE IT'S A FUN GAME[/h1]¬†
Cat City is by [b] Laush Studio[/b] the developer who created [b]In The Building Cats[/b] and the [b]Search All[/b] series. The game definitely has its flaws, but with a few tweaks, it would be an amazing game; in fact, it reminds me of one of my favorite cat games [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2315450/Street_of_Secrets/]Street of Secrets[/url]¬†¬†

The main scene has 50 cats doing random cat things throughout the "City." Unfortunately, you can't scroll to make the scene larger, so the cats are super tiny and difficult to spot. There is a Magnifying glass located in the top right corner, but it's more frustrating than helpful when you have to search for teeny-tiny cats in a large city scene using a tiny magnified circle...still, it's doable, and the Hints are unlimited, with a fairly quick recharge.

There are 7 Buildings within the city that can be accessed (they will become outlined when you scan the mouse over them). Each building has 3 individual rooms containing 50 cats in total, some of which are hidden in or behind elements within the scene. There is a [b]Cat Counter Icon[/b] showing the total number of Cats and Hidden Cats.[b]TIP:[/b] Read over the Achievements before starting the game because there are specific objects to find within these rooms.
1-House of Designers
2-Cook's House
3-Gardner's House
4-Students' Apartment
5-Cafe "Pleasant Meetings"
6-Bookshop "Adobe of Knowledge"
7-Shop "Valley of Taste"

[h3]Pros[/h3]
üëçüèªFun but frustratingly small cats on the City scene
üëçüèªChallenging
üëçüèª1-2 Hours playtime
üëçüèªLots of adorable cats
üëçüèªLots of adorable Hidden Cats
üëçüèªCat Counter & Hidden Cat Counter Icon
üëçüèª7 Buildings to enter with multiple rooms (3 rooms per building)
üëçüèªUnlimited Hint feature with a fairly fast recharge
üëçüèªMoving Elements within the City
üëçüèªCats Hidden in unusual locations
üëçüèªCool & unusual Achievements (30 Achievements)
üëçüèªItems to find other than Cats
¬†
[h3]Cons[/h3]
üëéüèªThe main "City" scene has super tiny graphics and even smaller cats
üëéüèªFrustrating game mechanics
üëéüèªBuildings are difficult to enter (they require multiple clicks or clicking on a specific window or door to enter)
üëéüèªHidden Cats and Achievement Objectives requires you to basically click every square inch
üëéüèªWhen you uncover a hidden cat, the cat doesn't always show up immediately, so they are easily missed
üëéüèªScenes can't be zoomed, cats are tiny
üëéüèªMagnifying Glass feature, but it's small and practically worthless
üëéüèªNot compatible with large monitors. (38" Alienware Curved Monitor) I had to keep readjusting the available resolutions; otherwise, the edges were cut off, and I couldn't see the lower portions of the rooms. I couldn't drag the scene in some of the available resolutions either [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/reviewingmadness/screenshots/?appid=2519420&sort=newestfirst&browsefilter=myfiles&view=imagewall ]See screenshot HERE[/url]¬†¬†
üëéüèªWaaayyy too much dialog from a talking cat with no way to fast-forward or skip the dialog (also difficult to read because of the white text & weird font)

Firstly i have to say the idea of a city with different buildings that you can enter with multiple rooms is a cool take on this genre.
However the lack of a scroll function made this game ridiculously needlessly difficult( i'm aware there is a magnifying glass but that is a poor replacement for a standard mouse scroll function (some of the cats are absolutely tiny in the city.
Also  having cats hidden behind literally anything at all just creates a game where you're literally just clicking over the entire screen in hopes it moves something for the hidden cats to appear. This really killed the relaxing vibe these games are meant to give. It doesnt help that the achievements arent working either. Istill dont have one achievement despite me going back and clicking on the glasses over and over but the achievement doesnt unlock. Also why not just keep the mouse pointer as a standard one this games mouse pointer is awful.

All in all i play these games to destress or as a palate cleanser between other bigger games and if im getting stressed i'm not having fun then this is simply not a developer/publisher i will be coming back to.

Although the artstyle is beautiful and the cats are well hidden, I feel like this game has more cons than pros. I love the fact that it has a little story, but the font bothered me too much that I couldn`t even read it. My eyes hurt trying to focus on the text, so unfortunately I ended up skipping it (so idk if the story is interesting or not). Another thing that bothered me was not being able to zoom in using the mouse wheel. Maybe if you only had to search the apartments this would not have bothered me that much since you are provided with a magnifying glass, but you also have to search the city, and even with the magnifying glass you are not able to zoom in enough. 

However, I believe that these problems can be fixed in the developer`s future releases, so I am honestly looking forward to their future games and I am excited to see the improvements.

I'm not sure how a game can be so perfectly relaxing and infuriating at the same time. 
It took me a little over an hour to beat the game. It's the perfect way to kill time while you're sitting in vc chatting with your friends. 
None of the cats are impossible to find, I appreciate a game that doesn't force me to scroll through google & guides. 
My only critique is the dialogue. It feels impossibly long and the font isn't pleasing from a graphic design stand point. 
I hope this review provides some clarification in the midst of the negative ones! :D

Cat City reminds me of "IN THE BUILDING: CATS 1, 2 and 3" in a way that I really, really enjoy the aspect of this seek-and-find design.

I have played a ton of hidden cat games recently and I do really enjoy them but this and ITB:C are probably the neatest way to find cats. This one has a story with it, but it honestly makes no sense - probably due to poor translation, but at least it's a little extra something for the game.

The art is great, the music is good and the adventure for finding things is exciting! A lot of people have complained about controls, but I had no issue on a laptop. However, the main city is really small and hard to find things, even with the magnifying glass. I feel like sometimes it doesn't show the entire area with the glass even if you move slowly, so be warned about that. 

The game is really, really good and I would recommend it to others, but be warned about the small graphic issues if you have sensitive eyes or hands as you will be clicking things a lot.

I bought this based on my previous experience with the devs earlier games, most of which I enjoyed.

This game is another matter altogether; I found it frustrating due to poor technological implementation:
1) entering the buildings are not always being cooperative; it's not that they require a specific entry point (like a door or a window, and sometimes 1 click is enough, but sometimes 20 clicks are you're still outside;
2) my sound settings get reset to their defaults every time I re-open the game;
3) the "special hidden" cats require way too much pixel hunting; I had to use a hint in a few occasions despite having clicked frantically in that very spot... almost like some cats require 3 or 4 clicks before "appearing"

On a different note, the story is quite heavy, dreary, and verbose... and it's using a terrible (but original) font in white letters over mostly pale blue backgrounds.

As a personal preference, so I can't blame the dev for trying something different, I prefer a zooming feature to a magnifying glass. That is extremely important when looking for the 50 cats across the city (not in the buildings.)

Overall, I cannot recommend this game as it's more frustrating than fun; I hope some technical improvements will be made on the next one!

Great for its genre, rooms had a fair amount of variety.

Cons:
- still lacks a proper zoom feature, which makes the main city level unplayable
- finding hidden cats eventually turns to pixel hunting, as some cats are only found by clicking on a small part of an object (i.e. clicking on a computer screen does not work, you must click on the computer's tiny power button to reveal the cat)

8/10 - It's a great game but their could be some additions, like increased zooming abilities and making the click radius of an object a bit larger. It's disheartening to have to click a very spesific button on a lamp that you can barely see even with the magnifying glass.

[h1]Hidden Whisker-Worthy Twist![/h1]

Game has an innovative magnifying glass mechanic which adds a fresh layer of excitement to the search process, focusing your attention on small areas and making cat-spotting a breeze. While most of the city's cats are easy to find, the final batch presents a satisfying challenge, with a hint system available for those moments of frustration. 

Exploring the buildings in the city adds depth to the gameplay, though some hidden cats require precise clicking skills. The storyline, while skippable, offers a decent backdrop, and the music, albeit a bit eclectic at times, provides a pleasant atmosphere. For experienced hidden object enthusiasts, completing the game may take just an hour or two, but the potential for future building additions could elevate its replay value significantly.

[b]If you're passionate about hidden object games and have a soft spot for felines, this game is a worthwhile investment, especially if you catch it on sale. Get ready to sharpen your detective skills and embark on a cat-tastic adventure. [/b]

Wish I could help a developer by praising the game, saying the it's a rough, uncut gem. Unfortunately the game doesn't offer enough to elicit something positive for me to say.
- Graphic wise, it showcases original Doom's level of low rez textures, while somehow running sluggishly on a mid to high end rig
- Gameplay is repetitive and the story is not particularly original. There is no real sense of danger, so you just keep walking on, mildly enjoying the game attempts at jumpscares. It's also very short, might be a smart move to make it just long enough so you don't finish it before the refund window closes.
Bottom line, it needs a lot more work put into it to make it worthy of attention. Keep it up!
This horror game was very engaging and offers a lot at a small price point would recommend.

Definitely a different horror experience than usual!
The impression is that there is much more than what you see at first glance. It certainly has some flaws on a technical level, but it manages to convey the right amount of anguish and discomfort typical of a nightmare and to make you scared 2/3 times.

I honestly feel like giving it a 6.5/10
I'm not gonna refund it at this cost, but it's 10 minutes of running forward and moving slightly left or right to avoid an obstacle or enemy. It's not very good.
I like it but it definitely needs much more polish. The controls are a little confusing but with time you could learn them. I kept getting log errors and later I crashed when I walked into a wall.

A decent foundation, but the lack of options (which result in audio being impossibly low to hear) definitely wasn't all that great.

I love me some roguelikes and DRPGs, though, and I'm curious to see where this one goes.

This next episode in [i]The Lancaster Leak[/i] series is another encounter with an entity. But this time it is a different one. A significant change from [i]O'Brien State Park[/i] is that instead of first person we play in the 3rd person this time. We have a fixed camera angle system in place since according to the story this is still a found footage and the protagonist (Ashley) we see through the lens of the security cameras only.

The idea is great and moving around in the office reminded me of the gameplay in the first [i]Resident Evil[/i] game or we can mention the first [i]Castlevania[/i] released in 2013. In these games we move from screen to screen. Orientation can sometimes be difficult if the camera suddenly shows us from the different angle in the same room. I guess a lot of games were like this in the PS1 era, correct?

The good thing with [i]Crisis At Call Center[/i] is that it takes place in the same location. Overall, we follow the story of Ashley in 3 consecutive nights. She is someone who stays at the office for extra hours to increase her income. To do that she carries out extra chores such as taking out the trash or washing the dishes. We always start in our "cubicle" as we have to look at the e-mail we receive to check what our job will be for the night. It's fun looking at an old Windows system - the story now takes place in the mid '90s. This also means that the VHS filter is not that strong. In fact, this is what [i]O'Brien State Park[/i] should have used.

Tension increases as the days (or nights) pass and the story (as you can guess) comes to a fatal conclusion on night 3. But this sequel is not just a story of another victim and another entity. No, this one does some more lore building which is fantastic. Also, the ending is suprising and really fun.

We are off to a really great start here with two found footage horror sims. The only issue I had was the several typos I found. This breaks the immersion - due to the VHS filter it's already a bit difficult to read but the errors are still noticeable. Hope the developer does more proofreading.

short game but should definitely be played, the atmosphere is incredible and it's one of the only indie horror games I've seen do the VHS filter correctly. The story kept me interested and entertained for the entire 30 minutes especially after it picks up after the second half. I like the world they're trying to build here and even though it's very similar to the SCP world and story structure I'm excited to see where this goes.

Please do more proofreading in the future. The typos the games start off with can be immersion breaking, especially in the case of their presentation and contextual goals. They deserve that extra care I would like to believe.

OOOOOOOOOOO I LIKE THIS GAME A LOT

the first Lancaster Leak was interesting enough, and although kinda slow and rather laggy, provided a solid short spook that acted as a jumping pad for something bigger.

This entry into the Lancaster Anthology has you playing from a fixed 3rd person perspective with tank controls, which I really enjoyed, (maybe I'm a shill for Silent Hill and RE but WHO CARES). I didn't realise this going into it however, as I didn't watch the trailer and the screenshots led me to believe it was a CCTV swapping sorta game, (kinda like I'm on Observation Duty). It's more than that however, and I welcomed it with open arms.

This game has a substantially substantial amount of substance, (nice), in comparison to the first outing, which in almost feels barren. Crisis at Call Centre however provides even more world-building, more tangible gameplay, (even though the controls may take some getting used to, and the game mainly consists of "chores"), and a longer run time by about double the last game.
O'Brien State Park ran you a cool 15-20 minutes, whereas this new outing will take about 30-35, and for a free game with this much polish, I'll take that gladly.
I'm surprised at how invested I am into this universe you're creating as I've never really been a fan of SCP and stuff like that, but this has me gripped in a way I never imagined I'd experience.

The sound design in this game, and the previous, is just top notch. Absolutely stellar work. I found myself jumping at the sound of taps turning on and the slow and tedious ticking of old PCs. The entity in question is scary in concept and that ending definitely made me p!ss myself a little, but I feel like if it was left more-so in the dark it would be more effective in-game.

This outing also runs significantly better than the last and the VHS grain filter didn't give me vertigo so props for optimisation <3

I love this game, this series and I absolutely CANNOT wait for Entity Exam. I will be keeping a keen eye out for it!

9/10

Though I really like the way this game has been stylized, the tanky controls and and empty gameplay left me more bored than scared. Whatever scare factor the antagonist has is hampered by its janky animations and the jumpscare at the end is pretty nonsensical.
Fine for what it is as a free game, but I wouldn't have put down money for it.
Feel bad for the bad rating but the controls are awful and confusing, and needs more clear instructions. I got stuck. The concept and art is awesome but its needs improvement.

The Lancaster Leak - Crisis At Call Center was a surprisingly enjoyable experience. This was my first time playing a game in the series, and I'm already eager to see where the story goes next. The game-play is relatively short, but it left me wanting more. While some might find the hidden object sections a bit tricky, I didn't mind the extra challenge. I'm hoping they'll add even more content in future installments to keep things interesting.  I'm not usually a fan of the VHS filter style, but I thought it was used effectively here and added to the game's atmosphere. Overall, I didn't expect to have as much fun as I did with "The Lancaster Leak - Crisis At Call Center", and I'll definitely be keeping an eye out for future releases in the series.

PS1-style horror games are popping up everywhere, but the Lancaster Leak series stands out from the crowd with how it experiments with the concept of a found footage horror game. O'Brien State Park was a pretty straightforward walking simulator, but Crisis at Call Center takes an old school tank controls fixed camera perspective under the guise of a collection of security cam footage.

Jeremy Fischer approaches lore building in a way that draws the player in. Phone calls, camera footage, and government files are mashed up to create a wild story that had me anxious to find out what would happen next. It reminds me of the film Noroi: The Curse, taking all sorts of media and mashing it into a wild, horrific document.

I can't wait to see where this series is going!

THE LANCASTER LEAK - Crisis at Call Center is my personal favourite of the lancaster leak games. The gameplay is shot entirely through security cameras as you work night shifts cleaning an office building. This game has a lot of intense puzzles and mechanics that would intice all gamers. Please

The game within itself would deserve a solid 4/10 as of now, my only request to the developer is to flesh out the walking controls a bit more, as they are very wonky when you're trying to run from the entity, a skip button for areas where only text is presented would be nice as well. Thank you.
tldr: fix walking controls and add skip button to certain areas.

Yeah, that was good fun. A significant improvement on the first in the series. Good use of fixed multicam, fun solution to the door problem, the windows clone is simple but effective, decently creepy monster behavior, great application of the VHS aesthetic, solid jumpscare. Playtime of ~30 minutes, worth a look...!

Typos take the shine off the framing device a bit, but you have to admire its utility in directing the player (on-screen past-tense captions). Not sure I'm that keen on the framing device as a *story* though - it's not like we haven't seen this stuff a bunch of times before.

All this said, however, I'd love to see the developer doing more with fixed multicam, I think they've a definite talent there!
Terrible. Tank controls that constantly leave me slamming into walls over and over and over again. Couldn't bear playing past the first level. Absolutely terrible

cool little game, bit of a hard control but you may get used to it, but honestly for a small short game, i'd say its good, and a little twist at the end for the cherry on top. Ambientation and vagueness is its strongests.

If you want a short horror game that recreates the feel of analog horror, this is the game for you.

This game effectively creates the atmosphere of analog horror and turns it into a playable experience. The gameplay isn‚Äôt too complicated and allows for the player to quickly understand what they have to do; this lets the player become more immersed in the environment. The tension builds at a good pace and the story continuing off of the previous game has left me excited for the next game in the series.

I liked this one more than the first. It's a more ambitious title compared to the linear 1st person first game although I think it does a great job of continuing what made the first game so great. Only criticisms would be some slightly janky animations here & there. My favourite aspect was how it greatly expanded on the story and brought more depth to the world-building.

It was kinda annoying you couldn't pick up all the plates at once or wash them all at once.

While better in certain aspects compared to the first game, this one is barely better. The controls aren‚Äôt that great (I moonwalked the entire game) and clunky. The camera will occasionally get stuck inside rooms you aren‚Äôt in. Besides that, the slower dialog is much better, the pacing is better, and the scares are better. I still can‚Äôt call this a great game though. If you have time to kill, play it.

While short, this game makes up for it by using jump scares that get your heart racing. The concept is great and the story kept me glued to the screen until it was over. 

I do have a few critiques/notes; 

- There are no instructions on how to move, which was frustrating, but at least I knew how to perform an action (E) and how to exit the computer/get to the game menu (esc)

- You're told how to run (shift) at the end of the game, but I didn't see the point in running since the creature never got close to me

- I'm confused about why the gate in the alleyway is closed on the first night and open for the rest of the game. You can't interact with it, sadly, but I would've liked to by performing actions like closing the gate or using it as an alternate exit route

- There are some spelling errors that pulled my focus away from the game play

Overall, I highly recommend this to anyone looking for a game with simple controls (perfect for beginners) and a story that still captures your attention like a longer, more complex game would.

Also the atmosphere is great, I loved the parts with the flashlight.

96% Score - Finished at 20 Minutes

Gameplay (1.5/2): I love the switch from first-person to tank controlled third-person! It works super well within the setting of the gameplay- not spending too much time in one area, or too sluggish time in another. I don't think the gameplay does anything particularly new as it consists of chores, edging into the eventual horror. But it does provide a short encapsulating experience that doesn't feel like a slog.

Story (1.5/2): As best as I can say- I don't think its doing anything groundbreaking but players will still be drawn in to the short yet unique sequences of gameplay. The writing has a draw that when gameplay is happening you're seeing a short series of events that don't feel drawn out. But as if you are learning about 'the entity' as the last series entry also followed. However, I found this experience much more enthralling and still recommend some indie horror fans to check out.

Writing (2/2): For a game like this, the writing isn't anything intensive. But it fits the genre style it's going for, doing so exceptionally. The uneasy slides in reading about 'the entity' always makes me curious about the next gameplay cycle or 'footage' we play. I think that's easily the best draw to this game is eating the trail of crumbs (building anticipation).

Visuals (1.75/2): The visual aesthetic works great- fitting back to its first entry. I do have one complaint- just the walking cycle felt strange and I wouldn't have complained the character moved just a small amount slower to really fit the animation. Otherwise some of the animations like the garbage throwing made me giggle every time. But no real issues with the visuals, works well.

Audio (2/2): While audio was a larger issue to me in the first game, it felt far more fit to the ambiance in this entry. It works very well, feeling that VHS static within the unorthodox style of tape footage. No complaints here- wonderful job with the atmosphere! Also compliments to the main voice actress, genuinely felt S tier and made me uncomfortable.

+1 Point it's a Quality Quick Free Game
Give it a try, I'll be there for Ep. 3

Just played this on Youtube (link below for those who want to see a gameplay sample before buying), and I thought it was a good sequel to The Lancaster Leak - O'Brien State Park. It doesn't directly follow on from the story of the previous game, but it is set in the same timeline. It also incorporates some gameplay differences; Crisis at Call Center is third- rather than first-person, using a Resident Evil-style series of fixed cameras as you navigate your environment. These camera angles work well with the controls to ensure the gameplay mechanics work smoothly.

Visual and sound design has been handled well, giving the game a sufficient degree of spooky atmosphere to creep the player out. The story this time around is that you're reviewing security footage from an office building, where a member of staff was killed by a monstrous entity. The game is only short (about half an hour) so it doesn't overstay its welcome.

Overall, I'd recommend this game; it was a decent way to spend half an hour, and I look forward to seeing what other instalments in The Lancaster Leaks series might be released in future.

(HEADS UP: This review was written on the day of release. Things may have changed between release and the time you are seeing this, so take these things with a grain of salt as they may have been fixed by the time you read this.)

This game is very much a mixed bag for me. Many of my issues are personal preferences and gripes, however this is my review, so I will list those here. This monster of a review will be split into multiple parts, so for the dumbed down version, scroll to the bottom, although for more specifics, I definitely recommend reading the whole thing.

*Graphics/Performance:* Now, this game is styled to look like something out of an early PS1 game, meaning the graphics by todays standards are not greatest, however, that is the style the game is going for, so I have no complaints there. My complaints are with the game's performance. For a game with such low poly textures and models (At least from what is visible through all the screen effects), trying to run this game on a Mac like me, on any setting higher than "Low" is unbearable. The game stutters like crazy and just runs really slow unless you're on a low setting and even then, it still still has fps drops. (For reference, I can run games like "The Forest" just fine with little to no FPS drops ever). The original Lancaster leak had this same problem, but it was a lot worse, so there seems to have been an effort to fix this. Either way, I give the graphics a good 7/10, and the performance a 4/10.

*Controls:* This game has tank controls, which for a lot of people could be an immediate turn off. For me tank controls are a little annoying but I can bear them. The problem with this however, is the fact that if you are walking towards the camera, your controls will inverse, so instead of turning right you will turn left for example. It's not a huge thing but gets really annoying at times. Overall I give the controls a 5/10

*Gameplay:* Another little gripe I have with this game is the gameplay. This game is comprised of multiple fetch quests. However the original Lancaster Leak was a glorified walking simulator so either way this is an improvement. But in the original I could excuse the lack of any real gameplay because of how excellently done the horror element was, but in this game, the horror element is kind of lackluster. I did not once find the entity scary, as there was never a moment in the game where it could actually kill you if it you were chased, and it only ever showed up during scripted sequences, making it seem much less scary. I would have loved if there was a portion of the game where the entity was wandering around, and you had to hide in lockers or something whenever it walked by, however that would require a much larger map, so it probably would not have worked. I give the gameplay a 7/10. It was fun for the first 10 or so minutes, but then it got very repetitive.

*Lore/Story:* This is the game's saving grace. The lore is very intriguing and the entity description and how the story was presented is absolutely perfect. On top of that the voice acting is absolutely incredible, it is seriously impressive the emotion that the character managed to convey in the very few lines they had. I give this section a 10/10

*Conclusion:* Overall, this game is a 6.6/10. The graphics fit the theme of the game, however the performance is absolutely atrocious at times, which takes away from it, the controls are annoying and janky, and the gameplay is very mediocre (However it is still an improvement over the gameplay from the last one). This game is absolutely saved by it's very well presented story. While it does have it's problems, it's only worth it due to the fact that it is free. If this even cost a dollar, I would say its not worth the money, dont buy it, but like I said it's free. So yeah, 6.6/10.

                                                                     -- BUGS/PROBLEMS --
-During the first appearance of the entity, the character does not look at it when it plays the weird frightened animations, which takes away from the immersion.

-During the ending cutscene, where the entity kills everybody in the call center, you can see both the hands of the entity and the hands of the body clipping through the exit door in the alley camera angle.

-You can grab the meeting room trash through the wall.

-There are multiple typo's throughout the many text sections of the game.
Unbelievable that this game (and all the other episodes) are free! Thoroughly enjoyed Call Center. The top-down perspective was unique and added an eerie element to gameplay.
it was about what you would expect for an free indie game, graphics are not very good and the game is really short...would still recommend playing

After adapting to the archaic tank controls, Crisis At Call Center is a short game following the torment of a innocent janitor at the hands of an entity. Game-play wise you'll mostly be tracking through the call center doing late night janitorial tasks with occasional background appearance by the creature. Beyond that there isn't much there. It's sole appeal is for fans of the VHS style (Like i am) that this series has made its staple.
A free, quick little scary game, no puzzles, just a spooky walkthrough and a backstory. Not bad at all. Rating: 7/10
I absolutely LOVE this game! It's so spooky and fun! I'm looking forward to playing more games by this creator!
It's a good game, great for a jump scare. Reminds me of retro classic horror games.

Absolutely one of the dumbest games available on Steam... This game makes "Rock Simulator" and "Tree Simulator" look like epic masterpieces.   

No score, no real objective at all.  You can shuffle the cards at will until you get a low card so you'll always guess correctly as well.  Granted, you can guess "black" or "higher" until you get through the entire deck.. but WHY!?!?  ...How is this "fun"?!?

https://youtu.be/TVuN7Wuet7Y

And with a price tag of $5 USD, I'm just left scratching my head.  This isn't a game that is trying to make a fun compelling game by 'keeping it simple', instead this is just laziness in abundance.  


NOT RECOMMENDED.    Even if this game were only a nickel, it would still not be worth it or the time you'd waste playing it.
